   <TITLE>Chapter 16</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>It was not in Miss Crawford's power to talk Fanny into any



<P>real forgetfulness of what had passed.&nbsp; When the evening



<P>was over, she went to bed full of it, her nerves still



<P>agitated by the shock of such an attack from her cousin Tom,



<P>so public and so persevered in, and her spirits sinking



<P>under her aunt's unkind reflection and reproach.



<P>To be called into notice in such a manner, to hear that it



<P>was but the prelude to something so infinitely worse,



<P>to be told that she must do what was so impossible as to act;



<P>and then to have the charge of obstinacy and ingratitude



<P>follow it, enforced with such a hint at the dependence



<P>of her situation, had been too distressing at the time



<P>to make the remembrance when she was alone much less so,



<P>especially with the superadded dread of what the



<P>morrow might produce in continuation of the subject.



<P>Miss Crawford had protected her only for the time;



<P>and if she were applied to again among themselves with all



<P>the authoritative urgency that Tom and Maria were capable of,



<P>and Edmund perhaps away, what should she do?&nbsp; She fell



<P>asleep before she could answer the question, and found



<P>it quite as puzzling when she awoke the next morning.



<P>The little white attic, which had continued her sleeping-room



<P>ever since her first entering the family, proving incompetent



<P>to suggest any reply, she had recourse, as soon as she



<P>was dressed, to another apartment more spacious and more



<P>meet for walking about in and thinking, and of which she



<P>had now for some time been almost equally mistress.



<P>It had been their school-room; so called till the Miss



<P>Bertrams would not allow it to be called so any longer,



<P>and inhabited as such to a later period.&nbsp; There Miss



<P>Lee had lived, and there they had read and written,



<P>and talked and laughed, till within the last three years,



<P>when she had quitted them.&nbsp; The room had then become useless,



<P>and for some time was quite deserted, except by Fanny,



<P>when she visited her plants, or wanted one of the books,



<P>which she was still glad to keep there, from the deficiency



<P>of space and accommodation in her little chamber above:



<P>but gradually, as her value for the comforts of it increased,



<P>she had added to her possessions, and spent more of her



<P>time there; and having nothing to oppose her, had so



<P>naturally and so artlessly worked herself into it, that it



<P>was now generally admitted to be hers.&nbsp; The East room,



<P>as it had been called ever since Maria Bertram was sixteen,



<P>was now considered Fanny's, almost as decidedly as the



<P>white attic:&nbsp; the smallness of the one making the use of



<P>the other so evidently reasonable that the Miss Bertrams,



<P>with every superiority in their own apartments which their



<P>own sense of superiority could demand, were entirely



<P>approving it; and Mrs. Norris, having stipulated for there



<P>never being a fire in it on Fanny's account, was tolerably



<P>resigned to her having the use of what nobody else wanted,



<P>though the terms in which she sometimes spoke of the



<P>indulgence seemed to imply that it was the best room in



<P>the house.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The aspect was so favourable that even without a fire



<P>it was habitable in many an early spring and late



<P>autumn morning to such a willing mind as Fanny's;



<P>and while there was a gleam of sunshine she hoped not



<P>to be driven from it entirely, even when winter came.



<P>The comfort of it in her hours of leisure was extreme.



<P>She could go there after anything unpleasant below,



<P>and find immediate consolation in some pursuit,



<P>or some train of thought at hand.&nbsp; Her plants, her books--



<P>of which she had been a collector from the first hour



<P>of her commanding a shilling--her writing-desk, and her



<P>works of charity and ingenuity, were all within her reach;



<P>or if indisposed for employment, if nothing but musing



<P>would do, she could scarcely see an object in that room



<P>which had not an interesting remembrance connected with it.



<P>Everything was a friend, or bore her thoughts to a friend;



<P>and though there had been sometimes much of suffering



<P>to her; though her motives had often been misunderstood,



<P>her feelings disregarded, and her comprehension undervalued;



<P>though she had known the pains of tyranny, of ridicule,



<P>and neglect, yet almost every recurrence of either had led



<P>to something consolatory:&nbsp; her aunt Bertram had spoken



<P>for her, or Miss Lee had been encouraging, or, what was yet



<P>more frequent or more dear, Edmund had been her champion



<P>and her friend:&nbsp; he had supported her cause or explained



<P>her meaning, he had told her not to cry, or had given her



<P>some proof of affection which made her tears delightful;



<P>and the whole was now so blended together, so harmonised



<P>by distance, that every former affliction had its charm.



<P>The room was most dear to her, and she would not have



<P>changed its furniture for the handsomest in the house,



<P>though what had been originally plain had suffered all



<P>the ill-usage of children; and its greatest elegancies



<P>and ornaments were a faded footstool of Julia's work,



<P>too ill done for the drawing-room, three transparencies,



<P>made in a rage for transparencies, for the three lower



<P>panes of one window, where Tintern Abbey held its station



<P>between a cave in Italy and a moonlight lake in Cumberland,



<P>a collection of family profiles, thought unworthy of being



<P>anywhere else, over the mantelpiece, and by their side,



<P>and pinned against the wall, a small sketch of a ship



<P>sent four years ago from the Mediterranean by William,



<P>with H.M.S. Antwerp at the bottom, in letters as tall as the



<P>mainmast.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To this nest of comforts Fanny now walked down to try



<P>its influence on an agitated, doubting spirit, to see



<P>if by looking at Edmund's profile she could catch any of



<P>his counsel, or by giving air to her geraniums she might



<P>inhale a breeze of mental strength herself.&nbsp; But she had



<P>more than fears of her own perseverance to remove:&nbsp; she had



<P>begun to feel undecided as to what she _ought_ _to_ _do_;



<P>and as she walked round the room her doubts were increasing.



<P>Was she _right_ in refusing what was so warmly asked,



<P>so strongly wished for--what might be so essential



<P>to a scheme on which some of those to whom she owed the



<P>greatest complaisance had set their hearts?&nbsp; Was it not



<P>ill-nature, selfishness, and a fear of exposing herself?



<P>And would Edmund's judgment, would his persuasion of Sir



<P>Thomas's disapprobation of the whole, be enough to justify



<P>her in a determined denial in spite of all the rest?



<P>It would be so horrible to her to act that she was inclined



<P>to suspect the truth and purity of her own scruples;



<P>and as she looked around her, the claims of her cousins



<P>to being obliged were strengthened by the sight of



<P>present upon present that she had received from them.



<P>The table between the windows was covered with work-boxes



<P>and netting-boxes which had been given her at different times,



<P>principally by Tom; and she grew bewildered as to the amount



<P>of the debt which all these kind remembrances produced.



<P>A tap at the door roused her in the midst of this attempt



<P>to find her way to her duty, and her gentle "Come in"



<P>was answered by the appearance of one, before whom all her



<P>doubts were wont to be laid.&nbsp; Her eyes brightened at the



<P>sight of Edmund.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Can I speak with you, Fanny, for a few minutes?"



<P>said he.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, certainly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I want to consult.&nbsp; I want your opinion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My opinion!" she cried, shrinking from such a compliment,



<P>highly as it gratified her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, your advice and opinion.&nbsp; I do not know what to do.



<P>This acting scheme gets worse and worse, you see.



<P>They have chosen almost as bad a play as they could,



<P>and now, to complete the business, are going to ask the



<P>help of a young man very slightly known to any of us.



<P>This is the end of all the privacy and propriety which was



<P>talked about at first.&nbsp; I know no harm of Charles Maddox;



<P>but the excessive intimacy which must spring from his being



<P>admitted among us in this manner is highly objectionable,



<P>the _more_ than intimacy--the familiarity.&nbsp; I cannot think



<P>of it with any patience; and it does appear to me an evil



<P>of such magnitude as must, _if_ _possible_, be prevented.



<P>Do not you see it in the same light?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; but what can be done?&nbsp; Your brother is so determined."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is but _one_ thing to be done, Fanny.&nbsp; I must



<P>take Anhalt myself.&nbsp; I am well aware that nothing else



<P>will quiet Tom."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny could not answer him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is not at all what I like," he continued.&nbsp; "No man can



<P>like being driven into the _appearance_ of such inconsistency.



<P>After being known to oppose the scheme from the beginning,



<P>there is absurdity in the face of my joining them _now_,



<P>when they are exceeding their first plan in every respect;



<P>but I can think of no other alternative.&nbsp; Can you, Fanny?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No," said Fanny slowly, "not immediately, but--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But what?&nbsp; I see your judgment is not with me.&nbsp; Think it



<P>a little over.&nbsp; Perhaps you are not so much aware as I am



<P>of the mischief that _may_, of the unpleasantness that _must_



<P>arise from a young man's being received in this manner:



<P>domesticated among us; authorised to come at all hours,



<P>and placed suddenly on a footing which must do away



<P>all restraints.&nbsp; To think only of the licence which every



<P>rehearsal must tend to create.&nbsp; It is all very bad!



<P>Put yourself in Miss Crawford's place, Fanny.



<P>Consider what it would be to act Amelia with a stranger.



<P>She has a right to be felt for, because she evidently



<P>feels for herself.&nbsp; I heard enough of what she said to you



<P>last night to understand her unwillingness to be acting



<P>with a stranger; and as she probably engaged in the part



<P>with different expectations--perhaps without considering



<P>the subject enough to know what was likely to be--



<P>it would be ungenerous, it would be really wrong to



<P>expose her to it.&nbsp; Her feelings ought to be respected.



<P>Does it not strike you so, Fanny?&nbsp; You hesitate."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am sorry for Miss Crawford; but I am more sorry to see



<P>you drawn in to do what you had resolved against, and what



<P>you are known to think will be disagreeable to my uncle.



<P>It will be such a triumph to the others!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They will not have much cause of triumph when they



<P>see how infamously I act.&nbsp; But, however, triumph there



<P>certainly will be, and I must brave it.&nbsp; But if I can be



<P>the means of restraining the publicity of the business,



<P>of limiting the exhibition, of concentrating our folly,



<P>I shall be well repaid.&nbsp; As I am now, I have no influence,



<P>I can do nothing:&nbsp; I have offended them, and they will



<P>not hear me; but when I have put them in good-humour



<P>by this concession, I am not without hopes of persuading



<P>them to confine the representation within a much



<P>smaller circle than they are now in the high road for.



<P>This will be a material gain.&nbsp; My object is to confine



<P>it to Mrs. Rushworth and the Grants.&nbsp; Will not this be



<P>worth gaining?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, it will be a great point."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But still it has not your approbation.&nbsp; Can you mention



<P>any other measure by which I have a chance of doing



<P>equal good?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I cannot think of anything else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Give me your approbation, then, Fanny.&nbsp; I am not



<P>comfortable without it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, cousin!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you are against me, I ought to distrust myself,



<P>and yet--But it is absolutely impossible to let Tom



<P>go on in this way, riding about the country in quest



<P>of anybody who can be persuaded to act--no matter whom:



<P>the look of a gentleman is to be enough.&nbsp; I thought _you_



<P>would have entered more into Miss Crawford's feelings."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No doubt she will be very glad.&nbsp; It must be a great relief



<P>to her," said Fanny, trying for greater warmth of manner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She never appeared more amiable than in her behaviour



<P>to you last night.&nbsp; It gave her a very strong claim



<P>on my goodwill."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She _was_ very kind, indeed, and I am glad to have her



<P>spared"...

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could not finish the generous effusion.&nbsp; Her conscience



<P>stopt her in the middle, but Edmund was satisfied.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall walk down immediately after breakfast," said he,



<P>"and am sure of giving pleasure there.&nbsp; And now, dear Fanny,



<P>I will not interrupt you any longer.&nbsp; You want to be reading.



<P>But I could not be easy till I had spoken to you,



<P>and come to a decision.&nbsp; Sleeping or waking, my head



<P>has been full of this matter all night.&nbsp; It is an evil,



<P>but I am certainly making it less than it might be.



<P>If Tom is up, I shall go to him directly and get it over,



<P>and when we meet at breakfast we shall be all in high



<P>good-humour at the prospect of acting the fool together



<P>with such unanimity.&nbsp; _You_, in the meanwhile, will be taking



<P>a trip into China, I suppose.&nbsp; How does Lord Macartney



<P>go on?"--opening a volume on the table and then taking up



<P>some others.&nbsp; "And here are Crabbe's Tales, and the Idler,



<P>at hand to relieve you, if you tire of your great book.



<P>I admire your little establishment exceedingly; and as



<P>soon as I am gone, you will empty your head of all this



<P>nonsense of acting, and sit comfortably down to your table.



<P>But do not stay here to be cold."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He went; but there was no reading, no China, no composure



<P>for Fanny.&nbsp; He had told her the most extraordinary,



<P>the most inconceivable, the most unwelcome news;



<P>and she could think of nothing else.&nbsp; To be acting!



<P>After all his objections--objections so just and so public!



<P>After all that she had heard him say, and seen him look,



<P>and known him to be feeling.&nbsp; Could it be possible?



<P>Edmund so inconsistent!&nbsp; Was he not deceiving himself?



<P>Was he not wrong?&nbsp; Alas! it was all Miss Crawford's doing.



<P>She had seen her influence in every speech, and was miserable.



<P>The doubts and alarms as to her own conduct, which had previously



<P>distressed her, and which had all slept while she listened



<P>to him, were become of little consequence now.&nbsp; This deeper



<P>anxiety swallowed them up.&nbsp; Things should take their course;



<P>she cared not how it ended.&nbsp; Her cousins might attack,



<P>but could hardly tease her.&nbsp; She was beyond their reach;



<P>and if at last obliged to yield--no matter--it was all



<P>misery now.



<P>

   <TITLE>Chapter 02</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B></B>



<P><B>CHAPTER II</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The little girl performed her long journey in safety;



<P>and at Northampton was met by Mrs. Norris, who thus



<P>regaled in the credit of being foremost to welcome her,



<P>and in the importance of leading her in to the others,



<P>and recommending her to their kindness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny Price was at this time just ten years old,



<P>and though there might not be much in her first appearance



<P>to captivate, there was, at least, nothing to disgust



<P>her relations.&nbsp; She was small of her age, with no



<P>glow of complexion, nor any other striking beauty;



<P>exceedingly timid and shy, and shrinking from notice;



<P>but her air, though awkward, was not vulgar, her voice



<P>was sweet, and when she spoke her countenance was pretty.



<P>Sir Thomas and Lady Bertram received her very kindly;



<P>and Sir Thomas, seeing how much she needed encouragement,



<P>tried to be all that was conciliating:&nbsp; but he had



<P>to work against a most untoward gravity of deportment;



<P>and Lady Bertram, without taking half so much trouble,



<P>or speaking one word where he spoke ten, by the mere aid



<P>of a good-humoured smile, became immediately the less awful



<P>character of the two.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The young people were all at home, and sustained their



<P>share in the introduction very well, with much good humour,



<P>and no embarrassment, at least on the part of the sons, who,



<P>at seventeen and sixteen, and tall of their age, had all



<P>the grandeur of men in the eyes of their little cousin.



<P>The two girls were more at a loss from being younger



<P>and in greater awe of their father, who addressed them



<P>on the occasion with rather an injudicious particularity.



<P>But they were too much used to company and praise to have



<P>anything like natural shyness; and their confidence



<P>increasing from their cousin's total want of it,



<P>they were soon able to take a full survey of her face



<P>and her frock in easy indifference.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were a remarkably fine family, the sons very well-looking,



<P>the daughters decidedly handsome, and all of them well-grown



<P>and forward of their age, which produced as striking



<P>a difference between the cousins in person, as education



<P>had given to their address; and no one would have supposed



<P>the girls so nearly of an age as they really were.&nbsp; There were



<P>in fact but two years between the youngest and Fanny.



<P>Julia Bertram was only twelve, and Maria but a year older.



<P>The little visitor meanwhile was as unhappy as possible.



<P>Afraid of everybody, ashamed of herself, and longing



<P>for the home she had left, she knew not how to look up,



<P>and could scarcely speak to be heard, or without crying.



<P>Mrs. Norris had been talking to her the whole way from



<P>Northampton of her wonderful good fortune, and the



<P>extraordinary degree of gratitude and good behaviour



<P>which it ought to produce, and her consciousness of



<P>misery was therefore increased by the idea of its being



<P>a wicked thing for her not to be happy.&nbsp; The fatigue,



<P>too, of so long a journey, became soon no trifling evil.



<P>In vain were the well-meant condescensions of Sir Thomas,



<P>and all the officious prognostications of Mrs. Norris



<P>that she would be a good girl; in vain did Lady Bertram



<P>smile and make her sit on the sofa with herself and pug,



<P>and vain was even the sight of a gooseberry tart towards



<P>giving her comfort; she could scarcely swallow two mouthfuls



<P>before tears interrupted her, and sleep seeming to be her



<P>likeliest friend, she was taken to finish her sorrows in bed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is not a very promising beginning," said Mrs. Norris,



<P>when Fanny had left the room.&nbsp; "After all that I said to her



<P>as we came along, I thought she would have behaved better;



<P>I told her how much might depend upon her acquitting



<P>herself well at first.&nbsp; I wish there may not be a little



<P>sulkiness of temper--her poor mother had a good deal;



<P>but we must make allowances for such a child--and I



<P>do not know that her being sorry to leave her home is



<P>really against her, for, with all its faults, it _was_



<P>her home, and she cannot as yet understand how much she



<P>has changed for the better; but then there is moderation



<P>in all things."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It required a longer time, however, than Mrs. Norris



<P>was inclined to allow, to reconcile Fanny to the novelty



<P>of Mansfield Park, and the separation from everybody



<P>she had been used to.&nbsp; Her feelings were very acute,



<P>and too little understood to be properly attended to.



<P>Nobody meant to be unkind, but nobody put themselves out



<P>of their way to secure her comfort.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The holiday allowed to the Miss Bertrams the next day,



<P>on purpose to afford leisure for getting acquainted with,



<P>and entertaining their young cousin, produced little union.



<P>They could not but hold her cheap on finding that she



<P>had but two sashes, and had never learned French; and when



<P>they perceived her to be little struck with the duet they



<P>were so good as to play, they could do no more than make



<P>her a generous present of some of their least valued toys,



<P>and leave her to herself, while they adjourned to whatever



<P>might be the favourite holiday sport of the moment,



<P>making artificial flowers or wasting gold paper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, whether near or from her cousins, whether in



<P>the schoolroom, the drawing-room, or the shrubbery,



<P>was equally forlorn, finding something to fear in



<P>every person and place.&nbsp; She was disheartened by Lady



<P>Bertram's silence, awed by Sir Thomas's grave looks,



<P>and quite overcome by Mrs. Norris's admonitions.



<P>Her elder cousins mortified her by reflections on her size,



<P>and abashed her by noticing her shyness:&nbsp; Miss Lee



<P>wondered at her ignorance, and the maid-servants sneered



<P>at her clothes; and when to these sorrows was added the idea



<P>of the brothers and sisters among whom she had always



<P>been important as playfellow, instructress, and nurse,



<P>the despondence that sunk her little heart was severe.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The grandeur of the house astonished, but could not console her.



<P>The rooms were too large for her to move in with ease:



<P>whatever she touched she expected to injure, and she



<P>crept about in constant terror of something or other;



<P>often retreating towards her own chamber to cry;



<P>and the little girl who was spoken of in the drawing-room



<P>when she left it at night as seeming so desirably sensible



<P>of her peculiar good fortune, ended every day's sorrows



<P>by sobbing herself to sleep.&nbsp; A week had passed in this way,



<P>and no suspicion of it conveyed by her quiet passive manner,



<P>when she was found one morning by her cousin Edmund,



<P>the youngest of the sons, sitting crying on the attic stairs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear little cousin," said he, with all the gentleness



<P>of an excellent nature, "what can be the matter?"&nbsp; And sitting



<P>down by her, he was at great pains to overcome her shame



<P>in being so surprised, and persuade her to speak openly.



<P>"Was she ill? or was anybody angry with her? or had she



<P>quarrelled with Maria and Julia? or was she puzzled



<P>about anything in her lesson that he could explain?



<P>Did she, in short, want anything he could possibly get her,



<P>or do for her?&nbsp; For a long while no answer could be



<P>obtained beyond a "no, no--not at all--no, thank you";



<P>but he still persevered; and no sooner had he begun to



<P>revert to her own home, than her increased sobs explained



<P>to him where the grievance lay.&nbsp; He tried to console her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are sorry to leave Mama, my dear little Fanny,"



<P>said he, "which shows you to be a very good girl; but you



<P>must remember that you are with relations and friends,



<P>who all love you, and wish to make you happy.&nbsp; Let us walk



<P>out in the park, and you shall tell me all about your



<P>brothers and sisters."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On pursuing the subject, he found that, dear as all



<P>these brothers and sisters generally were, there was one



<P>among them who ran more in her thoughts than the rest.



<P>It was William whom she talked of most, and wanted most



<P>to see.&nbsp; William, the eldest, a year older than herself,



<P>her constant companion and friend; her advocate with her



<P>mother (of whom he was the darling) in every distress.



<P>"William did not like she should come away; he had told



<P>her he should miss her very much indeed."&nbsp; "But William will



<P>write to you, I dare say."&nbsp; "Yes, he had promised he would,



<P>but he had told _her_ to write first."&nbsp; "And when shall



<P>you do it?"&nbsp; She hung her head and answered hesitatingly,



<P>"she did not know; she had not any paper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If that be all your difficulty, I will furnish you



<P>with paper and every other material, and you may write



<P>your letter whenever you choose.&nbsp; Would it make you



<P>happy to write to William?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, very."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then let it be done now.&nbsp; Come with me into the



<P>breakfast-room, we shall find everything there,



<P>and be sure of having the room to ourselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, cousin, will it go to the post?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, depend upon me it shall:&nbsp; it shall go with the



<P>other letters; and, as your uncle will frank it,



<P>it will cost William nothing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My uncle!" repeated Fanny, with a frightened look.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, when you have written the letter, I will take it



<P>to my father to frank."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny thought it a bold measure, but offered no further



<P>resistance; and they went together into the breakfast-room,



<P>where Edmund prepared her paper, and ruled her lines



<P>with all the goodwill that her brother could himself



<P>have felt, and probably with somewhat more exactness.



<P>He continued with her the whole time of her writing,



<P>to assist her with his penknife or his orthography,



<P>as either were wanted; and added to these attentions,



<P>which she felt very much, a kindness to her brother which



<P>delighted her beyond all the rest.&nbsp; He wrote with his own



<P>hand his love to his cousin William, and sent him half



<P>a guinea under the seal.&nbsp; Fanny's feelings on the occasion



<P>were such as she believed herself incapable of expressing;



<P>but her countenance and a few artless words fully



<P>conveyed all their gratitude and delight, and her cousin



<P>began to find her an interesting object.&nbsp; He talked



<P>to her more, and, from all that she said, was convinced



<P>of her having an affectionate heart, and a strong desire



<P>of doing right; and he could perceive her to be farther



<P>entitled to attention by great sensibility of her situation,



<P>and great timidity.&nbsp; He had never knowingly given her pain,



<P>but he now felt that she required more positive kindness;



<P>and with that view endeavoured, in the first place,



<P>to lessen her fears of them all, and gave her especially



<P>a great deal of good advice as to playing with Maria



<P>and Julia, and being as merry as possible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>From this day Fanny grew more comfortable.&nbsp; She felt



<P>that she had a friend, and the kindness of her cousin



<P>Edmund gave her better spirits with everybody else.



<P>The place became less strange, and the people less formidable;



<P>and if there were some amongst them whom she could not



<P>cease to fear, she began at least to know their ways,



<P>and to catch the best manner of conforming to them.



<P>The little rusticities and awkwardnesses which had at



<P>first made grievous inroads on the tranquillity of all,



<P>and not least of herself, necessarily wore away, and she



<P>was no longer materially afraid to appear before her uncle,



<P>nor did her aunt Norris's voice make her start very much.



<P>To her cousins she became occasionally an acceptable companion.



<P>Though unworthy, from inferiority of age and strength,



<P>to be their constant associate, their pleasures and schemes



<P>were sometimes of a nature to make a third very useful,



<P>especially when that third was of an obliging,



<P>yielding temper; and they could not but own, when their



<P>aunt inquired into her faults, or their brother Edmund



<P>urged her claims to their kindness, that "Fanny was



<P>good-natured enough."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund was uniformly kind himself; and she had nothing



<P>worse to endure on the part of Tom than that sort



<P>of merriment which a young man of seventeen will always



<P>think fair with a child of ten.&nbsp; He was just entering



<P>into life, full of spirits, and with all the liberal



<P>dispositions of an eldest son, who feels born only



<P>for expense and enjoyment.&nbsp; His kindness to his little



<P>cousin was consistent with his situation and rights:



<P>he made her some very pretty presents, and laughed at her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As her appearance and spirits improved, Sir Thomas and Mrs. Norris



<P>thought with greater satisfaction of their benevolent plan;



<P>and it was pretty soon decided between them that,



<P>though far from clever, she showed a tractable disposition,



<P>and seemed likely to give them little trouble.&nbsp; A mean



<P>opinion of her abilities was not confined to _them_.



<P>Fanny could read, work, and write, but she had been taught



<P>nothing more; and as her cousins found her ignorant



<P>of many things with which they had been long familiar,



<P>they thought her prodigiously stupid, and for the first



<P>two or three weeks were continually bringing some fresh



<P>report of it into the drawing-room. "Dear mama, only think,



<P>my cousin cannot put the map of Europe together--



<P>or my cousin cannot tell the principal rivers in Russia--



<P>or, she never heard of Asia Minor--or she does not know



<P>the difference between water-colours and crayons!--



<P>How strange!--Did you ever hear anything so stupid?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear," their considerate aunt would reply,



<P>"it is very bad, but you must not expect everybody



<P>to be as forward and quick at learning as yourself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, aunt, she is really so very ignorant!--Do you know,



<P>we asked her last night which way she would go to get



<P>to Ireland; and she said, she should cross to the Isle



<P>of Wight.&nbsp; She thinks of nothing but the Isle of Wight,



<P>and she calls it _the_ _Island_, as if there were no



<P>other island in the world.&nbsp; I am sure I should have been



<P>ashamed of myself, if I had not known better long before I



<P>was so old as she is.&nbsp; I cannot remember the time when I



<P>did not know a great deal that she has not the least



<P>notion of yet.&nbsp; How long ago it is, aunt, since we used



<P>to repeat the chronological order of the kings of England,



<P>with the dates of their accession, and most of the principal



<P>events of their reigns!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," added the other; "and of the Roman emperors



<P>as low as Severus; besides a great deal of the heathen



<P>mythology, and all the metals, semi-metals, planets,



<P>and distinguished philosophers."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true indeed, my dears, but you are blessed with



<P>wonderful memories, and your poor cousin has probably none



<P>at all.&nbsp; There is a vast deal of difference in memories,



<P>as well as in everything else, and therefore you must



<P>make allowance for your cousin, and pity her deficiency.



<P>And remember that, if you are ever so forward and clever



<P>yourselves, you should always be modest; for, much as you



<P>know already, there is a great deal more for you to learn."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I know there is, till I am seventeen.&nbsp; But I must



<P>tell you another thing of Fanny, so odd and so stupid.



<P>Do you know, she says she does not want to learn either



<P>music or drawing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure, my dear, that is very stupid indeed,



<P>and shows a great want of genius and emulation.



<P>But, all things considered, I do not know whether it is



<P>not as well that it should be so, for, though you know



<P>(owing to me) your papa and mama are so good as to bring



<P>her up with you, it is not at all necessary that she



<P>should be as accomplished as you are;--on the contrary,



<P>it is much more desirable that there should be a difference."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such were the counsels by which Mrs. Norris assisted to form



<P>her nieces' minds; and it is not very wonderful that,



<P>with all their promising talents and early information,



<P>they should be entirely deficient in the less common



<P>acquirements of self-knowledge, generosity and humility.



<P>In everything but disposition they were admirably taught.



<P>Sir Thomas did not know what was wanting, because, though a



<P>truly anxious father, he was not outwardly affectionate,



<P>and the reserve of his manner repressed all the flow of their



<P>spirits before him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To the education of her daughters Lady Bertram paid not



<P>the smallest attention.&nbsp; She had not time for such cares.



<P>She was a woman who spent her days in sitting, nicely dressed,



<P>on a sofa, doing some long piece of needlework, of little use



<P>and no beauty, thinking more of her pug than her children,



<P>but very indulgent to the latter when it did not put



<P>herself to inconvenience, guided in everything important



<P>by Sir Thomas, and in smaller concerns by her sister.



<P>Had she possessed greater leisure for the service of her girls,



<P>she would probably have supposed it unnecessary, for they



<P>were under the care of a governess, with proper masters,



<P>and could want nothing more.&nbsp; As for Fanny's being stupid



<P>at learning, "she could only say it was very unlucky,



<P>but some people _were_ stupid, and Fanny must take more pains:



<P>she did not know what else was to be done; and, except her



<P>being so dull, she must add she saw no harm in the poor



<P>little thing, and always found her very handy and quick



<P>in carrying messages, and fetching, what she wanted."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, with all her faults of ignorance and timidity,



<P>was fixed at Mansfield Park, and learning to transfer



<P>in its favour much of her attachment to her former home,



<P>grew up there not unhappily among her cousins.&nbsp; There was



<P>no positive ill-nature in Maria or Julia; and though



<P>Fanny was often mortified by their treatment of her,



<P>she thought too lowly of her own claims to feel injured



<P>by it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>From about the time of her entering the family,



<P>Lady Bertram, in consequence of a little ill-health,



<P>and a great deal of indolence, gave up the house in town,



<P>which she had been used to occupy every spring,



<P>and remained wholly in the country, leaving Sir Thomas



<P>to attend his duty in Parliament, with whatever increase



<P>or diminution of comfort might arise from her absence.



<P>In the country, therefore, the Miss Bertrams continued



<P>to exercise their memories, practise their duets, and grow



<P>tall and womanly:&nbsp; and their father saw them becoming



<P>in person, manner, and accomplishments, everything that



<P>could satisfy his anxiety.&nbsp; His eldest son was careless



<P>and extravagant, and had already given him much uneasiness;



<P>but his other children promised him nothing but good.



<P>His daughters, he felt, while they retained the name



<P>of Bertram, must be giving it new grace, and in quitting it,



<P>he trusted, would extend its respectable alliances;



<P>and the character of Edmund, his strong good sense



<P>and uprightness of mind, bid most fairly for utility,



<P>honour, and happiness to himself and all his connexions.



<P>He was to be a clergyman.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Amid the cares and the complacency which his own



<P>children suggested, Sir Thomas did not forget to do what



<P>he could for the children of Mrs. Price:&nbsp; he assisted



<P>her liberally in the education and disposal of her sons



<P>as they became old enough for a determinate pursuit;



<P>and Fanny, though almost totally separated from her family,



<P>was sensible of the truest satisfaction in hearing of any



<P>kindness towards them, or of anything at all promising



<P>in their situation or conduct.&nbsp; Once, and once only,



<P>in the course of many years, had she the happiness



<P>of being with William.&nbsp; Of the rest she saw nothing:



<P>nobody seemed to think of her ever going amongst them again,



<P>even for a visit, nobody at home seemed to want her;



<P>but William determining, soon after her removal,



<P>to be a sailor, was invited to spend a week with his



<P>sister in Northamptonshire before he went to sea.



<P>Their eager affection in meeting, their exquisite



<P>delight in being together, their hours of happy mirth,



<P>and moments of serious conference, may be imagined;



<P>as well as the sanguine views and spirits of the boy even



<P>to the last, and the misery of the girl when he left her.



<P>Luckily the visit happened in the Christmas holidays,



<P>when she could directly look for comfort to her cousin Edmund;



<P>and he told her such charming things of what William was



<P>to do, and be hereafter, in consequence of his profession,



<P>as made her gradually admit that the separation might



<P>have some use.&nbsp; Edmund's friendship never failed her:



<P>his leaving Eton for Oxford made no change in his kind



<P>dispositions, and only afforded more frequent opportunities



<P>of proving them.&nbsp; Without any display of doing more than



<P>the rest, or any fear of doing too much, he was always



<P>true to her interests, and considerate of her feelings,



<P>trying to make her good qualities understood, and to conquer



<P>the diffidence which prevented their being more apparent;



<P>giving her advice, consolation, and encouragement.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Kept back as she was by everybody else, his single support



<P>could not bring her forward; but his attentions were otherwise



<P>of the highest importance in assisting the improvement



<P>of her mind, and extending its pleasures.&nbsp; He knew her to



<P>be clever, to have a quick apprehension as well as good sense,



<P>and a fondness for reading, which, properly directed,



<P>must be an education in itself.&nbsp; Miss Lee taught her French,



<P>and heard her read the daily portion of history; but he



<P>recommended the books which charmed her leisure hours,



<P>he encouraged her taste, and corrected her judgment:



<P>he made reading useful by talking to her of what she read,



<P>and heightened its attraction by judicious praise.



<P>In return for such services she loved him better than



<P>anybody in the world except William:&nbsp; her heart was divided



<P>between the two.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 03</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER III</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The first event of any importance in the family was



<P>the death of Mr. Norris, which happened when Fanny was



<P>about fifteen, and necessarily introduced alterations



<P>and novelties.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris, on quitting the Parsonage,



<P>removed first to the Park, and afterwards to a small house



<P>of Sir Thomas's in the village, and consoled herself



<P>for the loss of her husband by considering that she



<P>could do very well without him; and for her reduction



<P>of income by the evident necessity of stricter economy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The living was hereafter for Edmund; and, had his uncle



<P>died a few years sooner, it would have been duly given



<P>to some friend to hold till he were old enough for orders.



<P>But Tom's extravagance had, previous to that event,



<P>been so great as to render a different disposal of the



<P>next presentation necessary, and the younger brother



<P>must help to pay for the pleasures of the elder.



<P>There was another family living actually held for Edmund;



<P>but though this circumstance had made the arrangement



<P>somewhat easier to Sir Thomas's conscience, he could not



<P>but feel it to be an act of injustice, and he earnestly



<P>tried to impress his eldest son with the same conviction,



<P>in the hope of its producing a better effect than anything he



<P>had yet been able to say or do.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I blush for you, Tom," said he, in his most dignified manner;



<P>"I blush for the expedient which I am driven on, and I trust



<P>I may pity your feelings as a brother on the occasion.



<P>You have robbed Edmund for ten, twenty, thirty years,



<P>perhaps for life, of more than half the income which ought



<P>to be his.&nbsp; It may hereafter be in my power, or in yours



<P>(I hope it will), to procure him better preferment;



<P>but it must not be forgotten that no benefit of that



<P>sort would have been beyond his natural claims on us,



<P>and that nothing can, in fact, be an equivalent for the



<P>certain advantage which he is now obliged to forego



<P>through the urgency of your debts."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tom listened with some shame and some sorrow;



<P>but escaping as quickly as possible, could soon with



<P>cheerful selfishness reflect, firstly, that he had



<P>not been half so much in debt as some of his friends;



<P>secondly, that his father had made a most tiresome piece



<P>of work of it; and, thirdly, that the future incumbent,



<P>whoever he might be, would, in all probability, die very soon.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On Mr. Norris's death the presentation became the right of



<P>a Dr. Grant, who came consequently to reside at Mansfield;



<P>and on proving to be a hearty man of forty-five, seemed



<P>likely to disappoint Mr. Bertram's calculations.



<P>But "no, he was a short-necked, apoplectic sort of fellow,



<P>and, plied well with good things, would soon pop off."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had a wife about fifteen years his junior, but no children;



<P>and they entered the neighbourhood with the usual fair



<P>report of being very respectable, agreeable people.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The time was now come when Sir Thomas expected his



<P>sister-in-law to claim her share in their niece,



<P>the change in Mrs. Norris's situation, and the improvement



<P>in Fanny's age, seeming not merely to do away any former



<P>objection to their living together, but even to give it



<P>the most decided eligibility; and as his own circumstances



<P>were rendered less fair than heretofore, by some recent



<P>losses on his West India estate, in addition to his eldest



<P>son's extravagance, it became not undesirable to himself to be



<P>relieved from the expense of her support, and the obligation



<P>of her future provision.&nbsp; In the fullness of his belief



<P>that such a thing must be, he mentioned its probability



<P>to his wife; and the first time of the subject's occurring



<P>to her again happening to be when Fanny was present,



<P>she calmly observed to her, "So, Fanny, you are going



<P>to leave us, and live with my sister.&nbsp; How shall you like it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was too much surprised to do more than repeat



<P>her aunt's words, "Going to leave you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, my dear; why should you be astonished?



<P>You have been five years with us, and my sister



<P>always meant to take you when Mr. Norris died.



<P>But you must come up and tack on my patterns all the same."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The news was as disagreeable to Fanny as it had been unexpected.



<P>She had never received kindness from her aunt Norris,



<P>and could not love her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall be very sorry to go away," said she, with a



<P>faltering voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, I dare say you will; _that's_ natural enough.



<P>I suppose you have had as little to vex you since you came



<P>into this house as any creature in the world."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope I am not ungrateful, aunt," said Fanny modestly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, my dear; I hope not.&nbsp; I have always found you



<P>a very good girl."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And am I never to live here again?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Never, my dear; but you are sure of a comfortable home.



<P>It can make very little difference to you, whether you are



<P>in one house or the other."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny left the room with a very sorrowful heart; she could



<P>not feel the difference to be so small, she could not think



<P>of living with her aunt with anything like satisfaction.



<P>As soon as she met with Edmund she told him her distress.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Cousin," said she, "something is going to happen which I



<P>do not like at all; and though you have often persuaded me



<P>into being reconciled to things that I disliked at first,



<P>you will not be able to do it now.&nbsp; I am going to live



<P>entirely with my aunt Norris."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; my aunt Bertram has just told me so.&nbsp; It is quite settled.



<P>I am to leave Mansfield Park, and go to the White House,



<P>I suppose, as soon as she is removed there."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Fanny, and if the plan were not unpleasant to you,



<P>I should call it an excellent one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, cousin!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It has everything else in its favour.&nbsp; My aunt is



<P>acting like a sensible woman in wishing for you.&nbsp; She is



<P>choosing a friend and companion exactly where she ought,



<P>and I am glad her love of money does not interfere.



<P>You will be what you ought to be to her.&nbsp; I hope it does



<P>not distress you very much, Fanny?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed it does:&nbsp; I cannot like it.&nbsp; I love this house



<P>and everything in it:&nbsp; I shall love nothing there.



<P>You know how uncomfortable I feel with her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can say nothing for her manner to you as a child;



<P>but it was the same with us all, or nearly so.&nbsp; She never



<P>knew how to be pleasant to children.&nbsp; But you are now



<P>of an age to be treated better; I think she is behaving



<P>better already; and when you are her only companion,



<P>you _must_ be important to her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can never be important to any one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What is to prevent you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Everything.&nbsp; My situation, my foolishness and awkwardness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As to your foolishness and awkwardness, my dear Fanny,



<P>believe me, you never have a shadow of either, but in using



<P>the words so improperly.&nbsp; There is no reason in the world



<P>why you should not be important where you are known.



<P>You have good sense, and a sweet temper, and I am sure you



<P>have a grateful heart, that could never receive kindness



<P>without wishing to return it.&nbsp; I do not know any better



<P>qualifications for a friend and companion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are too kind," said Fanny, colouring at such praise;



<P>"how shall I ever thank you as I ought, for thinking



<P>so well of me.&nbsp; Oh! cousin, if I am to go away, I shall



<P>remember your goodness to the last moment of my life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, indeed, Fanny, I should hope to be remembered at



<P>such a distance as the White House.&nbsp; You speak as if you



<P>were going two hundred miles off instead of only across



<P>the park; but you will belong to us almost as much as ever.



<P>The two families will be meeting every day in the year.



<P>The only difference will be that, living with your aunt,



<P>you will necessarily be brought forward as you ought to be.



<P>Here there are too many whom you can hide behind; but with



<P>her you will be forced to speak for yourself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; I do not say so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I must say it, and say it with pleasure.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris



<P>is much better fitted than my mother for having the charge



<P>of you now.&nbsp; She is of a temper to do a great deal



<P>for anybody she really interests herself about, and she



<P>will force you to do justice to your natural powers."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny sighed, and said, "I cannot see things as you do;



<P>but I ought to believe you to be right rather than myself,



<P>and I am very much obliged to you for trying to reconcile



<P>me to what must be.&nbsp; If I could suppose my aunt really



<P>to care for me, it would be delightful to feel myself



<P>of consequence to anybody.&nbsp; _ Here_, I know, I am of none,



<P>and yet I love the place so well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The place, Fanny, is what you will not quit, though you



<P>quit the house.&nbsp; You will have as free a command of the



<P>park and gardens as ever.&nbsp; Even _your_ constant little



<P>heart need not take fright at such a nominal change.



<P>You will have the same walks to frequent, the same library



<P>to choose from, the same people to look at, the same horse



<P>to ride."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true.&nbsp; Yes, dear old grey pony!&nbsp; Ah! cousin, when I



<P>remember how much I used to dread riding, what terrors



<P>it gave me to hear it talked of as likely to do me good



<P>(oh! how I have trembled at my uncle's opening his lips



<P>if horses were talked of), and then think of the kind



<P>pains you took to reason and persuade me out of my fears,



<P>and convince me that I should like it after a little while,



<P>and feel how right you proved to be, I am inclined to hope



<P>you may always prophesy as well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I am quite convinced that your being with Mrs. Norris



<P>will be as good for your mind as riding has been for



<P>your health, and as much for your ultimate happiness too."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So ended their discourse, which, for any very appropriate



<P>service it could render Fanny, might as well have been spared,



<P>for Mrs. Norris had not the smallest intention of taking her.



<P>It had never occurred to her, on the present occasion,



<P>but as a thing to be carefully avoided.&nbsp; To prevent its



<P>being expected, she had fixed on the smallest habitation



<P>which could rank as genteel among the buildings of Mansfield



<P>parish, the White House being only just large enough to



<P>receive herself and her servants, and allow a spare room



<P>for a friend, of which she made a very particular point.



<P>The spare rooms at the Parsonage had never been wanted,



<P>but the absolute necessity of a spare room for a friend



<P>was now never forgotten.&nbsp; Not all her precautions, however,



<P>could save her from being suspected of something better;



<P>or, perhaps, her very display of the importance of a



<P>spare room might have misled Sir Thomas to suppose it



<P>really intended for Fanny.&nbsp; Lady Bertram soon brought



<P>the matter to a certainty by carelessly observing to Mrs. Norris--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think, sister, we need not keep Miss Lee any longer,



<P>when Fanny goes to live with you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris almost started.&nbsp; "Live with me, dear Lady



<P>Bertram! what do you mean?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is she not to live with you?&nbsp; I thought you had settled



<P>it with Sir Thomas."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me! never.&nbsp; I never spoke a syllable about it to Sir Thomas,



<P>nor he to me.&nbsp; Fanny live with me! the last thing in the



<P>world for me to think of, or for anybody to wish that really



<P>knows us both.&nbsp; Good heaven! what could I do with Fanny?



<P>Me! a poor, helpless, forlorn widow, unfit for anything,



<P>my spirits quite broke down; what could I do with a girl



<P>at her time of life?&nbsp; A girl of fifteen! the very age



<P>of all others to need most attention and care, and put



<P>the cheerfullest spirits to the test!&nbsp; Sure Sir Thomas



<P>could not seriously expect such a thing!&nbsp; Sir Thomas is too



<P>much my friend.&nbsp; Nobody that wishes me well, I am sure,



<P>would propose it.&nbsp; How came Sir Thomas to speak to you



<P>about it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed, I do not know.&nbsp; I suppose he thought it best."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But what did he say?&nbsp; He could not say he _wished_ me



<P>to take Fanny.&nbsp; I am sure in his heart he could not wish



<P>me to do it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No; he only said he thought it very likely; and I thought



<P>so too.&nbsp; We both thought it would be a comfort to you.



<P>But if you do not like it, there is no more to be said.



<P>She is no encumbrance here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear sister, if you consider my unhappy state, how can she



<P>be any comfort to me?&nbsp; Here am I, a poor desolate widow,



<P>deprived of the best of husbands, my health gone in attending



<P>and nursing him, my spirits still worse, all my peace



<P>in this world destroyed, with hardly enough to support



<P>me in the rank of a gentlewoman, and enable me to live



<P>so as not to disgrace the memory of the dear departed--



<P>what possible comfort could I have in taking such a charge



<P>upon me as Fanny?&nbsp; If I could wish it for my own sake,



<P>I would not do so unjust a thing by the poor girl.



<P>She is in good hands, and sure of doing well.&nbsp; I must



<P>struggle through my sorrows and difficulties as I can."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then you will not mind living by yourself quite alone?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Lady Bertram, I do not complain.&nbsp; I know I cannot



<P>live as I have done, but I must retrench where I can,



<P>and learn to be a better manager.&nbsp; I _have_ _been_



<P>a liberal housekeeper enough, but I shall not be ashamed



<P>to practise economy now.&nbsp; My situation is as much



<P>altered as my income.&nbsp; A great many things were due



<P>from poor Mr. Norris, as clergyman of the parish,



<P>that cannot be expected from me.&nbsp; It is unknown how much



<P>was consumed in our kitchen by odd comers and goers.



<P>At the White House, matters must be better looked after.



<P>I _must_ live within my income, or I shall be miserable;



<P>and I own it would give me great satisfaction to be able



<P>to do rather more, to lay by a little at the end of



<P>the year."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say you will.&nbsp; You always do, don't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My object, Lady Bertram, is to be of use to those that



<P>come after me.&nbsp; It is for your children's good that I



<P>wish to be richer.&nbsp; I have nobody else to care for,



<P>but I should be very glad to think I could leave a little



<P>trifle among them worth their having."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are very good, but do not trouble yourself about them.



<P>They are sure of being well provided for.&nbsp; Sir Thomas



<P>will take care of that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, you know, Sir Thomas's means will be rather straitened



<P>if the Antigua estate is to make such poor returns."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! _that_ will soon be settled.&nbsp; Sir Thomas has been



<P>writing about it, I know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Lady Bertram," said Mrs. Norris, moving to go,



<P>"I can only say that my sole desire is to be of use



<P>to your family:&nbsp; and so, if Sir Thomas should ever speak



<P>again about my taking Fanny, you will be able to say that



<P>my health and spirits put it quite out of the question;



<P>besides that, I really should not have a bed to give her,



<P>for I must keep a spare room for a friend."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram repeated enough of this conversation



<P>to her husband to convince him how much he had mistaken



<P>his sister-in-law's views; and she was from that moment



<P>perfectly safe from all expectation, or the slightest



<P>allusion to it from him.&nbsp; He could not but wonder at her



<P>refusing to do anything for a niece whom she had been so



<P>forward to adopt; but, as she took early care to make him,



<P>as well as Lady Bertram, understand that whatever she



<P>possessed was designed for their family, he soon grew



<P>reconciled to a distinction which, at the same time



<P>that it was advantageous and complimentary to them,



<P>would enable him better to provide for Fanny himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny soon learnt how unnecessary had been her fears of a removal;



<P>and her spontaneous, untaught felicity on the discovery,



<P>conveyed some consolation to Edmund for his disappointment



<P>in what he had expected to be so essentially serviceable



<P>to her.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris took possession of the White House,



<P>the Grants arrived at the Parsonage, and these events over,



<P>everything at Mansfield went on for some time as usual.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Grants showing a disposition to be friendly and sociable,



<P>gave great satisfaction in the main among their new acquaintance.



<P>They had their faults, and Mrs. Norris soon found them out.



<P>The Doctor was very fond of eating, and would have a good



<P>dinner every day; and Mrs. Grant, instead of contriving



<P>to gratify him at little expense, gave her cook as high



<P>wages as they did at Mansfield Park, and was scarcely ever



<P>seen in her offices.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris could not speak with any



<P>temper of such grievances, nor of the quantity of butter



<P>and eggs that were regularly consumed in the house.



<P>"Nobody loved plenty and hospitality more than herself;



<P>nobody more hated pitiful doings; the Parsonage,



<P>she believed, had never been wanting in comforts of any sort,



<P>had never borne a bad character in _her_ _time_, but this



<P>was a way of going on that she could not understand.



<P>A fine lady in a country parsonage was quite out of place.



<P>_Her_ store-room, she thought, might have been good enough



<P>for Mrs. Grant to go into.&nbsp; Inquire where she would,



<P>she could not find out that Mrs. Grant had ever had more



<P>than five thousand pounds."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram listened without much interest to this



<P>sort of invective.&nbsp; She could not enter into the wrongs



<P>of an economist, but she felt all the injuries of beauty



<P>in Mrs. Grant's being so well settled in life without



<P>being handsome, and expressed her astonishment on



<P>that point almost as often, though not so diffusely,



<P>as Mrs. Norris discussed the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These opinions had been hardly canvassed a year before



<P>another event arose of such importance in the family,



<P>as might fairly claim some place in the thoughts and



<P>conversation of the ladies.&nbsp; Sir Thomas found it expedient



<P>to go to Antigua himself, for the better arrangement



<P>of his affairs, and he took his eldest son with him,



<P>in the hope of detaching him from some bad connexions



<P>at home.&nbsp; They left England with the probability of being



<P>nearly a twelvemonth absent.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The necessity of the measure in a pecuniary light,



<P>and the hope of its utility to his son, reconciled Sir



<P>Thomas to the effort of quitting the rest of his family,



<P>and of leaving his daughters to the direction of others



<P>at their present most interesting time of life.



<P>He could not think Lady Bertram quite equal to supply his



<P>place with them, or rather, to perform what should have



<P>been her own; but, in Mrs. Norris's watchful attention,



<P>and in Edmund's judgment, he had sufficient confidence



<P>to make him go without fears for their conduct.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram did not at all like to have her husband leave her;



<P>but she was not disturbed by any alarm for his safety,



<P>or solicitude for his comfort, being one of those persons



<P>who think nothing can be dangerous, or difficult,



<P>or fatiguing to anybody but themselves.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Miss Bertrams were much to be pitied on the occasion:



<P>not for their sorrow, but for their want of it.



<P>Their father was no object of love to them; he had never



<P>seemed the friend of their pleasures, and his absence



<P>was unhappily most welcome.&nbsp; They were relieved by it from



<P>all restraint; and without aiming at one gratification



<P>that would probably have been forbidden by Sir Thomas,



<P>they felt themselves immediately at their own disposal,



<P>and to have every indulgence within their reach.



<P>Fanny's relief, and her consciousness of it, were quite



<P>equal to her cousins'; but a more tender nature suggested



<P>that her feelings were ungrateful, and she really



<P>grieved because she could not grieve.&nbsp; "Sir Thomas,



<P>who had done so much for her and her brothers, and who was



<P>gone perhaps never to return! that she should see him



<P>go without a tear! it was a shameful insensibility."



<P>He had said to her, moreover, on the very last morning,



<P>that he hoped she might see William again in the course



<P>of the ensuing winter, and had charged her to write



<P>and invite him to Mansfield as soon as the squadron



<P>to which he belonged should be known to be in England.



<P>"This was so thoughtful and kind!" and would he only



<P>have smiled upon her, and called her "my dear Fanny,"



<P>while he said it, every former frown or cold address



<P>might have been forgotten.&nbsp; But he had ended his speech



<P>in a way to sink her in sad mortification, by adding,



<P>"If William does come to Mansfield, I hope you may be able



<P>to convince him that the many years which have passed



<P>since you parted have not been spent on your side entirely



<P>without improvement; though, I fear, he must find his sister



<P>at sixteen in some respects too much like his sister at ten."



<P>She cried bitterly over this reflection when her uncle



<P>was gone; and her cousins, on seeing her with red eyes,



<P>set her down as a hypocrite.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 17</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>It was, indeed, a triumphant day to Mr. Bertram and Maria.



<P>Such a victory over Edmund's discretion had been beyond



<P>their hopes, and was most delightful.&nbsp; There was no



<P>longer anything to disturb them in their darling project,



<P>and they congratulated each other in private on the



<P>jealous weakness to which they attributed the change,



<P>with all the glee of feelings gratified in every way.



<P>Edmund might still look grave, and say he did not like the



<P>scheme in general, and must disapprove the play in particular;



<P>their point was gained:&nbsp; he was to act, and he was



<P>driven to it by the force of selfish inclinations only.



<P>Edmund had descended from that moral elevation which he



<P>had maintained before, and they were both as much the better



<P>as the happier for the descent.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They behaved very well, however, to _him_ on the occasion,



<P>betraying no exultation beyond the lines about the corners



<P>of the mouth, and seemed to think it as great an escape



<P>to be quit of the intrusion of Charles Maddox, as if they



<P>had been forced into admitting him against their inclination.



<P>"To have it quite in their own family circle was what



<P>they had particularly wished.&nbsp; A stranger among them



<P>would have been the destruction of all their comfort";



<P>and when Edmund, pursuing that idea, gave a hint of his hope



<P>as to the limitation of the audience, they were ready,



<P>in the complaisance of the moment, to promise anything.



<P>It was all good-humour and encouragement.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris



<P>offered to contrive his dress, Mr. Yates assured him



<P>that Anhalt's last scene with the Baron admitted a good



<P>deal of action and emphasis, and Mr. Rushworth undertook



<P>to count his speeches.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps," said Tom, "Fanny may be more disposed to oblige



<P>us now.&nbsp; Perhaps you may persuade _her_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, she is quite determined.&nbsp; She certainly will not act."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! very well."&nbsp; And not another word was said; but Fanny



<P>felt herself again in danger, and her indifference



<P>to the danger was beginning to fail her already.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There were not fewer smiles at the Parsonage than at the Park



<P>on this change in Edmund; Miss Crawford looked very lovely



<P>in hers, and entered with such an instantaneous renewal



<P>of cheerfulness into the whole affair as could have but



<P>one effect on him.&nbsp; "He was certainly right in respecting



<P>such feelings; he was glad he had determined on it."



<P>And the morning wore away in satisfactions very sweet,



<P>if not very sound.&nbsp; One advantage resulted from it



<P>to Fanny:&nbsp; at the earnest request of Miss Crawford,



<P>Mrs. Grant had, with her usual good-humour, agreed



<P>to undertake the part for which Fanny had been wanted;



<P>and this was all that occurred to gladden _her_ heart



<P>during the day; and even this, when imparted by Edmund,



<P>brought a pang with it, for it was Miss Crawford to



<P>whom she was obliged--it was Miss Crawford whose kind



<P>exertions were to excite her gratitude, and whose merit



<P>in making them was spoken of with a glow of admiration.



<P>She was safe; but peace and safety were unconnected here.



<P>Her mind had been never farther from peace.&nbsp; She could



<P>not feel that she had done wrong herself, but she was



<P>disquieted in every other way.&nbsp; Her heart and her judgment



<P>were equally against Edmund's decision:&nbsp; she could not



<P>acquit his unsteadiness, and his happiness under it made



<P>her wretched.&nbsp; She was full of jealousy and agitation.



<P>Miss Crawford came with looks of gaiety which seemed



<P>an insult, with friendly expressions towards herself



<P>which she could hardly answer calmly.&nbsp; Everybody around



<P>her was gay and busy, prosperous and important; each had



<P>their object of interest, their part, their dress,



<P>their favourite scene, their friends and confederates:



<P>all were finding employment in consultations and comparisons,



<P>or diversion in the playful conceits they suggested.



<P>She alone was sad and insignificant:&nbsp; she had no share



<P>in anything; she might go or stay; she might be in the



<P>midst of their noise, or retreat from it to the solitude



<P>of the East room, without being seen or missed.&nbsp; She could



<P>almost think anything would have been preferable to this.



<P>Mrs. Grant was of consequence:&nbsp; _her_ good-nature had



<P>honourable mention; her taste and her time were considered;



<P>her presence was wanted; she was sought for, and attended,



<P>and praised; and Fanny was at first in some danger



<P>of envying her the character she had accepted.



<P>But reflection brought better feelings, and shewed her



<P>that Mrs. Grant was entitled to respect, which could never



<P>have belonged to _her_; and that, had she received even



<P>the greatest, she could never have been easy in joining



<P>a scheme which, considering only her uncle, she must



<P>condemn altogether.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's heart was not absolutely the only saddened one



<P>amongst them, as she soon began to acknowledge to herself.



<P>Julia was a sufferer too, though not quite so blamelessly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Henry Crawford had trifled with her feelings; but she



<P>had very long allowed and even sought his attentions,



<P>with a jealousy of her sister so reasonable as ought



<P>to have been their cure; and now that the conviction



<P>of his preference for Maria had been forced on her,



<P>she submitted to it without any alarm for Maria's situation,



<P>or any endeavour at rational tranquillity for herself.



<P>She either sat in gloomy silence, wrapt in such gravity



<P>as nothing could subdue, no curiosity touch, no wit amuse;



<P>or allowing the attentions of Mr. Yates, was talking with



<P>forced gaiety to him alone, and ridiculing the acting of



<P>the others.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a day or two after the affront was given,



<P>Henry Crawford had endeavoured to do it away by the usual



<P>attack of gallantry and compliment, but he had not cared



<P>enough about it to persevere against a few repulses;



<P>and becoming soon too busy with his play to have time



<P>for more than one flirtation, he grew indifferent to



<P>the quarrel, or rather thought it a lucky occurrence,



<P>as quietly putting an end to what might ere long



<P>have raised expectations in more than Mrs. Grant.



<P>She was not pleased to see Julia excluded from the play,



<P>and sitting by disregarded; but as it was not a matter



<P>which really involved her happiness, as Henry must be the



<P>best judge of his own, and as he did assure her, with a



<P>most persuasive smile, that neither he nor Julia had ever



<P>had a serious thought of each other, she could only renew



<P>her former caution as to the elder sister, entreat him



<P>not to risk his tranquillity by too much admiration there,



<P>and then gladly take her share in anything that brought



<P>cheerfulness to the young people in general, and that did



<P>so particularly promote the pleasure of the two so dear to her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I rather wonder Julia is not in love with Henry,"



<P>was her observation to Mary.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say she is," replied Mary coldly.&nbsp; "I imagine



<P>both sisters are."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Both! no, no, that must not be.&nbsp; Do not give him a hint



<P>of it.&nbsp; Think of Mr. Rushworth!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You had better tell Miss Bertram to think of Mr. Rushworth.



<P>It may do _her_ some good.&nbsp; I often think of Mr. Rushworth's



<P>property and independence, and wish them in other hands;



<P>but I never think of him.&nbsp; A man might represent the county



<P>with such an estate; a man might escape a profession



<P>and represent the county."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say he _will_ be in parliament soon.&nbsp; When Sir



<P>Thomas comes, I dare say he will be in for some borough,



<P>but there has been nobody to put him in the way of doing



<P>anything yet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sir Thomas is to achieve many mighty things when he



<P>comes home," said Mary, after a pause.&nbsp; "Do you remember



<P>Hawkins Browne's 'Address to Tobacco,' in imitation



<P>of Pope?--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Blest leaf! whose aromatic gales dispense



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; To Templars modesty, to Parsons sense.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I will parody them--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Blest Knight! whose dictatorial looks dispense



<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; To Children affluence, to Rushworth sense.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Will not that do, Mrs. Grant?&nbsp; Everything seems to depend



<P>upon Sir Thomas's return."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will find his consequence very just and reasonable



<P>when you see him in his family, I assure you.&nbsp; I do not think



<P>we do so well without him.&nbsp; He has a fine dignified manner,



<P>which suits the head of such a house, and keeps everybody



<P>in their place.&nbsp; Lady Bertram seems more of a cipher



<P>now than when he is at home; and nobody else can keep



<P>Mrs. Norris in order.&nbsp; But, Mary, do not fancy that Maria



<P>Bertram cares for Henry.&nbsp; I am sure _Julia_ does not,



<P>or she would not have flirted as she did last night with



<P>Mr. Yates; and though he and Maria are very good friends,



<P>I think she likes Sotherton too well to be inconstant."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I would not give much for Mr. Rushworth's chance if Henry



<P>stept in before the articles were signed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you have such a suspicion, something must be done;



<P>and as soon as the play is all over, we will talk to him



<P>seriously and make him know his own mind; and if he



<P>means nothing, we will send him off, though he is Henry,



<P>for a time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Julia _did_ suffer, however, though Mrs. Grant discerned



<P>it not, and though it escaped the notice of many of her



<P>own family likewise.&nbsp; She had loved, she did love still,



<P>and she had all the suffering which a warm temper and a



<P>high spirit were likely to endure under the disappointment



<P>of a dear, though irrational hope, with a strong sense



<P>of ill-usage. Her heart was sore and angry, and she



<P>was capable only of angry consolations.&nbsp; The sister



<P>with whom she was used to be on easy terms was now become



<P>her greatest enemy:&nbsp; they were alienated from each other;



<P>and Julia was not superior to the hope of some distressing



<P>end to the attentions which were still carrying on there,



<P>some punishment to Maria for conduct so shameful towards



<P>herself as well as towards Mr. Rushworth.&nbsp; With no material



<P>fault of temper, or difference of opinion, to prevent



<P>their being very good friends while their interests



<P>were the same, the sisters, under such a trial as this,



<P>had not affection or principle enough to make them merciful



<P>or just, to give them honour or compassion.&nbsp; Maria felt



<P>her triumph, and pursued her purpose, careless of Julia;



<P>and Julia could never see Maria distinguished by Henry



<P>Crawford without trusting that it would create jealousy,



<P>and bring a public disturbance at last.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny saw and pitied much of this in Julia; but there



<P>was no outward fellowship between them.&nbsp; Julia made



<P>no communication, and Fanny took no liberties.&nbsp; They were



<P>two solitary sufferers, or connected only by Fanny's consciousness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The inattention of the two brothers and the aunt to



<P>Julia's discomposure, and their blindness to its true cause,



<P>must be imputed to the fullness of their own minds.



<P>They were totally preoccupied.&nbsp; Tom was engrossed by



<P>the concerns of his theatre, and saw nothing that did



<P>not immediately relate to it.&nbsp; Edmund, between his



<P>theatrical and his real part, between Miss Crawford's



<P>claims and his own conduct, between love and consistency,



<P>was equally unobservant; and Mrs. Norris was too busy



<P>in contriving and directing the general little matters



<P>of the company, superintending their various dresses



<P>with economical expedient, for which nobody thanked her,



<P>and saving, with delighted integrity, half a crown here and



<P>there to the absent Sir Thomas, to have leisure for watching



<P>the behaviour, or guarding the happiness of his daughters.



<P>

</BODY>

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 01</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B><FONT SIZE=+3>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

Mansfield Park</FONT></B>



<P><B><FONT SIZE=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

by Jane Austen</FONT></B>



<P><B>CHAPTER I</B>



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>About thirty years ago Miss Maria Ward, of Huntingdon,



<P>with only seven thousand pounds, had the good luck



<P>to captivate Sir Thomas Bertram, of Mansfield Park,



<P>in the county of Northampton, and to be thereby raised



<P>to the rank of a baronet's lady, with all the comforts



<P>and consequences of an handsome house and large income.



<P>All Huntingdon exclaimed on the greatness of the match,



<P>and her uncle, the lawyer, himself, allowed her to be at least



<P>three thousand pounds short of any equitable claim to it.



<P>She had two sisters to be benefited by her elevation;



<P>and such of their acquaintance as thought Miss Ward and Miss



<P>Frances quite as handsome as Miss Maria, did not scruple



<P>to predict their marrying with almost equal advantage.



<P>But there certainly are not so many men of large fortune



<P>in the world as there are pretty women to deserve them.



<P>Miss Ward, at the end of half a dozen years, found



<P>herself obliged to be attached to the Rev. Mr. Norris,



<P>a friend of her brother-in-law, with scarcely any



<P>private fortune, and Miss Frances fared yet worse.



<P>Miss Ward's match, indeed, when it came to the point,



<P>was not contemptible:&nbsp; Sir Thomas being happily able
