<P>to give his friend an income in the living of Mansfield;



<P>and Mr. and Mrs. Norris began their career of conjugal



<P>felicity with very little less than a thousand a year.



<P>But Miss Frances married, in the common phrase,



<P>to disoblige her family, and by fixing on a lieutenant



<P>of marines, without education, fortune, or connexions,



<P>did it very thoroughly.&nbsp; She could hardly have made



<P>a more untoward choice.&nbsp; Sir Thomas Bertram had interest,



<P>which, from principle as well as pride--from a general



<P>wish of doing right, and a desire of seeing all that were



<P>connected with him in situations of respectability,



<P>he would have been glad to exert for the advantage



<P>of Lady Bertram's sister; but her husband's profession



<P>was such as no interest could reach; and before he



<P>had time to devise any other method of assisting them,



<P>an absolute breach between the sisters had taken place.



<P>It was the natural result of the conduct of each party,



<P>and such as a very imprudent marriage almost always produces.



<P>To save herself from useless remonstrance, Mrs. Price never



<P>wrote to her family on the subject till actually married.



<P>Lady Bertram, who was a woman of very tranquil feelings,



<P>and a temper remarkably easy and indolent, would have



<P>contented herself with merely giving up her sister,



<P>and thinking no more of the matter; but Mrs. Norris



<P>had a spirit of activity, which could not be satisfied



<P>till she had written a long and angry letter to Fanny,



<P>to point out the folly of her conduct, and threaten



<P>her with all its possible ill consequences.&nbsp; Mrs. Price,



<P>in her turn, was injured and angry; and an answer,



<P>which comprehended each sister in its bitterness, and bestowed



<P>such very disrespectful reflections on the pride of Sir



<P>Thomas as Mrs. Norris could not possibly keep to herself,



<P>put an end to all intercourse between them for a considerable



<P>period.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their homes were so distant, and the circles in which they



<P>moved so distinct, as almost to preclude the means of ever



<P>hearing of each other's existence during the eleven



<P>following years, or, at least, to make it very wonderful



<P>to Sir Thomas that Mrs. Norris should ever have it



<P>in her power to tell them, as she now and then did,



<P>in an angry voice, that Fanny had got another child.



<P>By the end of eleven years, however, Mrs. Price could no



<P>longer afford to cherish pride or resentment, or to lose one



<P>connexion that might possibly assist her.&nbsp; A large and still



<P>increasing family, an husband disabled for active service,



<P>but not the less equal to company and good liquor, and a



<P>very small income to supply their wants, made her eager



<P>to regain the friends she had so carelessly sacrificed;



<P>and she addressed Lady Bertram in a letter which spoke



<P>so much contrition and despondence, such a superfluity



<P>of children, and such a want of almost everything else,



<P>as could not but dispose them all to a reconciliation.



<P>She was preparing for her ninth lying-in; and after



<P>bewailing the circumstance, and imploring their countenance



<P>as sponsors to the expected child, she could not conceal



<P>how important she felt they might be to the future



<P>maintenance of the eight already in being.&nbsp; Her eldest



<P>was a boy of ten years old, a fine spirited fellow,



<P>who longed to be out in the world; but what could she do?



<P>Was there any chance of his being hereafter useful to Sir



<P>Thomas in the concerns of his West Indian property?



<P>No situation would be beneath him; or what did Sir Thomas



<P>think of Woolwich? or how could a boy be sent out to



<P>the East?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The letter was not unproductive.&nbsp; It re-established



<P>peace and kindness.&nbsp; Sir Thomas sent friendly



<P>advice and professions, Lady Bertram dispatched



<P>money and baby-linen, and Mrs. Norris wrote the letters.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such were its immediate effects, and within a twelvemonth



<P>a more important advantage to Mrs. Price resulted from it.



<P>Mrs. Norris was often observing to the others that she



<P>could not get her poor sister and her family out of



<P>her head, and that, much as they had all done for her,



<P>she seemed to be wanting to do more; and at length she



<P>could not but own it to be her wish that poor Mrs. Price



<P>should be relieved from the charge and expense of one child



<P>entirely out of her great number.&nbsp; "What if they were



<P>among them to undertake the care of her eldest daughter,



<P>a girl now nine years old, of an age to require more



<P>attention than her poor mother could possibly give?



<P>The trouble and expense of it to them would be nothing,



<P>compared with the benevolence of the action."&nbsp; Lady Bertram



<P>agreed with her instantly.&nbsp; "I think we cannot do better,"



<P>said she; "let us send for the child."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas could not give so instantaneous and unqualified



<P>a consent.&nbsp; He debated and hesitated;--it was a serious charge;--



<P>a girl so brought up must be adequately provided for,



<P>or there would be cruelty instead of kindness in taking



<P>her from her family.&nbsp; He thought of his own four children,



<P>of his two sons, of cousins in love, etc.;--but no sooner



<P>had he deliberately begun to state his objections,



<P>than Mrs. Norris interrupted him with a reply to them all,



<P>whether stated or not.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Sir Thomas, I perfectly comprehend you, and do



<P>justice to the generosity and delicacy of your notions,



<P>which indeed are quite of a piece with your general conduct;



<P>and I entirely agree with you in the main as to the propriety



<P>of doing everything one could by way of providing for a



<P>child one had in a manner taken into one's own hands;



<P>and I am sure I should be the last person in the world to



<P>withhold my mite upon such an occasion.&nbsp; Having no children



<P>of my own, who should I look to in any little matter I



<P>may ever have to bestow, but the children of my sisters?--



<P>and I am sure Mr. Norris is too just--but you know I am



<P>a woman of few words and professions.&nbsp; Do not let us



<P>be frightened from a good deed by a trifle.&nbsp; Give a girl



<P>an education, and introduce her properly into the world,



<P>and ten to one but she has the means of settling well,



<P>without farther expense to anybody.&nbsp; A niece of ours,



<P>Sir Thomas, I may say, or at least of_yours_, would not



<P>grow up in this neighbourhood without many advantages.



<P>I don't say she would be so handsome as her cousins.



<P>I dare say she would not; but she would be introduced into



<P>the society of this country under such very favourable



<P>circumstances as, in all human probability, would get her



<P>a creditable establishment.&nbsp; You are thinking of your sons--



<P>but do not you know that, of all things upon earth,



<P>_that_ is the least likely to happen, brought up as they



<P>would be, always together like brothers and sisters?



<P>It is morally impossible.&nbsp; I never knew an instance of it.



<P>It is, in fact, the only sure way of providing against



<P>the connexion.&nbsp; Suppose her a pretty girl, and seen by Tom



<P>or Edmund for the first time seven years hence, and I dare



<P>say there would be mischief.&nbsp; The very idea of her having



<P>been suffered to grow up at a distance from us all in poverty



<P>and neglect, would be enough to make either of the dear,



<P>sweet-tempered boys in love with her.&nbsp; But breed her up



<P>with them from this time, and suppose her even to have the



<P>beauty of an angel, and she will never be more to either than



<P>a sister."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is a great deal of truth in what you say,"



<P>replied Sir Thomas, "and far be it from me to throw any



<P>fanciful impediment in the way of a plan which would be



<P>so consistent with the relative situations of each.&nbsp; I only



<P>meant to observe that it ought not to be lightly engaged in,



<P>and that to make it really serviceable to Mrs. Price,



<P>and creditable to ourselves, we must secure to the child,



<P>or consider ourselves engaged to secure to her hereafter,



<P>as circumstances may arise, the provision of a gentlewoman,



<P>if no such establishment should offer as you are so sanguine



<P>in expecting."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thoroughly understand you," cried Mrs. Norris,



<P>"you are everything that is generous and considerate,



<P>and I am sure we shall never disagree on this point.



<P>Whatever I can do, as you well know, I am always ready



<P>enough to do for the good of those I love; and, though I



<P>could never feel for this little girl the hundredth



<P>part of the regard I bear your own dear children,



<P>nor consider her, in any respect, so much my own,



<P>I should hate myself if I were capable of neglecting her.



<P>Is not she a sister's child? and could I bear to see



<P>her want while I had a bit of bread to give her?



<P>My dear Sir Thomas, with all my faults I have a warm heart;



<P>and, poor as I am, would rather deny myself the necessaries



<P>of life than do an ungenerous thing.&nbsp; So, if you are not



<P>against it, I will write to my poor sister tomorrow,



<P>and make the proposal; and, as soon as matters are settled,



<P>_I_ will engage to get the child to Mansfield; _you_ shall



<P>have no trouble about it.&nbsp; My own trouble, you know,



<P>I never regard.&nbsp; I will send Nanny to London on purpose,



<P>and she may have a bed at her cousin the saddler's, and the



<P>child be appointed to meet her there.&nbsp; They may easily get



<P>her from Portsmouth to town by the coach, under the care



<P>of any creditable person that may chance to be going.



<P>I dare say there is always some reputable tradesman's wife



<P>or other going up."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Except to the attack on Nanny's cousin, Sir Thomas no longer



<P>made any objection, and a more respectable, though less



<P>economical rendezvous being accordingly substituted,



<P>everything was considered as settled, and the pleasures



<P>of so benevolent a scheme were already enjoyed.



<P>The division of gratifying sensations ought not,



<P>in strict justice, to have been equal; for Sir Thomas was



<P>fully resolved to be the real and consistent patron of the



<P>selected child, and Mrs. Norris had not the least intention



<P>of being at any expense whatever in her maintenance.



<P>As far as walking, talking, and contriving reached,



<P>she was thoroughly benevolent, and nobody knew better



<P>how to dictate liberality to others; but her love of money



<P>was equal to her love of directing, and she knew quite as



<P>well how to save her own as to spend that of her friends.



<P>Having married on a narrower income than she had been



<P>used to look forward to, she had, from the first,



<P>fancied a very strict line of economy necessary;



<P>and what was begun as a matter of prudence, soon grew



<P>into a matter of choice, as an object of that needful



<P>solicitude which there were no children to supply.



<P>Had there been a family to provide for, Mrs. Norris might



<P>never have saved her money; but having no care of that kind,



<P>there was nothing to impede her frugality, or lessen the



<P>comfort of making a yearly addition to an income which they



<P>had never lived up to.&nbsp; Under this infatuating principle,



<P>counteracted by no real affection for her sister,



<P>it was impossible for her to aim at more than the credit



<P>of projecting and arranging so expensive a charity;



<P>though perhaps she might so little know herself as to



<P>walk home to the Parsonage, after this conversation,



<P>in the happy belief of being the most liberal-minded



<P>sister and aunt in the world.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the subject was brought forward again, her views



<P>were more fully explained; and, in reply to Lady Bertram's



<P>calm inquiry of "Where shall the child come to first,



<P>sister, to you or to us?"&nbsp; Sir Thomas heard with some



<P>surprise that it would be totally out of Mrs. Norris's



<P>power to take any share in the personal charge of her.



<P>He had been considering her as a particularly welcome



<P>addition at the Parsonage, as a desirable companion



<P>to an aunt who had no children of her own; but he found



<P>himself wholly mistaken.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris was sorry to say



<P>that the little girl's staying with them, at least



<P>as things then were, was quite out of the question.



<P>Poor Mr. Norris's indifferent state of health made it



<P>an impossibility:&nbsp; he could no more bear the noise of a child



<P>than he could fly; if, indeed, he should ever get well



<P>of his gouty complaints, it would be a different matter:



<P>she should then be glad to take her turn, and think nothing



<P>of the inconvenience; but just now, poor Mr. Norris



<P>took up every moment of her time, and the very mention



<P>of such a thing she was sure would distract him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then she had better come to us," said Lady Bertram,



<P>with the utmost composure.&nbsp; After a short pause Sir Thomas



<P>added with dignity, "Yes, let her home be in this house.



<P>We will endeavour to do our duty by her, and she will,



<P>at least, have the advantage of companions of her own age,



<P>and of a regular instructress."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true," cried Mrs. Norris, "which are both very



<P>important considerations; and it will be just the same



<P>to Miss Lee whether she has three girls to teach,



<P>or only two--there can be no difference.&nbsp; I only wish I



<P>could be more useful; but you see I do all in my power.



<P>I am not one of those that spare their own trouble;



<P>and Nanny shall fetch her, however it may put me



<P>to inconvenience to have my chief counsellor away for



<P>three days.&nbsp; I suppose, sister, you will put the child



<P>in the little white attic, near the old nurseries.



<P>It will be much the best place for her, so near Miss Lee,



<P>and not far from the girls, and close by the housemaids,



<P>who could either of them help to dress her, you know,



<P>and take care of her clothes, for I suppose you would not



<P>think it fair to expect Ellis to wait on her as well as



<P>the others.&nbsp; Indeed, I do not see that you could possibly



<P>place her anywhere else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram made no opposition.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope she will prove a well-disposed girl,"



<P>continued Mrs. Norris, "and be sensible of her uncommon



<P>good fortune in having such friends."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Should her disposition be really bad," said Sir Thomas,



<P>"we must not, for our own children's sake, continue her



<P>in the family; but there is no reason to expect so great



<P>an evil.&nbsp; We shall probably see much to wish altered



<P>in her, and must prepare ourselves for gross ignorance,



<P>some meanness of opinions, and very distressing vulgarity



<P>of manner; but these are not incurable faults; nor, I trust,



<P>can they be dangerous for her associates.&nbsp; Had my daughters



<P>been _younger_ than herself, I should have considered



<P>the introduction of such a companion as a matter of very



<P>serious moment; but, as it is, I hope there can be nothing



<P>to fear for _them_, and everything to hope for _her_,



<P>from the association."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is exactly what I think," cried Mrs. Norris,



<P>"and what I was saying to my husband this morning.



<P>It will be an education for the child, said I, only being



<P>with her cousins; if Miss Lee taught her nothing, she would



<P>learn to be good and clever from _them_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope she will not tease my poor pug," said Lady Bertram;



<P>"I have but just got Julia to leave it alone."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There will be some difficulty in our way, Mrs. Norris,"



<P>observed Sir Thomas, "as to the distinction proper to be made



<P>between the girls as they grow up:&nbsp; how to preserve in the



<P>minds of my _daughters_ the consciousness of what they are,



<P>without making them think too lowly of their cousin;



<P>and how, without depressing her spirits too far,



<P>to make her remember that she is not a _Miss Bertram_.



<P>I should wish to see them very good friends, and would,



<P>on no account, authorise in my girls the smallest degree



<P>of arrogance towards their relation; but still they cannot



<P>be equals.&nbsp; Their rank, fortune, rights, and expectations



<P>will always be different.&nbsp; It is a point of great delicacy,



<P>and you must assist us in our endeavours to choose exactly



<P>the right line of conduct."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris was quite at his service; and though she



<P>perfectly agreed with him as to its being a most



<P>difficult thing, encouraged him to hope that between



<P>them it would be easily managed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It will be readily believed that Mrs. Norris did not write



<P>to her sister in vain.&nbsp; Mrs. Price seemed rather surprised



<P>that a girl should be fixed on, when she had so many fine boys,



<P>but accepted the offer most thankfully, assuring them of her



<P>daughter's being a very well-disposed, good-humoured girl,



<P>and trusting they would never have cause to throw her off.



<P>She spoke of her farther as somewhat delicate and puny,



<P>but was sanguine in the hope of her being materially better



<P>for change of air.&nbsp; Poor woman! she probably thought



<P>change of air might agree with many of her children.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 15</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Miss Crawford accepted the part very readily; and soon after



<P>Miss Bertram's return from the Parsonage, Mr. Rushworth



<P>arrived, and another character was consequently cast.



<P>He had the offer of Count Cassel and Anhalt, and at first



<P>did not know which to chuse, and wanted Miss Bertram



<P>to direct him; but upon being made to understand the



<P>different style of the characters, and which was which,



<P>and recollecting that he had once seen the play in London,



<P>and had thought Anhalt a very stupid fellow, he soon



<P>decided for the Count.&nbsp; Miss Bertram approved the decision,



<P>for the less he had to learn the better; and though she



<P>could not sympathise in his wish that the Count and



<P>Agatha might be to act together, nor wait very patiently



<P>while he was slowly turning over the leaves with the hope



<P>of still discovering such a scene, she very kindly took



<P>his part in hand, and curtailed every speech that admitted



<P>being shortened; besides pointing out the necessity



<P>of his being very much dressed, and chusing his colours.



<P>Mr. Rushworth liked the idea of his finery very well,



<P>though affecting to despise it; and was too much



<P>engaged with what his own appearance would be to think



<P>of the others, or draw any of those conclusions, or feel



<P>any of that displeasure which Maria had been half prepared for.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Thus much was settled before Edmund, who had been out all



<P>the morning, knew anything of the matter; but when he



<P>entered the drawing-room before dinner, the buzz of



<P>discussion was high between Tom, Maria, and Mr. Yates;



<P>and Mr. Rushworth stepped forward with great alacrity



<P>to tell him the agreeable news.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We have got a play," said he.&nbsp; "It is to be Lovers'



<P>Vows; and I am to be Count Cassel, and am to come



<P>in first with a blue dress and a pink satin cloak,



<P>and afterwards am to have another fine fancy suit,



<P>by way of a shooting-dress. I do not know how I shall like it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's eyes followed Edmund, and her heart beat for him



<P>as she heard this speech, and saw his look, and felt



<P>what his sensations must be.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Lovers' Vows!" in a tone of the greatest amazement,



<P>was his only reply to Mr. Rushworth, and he turned



<P>towards his brother and sisters as if hardly doubting



<P>a contradiction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," cried Mr. Yates.&nbsp; "After all our debatings



<P>and difficulties, we find there is nothing that will



<P>suit us altogether so well, nothing so unexceptionable,



<P>as Lovers' Vows.&nbsp; The wonder is that it should not have been



<P>thought of before.&nbsp; My stupidity was abominable, for here



<P>we have all the advantage of what I saw at Ecclesford;



<P>and it is so useful to have anything of a model!



<P>We have cast almost every part."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But what do you do for women?" said Edmund gravely,



<P>and looking at Maria.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Maria blushed in spite of herself as she answered,



<P>"I take the part which Lady Ravenshaw was to have done,



<P>and" (with a bolder eye) "Miss Crawford is to be Amelia."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should not have thought it the sort of play to be so



<P>easily filled up, with _us_," replied Edmund, turning away



<P>to the fire, where sat his mother, aunt, and Fanny,



<P>and seating himself with a look of great vexation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Rushworth followed him to say, "I come in three times,



<P>and have two-and-forty speeches.&nbsp; That's something,



<P>is not it?&nbsp; But I do not much like the idea of being so fine.



<P>I shall hardly know myself in a blue dress and a pink



<P>satin cloak."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund could not answer him.&nbsp; In a few minutes Mr. Bertram



<P>was called out of the room to satisfy some doubts



<P>of the carpenter; and being accompanied by Mr. Yates,



<P>and followed soon afterwards by Mr. Rushworth, Edmund almost



<P>immediately took the opportunity of saying, "I cannot,



<P>before Mr. Yates, speak what I feel as to this play,



<P>without reflecting on his friends at Ecclesford;



<P>but I must now, my dear Maria, tell _you_, that I



<P>think it exceedingly unfit for private representation,



<P>and that I hope you will give it up.&nbsp; I cannot but suppose



<P>you _will_ when you have read it carefully over.



<P>Read only the first act aloud to either your mother or aunt,



<P>and see how you can approve it.&nbsp; It will not be necessary



<P>to send you to your _father's_ judgment, I am convinced."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We see things very differently," cried Maria.



<P>"I am perfectly acquainted with the play, I assure you;



<P>and with a very few omissions, and so forth, which will



<P>be made, of course, I can see nothing objectionable in it;



<P>and _I_ am not the _only_ young woman you find who thinks



<P>it very fit for private representation."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am sorry for it," was his answer; "but in this matter



<P>it is _you_ who are to lead.&nbsp; _You_ must set the example.



<P>If others have blundered, it is your place to put



<P>them right, and shew them what true delicacy is.



<P>In all points of decorum _your_ conduct must be law



<P>to the rest of the party."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This picture of her consequence had some effect, for no



<P>one loved better to lead than Maria; and with far more



<P>good-humour she answered, "I am much obliged to you, Edmund;



<P>you mean very well, I am sure:&nbsp; but I still think you



<P>see things too strongly; and I really cannot undertake



<P>to harangue all the rest upon a subject of this kind.



<P>_There_ would be the greatest indecorum, I think."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you imagine that I could have such an idea in



<P>my head?&nbsp; No; let your conduct be the only harangue.



<P>Say that, on examining the part, you feel yourself



<P>unequal to it; that you find it requiring more exertion



<P>and confidence than you can be supposed to have.



<P>Say this with firmness, and it will be quite enough.



<P>All who can distinguish will understand your motive.



<P>The play will be given up, and your delicacy honoured as



<P>it ought."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do not act anything improper, my dear," said Lady Bertram.



<P>"Sir Thomas would not like it.--Fanny, ring the bell;



<P>I must have my dinner.--To be sure, Julia is dressed by



<P>this time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am convinced, madam," said Edmund, preventing Fanny,



<P>"that Sir Thomas would not like it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There, my dear, do you hear what Edmund says?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I were to decline the part," said Maria,



<P>with renewed zeal, "Julia would certainly take it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What!" cried Edmund, "if she knew your reasons!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! she might think the difference between us--



<P>the difference in our situations--that _she_ need



<P>not be so scrupulous as _I_ might feel necessary.



<P>I am sure she would argue so.&nbsp; No; you must excuse me;



<P>I cannot retract my consent; it is too far settled,



<P>everybody would be so disappointed, Tom would be quite angry;



<P>and if we are so very nice, we shall never act anything."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was just going to say the very same thing," said Mrs. Norris.



<P>"If every play is to be objected to, you will act nothing,



<P>and the preparations will be all so much money thrown away,



<P>and I am sure _that_ would be a discredit to us all.



<P>I do not know the play; but, as Maria says, if there



<P>is anything a little too warm (and it is so with most



<P>of them) it can be easily left out.&nbsp; We must not be



<P>over-precise, Edmund.&nbsp; As Mr. Rushworth is to act too,



<P>there can be no harm.&nbsp; I only wish Tom had known his own



<P>mind when the carpenters began, for there was the loss



<P>of half a day's work about those side-doors. The curtain



<P>will be a good job, however.&nbsp; The maids do their work



<P>very well, and I think we shall be able to send back



<P>some dozens of the rings.&nbsp; There is no occasion to put



<P>them so very close together.&nbsp; I _am_ of some use, I hope,



<P>in preventing waste and making the most of things.



<P>There should always be one steady head to superintend



<P>so many young ones.&nbsp; I forgot to tell Tom of something



<P>that happened to me this very day.&nbsp; I had been looking



<P>about me in the poultry-yard, and was just coming out,



<P>when who should I see but Dick Jackson making up



<P>to the servants' hall-door with two bits of deal board



<P>in his hand, bringing them to father, you may be sure;



<P>mother had chanced to send him of a message to father,



<P>and then father had bid him bring up them two bits of board,



<P>for he could not no how do without them.&nbsp; I knew what all



<P>this meant, for the servants' dinner-bell was ringing



<P>at the very moment over our heads; and as I hate such



<P>encroaching people (the Jacksons are very encroaching,



<P>I have always said so:&nbsp; just the sort of people to get



<P>all they can), I said to the boy directly (a great lubberly



<P>fellow of ten years old, you know, who ought to be ashamed



<P>of himself), "_I'll_ take the boards to your father,



<P>Dick, so get you home again as fast as you can."



<P>The boy looked very silly, and turned away without



<P>offering a word, for I believe I might speak pretty sharp;



<P>and I dare say it will cure him of coming marauding



<P>about the house for one while.&nbsp; I hate such greediness--



<P>so good as your father is to the family, employing the man



<P>all the year round!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nobody was at the trouble of an answer; the others



<P>soon returned; and Edmund found that to have endeavoured



<P>to set them right must be his only satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dinner passed heavily.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris related again



<P>her triumph over Dick Jackson, but neither play nor



<P>preparation were otherwise much talked of, for Edmund's



<P>disapprobation was felt even by his brother, though he



<P>would not have owned it.&nbsp; Maria, wanting Henry Crawford's



<P>animating support, thought the subject better avoided.



<P>Mr. Yates, who was trying to make himself agreeable to Julia,



<P>found her gloom less impenetrable on any topic than



<P>that of his regret at her secession from their company;



<P>and Mr. Rushworth, having only his own part and his own



<P>dress in his head, had soon talked away all that could



<P>be said of either.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But the concerns of the theatre were suspended only for an



<P>hour or two:&nbsp; there was still a great deal to be settled;



<P>and the spirits of evening giving fresh courage, Tom, Maria,



<P>and Mr. Yates, soon after their being reassembled



<P>in the drawing-room, seated themselves in committee



<P>at a separate table, with the play open before them,



<P>and were just getting deep in the subject when a most



<P>welcome interruption was given by the entrance of Mr. and



<P>Miss Crawford, who, late and dark and dirty as it was,



<P>could not help coming, and were received with the most grateful



<P>joy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, how do you go on?" and "What have you settled?"



<P>and "Oh! we can do nothing without you," followed the



<P>first salutations; and Henry Crawford was soon seated



<P>with the other three at the table, while his sister made



<P>her way to Lady Bertram, and with pleasant attention



<P>was complimenting _her_.&nbsp; "I must really congratulate



<P>your ladyship," said she, "on the play being chosen;



<P>for though you have borne it with exemplary patience, I am



<P>sure you must be sick of all our noise and difficulties.



<P>The actors may be glad, but the bystanders must be infinitely



<P>more thankful for a decision; and I do sincerely give



<P>you joy, madam, as well as Mrs. Norris, and everybody else



<P>who is in the same predicament," glancing half fearfully,



<P>half slyly, beyond Fanny to Edmund.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was very civilly answered by Lady Bertram,



<P>but Edmund said nothing.&nbsp; His being only a bystander was



<P>not disclaimed.&nbsp; After continuing in chat with the party



<P>round the fire a few minutes, Miss Crawford returned



<P>to the party round the table; and standing by them,



<P>seemed to interest herself in their arrangements till,



<P>as if struck by a sudden recollection, she exclaimed,



<P>"My good friends, you are most composedly at work upon



<P>these cottages and alehouses, inside and out; but pray let



<P>me know my fate in the meanwhile.&nbsp; Who is to be Anhalt?



<P>What gentleman among you am I to have the pleasure of making



<P>love to?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a moment no one spoke; and then many spoke together



<P>to tell the same melancholy truth, that they had not yet



<P>got any Anhalt.&nbsp; "Mr. Rushworth was to be Count Cassel,



<P>but no one had yet undertaken Anhalt."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had my choice of the parts," said Mr. Rushworth;



<P>"but I thought I should like the Count best, though I do



<P>not much relish the finery I am to have."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You chose very wisely, I am sure," replied Miss Crawford,



<P>with a brightened look; "Anhalt is a heavy part."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_The_ _Count_ has two-and-forty speeches,"



<P>returned Mr. Rushworth, "which is no trifle."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not at all surprised," said Miss Crawford,



<P>after a short pause, "at this want of an Anhalt.



<P>Amelia deserves no better.&nbsp; Such a forward young lady



<P>may well frighten the men."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should be but too happy in taking the part, if it



<P>were possible," cried Tom; "but, unluckily, the Butler



<P>and Anhalt are in together.&nbsp; I will not entirely give



<P>it up, however; I will try what can be done--I will look



<P>it over again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your _brother_ should take the part," said Mr. Yates,



<P>in a low voice.&nbsp; "Do not you think he would?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_I_ shall not ask him," replied Tom, in a cold,



<P>determined manner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford talked of something else, and soon afterwards



<P>rejoined the party at the fire.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They do not want me at all," said she, seating herself.



<P>"I only puzzle them, and oblige them to make civil speeches.



<P>Mr. Edmund Bertram, as you do not act yourself,



<P>you will be a disinterested adviser; and, therefore,



<P>I apply to _you_.&nbsp; What shall we do for an Anhalt?



<P>Is it practicable for any of the others to double it?



<P>What is your advice?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My advice," said he calmly, "is that you change the play."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_I_ should have no objection," she replied; "for though



<P>I should not particularly dislike the part of Amelia



<P>if well supported, that is, if everything went well,



<P>I shall be sorry to be an inconvenience; but as they



<P>do not chuse to hear your advice at _that_ _table_"



<P>(looking round), "it certainly will not be taken."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund said no more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If _any_ part could tempt _you_ to act, I suppose it would



<P>be Anhalt," observed the lady archly, after a short pause;



<P>"for he is a clergyman, you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_That_ circumstance would by no means tempt me,"



<P>he replied, "for I should be sorry to make the character



<P>ridiculous by bad acting.&nbsp; It must be very difficult



<P>to keep Anhalt from appearing a formal, solemn lecturer;



<P>and the man who chuses the profession itself is, perhaps,



<P>one of the last who would wish to represent it on the stage."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford was silenced, and with some feelings of resentment



<P>and mortification, moved her chair considerably nearer the



<P>tea-table, and gave all her attention to Mrs. Norris, who was



<P>presiding there.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fanny," cried Tom Bertram, from the other table,



<P>where the conference was eagerly carrying on, and the



<P>conversation incessant, "we want your services"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was up in a moment, expecting some errand; for the



<P>habit of employing her in that way was not yet overcome,



<P>in spite of all that Edmund could do.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! we do not want to disturb you from your seat.



<P>We do not want your _present_ services.&nbsp; We shall only want



<P>you in our play.&nbsp; You must be Cottager's wife."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Me!" cried Fanny, sitting down again with a most frightened look.



<P>"Indeed you must excuse me.&nbsp; I could not act anything



<P>if you were to give me the world.&nbsp; No, indeed, I cannot act."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed, but you must, for we cannot excuse you.



<P>It need not frighten you:&nbsp; it is a nothing of a part,



<P>a mere nothing, not above half a dozen speeches altogether,



<P>and it will not much signify if nobody hears a word you say;



<P>so you may be as creep-mouse as you like, but we must have



<P>you to look at."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you are afraid of half a dozen speeches," cried Mr. Rushworth,



<P>"what would you do with such a part as mine?&nbsp; I have forty-two

to



<P>learn."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is not that I am afraid of learning by heart,"



<P>said Fanny, shocked to find herself at that moment the



<P>only speaker in the room, and to feel that almost every



<P>eye was upon her; "but I really cannot act."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, yes, you can act well enough for _us_.



<P>Learn your part, and we will teach you all the rest.



<P>You have only two scenes, and as I shall be Cottager,



<P>I'll put you in and push you about, and you will do it



<P>very well, I'll answer for it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed, Mr. Bertram, you must excuse me.&nbsp; You cannot



<P>have an idea.&nbsp; It would be absolutely impossible for me.



<P>If I were to undertake it, I should only disappoint you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Phoo!&nbsp; Phoo!&nbsp; Do not be so shamefaced.&nbsp; You'll do it



<P>very well.&nbsp; Every allowance will be made for you.



<P>We do not expect perfection.&nbsp; You must get a brown gown,



<P>and a white apron, and a mob cap, and we must make



<P>you a few wrinkles, and a little of the crowsfoot at



<P>the corner of your eyes, and you will be a very proper,



<P>little old woman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must excuse me, indeed you must excuse me," cried Fanny,



<P>growing more and more red from excessive agitation,



<P>and looking distressfully at Edmund, who was kindly



<P>observing her; but unwilling to exasperate his brother



<P>by interference, gave her only an encouraging smile.



<P>Her entreaty had no effect on Tom:&nbsp; he only said again



<P>what he had said before; and it was not merely Tom,



<P>for the requisition was now backed by Maria, and Mr. Crawford,



<P>and Mr. Yates, with an urgency which differed from



<P>his but in being more gentle or more ceremonious,



<P>and which altogether was quite overpowering to Fanny;



<P>and before she could breathe after it, Mrs. Norris completed



<P>the whole by thus addressing her in a whisper at once angry



<P>and audible--"What a piece of work here is about nothing:



<P>I am quite ashamed of you, Fanny, to make such a difficulty



<P>of obliging your cousins in a trifle of this sort--so kind



<P>as they are to you!&nbsp; Take the part with a good grace,



<P>and let us hear no more of the matter, I entreat."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do not urge her, madam," said Edmund.&nbsp; "It is not fair to



<P>urge her in this manner.&nbsp; You see she does not like to act.



<P>Let her chuse for herself, as well as the rest of us.



<P>Her judgment may be quite as safely trusted.&nbsp; Do not urge



<P>her any more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not going to urge her," replied Mrs. Norris sharply;



<P>"but I shall think her a very obstinate, ungrateful girl,



<P>if she does not do what her aunt and cousins wish her--



<P>very ungrateful, indeed, considering who and what she is."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund was too angry to speak; but Miss Crawford,



<P>looking for a moment with astonished eyes at Mrs. Norris,



<P>and then at Fanny, whose tears were beginning to shew



<P>themselves, immediately said, with some keenness, "I do



<P>not like my situation:&nbsp; this _place_ is too hot for me,"



<P>and moved away her chair to the opposite side of the table,



<P>close to Fanny, saying to her, in a kind, low whisper,



<P>as she placed herself, "Never mind, my dear Miss Price,



<P>this is a cross evening:&nbsp; everybody is cross and teasing,



<P>but do not let us mind them"; and with pointed attention



<P>continued to talk to her and endeavour to raise her spirits,



<P>in spite of being out of spirits herself.&nbsp; By a look at



<P>her brother she prevented any farther entreaty from the



<P>theatrical board, and the really good feelings by which she



<P>was almost purely governed were rapidly restoring her



<P>to all the little she had lost in Edmund's favour.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny did not love Miss Crawford; but she felt very much



<P>obliged to her for her present kindness; and when,



<P>from taking notice of her work, and wishing _she_ could



<P>work as well, and begging for the pattern, and supposing



<P>Fanny was now preparing for her _appearance_, as of



<P>course she would come out when her cousin was married,



<P>Miss Crawford proceeded to inquire if she had heard lately



<P>from her brother at sea, and said that she had quite



<P>a curiosity to see him, and imagined him a very fine



<P>young man, and advised Fanny to get his picture drawn



<P>before he went to sea again--she could not help admitting



<P>it to be very agreeable flattery, or help listening,



<P>and answering with more animation than she had intended.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The consultation upon the play still went on, and Miss



<P>Crawford's attention was first called from Fanny by Tom



<P>Bertram's telling her, with infinite regret, that he



<P>found it absolutely impossible for him to undertake the



<P>part of Anhalt in addition to the Butler:&nbsp; he had been



<P>most anxiously trying to make it out to be feasible,



<P>but it would not do; he must give it up.&nbsp; "But there will



<P>not be the smallest difficulty in filling it," he added.



<P>"We have but to speak the word; we may pick and chuse.



<P>I could name, at this moment, at least six young men within



<P>six miles of us, who are wild to be admitted into our company,



<P>and there are one or two that would not disgrace us:



<P>I should not be afraid to trust either of the Olivers



<P>or Charles Maddox.&nbsp; Tom Oliver is a very clever fellow,



<P>and Charles Maddox is as gentlemanlike a man as you will



<P>see anywhere, so I will take my horse early to-morrow



<P>morning and ride over to Stoke, and settle with one



<P>of them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While he spoke, Maria was looking apprehensively round



<P>at Edmund in full expectation that he must oppose such



<P>an enlargement of the plan as this:&nbsp; so contrary to all



<P>their first protestations; but Edmund said nothing.



<P>After a moment's thought, Miss Crawford calmly replied,



<P>"As far as I am concerned, I can have no objection to



<P>anything that you all think eligible.&nbsp; Have I ever seen



<P>either of the gentlemen?&nbsp; Yes, Mr. Charles Maddox dined



<P>at my sister's one day, did not he, Henry?&nbsp; A quiet-looking



<P>young man.&nbsp; I remember him.&nbsp; Let _him_ be applied to,



<P>if you please, for it will be less unpleasant to me than



<P>to have a perfect stranger."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Charles Maddox was to be the man.&nbsp; Tom repeated his resolution



<P>of going to him early on the morrow; and though Julia,



<P>who had scarcely opened her lips before, observed, in a



<P>sarcastic manner, and with a glance first at Maria and then



<P>at Edmund, that "the Mansfield theatricals would enliven



<P>the whole neighbourhood exceedingly," Edmund still held



<P>his peace, and shewed his feelings only by a determined gravity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not very sanguine as to our play," said Miss Crawford,



<P>in an undervoice to Fanny, after some consideration;



<P>"and I can tell Mr. Maddox that I shall shorten some



<P>of _his_ speeches, and a great many of _my_ _own_,



<P>before we rehearse together.&nbsp; It will be very disagreeable,



<P>and by no means what I expected."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 29</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXIX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The ball was over, and the breakfast was soon over too;



<P>the last kiss was given, and William was gone.



<P>Mr. Crawford had, as he foretold, been very punctual,



<P>and short and pleasant had been the meal.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After seeing William to the last moment, Fanny walked



<P>back to the breakfast-room with a very saddened heart



<P>to grieve over the melancholy change; and there her uncle



<P>kindly left her to cry in peace, conceiving, perhaps,



<P>that the deserted chair of each young man might exercise



<P>her tender enthusiasm, and that the remaining cold pork



<P>bones and mustard in William's plate might but divide



<P>her feelings with the broken egg-shells in Mr. Crawford's.



<P>She sat and cried _con_ _amore_ as her uncle intended,



<P>but it was _con_ _amore_ fraternal and no other.



<P>William was gone, and she now felt as if she had wasted



<P>half his visit in idle cares and selfish solicitudes



<P>unconnected with him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's disposition was such that she could never even think



<P>of her aunt Norris in the meagreness and cheerlessness



<P>of her own small house, without reproaching herself



<P>for some little want of attention to her when they had



<P>been last together; much less could her feelings acquit



<P>her of having done and said and thought everything



<P>by William that was due to him for a whole fortnight.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a heavy, melancholy day.&nbsp; Soon after the second



<P>breakfast, Edmund bade them good-bye for a week, and mounted



<P>his horse for Peterborough, and then all were gone.



<P>Nothing remained of last night but remembrances, which she



<P>had nobody to share in.&nbsp; She talked to her aunt Bertram--



<P>she must talk to somebody of the ball; but her aunt had seen



<P>so little of what had passed, and had so little curiosity,



<P>that it was heavy work.&nbsp; Lady Bertram was not certain of



<P>anybody's dress or anybody's place at supper but her own.



<P>"She could not recollect what it was that she had heard



<P>about one of the Miss Maddoxes, or what it was that Lady



<P>Prescott had noticed in Fanny:&nbsp; she was not sure whether



<P>Colonel Harrison had been talking of Mr. Crawford or of



<P>William when he said he was the finest young man in the room--



<P>somebody had whispered something to her; she had forgot



<P>to ask Sir Thomas what it could be."&nbsp; And these were her



<P>longest speeches and clearest communications:&nbsp; the rest



<P>was only a languid "Yes, yes; very well; did you? did he?



<P>I did not see _that_; I should not know one from the other."



<P>This was very bad.&nbsp; It was only better than Mrs. Norris's



<P>sharp answers would have been; but she being gone home



<P>with all the supernumerary jellies to nurse a sick maid,



<P>there was peace and good-humour in their little party,



<P>though it could not boast much beside.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The evening was heavy like the day.&nbsp; "I cannot think



<P>what is the matter with me," said Lady Bertram,



<P>when the tea-things were removed.&nbsp; "I feel quite stupid.



<P>It must be sitting up so late last night.&nbsp; Fanny, you must



<P>do something to keep me awake.&nbsp; I cannot work.



<P>Fetch the cards; I feel so very stupid."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The cards were brought, and Fanny played at cribbage



<P>with her aunt till bedtime; and as Sir Thomas was reading



<P>to himself, no sounds were heard in the room for the next



<P>two hours beyond the reckonings of the game--"And _that_



<P>makes thirty-one; four in hand and eight in crib.



<P>You are to deal, ma'am; shall I deal for you?"&nbsp; Fanny thought



<P>and thought again of the difference which twenty-four hours



<P>had made in that room, and all that part of the house.



<P>Last night it had been hope and smiles, bustle and motion,



<P>noise and brilliancy, in the drawing-room, and out of



<P>the drawing-room, and everywhere.&nbsp; Now it was languor,



<P>and all but solitude.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A good night's rest improved her spirits.&nbsp; She could think



<P>of William the next day more cheerfully; and as the morning



<P>afforded her an opportunity of talking over Thursday night



<P>with Mrs. Grant and Miss Crawford, in a very handsome style,



<P>with all the heightenings of imagination, and all the



<P>laughs of playfulness which are so essential to the shade



<P>of a departed ball, she could afterwards bring her mind



<P>without much effort into its everyday state, and easily



<P>conform to the tranquillity of the present quiet week.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were indeed a smaller party than she had ever



<P>known there for a whole day together, and _he_ was gone



<P>on whom the comfort and cheerfulness of every family



<P>meeting and every meal chiefly depended.&nbsp; But this must



<P>be learned to be endured.&nbsp; He would soon be always gone;



<P>and she was thankful that she could now sit in the same room



<P>with her uncle, hear his voice, receive his questions,



<P>and even answer them, without such wretched feelings



<P>as she had formerly known.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We miss our two young men," was Sir Thomas's observation



<P>on both the first and second day, as they formed their



<P>very reduced circle after dinner; and in consideration



<P>of Fanny's swimming eyes, nothing more was said



<P>on the first day than to drink their good health;



<P>but on the second it led to something farther.



<P>William was kindly commended and his promotion hoped for.



<P>"And there is no reason to suppose," added Sir Thomas,



<P>"but that his visits to us may now be tolerably frequent.



<P>As to Edmund, we must learn to do without him.



<P>This will be the last winter of his belonging to us,



<P>as he has done."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said Lady Bertram, "but I wish he was not going away.



<P>They are all going away, I think.&nbsp; I wish they would stay



<P>at home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This wish was levelled principally at Julia, who had



<P>just applied for permission to go to town with Maria;



<P>and as Sir Thomas thought it best for each daughter that the



<P>permission should be granted, Lady Bertram, though in her own



<P>good-nature she would not have prevented it, was lamenting



<P>the change it made in the prospect of Julia's return,



<P>which would otherwise have taken place about this time.



<P>A great deal of good sense followed on Sir Thomas's side,



<P>tending to reconcile his wife to the arrangement.



<P>Everything that a considerate parent _ought_ to feel was



<P>advanced for her use; and everything that an affectionate



<P>mother _must_ feel in promoting her children's enjoyment



<P>was attributed to her nature.&nbsp; Lady Bertram agreed to it



<P>all with a calm "Yes"; and at the end of a quarter of



<P>an hour's silent consideration spontaneously observed,



<P>"Sir Thomas, I have been thinking--and I am very glad we



<P>took Fanny as we did, for now the others are away we feel



<P>the good of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas immediately improved this compliment by adding,



<P>"Very true.&nbsp; We shew Fanny what a good girl we think



<P>her by praising her to her face, she is now a very



<P>valuable companion.&nbsp; If we have been kind to _her_,



<P>she is now quite as necessary to _us_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said Lady Bertram presently; "and it is a comfort



<P>to think that we shall always have _her_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas paused, half smiled, glanced at his niece,



<P>and then gravely replied, "She will never leave us, I hope,



<P>till invited to some other home that may reasonably promise



<P>her greater happiness than she knows here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And _that_ is not very likely to be, Sir Thomas.



<P>Who should invite her?&nbsp; Maria might be very glad to see her



<P>at Sotherton now and then, but she would not think of asking



<P>her to live there; and I am sure she is better off here;



<P>and besides, I cannot do without her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The week which passed so quietly and peaceably at the



<P>great house in Mansfield had a very different character at



<P>the Parsonage.&nbsp; To the young lady, at least, in each family,



<P>it brought very different feelings.&nbsp; What was tranquillity



<P>and comfort to Fanny was tediousness and vexation to Mary.



<P>Something arose from difference of disposition and habit:



<P>one so easily satisfied, the other so unused to endure;



<P>but still more might be imputed to difference



<P>of circumstances.&nbsp; In some points of interest they



<P>were exactly opposed to each other.&nbsp; To Fanny's mind,



<P>Edmund's absence was really, in its cause and its tendency,



<P>a relief.&nbsp; To Mary it was every way painful.&nbsp; She felt



<P>the want of his society every day, almost every hour,



<P>and was too much in want of it to derive anything but



<P>irritation from considering the object for which he went.



<P>He could not have devised anything more likely to raise



<P>his consequence than this week's absence, occurring as



<P>it did at the very time of her brother's going away,



<P>of William Price's going too, and completing the sort



<P>of general break-up of a party which had been so animated.



<P>She felt it keenly.&nbsp; They were now a miserable trio,



<P>confined within doors by a series of rain and snow,



<P>with nothing to do and no variety to hope for.&nbsp; Angry as



<P>she was with Edmund for adhering to his own notions,



<P>and acting on them in defiance of her (and she had been



<P>so angry that they had hardly parted friends at the ball),



<P>she could not help thinking of him continually when absent,



<P>dwelling on his merit and affection, and longing again



<P>for the almost daily meetings they lately had.&nbsp; His absence



<P>was unnecessarily long.&nbsp; He should not have planned such



<P>an absence--he should not have left home for a week,



<P>when her own departure from Mansfield was so near.



<P>Then she began to blame herself.&nbsp; She wished she had not



<P>spoken so warmly in their last conversation.&nbsp; She was afraid



<P>she had used some strong, some contemptuous expressions



<P>in speaking of the clergy, and that should not have been.



<P>It was ill-bred; it was wrong.&nbsp; She wished such words unsaid



<P>with all her heart.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her vexation did not end with the week.&nbsp; All this was bad,



<P>but she had still more to feel when Friday came round



<P>again and brought no Edmund; when Saturday came and still



<P>no Edmund; and when, through the slight communication



<P>with the other family which Sunday produced, she learned



<P>that he had actually written home to defer his return,



<P>having promised to remain some days longer with his friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>If she had felt impatience and regret before--if she had



<P>been sorry for what she said, and feared its too strong



<P>effect on him--she now felt and feared it all tenfold more.



<P>She had, moreover, to contend with one disagreeable emotion



<P>entirely new to her--jealousy.&nbsp; His friend Mr. Owen had sisters;



<P>he might find them attractive.&nbsp; But, at any rate, his staying



<P>away at a time when, according to all preceding plans,



<P>she was to remove to London, meant something that she could



<P>not bear.&nbsp; Had Henry returned, as he talked of doing,



<P>at the end of three or four days, she should now have



<P>been leaving Mansfield.&nbsp; It became absolutely necessary



<P>for her to get to Fanny and try to learn something more.



<P>She could not live any longer in such solitary wretchedness;



<P>and she made her way to the Park, through difficulties



<P>of walking which she had deemed unconquerable a week before,



<P>for the chance of hearing a little in addition, for the



<P>sake of at least hearing his name.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The first half-hour was lost, for Fanny and Lady Bertram



<P>were together, and unless she had Fanny to herself she could



<P>hope for nothing.&nbsp; But at last Lady Bertram left the room,



<P>and then almost immediately Miss Crawford thus began,



<P>with a voice as well regulated as she could--"And how do



<P>_you_ like your cousin Edmund's staying away so long?



<P>Being the only young person at home, I consider _you_



<P>as the greatest sufferer.&nbsp; You must miss him.&nbsp; Does his



<P>staying longer surprise you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know," said Fanny hesitatingly.&nbsp; "Yes; I had



<P>not particularly expected it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps he will always stay longer than he talks of.



<P>It is the general way all young men do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He did not, the only time he went to see Mr. Owen before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"He finds the house more agreeable _now_. He is a very--



<P>a very pleasing young man himself, and I cannot help



<P>being rather concerned at not seeing him again before I



<P>go to London, as will now undoubtedly be the case.



<P>I am looking for Henry every day, and as soon as he



<P>comes there will be nothing to detain me at Mansfield.



<P>I should like to have seen him once more, I confess.



<P>But you must give my compliments to him.&nbsp; Yes; I think it must



<P>be compliments.&nbsp; Is not there a something wanted, Miss Price,



<P>in our language--a something between compliments and--



<P>and love--to suit the sort of friendly acquaintance we have



<P>had together?&nbsp; So many months' acquaintance!&nbsp; But compliments



<P>may be sufficient here.&nbsp; Was his letter a long one?



<P>Does he give you much account of what he is doing?



<P>Is it Christmas gaieties that he is staying for?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I only heard a part of the letter; it was to my uncle;



<P>but I believe it was very short; indeed I am sure it was



<P>but a few lines.&nbsp; All that I heard was that his friend



<P>had pressed him to stay longer, and that he had agreed



<P>to do so.&nbsp; A _few_ days longer, or _some_ days longer;



<P>I am not quite sure which."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! if he wrote to his father; but I thought it might



<P>have been to Lady Bertram or you.&nbsp; But if he wrote to



<P>his father, no wonder he was concise.&nbsp; Who could write



<P>chat to Sir Thomas?&nbsp; If he had written to you, there would



<P>have been more particulars.&nbsp; You would have heard of



<P>balls and parties.&nbsp; He would have sent you a description



<P>of everything and everybody.&nbsp; How many Miss Owens are there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Three grown up."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are they musical?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not at all know.&nbsp; I never heard."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is the first question, you know," said Miss Crawford,



<P>trying to appear gay and unconcerned, "which every



<P>woman who plays herself is sure to ask about another.



<P>But it is very foolish to ask questions about any



<P>young ladies--about any three sisters just grown up;



<P>for one knows, without being told, exactly what they are:



<P>all very accomplished and pleasing, and one very pretty.



<P>There is a beauty in every family; it is a regular thing.



<P>Two play on the pianoforte, and one on the harp;



<P>and all sing, or would sing if they were taught,



<P>or sing all the better for not being taught; or something



<P>like it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know nothing of the Miss Owens," said Fanny calmly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You know nothing and you care less, as people say.



<P>Never did tone express indifference plainer.&nbsp; Indeed, how can



<P>one care for those one has never seen?&nbsp; Well, when your



<P>cousin comes back, he will find Mansfield very quiet;



<P>all the noisy ones gone, your brother and mine and myself



<P>I do not like the idea of leaving Mrs. Grant now the time



<P>draws near.&nbsp; She does not like my going."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny felt obliged to speak.&nbsp; "'You cannot doubt your being



<P>missed by many," said she.&nbsp; "You will be very much missed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford turned her eye on her, as if wanting to hear



<P>or see more, and then laughingly said, "Oh yes! missed



<P>as every noisy evil is missed when it is taken away;



<P>that is, there is a great difference felt.&nbsp; But I am



<P>not fishing; don't compliment me.&nbsp; If I _am_ missed,



<P>it will appear.&nbsp; I may be discovered by those who want



<P>to see me.&nbsp; I shall not be in any doubtful, or distant,



<P>or unapproachable region."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now Fanny could not bring herself to speak, and Miss



<P>Crawford was disappointed; for she had hoped to hear



<P>some pleasant assurance of her power from one who she



<P>thought must know, and her spirits were clouded again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The Miss Owens," said she, soon afterwards; "suppose you



<P>were to have one of the Miss Owens settled at Thornton Lacey;



<P>how should you like it?&nbsp; Stranger things have happened.



<P>I dare say they are trying for it.&nbsp; And they are quite



<P>in the light, for it would be a very pretty establishment



<P>for them.&nbsp; I do not at all wonder or blame them.&nbsp; It is



<P>everybody's duty to do as well for themselves as they can.



<P>Sir Thomas Bertram's son is somebody; and now he is in their



<P>own line.&nbsp; Their father is a clergyman, and their brother



<P>is a clergyman, and they are all clergymen together.



<P>He is their lawful property; he fairly belongs to them.



<P>You don't speak, Fanny; Miss Price, you don't speak.



<P>But honestly now, do not you rather expect it than otherwise?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No," said Fanny stoutly, "I do not expect it at all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not at all!" cried Miss Crawford with alacrity.



<P>"I wonder at that.&nbsp; But I dare say you know exactly--



<P>I always imagine you are--perhaps you do not think him



<P>likely to marry at all--or not at present."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I do not," said Fanny softly, hoping she did not err



<P>either in the belief or the acknowledgment of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her companion looked at her keenly; and gathering greater



<P>spirit from the blush soon produced from such a look,



<P>only said, "He is best off as he is," and turned the subject.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 28</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXVIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Her uncle and both her aunts were in the drawing-room



<P>when Fanny went down.&nbsp; To the former she was an interesting



<P>object, and he saw with pleasure the general elegance



<P>of her appearance, and her being in remarkably good looks.



<P>The neatness and propriety of her dress was all that



<P>he would allow himself to commend in her presence,



<P>but upon her leaving the room again soon afterwards,



<P>he spoke of her beauty with very decided praise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said Lady Bertram, "she looks very well.



<P>I sent Chapman to her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Look well!&nbsp; Oh, yes!" cried Mrs. Norris, "she has



<P>good reason to look well with all her advantages:



<P>brought up in this family as she has been, with all



<P>the benefit of her cousins' manners before her.



<P>Only think, my dear Sir Thomas, what extraordinary



<P>advantages you and I have been the means of giving her.



<P>The very gown you have been taking notice of is your own



<P>generous present to her when dear Mrs. Rushworth married.



<P>What would she have been if we had not taken her by



<P>the hand?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas said no more; but when they sat down to table



<P>the eyes of the two young men assured him that the subject



<P>might be gently touched again, when the ladies withdrew,



<P>with more success.&nbsp; Fanny saw that she was approved;



<P>and the consciousness of looking well made her look



<P>still better.&nbsp; From a variety of causes she was happy,



<P>and she was soon made still happier; for in following her



<P>aunts out of the room, Edmund, who was holding open the door,



<P>said, as she passed him, "You must dance with me, Fanny;



<P>you must keep two dances for me; any two that you like,



<P>except the first."&nbsp; She had nothing more to wish for.



<P>She had hardly ever been in a state so nearly approaching



<P>high spirits in her life.&nbsp; Her cousins' former gaiety



<P>on the day of a ball was no longer surprising to her;



<P>she felt it to be indeed very charming, and was actually



<P>practising her steps about the drawing-room as long as she



<P>could be safe from the notice of her aunt Norris, who was



<P>entirely taken up at first in fresh arranging and injuring



<P>the noble fire which the butler had prepared.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Half an hour followed that would have been at least languid



<P>under any other circumstances, but Fanny's happiness



<P>still prevailed.&nbsp; It was but to think of her conversation



<P>with Edmund, and what was the restlessness of Mrs. Norris?



<P>What were the yawns of Lady Bertram?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The gentlemen joined them; and soon after began the sweet



<P>expectation of a carriage, when a general spirit of ease



<P>and enjoyment seemed diffused, and they all stood about



<P>and talked and laughed, and every moment had its pleasure



<P>and its hope.&nbsp; Fanny felt that there must be a struggle



<P>in Edmund's cheerfulness, but it was delightful to see



<P>the effort so successfully made.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the carriages were really heard, when the guests began



<P>really to assemble, her own gaiety of heart was much subdued:



<P>the sight of so many strangers threw her back into herself;



<P>and besides the gravity and formality of the first great circle,



<P>which the manners of neither Sir Thomas nor Lady Bertram



<P>were of a kind to do away, she found herself occasionally



<P>called on to endure something worse.&nbsp; She was introduced



<P>here and there by her uncle, and forced to be spoken to,



<P>and to curtsey, and speak again.&nbsp; This was a hard duty,



<P>and she was never summoned to it without looking at William,



<P>as he walked about at his ease in the background of the scene,



<P>and longing to be with him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The entrance of the Grants and Crawfords was a favourable epoch.



<P>The stiffness of the meeting soon gave way before their



<P>popular manners and more diffused intimacies:&nbsp; little groups



<P>were formed, and everybody grew comfortable.&nbsp; Fanny felt



<P>the advantage; and, drawing back from the toils of civility,



<P>would have been again most happy, could she have kept



<P>her eyes from wandering between Edmund and Mary Crawford.



<P>_She_ looked all loveliness--and what might not be



<P>the end of it?&nbsp; Her own musings were brought to an end



<P>on perceiving Mr. Crawford before her, and her thoughts



<P>were put into another channel by his engaging her almost



<P>instantly for the first two dances.&nbsp; Her happiness on this



<P>occasion was very much _a_ _la_ _mortal_, finely chequered.



<P>To be secure of a partner at first was a most essential good--



<P>for the moment of beginning was now growing seriously near;



<P>and she so little understood her own claims as to think



<P>that if Mr. Crawford had not asked her, she must have been



<P>the last to be sought after, and should have received



<P>a partner only through a series of inquiry, and bustle,



<P>and interference, which would have been terrible; but at



<P>the same time there was a pointedness in his manner of asking



<P>her which she did not like, and she saw his eye glancing



<P>for a moment at her necklace, with a smile--she thought



<P>there was a smile--which made her blush and feel wretched.



<P>And though there was no second glance to disturb her,



<P>though his object seemed then to be only quietly agreeable,



<P>she could not get the better of her embarrassment,



<P>heightened as it was by the idea of his perceiving it,



<P>and had no composure till he turned away to some one else.



<P>Then she could gradually rise up to the genuine satisfaction



<P>of having a partner, a voluntary partner, secured against



<P>the dancing began.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the company were moving into the ballroom, she found



<P>herself for the first time near Miss Crawford, whose eyes



<P>and smiles were immediately and more unequivocally directed



<P>as her brother's had been, and who was beginning to speak



<P>on the subject, when Fanny, anxious to get the story over,



<P>hastened to give the explanation of the second necklace:



<P>the real chain.&nbsp; Miss Crawford listened; and all her intended



<P>compliments and insinuations to Fanny were forgotten:



<P>she felt only one thing; and her eyes, bright as they



<P>had been before, shewing they could yet be brighter,



<P>she exclaimed with eager pleasure, "Did he?&nbsp; Did Edmund?



<P>That was like himself.&nbsp; No other man would have thought of it.



<P>I honour him beyond expression."&nbsp; And she looked around



<P>as if longing to tell him so.&nbsp; He was not near, he was



<P>attending a party of ladies out of the room; and Mrs. Grant



<P>coming up to the two girls, and taking an arm of each,



<P>they followed with the rest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's heart sunk, but there was no leisure for



<P>thinking long even of Miss Crawford's feelings.



<P>They were in the ballroom, the violins were playing,



<P>and her mind was in a flutter that forbade its fixing on



<P>anything serious.&nbsp; She must watch the general arrangements,



<P>and see how everything was done.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In a few minutes Sir Thomas came to her, and asked if



<P>she were engaged; and the "Yes, sir; to Mr. Crawford,"



<P>was exactly what he had intended to hear.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford



<P>was not far off; Sir Thomas brought him to her,



<P>saying something which discovered to Fanny, that _she_



<P>was to lead the way and open the ball; an idea that had



<P>never occurred to her before.&nbsp; Whenever she had thought



<P>of the minutiae of the evening, it had been as a matter



<P>of course that Edmund would begin with Miss Crawford;



<P>and the impression was so strong, that though _her_ _uncle_



<P>spoke the contrary, she could not help an exclamation



<P>of surprise, a hint of her unfitness, an entreaty even to



<P>be excused.&nbsp; To be urging her opinion against Sir Thomas's



<P>was a proof of the extremity of the case; but such was her



<P>horror at the first suggestion, that she could actually



<P>look him in the face and say that she hoped it might be



<P>settled otherwise; in vain, however:&nbsp; Sir Thomas smiled,



<P>tried to encourage her, and then looked too serious,



<P>and said too decidedly, "It must be so, my dear," for her



<P>to hazard another word; and she found herself the next



<P>moment conducted by Mr. Crawford to the top of the room,



<P>and standing there to be joined by the rest of the dancers,



<P>couple after couple, as they were formed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could hardly believe it.&nbsp; To be placed above so many



<P>elegant young women!&nbsp; The distinction was too great.



<P>It was treating her like her cousins!&nbsp; And her thoughts



<P>flew to those absent cousins with most unfeigned and truly



<P>tender regret, that they were not at home to take their



<P>own place in the room, and have their share of a pleasure



<P>which would have been so very delightful to them.



<P>So often as she had heard them wish for a ball at home



<P>as the greatest of all felicities!&nbsp; And to have them away



<P>when it was given--and for _her_ to be opening the ball--



<P>and with Mr. Crawford too!&nbsp; She hoped they would not envy



<P>her that distinction _now_; but when she looked back



<P>to the state of things in the autumn, to what they had all



<P>been to each other when once dancing in that house before,



<P>the present arrangement was almost more than she could



<P>understand herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The ball began.&nbsp; It was rather honour than happiness



<P>to Fanny, for the first dance at least:&nbsp; her partner was



<P>in excellent spirits, and tried to impart them to her;



<P>but she was a great deal too much frightened to have



<P>any enjoyment till she could suppose herself no longer



<P>looked at.&nbsp; Young, pretty, and gentle, however, she had



<P>no awkwardnesses that were not as good as graces,



<P>and there were few persons present that were not disposed



<P>to praise her.&nbsp; She was attractive, she was modest,



<P>she was Sir Thomas's niece, and she was soon said



<P>to be admired by Mr. Crawford.&nbsp; It was enough to give



<P>her general favour.&nbsp; Sir Thomas himself was watching



<P>her progress down the dance with much complacency;



<P>he was proud of his niece; and without attributing



<P>all her personal beauty, as Mrs. Norris seemed to do,



<P>to her transplantation to Mansfield, he was pleased



<P>with himself for having supplied everything else:



<P>education and manners she owed to him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford saw much of Sir Thomas's thoughts as he stood,



<P>and having, in spite of all his wrongs towards her,



<P>a general prevailing desire of recommending herself to him,



<P>took an opportunity of stepping aside to say something



<P>agreeable of Fanny.&nbsp; Her praise was warm, and he received



<P>it as she could wish, joining in it as far as discretion,



<P>and politeness, and slowness of speech would allow,



<P>and certainly appearing to greater advantage on the subject



<P>than his lady did soon afterwards, when Mary, perceiving her



<P>on a sofa very near, turned round before she began to dance,



<P>to compliment her on Miss Price's looks.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, she does look very well," was Lady Bertram's placid reply.



<P>"Chapman helped her to dress.&nbsp; I sent Chapman to her."



<P>Not but that she was really pleased to have Fanny admired;



<P>but she was so much more struck with her own kindness



<P>in sending Chapman to her, that she could not get it out



<P>of her head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford knew Mrs. Norris too well to think of



<P>gratifying _her_ by commendation of Fanny; to her, it was



<P>as the occasion offered--"Ah! ma'am, how much we want dear



<P>Mrs. Rushworth and Julia to-night!" and Mrs. Norris paid



<P>her with as many smiles and courteous words as she had



<P>time for, amid so much occupation as she found for herself



<P>in making up card-tables, giving hints to Sir Thomas,



<P>and trying to move all the chaperons to a better part of the room.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford blundered most towards Fanny herself in her



<P>intentions to please.&nbsp; She meant to be giving her little



<P>heart a happy flutter, and filling her with sensations



<P>of delightful self-consequence; and, misinterpreting Fanny's



<P>blushes, still thought she must be doing so when she



<P>went to her after the two first dances, and said, with a



<P>significant look, "Perhaps _you_ can tell me why my brother



<P>goes to town to-morrow? He says he has business there,



<P>but will not tell me what.&nbsp; The first time he ever denied



<P>me his confidence!&nbsp; But this is what we all come to.



<P>All are supplanted sooner or later.&nbsp; Now, I must apply



<P>to you for information.&nbsp; Pray, what is Henry going for?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny protested her ignorance as steadily as her



<P>embarrassment allowed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, then," replied Miss Crawford, laughing, "I must



<P>suppose it to be purely for the pleasure of conveying



<P>your brother, and of talking of you by the way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was confused, but it was the confusion of discontent;



<P>while Miss Crawford wondered she did not smile, and thought



<P>her over-anxious, or thought her odd, or thought her anything



<P>rather than insensible of pleasure in Henry's attentions.



<P>Fanny had a good deal of enjoyment in the course of the evening;



<P>but Henry's attentions had very little to do with it.



<P>She would much rather _not_ have been asked by him again



<P>so very soon, and she wished she had not been obliged



<P>to suspect that his previous inquiries of Mrs. Norris,



<P>about the supper hour, were all for the sake of securing her



<P>at that part of the evening.&nbsp; But it was not to be avoided:



<P>he made her feel that she was the object of all; though she



<P>could not say that it was unpleasantly done, that there



<P>was indelicacy or ostentation in his manner; and sometimes,



<P>when he talked of William, he was really not unagreeable,



<P>and shewed even a warmth of heart which did him credit.



<P>But still his attentions made no part of her satisfaction.



<P>She was happy whenever she looked at William, and saw how



<P>perfectly he was enjoying himself, in every five minutes



<P>that she could walk about with him and hear his account



<P>of his partners; she was happy in knowing herself admired;



<P>and she was happy in having the two dances with Edmund still



<P>to look forward to, during the greatest part of the evening,



<P>her hand being so eagerly sought after that her indefinite



<P>engagement with _him_ was in continual perspective.



<P>She was happy even when they did take place; but not from



<P>any flow of spirits on his side, or any such expressions



<P>of tender gallantry as had blessed the morning.



<P>His mind was fagged, and her happiness sprung from



<P>being the friend with whom it could find repose.



<P>"I am worn out with civility," said he.&nbsp; "I have been



<P>talking incessantly all night, and with nothing to say.



<P>But with _you_, Fanny, there may be peace.&nbsp; You will not
