<P>want to be talked to.&nbsp; Let us have the luxury of silence."



<P>Fanny would hardly even speak her agreement.&nbsp; A weariness,



<P>arising probably, in great measure, from the same feelings



<P>which he had acknowledged in the morning, was peculiarly



<P>to be respected, and they went down their two dances together



<P>with such sober tranquillity as might satisfy any looker-on



<P>that Sir Thomas had been bringing up no wife for his



<P>younger son.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The evening had afforded Edmund little pleasure.&nbsp; Miss Crawford



<P>had been in gay spirits when they first danced together,



<P>but it was not her gaiety that could do him good:



<P>it rather sank than raised his comfort; and afterwards,



<P>for he found himself still impelled to seek her again,



<P>she had absolutely pained him by her manner of speaking of the



<P>profession to which he was now on the point of belonging.



<P>They had talked, and they had been silent; he had reasoned,



<P>she had ridiculed; and they had parted at last with



<P>mutual vexation.&nbsp; Fanny, not able to refrain entirely from



<P>observing them, had seen enough to be tolerably satisfied.



<P>It was barbarous to be happy when Edmund was suffering.



<P>Yet some happiness must and would arise from the very



<P>conviction that he did suffer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When her two dances with him were over, her inclination



<P>and strength for more were pretty well at an end;



<P>and Sir Thomas, having seen her walk rather than dance



<P>down the shortening set, breathless, and with her hand at



<P>her side, gave his orders for her sitting down entirely.



<P>From that time Mr. Crawford sat down likewise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Fanny!" cried William, coming for a moment to visit her,



<P>and working away his partner's fan as if for life, "how soon



<P>she is knocked up!&nbsp; Why, the sport is but just begun.



<P>I hope we shall keep it up these two hours.&nbsp; How can you



<P>be tired so soon?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So soon! my good friend," said Sir Thomas, producing his



<P>watch with all necessary caution; "it is three o'clock,



<P>and your sister is not used to these sort of hours."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, then, Fanny, you shall not get up to-morrow before



<P>I go.&nbsp; Sleep as long as you can, and never mind me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; William."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What!&nbsp; Did she think of being up before you set off?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes, sir," cried Fanny, rising eagerly from her seat



<P>to be nearer her uncle; "I must get up and breakfast with him.



<P>It will be the last time, you know; the last morning."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You had better not.&nbsp; He is to have breakfasted and be



<P>gone by half-past nine.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford, I think you call



<P>for him at half-past nine?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was too urgent, however, and had too many tears in her



<P>eyes for denial; and it ended in a gracious "Well, well!"



<P>which was permission.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, half-past nine," said Crawford to William as the



<P>latter was leaving them, "and I shall be punctual,



<P>for there will be no kind sister to get up for _me_."



<P>And in a lower tone to Fanny, "I shall have only a desolate



<P>house to hurry from.&nbsp; Your brother will find my ideas



<P>of time and his own very different to-morrow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After a short consideration, Sir Thomas asked Crawford



<P>to join the early breakfast party in that house



<P>instead of eating alone:&nbsp; he should himself be of it;



<P>and the readiness with which his invitation was accepted



<P>convinced him that the suspicions whence, he must confess



<P>to himself, this very ball had in great measure sprung,



<P>were well founded.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford was in love with Fanny.



<P>He had a pleasing anticipation of what would be.&nbsp; His niece,



<P>meanwhile, did not thank him for what he had just done.



<P>She had hoped to have William all to herself the last morning.



<P>It would have been an unspeakable indulgence.&nbsp; But though



<P>her wishes were overthrown, there was no spirit of murmuring



<P>within her.&nbsp; On the contrary, she was so totally unused



<P>to have her pleasure consulted, or to have anything take



<P>place at all in the way she could desire, that she was more



<P>disposed to wonder and rejoice in having carried her point



<P>so far, than to repine at the counteraction which followed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Shortly afterward, Sir Thomas was again interfering



<P>a little with her inclination, by advising her to go



<P>immediately to bed.&nbsp; "Advise" was his word, but it



<P>was the advice of absolute power, and she had only



<P>to rise, and, with Mr. Crawford's very cordial adieus,



<P>pass quietly away; stopping at the entrance-door, like



<P>the Lady of Branxholm Hall, "one moment and no more,"



<P>to view the happy scene, and take a last look at the five



<P>or six determined couple who were still hard at work;



<P>and then, creeping slowly up the principal staircase,



<P>pursued by the ceaseless country-dance, feverish with hopes



<P>and fears, soup and negus, sore-footed and fatigued,



<P>restless and agitated, yet feeling, in spite of everything,



<P>that a ball was indeed delightful.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In thus sending her away, Sir Thomas perhaps might not



<P>be thinking merely of her health.&nbsp; It might occur to him



<P>that Mr. Crawford had been sitting by her long enough,



<P>or he might mean to recommend her as a wife by shewing



<P>her persuadableness.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 14</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Fanny seemed nearer being right than Edmund had supposed.



<P>The business of finding a play that would suit everybody



<P>proved to be no trifle; and the carpenter had received



<P>his orders and taken his measurements, had suggested



<P>and removed at least two sets of difficulties, and having



<P>made the necessity of an enlargement of plan and expense



<P>fully evident, was already at work, while a play was



<P>still to seek.&nbsp; Other preparations were also in hand.



<P>An enormous roll of green baize had arrived from Northampton,



<P>and been cut out by Mrs. Norris (with a saving by her



<P>good management of full three-quarters of a yard), and



<P>was actually forming into a curtain by the housemaids,



<P>and still the play was wanting; and as two or three days



<P>passed away in this manner, Edmund began almost to hope



<P>that none might ever be found.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There were, in fact, so many things to be attended to,



<P>so many people to be pleased, so many best characters



<P>required, and, above all, such a need that the play



<P>should be at once both tragedy and comedy, that there



<P>did seem as little chance of a decision as anything



<P>pursued by youth and zeal could hold out.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On the tragic side were the Miss Bertrams, Henry Crawford,



<P>and Mr. Yates; on the comic, Tom Bertram, not _quite_ alone,



<P>because it was evident that Mary Crawford's wishes,



<P>though politely kept back, inclined the same way:&nbsp; but his



<P>determinateness and his power seemed to make allies unnecessary;



<P>and, independent of this great irreconcilable difference,



<P>they wanted a piece containing very few characters



<P>in the whole, but every character first-rate, and three



<P>principal women.&nbsp; All the best plays were run over in vain.



<P>Neither Hamlet, nor Macbeth, nor Othello, nor Douglas,



<P>nor The Gamester, presented anything that could satisfy



<P>even the tragedians; and The Rivals, The School for Scandal,



<P>Wheel of Fortune, Heir at Law, and a long et cetera,



<P>were successively dismissed with yet warmer objections.



<P>No piece could be proposed that did not supply somebody



<P>with a difficulty, and on one side or the other it was



<P>a continual repetition of, "Oh no, _that_ will never do!



<P>Let us have no ranting tragedies.&nbsp; Too many characters.



<P>Not a tolerable woman's part in the play.&nbsp; Anything but _that_,



<P>my dear Tom.&nbsp; It would be impossible to fill it up.



<P>One could not expect anybody to take such a part.



<P>Nothing but buffoonery from beginning to end.



<P>_That_ might do, perhaps, but for the low parts.&nbsp; If I



<P>_must_ give my opinion, I have always thought it the most



<P>insipid play in the English language.&nbsp; _I_ do not wish



<P>to make objections; I shall be happy to be of any use, but I



<P>think we could not chuse worse."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny looked on and listened, not unamused to observe



<P>the selfishness which, more or less disguised, seemed to



<P>govern them all, and wondering how it would end.&nbsp; For her



<P>own gratification she could have wished that something



<P>might be acted, for she had never seen even half a play,



<P>but everything of higher consequence was against it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This will never do," said Tom Bertram at last.&nbsp; "We are



<P>wasting time most abominably.&nbsp; Something must be fixed on.



<P>No matter what, so that something is chosen.&nbsp; We must not be



<P>so nice.&nbsp; A few characters too many must not frighten us.



<P>We must _double_ them.&nbsp; We must descend a little.



<P>If a part is insignificant, the greater our credit in making



<P>anything of it.&nbsp; From this moment I make no difficulties.



<P>I take any part you chuse to give me, so as it be comic.



<P>Let it but be comic, I condition for nothing more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For about the fifth time he then proposed the Heir at Law,



<P>doubting only whether to prefer Lord Duberley or Dr. Pangloss



<P>for himself; and very earnestly, but very unsuccessfully,



<P>trying to persuade the others that there were some fine



<P>tragic parts in the rest of the dramatis personae.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The pause which followed this fruitless effort



<P>was ended by the same speaker, who, taking up one



<P>of the many volumes of plays that lay on the table,



<P>and turning it over, suddenly exclaimed--"Lovers' Vows!



<P>And why should not Lovers' Vows do for _us_ as well



<P>as for the Ravenshaws?&nbsp; How came it never to be thought



<P>of before?&nbsp; It strikes me as if it would do exactly.



<P>What say you all?&nbsp; Here are two capital tragic parts for



<P>Yates and Crawford, and here is the rhyming Butler for me,



<P>if nobody else wants it; a trifling part, but the sort



<P>of thing I should not dislike, and, as I said before,



<P>I am determined to take anything and do my best.



<P>And as for the rest, they may be filled up by anybody.



<P>It is only Count Cassel and Anhalt."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The suggestion was generally welcome.&nbsp; Everybody was growing



<P>weary of indecision, and the first idea with everybody was,



<P>that nothing had been proposed before so likely to suit



<P>them all.&nbsp; Mr. Yates was particularly pleased:&nbsp; he had



<P>been sighing and longing to do the Baron at Ecclesford,



<P>had grudged every rant of Lord Ravenshaw's, and been forced



<P>to re-rant it all in his own room.&nbsp; The storm through Baron



<P>Wildenheim was the height of his theatrical ambition;



<P>and with the advantage of knowing half the scenes by



<P>heart already, he did now, with the greatest alacrity,



<P>offer his services for the part.&nbsp; To do him justice,



<P>however, he did not resolve to appropriate it;



<P>for remembering that there was some very good ranting-ground



<P>in Frederick, he professed an equal willingness for that.



<P>Henry Crawford was ready to take either.&nbsp; Whichever Mr. Yates



<P>did not chuse would perfectly satisfy him, and a short



<P>parley of compliment ensued.&nbsp; Miss Bertram, feeling all



<P>the interest of an Agatha in the question, took on her



<P>to decide it, by observing to Mr. Yates that this was a



<P>point in which height and figure ought to be considered,



<P>and that _his_ being the tallest, seemed to fit him



<P>peculiarly for the Baron.&nbsp; She was acknowledged to be



<P>quite right, and the two parts being accepted accordingly,



<P>she was certain of the proper Frederick.&nbsp; Three of the



<P>characters were now cast, besides Mr. Rushworth, who was



<P>always answered for by Maria as willing to do anything;



<P>when Julia, meaning, like her sister, to be Agatha,



<P>began to be scrupulous on Miss Crawford's account.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is not behaving well by the absent," said she.



<P>"Here are not women enough.&nbsp; Amelia and Agatha may do



<P>for Maria and me, but here is nothing for your sister,



<P>Mr. Crawford."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Crawford desired _that_ might not be thought of:



<P>he was very sure his sister had no wish of acting



<P>but as she might be useful, and that she would not



<P>allow herself to be considered in the present case.



<P>But this was immediately opposed by Tom Bertram,



<P>who asserted the part of Amelia to be in every respect



<P>the property of Miss Crawford, if she would accept it.



<P>"It falls as naturally, as necessarily to her," said he,



<P>"as Agatha does to one or other of my sisters.&nbsp; It can be no



<P>sacrifice on their side, for it is highly comic."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A short silence followed.&nbsp; Each sister looked anxious;



<P>for each felt the best claim to Agatha, and was hoping



<P>to have it pressed on her by the rest.&nbsp; Henry Crawford,



<P>who meanwhile had taken up the play, and with seeming



<P>carelessness was turning over the first act, soon settled



<P>the business.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I must entreat Miss _Julia_ Bertram," said he, "not to



<P>engage in the part of Agatha, or it will be the ruin



<P>of all my solemnity.&nbsp; You must not, indeed you must not"



<P>(turning to her). "I could not stand your countenance



<P>dressed up in woe and paleness.&nbsp; The many laughs we have



<P>had together would infallibly come across me, and Frederick



<P>and his knapsack would be obliged to run away."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Pleasantly, courteously, it was spoken; but the



<P>manner was lost in the matter to Julia's feelings.



<P>She saw a glance at Maria which confirmed the injury



<P>to herself:&nbsp; it was a scheme, a trick; she was slighted,



<P>Maria was preferred; the smile of triumph which Maria



<P>was trying to suppress shewed how well it was understood;



<P>and before Julia could command herself enough to speak,



<P>her brother gave his weight against her too, by saying,



<P>"Oh yes!&nbsp; Maria must be Agatha.&nbsp; Maria will be the



<P>best Agatha.&nbsp; Though Julia fancies she prefers tragedy,



<P>I would not trust her in it.&nbsp; There is nothing of tragedy



<P>about her.&nbsp; She has not the look of it.&nbsp; Her features



<P>are not tragic features, and she walks too quick,



<P>and speaks too quick, and would not keep her countenance.



<P>She had better do the old countrywoman:&nbsp; the Cottager's wife;



<P>you had, indeed, Julia.&nbsp; Cottager's wife is a very pretty part,



<P>I assure you.&nbsp; The old lady relieves the high-flown



<P>benevolence of her husband with a good deal of spirit.



<P>You shall be Cottager's wife."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Cottager's wife!" cried Mr. Yates.&nbsp; "What are you



<P>talking of?&nbsp; The most trivial, paltry, insignificant part;



<P>the merest commonplace; not a tolerable speech in the whole.



<P>Your sister do that!&nbsp; It is an insult to propose it.



<P>At Ecclesford the governess was to have done it.



<P>We all agreed that it could not be offered to anybody else.



<P>A little more justice, Mr. Manager, if you please.



<P>You do not deserve the office, if you cannot appreciate



<P>the talents of your company a little better."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, as to _that_, my good friend, till I and my company



<P>have really acted there must be some guesswork; but I mean



<P>no disparagement to Julia.&nbsp; We cannot have two Agathas,



<P>and we must have one Cottager's wife; and I am sure I set



<P>her the example of moderation myself in being satisfied



<P>with the old Butler.&nbsp; If the part is trifling she will



<P>have more credit in making something of it; and if she



<P>is so desperately bent against everything humorous,



<P>let her take Cottager's speeches instead of Cottager's



<P>wife's, and so change the parts all through; _he_ is



<P>solemn and pathetic enough, I am sure.&nbsp; It could make



<P>no difference in the play, and as for Cottager himself,



<P>when he has got his wife's speeches, _I_ would undertake



<P>him with all my heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"With all your partiality for Cottager's wife,"



<P>said Henry Crawford, "it will be impossible to make



<P>anything of it fit for your sister, and we must not suffer



<P>her good-nature to be imposed on.&nbsp; We must not _allow_



<P>her to accept the part.&nbsp; She must not be left to her



<P>own complaisance.&nbsp; Her talents will be wanted in Amelia.



<P>Amelia is a character more difficult to be well represented



<P>than even Agatha.&nbsp; I consider Amelia is the most difficult



<P>character in the whole piece.&nbsp; It requires great powers,



<P>great nicety, to give her playfulness and simplicity



<P>without extravagance.&nbsp; I have seen good actresses fail



<P>in the part.&nbsp; Simplicity, indeed, is beyond the reach



<P>of almost every actress by profession.&nbsp; It requires



<P>a delicacy of feeling which they have not.&nbsp; It requires



<P>a gentlewoman--a Julia Bertram.&nbsp; You _will_ undertake it,



<P>I hope?" turning to her with a look of anxious entreaty,



<P>which softened her a little; but while she hesitated



<P>what to say, her brother again interposed with Miss



<P>Crawford's better claim.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no, Julia must not be Amelia.&nbsp; It is not at



<P>all the part for her.&nbsp; She would not like it.



<P>She would not do well.&nbsp; She is too tall and robust.



<P>Amelia should be a small, light, girlish, skipping figure.



<P>It is fit for Miss Crawford, and Miss Crawford only.



<P>She looks the part, and I am persuaded will do it admirably."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Without attending to this, Henry Crawford continued



<P>his supplication.&nbsp; "You must oblige us," said he,



<P>"indeed you must.&nbsp; When you have studied the character, I am



<P>sure you will feel it suit you.&nbsp; Tragedy may be your choice,



<P>but it will certainly appear that comedy chuses _you_.



<P>You will be to visit me in prison with a basket of provisions;



<P>you will not refuse to visit me in prison?&nbsp; I think I



<P>see you coming in with your basket"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The influence of his voice was felt.&nbsp; Julia wavered;



<P>but was he only trying to soothe and pacify her, and make



<P>her overlook the previous affront?&nbsp; She distrusted him.



<P>The slight had been most determined.&nbsp; He was, perhaps,



<P>but at treacherous play with her.&nbsp; She looked suspiciously



<P>at her sister; Maria's countenance was to decide it:



<P>if she were vexed and alarmed--but Maria looked all



<P>serenity and satisfaction, and Julia well knew that on



<P>this ground Maria could not be happy but at her expense.



<P>With hasty indignation, therefore, and a tremulous voice,



<P>she said to him, "You do not seem afraid of not



<P>keeping your countenance when I come in with a basket



<P>of provisions--though one might have supposed--but it



<P>is only as Agatha that I was to be so overpowering!"



<P>She stopped--Henry Crawford looked rather foolish,



<P>and as if he did not know what to say.&nbsp; Tom Bertram



<P>began again--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Crawford must be Amelia.&nbsp; She will be an excellent Amelia."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do not be afraid of _my_ wanting the character,"



<P>cried Julia, with angry quickness:&nbsp; "I am _not_ to be Agatha,



<P>and I am sure I will do nothing else; and as to Amelia,



<P>it is of all parts in the world the most disgusting to me.



<P>I quite detest her.&nbsp; An odious, little, pert, unnatural,



<P>impudent girl.&nbsp; I have always protested against comedy,



<P>and this is comedy in its worst form."&nbsp; And so saying,



<P>she walked hastily out of the room, leaving awkward feelings



<P>to more than one, but exciting small compassion in any



<P>except Fanny, who had been a quiet auditor of the whole,



<P>and who could not think of her as under the agitations of



<P>_jealousy_ without great pity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A short silence succeeded her leaving them; but her brother



<P>soon returned to business and Lovers' Vows, and was



<P>eagerly looking over the play, with Mr. Yates's help,



<P>to ascertain what scenery would be necessary--while Maria



<P>and Henry Crawford conversed together in an under-voice,



<P>and the declaration with which she began of, "I am



<P>sure I would give up the part to Julia most willingly,



<P>but that though I shall probably do it very ill,



<P>I feel persuaded _she_ would do it worse," was doubtless



<P>receiving all the compliments it called for.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When this had lasted some time, the division of the party



<P>was completed by Tom Bertram and Mr. Yates walking off



<P>together to consult farther in the room now beginning



<P>to be called _the_ _Theatre_, and Miss Bertram's resolving



<P>to go down to the Parsonage herself with the offer



<P>of Amelia to Miss Crawford; and Fanny remained alone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The first use she made of her solitude was to take up



<P>the volume which had been left on the table, and begin



<P>to acquaint herself with the play of which she had heard



<P>so much.&nbsp; Her curiosity was all awake, and she ran



<P>through it with an eagerness which was suspended only



<P>by intervals of astonishment, that it could be chosen



<P>in the present instance, that it could be proposed



<P>and accepted in a private theatre!&nbsp; Agatha and Amelia



<P>appeared to her in their different ways so totally



<P>improper for home representation--the situation of one,



<P>and the language of the other, so unfit to be expressed



<P>by any woman of modesty, that she could hardly suppose



<P>her cousins could be aware of what they were engaging in;



<P>and longed to have them roused as soon as possible



<P>by the remonstrance which Edmund would certainly make.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 38</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXXVIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The novelty of travelling, and the happiness of being



<P>with William, soon produced their natural effect on



<P>Fanny's spirits, when Mansfield Park was fairly left behind;



<P>and by the time their first stage was ended, and they



<P>were to quit Sir Thomas's carriage, she was able to take



<P>leave of the old coachman, and send back proper messages,



<P>with cheerful looks.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Of pleasant talk between the brother and sister there



<P>was no end.&nbsp; Everything supplied an amusement to the high



<P>glee of William's mind, and he was full of frolic and



<P>joke in the intervals of their higher-toned subjects,



<P>all of which ended, if they did not begin, in praise



<P>of the Thrush, conjectures how she would be employed,



<P>schemes for an action with some superior force,



<P>which (supposing the first lieutenant out of the way,



<P>and William was not very merciful to the first lieutenant)



<P>was to give himself the next step as soon as possible,



<P>or speculations upon prize-money, which was to be generously



<P>distributed at home, with only the reservation of enough



<P>to make the little cottage comfortable, in which he and Fanny



<P>were to pass all their middle and later life together.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's immediate concerns, as far as they involved



<P>Mr. Crawford, made no part of their conversation.



<P>William knew what had passed, and from his heart lamented



<P>that his sister's feelings should be so cold towards a man



<P>whom he must consider as the first of human characters;



<P>but he was of an age to be all for love, and therefore



<P>unable to blame; and knowing her wish on the subject,



<P>he would not distress her by the slightest allusion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had reason to suppose herself not yet forgotten by



<P>Mr. Crawford.&nbsp; She had heard repeatedly from his sister within



<P>the three weeks which had passed since their leaving Mansfield,



<P>and in each letter there had been a few lines from himself,



<P>warm and determined like his speeches.&nbsp; It was a correspondence



<P>which Fanny found quite as unpleasant as she had feared.



<P>Miss Crawford's style of writing, lively and affectionate,



<P>was itself an evil, independent of what she was thus



<P>forced into reading from the brother's pen, for Edmund



<P>would never rest till she had read the chief of the letter



<P>to him; and then she had to listen to his admiration



<P>of her language, and the warmth of her attachments.



<P>There had, in fact, been so much of message, of allusion,



<P>of recollection, so much of Mansfield in every letter,



<P>that Fanny could not but suppose it meant for him to hear;



<P>and to find herself forced into a purpose of that kind,



<P>compelled into a correspondence which was bringing her



<P>the addresses of the man she did not love, and obliging



<P>her to administer to the adverse passion of the man she did,



<P>was cruelly mortifying.&nbsp; Here, too, her present removal



<P>promised advantage.&nbsp; When no longer under the same roof



<P>with Edmund, she trusted that Miss Crawford would have no



<P>motive for writing strong enough to overcome the trouble,



<P>and that at Portsmouth their correspondence would dwindle



<P>into nothing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With such thoughts as these, among ten hundred others,



<P>Fanny proceeded in her journey safely and cheerfully,



<P>and as expeditiously as could rationally be hoped



<P>in the dirty month of February.&nbsp; They entered Oxford,



<P>but she could take only a hasty glimpse of Edmund's



<P>college as they passed along, and made no stop anywhere



<P>till they reached Newbury, where a comfortable meal,



<P>uniting dinner and supper, wound up the enjoyments and



<P>fatigues of the day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next morning saw them off again at an early hour;



<P>and with no events, and no delays, they regularly advanced,



<P>and were in the environs of Portsmouth while there was yet



<P>daylight for Fanny to look around her, and wonder at the



<P>new buildings.&nbsp; They passed the drawbridge, and entered



<P>the town; and the light was only beginning to fail as,



<P>guided by William's powerful voice, they were rattled



<P>into a narrow street, leading from the High Street,



<P>and drawn up before the door of a small house now inhabited



<P>by Mr. Price.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was all agitation and flutter; all hope and apprehension.



<P>The moment they stopped, a trollopy-looking maidservant,



<P>seemingly in waiting for them at the door, stepped forward,



<P>and more intent on telling the news than giving them any help,



<P>immediately began with, "The Thrush is gone out of harbour,



<P>please sir, and one of the officers has been here to--



<P>" She was interrupted by a fine tall boy of eleven years old,



<P>who, rushing out of the house, pushed the maid aside,



<P>and while William was opening the chaise-door himself,



<P>called out, "You are just in time.&nbsp; We have been looking



<P>for you this half-hour. The Thrush went out of harbour



<P>this morning.&nbsp; I saw her.&nbsp; It was a beautiful sight.



<P>And they think she will have her orders in a day or two.



<P>And Mr. Campbell was here at four o'clock to ask for you:



<P>he has got one of the Thrush's boats, and is going off



<P>to her at six, and hoped you would be here in time to go



<P>with him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A stare or two at Fanny, as William helped her out of



<P>the carriage, was all the voluntary notice which this



<P>brother bestowed; but he made no objection to her



<P>kissing him, though still entirely engaged in detailing



<P>farther particulars of the Thrush's going out of harbour,



<P>in which he had a strong right of interest, being to



<P>commence his career of seamanship in her at this very time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Another moment and Fanny was in the narrow entrance-passage



<P>of the house, and in her mother's arms, who met her



<P>there with looks of true kindness, and with features



<P>which Fanny loved the more, because they brought her aunt



<P>Bertram's before her, and there were her two sisters:



<P>Susan, a well-grown fine girl of fourteen, and Betsey,



<P>the youngest of the family, about five--both glad to see



<P>her in their way, though with no advantage of manner



<P>in receiving her.&nbsp; But manner Fanny did not want.



<P>Would they but love her, she should be satisfied.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was then taken into a parlour, so small that her



<P>first conviction was of its being only a passage-room



<P>to something better, and she stood for a moment expecting



<P>to be invited on; but when she saw there was no other door,



<P>and that there were signs of habitation before her,



<P>she called back her thoughts, reproved herself, and grieved



<P>lest they should have been suspected.&nbsp; Her mother,



<P>however, could not stay long enough to suspect anything.



<P>She was gone again to the street-door, to welcome William.



<P>"Oh! my dear William, how glad I am to see you.



<P>But have you heard about the Thrush?&nbsp; She is gone out of



<P>harbour already; three days before we had any thought of it;



<P>and I do not know what I am to do about Sam's things,



<P>they will never be ready in time; for she may have her orders



<P>to-morrow, perhaps.&nbsp; It takes me quite unawares.&nbsp; And now



<P>you must be off for Spithead too.&nbsp; Campbell has been here,



<P>quite in a worry about you; and now what shall we do?



<P>I thought to have had such a comfortable evening with you,



<P>and here everything comes upon me at once."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her son answered cheerfully, telling her that everything



<P>was always for the best; and making light of his own



<P>inconvenience in being obliged to hurry away so soon.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure, I had much rather she had stayed in harbour,



<P>that I might have sat a few hours with you in comfort;



<P>but as there is a boat ashore, I had better go off at once,



<P>and there is no help for it.&nbsp; Whereabouts does the Thrush



<P>lay at Spithead?&nbsp; Near the Canopus?&nbsp; But no matter;



<P>here's Fanny in the parlour, and why should we stay in



<P>the passage?&nbsp; Come, mother, you have hardly looked at your



<P>own dear Fanny yet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In they both came, and Mrs. Price having kindly kissed



<P>her daughter again, and commented a little on her growth,



<P>began with very natural solicitude to feel for their



<P>fatigues and wants as travellers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor dears! how tired you must both be! and now,



<P>what will you have?&nbsp; I began to think you would never come.



<P>Betsey and I have been watching for you this half-hour.



<P>And when did you get anything to eat?&nbsp; And what would you



<P>like to have now?&nbsp; I could not tell whether you would be



<P>for some meat, or only a dish of tea, after your journey,



<P>or else I would have got something ready.&nbsp; And now I



<P>am afraid Campbell will be here before there is time



<P>to dress a steak, and we have no butcher at hand.



<P>It is very inconvenient to have no butcher in the street.



<P>We were better off in our last house.&nbsp; Perhaps you would



<P>like some tea as soon as it can be got."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They both declared they should prefer it to anything.



<P>"Then, Betsey, my dear, run into the kitchen and see if Rebecca



<P>has put the water on; and tell her to bring in the tea-things



<P>as soon as she can.&nbsp; I wish we could get the bell mended;



<P>but Betsey is a very handy little messenger."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Betsey went with alacrity, proud to shew her abilities



<P>before her fine new sister.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear me!" continued the anxious mother, "what a sad



<P>fire we have got, and I dare say you are both starved



<P>with cold.&nbsp; Draw your chair nearer, my dear.&nbsp; I cannot



<P>think what Rebecca has been about.&nbsp; I am sure I told her



<P>to bring some coals half an hour ago.&nbsp; Susan, you should



<P>have taken care of the fire."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was upstairs, mama, moving my things," said Susan,



<P>in a fearless, self-defending tone, which startled Fanny.



<P>"You know you had but just settled that my sister Fanny



<P>and I should have the other room; and I could not get



<P>Rebecca to give me any help."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Farther discussion was prevented by various bustles:



<P>first, the driver came to be paid; then there was a squabble



<P>between Sam and Rebecca about the manner of carrying up



<P>his sister's trunk, which he would manage all his own way;



<P>and lastly, in walked Mr. Price himself, his own loud



<P>voice preceding him, as with something of the oath kind



<P>he kicked away his son's port-manteau and his daughter's



<P>bandbox in the passage, and called out for a candle;



<P>no candle was brought, however, and he walked into the room.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny with doubting feelings had risen to meet him,



<P>but sank down again on finding herself undistinguished



<P>in the dusk, and unthought of.&nbsp; With a friendly shake



<P>of his son's hand, and an eager voice, he instantly began--



<P>"Ha! welcome back, my boy.&nbsp; Glad to see you.&nbsp; Have you heard



<P>the news?&nbsp; The Thrush went out of harbour this morning.



<P>Sharp is the word, you see!&nbsp; By G--, you are just in time!



<P>The doctor has been here inquiring for you:&nbsp; he has got



<P>one of the boats, and is to be off for Spithead by six,



<P>so you had better go with him.&nbsp; I have been to Turner's



<P>about your mess; it is all in a way to be done.



<P>I should not wonder if you had your orders to-morrow:



<P>but you cannot sail with this wind, if you are to cruise



<P>to the westward; and Captain Walsh thinks you will certainly



<P>have a cruise to the westward, with the Elephant.



<P>By G--, I wish you may!&nbsp; But old Scholey was saying,



<P>just now, that he thought you would be sent first to



<P>the Texel.&nbsp; Well, well, we are ready, whatever happens.



<P>But by G--, you lost a fine sight by not being here



<P>in the morning to see the Thrush go out of harbour!



<P>I would not have been out of the way for a thousand pounds.



<P>Old Scholey ran in at breakfast-time, to say she had



<P>slipped her moorings and was coming out, I jumped up,



<P>and made but two steps to the platform.&nbsp; If ever there



<P>was a perfect beauty afloat, she is one; and there she lays



<P>at Spithead, and anybody in England would take her for an



<P>eight-and-twenty. I was upon the platform two hours this



<P>afternoon looking at her.&nbsp; She lays close to the Endymion,



<P>between her and the Cleopatra, just to the eastward of the



<P>sheer hulk."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ha!" cried William, "_that's_ just where I should have



<P>put her myself.&nbsp; It's the best berth at Spithead.



<P>But here is my sister, sir; here is Fanny," turning and



<P>leading her forward; "it is so dark you do not see her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With an acknowledgment that he had quite forgot her,



<P>Mr. Price now received his daughter; and having given



<P>her a cordial hug, and observed that she was grown into



<P>a woman, and he supposed would be wanting a husband soon,



<P>seemed very much inclined to forget her again.



<P>Fanny shrunk back to her seat, with feelings sadly



<P>pained by his language and his smell of spirits;



<P>and he talked on only to his son, and only of the Thrush,



<P>though William, warmly interested as he was in that subject,



<P>more than once tried to make his father think of Fanny,



<P>and her long absence and long journey.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After sitting some time longer, a candle was obtained;



<P>but as there was still no appearance of tea, nor, from



<P>Betsey's reports from the kitchen, much hope of any under



<P>a considerable period, William determined to go and change



<P>his dress, and make the necessary preparations for his removal



<P>on board directly, that he might have his tea in comfort



<P>afterwards.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As he left the room, two rosy-faced boys, ragged and dirty,



<P>about eight and nine years old, rushed into it just released



<P>from school, and coming eagerly to see their sister,



<P>and tell that the Thrush was gone out of harbour;



<P>Tom and Charles.&nbsp; Charles had been born since Fanny's



<P>going away, but Tom she had often helped to nurse,



<P>and now felt a particular pleasure in seeing again.



<P>Both were kissed very tenderly, but Tom she wanted



<P>to keep by her, to try to trace the features of the baby



<P>she had loved, and talked to, of his infant preference



<P>of herself.&nbsp; Tom, however, had no mind for such treatment:



<P>he came home not to stand and be talked to, but to run about



<P>and make a noise; and both boys had soon burst from her,



<P>and slammed the parlour-door till her temples ached.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had now seen all that were at home; there remained



<P>only two brothers between herself and Susan,



<P>one of whom was a clerk in a public office in London,



<P>and the other midshipman on board an Indiaman.



<P>But though she had _seen_ all the members of the family,



<P>she had not yet _heard_ all the noise they could make.



<P>Another quarter of an hour brought her a great deal more.



<P>William was soon calling out from the landing-place



<P>of the second story for his mother and for Rebecca.



<P>He was in distress for something that he had left there,



<P>and did not find again.&nbsp; A key was mislaid, Betsey accused



<P>of having got at his new hat, and some slight, but essential



<P>alteration of his uniform waistcoat, which he had been



<P>promised to have done for him, entirely neglected.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Price, Rebecca, and Betsey all went up to defend themselves,



<P>all talking together, but Rebecca loudest, and the job



<P>was to be done as well as it could in a great hurry;



<P>William trying in vain to send Betsey down again, or keep



<P>her from being troublesome where she was; the whole of which,



<P>as almost every door in the house was open, could be plainly



<P>distinguished in the parlour, except when drowned at intervals



<P>by the superior noise of Sam, Tom, and Charles chasing



<P>each other up and down stairs, and tumbling about and hallooing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was almost stunned.&nbsp; The smallness of the house



<P>and thinness of the walls brought everything so close



<P>to her, that, added to the fatigue of her journey, and all



<P>her recent agitation, she hardly knew how to bear it.



<P>_Within_ the room all was tranquil enough, for Susan having



<P>disappeared with the others, there were soon only her father



<P>and herself remaining; and he, taking out a newspaper,



<P>the accustomary loan of a neighbour, applied himself to



<P>studying it, without seeming to recollect her existence.



<P>The solitary candle was held between himself and the paper,



<P>without any reference to her possible convenience;



<P>but she had nothing to do, and was glad to have the light



<P>screened from her aching head, as she sat in bewildered,



<P>broken, sorrowful contemplation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was at home.&nbsp; But, alas! it was not such a home,



<P>she had not such a welcome, as--she checked herself;



<P>she was unreasonable.&nbsp; What right had she to be of importance



<P>to her family?&nbsp; She could have none, so long lost sight of!



<P>William's concerns must be dearest, they always had been,



<P>and he had every right.&nbsp; Yet to have so little said



<P>or asked about herself, to have scarcely an inquiry made



<P>after Mansfield!&nbsp; It did pain her to have Mansfield forgotten;



<P>the friends who had done so much--the dear, dear friends!



<P>But here, one subject swallowed up all the rest.



<P>Perhaps it must be so.&nbsp; The destination of the Thrush



<P>must be now preeminently interesting.&nbsp; A day or two



<P>might shew the difference.&nbsp; _She_ only was to blame.



<P>Yet she thought it would not have been so at Mansfield.



<P>No, in her uncle's house there would have been a



<P>consideration of times and seasons, a regulation of subject,



<P>a propriety, an attention towards everybody which there



<P>was not here.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The only interruption which thoughts like these received



<P>for nearly half an hour was from a sudden burst of her



<P>father's, not at all calculated to compose them.&nbsp; At a more



<P>than ordinary pitch of thumping and hallooing in the passage,



<P>he exclaimed, "Devil take those young dogs!&nbsp; How they are



<P>singing out!&nbsp; Ay, Sam's voice louder than all the rest!



<P>That boy is fit for a boatswain.&nbsp; Holla, you there!



<P>Sam, stop your confounded pipe, or I shall be after you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This threat was so palpably disregarded, that though



<P>within five minutes afterwards the three boys all burst



<P>into the room together and sat down, Fanny could not



<P>consider it as a proof of anything more than their being



<P>for the time thoroughly fagged, which their hot faces



<P>and panting breaths seemed to prove, especially as they



<P>were still kicking each other's shins, and hallooing



<P>out at sudden starts immediately under their father's eye.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next opening of the door brought something more welcome:



<P>it was for the tea-things, which she had begun almost



<P>to despair of seeing that evening.&nbsp; Susan and an



<P>attendant girl, whose inferior appearance informed Fanny,



<P>to her great surprise, that she had previously seen the



<P>upper servant, brought in everything necessary for the meal;



<P>Susan looking, as she put the kettle on the fire and glanced



<P>at her sister, as if divided between the agreeable triumph



<P>of shewing her activity and usefulness, and the dread



<P>of being thought to demean herself by such an office.



<P>"She had been into the kitchen," she said, "to hurry Sally



<P>and help make the toast, and spread the bread and butter,



<P>or she did not know when they should have got tea,



<P>and she was sure her sister must want something after



<P>her journey."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was very thankful.&nbsp; She could not but own that she



<P>should be very glad of a little tea, and Susan immediately



<P>set about making it, as if pleased to have the employment



<P>all to herself; and with only a little unnecessary bustle,



<P>and some few injudicious attempts at keeping her brothers



<P>in better order than she could, acquitted herself very well.



<P>Fanny's spirit was as much refreshed as her body; her head



<P>and heart were soon the better for such well-timed kindness.



<P>Susan had an open, sensible countenance; she was like William,



<P>and Fanny hoped to find her like him in disposition



<P>and goodwill towards herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In this more placid state of things William reentered,



<P>followed not far behind by his mother and Betsey.



<P>He, complete in his lieutenant's uniform, looking and



<P>moving all the taller, firmer, and more graceful for it,



<P>and with the happiest smile over his face, walked up directly



<P>to Fanny, who, rising from her seat, looked at him for a



<P>moment in speechless admiration, and then threw her arms



<P>round his neck to sob out her various emotions of pain and



<P>pleasure.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Anxious not to appear unhappy, she soon recovered herself;



<P>and wiping away her tears, was able to notice and admire



<P>all the striking parts of his dress; listening with reviving



<P>spirits to his cheerful hopes of being on shore some part



<P>of every day before they sailed, and even of getting



<P>her to Spithead to see the sloop.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next bustle brought in Mr. Campbell, the surgeon



<P>of the Thrush, a very well-behaved young man, who came



<P>to call for his friend, and for whom there was with some



<P>contrivance found a chair, and with some hasty washing of



<P>the young tea-maker's, a cup and saucer; and after another



<P>quarter of an hour of earnest talk between the gentlemen,



<P>noise rising upon noise, and bustle upon bustle, men and



<P>boys at last all in motion together, the moment came



<P>for setting off; everything was ready, William took leave,



<P>and all of them were gone; for the three boys, in spite



<P>of their mother's entreaty, determined to see their brother



<P>and Mr. Campbell to the sally-port; and Mr. Price walked



<P>off at the same time to carry back his neighbour's newspaper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Something like tranquillity might now be hoped for;



<P>and accordingly, when Rebecca had been prevailed on



<P>to carry away the tea-things, and Mrs. Price had walked



<P>about the room some time looking for a shirt-sleeve, which



<P>Betsey at last hunted out from a drawer in the kitchen,



<P>the small party of females were pretty well composed,



<P>and the mother having lamented again over the impossibility



<P>of getting Sam ready in time, was at leisure to think



<P>of her eldest daughter and the friends she had come from.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A few inquiries began:&nbsp; but one of the earliest--"How did



<P>sister Bertram manage about her servants?&nbsp; "Was she



<P>as much plagued as herself to get tolerable servants?"--



<P>soon led her mind away from Northamptonshire, and fixed it



<P>on her own domestic grievances, and the shocking character



<P>of all the Portsmouth servants, of whom she believed her



<P>own two were the very worst, engrossed her completely.



<P>The Bertrams were all forgotten in detailing the faults



<P>of Rebecca, against whom Susan had also much to depose,



<P>and little Betsey a great deal more, and who did seem



<P>so thoroughly without a single recommendation, that Fanny



<P>could not help modestly presuming that her mother meant



<P>to part with her when her year was up.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Her year!" cried Mrs. Price; "I am sure I hope I



<P>shall be rid of her before she has staid a year,



<P>for that will not be up till November.&nbsp; Servants are come



<P>to such a pass, my dear, in Portsmouth, that it is quite



<P>a miracle if one keeps them more than half a year.



<P>I have no hope of ever being settled; and if I was to



<P>part with Rebecca, I should only get something worse.



<P>And yet I do not think I am a very difficult mistress



<P>to please; and I am sure the place is easy enough,



<P>for there is always a girl under her, and I often do half



<P>the work myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was silent; but not from being convinced that there



<P>might not be a remedy found for some of these evils.



<P>As she now sat looking at Betsey, she could not but think



<P>particularly of another sister, a very pretty little girl,



<P>whom she had left there not much younger when she went



<P>into Northamptonshire, who had died a few years afterwards.



<P>There had been something remarkably amiable about her.



<P>Fanny in those early days had preferred her to Susan;



<P>and when the news of her death had at last reached Mansfield,



<P>had for a short time been quite afflicted.&nbsp; The sight



<P>of Betsey brought the image of little Mary back again,



<P>but she would not have pained her mother by alluding to her



<P>for the world.&nbsp; While considering her with these ideas,



<P>Betsey, at a small distance, was holding out something to



<P>catch her eyes, meaning to screen it at the same time from



<P>Susan's.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What have you got there, my love?" said Fanny;



<P>"come and shew it to me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a silver knife.&nbsp; Up jumped Susan, claiming it



<P>as her own, and trying to get it away; but the child ran



<P>to her mother's protection, and Susan could only reproach,



<P>which she did very warmly, and evidently hoping to



<P>interest Fanny on her side.&nbsp; "It was very hard that she



<P>was not to have her _own_ knife; it was her own knife;



<P>little sister Mary had left it to her upon her deathbed,



<P>and she ought to have had it to keep herself long ago.



<P>But mama kept it from her, and was always letting Betsey



<P>get hold of it; and the end of it would be that Betsey



<P>would spoil it, and get it for her own, though mama



<P>had _promised_ her that Betsey should not have it in her



<P>own hands."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was quite shocked.&nbsp; Every feeling of duty,



<P>honour, and tenderness was wounded by her sister's



<P>speech and her mother's reply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Susan," cried Mrs. Price, in a complaining voice,



<P>"now, how can you be so cross?&nbsp; You are always quarrelling



<P>about that knife.&nbsp; I wish you would not be so quarrelsome.



<P>Poor little Betsey; how cross Susan is to you!&nbsp; But you



<P>should not have taken it out, my dear, when I sent you



<P>to the drawer.&nbsp; You know I told you not to touch it,



<P>because Susan is so cross about it.&nbsp; I must hide it



<P>another time, Betsey.&nbsp; Poor Mary little thought it would



<P>be such a bone of contention when she gave it me to keep,



<P>only two hours before she died.&nbsp; Poor little soul! she could



<P>but just speak to be heard, and she said so prettily, "Let sister



<P>Susan have my knife, mama, when I am dead and buried."



<P>Poor little dear! she was so fond of it, Fanny, that she



<P>would have it lay by her in bed, all through her illness.



<P>It was the gift of her good godmother, old Mrs. Admiral



<P>Maxwell, only six weeks before she was taken for death.



<P>Poor little sweet creature!&nbsp; Well, she was taken away



<P>from evil to come.&nbsp; My own Betsey" (fondling her),



<P>"_you_ have not the luck of such a good godmother.



<P>Aunt Norris lives too far off to think of such little



<P>people as you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny had indeed nothing to convey from aunt Norris,



<P>but a message to say she hoped that her god-daughter



<P>was a good girl, and learnt her book.&nbsp; There had been



<P>at one moment a slight murmur in the drawing-room



<P>at Mansfield Park about sending her a prayer-book;



<P>but no second sound had been heard of such a purpose.



<P>Mrs. Norris, however, had gone home and taken down two



<P>old prayer-books of her husband with that idea; but,



<P>upon examination, the ardour of generosity went off.



<P>One was found to have too small a print for a child's eyes,



<P>and the other to be too cumbersome for her to carry about.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, fatigued and fatigued again, was thankful to accept



<P>the first invitation of going to bed; and before Betsey



<P>had finished her cry at being allowed to sit up only one



<P>hour extraordinary in honour of sister, she was off,



<P>leaving all below in confusion and noise again; the boys



<P>begging for toasted cheese, her father calling out for his



<P>rum and water, and Rebecca never where she ought to be.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was nothing to raise her spirits in the confined



<P>and scantily furnished chamber that she was to share



<P>with Susan.&nbsp; The smallness of the rooms above and below,



<P>indeed, and the narrowness of the passage and staircase,



<P>struck her beyond her imagination.&nbsp; She soon learned to think



<P>with respect of her own little attic at Mansfield Park,



<P>in&nbsp; that&nbsp; house reckoned too small for anybody's comfort.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 04</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER IV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Tom Bertram had of late spent so little of his time at



<P>home that he could be only nominally missed; and Lady



<P>Bertram was soon astonished to find how very well they



<P>did even without his father, how well Edmund could



<P>supply his place in carving, talking to the steward,



<P>writing to the attorney, settling with the servants,



<P>and equally saving her from all possible fatigue or exertion



<P>in every particular but that of directing her letters.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The earliest intelligence of the travellers' safe arrival



<P>at Antigua, after a favourable voyage, was received;



<P>though not before Mrs. Norris had been indulging in very



<P>dreadful fears, and trying to make Edmund participate them



<P>whenever she could get him alone; and as she depended



<P>on being the first person made acquainted with any



<P>fatal catastrophe, she had already arranged the manner of



<P>breaking it to all the others, when Sir Thomas's assurances



<P>of their both being alive and well made it necessary to lay



<P>by her agitation and affectionate preparatory speeches for a while.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The winter came and passed without their being



<P>called for; the accounts continued perfectly good;



<P>and Mrs. Norris, in promoting gaieties for her nieces,



<P>assisting their toilets, displaying their accomplishments,



<P>and looking about for their future husbands, had so much



<P>to do as, in addition to all her own household cares,



<P>some interference in those of her sister, and Mrs. Grant's



<P>wasteful doings to overlook, left her very little occasion



<P>to be occupied in fears for the absent.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Miss Bertrams were now fully established among the



<P>belles of the neighbourhood; and as they joined to beauty



<P>and brilliant acquirements a manner naturally easy,



<P>and carefully formed to general civility and obligingness,



<P>they possessed its favour as well as its admiration.



<P>Their vanity was in such good order that they seemed



<P>to be quite free from it, and gave themselves no airs;



<P>while the praises attending such behaviour, secured and



<P>brought round by their aunt, served to strengthen them in



<P>believing they had no faults.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram did not go into public with her daughters.



<P>She was too indolent even to accept a mother's gratification



<P>in witnessing their success and enjoyment at the expense



<P>of any personal trouble, and the charge was made over



<P>to her sister, who desired nothing better than a post



<P>of such honourable representation, and very thoroughly



<P>relished the means it afforded her of mixing in society



<P>without having horses to hire.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny had no share in the festivities of the season;



<P>but she enjoyed being avowedly useful as her aunt's companion



<P>when they called away the rest of the family; and, as Miss



<P>Lee had left Mansfield, she naturally became everything



<P>to Lady Bertram during the night of a ball or a party.



<P>She talked to her, listened to her, read to her;



<P>and the tranquillity of such evenings, her perfect security



<P>in such a _tete-a-tete_ from any sound of unkindness,



<P>was unspeakably welcome to a mind which had seldom



<P>known a pause in its alarms or embarrassments.&nbsp; As to



<P>her cousins' gaieties, she loved to hear an account of them,



<P>especially of the balls, and whom Edmund had danced with;



<P>but thought too lowly of her own situation to imagine



<P>she should ever be admitted to the same, and listened,



<P>therefore, without an idea of any nearer concern in them.



<P>Upon the whole, it was a comfortable winter to her;



<P>for though it brought no William to England, the never-failing



<P>hope of his arrival was worth much.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The ensuing spring deprived her of her valued friend,



<P>the old grey pony; and for some time she was in danger of



<P>feeling the loss in her health as well as in her affections;



<P>for in spite of the acknowledged importance of her riding



<P>on horse-back, no measures were taken for mounting



<P>her again, "because," as it was observed by her aunts,



<P>"she might ride one of her cousin's horses at any time



<P>when they did not want them," and as the Miss Bertrams



<P>regularly wanted their horses every fine day, and had no



<P>idea of carrying their obliging manners to the sacrifice



<P>of any real pleasure, that time, of course, never came.



<P>They took their cheerful rides in the fine mornings



<P>of April and May; and Fanny either sat at home the whole



<P>day with one aunt, or walked beyond her strength at the



<P>instigation of the other:&nbsp; Lady Bertram holding exercise



<P>to be as unnecessary for everybody as it was unpleasant



<P>to herself; and Mrs. Norris, who was walking all day,



<P>thinking everybody ought to walk as much.&nbsp; Edmund was absent



<P>at this time, or the evil would have been earlier remedied.



<P>When he returned, to understand how Fanny was situated,



<P>and perceived its ill effects, there seemed with him but



<P>one thing to be done; and that "Fanny must have a horse"



<P>was the resolute declaration with which he opposed



<P>whatever could be urged by the supineness of his mother,



<P>or the economy of his aunt, to make it appear unimportant.



<P>Mrs. Norris could not help thinking that some steady



<P>old thing might be found among the numbers belonging



<P>to the Park that would do vastly well; or that one might



<P>be borrowed of the steward; or that perhaps Dr. Grant



<P>might now and then lend them the pony he sent to the post.



<P>She could not but consider it as absolutely unnecessary,



<P>and even improper, that Fanny should have a regular



<P>lady's horse of her own, in the style of her cousins.



<P>She was sure Sir Thomas had never intended it:&nbsp; and she



<P>must say that, to be making such a purchase in his absence,



<P>and adding to the great expenses of his stable,



<P>at a time when a large part of his income was unsettled,



<P>seemed to her very unjustifiable.&nbsp; "Fanny must have



<P>a horse," was Edmund's only reply.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris could



<P>not see it in the same light.&nbsp; Lady Bertram did:



<P>she entirely agreed with her son as to the necessity of it,



<P>and as to its being considered necessary by his father;



<P>she only pleaded against there being any hurry; she only



<P>wanted him to wait till Sir Thomas's return, and then Sir



<P>Thomas might settle it all himself.&nbsp; He would be at home



<P>in September, and where would be the harm of only waiting



<P>till September?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Though Edmund was much more displeased with his aunt than



<P>with his mother, as evincing least regard for her niece,



<P>he could not help paying more attention to what she said;



<P>and at length determined on a method of proceeding



<P>which would obviate the risk of his father's thinking he



<P>had done too much, and at the same time procure for Fanny



<P>the immediate means of exercise, which he could not bear



<P>she should be without.&nbsp; He had three horses of his own,



<P>but not one that would carry a woman.&nbsp; Two of them



<P>were hunters; the third, a useful road-horse: this third he



<P>resolved to exchange for one that his cousin might ride;



<P>he knew where such a one was to be met with; and having once



<P>made up his mind, the whole business was soon completed.



<P>The new mare proved a treasure; with a very little



<P>trouble she became exactly calculated for the purpose,



<P>and Fanny was then put in almost full possession of her.



<P>She had not supposed before that anything could ever suit



<P>her like the old grey pony; but her delight in Edmund's



<P>mare was far beyond any former pleasure of the sort;



<P>and the addition it was ever receiving in the consideration



<P>of that kindness from which her pleasure sprung,



<P>was beyond all her words to express.&nbsp; She regarded



<P>her cousin as an example of everything good and great,



<P>as possessing worth which no one but herself could



<P>ever appreciate, and as entitled to such gratitude



<P>from her as no feelings could be strong enough to pay.



<P>Her sentiments towards him were compounded of all that



<P>was respectful, grateful, confiding, and tender.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As the horse continued in name, as well as fact,



<P>the property of Edmund, Mrs. Norris could tolerate its being



<P>for Fanny's use; and had Lady Bertram ever thought about



<P>her own objection again, he might have been excused in her



<P>eyes for not waiting till Sir Thomas's return in September,



<P>for when September came Sir Thomas was still abroad,



<P>and without any near prospect of finishing his business.



<P>Unfavourable circumstances had suddenly arisen at a moment



<P>when he was beginning to turn all his thoughts towards England;



<P>and the very great uncertainty in which everything was then



<P>involved determined him on sending home his son, and waiting



<P>the final arrangement by himself Tom arrived safely,



<P>bringing an excellent account of his father's health;



<P>but to very little purpose, as far as Mrs. Norris



<P>was concerned.&nbsp; Sir Thomas's sending away his son seemed



<P>to her so like a parent's care, under the influence of a



<P>foreboding of evil to himself, that she could not help



<P>feeling dreadful presentiments; and as the long evenings



<P>of autumn came on, was so terribly haunted by these ideas,



<P>in the sad solitariness of her cottage, as to be obliged



<P>to take daily refuge in the dining-room of the Park.



<P>The return of winter engagements, however, was not



<P>without its effect; and in the course of their progress,



<P>her mind became so pleasantly occupied in superintending



<P>the fortunes of her eldest niece, as tolerably to quiet



<P>her nerves.&nbsp; "If poor Sir Thomas were fated never to return,



<P>it would be peculiarly consoling to see their dear Maria



<P>well married," she very often thought; always when they



<P>were in the company of men of fortune, and particularly on



<P>the introduction of a young man who had recently succeeded



<P>to one of the largest estates and finest places in the country.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Rushworth was from the first struck with the beauty



<P>of Miss Bertram, and, being inclined to marry, soon fancied



<P>himself in love.&nbsp; He was a heavy young man, with not more



<P>than common sense; but as there was nothing disagreeable



<P>in his figure or address, the young lady was well pleased



<P>with her conquest.&nbsp; Being now in her twenty-first year,



<P>Maria Bertram was beginning to think matrimony a duty;



<P>and as a marriage with Mr. Rushworth would give her the



<P>enjoyment of a larger income than her father's, as well as



<P>ensure her the house in town, which was now a prime object,



<P>it became, by the same rule of moral obligation,



<P>her evident duty to marry Mr. Rushworth if she could.



<P>Mrs. Norris was most zealous in promoting the match,



<P>by every suggestion and contrivance likely to enhance



<P>its desirableness to either party; and, among other means,



<P>by seeking an intimacy with the gentleman's mother,



<P>who at present lived with him, and to whom she even forced



<P>Lady Bertram to go through ten miles of indifferent road



<P>to pay a morning visit.&nbsp; It was not long before a good



<P>understanding took place between this lady and herself.



<P>Mrs. Rushworth acknowledged herself very desirous that



<P>her son should marry, and declared that of all the young



<P>ladies she had ever seen, Miss Bertram seemed, by her



<P>amiable qualities and accomplishments, the best adapted



<P>to make him happy.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris accepted the compliment,



<P>and admired the nice discernment of character which



<P>could so well distinguish merit.&nbsp; Maria was indeed



<P>the pride and delight of them all--perfectly faultless--



<P>an angel; and, of course, so surrounded by admirers, must be



<P>difficult in her choice:&nbsp; but yet, as far as Mrs. Norris



<P>could allow herself to decide on so short an acquaintance,



<P>Mr. Rushworth appeared precisely the young man to deserve



<P>and attach her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After dancing with each other at a proper number of balls,



<P>the young people justified these opinions, and an engagement,



<P>with a due reference to the absent Sir Thomas, was entered into,



<P>much to the satisfaction of their respective families,



<P>and of the general lookers-on of the neighbourhood,



<P>who had, for many weeks past, felt the expediency



<P>of Mr. Rushworth's marrying Miss Bertram.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was some months before Sir Thomas's consent could



<P>be received; but, in the meanwhile, as no one felt



<P>a doubt of his most cordial pleasure in the connexion,



<P>the intercourse of the two families was carried on



<P>without restraint, and no other attempt made at secrecy



<P>than Mrs. Norris's talking of it everywhere as a matter



<P>not to be talked of at present.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund was the only one of the family who could see a fault



<P>in the business; but no representation of his aunt's could



<P>induce him to find Mr. Rushworth a desirable companion.



<P>He could allow his sister to be the best judge of her



<P>own happiness, but he was not pleased that her happiness



<P>should centre in a large income; nor could he refrain



<P>from often saying to himself, in Mr. Rushworth's company--



<P>"If this man had not twelve thousand a year, he would be



<P>a very stupid fellow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas, however, was truly happy in the prospect of an



<P>alliance so unquestionably advantageous, and of which he



<P>heard nothing but the perfectly good and agreeable.



<P>It was a connexion exactly of the right sort--



<P>in the same county, and the same interest--and his most



<P>hearty concurrence was conveyed as soon as possible.



<P>He only conditioned that the marriage should not take



<P>place before his return, which he was again looking



<P>eagerly forward to.&nbsp; He wrote in April, and had strong



<P>hopes of settling everything to his entire satisfaction,



<P>and leaving Antigua before the end of the summer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such was the state of affairs in the month of July;



<P>and Fanny had just reached her eighteenth year, when the



<P>society of the village received an addition in the brother



<P>and sister of Mrs. Grant, a Mr. and Miss Crawford,



<P>the children of her mother by a second marriage.



<P>They were young people of fortune.&nbsp; The son had a good



<P>estate in Norfolk, the daughter twenty thousand pounds.



<P>As children, their sister had been always very fond



<P>of them; but, as her own marriage had been soon followed



<P>by the death of their common parent, which left them



<P>to the care of a brother of their father, of whom



<P>Mrs. Grant knew nothing, she had scarcely seen them since.



<P>In their uncle's house they had found a kind home.



<P>Admiral and Mrs. Crawford, though agreeing in nothing else,



<P>were united in affection for these children, or, at least,



<P>were no farther adverse in their feelings than that each



<P>had their favourite, to whom they showed the greatest



<P>fondness of the two.&nbsp; The Admiral delighted in the boy,



<P>Mrs. Crawford doted on the girl; and it was the lady's



<P>death which now obliged her _protegee_, after some months'



<P>further trial at her uncle's house, to find another home.



<P>Admiral Crawford was a man of vicious conduct, who chose,



<P>instead of retaining his niece, to bring his mistress



<P>under his own roof; and to this Mrs. Grant was indebted



<P>for her sister's proposal of coming to her, a measure quite



<P>as welcome on one side as it could be expedient on the other;



<P>for Mrs. Grant, having by this time run through the usual



<P>resources of ladies residing in the country without a



<P>family of children--having more than filled her favourite



<P>sitting-room with pretty furniture, and made a choice



<P>collection of plants and poultry--was very much in want



<P>of some variety at home.&nbsp; The arrival, therefore, of a sister



<P>whom she had always loved, and now hoped to retain with



<P>her as long as she remained single, was highly agreeable;



<P>and her chief anxiety was lest Mansfield should not satisfy



<P>the habits of a young woman who had been mostly used



<P>to London.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford was not entirely free from similar



<P>apprehensions, though they arose principally from doubts



<P>of her sister's style of living and tone of society;



<P>and it was not till after she had tried in vain to persuade



<P>her brother to settle with her at his own country house,



<P>that she could resolve to hazard herself among her



<P>other relations.&nbsp; To anything like a permanence of abode,



<P>or limitation of society, Henry Crawford had, unluckily,



<P>a great dislike:&nbsp; he could not accommodate his sister



<P>in an article of such importance; but he escorted her,



<P>with the utmost kindness, into Northamptonshire,



<P>and as readily engaged to fetch her away again, at half



<P>an hour's notice, whenever she were weary of the place.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The meeting was very satisfactory on each side.



<P>Miss Crawford found a sister without preciseness



<P>or rusticity, a sister's husband who looked the gentleman,



<P>and a house commodious and well fitted up; and Mrs. Grant



<P>received in those whom she hoped to love better than ever



<P>a young man and woman of very prepossessing appearance.



<P>Mary Crawford was remarkably pretty; Henry, though not handsome,



<P>had air and countenance; the manners of both were lively



<P>and pleasant, and Mrs. Grant immediately gave them credit



<P>for everything else.&nbsp; She was delighted with each,



<P>but Mary was her dearest object; and having never been



<P>able to glory in beauty of her own, she thoroughly enjoyed



<P>the power of being proud of her sister's. She had not waited



<P>her arrival to look out for a suitable match for her:



<P>she had fixed on Tom Bertram; the eldest son of a baronet



<P>was not too good for a girl of twenty thousand pounds,



<P>with all the elegance and accomplishments which Mrs. Grant



<P>foresaw in her; and being a warm-hearted, unreserved woman,



<P>Mary had not been three hours in the house before she



<P>told her what she had planned.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford was glad to find a family of such consequence



<P>so very near them, and not at all displeased either at



<P>her sister's early care, or the choice it had fallen on.



<P>Matrimony was her object, provided she could marry well:



<P>and having seen Mr. Bertram in town, she knew that



<P>objection could no more be made to his person than to



<P>his situation in life.&nbsp; While she treated it as a joke,



<P>therefore, she did not forget to think of it seriously.



<P>The scheme was soon repeated to Henry.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And now," added Mrs. Grant, "I have thought of something



<P>to make it complete.&nbsp; I should dearly love to settle you



<P>both in this country; and therefore, Henry, you shall



<P>marry the youngest Miss Bertram, a nice, handsome,



<P>good-humoured, accomplished girl, who will make you very happy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Henry bowed and thanked her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear sister," said Mary, "if you can persuade him



<P>into anything of the sort, it will be a fresh matter of



<P>delight to me to find myself allied to anybody so clever,



<P>and I shall only regret that you have not half a dozen



<P>daughters to dispose of.&nbsp; If you can persuade Henry



<P>to marry, you must have the address of a Frenchwoman.



<P>All that English abilities can do has been tried already.



<P>I have three very particular friends who have been all



<P>dying for him in their turn; and the pains which they,



<P>their mothers (very clever women), as well as my dear



<P>aunt and myself, have taken to reason, coax, or trick



<P>him into marrying, is inconceivable!&nbsp; He is the most



<P>horrible flirt that can be imagined.&nbsp; If your Miss



<P>Bertrams do not like to have their hearts broke, let them



<P>avoid Henry."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear brother, I will not believe this of you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I am sure you are too good.&nbsp; You will be kinder than Mary.



<P>You will allow for the doubts of youth and inexperience.



<P>I am of a cautious temper, and unwilling to risk my



<P>happiness in a hurry.&nbsp; Nobody can think more highly of



<P>the matrimonial state than myself I consider the blessing



<P>of a wife as most justly described in those discreet



<P>lines of the poet--'Heaven's _last_ best gift.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There, Mrs. Grant, you see how he dwells on one word,



<P>and only look at his smile.&nbsp; I assure you he is very detestable;



<P>the Admiral's lessons have quite spoiled him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I pay very little regard," said Mrs. Grant, "to what



<P>any young person says on the subject of marriage.



<P>If they profess a disinclination for it, I only set it



<P>down that they have not yet seen the right person."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dr. Grant laughingly congratulated Miss Crawford



<P>on feeling no disinclination to the state herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes!&nbsp; I am not at all ashamed of it.&nbsp; I would



<P>have everybody marry if they can do it properly:



<P>I do not like to have people throw themselves away;



<P>but everybody should marry as soon as they can do it



<P>to advantage."



<P>

<HTML>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
