   <TITLE>Chapter 10</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER X</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A quarter of an hour, twenty minutes, passed away,



<P>and Fanny was still thinking of Edmund, Miss Crawford,



<P>and herself, without interruption from any one.&nbsp; She began



<P>to be surprised at being left so long, and to listen



<P>with an anxious desire of hearing their steps and their



<P>voices again.&nbsp; She listened, and at length she heard;



<P>she heard voices and feet approaching; but she had just



<P>satisfied herself that it was not those she wanted,



<P>when Miss Bertram, Mr. Rushworth, and Mr. Crawford issued



<P>from the same path which she had trod herself, and were



<P>before her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Price all alone" and "My dear Fanny, how comes this?"



<P>were the first salutations.&nbsp; She told her story.



<P>"Poor dear Fanny," cried her cousin, "how ill you have been



<P>used by them!&nbsp; You had better have staid with us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Then seating herself with a gentleman on each side,



<P>she resumed the conversation which had engaged them before,



<P>and discussed the possibility of improvements with



<P>much animation.&nbsp; Nothing was fixed on; but Henry Crawford



<P>was full of ideas and projects, and, generally speaking,



<P>whatever he proposed was immediately approved, first by her,



<P>and then by Mr. Rushworth, whose principal business



<P>seemed to be to hear the others, and who scarcely risked



<P>an original thought of his own beyond a wish that they



<P>had seen his friend Smith's place.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After some minutes spent in this way, Miss Bertram,



<P>observing the iron gate, expressed a wish of passing



<P>through it into the park, that their views and their



<P>plans might be more comprehensive.&nbsp; It was the very thing



<P>of all others to be wished, it was the best, it was



<P>the only way of proceeding with any advantage, in Henry



<P>Crawford's opinion; and he directly saw a knoll not half



<P>a mile off, which would give them exactly the requisite



<P>command of the house.&nbsp; Go therefore they must to that knoll,



<P>and through that gate; but the gate was locked.



<P>Mr. Rushworth wished he had brought the key; he had been



<P>very near thinking whether he should not bring the key;



<P>he was determined he would never come without the key again;



<P>but still this did not remove the present evil.&nbsp; They could



<P>not get through; and as Miss Bertram's inclination for so



<P>doing did by no means lessen, it ended in Mr. Rushworth's



<P>declaring outright that he would go and fetch the key.



<P>He set off accordingly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is undoubtedly the best thing we can do now, as we



<P>are so far from the house already," said Mr. Crawford,



<P>when he was gone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, there is nothing else to be done.&nbsp; But now, sincerely,



<P>do not you find the place altogether worse than you expected?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed, far otherwise.&nbsp; I find it better, grander, more



<P>complete in its style, though that style may not be the best.



<P>And to tell you the truth," speaking rather lower, "I do not



<P>think that _I_ shall ever see Sotherton again with so much



<P>pleasure as I do now.&nbsp; Another summer will hardly improve it to



<P>me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After a moment's embarrassment the lady replied, "You are



<P>too much a man of the world not to see with the eyes



<P>of the world.&nbsp; If other people think Sotherton improved,



<P>I have no doubt that you will."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am afraid I am not quite so much the man of the world



<P>as might be good for me in some points.&nbsp; My feelings



<P>are not quite so evanescent, nor my memory of the past



<P>under such easy dominion as one finds to be the case



<P>with men of the world."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was followed by a short silence.&nbsp; Miss Bertram



<P>began again.&nbsp; "You seemed to enjoy your drive here very much



<P>this morning.&nbsp; I was glad to see you so well entertained.



<P>You and Julia were laughing the whole way."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Were we?&nbsp; Yes, I believe we were; but I have not



<P>the least recollection at what.&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; I believe



<P>I was relating to her some ridiculous stories



<P>of an old Irish groom of my uncle's. Your sister loves to laugh."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You think her more light-hearted than I am?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"More easily amused," he replied; "consequently, you know,"



<P>smiling, "better company.&nbsp; I could not have hoped



<P>to entertain you with Irish anecdotes during a ten miles' drive."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Naturally, I believe, I am as lively as Julia, but I



<P>have more to think of now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have, undoubtedly; and there are situations in



<P>which very high spirits would denote insensibility.



<P>Your prospects, however, are too fair to justify want



<P>of spirits.&nbsp; You have a very smiling scene before you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you mean literally or figuratively?&nbsp; Literally,



<P>I conclude.&nbsp; Yes, certainly, the sun shines, and the park



<P>looks very cheerful.&nbsp; But unluckily that iron gate,



<P>that ha-ha, give me a feeling of restraint and hardship.



<P>"I cannot get out, as the starling said."&nbsp; As she spoke,



<P>and it was with expression, she walked to the gate:



<P>he followed her.&nbsp; "Mr. Rushworth is so long fetching



<P>this key!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And for the world you would not get out without the key



<P>and without Mr. Rushworth's authority and protection,



<P>or I think you might with little difficulty pass round



<P>the edge of the gate, here, with my assistance; I think it



<P>might be done, if you really wished to be more at large,



<P>and could allow yourself to think it not prohibited."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Prohibited! nonsense!&nbsp; I certainly can get out that way,



<P>and I will.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth will be here in a moment,



<P>you know; we shall not be out of sight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Or if we are, Miss Price will be so good as to tell him



<P>that he will find us near that knoll:&nbsp; the grove of oak



<P>on the knoll."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, feeling all this to be wrong, could not help



<P>making an effort to prevent it.&nbsp; "You will hurt yourself,



<P>Miss Bertram," she cried; "you will certainly hurt



<P>yourself against those spikes; you will tear your gown;



<P>you will be in danger of slipping into the ha-ha. You had



<P>better not go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her cousin was safe on the other side while these words



<P>were spoken, and, smiling with all the good-humour



<P>of success, she said, "Thank you, my dear Fanny,



<P>but I and my gown are alive and well, and so good-bye."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was again left to her solitude, and with no increase



<P>of pleasant feelings, for she was sorry for almost all



<P>that she had seen and heard, astonished at Miss Bertram,



<P>and angry with Mr. Crawford.&nbsp; By taking a circuitous



<P>route, and, as it appeared to her, very unreasonable



<P>direction to the knoll, they were soon beyond her eye;



<P>and for some minutes longer she remained without sight



<P>or sound of any companion.&nbsp; She seemed to have the little



<P>wood all to herself.&nbsp; She could almost have thought



<P>that Edmund and Miss Crawford had left it, but that



<P>it was impossible for Edmund to forget her so entirely.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was again roused from disagreeable musings by sudden footsteps:

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>somebody was coming at a quick pace down the principal walk.



<P>She expected Mr. Rushworth, but it was Julia, who,



<P>hot and out of breath, and with a look of disappointment,



<P>cried out on seeing her, "Heyday!&nbsp; Where are the others?



<P>I thought Maria and Mr. Crawford were with you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny explained.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A pretty trick, upon my word!&nbsp; I cannot see them anywhere,"



<P>looking eagerly into the park.&nbsp; "But they cannot be very



<P>far off, and I think I am equal to as much as Maria,



<P>even without help."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, Julia, Mr. Rushworth will be here in a moment



<P>with the key.&nbsp; Do wait for Mr. Rushworth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not I, indeed.&nbsp; I have had enough of the family for



<P>one morning.&nbsp; Why, child, I have but this moment escaped from



<P>his horrible mother.&nbsp; Such a penance as I have been enduring,



<P>while you were sitting here so composed and so happy!



<P>It might have been as well, perhaps, if you had been in



<P>my place, but you always contrive to keep out of these scrapes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was a most unjust reflection, but Fanny could allow



<P>for it, and let it pass:&nbsp; Julia was vexed, and her



<P>temper was hasty; but she felt that it would not last,



<P>and therefore, taking no notice, only asked her if she



<P>had not seen Mr. Rushworth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, yes, we saw him.&nbsp; He was posting away as if upon



<P>life and death, and could but just spare time to tell us



<P>his errand, and where you all were."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a pity he should have so much trouble for nothing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_That_ is Miss Maria's concern.&nbsp; I am not obliged



<P>to punish myself for _her_ sins.&nbsp; The mother I could



<P>not avoid, as long as my tiresome aunt was dancing about



<P>with the housekeeper, but the son I _can_ get away from."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And she immediately scrambled across the fence,



<P>and walked away, not attending to Fanny's last question of



<P>whether she had seen anything of Miss Crawford and Edmund.



<P>The sort of dread in which Fanny now sat of seeing



<P>Mr. Rushworth prevented her thinking so much of their



<P>continued absence, however, as she might have done.



<P>She felt that he had been very ill-used, and was quite



<P>unhappy in having to communicate what had passed.



<P>He joined her within five minutes after Julia's exit;



<P>and though she made the best of the story, he was evidently



<P>mortified and displeased in no common degree.&nbsp; At first



<P>he scarcely said anything; his looks only expressed his



<P>extreme surprise and vexation, and he walked to the gate



<P>and stood there, without seeming to know what to do.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They desired me to stay--my cousin Maria charged me to say



<P>that you would find them at that knoll, or thereabouts."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not believe I shall go any farther," said he sullenly;



<P>"I see nothing of them.&nbsp; By the time I get to the knoll they



<P>may be gone somewhere else.&nbsp; I have had walking enough."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And he sat down with a most gloomy countenance by Fanny.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very sorry," said she; "it is very unlucky."&nbsp; And she



<P>longed to be able to say something more to the purpose.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After an interval of silence, "I think they might as well



<P>have staid for me," said he.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Bertram thought you would follow her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should not have had to follow her if she had staid."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This could not be denied, and Fanny was silenced.



<P>After another pause, he went on--"Pray, Miss Price,



<P>are you such a great admirer of this Mr. Crawford as some



<P>people are?&nbsp; For my part, I can see nothing in him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not think him at all handsome."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Handsome!&nbsp; Nobody can call such an undersized man handsome.



<P>He is not five foot nine.&nbsp; I should not wonder if he is not more



<P>than five foot eight.&nbsp; I think he is an ill-looking fellow.



<P>In my opinion, these Crawfords are no addition at all.



<P>We did very well without them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A small sigh escaped Fanny here, and she did not know



<P>how to contradict him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I had made any difficulty about fetching the key,



<P>there might have been some excuse, but I went the very



<P>moment she said she wanted it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing could be more obliging than your manner, I am sure,



<P>and I dare say you walked as fast as you could; but still



<P>it is some distance, you know, from this spot to the house,



<P>quite into the house; and when people are waiting,



<P>they are bad judges of time, and every half minute seems



<P>like five."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He got up and walked to the gate again, and "wished he



<P>had had the key about him at the time."&nbsp; Fanny thought she



<P>discerned in his standing there an indication of relenting,



<P>which encouraged her to another attempt, and she said,



<P>therefore, "It is a pity you should not join them.



<P>They expected to have a better view of the house from



<P>that part of the park, and will be thinking how it



<P>may be improved; and nothing of that sort, you know,



<P>can be settled without you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She found herself more successful in sending away than



<P>in retaining a companion.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth was worked on.



<P>"Well," said he, "if you really think I had better go:



<P>it would be foolish to bring the key for nothing."



<P>And letting himself out, he walked off without farther



<P>ceremony.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's thoughts were now all engrossed by the two who



<P>had left her so long ago, and getting quite impatient,



<P>she resolved to go in search of them.&nbsp; She followed



<P>their steps along the bottom walk, and had just turned



<P>up into another, when the voice and the laugh of Miss



<P>Crawford once more caught her ear; the sound approached,



<P>and a few more windings brought them before her.



<P>They were just returned into the wilderness from the park,



<P>to which a sidegate, not fastened, had tempted them very



<P>soon after their leaving her, and they had been across



<P>a portion of the park into the very avenue which Fanny



<P>had been hoping the whole morning to reach at last,



<P>and had been sitting down under one of the trees.



<P>This was their history.&nbsp; It was evident that they had been



<P>spending their time pleasantly, and were not aware of the



<P>length of their absence.&nbsp; Fanny's best consolation was



<P>in being assured that Edmund had wished for her very much,



<P>and that he should certainly have come back for her,



<P>had she not been tired already; but this was not quite



<P>sufficient to do away with the pain of having been left



<P>a whole hour, when he had talked of only a few minutes,



<P>nor to banish the sort of curiosity she felt to know



<P>what they had been conversing about all that time;



<P>and the result of the whole was to her disappointment



<P>and depression, as they prepared by general agreement to



<P>return to the house.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On reaching the bottom of the steps to the terrace,



<P>Mrs. Rushworth and Mrs. Norris presented themselves



<P>at the top, just ready for the wilderness, at the end



<P>of an hour and a half from their leaving the house.



<P>Mrs. Norris had been too well employed to move faster.



<P>Whatever cross-accidents had occurred to intercept the pleasures



<P>of her nieces, she had found a morning of complete enjoyment;



<P>for the housekeeper, after a great many courtesies on



<P>the subject of pheasants, had taken her to the dairy,



<P>told her all about their cows, and given her the receipt



<P>for a famous cream cheese; and since Julia's leaving them



<P>they had been met by the gardener, with whom she had made



<P>a most satisfactory acquaintance, for she had set him



<P>right as to his grandson's illness, convinced him that it



<P>was an ague, and promised him a charm for it; and he,



<P>in return, had shewn her all his choicest nursery of plants,



<P>and actually presented her with a very curious specimen



<P>of heath.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On this _ rencontre_ they all returned to the house together,



<P>there to lounge away the time as they could with sofas,



<P>and chit-chat, and Quarterly Reviews, till the return



<P>of the others, and the arrival of dinner.&nbsp; It was late



<P>before the Miss Bertrams and the two gentlemen came in,



<P>and their ramble did not appear to have been more than



<P>partially agreeable, or at all productive of anything



<P>useful with regard to the object of the day.&nbsp; By their



<P>own accounts they had been all walking after each other,



<P>and the junction which had taken place at last seemed,



<P>to Fanny's observation, to have been as much too late



<P>for re-establishing harmony, as it confessedly had



<P>been for determining on any alteration.&nbsp; She felt,



<P>as she looked at Julia and Mr. Rushworth, that hers



<P>was not the only dissatisfied bosom amongst them:



<P>there was gloom on the face of each.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford



<P>and Miss Bertram were much more gay, and she thought



<P>that he was taking particular pains, during dinner,



<P>to do away any little resentment of the other two,



<P>and restore general good-humour.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Dinner was soon followed by tea and coffee, a ten miles'



<P>drive home allowed no waste of hours; and from the time



<P>of their sitting down to table, it was a quick succession



<P>of busy nothings till the carriage came to the door,



<P>and Mrs. Norris, having fidgeted about, and obtained a



<P>few pheasants' eggs and a cream cheese from the housekeeper,



<P>and made abundance of civil speeches to Mrs. Rushworth,



<P>was ready to lead the way.&nbsp; At the same moment Mr. Crawford,



<P>approaching Julia, said, "I hope I am not to lose



<P>my companion, unless she is afraid of the evening air



<P>in so exposed a seat."&nbsp; The request had not been foreseen,



<P>but was very graciously received, and Julia's day was



<P>likely to end almost as well as it began.&nbsp; Miss Bertram



<P>had made up her mind to something different, and was a



<P>little disappointed; but her conviction of being really



<P>the one preferred comforted her under it, and enabled her



<P>to receive Mr. Rushworth's parting attentions as she ought.



<P>He was certainly better pleased to hand her into



<P>the barouche than to assist her in ascending the box,



<P>and his complacency seemed confirmed by the arrangement.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Fanny, this has been a fine day for you, upon my word,"



<P>said Mrs. Norris, as they drove through the park.



<P>"Nothing but pleasure from beginning to end!&nbsp; I am sure



<P>you ought to be very much obliged to your aunt Bertram



<P>and me for contriving to let you go.&nbsp; A pretty good day's



<P>amusement you have had!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Maria was just discontented enough to say directly, "I think



<P>_you_ have done pretty well yourself, ma'am. Your lap seems



<P>full of good things, and here is a basket of something



<P>between us which has been knocking my elbow unmercifully."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, it is only a beautiful little heath,



<P>which that nice old gardener would make me take; but if



<P>it is in your way, I will have it in my lap directly.



<P>There, Fanny, you shall carry that parcel for me;



<P>take great care of it:&nbsp; do not let it fall; it is a



<P>cream cheese, just like the excellent one we had at dinner.



<P>Nothing would satisfy that good old Mrs. Whitaker,



<P>but my taking one of the cheeses.&nbsp; I stood out as long



<P>as I could, till the tears almost came into her eyes,



<P>and I knew it was just the sort that my sister would



<P>be delighted with.&nbsp; That Mrs. Whitaker is a treasure!



<P>She was quite shocked when I asked her whether wine was allowed



<P>at the second table, and she has turned away two housemaids



<P>for wearing white gowns.&nbsp; Take care of the cheese, Fanny.



<P>Now I can manage the other parcel and the basket very well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What else have you been spunging?" said Maria,



<P>half-pleased that Sotherton should be so complimented.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Spunging, my dear!&nbsp; It is nothing but four of those



<P>beautiful pheasants' eggs, which Mrs. Whitaker would



<P>quite force upon me:&nbsp; she would not take a denial.



<P>She said it must be such an amusement to me, as she



<P>understood I lived quite alone, to have a few living



<P>creatures of that sort; and so to be sure it will.



<P>I shall get the dairymaid to set them under the first



<P>spare hen, and if they come to good I can have them moved



<P>to my own house and borrow a coop; and it will be a great



<P>delight to me in my lonely hours to attend to them.



<P>And if I have good luck, your mother shall have some."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a beautiful evening, mild and still, and the



<P>drive was as pleasant as the serenity of Nature



<P>could make it; but when Mrs. Norris ceased speaking,



<P>it was altogether a silent drive to those within.



<P>Their spirits were in general exhausted; and to determine



<P>whether the day had afforded most pleasure or pain,



<P>might occupy the meditations of almost all.



<P>

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 11</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The day at Sotherton, with all its imperfections,



<P>afforded the Miss Bertrams much more agreeable feelings



<P>than were derived from the letters from Antigua,



<P>which soon afterwards reached Mansfield.&nbsp; It was much



<P>pleasanter to think of Henry Crawford than of their father;



<P>and to think of their father in England again within



<P>a certain period, which these letters obliged them to do,



<P>was a most unwelcome exercise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>November was the black month fixed for his return.



<P>Sir Thomas wrote of it with as much decision as experience



<P>and anxiety could authorise.&nbsp; His business was so nearly



<P>concluded as to justify him in proposing to take his



<P>passage in the September packet, and he consequently



<P>looked forward with the hope of being with his beloved



<P>family again early in November.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Maria was more to be pitied than Julia; for to her the



<P>father brought a husband, and the return of the friend most



<P>solicitous for her happiness would unite her to the lover,



<P>on whom she had chosen that happiness should depend.



<P>It was a gloomy prospect, and all she could do was to



<P>throw a mist over it, and hope when the mist cleared



<P>away she should see something else.&nbsp; It would hardly



<P>be _early_ in November, there were generally delays,



<P>a bad passage or _something_; that favouring _something_



<P>which everybody who shuts their eyes while they look,



<P>or their understandings while they reason, feels the



<P>comfort of.&nbsp; It would probably be the middle of November



<P>at least; the middle of November was three months off.



<P>Three months comprised thirteen weeks.&nbsp; Much might happen



<P>in thirteen weeks.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas would have been deeply mortified by a suspicion



<P>of half that his daughters felt on the subject of his return,



<P>and would hardly have found consolation in a knowledge of the



<P>interest it excited in the breast of another young lady.



<P>Miss Crawford, on walking up with her brother to spend



<P>the evening at Mansfield Park, heard the good news;



<P>and though seeming to have no concern in the affair



<P>beyond politeness, and to have vented all her feelings



<P>in a quiet congratulation, heard it with an attention



<P>not so easily satisfied.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris gave the particulars



<P>of the letters, and the subject was dropt; but after tea,



<P>as Miss Crawford was standing at an open window with



<P>Edmund and Fanny looking out on a twilight scene,



<P>while the Miss Bertrams, Mr. Rushworth, and Henry Crawford



<P>were all busy with candles at the pianoforte, she suddenly



<P>revived it by turning round towards the group, and saying,



<P>"How happy Mr. Rushworth looks!&nbsp; He is thinking of November."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund looked round at Mr. Rushworth too, but had nothing



<P>to say.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your father's return will be a very interesting event."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It will, indeed, after such an absence; an absence



<P>not only long, but including so many dangers."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It will be the forerunner also of other interesting events:



<P>your sister's marriage, and your taking orders."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Don't be affronted," said she, laughing, "but it does



<P>put me in mind of some of the old heathen heroes, who,



<P>after performing great exploits in a foreign land,



<P>offered sacrifices to the gods on their safe return."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is no sacrifice in the case," replied Edmund,



<P>with a serious smile, and glancing at the pianoforte again;



<P>"it is entirely her own doing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes I know it is.&nbsp; I was merely joking.&nbsp; She has



<P>done no more than what every young woman would do;



<P>and I have no doubt of her being extremely happy.



<P>My other sacrifice, of course, you do not understand."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My taking orders, I assure you, is quite as voluntary



<P>as Maria's marrying."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is fortunate that your inclination and your father's



<P>convenience should accord so well.&nbsp; There is a very good



<P>living kept for you, I understand, hereabouts."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Which you suppose has biassed me?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But _that_ I am sure it has not," cried Fanny.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you for your good word, Fanny, but it is more than



<P>I would affirm myself.&nbsp; On the contrary, the knowing



<P>that there was such a provision for me probably did



<P>bias me.&nbsp; Nor can I think it wrong that it should.



<P>There was no natural disinclination to be overcome,



<P>and I see no reason why a man should make a worse clergyman



<P>for knowing that he will have a competence early in life.



<P>I was in safe hands.&nbsp; I hope I should not have been



<P>influenced myself in a wrong way, and I am sure my father



<P>was too conscientious to have allowed it.&nbsp; I have no doubt



<P>that I was biased, but I think it was blamelessly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is the same sort of thing," said Fanny, after a



<P>short pause, "as for the son of an admiral to go into



<P>the navy, or the son of a general to be in the army,



<P>and nobody sees anything wrong in that.&nbsp; Nobody wonders



<P>that they should prefer the line where their friends can



<P>serve them best, or suspects them to be less in earnest



<P>in it than they appear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, my dear Miss Price, and for reasons good.&nbsp; The profession,



<P>either navy or army, is its own justification.&nbsp; It has



<P>everything in its favour:&nbsp; heroism, danger, bustle, fashion.



<P>Soldiers and sailors are always acceptable in society.



<P>Nobody can wonder that men are soldiers and sailors."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But the motives of a man who takes orders with the certainty



<P>of preferment may be fairly suspected, you think?"



<P>said Edmund.&nbsp; "To be justified in your eyes, he must



<P>do it in the most complete uncertainty of any provision."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What! take orders without a living!&nbsp; No; that is



<P>madness indeed; absolute madness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Shall I ask you how the church is to be filled, if a man



<P>is neither to take orders with a living nor without?



<P>No; for you certainly would not know what to say.



<P>But I must beg some advantage to the clergyman from



<P>your own argument.&nbsp; As he cannot be influenced by those



<P>feelings which you rank highly as temptation and reward



<P>to the soldier and sailor in their choice of a profession,



<P>as heroism, and noise, and fashion, are all against him,



<P>he ought to be less liable to the suspicion of wanting



<P>sincerity or good intentions in the choice of his."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! no doubt he is very sincere in preferring an income



<P>ready made, to the trouble of working for one; and has



<P>the best intentions of doing nothing all the rest of his



<P>days but eat, drink, and grow fat.&nbsp; It is indolence,



<P>Mr. Bertram, indeed.&nbsp; Indolence and love of ease; a want



<P>of all laudable ambition, of taste for good company,



<P>or of inclination to take the trouble of being agreeable,



<P>which make men clergymen.&nbsp; A clergyman has nothing



<P>to do but be slovenly and selfish--read the newspaper,



<P>watch the weather, and quarrel with his wife.&nbsp; His curate



<P>does all the work, and the business of his own life is



<P>to dine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There are such clergymen, no doubt, but I think they



<P>are not so common as to justify Miss Crawford in esteeming



<P>it their general character.&nbsp; I suspect that in this



<P>comprehensive and (may I say) commonplace censure, you are



<P>not judging from yourself, but from prejudiced persons,



<P>whose opinions you have been in the habit of hearing.



<P>It is impossible that your own observation can have given



<P>you much knowledge of the clergy.&nbsp; You can have been



<P>personally acquainted with very few of a set of men you



<P>condemn so conclusively.&nbsp; You are speaking what you have



<P>been told at your uncle's table."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I speak what appears to me the general opinion;



<P>and where an opinion is general, it is usually correct.



<P>Though _I_ have not seen much of the domestic lives



<P>of clergymen, it is seen by too many to leave any deficiency



<P>of information."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Where any one body of educated men, of whatever denomination,



<P>are condemned indiscriminately, there must be a deficiency



<P>of information, or (smiling) of something else.



<P>Your uncle, and his brother admirals, perhaps knew little



<P>of clergymen beyond the chaplains whom, good or bad,



<P>they were always wishing away."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor William!&nbsp; He has met with great kindness from



<P>the chaplain of the Antwerp," was a tender apostrophe



<P>of Fanny's, very much to the purpose of her own feelings



<P>if not of the conversation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have been so little addicted to take my opinions from



<P>my uncle," said Miss Crawford, "that I can hardly suppose--



<P>and since you push me so hard, I must observe, that I am



<P>not entirely without the means of seeing what clergymen are,



<P>being at this present time the guest of my own brother,



<P>Dr. Grant.&nbsp; And though Dr. Grant is most kind and obliging



<P>to me, and though he is really a gentleman, and, I dare say,



<P>a good scholar and clever, and often preaches good sermons,



<P>and is very respectable, _I_ see him to be an indolent,



<P>selfish _bon_ _vivant_, who must have his palate consulted



<P>in everything; who will not stir a finger for the convenience



<P>of any one; and who, moreover, if the cook makes a blunder,



<P>is out of humour with his excellent wife.&nbsp; To own the truth,



<P>Henry and I were partly driven out this very evening



<P>by a disappointment about a green goose, which he could



<P>not get the better of.&nbsp; My poor sister was forced to stay



<P>and bear it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not wonder at your disapprobation, upon my word.



<P>It is a great defect of temper, made worse by a very faulty



<P>habit of self-indulgence; and to see your sister suffering



<P>from it must be exceedingly painful to such feelings



<P>as yours.&nbsp; Fanny, it goes against us.&nbsp; We cannot attempt



<P>to defend Dr. Grant."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No," replied Fanny, "but we need not give up his profession



<P>for all that; because, whatever profession Dr. Grant



<P>had chosen, he would have taken a--not a good temper into it;



<P>and as he must, either in the navy or army, have had a



<P>great many more people under his command than he has now,



<P>I think more would have been made unhappy by him as a



<P>sailor or soldier than as a clergyman.&nbsp; Besides, I cannot



<P>but suppose that whatever there may be to wish otherwise



<P>in Dr. Grant would have been in a greater danger of



<P>becoming worse in a more active and worldly profession,



<P>where he would have had less time and obligation--



<P>where he might have escaped that knowledge of himself,



<P>the _frequency_, at least, of that knowledge which it



<P>is impossible he should escape as he is now.&nbsp; A man--



<P>a sensible man like Dr. Grant, cannot be in the habit



<P>of teaching others their duty every week, cannot go



<P>to church twice every Sunday, and preach such very good



<P>sermons in so good a manner as he does, without being



<P>the better for it himself.&nbsp; It must make him think;



<P>and I have no doubt that he oftener endeavours to restrain



<P>himself than he would if he had been anything but a clergyman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We cannot prove to the contrary, to be sure; but I wish



<P>you a better fate, Miss Price, than to be the wife of a man



<P>whose amiableness depends upon his own sermons; for though



<P>he may preach himself into a good-humour every Sunday,



<P>it will be bad enough to have him quarrelling about green



<P>geese from Monday morning till Saturday night."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think the man who could often quarrel with Fanny,"



<P>said Edmund affectionately, "must be beyond the reach



<P>of any sermons."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny turned farther into the window; and Miss



<P>Crawford had only time to say, in a pleasant manner,



<P>"I fancy Miss Price has been more used to deserve



<P>praise than to hear it"; when, being earnestly invited



<P>by the Miss Bertrams to join in a glee, she tripped off



<P>to the instrument, leaving Edmund looking after her



<P>in an ecstasy of admiration of all her many virtues,



<P>from her obliging manners down to her light and graceful tread.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There goes good-humour, I am sure," said he presently.



<P>"There goes a temper which would never give pain!



<P>How well she walks! and how readily she falls in with the



<P>inclination of others! joining them the moment she is asked.



<P>What a pity," he added, after an instant's reflection,



<P>"that she should have been in such hands!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny agreed to it, and had the pleasure of seeing him continue



<P>at the window with her, in spite of the expected glee;



<P>and of having his eyes soon turned, like hers, towards the



<P>scene without, where all that was solemn, and soothing,



<P>and lovely, appeared in the brilliancy of an unclouded night,



<P>and the contrast of the deep shade of the woods.&nbsp; Fanny spoke



<P>her feelings.&nbsp; "Here's harmony!" said she; "here's repose!



<P>Here's what may leave all painting and all music behind,



<P>and what poetry only can attempt to describe!&nbsp; Here's what



<P>may tranquillise every care, and lift the heart to rapture!



<P>When I look out on such a night as this, I feel as if there



<P>could be neither wickedness nor sorrow in the world;



<P>and there certainly would be less of both if the sublimity



<P>of Nature were more attended to, and people were carried



<P>more out of themselves by contemplating such a scene."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like to hear your enthusiasm, Fanny.&nbsp; It is a lovely night,



<P>and they are much to be pitied who have not been taught



<P>to feel, in some degree, as you do; who have not,



<P>at least, been given a taste for Nature in early life.



<P>They lose a great deal."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_You_ taught me to think and feel on the subject, cousin."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had a very apt scholar.&nbsp; There's Arcturus looking



<P>very bright."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, and the Bear.&nbsp; I wish I could see Cassiopeia."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We must go out on the lawn for that.&nbsp; Should you be afraid?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not in the least.&nbsp; It is a great while since we have



<P>had any star-gazing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; I do not know how it has happened."&nbsp; The glee began.



<P>"We will stay till this is finished, Fanny," said he,



<P>turning his back on the window; and as it advanced,



<P>she had the mortification of seeing him advance too,



<P>moving forward by gentle degrees towards the instrument,



<P>and when it ceased, he was close by the singers, among the most



<P>urgent in requesting to hear the glee again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny sighed alone at the window till scolded away



<P>by Mrs. Norris's threats of catching cold.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 05</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER V</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The young people were pleased with each other from



<P>the first.&nbsp; On each side there was much to attract,



<P>and their acquaintance soon promised as early an intimacy



<P>as good manners would warrant.&nbsp; Miss Crawford's



<P>beauty did her no disservice with the Miss Bertrams.



<P>They were too handsome themselves to dislike any woman



<P>for being so too, and were almost as much charmed as their



<P>brothers with her lively dark eye, clear brown complexion,



<P>and general prettiness.&nbsp; Had she been tall, full formed,



<P>and fair, it might have been more of a trial:&nbsp; but as it was,



<P>there could be no comparison; and she was most allowably



<P>a sweet, pretty girl, while they were the finest young



<P>women in the country.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her brother was not handsome:&nbsp; no, when they first saw him



<P>he was absolutely plain, black and plain; but still he



<P>was the gentleman, with a pleasing address.&nbsp; The second



<P>meeting proved him not so very plain:&nbsp; he was plain,



<P>to be sure, but then he had so much countenance, and his



<P>teeth were so good, and he was so well made, that one



<P>soon forgot he was plain; and after a third interview,



<P>after dining in company with him at the Parsonage,



<P>he was no longer allowed to be called so by anybody.



<P>He was, in fact, the most agreeable young man the sisters



<P>had ever known, and they were equally delighted with him.



<P>Miss Bertram's engagement made him in equity the property



<P>of Julia, of which Julia was fully aware; and before he had



<P>been at Mansfield a week, she was quite ready to be fallen



<P>in love with.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Maria's notions on the subject were more confused



<P>and indistinct.&nbsp; She did not want to see or understand.



<P>"There could be no harm in her liking an agreeable man--



<P>everybody knew her situation--Mr. Crawford must take care



<P>of himself."&nbsp; Mr. Crawford did not mean to be in any danger!



<P>the Miss Bertrams were worth pleasing, and were ready



<P>to be pleased; and he began with no object but of making



<P>them like him.&nbsp; He did not want them to die of love;



<P>but with sense and temper which ought to have made him



<P>judge and feel better, he allowed himself great latitude



<P>on such points.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I like your Miss Bertrams exceedingly, sister," said he,



<P>as he returned from attending them to their carriage



<P>after the said dinner visit; "they are very elegant,



<P>agreeable girls."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So they are indeed, and I am delighted to hear you say it.



<P>But you like Julia best."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes!&nbsp; I like Julia best."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But do you really? for Miss Bertram is in general thought



<P>the handsomest."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So I should suppose.&nbsp; She has the advantage in every feature,



<P>and I prefer her countenance; but I like Julia best;



<P>Miss Bertram is certainly the handsomest, and I have found



<P>her the most agreeable, but I shall always like Julia best,



<P>because you order me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall not talk to you, Henry, but I know you _will_



<P>like her best at last."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do not I tell you that I like her best _at_ _first_?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And besides, Miss Bertram is engaged.&nbsp; Remember that,



<P>my dear brother.&nbsp; Her choice is made."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, and I like her the better for it.&nbsp; An engaged



<P>woman is always more agreeable than a disengaged.



<P>She is satisfied with herself.&nbsp; Her cares are over,



<P>and she feels that she may exert all her powers of pleasing



<P>without suspicion.&nbsp; All is safe with a lady engaged:



<P>no harm can be done."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, as to that, Mr. Rushworth is a very good sort



<P>of young man, and it is a great match for her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But Miss Bertram does not care three straws for him;



<P>_that_ is your opinion of your intimate friend.&nbsp; _I_ do



<P>not subscribe to it.&nbsp; I am sure Miss Bertram is very much



<P>attached to Mr. Rushworth.&nbsp; I could see it in her eyes,



<P>when he was mentioned.&nbsp; I think too well of Miss Bertram



<P>to suppose she would ever give her hand without her heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mary, how shall we manage him?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We must leave him to himself, I believe.&nbsp; Talking does



<P>no good.&nbsp; He will be taken in at last."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I would not have him _taken_ _in_; I would not have



<P>him duped; I would have it all fair and honourable."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh dear! let him stand his chance and be taken in.



<P>It will do just as well.&nbsp; Everybody is taken in at some



<P>period or other."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not always in marriage, dear Mary."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"In marriage especially.&nbsp; With all due respect to such



<P>of the present company as chance to be married, my dear



<P>Mrs. Grant, there is not one in a hundred of either sex



<P>who is not taken in when they marry.&nbsp; Look where I will,



<P>I see that it _is_ so; and I feel that it _must_ be so,



<P>when I consider that it is, of all transactions, the one



<P>in which people expect most from others, and are least



<P>honest themselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!&nbsp; You have been in a bad school for matrimony,



<P>in Hill Street."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My poor aunt had certainly little cause to love



<P>the state; but, however, speaking from my own observation,



<P>it is a manoeuvring business.&nbsp; I know so many who



<P>have married in the full expectation and confidence



<P>of some one particular advantage in the connexion,



<P>or accomplishment, or good quality in the person, who have



<P>found themselves entirely deceived, and been obliged



<P>to put up with exactly the reverse.&nbsp; What is this but a take in?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear child, there must be a little imagination here.



<P>I beg your pardon, but I cannot quite believe you.



<P>Depend upon it, you see but half.&nbsp; You see the evil,



<P>but you do not see the consolation.&nbsp; There will be



<P>little rubs and disappointments everywhere, and we



<P>are all apt to expect too much; but then, if one scheme



<P>of happiness fails, human nature turns to another;



<P>if the first calculation is wrong, we make a second better:



<P>we find comfort somewhere--and those evil-minded observers,



<P>dearest Mary, who make much of a little, are more taken



<P>in and deceived than the parties themselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well done, sister!&nbsp; I honour your _esprit_ _du_ _corps_.



<P>When I am a wife, I mean to be just as staunch myself;



<P>and I wish my friends in general would be so too.&nbsp; It would



<P>save me many a heartache."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are as bad as your brother, Mary; but we will cure



<P>you both.&nbsp; Mansfield shall cure you both, and without



<P>any taking in.&nbsp; Stay with us, and we will cure you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Crawfords, without wanting to be cured, were very



<P>willing to stay.&nbsp; Mary was satisfied with the Parsonage



<P>as a present home, and Henry equally ready to lengthen



<P>his visit.&nbsp; He had come, intending to spend only a few



<P>days with them; but Mansfield promised well, and there



<P>was nothing to call him elsewhere.&nbsp; It delighted Mrs. Grant



<P>to keep them both with her, and Dr. Grant was exceedingly



<P>well contented to have it so:&nbsp; a talking pretty young



<P>woman like Miss Crawford is always pleasant society



<P>to an indolent, stay-at-home man; and Mr. Crawford's



<P>being his guest was an excuse for drinking claret every day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Miss Bertrams' admiration of Mr. Crawford was more



<P>rapturous than anything which Miss Crawford's habits made



<P>her likely to feel.&nbsp; She acknowledged, however, that the



<P>Mr. Bertrams were very fine young men, that two such



<P>young men were not often seen together even in London,



<P>and that their manners, particularly those of the eldest,



<P>were very good.&nbsp; _He_ had been much in London,



<P>and had more liveliness and gallantry than Edmund,



<P>and must, therefore, be preferred; and, indeed, his being



<P>the eldest was another strong claim.&nbsp; She had felt an early



<P>presentiment that she _should_ like the eldest best.



<P>She knew it was her way.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tom Bertram must have been thought pleasant, indeed, at any rate;



<P>he was the sort of young man to be generally liked,



<P>his agreeableness was of the kind to be oftener found



<P>agreeable than some endowments of a higher stamp, for he



<P>had easy manners, excellent spirits, a large acquaintance,



<P>and a great deal to say; and the reversion of Mansfield Park,



<P>and a baronetcy, did no harm to all this.&nbsp; Miss Crawford



<P>soon felt that he and his situation might do.&nbsp; She looked



<P>about her with due consideration, and found almost everything



<P>in his favour:&nbsp; a park, a real park, five miles round,



<P>a spacious modern-built house, so well placed and well



<P>screened as to deserve to be in any collection of engravings



<P>of gentlemen's seats in the kingdom, and wanting only to be



<P>completely new furnished--pleasant sisters, a quiet mother,



<P>and an agreeable man himself--with the advantage of



<P>being tied up from much gaming at present by a promise



<P>to his father, and of being Sir Thomas hereafter.



<P>It might do very well; she believed she should accept him;



<P>and she began accordingly to interest herself a little



<P>about the horse which he had to run at the B------- races.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These races were to call him away not long after their



<P>acquaintance began; and as it appeared that the family



<P>did not, from his usual goings on, expect him back



<P>again for many weeks, it would bring his passion to an



<P>early proof.&nbsp; Much was said on his side to induce her



<P>to attend the races, and schemes were made for a large



<P>party to them, with all the eagerness of inclination,



<P>but it would only do to be talked of.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And Fanny, what was _she_ doing and thinking all this



<P>while? and what was _her_ opinion of the newcomers?



<P>Few young ladies of eighteen could be less called on



<P>to speak their opinion than Fanny.&nbsp; In a quiet way,



<P>very little attended to, she paid her tribute of admiration



<P>to Miss Crawford's beauty; but as she still continued



<P>to think Mr. Crawford very plain, in spite of her two



<P>cousins having repeatedly proved the contrary, she never



<P>mentioned _him_.&nbsp; The notice, which she excited herself,



<P>was to this effect.&nbsp; "I begin now to understand you all,



<P>except Miss Price," said Miss Crawford, as she was



<P>walking with the Mr. Bertrams.&nbsp; "Pray, is she out,



<P>or is she not?&nbsp; I am puzzled.&nbsp; She dined at the Parsonage,



<P>with the rest of you, which seemed like being _out_;



<P>and yet she says so little, that I can hardly suppose



<P>she _is_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund, to whom this was chiefly addressed, replied, "I believe



<P>I know what you mean, but I will not undertake to answer



<P>the question.&nbsp; My cousin is grown up.&nbsp; She has the age



<P>and sense of a woman, but the outs and not outs are beyond me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And yet, in general, nothing can be more easily ascertained.



<P>The distinction is so broad.&nbsp; Manners as well as



<P>appearance are, generally speaking, so totally different.



<P>Till now, I could not have supposed it possible to be



<P>mistaken as to a girl's being out or not.&nbsp; A girl not



<P>out has always the same sort of dress:&nbsp; a close bonnet,



<P>for instance; looks very demure, and never says a word.



<P>You may smile, but it is so, I assure you; and except



<P>that it is sometimes carried a little too far, it is



<P>all very proper.&nbsp; Girls should be quiet and modest.



<P>The most objectionable part is, that the alteration



<P>of manners on being introduced into company is frequently



<P>too sudden.&nbsp; They sometimes pass in such very little



<P>time from reserve to quite the opposite--to confidence!



<P>_That_ is the faulty part of the present system.



<P>One does not like to see a girl of eighteen or nineteen



<P>so immediately up to every thing--and perhaps when one



<P>has seen her hardly able to speak the year before.



<P>Mr. Bertram, I dare say _you_ have sometimes met with



<P>such changes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I believe I have, but this is hardly fair; I see what you



<P>are at.&nbsp; You are quizzing me and Miss Anderson."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed.&nbsp; Miss Anderson!&nbsp; I do not know who or what



<P>you mean.&nbsp; I am quite in the dark.&nbsp; But I _will_ quiz you



<P>with a great deal of pleasure, if you will tell me what about."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah! you carry it off very well, but I cannot be quite



<P>so far imposed on.&nbsp; You must have had Miss Anderson



<P>in your eye, in describing an altered young lady.



<P>You paint too accurately for mistake.&nbsp; It was exactly so.



<P>The Andersons of Baker Street.&nbsp; We were speaking of them



<P>the other day, you know.&nbsp; Edmund, you have heard me mention



<P>Charles Anderson.&nbsp; The circumstance was precisely as this



<P>lady has represented it.&nbsp; When Anderson first introduced



<P>me to his family, about two years ago, his sister was



<P>not _out_, and I could not get her to speak to me.



<P>I sat there an hour one morning waiting for Anderson,



<P>with only her and a little girl or two in the room,



<P>the governess being sick or run away, and the mother



<P>in and out every moment with letters of business, and I



<P>could hardly get a word or a look from the young lady--



<P>nothing like a civil answer--she screwed up her mouth,



<P>and turned from me with such an air!&nbsp; I did not see



<P>her again for a twelvemonth.&nbsp; She was then _out_.



<P>I met her at Mrs. Holford's, and did not recollect her.



<P>She came up to me, claimed me as an acquaintance, stared me



<P>out of countenance; and talked and laughed till I did not



<P>know which way to look.&nbsp; I felt that I must be the jest



<P>of the room at the time, and Miss Crawford, it is plain,



<P>has heard the story."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And a very pretty story it is, and with more truth



<P>in it, I dare say, than does credit to Miss Anderson.



<P>It is too common a fault.&nbsp; Mothers certainly have not yet



<P>got quite the right way of managing their daughters.



<P>I do not know where the error lies.&nbsp; I do not pretend to set



<P>people right, but I do see that they are often wrong."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Those who are showing the world what female manners



<P>_should_ be," said Mr. Bertram gallantly, "are doing



<P>a great deal to set them right."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The error is plain enough," said the less courteous Edmund;



<P>"such girls are ill brought up.&nbsp; They are given wrong notions



<P>from the beginning.&nbsp; They are always acting upon motives



<P>of vanity, and there is no more real modesty in their



<P>behaviour _before_ they appear in public than afterwards."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know," replied Miss Crawford hesitatingly.



<P>"Yes, I cannot agree with you there.&nbsp; It is certainly



<P>the modestest part of the business.&nbsp; It is much worse to



<P>have girls not out give themselves the same airs and take



<P>the same liberties as if they were, which I have seen done.



<P>That is worse than anything--quite disgusting!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, _that_ is very inconvenient indeed," said Mr. Bertram.



<P>"It leads one astray; one does not know what to do.



<P>The close bonnet and demure air you describe so well (and



<P>nothing was ever juster), tell one what is expected;



<P>but I got into a dreadful scrape last year from the want



<P>of them.&nbsp; I went down to Ramsgate for a week with a friend



<P>last September, just after my return from the West Indies.



<P>My friend Sneyd--you have heard me speak of Sneyd, Edmund--



<P>his father, and mother, and sisters, were there, all new



<P>to me.&nbsp; When we reached Albion Place they were out;



<P>we went after them, and found them on the pier:&nbsp; Mrs. and



<P>the two Miss Sneyds, with others of their acquaintance.



<P>I made my bow in form; and as Mrs. Sneyd was surrounded



<P>by men, attached myself to one of her daughters,



<P>walked by her side all the way home, and made myself



<P>as agreeable as I could; the young lady perfectly easy



<P>in her manners, and as ready to talk as to listen.



<P>I had not a suspicion that I could be doing anything wrong.



<P>They looked just the same:&nbsp; both well-dressed, with veils



<P>and parasols like other girls; but I afterwards found



<P>that I had been giving all my attention to the youngest,



<P>who was not _out_, and had most excessively offended



<P>the eldest.&nbsp; Miss Augusta ought not to have been noticed



<P>for the next six months; and Miss Sneyd, I believe, has never



<P>forgiven me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That was bad indeed.&nbsp; Poor Miss Sneyd.&nbsp; "Though I have no



<P>younger sister, I feel for her.&nbsp; To be neglected before



<P>one's time must be very vexatious; but it was entirely



<P>the mother's fault.&nbsp; Miss Augusta should have been with



<P>her governess.&nbsp; Such half-and-half doings never prosper.



<P>But now I must be satisfied about Miss Price.



<P>Does she go to balls?&nbsp; Does she dine out every where,



<P>as well as at my sister's?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No," replied Edmund; "I do not think she has ever been



<P>to a ball.&nbsp; My mother seldom goes into company herself,



<P>and dines nowhere but with Mrs. Grant, and Fanny stays at



<P>home with _her_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! then the point is clear.&nbsp; Miss Price is not out."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 39</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXXIX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Could Sir Thomas have seen all his niece's feelings,



<P>when she wrote her first letter to her aunt, he would



<P>not have despaired; for though a good night's rest,



<P>a pleasant morning, the hope of soon seeing William again,



<P>and the comparatively quiet state of the house, from Tom



<P>and Charles being gone to school, Sam on some project of



<P>his own, and her father on his usual lounges, enabled her



<P>to express herself cheerfully on the subject of home,



<P>there were still, to her own perfect consciousness,



<P>many drawbacks suppressed.&nbsp; Could he have seen only half



<P>that she felt before the end of a week, he would have



<P>thought Mr. Crawford sure of her, and been delighted with



<P>his own sagacity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Before the week ended, it was all disappointment.



<P>In the first place, William was gone.&nbsp; The Thrush



<P>had had her orders, the wind had changed, and he was



<P>sailed within four days from their reaching Portsmouth;



<P>and during those days she had seen him only twice,



<P>in a short and hurried way, when he had come ashore



<P>on duty.&nbsp; There had been no free conversation, no walk



<P>on the ramparts, no visit to the dockyard, no acquaintance



<P>with the Thrush, nothing of all that they had planned



<P>and depended on.&nbsp; Everything in that quarter failed her,



<P>except William's affection.&nbsp; His last thought on leaving



<P>home was for her.&nbsp; He stepped back again to the door



<P>to say, "Take care of Fanny, mother.&nbsp; She is tender,



<P>and not used to rough it like the rest of us.&nbsp; I charge you,



<P>take care of Fanny."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>William was gone:&nbsp; and the home he had left her in was,



<P>Fanny could not conceal it from herself, in almost every



<P>respect the very reverse of what she could have wished.



<P>It was the abode of noise, disorder, and impropriety.



<P>Nobody was in their right place, nothing was done as it ought



<P>to be.&nbsp; She could not respect her parents as she had hoped.



<P>On her father, her confidence had not been sanguine, but he



<P>was more negligent of his family, his habits were worse,



<P>and his manners coarser, than she had been prepared for.



<P>He did not want abilities but he had no curiosity,



<P>and no information beyond his profession; he read only



<P>the newspaper and the navy-list; he talked only of



<P>the dockyard, the harbour, Spithead, and the Motherbank;



<P>he swore and he drank, he was dirty and gross.



<P>She had never been able to recall anything approaching



<P>to tenderness in his former treatment of herself.



<P>There had remained only a general impression of roughness



<P>and loudness; and now he scarcely ever noticed her,



<P>but to make her the object of a coarse joke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her disappointment in her mother was greater:



<P>_there_ she had hoped much, and found almost nothing.



<P>Every flattering scheme of being of consequence to her



<P>soon fell to the ground.&nbsp; Mrs. Price was not unkind;



<P>but, instead of gaining on her affection and confidence,



<P>and becoming more and more dear, her daughter never met



<P>with greater kindness from her than on the first day of



<P>her arrival.&nbsp; The instinct of nature was soon satisfied,



<P>and Mrs. Price's attachment had no other source.



<P>Her heart and her time were already quite full;



<P>she had neither leisure nor affection to bestow on Fanny.



<P>Her daughters never had been much to her.&nbsp; She was fond



<P>of her sons, especially of William, but Betsey was the first



<P>of her girls whom she had ever much regarded.&nbsp; To her she



<P>was most injudiciously indulgent.&nbsp; William was her pride;



<P>Betsey her darling; and John, Richard, Sam, Tom, and Charles



<P>occupied all the rest of her maternal solicitude, alternately



<P>her worries and her comforts.&nbsp; These shared her heart:



<P>her time was given chiefly to her house and her servants.



<P>Her days were spent in a kind of slow bustle; all was busy



<P>without getting on, always behindhand and lamenting it,



<P>without altering her ways; wishing to be an economist,



<P>without contrivance or regularity; dissatisfied with



<P>her servants, without skill to make them better,



<P>and whether helping, or reprimanding, or indulging them,



<P>without any power of engaging their respect.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Of her two sisters, Mrs. Price very much more resembled Lady



<P>Bertram than Mrs. Norris.&nbsp; She was a manager by necessity,



<P>without any of Mrs. Norris's inclination for it, or any



<P>of her activity.&nbsp; Her disposition was naturally easy



<P>and indolent, like Lady Bertram's; and a situation of similar



<P>affluence and do-nothingness would have been much more



<P>suited to her capacity than the exertions and self-denials



<P>of the one which her imprudent marriage had placed her in.



<P>She might have made just as good a woman of consequence



<P>as Lady Bertram, but Mrs. Norris would have been a more



<P>respectable mother of nine children on a small income.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Much of all this Fanny could not but be sensible of.



<P>She might scruple to make use of the words, but she



<P>must and did feel that her mother was a partial,



<P>ill-judging parent, a dawdle, a slattern, who neither taught



<P>nor restrained her children, whose house was the scene



<P>of mismanagement and discomfort from beginning to end,



<P>and who had no talent, no conversation, no affection



<P>towards herself; no curiosity to know her better,



<P>no desire of her friendship, and no inclination for her



<P>company that could lessen her sense of such feelings.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was very anxious to be useful, and not to appear above



<P>her home, or in any way disqualified or disinclined, by her



<P>foreign education, from contributing her help to its comforts,



<P>and therefore set about working for Sam immediately;



<P>and by working early and late, with perseverance and



<P>great despatch, did so much that the boy was shipped



<P>off at last, with more than half his linen ready.



<P>She had great pleasure in feeling her usefulness, but could



<P>not conceive how they would have managed without her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sam, loud and overbearing as he was, she rather regretted



<P>when he went, for he was clever and intelligent, and glad



<P>to be employed in any errand in the town; and though



<P>spurning the remonstrances of Susan, given as they were,



<P>though very reasonable in themselves, with ill-timed



<P>and powerless warmth, was beginning to be influenced



<P>by Fanny's services and gentle persuasions; and she found



<P>that the best of the three younger ones was gone in him:



<P>Tom and Charles being at least as many years as they were



<P>his juniors distant from that age of feeling and reason,



<P>which might suggest the expediency of making friends,



<P>and of endeavouring to be less disagreeable.&nbsp; Their sister



<P>soon despaired of making the smallest impression on _them_;



<P>they were quite untameable by any means of address which she



<P>had spirits or time to attempt.&nbsp; Every afternoon brought



<P>a return of their riotous games all over the house; and she



<P>very early learned to sigh at the approach of Saturday's



<P>constant half-holiday.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Betsey, too, a spoiled child, trained up to think the



<P>alphabet her greatest enemy, left to be with the servants



<P>at her pleasure, and then encouraged to report any evil



<P>of them, she was almost as ready to despair of being



<P>able to love or assist; and of Susan's temper she had



<P>many doubts.&nbsp; Her continual disagreements with her mother,



<P>her rash squabbles with Tom and Charles, and petulance



<P>with Betsey, were at least so distressing to Fanny that,



<P>though admitting they were by no means without provocation,



<P>she feared the disposition that could push them to such



<P>length must be far from amiable, and from affording



<P>any repose to herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such was the home which was to put Mansfield out of



<P>her head, and teach her to think of her cousin Edmund with



<P>moderated feelings.&nbsp; On the contrary, she could think of



<P>nothing but Mansfield, its beloved inmates, its happy ways.



<P>Everything where she now was in full contrast to it.



<P>The elegance, propriety, regularity, harmony, and perhaps,



<P>above all, the peace and tranquillity of Mansfield,



<P>were brought to her remembrance every hour of the day,



<P>by the prevalence of everything opposite to them _here_.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The living in incessant noise was, to a frame and temper



<P>delicate and nervous like Fanny's, an evil which no



<P>superadded elegance or harmony could have entirely



<P>atoned for.&nbsp; It was the greatest misery of all.



<P>At Mansfield, no sounds of contention, no raised voice,



<P>no abrupt bursts, no tread of violence, was ever heard;



<P>all proceeded in a regular course of cheerful orderliness;



<P>everybody had their due importance; everybody's feelings



<P>were consulted.&nbsp; If tenderness could be ever supposed wanting,



<P>good sense and good breeding supplied its place; and as to



<P>the little irritations sometimes introduced by aunt Norris,



<P>they were short, they were trifling, they were as a drop



<P>of water to the ocean, compared with the ceaseless



<P>tumult of her present abode.&nbsp; Here everybody was noisy,



<P>every voice was loud (excepting, perhaps, her mother's,



<P>which resembled the soft monotony of Lady Bertram's,



<P>only worn into fretfulness). Whatever was wanted was



<P>hallooed for, and the servants hallooed out their excuses



<P>from the kitchen.&nbsp; The doors were in constant banging,



<P>the stairs were never at rest, nothing was done without



<P>a clatter, nobody sat still, and nobody could command



<P>attention when they spoke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In a review of the two houses, as they appeared to her



<P>before the end of a week, Fanny was tempted to apply



<P>to them Dr. Johnson's celebrated judgment as to matrimony



<P>and celibacy, and say, that though Mansfield Park might



<P>have some pains, Portsmouth could have no pleasures.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 13</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The Honourable John Yates, this new friend, had not much



<P>to recommend him beyond habits of fashion and expense,



<P>and being the younger son of a lord with a tolerable



<P>independence; and Sir Thomas would probably have thought



<P>his introduction at Mansfield by no means desirable.



<P>Mr. Bertram's acquaintance with him had begun at Weymouth,



<P>where they had spent ten days together in the same society,



<P>and the friendship, if friendship it might be called,



<P>had been proved and perfected by Mr. Yates's being invited



<P>to take Mansfield in his way, whenever he could, and by his



<P>promising to come; and he did come rather earlier than had



<P>been expected, in consequence of the sudden breaking-up



<P>of a large party assembled for gaiety at the house



<P>of another friend, which he had left Weymouth to join.



<P>He came on the wings of disappointment, and with his head



<P>full of acting, for it had been a theatrical party;



<P>and the play in which he had borne a part was within



<P>two days of representation, when the sudden death



<P>of one of the nearest connexions of the family had



<P>destroyed the scheme and dispersed the performers.



<P>To be so near happiness, so near fame, so near the long



<P>paragraph in praise of the private theatricals at Ecclesford,



<P>the seat of the Right Hon. Lord Ravenshaw, in Cornwall,



<P>which would of course have immortalised the whole party



<P>for at least a twelvemonth! and being so near, to lose



<P>it all, was an injury to be keenly felt, and Mr. Yates



<P>could talk of nothing else.&nbsp; Ecclesford and its theatre,



<P>with its arrangements and dresses, rehearsals and jokes,



<P>was his never-failing subject, and to boast of the past his



<P>only consolation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Happily for him, a love of the theatre is so general,



<P>an itch for acting so strong among young people, that he



<P>could hardly out-talk the interest of his hearers.



<P>From the first casting of the parts to the epilogue



<P>it was all bewitching, and there were few who did



<P>not wish to have been a party concerned, or would have



<P>hesitated to try their skill.&nbsp; The play had been Lovers'



<P>Vows, and Mr. Yates was to have been Count Cassel.



<P>"A trifling part," said he, "and not at all to my taste,



<P>and such a one as I certainly would not accept again;



<P>but I was determined to make no difficulties.



<P>Lord Ravenshaw and the duke had appropriated the only two



<P>characters worth playing before I reached Ecclesford;



<P>and though Lord Ravenshaw offered to resign his to me,



<P>it was impossible to take it, you know.&nbsp; I was sorry



<P>for _him_ that he should have so mistaken his powers,



<P>for he was no more equal to the Baron--a little man



<P>with a weak voice, always hoarse after the first



<P>ten minutes.&nbsp; It must have injured the piece materially;



<P>but _I_ was resolved to make no difficulties.



<P>Sir Henry thought the duke not equal to Frederick,



<P>but that was because Sir Henry wanted the part himself;



<P>whereas it was certainly in the best hands of the two.



<P>I was surprised to see Sir Henry such a stick.



<P>Luckily the strength of the piece did not depend upon him.



<P>Our Agatha was inimitable, and the duke was thought very great



<P>by many.&nbsp; And upon the whole, it would certainly have gone



<P>off wonderfully."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was a hard case, upon my word"; and, "I do think you



<P>were very much to be pitied," were the kind responses



<P>of listening sympathy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is not worth complaining about; but to be sure the



<P>poor old dowager could not have died at a worse time;



<P>and it is impossible to help wishing that the news could



<P>have been suppressed for just the three days we wanted.



<P>It was but three days; and being only a grandmother,



<P>and all happening two hundred miles off, I think there would



<P>have been no great harm, and it was suggested, I know;



<P>but Lord Ravenshaw, who I suppose is one of the most correct



<P>men in England, would not hear of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"An afterpiece instead of a comedy," said Mr. Bertram.



<P>"Lovers' Vows were at an end, and Lord and Lady Ravenshaw



<P>left to act My Grandmother by themselves.&nbsp; Well, the jointure



<P>may comfort _him_; and perhaps, between friends, he began



<P>to tremble for his credit and his lungs in the Baron,



<P>and was not sorry to withdraw; and to make _you_ amends,



<P>Yates, I think we must raise a little theatre at Mansfield,



<P>and ask you to be our manager."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This, though the thought of the moment, did not end



<P>with the moment; for the inclination to act was awakened,



<P>and in no one more strongly than in him who was now



<P>master of the house; and who, having so much leisure



<P>as to make almost any novelty a certain good, had likewise



<P>such a degree of lively talents and comic taste,



<P>as were exactly adapted to the novelty of acting.



<P>The thought returned again and again.&nbsp; "Oh for the



<P>Ecclesford theatre and scenery to try something with."



<P>Each sister could echo the wish; and Henry Crawford,



<P>to whom, in all the riot of his gratifications it was



<P>yet an untasted pleasure, was quite alive at the idea.



<P>"I really believe," said he, "I could be fool enough



<P>at this moment to undertake any character that ever



<P>was written, from Shylock or Richard III down to the singing



<P>hero of a farce in his scarlet coat and cocked hat.



<P>I feel as if I could be anything or everything;



<P>as if I could rant and storm, or sigh or cut capers,



<P>in any tragedy or comedy in the English language.&nbsp; Let us



<P>be doing something.&nbsp; Be it only half a play, an act, a scene;



<P>what should prevent us?&nbsp; Not these countenances, I am sure,"



<P>looking towards the Miss Bertrams; "and for a theatre,



<P>what signifies a theatre?&nbsp; We shall be only amusing ourselves.



<P>Any room in this house might suffice."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We must have a curtain," said Tom Bertram; "a few yards



<P>of green baize for a curtain, and perhaps that may be enough."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, quite enough," cried Mr. Yates, "with only just a side wing



<P>or two run up, doors in flat, and three or four scenes to be



<P>let down; nothing more would be necessary on such a plan as this.



<P>For mere amusement among ourselves we should want nothing more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I believe we must be satisfied with _less_," said Maria.



<P>"There would not be time, and other difficulties



<P>would arise.&nbsp; We must rather adopt Mr. Crawford's views,



<P>and make the _performance_, not the_theatre_, our object.



<P>Many parts of our best plays are independent of scenery."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nay," said Edmund, who began to listen with alarm.



<P>"Let us do nothing by halves.&nbsp; If we are to act, let it be in



<P>a theatre completely fitted up with pit, boxes, and gallery,



<P>and let us have a play entire from beginning to end; so as it



<P>be a German play, no matter what, with a good tricking,



<P>shifting afterpiece, and a figure-dance, and a hornpipe,



<P>and a song between the acts.&nbsp; If we do not outdo Ecclesford,



<P>we do nothing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now, Edmund, do not be disagreeable," said Julia.



<P>"Nobody loves a play better than you do, or can have gone



<P>much farther to see one."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"True, to see real acting, good hardened real acting;



<P>but I would hardly walk from this room to the next to



<P>look at the raw efforts of those who have not been



<P>bred to the trade:&nbsp; a set of gentlemen and ladies,



<P>who have all the disadvantages of education and decorum



<P>to struggle through."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After a short pause, however, the subject still continued,



<P>and was discussed with unabated eagerness, every one's



<P>inclination increasing by the discussion, and a knowledge



<P>of the inclination of the rest; and though nothing was settled



<P>but that Tom Bertram would prefer a comedy, and his sisters



<P>and Henry Crawford a tragedy, and that nothing in the world



<P>could be easier than to find a piece which would please



<P>them all, the resolution to act something or other seemed



<P>so decided as to make Edmund quite uncomfortable.&nbsp; He was



<P>determined to prevent it, if possible, though his mother,



<P>who equally heard the conversation which passed at table,



<P>did not evince the least disapprobation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The same evening afforded him an opportunity of trying



<P>his strength.&nbsp; Maria, Julia, Henry Crawford, and Mr. Yates



<P>were in the billiard-room. Tom, returning from them into



<P>the drawing-room, where Edmund was standing thoughtfully



<P>by the fire, while Lady Bertram was on the sofa at a



<P>little distance, and Fanny close beside her arranging



<P>her work, thus began as he entered--"Such a horribly vile



<P>billiard-table as ours is not to be met with, I believe,



<P>above ground.&nbsp; I can stand it no longer, and I think,



<P>I may say, that nothing shall ever tempt me to it again;



<P>but one good thing I have just ascertained:&nbsp; it is the very



<P>room for a theatre, precisely the shape and length for it;



<P>and the doors at the farther end, communicating with each other,



<P>as they may be made to do in five minutes, by merely moving



<P>the bookcase in my father's room, is the very thing we



<P>could have desired, if we had sat down to wish for it;



<P>and my father's room will be an excellent greenroom.



<P>It seems to join the billiard-room on purpose."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are not serious, Tom, in meaning to act?" said Edmund,



<P>in a low voice, as his brother approached the fire.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not serious! never more so, I assure you.&nbsp; What is there



<P>to surprise you in it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think it would be very wrong.&nbsp; In a _general_ light,



<P>private theatricals are open to some objections, but as _we_



<P>are circumstanced, I must think it would be highly injudicious,



<P>and more than injudicious to attempt anything of the kind.



<P>It would shew great want of feeling on my father's account,



<P>absent as he is, and in some degree of constant danger;



<P>and it would be imprudent, I think, with regard to Maria,



<P>whose situation is a very delicate one, considering everything,



<P>extremely delicate."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You take up a thing so seriously! as if we were going
