<P>to act three times a week till my father's return,



<P>and invite all the country.&nbsp; But it is not to be a



<P>display of that sort.&nbsp; We mean nothing but a little



<P>amusement among ourselves, just to vary the scene,



<P>and exercise our powers in something new.&nbsp; We want



<P>no audience, no publicity.&nbsp; We may be trusted, I think,



<P>in chusing some play most perfectly unexceptionable;



<P>and I can conceive no greater harm or danger to any of us



<P>in conversing in the elegant written language of some



<P>respectable author than in chattering in words of our own.



<P>I have no fears and no scruples.&nbsp; And as to my father's



<P>being absent, it is so far from an objection, that I



<P>consider it rather as a motive; for the expectation



<P>of his return must be a very anxious period to my mother;



<P>and if we can be the means of amusing that anxiety,



<P>and keeping up her spirits for the next few weeks, I shall



<P>think our time very well spent, and so, I am sure, will he.



<P>It is a _very_ anxious period for her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As he said this, each looked towards their mother.



<P>Lady Bertram, sunk back in one corner of the sofa,



<P>the picture of health, wealth, ease, and tranquillity,



<P>was just falling into a gentle doze, while Fanny was getting



<P>through the few difficulties of her work for her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund smiled and shook his head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"By Jove! this won't do," cried Tom, throwing himself into



<P>a chair with a hearty laugh.&nbsp; "To be sure, my dear mother,



<P>your anxiety--I was unlucky there."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What is the matter?" asked her ladyship, in the heavy



<P>tone of one half-roused; "I was not asleep."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh dear, no, ma'am, nobody suspected you!&nbsp; Well, Edmund,"



<P>he continued, returning to the former subject, posture,



<P>and voice, as soon as Lady Bertram began to nod again,



<P>"but _this_ I _will_ maintain, that we shall be doing



<P>no harm."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot agree with you; I am convinced that my father



<P>would totally disapprove it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I am convinced to the contrary.&nbsp; Nobody is fonder of



<P>the exercise of talent in young people, or promotes it more,



<P>than my father, and for anything of the acting, spouting,



<P>reciting kind, I think he has always a decided taste.



<P>I am sure he encouraged it in us as boys.&nbsp; How many a time



<P>have we mourned over the dead body of Julius Caesar,



<P>and to _be'd_ and not _to_ _be'd_, in this very room,



<P>for his amusement?&nbsp; And I am sure, _my_ _name_ _was_ _Norval_,



<P>every evening of my life through one Christmas holidays."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was a very different thing.&nbsp; You must see the



<P>difference yourself.&nbsp; My father wished us, as schoolboys,



<P>to speak well, but he would never wish his grown-up



<P>daughters to be acting plays.&nbsp; His sense of decorum is strict."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know all that," said Tom, displeased.&nbsp; "I know my father



<P>as well as you do; and I'll take care that his daughters



<P>do nothing to distress him.&nbsp; Manage your own concerns,



<P>Edmund, and I'll take care of the rest of the family."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you are resolved on acting," replied the persevering Edmund,



<P>"I must hope it will be in a very small and quiet way;



<P>and I think a theatre ought not to be attempted.



<P>It would be taking liberties with my father's house



<P>in his absence which could not be justified."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"For everything of that nature I will be answerable,"



<P>said Tom, in a decided tone.&nbsp; "His house shall not be hurt.



<P>I have quite as great an interest in being careful



<P>of his house as you can have; and as to such alterations



<P>as I was suggesting just now, such as moving a bookcase,



<P>or unlocking a door, or even as using the billiard-room



<P>for the space of a week without playing at billiards in it,



<P>you might just as well suppose he would object to our sitting



<P>more in this room, and less in the breakfast-room, than



<P>we did before he went away, or to my sister's pianoforte



<P>being moved from one side of the room to the other.



<P>Absolute nonsense!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The innovation, if not wrong as an innovation, will be



<P>wrong as an expense."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, the expense of such an undertaking would be prodigious!



<P>Perhaps it might cost a whole twenty pounds.&nbsp; Something of



<P>a theatre we must have undoubtedly, but it will be on the



<P>simplest plan:&nbsp; a green curtain and a little carpenter's work,



<P>and that's all; and as the carpenter's work may be all



<P>done at home by Christopher Jackson himself, it will be



<P>too absurd to talk of expense; and as long as Jackson



<P>is employed, everything will be right with Sir Thomas.



<P>Don't imagine that nobody in this house can see or judge



<P>but yourself.&nbsp; Don't act yourself, if you do not like it,



<P>but don't expect to govern everybody else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, as to acting myself," said Edmund, "_that_ I



<P>absolutely protest against."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tom walked out of the room as he said it, and Edmund was



<P>left to sit down and stir the fire in thoughtful vexation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, who had heard it all, and borne Edmund company



<P>in every feeling throughout the whole, now ventured to say,



<P>in her anxiety to suggest some comfort, "Perhaps they may



<P>not be able to find any play to suit them.&nbsp; Your brother's



<P>taste and your sisters' seem very different."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have no hope there, Fanny.&nbsp; If they persist in the scheme,



<P>they will find something.&nbsp; I shall speak to my sisters



<P>and try to dissuade _them_, and that is all I can do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should think my aunt Norris would be on your side."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say she would, but she has no influence with



<P>either Tom or my sisters that could be of any use;



<P>and if I cannot convince them myself, I shall let things



<P>take their course, without attempting it through her.



<P>Family squabbling is the greatest evil of all, and we had



<P>better do anything than be altogether by the ears."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>His sisters, to whom he had an opportunity of speaking



<P>the next morning, were quite as impatient of his advice,



<P>quite as unyielding to his representation, quite as determined



<P>in the cause of pleasure, as Tom.&nbsp; Their mother had no



<P>objection to the plan, and they were not in the least afraid



<P>of their father's disapprobation.&nbsp; There could be no harm



<P>in what had been done in so many respectable families,



<P>and by so many women of the first consideration; and it



<P>must be scrupulousness run mad that could see anything to



<P>censure in a plan like theirs, comprehending only brothers



<P>and sisters and intimate friends, and which would never



<P>be heard of beyond themselves.&nbsp; Julia _did_ seem inclined



<P>to admit that Maria's situation might require particular



<P>caution and delicacy--but that could not extend to _her_--



<P>she was at liberty; and Maria evidently considered her



<P>engagement as only raising her so much more above restraint,



<P>and leaving her less occasion than Julia to consult



<P>either father or mother.&nbsp; Edmund had little to hope,



<P>but he was still urging the subject when Henry Crawford



<P>entered the room, fresh from the Parsonage, calling out,



<P>"No want of hands in our theatre, Miss Bertram.



<P>No want of understrappers:&nbsp; my sister desires her love,



<P>and hopes to be admitted into the company, and will be happy



<P>to take the part of any old duenna or tame confidante,



<P>that you may not like to do yourselves."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Maria gave Edmund a glance, which meant, "What say you now?



<P>Can we be wrong if Mary Crawford feels the same?"



<P>And Edmund, silenced, was obliged to acknowledge that the



<P>charm of acting might well carry fascination to the mind



<P>of genius; and with the ingenuity of love, to dwell more



<P>on the obliging, accommodating purport of the message



<P>than on anything else.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The scheme advanced.&nbsp; Opposition was vain; and as to



<P>Mrs. Norris, he was mistaken in supposing she would wish



<P>to make any.&nbsp; She started no difficulties that were



<P>not talked down in five minutes by her eldest nephew



<P>and niece, who were all-powerful with her; and as the



<P>whole arrangement was to bring very little expense



<P>to anybody, and none at all to herself, as she foresaw



<P>in it all the comforts of hurry, bustle, and importance,



<P>and derived the immediate advantage of fancying herself



<P>obliged to leave her own house, where she had been living



<P>a month at her own cost, and take up her abode in theirs,



<P>that every hour might be spent in their service, she was,



<P>in fact, exceedingly delighted with the project.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.03 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 07</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Fanny, and how do you like Miss Crawford _now_?"



<P>said Edmund the next day, after thinking some time on the



<P>subject himself.&nbsp; "How did you like her yesterday?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well--very much.&nbsp; I like to hear her talk.



<P>She entertains me; and she is so extremely pretty, that I



<P>have great pleasure in looking at her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is her countenance that is so attractive.&nbsp; She has



<P>a wonderful play of feature!&nbsp; But was there nothing in her



<P>conversation that struck you, Fanny, as not quite right?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes! she ought not to have spoken of her uncle as she did.



<P>I was quite astonished.&nbsp; An uncle with whom she has been



<P>living so many years, and who, whatever his faults may be,



<P>is so very fond of her brother, treating him, they say,



<P>quite like a son.&nbsp; I could not have believed it!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I thought you would be struck.&nbsp; It was very wrong;



<P>very indecorous."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And very ungrateful, I think."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ungrateful is a strong word.&nbsp; I do not know that her uncle



<P>has any claim to her _gratitude_; his wife certainly had;



<P>and it is the warmth of her respect for her aunt's memory



<P>which misleads her here.&nbsp; She is awkwardly circumstanced.



<P>With such warm feelings and lively spirits it must be



<P>difficult to do justice to her affection for Mrs. Crawford,



<P>without throwing a shade on the Admiral.&nbsp; I do not pretend



<P>to know which was most to blame in their disagreements,



<P>though the Admiral's present conduct might incline one



<P>to the side of his wife; but it is natural and amiable



<P>that Miss Crawford should acquit her aunt entirely.



<P>I do not censure her _opinions_; but there certainly _is_



<P>impropriety in making them public."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do not you think," said Fanny, after a little consideration,



<P>"that this impropriety is a reflection itself upon



<P>Mrs. Crawford, as her niece has been entirely brought



<P>up by her?&nbsp; She cannot have given her right notions



<P>of what was due to the Admiral."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is a fair remark.&nbsp; Yes, we must suppose the faults



<P>of the niece to have been those of the aunt; and it makes



<P>one more sensible of the disadvantages she has been under.



<P>But I think her present home must do her good.



<P>Mrs. Grant's manners are just what they ought to be.



<P>She speaks of her brother with a very pleasing affection."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, except as to his writing her such short letters.



<P>She made me almost laugh; but I cannot rate so very highly



<P>the love or good-nature of a brother who will not give



<P>himself the trouble of writing anything worth reading



<P>to his sisters, when they are separated.&nbsp; I am sure William



<P>would never have used _me_ so, under any circumstances.



<P>And what right had she to suppose that _you_ would not write



<P>long letters when you were absent?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The right of a lively mind, Fanny, seizing whatever



<P>may contribute to its own amusement or that of others;



<P>perfectly allowable, when untinctured by ill-humour



<P>or roughness; and there is not a shadow of either in the



<P>countenance or manner of Miss Crawford:&nbsp; nothing sharp,



<P>or loud, or coarse.&nbsp; She is perfectly feminine, except m



<P>the instances we have been speaking of.&nbsp; There she cannot



<P>be justified.&nbsp; I am glad you saw it all as I did."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having formed her mind and gained her affections, he had a



<P>good chance of her thinking like him; though at this period,



<P>and on this subject, there began now to be some danger



<P>of dissimilarity, for he was in a line of admiration



<P>of Miss Crawford, which might lead him where Fanny could



<P>not follow.&nbsp; Miss Crawford's attractions did not lessen.



<P>The harp arrived, and rather added to her beauty, wit,



<P>and good-humour; for she played with the greatest obligingness,



<P>with an expression and taste which were peculiarly becoming,



<P>and there was something clever to be said at the close



<P>of every air.&nbsp; Edmund was at the Parsonage every day,



<P>to be indulged with his favourite instrument:



<P>one morning secured an invitation for the next;



<P>for the lady could not be unwilling to have a listener,



<P>and every thing was soon in a fair train.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A young woman, pretty, lively, with a harp as



<P>elegant as herself, and both placed near a window,



<P>cut down to the ground, and opening on a little lawn,



<P>surrounded by shrubs in the rich foliage of summer,



<P>was enough to catch any man's heart.&nbsp; The season, the scene,



<P>the air, were all favourable to tenderness and sentiment.



<P>Mrs. Grant and her tambour frame were not without their use:



<P>it was all in harmony; and as everything will turn to account



<P>when love is once set going, even the sandwich tray,



<P>and Dr. Grant doing the honours of it, were worth looking at.



<P>Without studying the business, however, or knowing



<P>what he was about, Edmund was beginning, at the end



<P>of a week of such intercourse, to be a good deal in love;



<P>and to the credit of the lady it may be added that,



<P>without his being a man of the world or an elder brother,



<P>without any of the arts of flattery or the gaieties of



<P>small talk, he began to be agreeable to her.&nbsp; She felt it



<P>to be so, though she had not foreseen, and could hardly



<P>understand it; for he was not pleasant by any common rule:



<P>he talked no nonsense; he paid no compliments; his opinions



<P>were unbending, his attentions tranquil and simple.



<P>There was a charm, perhaps, in his sincerity, his steadiness,



<P>his integrity, which Miss Crawford might be equal



<P>to feel, though not equal to discuss with herself.



<P>She did not think very much about it, however:&nbsp; he pleased



<P>her for the present; she liked to have him near her;



<P>it was enough.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny could not wonder that Edmund was at the Parsonage



<P>every morning; she would gladly have been there too,



<P>might she have gone in uninvited and unnoticed, to hear



<P>the harp; neither could she wonder that, when the evening



<P>stroll was over, and the two families parted again,



<P>he should think it right to attend Mrs. Grant and her



<P>sister to their home, while Mr. Crawford was devoted



<P>to the ladies of the Park; but she thought it a very



<P>bad exchange; and if Edmund were not there to mix the wine



<P>and water for her, would rather go without it than not.



<P>She was a little surprised that he could spend so many



<P>hours with Miss Crawford, and not see more of the sort



<P>of fault which he had already observed, and of which _she_



<P>was almost always reminded by a something of the same



<P>nature whenever she was in her company; but so it was.



<P>Edmund was fond of speaking to her of Miss Crawford,



<P>but he seemed to think it enough that the Admiral had



<P>since been spared; and she scrupled to point out her own



<P>remarks to him, lest it should appear like ill-nature.



<P>The first actual pain which Miss Crawford occasioned her



<P>was the consequence of an inclination to learn to ride,



<P>which the former caught, soon after her being settled



<P>at Mansfield, from the example of the young ladies at the Park,



<P>and which, when Edmund's acquaintance with her increased,



<P>led to his encouraging the wish, and the offer of his own



<P>quiet mare for the purpose of her first attempts, as the best



<P>fitted for a beginner that either stable could furnish.



<P>No pain, no injury, however, was designed by him to his



<P>cousin in this offer:&nbsp; _she_ was not to lose a day's exercise



<P>by it.&nbsp; The mare was only to be taken down to the Parsonage



<P>half an hour before her ride were to begin; and Fanny,



<P>on its being first proposed, so far from feeling slighted,



<P>was almost over-powered with gratitude that he should be



<P>asking her leave for it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford made her first essay with great credit



<P>to herself, and no inconvenience to Fanny.&nbsp; Edmund,



<P>who had taken down the mare and presided at the whole,



<P>returned with it in excellent time, before either Fanny



<P>or the steady old coachman, who always attended her when



<P>she rode without her cousins, were ready to set forward.



<P>The second day's trial was not so guiltless.&nbsp; Miss Crawford's



<P>enjoyment of riding was such that she did not know how to



<P>leave off.&nbsp; Active and fearless, and though rather small,



<P>strongly made, she seemed formed for a horsewoman; and to



<P>the pure genuine pleasure of the exercise, something was



<P>probably added in Edmund's attendance and instructions,



<P>and something more in the conviction of very much surpassing



<P>her sex in general by her early progress, to make her



<P>unwilling to dismount.&nbsp; Fanny was ready and waiting,



<P>and Mrs. Norris was beginning to scold her for not being gone,



<P>and still no horse was announced, no Edmund appeared.



<P>To avoid her aunt, and look for him, she went out.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The houses, though scarcely half a mile apart, were not



<P>within sight of each other; but, by walking fifty yards



<P>from the hall door, she could look down the park,



<P>and command a view of the Parsonage and all its demesnes,



<P>gently rising beyond the village road; and in Dr. Grant's



<P>meadow she immediately saw the group--Edmund and Miss



<P>Crawford both on horse-back, riding side by side, Dr. and



<P>Mrs. Grant, and Mr. Crawford, with two or three grooms,



<P>standing about and looking on.&nbsp; A happy party it appeared



<P>to her, all interested in one object:&nbsp; cheerful beyond



<P>a doubt, for the sound of merriment ascended even to her.



<P>It was a sound which did not make _her_ cheerful;



<P>she wondered that Edmund should forget her, and felt



<P>a pang.&nbsp; She could not turn her eyes from the meadow;



<P>she could not help watching all that passed.&nbsp; At first Miss



<P>Crawford and her companion made the circuit of the field,



<P>which was not small, at a foot's pace; then, at _her_



<P>apparent suggestion, they rose into a canter; and to Fanny's



<P>timid nature it was most astonishing to see how well



<P>she sat.&nbsp; After a few minutes they stopped entirely.



<P>Edmund was close to her; he was speaking to her;



<P>he was evidently directing her management of the bridle;



<P>he had hold of her hand; she saw it, or the imagination



<P>supplied what the eye could not reach.&nbsp; She

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>must not wonder at all this; what could be more natural



<P>than that Edmund should be making himself useful,



<P>and proving his good-nature by any one?&nbsp; She could not



<P>but think, indeed, that Mr. Crawford might as well have



<P>saved him the trouble; that it would have been particularly



<P>proper and becoming in a brother to have done it himself;



<P>but Mr. Crawford, with all his boasted good-nature, and all



<P>his coachmanship, probably knew nothing of the matter,



<P>and had no active kindness in comparison of Edmund.



<P>She began to think it rather hard upon the mare to have



<P>such double duty; if she were forgotten, the poor mare



<P>should be remembered.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her feelings for one and the other were soon a little



<P>tranquillised by seeing the party in the meadow disperse,



<P>and Miss Crawford still on horseback, but attended by Edmund



<P>on foot, pass through a gate into the lane, and so into



<P>the park, and make towards the spot where she stood.



<P>She began then to be afraid of appearing rude and impatient;



<P>and walked to meet them with a great anxiety to avoid



<P>the suspicion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Miss Price," said Miss Crawford, as soon as she



<P>was at all within hearing, "I am come to make my own



<P>apologies for keeping you waiting; but I have nothing



<P>in the world to say for myself--I knew it was very late,



<P>and that I was behaving extremely ill; and therefore,



<P>if you please, you must forgive me.&nbsp; Selfishness must



<P>always be forgiven, you know, because there is no hope



<P>of a cure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's answer was extremely civil, and Edmund added



<P>his conviction that she could be in no hurry.&nbsp; "For there



<P>is more than time enough for my cousin to ride twice



<P>as far as she ever goes," said he, "and you have been



<P>promoting her comfort by preventing her from setting off



<P>half an hour sooner:&nbsp; clouds are now coming up, and she



<P>will not suffer from the heat as she would have done then.



<P>I wish _you_ may not be fatigued by so much exercise.



<P>I wish you had saved yourself this walk home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No part of it fatigues me but getting off this horse,



<P>I assure you," said she, as she sprang down with his help;



<P>"I am very strong.&nbsp; Nothing ever fatigues me but doing



<P>what I do not like.&nbsp; Miss Price, I give way to you with



<P>a very bad grace; but I sincerely hope you will have



<P>a pleasant ride, and that I may have nothing but good



<P>to hear of this dear, delightful, beautiful animal."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The old coachman, who had been waiting about with his



<P>own horse, now joining them, Fanny was lifted on hers,



<P>and they set off across another part of the park;



<P>her feelings of discomfort not lightened by seeing,



<P>as she looked back, that the others were walking down



<P>the hill together to the village; nor did her attendant



<P>do her much good by his comments on Miss Crawford's great



<P>cleverness as a horse-woman, which he had been watching



<P>with an interest almost equal to her own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a pleasure to see a lady with such a good heart



<P>for riding!" said he.&nbsp; "I never see one sit a horse better.



<P>She did not seem to have a thought of fear.&nbsp; Very different



<P>from you, miss, when you first began, six years ago come



<P>next Easter.&nbsp; Lord bless you! how you did tremble when Sir



<P>Thomas first had you put on!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the drawing-room Miss Crawford was also celebrated.



<P>Her merit in being gifted by Nature with strength



<P>and courage was fully appreciated by the Miss Bertrams;



<P>her delight in riding was like their own; her early



<P>excellence in it was like their own, and they had great



<P>pleasure in praising it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was sure she would ride well," said Julia; "she has



<P>the make for it.&nbsp; Her figure is as neat as her brother's."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," added Maria, "and her spirits are as good, and she



<P>has the same energy of character.&nbsp; I cannot but think



<P>that good horsemanship has a great deal to do with the mind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When they parted at night Edmund asked Fanny whether she



<P>meant to ride the next day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I do not know--not if you want the mare," was her answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not want her at all for myself," said he;



<P>"'but whenever you are next inclined to stay at home,



<P>I think Miss Crawford would be glad to have her a longer time--



<P>for a whole morning, in short.&nbsp; She has a great desire to get



<P>as far as Mansfield Common:&nbsp; Mrs. Grant has been telling



<P>her of its fine views, and I have no doubt of her being



<P>perfectly equal to it.&nbsp; But any morning will do for this.



<P>She would be extremely sorry to interfere with you.



<P>It would be very wrong if she did.&nbsp; _She_ rides only



<P>for pleasure; _you_ for health."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall not ride to-morrow, certainly," said Fanny;



<P>"I have been out very often lately, and would rather



<P>stay at home.&nbsp; You know I am strong enough now to walk



<P>very well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund looked pleased, which must be Fanny's comfort,



<P>and the ride to Mansfield Common took place the next morning:



<P>the party included all the young people but herself,



<P>and was much enjoyed at the time, and doubly enjoyed



<P>again in the evening discussion.&nbsp; A successful scheme



<P>of this sort generally brings on another; and the having



<P>been to Mansfield Common disposed them all for going



<P>somewhere else the day after.&nbsp; There were many other



<P>views to be shewn; and though the weather was hot,



<P>there were shady lanes wherever they wanted to go.



<P>A young party is always provided with a shady lane.



<P>Four fine mornings successively were spent in this manner,



<P>in shewing the Crawfords the country, and doing the



<P>honours of its finest spots.&nbsp; Everything answered;



<P>it was all gaiety and good-humour, the heat only supplying



<P>inconvenience enough to be talked of with pleasure--



<P>till the fourth day, when the happiness of one of the party



<P>was exceedingly clouded.&nbsp; Miss Bertram was the one.



<P>Edmund and Julia were invited to dine at the Parsonage,



<P>and _she_ was excluded.&nbsp; It was meant and done by Mrs. Grant,



<P>with perfect good-humour, on Mr. Rushworth's account,



<P>who was partly expected at the Park that day; but it was felt



<P>as a very grievous injury, and her good manners were severely



<P>taxed to conceal her vexation and anger till she reached home.



<P>As Mr. Rushworth did _not_ come, the injury was increased,



<P>and she had not even the relief of shewing her power over him;



<P>she could only be sullen to her mother, aunt, and cousin,



<P>and throw as great a gloom as possible over their dinner



<P>and dessert.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Between ten and eleven Edmund and Julia walked into the



<P>drawing-room, fresh with the evening air, glowing and cheerful,



<P>the very reverse of what they found in the three ladies



<P>sitting there, for Maria would scarcely raise her eyes



<P>from her book, and Lady Bertram was half-asleep; and even



<P>Mrs. Norris, discomposed by her niece's ill-humour,



<P>and having asked one or two questions about the dinner,



<P>which were not immediately attended to, seemed almost



<P>determined to say no more.&nbsp; For a few minutes the brother



<P>and sister were too eager in their praise of the night



<P>and their remarks on the stars, to think beyond themselves;



<P>but when the first pause came, Edmund, looking around,



<P>said, "But where is Fanny?&nbsp; Is she gone to bed?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, not that I know of," replied Mrs. Norris; "she was



<P>here a moment ago."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her own gentle voice speaking from the other end



<P>of the room, which was a very long one, told them



<P>that she was on the sofa.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris began scolding.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is a very foolish trick, Fanny, to be idling away all



<P>the evening upon a sofa.&nbsp; Why cannot you come and sit here,



<P>and employ yourself as _we_ do?&nbsp; If you have no work



<P>of your own, I can supply you from the poor basket.



<P>There is all the new calico, that was bought last week,



<P>not touched yet.&nbsp; I am sure I almost broke my back



<P>by cutting it out.&nbsp; You should learn to think of



<P>other people; and, take my word for it, it is a shocking



<P>trick for a young person to be always lolling upon a sofa."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Before half this was said, Fanny was returned to her



<P>seat at the table, and had taken up her work again;



<P>and Julia, who was in high good-humour, from the pleasures



<P>of the day, did her the justice of exclaiming, "I must say,



<P>ma'am, that Fanny is as little upon the sofa as anybody



<P>in the house."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fanny," said Edmund, after looking at her attentively,



<P>"I am sure you have the headache."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could not deny it, but said it was not very bad.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I can hardly believe you," he replied; "I know your looks



<P>too well.&nbsp; How long have you had it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Since a little before dinner.&nbsp; It is nothing but the heat."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did you go out in the heat?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Go out! to be sure she did," said Mrs. Norris:



<P>"would you have her stay within such a fine day as this?



<P>Were not we _all_ out?&nbsp; Even your mother was out to-day



<P>for above an hour."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, indeed, Edmund," added her ladyship, who had been



<P>thoroughly awakened by Mrs. Norris's sharp reprimand



<P>to Fanny; "I was out above an hour.&nbsp; I sat three-quarters



<P>of an hour in the flower-garden, while Fanny cut the roses;



<P>and very pleasant it was, I assure you, but very hot.



<P>It was shady enough in the alcove, but I declare I quite



<P>dreaded the coming home again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fanny has been cutting roses, has she?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, and I am afraid they will be the last this year.



<P>Poor thing!&nbsp; _She_ found it hot enough; but they were so



<P>full-blown that one could not wait."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There was no help for it, certainly," rejoined Mrs. Norris,



<P>in a rather softened voice; "but I question whether her



<P>headache might not be caught _then_, sister.&nbsp; There is



<P>nothing so likely to give it as standing and stooping



<P>in a hot sun; but I dare say it will be well to-morrow.



<P>Suppose you let her have your aromatic vinegar; I always



<P>forget to have mine filled."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She has got it," said Lady Bertram; "she has had it ever



<P>since she came back from your house the second time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What!" cried Edmund; "has she been walking as well as



<P>cutting roses; walking across the hot park to your house,



<P>and doing it twice, ma'am?&nbsp; No wonder her head aches."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris was talking to Julia, and did not hear.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was afraid it would be too much for her," said Lady Bertram;



<P>"but when the roses were gathered, your aunt wished



<P>to have them, and then you know they must be taken home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But were there roses enough to oblige her to go twice?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No; but they were to be put into the spare room to dry;



<P>and, unluckily, Fanny forgot to lock the door of the room



<P>and bring away the key, so she was obliged to go again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund got up and walked about the room, saying, "And could



<P>nobody be employed on such an errand but Fanny?&nbsp; Upon my word,



<P>ma'am, it has been a very ill-managed business."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am sure I do not know how it was to have been done better,"



<P>cried Mrs. Norris, unable to be longer deaf; "unless I had



<P>gone myself, indeed; but I cannot be in two places at once;



<P>and I was talking to Mr. Green at that very time about



<P>your mother's dairymaid, by _her_ desire, and had promised



<P>John Groom to write to Mrs. Jefferies about his son,



<P>and the poor fellow was waiting for me half an hour.



<P>I think nobody can justly accuse me of sparing myself upon



<P>any occasion, but really I cannot do everything at once.



<P>And as for Fanny's just stepping down to my house for me--



<P>it is not much above a quarter of a mile--I cannot think I



<P>was unreasonable to ask it.&nbsp; How often do I pace it three



<P>times a day, early and late, ay, and in all weathers too,



<P>and say nothing about it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish Fanny had half your strength, ma'am."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If Fanny would be more regular in her exercise, she would



<P>not be knocked up so soon.&nbsp; She has not been out on



<P>horseback now this long while, and I am persuaded that,



<P>when she does not ride, she ought to walk.&nbsp; If she had



<P>been riding before, I should not have asked it of her.



<P>But I thought it would rather do her good after being



<P>stooping among the roses; for there is nothing so



<P>refreshing as a walk after a fatigue of that kind;



<P>and though the sun was strong, it was not so very hot.



<P>Between ourselves, Edmund," nodding significantly at



<P>his mother, "it was cutting the roses, and dawdling



<P>about in the flower-garden, that did the mischief."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am afraid it was, indeed," said the more candid



<P>Lady Bertram, who had overheard her; "I am very much afraid



<P>she caught the headache there, for the heat was enough



<P>to kill anybody.&nbsp; It was as much as I could bear myself.



<P>Sitting and calling to Pug, and trying to keep him from



<P>the flower-beds, was almost too much for me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund said no more to either lady; but going quietly



<P>to another table, on which the supper-tray yet remained,



<P>brought a glass of Madeira to Fanny, and obliged her to drink



<P>the greater part.&nbsp; She wished to be able to decline it;



<P>but the tears, which a variety of feelings created,



<P>made it easier to swallow than to speak.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Vexed as Edmund was with his mother and aunt, he was still



<P>more angry with himself.&nbsp; His own forgetfulness of her was



<P>worse than anything which they had done.&nbsp; Nothing of this



<P>would have happened had she been properly considered;



<P>but she had been left four days together without any choice



<P>of companions or exercise, and without any excuse for



<P>avoiding whatever her unreasonable aunts might require.



<P>He was ashamed to think that for four days together she had



<P>not had the power of riding, and very seriously resolved,



<P>however unwilling he must be to check a pleasure of Miss



<P>Crawford's, that it should never happen again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny went to bed with her heart as full as on the first



<P>evening of her arrival at the Park.&nbsp; The state of her



<P>spirits had probably had its share in her indisposition;



<P>for she had been feeling neglected, and been struggling



<P>against discontent and envy for some days past.



<P>As she leant on the sofa, to which she had retreated



<P>that she might not be seen, the pain of her mind



<P>had been much beyond that in her head; and the sudden



<P>change which Edmund's kindness had then occasioned,



<P>made her hardly know how to support herself.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 06</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. Bertram set off for--------, and Miss Crawford



<P>was prepared to find a great chasm in their society,



<P>and to miss him decidedly in the meetings which were now



<P>becoming almost daily between the families; and on their



<P>all dining together at the Park soon after his going,



<P>she retook her chosen place near the bottom of the table,



<P>fully expecting to feel a most melancholy difference in



<P>the change of masters.&nbsp; It would be a very flat business,



<P>she was sure.&nbsp; In comparison with his brother, Edmund would



<P>have nothing to say.&nbsp; The soup would be sent round in a



<P>most spiritless manner, wine drank without any smiles



<P>or agreeable trifling, and the venison cut up without



<P>supplying one pleasant anecdote of any former haunch,



<P>or a single entertaining story, about "my friend such a one."



<P>She must try to find amusement in what was passing at the



<P>upper end of the table, and in observing Mr. Rushworth,



<P>who was now making his appearance at Mansfield for the first



<P>time since the Crawfords' arrival.&nbsp; He had been visiting



<P>a friend in the neighbouring county, and that friend



<P>having recently had his grounds laid out by an improver,



<P>Mr. Rushworth was returned with his head full of the subject,



<P>and very eager to be improving his own place in the same way;



<P>and though not saying much to the purpose, could talk



<P>of nothing else.&nbsp; The subject had been already handled



<P>in the drawing-room; it was revived in the dining-parlour.



<P>Miss Bertram's attention and opinion was evidently



<P>his chief aim; and though her deportment showed rather



<P>conscious superiority than any solicitude to oblige him,



<P>the mention of Sotherton Court, and the ideas attached



<P>to it, gave her a feeling of complacency, which prevented



<P>her from being very ungracious.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish you could see Compton," said he; "it is the most



<P>complete thing!&nbsp; I never saw a place so altered in my life.



<P>I told Smith I did not know where I was.&nbsp; The approach _now_,



<P>is one of the finest things in the country:&nbsp; you see the



<P>house in the most surprising manner.&nbsp; I declare, when I



<P>got back to Sotherton yesterday, it looked like a prison--



<P>quite a dismal old prison."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, for shame!" cried Mrs. Norris.&nbsp; "A prison indeed?



<P>Sotherton Court is the noblest old place in the world."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It wants improvement, ma'am, beyond anything.&nbsp; I never



<P>saw a place that wanted so much improvement in my life;



<P>and it is so forlorn that I do not know what can be done



<P>with it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No wonder that Mr. Rushworth should think so at present,"



<P>said Mrs. Grant to Mrs. Norris, with a smile; "but depend



<P>upon it, Sotherton will have _every_ improvement in time



<P>which his heart can desire."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I must try to do something with it," said Mr. Rushworth,



<P>"but I do not know what.&nbsp; I hope I shall have some good



<P>friend to help me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your best friend upon such an occasion," said Miss



<P>Bertram calmly, "would be Mr. Repton, I imagine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is what I was thinking of.&nbsp; As he has done so



<P>well by Smith, I think I had better have him at once.



<P>His terms are five guineas a day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, and if they were _ten_," cried Mrs. Norris,



<P>"I am sure _you_ need not regard it.&nbsp; The expense need



<P>not be any impediment.&nbsp; If I were you, I should not



<P>think of the expense.&nbsp; I would have everything done



<P>in the best style, and made as nice as possible.



<P>Such a place as Sotherton Court deserves everything that



<P>taste and money can do.&nbsp; You have space to work upon there,



<P>and grounds that will well reward you.&nbsp; For my own part,



<P>if I had anything within the fiftieth part of the size



<P>of Sotherton, I should be always planting and improving,



<P>for naturally I am excessively fond of it.&nbsp; It would be



<P>too ridiculous for me to attempt anything where I am now,



<P>with my little half acre.&nbsp; It would be quite a burlesque.



<P>But if I had more room, I should take a prodigious delight



<P>in improving and planting.&nbsp; We did a vast deal in that way



<P>at the Parsonage:&nbsp; we made it quite a different place



<P>from what it was when we first had it.&nbsp; You young ones



<P>do not remember much about it, perhaps; but if dear Sir



<P>Thomas were here, he could tell you what improvements



<P>we made:&nbsp; and a great deal more would have been done,



<P>but for poor Mr. Norris's sad state of health.&nbsp; He could



<P>hardly ever get out, poor man, to enjoy anything, and _that_



<P>disheartened me from doing several things that Sir Thomas



<P>and I used to talk of.&nbsp; If it had not been for _that_,



<P>we should have carried on the garden wall, and made the



<P>plantation to shut out the churchyard, just as Dr. Grant



<P>has done.&nbsp; We were always doing something as it was.



<P>It was only the spring twelvemonth before Mr. Norris's



<P>death that we put in the apricot against the stable wall,



<P>which is now grown such a noble tree, and getting



<P>to such perfection, sir," addressing herself then to



<P>Dr. Grant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The tree thrives well, beyond a doubt, madam," replied Dr. Grant.



<P>"The soil is good; and I never pass it without regretting



<P>that the fruit should be so little worth the trouble of gathering."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sir, it is a Moor Park, we bought it as a Moor Park,



<P>and it cost us--that is, it was a present from Sir Thomas,



<P>but I saw the bill--and I know it cost seven shillings,



<P>and was charged as a Moor Park."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You were imposed on, ma'am," replied Dr. Grant:



<P>"these potatoes have as much the flavour of a Moor Park



<P>apricot as the fruit from that tree.&nbsp; It is an insipid



<P>fruit at the best; but a good apricot is eatable,



<P>which none from my garden are."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The truth is, ma'am," said Mrs. Grant, pretending to



<P>whisper across the table to Mrs. Norris, "that Dr. Grant



<P>hardly knows what the natural taste of our apricot is:



<P>he is scarcely ever indulged with one, for it is so



<P>valuable a fruit; with a little assistance, and ours is



<P>such a remarkably large, fair sort, that what with early



<P>tarts and preserves, my cook contrives to get them all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris, who had begun to redden, was appeased;



<P>and, for a little while, other subjects took place of the



<P>improvements of Sotherton.&nbsp; Dr. Grant and Mrs. Norris



<P>were seldom good friends; their acquaintance had begun



<P>in dilapidations, and their habits were totally dissimilar.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After a short interruption Mr. Rushworth began again.



<P>"Smith's place is the admiration of all the country;



<P>and it was a mere nothing before Repton took it in hand.



<P>I think I shall have Repton."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Rushworth," said Lady Bertram, "if I were you,



<P>I would have a very pretty shrubbery.&nbsp; One likes to get



<P>out into a shrubbery in fine weather."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Rushworth was eager to assure her ladyship of his



<P>acquiescence, and tried to make out something complimentary;



<P>but, between his submission to _her_ taste, and his having



<P>always intended the same himself, with the superadded



<P>objects of professing attention to the comfort of ladies



<P>in general, and of insinuating that there was one only whom



<P>he was anxious to please, he grew puzzled, and Edmund was



<P>glad to put an end to his speech by a proposal of wine.



<P>Mr. Rushworth, however, though not usually a great talker,



<P>had still more to say on the subject next his heart.



<P>"Smith has not much above a hundred acres altogether



<P>in his grounds, which is little enough, and makes it more



<P>surprising that the place can have been so improved.



<P>Now, at Sotherton we have a good seven hundred,



<P>without reckoning the water meadows; so that I think,



<P>if so much could be done at Compton, we need not despair.



<P>There have been two or three fine old trees cut down, that grew



<P>too near the house, and it opens the prospect amazingly,



<P>which makes me think that Repton, or anybody of that sort,



<P>would certainly have the avenue at Sotherton down:&nbsp; the avenue



<P>that leads from the west front to the top of the hill,



<P>you know," turning to Miss Bertram particularly as he spoke.



<P>But Miss Bertram thought it most becoming to reply--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The avenue!&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; I do not recollect it.&nbsp; I really know



<P>very little of Sotherton."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, who was sitting on the other side of Edmund,



<P>exactly opposite Miss Crawford, and who had been attentively



<P>listening, now looked at him, and said in a low voice--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Cut down an avenue!&nbsp; What a pity!&nbsp; Does it not make you



<P>think of Cowper?&nbsp; 'Ye fallen avenues, once more I mourn



<P>your fate unmerited.'&nbsp; "

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He smiled as he answered, "I am afraid the avenue stands



<P>a bad chance, Fanny."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should like to see Sotherton before it is cut down,



<P>to see the place as it is now, in its old state; but I do



<P>not suppose I shall."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you never been there?&nbsp; No, you never can;



<P>and, unluckily, it is out of distance for a ride.



<P>I wish we could contrive it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! it does not signify.&nbsp; Whenever I do see it,



<P>you will tell me how it has been altered."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I collect," said Miss Crawford, "that Sotherton



<P>is an old place, and a place of some grandeur.



<P>In any particular style of building?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The house was built in Elizabeth's time, and is a large,



<P>regular, brick building; heavy, but respectable looking,



<P>and has many good rooms.&nbsp; It is ill placed.&nbsp; It stands



<P>in one of the lowest spots of the park; in that respect,



<P>unfavourable for improvement.&nbsp; But the woods are fine,



<P>and there is a stream, which, I dare say, might be made



<P>a good deal of.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth is quite right, I think,



<P>in meaning to give it a modern dress, and I have no doubt



<P>that it will be all done extremely well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford listened with submission, and said to herself,



<P>"He is a well-bred man; he makes the best of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not wish to influence Mr. Rushworth," he continued;



<P>"but, had I a place to new fashion, I should not put



<P>myself into the hands of an improver.&nbsp; I would rather



<P>have an inferior degree of beauty, of my own choice,



<P>and acquired progressively.&nbsp; I would rather abide by my own



<P>blunders than by his."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_You_ would know what you were about, of course;



<P>but that would not suit _me_.&nbsp; I have no eye or



<P>ingenuity for such matters, but as they are before me;



<P>and had I a place of my own in the country, I should be



<P>most thankful to any Mr. Repton who would undertake it,



<P>and give me as much beauty as he could for my money;



<P>and I should never look at it till it was complete."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It would be delightful to _me_ to see the progress



<P>of it all," said Fanny.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ay, you have been brought up to it.&nbsp; It was no part of



<P>my education; and the only dose I ever had, being administered



<P>by not the first favourite in the world, has made me consider



<P>improvements _in_ _hand_ as the greatest of nuisances.



<P>Three years ago the Admiral, my honoured uncle, bought a



<P>cottage at Twickenham for us all to spend our summers in;



<P>and my aunt and I went down to it quite in raptures;



<P>but it being excessively pretty, it was soon found



<P>necessary to be improved, and for three months we were



<P>all dirt and confusion, without a gravel walk to step on,



<P>or a bench fit for use.&nbsp; I would have everything as complete



<P>as possible in the country, shrubberies and flower-gardens,



<P>and rustic seats innumerable:&nbsp; but it must all be done



<P>without my care.&nbsp; Henry is different; he loves to be doing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund was sorry to hear Miss Crawford, whom he was much



<P>disposed to admire, speak so freely of her uncle.



<P>It did not suit his sense of propriety, and he was silenced,



<P>till induced by further smiles and liveliness to put



<P>the matter by for the present.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Bertram," said she, "I have tidings of my harp at last.



<P>I am assured that it is safe at Northampton; and there it



<P>has probably been these ten days, in spite of the solemn



<P>assurances we have so often received to the contrary."



<P>Edmund expressed his pleasure and surprise.&nbsp; "The truth is,



<P>that our inquiries were too direct; we sent a servant,



<P>we went ourselves:&nbsp; this will not do seventy miles from London;



<P>but this morning we heard of it in the right way.



<P>It was seen by some farmer, and he told the miller,



<P>and the miller told the butcher, and the butcher's



<P>son-in-law left word at the shop."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very glad that you have heard of it, by whatever means,



<P>and hope there will be no further delay."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am to have it to-morrow; but how do you think it



<P>is to be conveyed?&nbsp; Not by a wagon or cart:&nbsp; oh no!



<P>nothing of that kind could be hired in the village.



<P>I might as well have asked for porters and a handbarrow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You would find it difficult, I dare say, just now,



<P>in the middle of a very late hay harvest, to hire a horse



<P>and cart?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was astonished to find what a piece of work was made of it!



<P>To want a horse and cart in the country seemed impossible,



<P>so I told my maid to speak for one directly; and as I cannot



<P>look out of my dressing-closet without seeing one farmyard,



<P>nor walk in the shrubbery without passing another,



<P>I thought it would be only ask and have, and was rather



<P>grieved that I could not give the advantage to all.



<P>Guess my surprise, when I found that I had been asking



<P>the most unreasonable, most impossible thing in the world;



<P>had offended all the farmers, all the labourers,



<P>all the hay in the parish!&nbsp; As for Dr. Grant's bailiff,



<P>I believe I had better keep out of _his_ way; and my



<P>brother-in-law himself, who is all kindness in general,



<P>looked rather black upon me when he found what I had



<P>been at."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You could not be expected to have thought on the subject before;



<P>but when you _do_ think of it, you must see the importance



<P>of getting in the grass.&nbsp; The hire of a cart at any time



<P>might not be so easy as you suppose:&nbsp; our farmers are



<P>not in the habit of letting them out; but, in harvest,



<P>it must be quite out of their power to spare a horse."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall understand all your ways in time; but, coming down



<P>with the true London maxim, that everything is to be



<P>got with money, I was a little embarrassed at first



<P>by the sturdy independence of your country customs.



<P>However, I am to have my harp fetched to-morrow. Henry,



<P>who is good-nature itself, has offered to fetch



<P>it in his barouche.&nbsp; Will it not be honourably conveyed?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund spoke of the harp as his favourite instrument,



<P>and hoped to be soon allowed to hear her.&nbsp; Fanny had never



<P>heard the harp at all, and wished for it very much.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall be most happy to play to you both," said Miss



<P>Crawford; "at least as long as you can like to listen:



<P>probably much longer, for I dearly love music myself,



<P>and where the natural taste is equal the player must



<P>always be best off, for she is gratified in more ways



<P>than one.&nbsp; Now, Mr. Bertram, if you write to your brother,



<P>I entreat you to tell him that my harp is come:



<P>he heard so much of my misery about it.&nbsp; And you may say,



<P>if you please, that I shall prepare my most plaintive



<P>airs against his return, in compassion to his feelings,



<P>as I know his horse will lose."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I write, I will say whatever you wish me; but I do not,



<P>at present, foresee any occasion for writing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I dare say, nor if he were to be gone a twelvemonth,



<P>would you ever write to him, nor he to you, if it could



<P>be helped.&nbsp; The occasion would never be foreseen.



<P>What strange creatures brothers are!&nbsp; You would not write



<P>to each other but upon the most urgent necessity in the world;



<P>and when obliged to take up the pen to say that such a horse



<P>is ill, or such a relation dead, it is done in the fewest



<P>possible words.&nbsp; You have but one style among you.



<P>I know it perfectly.&nbsp; Henry, who is in every other respect



<P>exactly what a brother should be, who loves me, consults me,



<P>confides in me, and will talk to me by the hour together,



<P>has never yet turned the page in a letter; and very often



<P>it is nothing more than--'Dear Mary, I am just arrived.



<P>Bath seems full, and everything as usual.&nbsp; Yours sincerely.'



<P>That is the true manly style; that is a complete



<P>brother's letter."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When they are at a distance from all their family,"



<P>said Fanny, colouring for William's sake, "they can write



<P>long letters."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Price has a brother at sea," said Edmund,



<P>"whose excellence as a correspondent makes her think



<P>you too severe upon us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"At sea, has she?&nbsp; In the king's service, of course?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny would rather have had Edmund tell the story,



<P>but his determined silence obliged her to relate her



<P>brother's situation:&nbsp; her voice was animated in speaking



<P>of his profession, and the foreign stations he had been on;



<P>but she could not mention the number of years that he



<P>had been absent without tears in her eyes.&nbsp; Miss Crawford



<P>civilly wished him an early promotion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you know anything of my cousin's captain?" said Edmund;



<P>"Captain Marshall?&nbsp; You have a large acquaintance in the navy,



<P>I conclude?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Among admirals, large enough; but," with an air of grandeur,



<P>"we know very little of the inferior ranks.&nbsp; Post-captains may



<P>be very good sort of men, but they do not belong to _us_.



<P>Of various admirals I could tell you a great deal:



<P>of them and their flags, and the gradation of their pay,



<P>and their bickerings and jealousies.&nbsp; But, in general,



<P>I can assure you that they are all passed over, and all



<P>very ill used.&nbsp; Certainly, my home at my uncle's brought



<P>me acquainted with a circle of admirals.&nbsp; Of _Rears_ and



<P>_Vices_ I saw enough.&nbsp; Now do not be suspecting me of a pun,



<P>I entreat."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund again felt grave, and only replied, "It is



<P>a noble profession."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, the profession is well enough under two circumstances:



<P>if it make the fortune, and there be discretion in spending it;



<P>but, in short, it is not a favourite profession of mine.



<P>It has never worn an amiable form to _me_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund reverted to the harp, and was again very happy



<P>in the prospect of hearing her play.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The subject of improving grounds, meanwhile, was still



<P>under consideration among the others; and Mrs. Grant could



<P>not help addressing her brother, though it was calling



<P>his attention from Miss Julia Bertram.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Henry, have _you_ nothing to say?&nbsp; You have been



<P>an improver yourself, and from what I hear of Everingham,



<P>it may vie with any place in England.&nbsp; Its natural beauties,



<P>I am sure, are great.&nbsp; Everingham, as it _used_ to be,



<P>was perfect in my estimation:&nbsp; such a happy fall of ground,



<P>and such timber!&nbsp; What would I not give to see it again?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing could be so gratifying to me as to hear your



<P>opinion of it," was his answer; "but I fear there would



<P>be some disappointment:&nbsp; you would not find it equal



<P>to your present ideas.&nbsp; In extent, it is a mere nothing;



<P>you would be surprised at its insignificance; and,



<P>as for improvement, there was very little for me to do--



<P>too little:&nbsp; I should like to have been busy much longer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are fond of the sort of thing?" said Julia.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Excessively; but what with the natural advantages of



<P>the ground, which pointed out, even to a very young eye,



<P>what little remained to be done, and my own consequent



<P>resolutions, I had not been of age three months before



<P>Everingham was all that it is now.&nbsp; My plan was laid



<P>at Westminster, a little altered, perhaps, at Cambridge,



<P>and at one-and-twenty executed.&nbsp; I am inclined to envy



<P>Mr. Rushworth for having so much happiness yet before him.



<P>I have been a devourer of my own."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Those who see quickly, will resolve quickly, and act quickly,"



<P>said Julia.&nbsp; "_You_ can never want employment.



<P>Instead of envying Mr. Rushworth, you should assist



<P>him with your opinion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Grant, hearing the latter part of this speech,



<P>enforced it warmly, persuaded that no judgment could



<P>be equal to her brother's; and as Miss Bertram caught



<P>at the idea likewise, and gave it her full support,



<P>declaring that, in her opinion, it was infinitely better



<P>to consult with friends and disinterested advisers,



<P>than immediately to throw the business into the hands of a



<P>professional man, Mr. Rushworth was very ready to request



<P>the favour of Mr. Crawford's assistance; and Mr. Crawford,



<P>after properly depreciating his own abilities, was quite at



<P>his service in any way that could be useful.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth



<P>then began to propose Mr. Crawford's doing him the honour



<P>of coming over to Sotherton, and taking a bed there;



<P>when Mrs. Norris, as if reading in her two nieces'



<P>minds their little approbation of a plan which was to take



<P>Mr. Crawford away, interposed with an amendment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There can be no doubt of Mr. Crawford's willingness;



<P>but why should not more of us go?&nbsp; Why should not we



<P>make a little party?&nbsp; Here are many that would be



<P>interested in your improvements, my dear Mr. Rushworth,



<P>and that would like to hear Mr. Crawford's opinion on



<P>the spot, and that might be of some small use to you with



<P>_their_ opinions; and, for my own part, I have been long



<P>wishing to wait upon your good mother again; nothing but



<P>having no horses of my own could have made me so remiss;



<P>but now I could go and sit a few hours with Mrs. Rushworth,



<P>while the rest of you walked about and settled things,



<P>and then we could all return to a late dinner here,



<P>or dine at Sotherton, just as might be most agreeable to



<P>your mother, and have a pleasant drive home by moonlight.



<P>I dare say Mr. Crawford would take my two nieces and me



<P>in his barouche, and Edmund can go on horseback, you know,



<P>sister, and Fanny will stay at home with you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram made no objection; and every one concerned in



<P>the going was forward in expressing their ready concurrence,



<P>excepting Edmund, who heard it all and said nothing.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 12</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

&nbsp;



<P><B>CHAPTER XII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas was to return in November, and his eldest



<P>son had duties to call him earlier home.&nbsp; The approach



<P>of September brought tidings of Mr. Bertram, first in a



<P>letter to the gamekeeper and then in a letter to Edmund;



<P>and by the end of August he arrived himself, to be gay,



<P>agreeable, and gallant again as occasion served,



<P>or Miss Crawford demanded; to tell of races and Weymouth,



<P>and parties and friends, to which she might have listened



<P>six weeks before with some interest, and altogether



<P>to give her the fullest conviction, by the power



<P>of actual comparison, of her preferring his younger brother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was very vexatious, and she was heartily sorry for it;



<P>but so it was; and so far from now meaning to marry



<P>the elder, she did not even want to attract him beyond



<P>what the simplest claims of conscious beauty required:



<P>his lengthened absence from Mansfield, without anything



<P>but pleasure in view, and his own will to consult, made it



<P>perfectly clear that he did not care about her; and his



<P>indifference was so much more than equalled by her own,



<P>that were he now to step forth the owner of Mansfield Park,



<P>the Sir Thomas complete, which he was to be in time, she did



<P>not believe she could accept him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The season and duties which brought Mr. Bertram back to



<P>Mansfield took Mr. Crawford into Norfolk.&nbsp; Everingham could



<P>not do without him in the beginning of September.&nbsp; He went



<P>for a fortnight--a fortnight of such dullness to the Miss



<P>Bertrams as ought to have put them both on their guard,



<P>and made even Julia admit, in her jealousy of her sister,



<P>the absolute necessity of distrusting his attentions,



<P>and wishing him not to return; and a fortnight of sufficient



<P>leisure, in the intervals of shooting and sleeping, to have



<P>convinced the gentleman that he ought to keep longer away,



<P>had he been more in the habit of examining his own motives,



<P>and of reflecting to what the indulgence of his idle vanity



<P>was tending; but, thoughtless and selfish from prosperity



<P>and bad example, he would not look beyond the present moment.



<P>The sisters, handsome, clever, and encouraging, were an



<P>amusement to his sated mind; and finding nothing in Norfolk



<P>to equal the social pleasures of Mansfield, he gladly



<P>returned to it at the time appointed, and was welcomed



<P>thither quite as gladly by those whom he came to trifle with



<P>further.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Maria, with only Mr. Rushworth to attend to her, and doomed



<P>to the repeated details of his day's sport, good or bad,



<P>his boast of his dogs, his jealousy of his neighbours,



<P>his doubts of their qualifications, and his zeal after poachers,



<P>subjects which will not find their way to female feelings



<P>without some talent on one side or some attachment on



<P>the other, had missed Mr. Crawford grievously; and Julia,



<P>unengaged and unemployed, felt all the right of missing him



<P>much more.&nbsp; Each sister believed herself the favourite.



<P>Julia might be justified in so doing by the hints



<P>of Mrs. Grant, inclined to credit what she wished,



<P>and Maria by the hints of Mr. Crawford himself.



<P>Everything returned into the same channel as before his absence;



<P>his manners being to each so animated and agreeable



<P>as to lose no ground with either, and just stopping short



<P>of the consistence, the steadiness, the solicitude,



<P>and the warmth which might excite general notice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was the only one of the party who found anything



<P>to dislike; but since the day at Sotherton, she could never



<P>see Mr. Crawford with either sister without observation,



<P>and seldom without wonder or censure; and had her



<P>confidence in her own judgment been equal to her exercise



<P>of it in every other respect, had she been sure that she



<P>was seeing clearly, and judging candidly, she would



<P>probably have made some important communications to her



<P>usual confidant.&nbsp; As it was, however, she only hazarded



<P>a hint, and the hint was lost.&nbsp; "I am rather surprised,"



<P>said she, "that Mr. Crawford should come back again so soon,



<P>after being here so long before, full seven weeks;



<P>for I had understood he was so very fond of change and



<P>moving about, that I thought something would certainly



<P>occur, when he was once gone, to take him elsewhere.



<P>He is used to much gayer places than Mansfield."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is to his credit," was Edmund's answer; "and I dare



<P>say it gives his sister pleasure.&nbsp; She does not like his



<P>unsettled habits."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What a favourite he is with my cousins!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, his manners to women are such as must please.



<P>Mrs. Grant, I believe, suspects him of a preference for Julia;



<P>I have never seen much symptom of it, but I wish it may



<P>be so.&nbsp; He has no faults but what a serious attachment



<P>would remove."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If Miss Bertram were not engaged," said Fanny cautiously,



<P>"I could sometimes almost think that he admired her more



<P>than Julia."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Which is, perhaps, more in favour of his liking



<P>Julia best, than you, Fanny, may be aware; for I believe



<P>it often happens that a man, before he has quite made up



<P>his own mind, will distinguish the sister or intimate



<P>friend of the woman he is really thinking of more than



<P>the woman herself Crawford has too much sense to stay



<P>here if he found himself in any danger from Maria;



<P>and I am not at all afraid for her, after such a proof



<P>as she has given that her feelings are not strong."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny supposed she must have been mistaken, and meant to



<P>think differently in future; but with all that submission



<P>to Edmund could do, and all the help of the coinciding



<P>looks and hints which she occasionally noticed in some



<P>of the others, and which seemed to say that Julia was



<P>Mr. Crawford's choice, she knew not always what to think.



<P>She was privy, one evening, to the hopes of her aunt



<P>Norris on the subject, as well as to her feelings,



<P>and the feelings of Mrs. Rushworth, on a point of some



<P>similarity, and could not help wondering as she listened;



<P>and glad would she have been not to be obliged to listen,



<P>for it was while all the other young people were dancing,



<P>and she sitting, most unwillingly, among the chaperons at



<P>the fire, longing for the re-entrance of her elder cousin,



<P>on whom all her own hopes of a partner then depended.



<P>It was Fanny's first ball, though without the preparation



<P>or splendour of many a young lady's first ball, being the



<P>thought only of the afternoon, built on the late acquisition



<P>of a violin player in the servants' hall, and the possibility



<P>of raising five couple with the help of Mrs. Grant and a new



<P>intimate friend of Mr. Bertram's just arrived on a visit.



<P>It had, however, been a very happy one to Fanny through



<P>four dances, and she was quite grieved to be losing



<P>even a quarter of an hour.&nbsp; While waiting and wishing,



<P>looking now at the dancers and now at the door, this dialogue



<P>between the two above-mentioned ladies was forced on her--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I think, ma'am," said Mrs. Norris, her eyes directed



<P>towards Mr. Rushworth and Maria, who were partners for



<P>the second time, "we shall see some happy faces again now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, ma'am, indeed," replied the other, with a stately simper,



<P>"there will be some satisfaction in looking on _now_,



<P>and I think it was rather a pity they should have been



<P>obliged to part.&nbsp; Young folks in their situation



<P>should be excused complying with the common forms.



<P>I wonder my son did not propose it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I dare say he did, ma'am. Mr. Rushworth is never remiss.



<P>But dear Maria has such a strict sense of propriety, so much



<P>of that true delicacy which one seldom meets with nowadays,



<P>Mrs. Rushworth--that wish of avoiding particularity!



<P>Dear ma'am, only look at her face at this moment;



<P>how different from what it was the two last dances!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Bertram did indeed look happy, her eyes were



<P>sparkling with pleasure, and she was speaking with



<P>great animation, for Julia and her partner, Mr. Crawford,



<P>were close to her; they were all in a cluster together.



<P>How she had looked before, Fanny could not recollect,



<P>for she had been dancing with Edmund herself, and had



<P>not thought about her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris continued, "It is quite delightful, ma'am, to



<P>see young people so properly happy, so well suited,



<P>and so much the thing!&nbsp; I cannot but think of dear Sir



<P>Thomas's delight.&nbsp; And what do you say, ma'am, to the chance



<P>of another match?&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth has set a good example,



<P>and such things are very catching."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Rushworth, who saw nothing but her son, was quite



<P>at a loss.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The couple above, ma'am. Do you see no symptoms there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh dear!&nbsp; Miss Julia and Mr. Crawford.&nbsp; Yes, indeed,



<P>a very pretty match.&nbsp; What is his property?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Four thousand a year."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well.&nbsp; Those who have not more must be satisfied with



<P>what they have.&nbsp; Four thousand a year is a pretty estate,



<P>and he seems a very genteel, steady young man, so I hope



<P>Miss Julia will be very happy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is not a settled thing, ma'am, yet.&nbsp; We only speak of it



<P>among friends.&nbsp; But I have very little doubt it _will_ be.



<P>He is growing extremely particular in his attentions."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny could listen no farther.&nbsp; Listening and wondering were all



<P>suspended for a time, for Mr. Bertram was in the room again;



<P>and though feeling it would be a great honour to be asked



<P>by him, she thought it must happen.&nbsp; He came towards



<P>their little circle; but instead of asking her to dance,



<P>drew a chair near her, and gave her an account of the present



<P>state of a sick horse, and the opinion of the groom,



<P>from whom he had just parted.&nbsp; Fanny found that it was



<P>not to be, and in the modesty of her nature immediately



<P>felt that she had been unreasonable in expecting it.



<P>When he had told of his horse, he took a newspaper from



<P>the table, and looking over it, said in a languid way,



<P>"If you want to dance, Fanny, I will stand up with you."



<P>With more than equal civility the offer was declined;



<P>she did not wish to dance.&nbsp; "I am glad of it," said he,



<P>in a much brisker tone, and throwing down the newspaper



<P>again, "for I am tired to death.&nbsp; I only wonder how



<P>the good people can keep it up so long.&nbsp; They had need



<P>be _all_ in love, to find any amusement in such folly;



<P>and so they are, I fancy.&nbsp; If you look at them you may



<P>see they are so many couple of lovers--all but Yates



<P>and Mrs. Grant--and, between ourselves, she, poor woman,



<P>must want a lover as much as any one of them.&nbsp; A desperate



<P>dull life hers must be with the doctor," making a sly face



<P>as he spoke towards the chair of the latter, who proving,



<P>however, to be close at his elbow, made so instantaneous



<P>a change of expression and subject necessary, as Fanny,



<P>in spite of everything, could hardly help laughing at.



<P>"A strange business this in America, Dr. Grant!&nbsp; What is



<P>your opinion?&nbsp; I always come to you to know what I am to



<P>think of public matters."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Tom," cried his aunt soon afterwards, "as you



<P>are not dancing, I dare say you will have no objection



<P>to join us in a rubber; shall you?"&nbsp; Then leaving her seat,



<P>and coming to him to enforce the proposal, added in



<P>a whisper, "We want to make a table for Mrs. Rushworth,



<P>you know.&nbsp; Your mother is quite anxious about it,



<P>but cannot very well spare time to sit down herself,



<P>because of her fringe.&nbsp; Now, you and I and Dr. Grant will



<P>just do; and though _we_ play but half-crowns, you know,



<P>you may bet half-guineas with _him_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should be most happy," replied he aloud, and jumping up



<P>with alacrity, "it would give me the greatest pleasure;



<P>but that I am this moment going to dance."&nbsp; Come, Fanny,



<P>taking her hand, "do not be dawdling any longer,



<P>or the dance will be over."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was led off very willingly, though it was impossible



<P>for her to feel much gratitude towards her cousin,



<P>or distinguish, as he certainly did, between the selfishness



<P>of another person and his own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A pretty modest request upon my word," he indignantly



<P>exclaimed as they walked away.&nbsp; "To want to nail me



<P>to a card-table for the next two hours with herself and



<P>Dr. Grant, who are always quarrelling, and that poking



<P>old woman, who knows no more of whist than of algebra.



<P>I wish my good aunt would be a little less busy!&nbsp; And to ask



<P>me in such a way too! without ceremony, before them all,



<P>so as to leave me no possibility of refusing.&nbsp; _That_ is



<P>what I dislike most particularly.&nbsp; It raises my spleen



<P>more than anything, to have the pretence of being asked,



<P>of being given a choice, and at the same time addressed



<P>in such a way as to oblige one to do the very thing,



<P>whatever it be!&nbsp; If I had not luckily thought of standing



<P>up with you I could not have got out of it.&nbsp; It is a great



<P>deal too bad.&nbsp; But when my aunt has got a fancy in her head,



<P>nothing can stop her."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 48</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XLVIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Let other pens dwell on guilt and misery.&nbsp; I quit such odious



<P>subjects as soon as I can, impatient to restore everybody,



<P>not greatly in fault themselves, to tolerable comfort,



<P>and to have done with all the rest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>My Fanny, indeed, at this very time, I have the satisfaction



<P>of knowing, must have been happy in spite of everything.



<P>She must have been a happy creature in spite of all that she felt,



<P>or thought she felt, for the distress of those around her.



<P>She had sources of delight that must force their way.



<P>She was returned to Mansfield Park, she was useful,



<P>she was beloved; she was safe from Mr. Crawford;



<P>and when Sir Thomas came back she had every proof that



<P>could be given in his then melancholy state of spirits,



<P>of his perfect approbation and increased regard;



<P>and happy as all this must make her, she would still have



<P>been happy without any of it, for Edmund was no longer



<P>the dupe of Miss Crawford.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It is true that Edmund was very far from happy himself.



<P>He was suffering from disappointment and regret,



<P>grieving over what was, and wishing for what could never be.



<P>She knew it was so, and was sorry; but it was with a



<P>sorrow so founded on satisfaction, so tending to ease,



<P>and so much in harmony with every dearest sensation,



<P>that there are few who might not have been glad to exchange



<P>their greatest gaiety for it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas, poor Sir Thomas, a parent, and conscious of errors



<P>in his own conduct as a parent, was the longest to suffer.



<P>He felt that he ought not to have allowed the marriage;



<P>that his daughter's sentiments had been sufficiently known



<P>to him to render him culpable in authorising it; that in so



<P>doing he had sacrificed the right to the expedient, and been



<P>governed by motives of selfishness and worldly wisdom.



<P>These were reflections that required some time to soften;
