<P>but time will do almost everything; and though little



<P>comfort arose on Mrs. Rushworth's side for the misery she



<P>had occasioned, comfort was to be found greater than he had



<P>supposed in his other children.&nbsp; Julia's match became a less



<P>desperate business than he had considered it at first.



<P>She was humble, and wishing to be forgiven; and Mr. Yates,



<P>desirous of being really received into the family, was disposed



<P>to look up to him and be guided.&nbsp; He was not very solid;



<P>but there was a hope of his becoming less trifling,



<P>of his being at least tolerably domestic and quiet;



<P>and at any rate, there was comfort in finding his estate



<P>rather more, and his debts much less, than he had feared,



<P>and in being consulted and treated as the friend best



<P>worth attending to.&nbsp; There was comfort also in Tom,



<P>who gradually regained his health, without regaining the



<P>thoughtlessness and selfishness of his previous habits.



<P>He was the better for ever for his illness.&nbsp; He had suffered,



<P>and he had learned to think:&nbsp; two advantages that he had



<P>never known before; and the self-reproach arising from



<P>the deplorable event in Wimpole Street, to which he felt



<P>himself accessory by all the dangerous intimacy of his



<P>unjustifiable theatre, made an impression on his mind which,



<P>at the age of six-and-twenty, with no want of sense



<P>or good companions, was durable in its happy effects.



<P>He became what he ought to be:&nbsp; useful to his father,



<P>steady and quiet, and not living merely for himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here was comfort indeed! and quite as soon as Sir



<P>Thomas could place dependence on such sources of good,



<P>Edmund was contributing to his father's ease by improvement



<P>in the only point in which he had given him pain before--



<P>improvement in his spirits.&nbsp; After wandering about and



<P>sitting under trees with Fanny all the summer evenings,



<P>he had so well talked his mind into submission as to be



<P>very tolerably cheerful again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These were the circumstances and the hopes which gradually



<P>brought their alleviation to Sir Thomas, deadening his sense



<P>of what was lost, and in part reconciling him to himself;



<P>though the anguish arising from the conviction of his



<P>own errors in the education of his daughters was never



<P>to be entirely done away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Too late he became aware how unfavourable to the character



<P>of any young people must be the totally opposite treatment



<P>which Maria and Julia had been always experiencing at home,



<P>where the excessive indulgence and flattery of their aunt



<P>had been continually contrasted with his own severity.



<P>He saw how ill he had judged, in expecting to counteract



<P>what was wrong in Mrs. Norris by its reverse in himself;



<P>clearly saw that he had but increased the evil by teaching



<P>them to repress their spirits in his presence so as to make



<P>their real disposition unknown to him, and sending them



<P>for all their indulgences to a person who had been able



<P>to attach them only by the blindness of her affection,



<P>and the excess of her praise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here had been grievous mismanagement; but, bad as it was,



<P>he gradually grew to feel that it had not been the most



<P>direful mistake in his plan of education.&nbsp; Something must



<P>have been wanting _within_, or time would have worn



<P>away much of its ill effect.&nbsp; He feared that principle,



<P>active principle, had been wanting; that they had never



<P>been properly taught to govern their inclinations and



<P>tempers by that sense of duty which can alone suffice.



<P>They had been instructed theoretically in their religion,



<P>but never required to bring it into daily practice.



<P>To be distinguished for elegance and accomplishments,



<P>the authorised object of their youth, could have had no



<P>useful influence that way, no moral effect on the mind.



<P>He had meant them to be good, but his cares had been directed



<P>to the understanding and manners, not the disposition;



<P>and of the necessity of self-denial and humility,



<P>he feared they had never heard from any lips that could



<P>profit them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Bitterly did he deplore a deficiency which now he



<P>could scarcely comprehend to have been possible.



<P>Wretchedly did he feel, that with all the cost and care



<P>of an anxious and expensive education, he had brought up



<P>his daughters without their understanding their first duties,



<P>or his being acquainted with their character and temper.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The high spirit and strong passions of Mrs. Rushworth,



<P>especially, were made known to him only in their sad result.



<P>She was not to be prevailed on to leave Mr. Crawford.



<P>She hoped to marry him, and they continued together



<P>till she was obliged to be convinced that such hope



<P>was vain, and till the disappointment and wretchedness



<P>arising from the conviction rendered her temper so bad,



<P>and her feelings for him so like hatred, as to make them



<P>for a while each other's punishment, and then induce



<P>a voluntary separation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had lived with him to be reproached as the ruin



<P>of all his happiness in Fanny, and carried away no better



<P>consolation in leaving him than that she _had_ divided them.



<P>What can exceed the misery of such a mind in such a situation?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Rushworth had no difficulty in procuring a divorce;



<P>and so ended a marriage contracted under such circumstances



<P>as to make any better end the effect of good luck not to



<P>be reckoned on.&nbsp; She had despised him, and loved another;



<P>and he had been very much aware that it was so.



<P>The indignities of stupidity, and the disappointments



<P>of selfish passion, can excite little pity.&nbsp; His punishment



<P>followed his conduct, as did a deeper punishment the



<P>deeper guilt of his wife.&nbsp; _He_ was released from the



<P>engagement to be mortified and unhappy, till some other



<P>pretty girl could attract him into matrimony again,



<P>and he might set forward on a second, and, it is to



<P>be hoped, more prosperous trial of the state:&nbsp; if duped,



<P>to be duped at least with good humour and good luck;



<P>while she must withdraw with infinitely stronger feelings



<P>to a retirement and reproach which could allow no second



<P>spring of hope or character.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Where she could be placed became a subject of most



<P>melancholy and momentous consultation.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris,



<P>whose attachment seemed to augment with the demerits



<P>of her niece, would have had her received at home and



<P>countenanced by them all.&nbsp; Sir Thomas would not hear of it;



<P>and Mrs. Norris's anger against Fanny was so much the greater,



<P>from considering _her_ residence there as the motive.



<P>She persisted in placing his scruples to _her_ account,



<P>though Sir Thomas very solemnly assured her that,



<P>had there been no young woman in question, had there



<P>been no young person of either sex belonging to him,



<P>to be endangered by the society or hurt by the character



<P>of Mrs. Rushworth, he would never have offered so great an



<P>insult to the neighbourhood as to expect it to notice her.



<P>As a daughter, he hoped a penitent one, she should be



<P>protected by him, and secured in every comfort, and supported



<P>by every encouragement to do right, which their relative



<P>situations admitted; but farther than _that_ he could not go.



<P>Maria had destroyed her own character, and he would not,



<P>by a vain attempt to restore what never could be restored,



<P>by affording his sanction to vice, or in seeking to lessen



<P>its disgrace, be anywise accessory to introducing such



<P>misery in another man's family as he had known himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It ended in Mrs. Norris's resolving to quit Mansfield



<P>and devote herself to her unfortunate Maria, and in an



<P>establishment being formed for them in another country,



<P>remote and private, where, shut up together with little society,



<P>on one side no affection, on the other no judgment,



<P>it may be reasonably supposed that their tempers became



<P>their mutual punishment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris's removal from Mansfield was the great supplementary



<P>comfort of Sir Thomas's life.&nbsp; His opinion of her had



<P>been sinking from the day of his return from Antigua:



<P>in every transaction together from that period, in their



<P>daily intercourse, in business, or in chat, she had been



<P>regularly losing ground in his esteem, and convincing



<P>him that either time had done her much disservice,



<P>or that he had considerably over-rated her sense,



<P>and wonderfully borne with her manners before.&nbsp; He had



<P>felt her as an hourly evil, which was so much the worse,



<P>as there seemed no chance of its ceasing but with life;



<P>she seemed a part of himself that must be borne for ever.



<P>To be relieved from her, therefore, was so great a



<P>felicity that, had she not left bitter remembrances



<P>behind her, there might have been danger of his learning



<P>almost to approve the evil which produced such a good.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was regretted by no one at Mansfield.&nbsp; She had never



<P>been able to attach even those she loved best; and since



<P>Mrs. Rushworth's elopement, her temper had been in a state



<P>of such irritation as to make her everywhere tormenting.



<P>Not even Fanny had tears for aunt Norris, not even when



<P>she was gone for ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That Julia escaped better than Maria was owing, in some measure,



<P>to a favourable difference of disposition and circumstance,



<P>but in a greater to her having been less the darling



<P>of that very aunt, less flattered and less spoilt.



<P>Her beauty and acquirements had held but a second place.



<P>She had been always used to think herself a little inferior



<P>to Maria.&nbsp; Her temper was naturally the easiest of the two;



<P>her feelings, though quick, were more controllable,



<P>and education had not given her so very hurtful a degree



<P>of self-consequence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had submitted the best to the disappointment



<P>in Henry Crawford.&nbsp; After the first bitterness of the



<P>conviction of being slighted was over, she had been



<P>tolerably soon in a fair way of not thinking of him again;



<P>and when the acquaintance was renewed in town,



<P>and Mr. Rushworth's house became Crawford's object,



<P>she had had the merit of withdrawing herself from it,



<P>and of chusing that time to pay a visit to her other friends,



<P>in order to secure herself from being again too much attracted.



<P>This had been her motive in going to her cousin's.



<P>Mr. Yates's convenience had had nothing to do with it.



<P>She had been allowing his attentions some time,



<P>but with very little idea of ever accepting him;



<P>and had not her sister's conduct burst forth as it did,



<P>and her increased dread of her father and of home,



<P>on that event, imagining its certain consequence to herself



<P>would be greater severity and restraint, made her hastily



<P>resolve on avoiding such immediate horrors at all risks,



<P>it is probable that Mr. Yates would never have succeeded.



<P>She had not eloped with any worse feelings than those



<P>of selfish alarm.&nbsp; It had appeared to her the only



<P>thing to be done.&nbsp; Maria's guilt had induced Julia's folly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Henry Crawford, ruined by early independence and bad



<P>domestic example, indulged in the freaks of a cold-blooded



<P>vanity a little too long.&nbsp; Once it had, by an opening



<P>undesigned and unmerited, led him into the way of happiness.



<P>Could he have been satisfied with the conquest of one



<P>amiable woman's affections, could he have found sufficient



<P>exultation in overcoming the reluctance, in working himself



<P>into the esteem and tenderness of Fanny Price, there would



<P>have been every probability of success and felicity for him.



<P>His affection had already done something.&nbsp; Her influence



<P>over him had already given him some influence over her.



<P>Would he have deserved more, there can be no doubt



<P>that more would have been obtained, especially when



<P>that marriage had taken place, which would have given



<P>him the assistance of her conscience in subduing her



<P>first inclination, and brought them very often together.



<P>Would he have persevered, and uprightly, Fanny must have



<P>been his reward, and a reward very voluntarily bestowed,



<P>within a reasonable period from Edmund's marrying Mary.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Had he done as he intended, and as he knew he ought,



<P>by going down to Everingham after his return from Portsmouth,



<P>he might have been deciding his own happy destiny.



<P>But he was pressed to stay for Mrs. Fraser's party;



<P>his staying was made of flattering consequence, and he



<P>was to meet Mrs. Rushworth there.&nbsp; Curiosity and vanity



<P>were both engaged, and the temptation of immediate pleasure



<P>was too strong for a mind unused to make any sacrifice



<P>to right:&nbsp; he resolved to defer his Norfolk journey,



<P>resolved that writing should answer the purpose of it,



<P>or that its purpose was unimportant, and staid.&nbsp; He saw



<P>Mrs. Rushworth, was received by her with a coldness which



<P>ought to have been repulsive, and have established apparent



<P>indifference between them for ever; but he was mortified,



<P>he could not bear to be thrown off by the woman whose



<P>smiles had been so wholly at his command:&nbsp; he must exert



<P>himself to subdue so proud a display of resentment; it was



<P>anger on Fanny's account; he must get the better of it,



<P>and make Mrs. Rushworth Maria Bertram again in her treatment



<P>of himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In this spirit he began the attack, and by animated



<P>perseverance had soon re-established the sort of familiar



<P>intercourse, of gallantry, of flirtation, which bounded



<P>his views; but in triumphing over the discretion which,



<P>though beginning in anger, might have saved them both,



<P>he had put himself in the power of feelings on her side



<P>more strong than he had supposed.&nbsp; She loved him;



<P>there was no withdrawing attentions avowedly dear to her.



<P>He was entangled by his own vanity, with as little



<P>excuse of love as possible, and without the smallest



<P>inconstancy of mind towards her cousin.&nbsp; To keep Fanny



<P>and the Bertrams from a knowledge of what was passing



<P>became his first object.&nbsp; Secrecy could not have been



<P>more desirable for Mrs. Rushworth's credit than he



<P>felt it for his own.&nbsp; When he returned from Richmond,



<P>he would have been glad to see Mrs. Rushworth no more.



<P>All that followed was the result of her imprudence;



<P>and he went off with her at last, because he could



<P>not help it, regretting Fanny even at the moment,



<P>but regretting her infinitely more when all the bustle of



<P>the intrigue was over, and a very few months had taught him,



<P>by the force of contrast, to place a yet higher value



<P>on the sweetness of her temper, the purity of her mind,



<P>and the excellence of her principles.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That punishment, the public punishment of disgrace,



<P>should in a just measure attend _his_ share of the offence is,



<P>we know, not one of the barriers which society gives



<P>to virtue.&nbsp; In this world the penalty is less equal than



<P>could be wished; but without presuming to look forward



<P>to a juster appointment hereafter, we may fairly consider



<P>a man of sense, like Henry Crawford, to be providing



<P>for himself no small portion of vexation and regret:



<P>vexation that must rise sometimes to self-reproach, and



<P>regret to wretchedness, in having so requited hospitality,



<P>so injured family peace, so forfeited his best, most estimable,



<P>and endeared acquaintance, and so lost the woman whom



<P>he had rationally as well as passionately loved.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After what had passed to wound and alienate the two families,



<P>the continuance of the Bertrams and Grants in such



<P>close neighbourhood would have been most distressing;



<P>but the absence of the latter, for some months purposely



<P>lengthened, ended very fortunately in the necessity,



<P>or at least the practicability, of a permanent removal.



<P>Dr. Grant, through an interest on which he had almost



<P>ceased to form hopes, succeeded to a stall in Westminster,



<P>which, as affording an occasion for leaving Mansfield,



<P>an excuse for residence in London, and an increase of



<P>income to answer the expenses of the change, was highly



<P>acceptable to those who went and those who staid.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Grant, with a temper to love and be loved, must have



<P>gone with some regret from the scenes and people she



<P>had been used to; but the same happiness of disposition



<P>must in any place, and any society, secure her a great



<P>deal to enjoy, and she had again a home to offer Mary;



<P>and Mary had had enough of her own friends, enough of vanity,



<P>ambition, love, and disappointment in the course of the



<P>last half-year, to be in need of the true kindness of her



<P>sister's heart, and the rational tranquillity of her ways.



<P>They lived together; and when Dr. Grant had brought



<P>on apoplexy and death, by three great institutionary



<P>dinners in one week, they still lived together; for Mary,



<P>though perfectly resolved against ever attaching herself



<P>to a younger brother again, was long in finding among



<P>the dashing representatives, or idle heir-apparents,



<P>who were at the command of her beauty, and her 20,000,



<P>any one who could satisfy the better taste she had acquired



<P>at Mansfield, whose character and manners could authorise



<P>a hope of the domestic happiness she had there learned



<P>to estimate, or put Edmund Bertram sufficiently out of her head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund had greatly the advantage of her in this respect.



<P>He had not to wait and wish with vacant affections for an



<P>object worthy to succeed her in them.&nbsp; Scarcely had he



<P>done regretting Mary Crawford, and observing to Fanny



<P>how impossible it was that he should ever meet with such



<P>another woman, before it began to strike him whether



<P>a very different kind of woman might not do just as well,



<P>or a great deal better:&nbsp; whether Fanny herself were not



<P>growing as dear, as important to him in all her smiles



<P>and all her ways, as Mary Crawford had ever been;



<P>and whether it might not be a possible, an hopeful



<P>undertaking to persuade her that her warm and sisterly



<P>regard for him would be foundation enough for wedded love.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I purposely abstain from dates on this occasion,



<P>that every one may be at liberty to fix their own,



<P>aware that the cure of unconquerable passions, and the



<P>transfer of unchanging attachments, must vary much as



<P>to time in different people.&nbsp; I only entreat everybody



<P>to believe that exactly at the time when it was quite



<P>natural that it should be so, and not a week earlier,



<P>Edmund did cease to care about Miss Crawford, and became



<P>as anxious to marry Fanny as Fanny herself could desire.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With such a regard for her, indeed, as his had long been,



<P>a regard founded on the most endearing claims of innocence



<P>and helplessness, and completed by every recommendation



<P>of growing worth, what could be more natural than



<P>the change?&nbsp; Loving, guiding, protecting her, as he



<P>had been doing ever since her being ten years old,



<P>her mind in so great a degree formed by his care,



<P>and her comfort depending on his kindness, an object to him



<P>of such close and peculiar interest, dearer by all his



<P>own importance with her than any one else at Mansfield,



<P>what was there now to add, but that he should learn



<P>to prefer soft light eyes to sparkling dark ones.



<P>And being always with her, and always talking confidentially,



<P>and his feelings exactly in that favourable state



<P>which a recent disappointment gives, those soft light



<P>eyes could not be very long in obtaining the pre-eminence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having once set out, and felt that he had done so on



<P>this road to happiness, there was nothing on the side



<P>of prudence to stop him or make his progress slow;



<P>no doubts of her deserving, no fears of opposition of taste,



<P>no need of drawing new hopes of happiness from dissimilarity



<P>of temper.&nbsp; Her mind, disposition, opinions, and habits



<P>wanted no half-concealment, no self-deception on the present,



<P>no reliance on future improvement.&nbsp; Even in the midst



<P>of his late infatuation, he had acknowledged Fanny's



<P>mental superiority.&nbsp; What must be his sense of it now,



<P>therefore?&nbsp; She was of course only too good for him;



<P>but as nobody minds having what is too good for them,



<P>he was very steadily earnest in the pursuit of the blessing,



<P>and it was not possible that encouragement from her should



<P>be long wanting.&nbsp; Timid, anxious, doubting as she was,



<P>it was still impossible that such tenderness as hers



<P>should not, at times, hold out the strongest hope of success,



<P>though it remained for a later period to tell him the whole



<P>delightful and astonishing truth.&nbsp; His happiness in knowing



<P>himself to have been so long the beloved of such a heart,



<P>must have been great enough to warrant any strength of



<P>language in which he could clothe it to her or to himself;



<P>it must have been a delightful happiness.&nbsp; But there



<P>was happiness elsewhere which no description can reach.



<P>Let no one presume to give the feelings of a young woman



<P>on receiving the assurance of that affection of which



<P>she has scarcely allowed herself to entertain a hope.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their own inclinations ascertained, there were no



<P>difficulties behind, no drawback of poverty or parent.



<P>It was a match which Sir Thomas's wishes had even forestalled.



<P>Sick of ambitious and mercenary connexions, prizing more



<P>and more the sterling good of principle and temper,



<P>and chiefly anxious to bind by the strongest securities



<P>all that remained to him of domestic felicity, he had



<P>pondered with genuine satisfaction on the more than



<P>possibility of the two young friends finding their natural



<P>consolation in each other for all that had occurred



<P>of disappointment to either; and the joyful consent



<P>which met Edmund's application, the high sense of having



<P>realised a great acquisition in the promise of Fanny



<P>for a daughter, formed just such a contrast with his



<P>early opinion on the subject when the poor little girl's



<P>coming had been first agitated, as time is for ever



<P>producing between the plans and decisions of mortals,



<P>for their own instruction, and their neighbours' entertainment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was indeed the daughter that he wanted.&nbsp; His charitable



<P>kindness had been rearing a prime comfort for himself.



<P>His liberality had a rich repayment, and the general



<P>goodness of his intentions by her deserved it.&nbsp; He might



<P>have made her childhood happier; but it had been an error



<P>of judgment only which had given him the appearance



<P>of harshness, and deprived him of her early love;



<P>and now, on really knowing each other, their mutual



<P>attachment became very strong.&nbsp; After settling her at



<P>Thornton Lacey with every kind attention to her comfort,



<P>the object of almost every day was to see her there,



<P>or to get her away from it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Selfishly dear as she had long been to Lady Bertram,



<P>she could not be parted with willingly by _her_.



<P>No happiness of son or niece could make her wish



<P>the marriage.&nbsp; But it was possible to part with her,



<P>because Susan remained to supply her place.



<P>Susan became the stationary niece, delighted to be so;



<P>and equally well adapted for it by a readiness of mind,



<P>and an inclination for usefulness, as Fanny had been



<P>by sweetness of temper, and strong feelings of gratitude.



<P>Susan could never be spared.&nbsp; First as a comfort to Fanny,



<P>then as an auxiliary, and last as her substitute,



<P>she was established at Mansfield, with every appearance



<P>of equal permanency.&nbsp; Her more fearless disposition



<P>and happier nerves made everything easy to her there.



<P>With quickness in understanding the tempers of those she



<P>had to deal with, and no natural timidity to restrain



<P>any consequent wishes, she was soon welcome and useful



<P>to all; and after Fanny's removal succeeded so naturally



<P>to her influence over the hourly comfort of her aunt,



<P>as gradually to become, perhaps, the most beloved of the two.



<P>In _her_ usefulness, in Fanny's excellence, in William's



<P>continued good conduct and rising fame, and in the general



<P>well-doing and success of the other members of the family,



<P>all assisting to advance each other, and doing credit



<P>to his countenance and aid, Sir Thomas saw repeated,



<P>and for ever repeated, reason to rejoice in what he had



<P>done for them all, and acknowledge the advantages of early



<P>hardship and discipline, and the consciousness of being born



<P>to struggle and endure.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With so much true merit and true love, and no want of



<P>fortune and friends, the happiness of the married cousins



<P>must appear as secure as earthly happiness can be.



<P>Equally formed for domestic life, and attached to



<P>country pleasures, their home was the home of affection



<P>and comfort; and to complete the picture of good,



<P>the acquisition of Mansfield living, by the death of



<P>Dr. Grant, occurred just after they had been married long



<P>enough to begin to want an increase of income, and feel



<P>their distance from the paternal abode an inconvenience.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On that event they removed to Mansfield; and the Parsonage



<P>there, which, under each of its two former owners, Fanny had



<P>never been able to approach but with some painful sensation



<P>of restraint or alarm, soon grew as dear to her heart,



<P>and as thoroughly perfect in her eyes, as everything else



<P>within the view and patronage of Mansfield Park had long been.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>&lt;THE END>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 40</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XL</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Fanny was right enough in not expecting to hear from Miss



<P>Crawford now at the rapid rate in which their correspondence



<P>had begun; Mary's next letter was after a decidedly longer



<P>interval than the last, but she was not right in supposing



<P>that such an interval would be felt a great relief



<P>to herself.&nbsp; Here was another strange revolution of mind!



<P>She was really glad to receive the letter when it did come.



<P>In her present exile from good society, and distance from



<P>everything that had been wont to interest her, a letter



<P>from one belonging to the set where her heart lived,



<P>written with affection, and some degree of elegance,



<P>was thoroughly acceptable.&nbsp; The usual plea of increasing



<P>engagements was made in excuse for not having



<P>written to her earlier; "And now that I have begun,"



<P>she continued, "my letter will not be worth your reading,



<P>for there will be no little offering of love at the end,



<P>no three or four lines _passionnees_ from the most



<P>devoted H. C. in the world, for Henry is in Norfolk;



<P>business called him to Everingham ten days ago,



<P>or perhaps he only pretended to call, for the sake of being



<P>travelling at the same time that you were.&nbsp; But there



<P>he is, and, by the bye, his absence may sufficiently account



<P>for any remissness of his sister's in writing, for there



<P>has been no 'Well, Mary, when do you write to Fanny?



<P>Is not it time for you to write to Fanny?' to spur me on.



<P>At last, after various attempts at meeting, I have seen



<P>your cousins, 'dear Julia and dearest Mrs. Rushworth';



<P>they found me at home yesterday, and we were glad to



<P>see each other again.&nbsp; We _seemed_ _very_ glad to see



<P>each other, and I do really think we were a little.



<P>We had a vast deal to say.&nbsp; Shall I tell you how



<P>Mrs. Rushworth looked when your name was mentioned?



<P>I did not use to think her wanting in self-possession,



<P>but she had not quite enough for the demands of yesterday.



<P>Upon the whole, Julia was in the best looks of the two,



<P>at least after you were spoken of.&nbsp; There was no



<P>recovering the complexion from the moment that I spoke



<P>of 'Fanny,' and spoke of her as a sister should.



<P>But Mrs. Rushworth's day of good looks will come;



<P>we have cards for her first party on the 28th.&nbsp; Then she



<P>will be in beauty, for she will open one of the best



<P>houses in Wimpole Street.&nbsp; I was in it two years ago,



<P>when it was Lady Lascelle's, and prefer it to almost



<P>any I know in London, and certainly she will then feel,



<P>to use a vulgar phrase, that she has got her pennyworth



<P>for her penny.&nbsp; Henry could not have afforded her such



<P>a house.&nbsp; I hope she will recollect it, and be satisfied,



<P>as well as she may, with moving the queen of a palace,



<P>though the king may appear best in the background;



<P>and as I have no desire to tease her, I shall never _force_



<P>your name upon her again.&nbsp; She will grow sober by degrees.



<P>From all that I hear and guess, Baron Wildenheim's



<P>attentions to Julia continue, but I do not know that he



<P>has any serious encouragement.&nbsp; She ought to do better.



<P>A poor honourable is no catch, and I cannot imagine any



<P>liking in the case, for take away his rants, and the poor



<P>baron has nothing.&nbsp; What a difference a vowel makes!



<P>If his rents were but equal to his rants!&nbsp; Your cousin



<P>Edmund moves slowly; detained, perchance, by parish duties.



<P>There may be some old woman at Thornton Lacey to be converted.



<P>I am unwilling to fancy myself neglected for a _young_ one.



<P>Adieu! my dear sweet Fanny, this is a long letter from London:



<P>write me a pretty one in reply to gladden Henry's eyes,



<P>when he comes back, and send me an account of all the dashing



<P>young captains whom you disdain for his sake."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was great food for meditation in this letter,



<P>and chiefly for unpleasant meditation; and yet, with all



<P>the uneasiness it supplied, it connected her with the absent,



<P>it told her of people and things about whom she had never



<P>felt so much curiosity as now, and she would have been



<P>glad to have been sure of such a letter every week.



<P>Her correspondence with her aunt Bertram was her only



<P>concern of higher interest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As for any society in Portsmouth, that could at all make



<P>amends for deficiencies at home, there were none within



<P>the circle of her father's and mother's acquaintance



<P>to afford her the smallest satisfaction:&nbsp; she saw nobody



<P>in whose favour she could wish to overcome her own



<P>shyness and reserve.&nbsp; The men appeared to her all coarse,



<P>the women all pert, everybody underbred; and she gave



<P>as little contentment as she received from introductions



<P>either to old or new acquaintance.&nbsp; The young ladies who



<P>approached her at first with some respect, in consideration



<P>of her coming from a baronet's family, were soon offended



<P>by what they termed "airs"; for, as she neither played



<P>on the pianoforte nor wore fine pelisses, they could,



<P>on farther observation, admit no right of superiority.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The first solid consolation which Fanny received for



<P>the evils of home, the first which her judgment could



<P>entirely approve, and which gave any promise of durability,



<P>was in a better knowledge of Susan, and a hope of being



<P>of service to her.&nbsp; Susan had always behaved pleasantly



<P>to herself, but the determined character of her general



<P>manners had astonished and alarmed her, and it was at least



<P>a fortnight before she began to understand a disposition



<P>so totally different from her own.&nbsp; Susan saw that much



<P>was wrong at home, and wanted to set it right.&nbsp; That a girl



<P>of fourteen, acting only on her own unassisted reason,



<P>should err in the method of reform, was not wonderful;



<P>and Fanny soon became more disposed to admire the natural



<P>light of the mind which could so early distinguish justly,



<P>than to censure severely the faults of conduct to which it led.



<P>Susan was only acting on the same truths, and pursuing



<P>the same system, which her own judgment acknowledged,



<P>but which her more supine and yielding temper would



<P>have shrunk from asserting.&nbsp; Susan tried to be useful,



<P>where _she_ could only have gone away and cried; and that



<P>Susan was useful she could perceive; that things, bad as



<P>they were, would have been worse but for such interposition,



<P>and that both her mother and Betsey were restrained from



<P>some excesses of very offensive indulgence and vulgarity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In every argument with her mother, Susan had in point



<P>of reason the advantage, and never was there any maternal



<P>tenderness to buy her off.&nbsp; The blind fondness which was



<P>for ever producing evil around her she had never known.



<P>There was no gratitude for affection past or present



<P>to make her better bear with its excesses to the others.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All this became gradually evident, and gradually placed



<P>Susan before her sister as an object of mingled compassion



<P>and respect.&nbsp; That her manner was wrong, however, at times



<P>very wrong, her measures often ill-chosen and ill-timed,



<P>and her looks and language very often indefensible,



<P>Fanny could not cease to feel; but she began to hope they



<P>might be rectified.&nbsp; Susan, she found, looked up to her



<P>and wished for her good opinion; and new as anything like an



<P>office of authority was to Fanny, new as it was to imagine



<P>herself capable of guiding or informing any one, she did



<P>resolve to give occasional hints to Susan, and endeavour



<P>to exercise for her advantage the juster notions of what was



<P>due to everybody, and what would be wisest for herself,



<P>which her own more favoured education had fixed in her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her influence, or at least the consciousness and use of it,



<P>originated in an act of kindness by Susan, which, after many



<P>hesitations of delicacy, she at last worked herself up to.



<P>It had very early occurred to her that a small sum



<P>of money might, perhaps, restore peace for ever on the



<P>sore subject of the silver knife, canvassed as it now



<P>was continually, and the riches which she was in possession



<P>of herself, her uncle having given her 10 at parting,



<P>made her as able as she was willing to be generous.



<P>But she was so wholly unused to confer favours,



<P>except on the very poor, so unpractised in removing evils,



<P>or bestowing kindnesses among her equals, and so fearful



<P>of appearing to elevate herself as a great lady at home,



<P>that it took some time to determine that it would not be



<P>unbecoming in her to make such a present.&nbsp; It was made,



<P>however, at last:&nbsp; a silver knife was bought for Betsey,



<P>and accepted with great delight, its newness giving it



<P>every advantage over the other that could be desired;



<P>Susan was established in the full possession of her own,



<P>Betsey handsomely declaring that now she had got one so much



<P>prettier herself, she should never want _that_ again; and no



<P>reproach seemed conveyed to the equally satisfied mother,



<P>which Fanny had almost feared to be impossible.&nbsp; The deed



<P>thoroughly answered:&nbsp; a source of domestic altercation



<P>was entirely done away, and it was the means of opening



<P>Susan's heart to her, and giving her something more to love



<P>and be interested in.&nbsp; Susan shewed that she had delicacy:



<P>pleased as she was to be mistress of property which she



<P>had been struggling for at least two years, she yet



<P>feared that her sister's judgment had been against her,



<P>and that a reproof was designed her for having so struggled



<P>as to make the purchase necessary for the tranquillity of



<P>the house.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her temper was open.&nbsp; She acknowledged her fears,



<P>blamed herself for having contended so warmly;



<P>and from that hour Fanny, understanding the worth of her



<P>disposition and perceiving how fully she was inclined



<P>to seek her good opinion and refer to her judgment,



<P>began to feel again the blessing of affection, and to



<P>entertain the hope of being useful to a mind so much in



<P>need of help, and so much deserving it.&nbsp; She gave advice,



<P>advice too sound to be resisted by a good understanding,



<P>and given so mildly and considerately as not to irritate



<P>an imperfect temper, and she had the happiness of observing



<P>its good effects not unfrequently.&nbsp; More was not expected



<P>by one who, while seeing all the obligation and expediency



<P>of submission and forbearance, saw also with sympathetic



<P>acuteness of feeling all that must be hourly grating



<P>to a girl like Susan.&nbsp; Her greatest wonder on the subject



<P>soon became--not that Susan should have been provoked into



<P>disrespect and impatience against her better knowledge--



<P>but that so much better knowledge, so many good notions



<P>should have been hers at all; and that, brought up in the



<P>midst of negligence and error, she should have formed



<P>such proper opinions of what ought to be; she, who had



<P>had no cousin Edmund to direct her thoughts or fix her principles.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The intimacy thus begun between them was a material



<P>advantage to each.&nbsp; By sitting together upstairs,



<P>they avoided a great deal of the disturbance of the house;



<P>Fanny had peace, and Susan learned to think it no



<P>misfortune to be quietly employed.&nbsp; They sat without



<P>a fire; but that was a privation familiar even to Fanny,



<P>and she suffered the less because reminded by it of



<P>the East room.&nbsp; It was the only point of resemblance.



<P>In space, light, furniture, and prospect, there was nothing



<P>alike in the two apartments; and she often heaved a sigh



<P>at the remembrance of all her books and boxes, and various



<P>comforts there.&nbsp; By degrees the girls came to spend the



<P>chief of the morning upstairs, at first only in working



<P>and talking, but after a few days, the remembrance of the



<P>said books grew so potent and stimulative that Fanny found



<P>it impossible not to try for books again.&nbsp; There were none



<P>in her father's house; but wealth is luxurious and daring,



<P>and some of hers found its way to a circulating library.



<P>She became a subscriber; amazed at being anything _in_



<P>_propria_ _persona_, amazed at her own doings in every way,



<P>to be a renter, a chuser of books!&nbsp; And to be having any



<P>one's improvement in view in her choice!&nbsp; But so it was.



<P>Susan had read nothing, and Fanny longed to give her



<P>a share in her own first pleasures, and inspire a taste



<P>for the biography and poetry which she delighted in herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In this occupation she hoped, moreover, to bury some



<P>of the recollections of Mansfield, which were too apt



<P>to seize her mind if her fingers only were busy;



<P>and, especially at this time, hoped it might be useful



<P>in diverting her thoughts from pursuing Edmund to London,



<P>whither, on the authority of her aunt's last letter,



<P>she knew he was gone.&nbsp; She had no doubt of what would ensue.



<P>The promised notification was hanging over her head.



<P>The postman's knock within the neighbourhood was beginning



<P>to bring its daily terrors, and if reading could banish



<P>the idea for even half an hour, it was something gained.



<P>

   <TITLE>Chapter 41</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XLI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>A week was gone since Edmund might be supposed



<P>in town, and Fanny had heard nothing of him.



<P>There were three different conclusions to be drawn from



<P>his silence, between which her mind was in fluctuation;



<P>each of them at times being held the most probable.



<P>Either his going had been again delayed, or he had yet



<P>procured no opportunity of seeing Miss Crawford alone,



<P>or he was too happy for letter-writing!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>One morning, about this time, Fanny having now been nearly



<P>four weeks from Mansfield, a point which she never failed



<P>to think over and calculate every day, as she and Susan



<P>were preparing to remove, as usual, upstairs, they were



<P>stopped by the knock of a visitor, whom they felt they could



<P>not avoid, from Rebecca's alertness in going to the door,



<P>a duty which always interested her beyond any other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a gentleman's voice; it was a voice that Fanny



<P>was just turning pale about, when Mr. Crawford walked



<P>into the room.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Good sense, like hers, will always act when really



<P>called upon; and she found that she had been able to name



<P>him to her mother, and recall her remembrance of the name,



<P>as that of "William's friend," though she could not



<P>previously have believed herself capable of uttering a



<P>syllable at such a moment.&nbsp; The consciousness of his being



<P>known there only as William's friend was some support.



<P>Having introduced him, however, and being all reseated,



<P>the terrors that occurred of what this visit might lead



<P>to were overpowering, and she fancied herself on the point



<P>of fainting away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While trying to keep herself alive, their visitor, who had



<P>at first approached her with as animated a countenance



<P>as ever, was wisely and kindly keeping his eyes away,



<P>and giving her time to recover, while he devoted himself



<P>entirely to her mother, addressing her, and attending to



<P>her with the utmost politeness and propriety, at the same



<P>time with a degree of friendliness, of interest at least,



<P>which was making his manner perfect.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Price's manners were also at their best.&nbsp; Warmed by



<P>the sight of such a friend to her son, and regulated



<P>by the wish of appearing to advantage before him, she was



<P>overflowing with gratitude--artless, maternal gratitude--



<P>which could not be unpleasing.&nbsp; Mr. Price was out,



<P>which she regretted very much.&nbsp; Fanny was just recovered



<P>enough to feel that _she_ could not regret it; for to her



<P>many other sources of uneasiness was added the severe



<P>one of shame for the home in which he found her.



<P>She might scold herself for the weakness, but there was



<P>no scolding it away.&nbsp; She was ashamed, and she would have



<P>been yet more ashamed of her father than of all the rest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They talked of William, a subject on which Mrs. Price



<P>could never tire; and Mr. Crawford was as warm in his



<P>commendation as even her heart could wish.&nbsp; She felt



<P>that she had never seen so agreeable a man in her life;



<P>and was only astonished to find that, so great and so



<P>agreeable as he was, he should be come down to Portsmouth



<P>neither on a visit to the port-admiral, nor the commissioner,



<P>nor yet with the intention of going over to the island,



<P>nor of seeing the dockyard.&nbsp; Nothing of all that she



<P>had been used to think of as the proof of importance,



<P>or the employment of wealth, had brought him to Portsmouth.



<P>He had reached it late the night before, was come for a



<P>day or two, was staying at the Crown, had accidentally



<P>met with a navy officer or two of his acquaintance since



<P>his arrival, but had no object of that kind in coming.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By the time he had given all this information, it was not



<P>unreasonable to suppose that Fanny might be looked at



<P>and spoken to; and she was tolerably able to bear his eye,



<P>and hear that he had spent half an hour with his sister



<P>the evening before his leaving London; that she had sent



<P>her best and kindest love, but had had no time for writing;



<P>that he thought himself lucky in seeing Mary for even half



<P>an hour, having spent scarcely twenty-four hours in London,



<P>after his return from Norfolk, before he set off again;



<P>that her cousin Edmund was in town, had been in town,



<P>he understood, a few days; that he had not seen him himself,



<P>but that he was well, had left them all well at Mansfield,



<P>and was to dine, as yesterday, with the Frasers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny listened collectedly, even to the last-mentioned



<P>circumstance; nay, it seemed a relief to her worn



<P>mind to be at any certainty; and the words, "then by



<P>this time it is all settled," passed internally,



<P>without more evidence of emotion than a faint blush

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After talking a little more about Mansfield, a subject



<P>in which her interest was most apparent, Crawford began



<P>to hint at the expediency of an early walk.&nbsp; "It was a



<P>lovely morning, and at that season of the year a fine morning



<P>so often turned off, that it was wisest for everybody not



<P>to delay their exercise"; and such hints producing nothing,



<P>he soon proceeded to a positive recommendation to Mrs. Price



<P>and her daughters to take their walk without loss of time.



<P>Now they came to an understanding.&nbsp; Mrs. Price, it appeared,



<P>scarcely ever stirred out of doors, except of a Sunday;



<P>she owned she could seldom, with her large family,



<P>find time for a walk.&nbsp; "Would she not, then, persuade her



<P>daughters to take advantage of such weather, and allow



<P>him the pleasure of attending them?"&nbsp; Mrs. Price was



<P>greatly obliged and very complying.&nbsp; "Her daughters



<P>were very much confined; Portsmouth was a sad place;



<P>they did not often get out; and she knew they had some



<P>errands in the town, which they would be very glad to do."



<P>And the consequence was, that Fanny, strange as it was--



<P>strange, awkward, and distressing--found herself and Susan,



<P>within ten minutes, walking towards the High Street



<P>with Mr. Crawford.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was soon pain upon pain, confusion upon confusion;



<P>for they were hardly in the High Street before they met



<P>her father, whose appearance was not the better from its



<P>being Saturday.&nbsp; He stopt; and, ungentlemanlike as he looked,



<P>Fanny was obliged to introduce him to Mr. Crawford.



<P>She could not have a doubt of the manner in which



<P>Mr. Crawford must be struck.&nbsp; He must be ashamed



<P>and disgusted altogether.&nbsp; He must soon give her up,



<P>and cease to have the smallest inclination for the match;



<P>and yet, though she had been so much wanting his affection



<P>to be cured, this was a sort of cure that would be almost



<P>as bad as the complaint; and I believe there is scarcely



<P>a young lady in the United Kingdoms who would not rather



<P>put up with the misfortune of being sought by a clever,



<P>agreeable man, than have him driven away by the vulgarity



<P>of her nearest relations.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Crawford probably could not regard his future



<P>father-in-law with any idea of taking him for a model



<P>in dress; but (as Fanny instantly, and to her great



<P>relief, discerned) her father was a very different man,



<P>a very different Mr. Price in his behaviour to this most



<P>highly respected stranger, from what he was in his own



<P>family at home.&nbsp; His manners now, though not polished,



<P>were more than passable:&nbsp; they were grateful, animated, manly;



<P>his expressions were those of an attached father,



<P>and a sensible man; his loud tones did very well in the



<P>open air, and there was not a single oath to be heard.



<P>Such was his instinctive compliment to the good manners



<P>of Mr. Crawford; and, be the consequence what it might,



<P>Fanny's immediate feelings were infinitely soothed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The conclusion of the two gentlemen's civilities was an offer



<P>of Mr. Price's to take Mr. Crawford into the dockyard,



<P>which Mr. Crawford, desirous of accepting as a favour



<P>what was intended as such, though he had seen the dockyard



<P>again and again, and hoping to be so much the longer



<P>with Fanny, was very gratefully disposed to avail himself of,



<P>if the Miss Prices were not afraid of the fatigue;



<P>and as it was somehow or other ascertained, or inferred,



<P>or at least acted upon, that they were not at all afraid,



<P>to the dockyard they were all to go; and but for



<P>Mr. Crawford, Mr. Price would have turned thither directly,



<P>without the smallest consideration for his daughters'



<P>errands in the High Street.&nbsp; He took care, however, that they



<P>should be allowed to go to the shops they came out expressly



<P>to visit; and it did not delay them long, for Fanny could



<P>so little bear to excite impatience, or be waited for,



<P>that before the gentlemen, as they stood at the door,



<P>could do more than begin upon the last naval regulations,



<P>or settle the number of three-deckers now in commission,



<P>their companions were ready to proceed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were then to set forward for the dockyard at once,



<P>and the walk would have been conducted--according to



<P>Mr. Crawford's opinion--in a singular manner,



<P>had Mr. Price been allowed the entire regulation of it,



<P>as the two girls, he found, would have been left



<P>to follow, and keep up with them or not, as they could,



<P>while they walked on together at their own hasty pace.



<P>He was able to introduce some improvement occasionally,



<P>though by no means to the extent he wished; he absolutely



<P>would not walk away from them; and at any crossing



<P>or any crowd, when Mr. Price was only calling out,



<P>"Come, girls; come, Fan; come, Sue, take care of yourselves;



<P>keep a sharp lookout!" he would give them his particular



<P>attendance.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Once fairly in the dockyard, he began to reckon upon



<P>some happy intercourse with Fanny, as they were very soon



<P>joined by a brother lounger of Mr. Price's, who was come



<P>to take his daily survey of how things went on, and who



<P>must prove a far more worthy companion than himself;



<P>and after a time the two officers seemed very well satisfied



<P>going about together, and discussing matters of equal



<P>and never-failing interest, while the young people sat down



<P>upon some timbers in the yard, or found a seat on board



<P>a vessel in the stocks which they all went to look at.



<P>Fanny was most conveniently in want of rest.&nbsp; Crawford could



<P>not have wished her more fatigued or more ready to sit down;



<P>but he could have wished her sister away.&nbsp; A quick-looking



<P>girl of Susan's age was the very worst third in the world:



<P>totally different from Lady Bertram, all eyes and ears;



<P>and there was no introducing the main point before her.



<P>He must content himself with being only generally agreeable,



<P>and letting Susan have her share of entertainment,



<P>with the indulgence, now and then, of a look or hint



<P>for the better-informed and conscious Fanny.&nbsp; Norfolk was



<P>what he had mostly to talk of:&nbsp; there he had been some time,



<P>and everything there was rising in importance from his



<P>present schemes.&nbsp; Such a man could come from no place,



<P>no society, without importing something to amuse;



<P>his journeys and his acquaintance were all of use,



<P>and Susan was entertained in a way quite new to her.



<P>For Fanny, somewhat more was related than the accidental



<P>agreeableness of the parties he had been in.



<P>For her approbation, the particular reason of his going into



<P>Norfolk at all, at this unusual time of year, was given.



<P>It had been real business, relative to the renewal of a



<P>lease in which the welfare of a large and--he believed--



<P>industrious family was at stake.&nbsp; He had suspected his



<P>agent of some underhand dealing; of meaning to bias him



<P>against the deserving; and he had determined to go himself,



<P>and thoroughly investigate the merits of the case.



<P>He had gone, had done even more good than he had foreseen,



<P>had been useful to more than his first plan had comprehended,



<P>and was now able to congratulate himself upon it, and to



<P>feel that in performing a duty, he had secured agreeable



<P>recollections for his own mind.&nbsp; He had introduced himself



<P>to some tenants whom he had never seen before; he had begun



<P>making acquaintance with cottages whose very existence,



<P>though on his own estate, had been hitherto unknown to him.



<P>This was aimed, and well aimed, at Fanny.&nbsp; It was pleasing



<P>to hear him speak so properly; here he had been acting



<P>as he ought to do.&nbsp; To be the friend of the poor and



<P>the oppressed!&nbsp; Nothing could be more grateful to her;



<P>and she was on the point of giving him an approving look,



<P>when it was all frightened off by his adding a something



<P>too pointed of his hoping soon to have an assistant,



<P>a friend, a guide in every plan of utility or charity



<P>for Everingham:&nbsp; a somebody that would make Everingham



<P>and all about it a dearer object than it had ever been



<P>yet.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She turned away, and wished he would not say such things.



<P>She was willing to allow he might have more good



<P>qualities than she had been wont to suppose.&nbsp; She began



<P>to feel the possibility of his turning out well at last;



<P>but he was and must ever be completely unsuited to her,



<P>and ought not to think of her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He perceived that enough had been said of Everingham,



<P>and that it would be as well to talk of something else,



<P>and turned to Mansfield.&nbsp; He could not have chosen better;



<P>that was a topic to bring back her attention and her looks



<P>almost instantly.&nbsp; It was a real indulgence to her to hear



<P>or to speak of Mansfield.&nbsp; Now so long divided from



<P>everybody who knew the place, she felt it quite the voice



<P>of a friend when he mentioned it, and led the way to her



<P>fond exclamations in praise of its beauties and comforts,



<P>and by his honourable tribute to its inhabitants allowed



<P>her to gratify her own heart in the warmest eulogium,



<P>in speaking of her uncle as all that was clever and good,



<P>and her aunt as having the sweetest of all sweet tempers.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had a great attachment to Mansfield himself; he said so;



<P>he looked forward with the hope of spending much, very much,



<P>of his time there; always there, or in the neighbourhood.



<P>He particularly built upon a very happy summer and



<P>autumn there this year; he felt that it would be so:



<P>he depended upon it; a summer and autumn infinitely superior



<P>to the last.&nbsp; As animated, as diversified, as social,



<P>but with circumstances of superiority undescribable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mansfield, Sotherton, Thornton Lacey," he continued;



<P>"what a society will be comprised in those houses!



<P>And at Michaelmas, perhaps, a fourth may be added:



<P>some small hunting-box in the vicinity of everything so dear;



<P>for as to any partnership in Thornton Lacey, as Edmund



<P>Bertram once good-humouredly proposed, I hope I foresee



<P>two objections:&nbsp; two fair, excellent, irresistible objections



<P>to that plan."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was doubly silenced here; though when the moment



<P>was passed, could regret that she had not forced herself into



<P>the acknowledged comprehension of one half of his meaning,



<P>and encouraged him to say something more of his sister



<P>and Edmund.&nbsp; It was a subject which she must learn to speak of,



<P>and the weakness that shrunk from it would soon be quite



<P>unpardonable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When Mr. Price and his friend had seen all that they wished,



<P>or had time for, the others were ready to return;



<P>and in the course of their walk back, Mr. Crawford contrived



<P>a minute's privacy for telling Fanny that his only



<P>business in Portsmouth was to see her; that he was come



<P>down for a couple of days on her account, and hers only,



<P>and because he could not endure a longer total separation.



<P>She was sorry, really sorry; and yet in spite of this and the



<P>two or three other things which she wished he had not said,



<P>she thought him altogether improved since she had seen him;



<P>he was much more gentle, obliging, and attentive to other



<P>people's feelings than he had ever been at Mansfield;



<P>she had never seen him so agreeable--so _near_ being agreeable;



<P>his behaviour to her father could not offend, and there



<P>was something particularly kind and proper in the notice



<P>he took of Susan.&nbsp; He was decidedly improved.&nbsp; She wished



<P>the next day over, she wished he had come only for one day;



<P>but it was not so very bad as she would have expected:



<P>the pleasure of talking of Mansfield was so very great!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Before they parted, she had to thank him for another pleasure,



<P>and one of no trivial kind.&nbsp; Her father asked him to do



<P>them the honour of taking his mutton with them, and Fanny



<P>had time for only one thrill of horror, before he declared



<P>himself prevented by a prior engagement.&nbsp; He was engaged



<P>to dinner already both for that day and the next; he had met



<P>with some acquaintance at the Crown who would not be denied;



<P>he should have the honour, however, of waiting on them



<P>again on the morrow, etc., and so they parted--Fanny in



<P>a state of actual felicity from escaping so horrible an evil!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To have had him join their family dinner-party, and see



<P>all their deficiencies, would have been dreadful!



<P>Rebecca's cookery and Rebecca's waiting, and Betsey's



<P>eating at table without restraint, and pulling everything



<P>about as she chose, were what Fanny herself was not yet



<P>enough inured to for her often to make a tolerable meal.



<P>_She_ was nice only from natural delicacy, but _he_ had been



<P>brought up in a school of luxury and epicurism.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 43</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XLIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>It was presumed that Mr. Crawford was travelling back,



<P>to London, on the morrow, for nothing more was seen



<P>of him at Mr. Price's; and two days afterwards, it was



<P>a fact ascertained to Fanny by the following letter from



<P>his sister, opened and read by her, on another account,



<P>with the most anxious curiosity:--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have to inform you, my dearest Fanny, that Henry



<P>has been down to Portsmouth to see you; that he had a



<P>delightful walk with you to the dockyard last Saturday,



<P>and one still more to be dwelt on the next day,



<P>on the ramparts; when the balmy air, the sparkling sea,



<P>and your sweet looks and conversation were altogether



<P>in the most delicious harmony, and afforded sensations



<P>which are to raise ecstasy even in retrospect.&nbsp; This, as well



<P>as I understand, is to be the substance of my information.



<P>He makes me write, but I do not know what else is to



<P>be communicated, except this said visit to Portsmouth,



<P>and these two said walks, and his introduction to



<P>your family, especially to a fair sister of yours, a fine



<P>girl of fifteen, who was of the party on the ramparts,



<P>taking her first lesson, I presume, in love.&nbsp; I have



<P>not time for writing much, but it would be out of place



<P>if I had, for this is to be a mere letter of business,



<P>penned for the purpose of conveying necessary information,



<P>which could not be delayed without risk of evil.&nbsp; My dear,



<P>dear Fanny, if I had you here, how I would talk to you!



<P>You should listen to me till you were tired, and advise



<P>me till you were still tired more; but it is impossible



<P>to put a hundredth part of my great mind on paper,



<P>so I will abstain altogether, and leave you to guess what



<P>you like.&nbsp; I have no news for you.&nbsp; You have politics,



<P>of course; and it would be too bad to plague you with



<P>the names of people and parties that fill up my time.



<P>I ought to have sent you an account of your cousin's



<P>first party, but I was lazy, and now it is too long ago;



<P>suffice it, that everything was just as it ought to be,



<P>in a style that any of her connexions must have been



<P>gratified to witness, and that her own dress and manners did



<P>her the greatest credit.&nbsp; My friend, Mrs. Fraser, is mad



<P>for such a house, and it would not make _me_ miserable.



<P>I go to Lady Stornaway after Easter; she seems in high spirits,



<P>and very happy.&nbsp; I fancy Lord S. is very good-humoured



<P>and pleasant in his own family, and I do not think him so



<P>very ill-looking as I did--at least, one sees many worse.



<P>He will not do by the side of your cousin Edmund.



<P>Of the last-mentioned hero, what shall I say?&nbsp; If I



<P>avoided his name entirely, it would look suspicious.



<P>I will say, then, that we have seen him two or three times,



<P>and that my friends here are very much struck with his



<P>gentlemanlike appearance.&nbsp; Mrs. Fraser (no bad judge)



<P>declares she knows but three men in town who have so good



<P>a person, height, and air; and I must confess, when he dined



<P>here the other day, there were none to compare with him,



<P>and we were a party of sixteen.&nbsp; Luckily there is no



<P>distinction of dress nowadays to tell tales, but--but--



<P>but Yours affectionately."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>I had almost forgot (it was Edmund's fault:&nbsp; he gets into



<P>my head more than does me good) one very material thing I



<P>had to say from Henry and myself--I mean about our taking



<P>you back into Northamptonshire.&nbsp; My dear little creature,



<P>do not stay at Portsmouth to lose your pretty looks.



<P>Those vile sea-breezes are the ruin of beauty and health.



<P>My poor aunt always felt affected if within ten miles



<P>of the sea, which the Admiral of course never believed,



<P>but I know it was so.&nbsp; I am at your service and Henry's,



<P>at an hour's notice.&nbsp; I should like the scheme, and we would



<P>make a little circuit, and shew you Everingham in our way,



<P>and perhaps you would not mind passing through London,



<P>and seeing the inside of St. George's, Hanover Square.



<P>Only keep your cousin Edmund from me at such a time:



<P>I should not like to be tempted.&nbsp; What a long letter!



<P>one word more.&nbsp; Henry, I find, has some idea of going



<P>into Norfolk again upon some business that _you_ approve;



<P>but this cannot possibly be permitted before the middle



<P>of next week; that is, he cannot anyhow be spared till



<P>after the l4th, for _we_ have a party that evening.



<P>The value of a man like Henry, on such an occasion,



<P>is what you can have no conception of; so you must take it



<P>upon my word to be inestimable.&nbsp; He will see the Rushworths,



<P>which own I am not sorry for--having a little curiosity,



<P>and so I think has he--though he will not acknowledge



<P>it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was a letter to be run through eagerly, to be



<P>read deliberately, to supply matter for much reflection,



<P>and to leave everything in greater suspense than ever.



<P>The only certainty to be drawn from it was, that nothing



<P>decisive had yet taken place.&nbsp; Edmund had not yet spoken.



<P>How Miss Crawford really felt, how she meant to act,



<P>or might act without or against her meaning; whether his



<P>importance to her were quite what it had been before



<P>the last separation; whether, if lessened, it were likely



<P>to lessen more, or to recover itself, were subjects



<P>for endless conjecture, and to be thought of on that day



<P>and many days to come, without producing any conclusion.



<P>The idea that returned the oftenest was that Miss Crawford,



<P>after proving herself cooled and staggered by a return



<P>to London habits, would yet prove herself in the end



<P>too much attached to him to give him up.&nbsp; She would



<P>try to be more ambitious than her heart would allow.



<P>She would hesitate, she would tease, she would condition,



<P>she would require a great deal, but she would finally



<P>accept.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was Fanny's most frequent expectation.&nbsp; A house



<P>in town--that, she thought, must be impossible.



<P>Yet there was no saying what Miss Crawford might not ask.



<P>The prospect for her cousin grew worse and worse.



<P>The woman who could speak of him, and speak only of



<P>his appearance!&nbsp; What an unworthy attachment!&nbsp; To be



<P>deriving support from the commendations of Mrs. Fraser!



<P>_She_ who had known him intimately half a year!



<P>Fanny was ashamed of her.&nbsp; Those parts of the letter which



<P>related only to Mr. Crawford and herself, touched her,



<P>in comparison, slightly.&nbsp; Whether Mr. Crawford went



<P>into Norfolk before or after the 14th was certainly



<P>no concern of hers, though, everything considered,



<P>she thought he _would_ go without delay.&nbsp; That Miss



<P>Crawford should endeavour to secure a meeting between him



<P>and Mrs. Rushworth, was all in her worst line of conduct,



<P>and grossly unkind and ill-judged; but she hoped _he_



<P>would not be actuated by any such degrading curiosity.



<P>He acknowledged no such inducement, and his sister



<P>ought to have given him credit for better feelings than



<P>her own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was yet more impatient for another letter from



<P>town after receiving this than she had been before;



<P>and for a few days was so unsettled by it altogether,



<P>by what had come, and what might come, that her usual



<P>readings and conversation with Susan were much suspended.



<P>She could not command her attention as she wished.



<P>If Mr. Crawford remembered her message to her cousin,



<P>she thought it very likely, most likely, that he would write



<P>to her at all events; it would be most consistent with his



<P>usual kindness; and till she got rid of this idea, till it



<P>gradually wore off, by no letters appearing in the course



<P>of three or four days more, she was in a most restless,



<P>anxious state

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At length, a something like composure succeeded.



<P>Suspense must be submitted to, and must not be allowed



<P>to wear her out, and make her useless.&nbsp; Time did something,



<P>her own exertions something more, and she resumed her



<P>attentions to Susan, and again awakened the same interest



<P>in them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Susan was growing very fond of her, and though without



<P>any of the early delight in books which had been



<P>so strong in Fanny, with a disposition much less



<P>inclined to sedentary pursuits, or to information for



<P>information's sake, she had so strong a desire of not



<P>_appearing_ ignorant, as, with a good clear understanding,



<P>made her a most attentive, profitable, thankful pupil.



<P>Fanny was her oracle.&nbsp; Fanny's explanations and remarks



<P>were a most important addition to every essay, or every



<P>chapter of history.&nbsp; What Fanny told her of former times



<P>dwelt more on her mind than the pages of Goldsmith; and she



<P>paid her sister the compliment of preferring her style



<P>to that of any printed author.&nbsp; The early habit of reading was



<P>wanting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their conversations, however, were not always on subjects



<P>so high as history or morals.&nbsp; Others had their hour;



<P>and of lesser matters, none returned so often,



<P>or remained so long between them, as Mansfield Park,



<P>a description of the people, the manners, the amusements,



<P>the ways of Mansfield Park.&nbsp; Susan, who had an innate taste



<P>for the genteel and well-appointed, was eager to hear,



<P>and Fanny could not but indulge herself in dwelling on



<P>so beloved a theme.&nbsp; She hoped it was not wrong; though,



<P>after a time, Susan's very great admiration of everything



<P>said or done in her uncle's house, and earnest longing



<P>to go into Northamptonshire, seemed almost to blame



<P>her for exciting feelings which could not be gratified.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Susan was very little better fitted for home



<P>than her elder sister; and as Fanny grew thoroughly



<P>to understand this, she began to feel that when her



<P>own release from Portsmouth came, her happiness would



<P>have a material drawback in leaving Susan behind.



<P>That a girl so capable of being made everything good should



<P>be left in such hands, distressed her more and more.



<P>Were _she_ likely to have a home to invite her to,



<P>what a blessing it would be!&nbsp; And had it been possible



<P>for her to return Mr. Crawford's regard, the probability



<P>of his being very far from objecting to such a measure would



<P>have been the greatest increase of all her own comforts.



<P>She thought he was really good-tempered, and could fancy



<P>his entering into a plan of that sort most pleasantly.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 42</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XLII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The Prices were just setting off for church the next day



<P>when Mr. Crawford appeared again.&nbsp; He came, not to stop,



<P>but to join them; he was asked to go with them to the



<P>Garrison chapel, which was exactly what he had intended,



<P>and they all walked thither together.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The family were now seen to advantage.&nbsp; Nature had given



<P>them no inconsiderable share of beauty, and every Sunday



<P>dressed them in their cleanest skins and best attire.



<P>Sunday always brought this comfort to Fanny, and on this



<P>Sunday she felt it more than ever.&nbsp; Her poor mother now



<P>did not look so very unworthy of being Lady Bertram's



<P>sister as she was but too apt to look.&nbsp; It often grieved



<P>her to the heart to think of the contrast between them;



<P>to think that where nature had made so little difference,



<P>circumstances should have made so much, and that her mother,



<P>as handsome as Lady Bertram, and some years her junior,



<P>should have an appearance so much more worn and faded,



<P>so comfortless, so slatternly, so shabby.&nbsp; But Sunday



<P>made her a very creditable and tolerably cheerful-looking



<P>Mrs. Price, coming abroad with a fine family of children,



<P>feeling a little respite of her weekly cares, and only



<P>discomposed if she saw her boys run into danger, or Rebecca



<P>pass by with a flower in her hat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In chapel they were obliged to divide, but Mr. Crawford



<P>took care not to be divided from the female branch;



<P>and after chapel he still continued with them, and made



<P>one in the family party on the ramparts.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Price took her weekly walk on the ramparts every



<P>fine Sunday throughout the year, always going directly



<P>after morning service and staying till dinner-time. It



<P>was her public place:&nbsp; there she met her acquaintance,



<P>heard a little news, talked over the badness of the



<P>Portsmouth servants, and wound up her spirits for the six



<P>days ensuing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Thither they now went; Mr. Crawford most happy to consider



<P>the Miss Prices as his peculiar charge; and before they



<P>had been there long, somehow or other, there was no



<P>saying how, Fanny could not have believed it, but he



<P>was walking between them with an arm of each under his,



<P>and she did not know how to prevent or put an end to it.



<P>It made her uncomfortable for a time, but yet there



<P>were enjoyments in the day and in the view which would



<P>be felt.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The day was uncommonly lovely.&nbsp; It was really March;



<P>but it was April in its mild air, brisk soft wind,



<P>and bright sun, occasionally clouded for a minute;



<P>and everything looked so beautiful under the influence



<P>of such a sky, the effects of the shadows pursuing each



<P>other on the ships at Spithead and the island beyond,



<P>with the ever-varying hues of the sea, now at high water,



<P>dancing in its glee and dashing against the ramparts with



<P>so fine a sound, produced altogether such a combination



<P>of charms for Fanny, as made her gradually almost careless



<P>of the circumstances under which she felt them.&nbsp; Nay, had she



<P>been without his arm, she would soon have known that she



<P>needed it, for she wanted strength for a two hours'



<P>saunter of this kind, coming, as it generally did,



<P>upon a week's previous inactivity.&nbsp; Fanny was beginning



<P>to feel the effect of being debarred from her usual



<P>regular exercise; she had lost ground as to health



<P>since her being in Portsmouth; and but for Mr. Crawford



<P>and the beauty of the weather would soon have been knocked



<P>up now.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The loveliness of the day, and of the view, he felt



<P>like herself.&nbsp; They often stopt with the same sentiment



<P>and taste, leaning against the wall, some minutes,



<P>to look and admire; and considering he was not Edmund,



<P>Fanny could not but allow that he was sufficiently open



<P>to the charms of nature, and very well able to express



<P>his admiration.&nbsp; She had a few tender reveries now and then,



<P>which he could sometimes take advantage of to look in her



<P>face without detection; and the result of these looks was,



<P>that though as bewitching as ever, her face was less



<P>blooming than it ought to be.&nbsp; She _said_ she was



<P>very well, and did not like to be supposed otherwise;



<P>but take it all in all, he was convinced that her present



<P>residence could not be comfortable, and therefore could



<P>not be salutary for her, and he was growing anxious for



<P>her being again at Mansfield, where her own happiness,



<P>and his in seeing her, must be so much greater.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have been here a month, I think?" said he.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No; not quite a month.&nbsp; It is only four weeks to-morrow



<P>since I left Mansfield."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are a most accurate and honest reckoner.&nbsp; I should



<P>call that a month."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did not arrive here till Tuesday evening."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And it is to be a two months' visit, is not?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes.&nbsp; My uncle talked of two months.&nbsp; I suppose it



<P>will not be less."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And how are you to be conveyed back again?&nbsp; Who comes



<P>for you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know.&nbsp; I have heard nothing about it yet



<P>from my aunt.&nbsp; Perhaps I may be to stay longer.



<P>It may not be convenient for me to be fetched exactly



<P>at the two months' end."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After a moment's reflection, Mr. Crawford replied,



<P>"I know Mansfield, I know its way, I know its faults



<P>towards _you_.&nbsp; I know the danger of your being so



<P>far forgotten, as to have your comforts give way to the



<P>imaginary convenience of any single being in the family.



<P>I am aware that you may be left here week after week,



<P>if Sir Thomas cannot settle everything for coming himself,



<P>or sending your aunt's maid for you, without involving



<P>the slightest alteration of the arrangements which he



<P>may have laid down for the next quarter of a year.



<P>This will not do.&nbsp; Two months is an ample allowance;
