<P>I should think six weeks quite enough.&nbsp; I am considering



<P>your sister's health," said he, addressing himself to Susan,



<P>"which I think the confinement of Portsmouth unfavourable to.



<P>She requires constant air and exercise.&nbsp; When you know her



<P>as well as I do, I am sure you will agree that she does,



<P>and that she ought never to be long banished from the free air



<P>and liberty of the country.&nbsp; If, therefore" (turning again



<P>to Fanny), "you find yourself growing unwell, and any



<P>difficulties arise about your returning to Mansfield,



<P>without waiting for the two months to be ended,



<P>_that_ must not be regarded as of any consequence,



<P>if you feel yourself at all less strong or comfortable



<P>than usual, and will only let my sister know it, give her



<P>only the slightest hint, she and I will immediately



<P>come down, and take you back to Mansfield.&nbsp; You know



<P>the ease and the pleasure with which this would be done.



<P>You know all that would be felt on the occasion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny thanked him, but tried to laugh it off.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am perfectly serious," he replied, "as you perfectly know.



<P>And I hope you will not be cruelly concealing any



<P>tendency to indisposition.&nbsp; Indeed, you shall _not_;



<P>it shall not be in your power; for so long only as you



<P>positively say, in every letter to Mary, 'I am well,'



<P>and I know you cannot speak or write a falsehood, so long



<P>only shall you be considered as well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny thanked him again, but was affected and distressed



<P>to a degree that made it impossible for her to say much,



<P>or even to be certain of what she ought to say.



<P>This was towards the close of their walk.&nbsp; He attended



<P>them to the last, and left them only at the door of their



<P>own house, when he knew them to be going to dinner,



<P>and therefore pretended to be waited for elsewhere.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish you were not so tired," said he, still detaining



<P>Fanny after all the others were in the house--"I wish I



<P>left you in stronger health.&nbsp; Is there anything I can



<P>do for you in town?&nbsp; I have half an idea of going into



<P>Norfolk again soon.&nbsp; I am not satisfied about Maddison.



<P>I am sure he still means to impose on me if possible,



<P>and get a cousin of his own into a certain mill, which I



<P>design for somebody else.&nbsp; I must come to an understanding



<P>with him.&nbsp; I must make him know that I will not be



<P>tricked on the south side of Everingham, any more than on



<P>the north:&nbsp; that I will be master of my own property.



<P>I was not explicit enough with him before.&nbsp; The mischief



<P>such a man does on an estate, both as to the credit of his



<P>employer and the welfare of the poor, is inconceivable.



<P>I have a great mind to go back into Norfolk directly,



<P>and put everything at once on such a footing as cannot



<P>be afterwards swerved from.&nbsp; Maddison is a clever fellow;



<P>I do not wish to displace him, provided he does not try



<P>to displace _me_; but it would be simple to be duped



<P>by a man who has no right of creditor to dupe me,



<P>and worse than simple to let him give me a hard-hearted,



<P>griping fellow for a tenant, instead of an honest man,



<P>to whom I have given half a promise already.&nbsp; Would it not



<P>be worse than simple?&nbsp; Shall I go?&nbsp; Do you advise it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I advise!&nbsp; You know very well what is right."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes.&nbsp; When you give me your opinion, I always know



<P>what is right.&nbsp; Your judgment is my rule of right."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh, no! do not say so.&nbsp; We have all a better guide



<P>in ourselves, if we would attend to it, than any other person



<P>can be.&nbsp; Good-bye; I wish you a pleasant journey to-morrow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Is there nothing I can do for you in town?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing; I am much obliged to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you no message for anybody?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My love to your sister, if you please; and when you see



<P>my cousin, my cousin Edmund, I wish you would be so good



<P>as to say that I suppose I shall soon hear from him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly; and if he is lazy or negligent, I will write



<P>his excuses myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He could say no more, for Fanny would be no longer detained.



<P>He pressed her hand, looked at her, and was gone.



<P>_He_ went to while away the next three hours as he could,



<P>with his other acquaintance, till the best dinner that



<P>a capital inn afforded was ready for their enjoyment,



<P>and _she_ turned in to her more simple one immediately.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their general fare bore a very different character;



<P>and could he have suspected how many privations, besides that



<P>of exercise, she endured in her father's house, he would



<P>have wondered that her looks were not much more affected



<P>than he found them.&nbsp; She was so little equal to Rebecca's



<P>puddings and Rebecca's hashes, brought to table, as they



<P>all were, with such accompaniments of half-cleaned plates,



<P>and not half-cleaned knives and forks, that she was very



<P>often constrained to defer her heartiest meal till she could



<P>send her brothers in the evening for biscuits and buns.



<P>After being nursed up at Mansfield, it was too late in the



<P>day to be hardened at Portsmouth; and though Sir Thomas,



<P>had he known all, might have thought his niece in the



<P>most promising way of being starved, both mind and body,



<P>into a much juster value for Mr. Crawford's good company



<P>and good fortune, he would probably have feared to push



<P>his experiment farther, lest she might die under the cure.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was out of spirits all the rest of the day.



<P>Though tolerably secure of not seeing Mr. Crawford again,



<P>she could not help being low.&nbsp; It was parting with somebody



<P>of the nature of a friend; and though, in one light,



<P>glad to have him gone, it seemed as if she was now



<P>deserted by everybody; it was a sort of renewed separation



<P>from Mansfield; and she could not think of his returning



<P>to town, and being frequently with Mary and Edmund,



<P>without feelings so near akin to envy as made her hate



<P>herself for having them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her dejection had no abatement from anything passing



<P>around her; a friend or two of her father's, as always



<P>happened if he was not with them, spent the long,



<P>long evening there; and from six o'clock till half-past nine,



<P>there was little intermission of noise or grog.&nbsp; She was



<P>very low.&nbsp; The wonderful improvement which she still



<P>fancied in Mr. Crawford was the nearest to administering



<P>comfort of anything within the current of her thoughts.



<P>Not considering in how different a circle she had been



<P>just seeing him, nor how much might be owing to contrast,



<P>she was quite persuaded of his being astonishingly



<P>more gentle and regardful of others than formerly.



<P>And, if in little things, must it not be so in great?



<P>So anxious for her health and comfort, so very feeling



<P>as he now expressed himself, and really seemed, might not



<P>it be fairly supposed that he would not much longer



<P>persevere in a suit so distressing to her?



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 46</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XLVI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>As Fanny could not doubt that her answer was conveying



<P>a real disappointment, she was rather in expectation,



<P>from her knowledge of Miss Crawford's temper, of being



<P>urged again; and though no second letter arrived for the



<P>space of a week, she had still the same feeling when it



<P>did come.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On receiving it, she could instantly decide on its



<P>containing little writing, and was persuaded of its



<P>having the air of a letter of haste and business.



<P>Its object was unquestionable; and two moments were



<P>enough to start the probability of its being merely



<P>to give her notice that they should be in Portsmouth



<P>that very day, and to throw her into all the agitation



<P>of doubting what she ought to do in such a case.



<P>If two moments, however, can surround with difficulties,



<P>a third can disperse them; and before she had opened



<P>the letter, the possibility of Mr. and Miss Crawford's



<P>having applied to her uncle and obtained his permission



<P>was giving her ease.&nbsp; This was the letter--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A most scandalous, ill-natured rumour has just reached me,



<P>and I write, dear Fanny, to warn you against giving the



<P>least credit to it, should it spread into the country.



<P>Depend upon it, there is some mistake, and that a day or two



<P>will clear it up; at any rate, that Henry is blameless,



<P>and in spite of a moment's _etourderie_, thinks of



<P>nobody but you.&nbsp; Say not a word of it; hear nothing,



<P>surmise nothing, whisper nothing till I write again.



<P>I am sure it will be all hushed up, and nothing proved



<P>but Rushworth's folly.&nbsp; If they are gone, I would lay



<P>my life they are only gone to Mansfield Park, and Julia



<P>with them.&nbsp; But why would not you let us come for you?



<P>I wish you may not repent it.--Yours, etc."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny stood aghast.&nbsp; As no scandalous, ill-natured rumour



<P>had reached her, it was impossible for her to understand



<P>much of this strange letter.&nbsp; She could only perceive



<P>that it must relate to Wimpole Street and Mr. Crawford,



<P>and only conjecture that something very imprudent had just



<P>occurred in that quarter to draw the notice of the world,



<P>and to excite her jealousy, in Miss Crawford's apprehension,



<P>if she heard it.&nbsp; Miss Crawford need not be alarmed



<P>for her.&nbsp; She was only sorry for the parties concerned



<P>and for Mansfield, if the report should spread so far;



<P>but she hoped it might not.&nbsp; If the Rushworths were gone



<P>themselves to Mansfield, as was to be inferred from



<P>what Miss Crawford said, it was not likely that anything



<P>unpleasant should have preceded them, or at least should



<P>make any impression.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As to Mr. Crawford, she hoped it might give him a knowledge



<P>of his own disposition, convince him that he was not capable



<P>of being steadily attached to any one woman in the world,



<P>and shame him from persisting any longer in addressing herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was very strange!&nbsp; She had begun to think he really



<P>loved her, and to fancy his affection for her something



<P>more than common; and his sister still said that he cared



<P>for nobody else.&nbsp; Yet there must have been some marked



<P>display of attentions to her cousin, there must have



<P>been some strong indiscretion, since her correspondent



<P>was not of a sort to regard a slight one.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Very uncomfortable she was, and must continue, till she



<P>heard from Miss Crawford again.&nbsp; It was impossible to



<P>banish the letter from her thoughts, and she could not



<P>relieve herself by speaking of it to any human being.



<P>Miss Crawford need not have urged secrecy with so much warmth;



<P>she might have trusted to her sense of what was due



<P>to her cousin.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next day came and brought no second letter.



<P>Fanny was disappointed.&nbsp; She could still think of little



<P>else all the morning; but, when her father came back



<P>in the afternoon with the daily newspaper as usual,



<P>she was so far from expecting any elucidation through such



<P>a channel that the subject was for a moment out of her head.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was deep in other musing.&nbsp; The remembrance of her first



<P>evening in that room, of her father and his newspaper,



<P>came across her.&nbsp; No candle was now wanted.



<P>The sun was yet an hour and half above the horizon.



<P>She felt that she had, indeed, been three months there;



<P>and the sun's rays falling strongly into the parlour,



<P>instead of cheering, made her still more melancholy,



<P>for sunshine appeared to her a totally different thing



<P>in a town and in the country.&nbsp; Here, its power was only



<P>a glare:&nbsp; a stifling, sickly glare, serving but to bring



<P>forward stains and dirt that might otherwise have slept.



<P>There was neither health nor gaiety in sunshine in a town.



<P>She sat in a blaze of oppressive heat, in a cloud of



<P>moving dust, and her eyes could only wander from the walls,



<P>marked by her father's head, to the table cut and notched



<P>by her brothers, where stood the tea-board never



<P>thoroughly cleaned, the cups and saucers wiped in streaks,



<P>the milk a mixture of motes floating in thin blue,



<P>and the bread and butter growing every minute more



<P>greasy than even Rebecca's hands had first produced it.



<P>Her father read his newspaper, and her mother lamented



<P>over the ragged carpet as usual, while the tea was



<P>in preparation, and wished Rebecca would mend it;



<P>and Fanny was first roused by his calling out to her,



<P>after humphing and considering over a particular paragraph:



<P>"What's the name of your great cousins in town, Fan?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A moment's recollection enabled her to say, "Rushworth, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And don't they live in Wimpole Street?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then, there's the devil to pay among them, that's all!



<P>There" (holding out the paper to her); "much good may such



<P>fine relations do you.&nbsp; I don't know what Sir Thomas may



<P>think of such matters; he may be too much of the courtier



<P>and fine gentleman to like his daughter the less.&nbsp; But, by G--



<P>! if she belonged to _me_, I'd give her the rope's end



<P>as long as I could stand over her.&nbsp; A little flogging for



<P>man and woman too would be the best way of preventing such things."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny read to herself that "it was with infinite concern



<P>the newspaper had to announce to the world a matrimonial



<P>_fracas_ in the family of Mr. R. of Wimpole Street;



<P>the beautiful Mrs. R., whose name had not long been



<P>enrolled in the lists of Hymen, and who had promised



<P>to become so brilliant a leader in the fashionable world,



<P>having quitted her husband's roof in company with the



<P>well-known and captivating Mr. C., the intimate friend



<P>and associate of Mr. R., and it was not known even



<P>to the editor of the newspaper whither they were gone."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a mistake, sir," said Fanny instantly; "it must be



<P>a mistake, it cannot be true; it must mean some other people."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She spoke from the instinctive wish of delaying shame;



<P>she spoke with a resolution which sprung from despair,



<P>for she spoke what she did not, could not believe herself.



<P>It had been the shock of conviction as she read.&nbsp; The truth



<P>rushed on her; and how she could have spoken at all, how she



<P>could even have breathed, was afterwards matter of wonder



<P>to herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Price cared too little about the report to make her



<P>much answer.&nbsp; "It might be all a lie," he acknowledged;



<P>"but so many fine ladies were going to the devil nowadays



<P>that way, that there was no answering for anybody."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed, I hope it is not true," said Mrs. Price plaintively;



<P>"it would be so very shocking!&nbsp; If I have spoken once



<P>to Rebecca about that carpet, I am sure I have spoke at



<P>least a dozen times; have not I, Betsey?&nbsp; And it would



<P>not be ten minutes' work."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The horror of a mind like Fanny's, as it received the



<P>conviction of such guilt, and began to take in some part



<P>of the misery that must ensue, can hardly be described.



<P>At first, it was a sort of stupefaction; but every moment



<P>was quickening her perception of the horrible evil.



<P>She could not doubt, she dared not indulge a hope,



<P>of the paragraph being false.&nbsp; Miss Crawford's letter,



<P>which she had read so often as to make every line her own,



<P>was in frightful conformity with it.&nbsp; Her eager defence



<P>of her brother, her hope of its being _hushed_ _up_,



<P>her evident agitation, were all of a piece with something



<P>very bad; and if there was a woman of character in existence,



<P>who could treat as a trifle this sin of the first magnitude,



<P>who would try to gloss it over, and desire to have it



<P>unpunished, she could believe Miss Crawford to be the woman!



<P>Now she could see her own mistake as to _who_ were gone,



<P>or _said_ to be gone.&nbsp; It was not Mr. and Mrs. Rushworth;



<P>it was Mrs. Rushworth and Mr. Crawford.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny seemed to herself never to have been shocked before.



<P>There was no possibility of rest.&nbsp; The evening passed



<P>without a pause of misery, the night was totally sleepless.



<P>She passed only from feelings of sickness to shudderings



<P>of horror; and from hot fits of fever to cold.&nbsp; The event



<P>was so shocking, that there were moments even when her



<P>heart revolted from it as impossible:&nbsp; when she thought



<P>it could not be.&nbsp; A woman married only six months ago;



<P>a man professing himself devoted, even _engaged_ to another;



<P>that other her near relation; the whole family,



<P>both families connected as they were by tie upon tie;



<P>all friends, all intimate together!&nbsp; It was too horrible



<P>a confusion of guilt, too gross a complication of evil,



<P>for human nature, not in a state of utter barbarism,



<P>to be capable of! yet her judgment told her it was so.



<P>_His_ unsettled affections, wavering with his vanity,



<P>_Maria's_ decided attachment, and no sufficient principle



<P>on either side, gave it possibility:&nbsp; Miss Crawford's



<P>letter stampt it a fact.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>What would be the consequence?&nbsp; Whom would it not injure?



<P>Whose views might it not affect?&nbsp; Whose peace would it



<P>not cut up for ever?&nbsp; Miss Crawford, herself, Edmund;



<P>but it was dangerous, perhaps, to tread such ground.



<P>She confined herself, or tried to confine herself, to the simple,



<P>indubitable family misery which must envelop all, if it were



<P>indeed a matter of certified guilt and public exposure.



<P>The mother's sufferings, the father's; there she paused.



<P>Julia's, Tom's, Edmund's; there a yet longer pause.



<P>They were the two on whom it would fall most horribly.



<P>Sir Thomas's parental solicitude and high sense of honour



<P>and decorum, Edmund's upright principles, unsuspicious temper,



<P>and genuine strength of feeling, made her think it



<P>scarcely possible for them to support life and reason



<P>under such disgrace; and it appeared to her that, as far



<P>as this world alone was concerned, the greatest blessing



<P>to every one of kindred with Mrs. Rushworth would be



<P>instant annihilation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nothing happened the next day, or the next, to weaken



<P>her terrors.&nbsp; Two posts came in, and brought no refutation,



<P>public or private.&nbsp; There was no second letter to explain



<P>away the first from Miss Crawford; there was no intelligence



<P>from Mansfield, though it was now full time for her



<P>to hear again from her aunt.&nbsp; This was an evil omen.



<P>She had, indeed, scarcely the shadow of a hope to soothe



<P>her mind, and was reduced to so low and wan and trembling



<P>a condition, as no mother, not unkind, except Mrs. Price



<P>could have overlooked, when the third day did bring the



<P>sickening knock, and a letter was again put into her hands.



<P>It bore the London postmark, and came from Edmund.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dear Fanny,--You know our present wretchedness.



<P>May God support you under your share!&nbsp; We have been here



<P>two days, but there is nothing to be done.&nbsp; They cannot



<P>be traced.&nbsp; You may not have heard of the last blow--



<P>Julia's elopement; she is gone to Scotland with Yates.



<P>She left London a few hours before we entered it.



<P>At any other time this would have been felt dreadfully.



<P>Now it seems nothing; yet it is an heavy aggravation.



<P>My father is not overpowered.&nbsp; More cannot be hoped.



<P>He is still able to think and act; and I write,



<P>by his desire, to propose your returning home.



<P>He is anxious to get you there for my mother's sake.



<P>I shall be at Portsmouth the morning after you receive this,



<P>and hope to find you ready to set off for Mansfield.



<P>My father wishes you to invite Susan to go with you for a



<P>few months.&nbsp; Settle it as you like; say what is proper;



<P>I am sure you will feel such an instance of his



<P>kindness at such a moment!&nbsp; Do justice to his meaning,



<P>however I may confuse it.&nbsp; You may imagine something



<P>of my present state.&nbsp; There is no end of the evil let



<P>loose upon us.&nbsp; You will see me early by the mail.--



<P>Yours, etc."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Never had Fanny more wanted a cordial.&nbsp; Never had she felt



<P>such a one as this letter contained.&nbsp; To-morrow! to leave



<P>Portsmouth to-morrow! She was, she felt she was, in the



<P>greatest danger of being exquisitely happy, while so many



<P>were miserable.&nbsp; The evil which brought such good to her!



<P>She dreaded lest she should learn to be insensible of it.



<P>To be going so soon, sent for so kindly, sent for as



<P>a comfort, and with leave to take Susan, was altogether



<P>such a combination of blessings as set her heart in



<P>a glow, and for a time seemed to distance every pain,



<P>and make her incapable of suitably sharing the distress



<P>even of those whose distress she thought of most.



<P>Julia's elopement could affect her comparatively but little;



<P>she was amazed and shocked; but it could not occupy her,



<P>could not dwell on her mind.&nbsp; She was obliged to call



<P>herself to think of it, and acknowledge it to be terrible



<P>and grievous, or it was escaping her, in the midst of all



<P>the agitating pressing joyful cares attending this summons



<P>to herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There is nothing like employment, active indispensable employment,



<P>for relieving sorrow.&nbsp; Employment, even melancholy,



<P>may dispel melancholy, and her occupations were hopeful.



<P>She had so much to do, that not even the horrible



<P>story of Mrs. Rushworth--now fixed to the last point



<P>of certainty could affect her as it had done before.



<P>She had not time to be miserable.&nbsp; Within twenty-four



<P>hours she was hoping to be gone; her father and mother



<P>must be spoken to, Susan prepared, everything got ready.



<P>Business followed business; the day was hardly long enough.



<P>The happiness she was imparting, too, happiness very little



<P>alloyed by the black communication which must briefly



<P>precede it--the joyful consent of her father and mother



<P>to Susan's going with her--the general satisfaction with



<P>which the going of both seemed regarded, and the ecstasy



<P>of Susan herself, was all serving to support her spirits.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The affliction of the Bertrams was little felt in the family.



<P>Mrs. Price talked of her poor sister for a few minutes,



<P>but how to find anything to hold Susan's clothes,



<P>because Rebecca took away all the boxes and spoilt them,



<P>was much more in her thoughts:&nbsp; and as for Susan,



<P>now unexpectedly gratified in the first wish of her heart,



<P>and knowing nothing personally of those who had sinned,



<P>or of those who were sorrowing--if she could help rejoicing



<P>from beginning to end, it was as much as ought to be expected



<P>from human virtue at fourteen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As nothing was really left for the decision of Mrs. Price,



<P>or the good offices of Rebecca, everything was rationally



<P>and duly accomplished, and the girls were ready for



<P>the morrow.&nbsp; The advantage of much sleep to prepare



<P>them for their journey was impossible.&nbsp; The cousin



<P>who was travelling towards them could hardly have less



<P>than visited their agitated spirits--one all happiness,



<P>the other all varying and indescribable perturbation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By eight in the morning Edmund was in the house.&nbsp; The girls



<P>heard his entrance from above, and Fanny went down.



<P>The idea of immediately seeing him, with the knowledge



<P>of what he must be suffering, brought back all her own



<P>first feelings.&nbsp; He so near her, and in misery.&nbsp; She was



<P>ready to sink as she entered the parlour.&nbsp; He was alone,



<P>and met her instantly; and she found herself pressed



<P>to his heart with only these words, just articulate,



<P>"My Fanny, my only sister; my only comfort now!"



<P>She could say nothing; nor for some minutes could he



<P>say more.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He turned away to recover himself, and when he spoke again,



<P>though his voice still faltered, his manner shewed



<P>the wish of self-command, and the resolution of avoiding



<P>any farther allusion.&nbsp; "Have you breakfasted?&nbsp; When shall



<P>you be ready?&nbsp; Does Susan go?" were questions following



<P>each other rapidly.&nbsp; His great object was to be off



<P>as soon as possible.&nbsp; When Mansfield was considered,



<P>time was precious; and the state of his own mind made



<P>him find relief only in motion.&nbsp; It was settled that he



<P>should order the carriage to the door in half an hour.



<P>Fanny answered for their having breakfasted and being quite



<P>ready in half an hour.&nbsp; He had already ate, and declined



<P>staying for their meal.&nbsp; He would walk round the ramparts,



<P>and join them with the carriage.&nbsp; He was gone again;



<P>glad to get away even from Fanny.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He looked very ill; evidently suffering under



<P>violent emotions, which he was determined to suppress.



<P>She knew it must be so, but it was terrible to her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The carriage came; and he entered the house again at



<P>the same moment, just in time to spend a few minutes with



<P>the family, and be a witness--but that he saw nothing--



<P>of the tranquil manner in which the daughters were



<P>parted with, and just in time to prevent their sitting



<P>down to the breakfast-table, which, by dint of much



<P>unusual activity, was quite and completely ready as



<P>the carriage drove from the door.&nbsp; Fanny's last meal



<P>in her father's house was in character with her first:



<P>she was dismissed from it as hospitably as she had been welcomed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How her heart swelled with joy and gratitude as she



<P>passed the barriers of Portsmouth, and how Susan's face



<P>wore its broadest smiles, may be easily conceived.



<P>Sitting forwards, however, and screened by her bonnet,



<P>those smiles were unseen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The journey was likely to be a silent one.&nbsp; Edmund's deep



<P>sighs often reached Fanny.&nbsp; Had he been alone with her,



<P>his heart must have opened in spite of every resolution;



<P>but Susan's presence drove him quite into himself, and his



<P>attempts to talk on indifferent subjects could never be



<P>long supported.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny watched him with never-failing solicitude,



<P>and sometimes catching his eye, revived an affectionate smile,



<P>which comforted her; but the first day's journey passed



<P>without her hearing a word from him on the subjects



<P>that were weighing him down.&nbsp; The next morning produced



<P>a little more.&nbsp; Just before their setting out from Oxford,



<P>while Susan was stationed at a window, in eager observation



<P>of the departure of a large family from the inn,



<P>the other two were standing by the fire; and Edmund,



<P>particularly struck by the alteration in Fanny's looks,



<P>and from his ignorance of the daily evils of her



<P>father's house, attributing an undue share of the change,



<P>attributing _all_ to the recent event, took her hand,



<P>and said in a low, but very expressive tone, "No wonder--



<P>you must feel it--you must suffer.&nbsp; How a man who had



<P>once loved, could desert you!&nbsp; But _yours_--your regard



<P>was new compared with----Fanny, think of _me_!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The first division of their journey occupied a long day,



<P>and brought them, almost knocked up, to Oxford;



<P>but the second was over at a much earlier hour.



<P>They were in the environs of Mansfield long before



<P>the usual dinner-time, and as they approached the



<P>beloved place, the hearts of both sisters sank a little.



<P>Fanny began to dread the meeting with her aunts and Tom,



<P>under so dreadful a humiliation; and Susan to feel with



<P>some anxiety, that all her best manners, all her lately



<P>acquired knowledge of what was practised here, was on



<P>the point of being called into action.&nbsp; Visions of good



<P>and ill breeding, of old vulgarisms and new gentilities,



<P>were before her; and she was meditating much upon



<P>silver forks, napkins, and finger-glasses. Fanny had



<P>been everywhere awake to the difference of the country



<P>since February; but when they entered the Park her



<P>perceptions and her pleasures were of the keenest sort.



<P>It was three months, full three months, since her



<P>quitting it, and the change was from winter to summer.



<P>Her eye fell everywhere on lawns and plantations of the



<P>freshest green; and the trees, though not fully clothed,



<P>were in that delightful state when farther beauty is known



<P>to be at hand, and when, while much is actually given



<P>to the sight, more yet remains for the imagination.



<P>Her enjoyment, however, was for herself alone.&nbsp; Edmund could



<P>not share it.&nbsp; She looked at him, but he was leaning back,



<P>sunk in a deeper gloom than ever, and with eyes closed,



<P>as if the view of cheerfulness oppressed him, and the



<P>lovely scenes of home must be shut out.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It made her melancholy again; and the knowledge of what must



<P>be enduring there, invested even the house, modern, airy,



<P>and well situated as it was, with a melancholy aspect.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By one of the suffering party within they were expected



<P>with such impatience as she had never known before.



<P>Fanny had scarcely passed the solemn-looking servants,



<P>when Lady Bertram came from the drawing-room to meet her;



<P>came with no indolent step; and falling on her neck, said,



<P>"Dear Fanny! now I shall be comfortable.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 47</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XLVII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>It had been a miserable party, each of the three believing



<P>themselves most miserable.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris, however, as most



<P>attached to Maria, was really the greatest sufferer.



<P>Maria was her first favourite, the dearest of all;



<P>the match had been her own contriving, as she had been



<P>wont with such pride of heart to feel and say, and this



<P>conclusion of it almost overpowered her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was an altered creature, quieted, stupefied, indifferent to



<P>everything that passed.&nbsp; The being left with her sister



<P>and nephew, and all the house under her care, had been



<P>an advantage entirely thrown away; she had been unable



<P>to direct or dictate, or even fancy herself useful.



<P>When really touched by affliction, her active powers



<P>had been all benumbed; and neither Lady Bertram nor Tom



<P>had received from her the smallest support or attempt



<P>at support.&nbsp; She had done no more for them than they



<P>had done for each other.&nbsp; They had been all solitary,



<P>helpless, and forlorn alike; and now the arrival of the



<P>others only established her superiority in wretchedness.



<P>Her companions were relieved, but there was no good



<P>for _her_.&nbsp; Edmund was almost as welcome to his brother



<P>as Fanny to her aunt; but Mrs. Norris, instead of having



<P>comfort from either, was but the more irritated by the



<P>sight of the person whom, in the blindness of her anger,



<P>she could have charged as the daemon of the piece.



<P>Had Fanny accepted Mr. Crawford this could not have happened.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Susan too was a grievance.&nbsp; She had not spirits to notice



<P>her in more than a few repulsive looks, but she felt



<P>her as a spy, and an intruder, and an indigent niece,



<P>and everything most odious.&nbsp; By her other aunt, Susan was



<P>received with quiet kindness.&nbsp; Lady Bertram could not



<P>give her much time, or many words, but she felt her,



<P>as Fanny's sister, to have a claim at Mansfield,



<P>and was ready to kiss and like her; and Susan was more



<P>than satisfied, for she came perfectly aware that nothing



<P>but ill-humour was to be expected from aunt Norris;



<P>and was so provided with happiness, so strong in that



<P>best of blessings, an escape from many certain evils,



<P>that she could have stood against a great deal more



<P>indifference than she met with from the others.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was now left a good deal to herself, to get acquainted



<P>with the house and grounds as she could, and spent her



<P>days very happily in so doing, while those who might



<P>otherwise have attended to her were shut up, or wholly



<P>occupied each with the person quite dependent on them,



<P>at this time, for everything like comfort; Edmund trying



<P>to bury his own feelings in exertions for the relief



<P>of his brother's, and Fanny devoted to her aunt Bertram,



<P>returning to every former office with more than former zeal,



<P>and thinking she could never do enough for one who seemed



<P>so much to want her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To talk over the dreadful business with Fanny, talk and lament,



<P>was all Lady Bertram's consolation.&nbsp; To be listened to and



<P>borne with, and hear the voice of kindness and sympathy



<P>in return, was everything that could be done for her.



<P>To be otherwise comforted was out of the question.



<P>The case admitted of no comfort.&nbsp; Lady Bertram did not



<P>think deeply, but, guided by Sir Thomas, she thought



<P>justly on all important points; and she saw, therefore,



<P>in all its enormity, what had happened, and neither



<P>endeavoured herself, nor required Fanny to advise her,



<P>to think little of guilt and infamy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her affections were not acute, nor was her mind tenacious.



<P>After a time, Fanny found it not impossible to direct



<P>her thoughts to other subjects, and revive some interest



<P>in the usual occupations; but whenever Lady Bertram _was_



<P>fixed on the event, she could see it only in one light,



<P>as comprehending the loss of a daughter, and a disgrace



<P>never to be wiped off.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny learnt from her all the particulars which had



<P>yet transpired.&nbsp; Her aunt was no very methodical narrator,



<P>but with the help of some letters to and from Sir Thomas,



<P>and what she already knew herself, and could reasonably



<P>combine, she was soon able to understand quite as much



<P>as she wished of the circumstances attending the story.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Rushworth had gone, for the Easter holidays,



<P>to Twickenham, with a family whom she had just grown



<P>intimate with:&nbsp; a family of lively, agreeable manners,



<P>and probably of morals and discretion to suit, for to _their_



<P>house Mr. Crawford had constant access at all times.



<P>His having been in the same neighbourhood Fanny already knew.



<P>Mr. Rushworth had been gone at this time to Bath, to pass



<P>a few days with his mother, and bring her back to town,



<P>and Maria was with these friends without any restraint,



<P>without even Julia; for Julia had removed from Wimpole Street



<P>two or three weeks before, on a visit to some relations



<P>of Sir Thomas; a removal which her father and mother were



<P>now disposed to attribute to some view of convenience



<P>on Mr. Yates's account.&nbsp; Very soon after the Rushworths'



<P>return to Wimpole Street, Sir Thomas had received a



<P>letter from an old and most particular friend in London,



<P>who hearing and witnessing a good deal to alarm him



<P>in that quarter, wrote to recommend Sir Thomas's coming



<P>to London himself, and using his influence with his



<P>daughter to put an end to the intimacy which was already



<P>exposing her to unpleasant remarks, and evidently making



<P>Mr. Rushworth uneasy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas was preparing to act upon this letter, without



<P>communicating its contents to any creature at Mansfield,



<P>when it was followed by another, sent express from the



<P>same friend, to break to him the almost desperate situation



<P>in which affairs then stood with the young people.



<P>Mrs. Rushworth had left her husband's house:&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth



<P>had been in great anger and distress to _him_ (Mr. Harding)



<P>for his advice; Mr. Harding feared there had been _at_



<P>_least_ very flagrant indiscretion.&nbsp; The maidservant



<P>of Mrs. Rushworth, senior, threatened alarmingly.&nbsp; He was



<P>doing all in his power to quiet everything, with the hope



<P>of Mrs. Rushworth's return, but was so much counteracted



<P>in Wimpole Street by the influence of Mr. Rushworth's mother,



<P>that the worst consequences might be apprehended.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This dreadful communication could not be kept from the rest



<P>of the family.&nbsp; Sir Thomas set off, Edmund would go with him,



<P>and the others had been left in a state of wretchedness,



<P>inferior only to what followed the receipt of the next



<P>letters from London.&nbsp; Everything was by that time public



<P>beyond a hope.&nbsp; The servant of Mrs. Rushworth, the mother,



<P>had exposure in her power, and supported by her mistress,



<P>was not to be silenced.&nbsp; The two ladies, even in the short



<P>time they had been together, had disagreed; and the bitterness



<P>of the elder against her daughter-in-law might perhaps arise



<P>almost as much from the personal disrespect with which



<P>she had herself been treated as from sensibility for her son.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>However that might be, she was unmanageable.&nbsp; But had she



<P>been less obstinate, or of less weight with her son,



<P>who was always guided by the last speaker, by the person



<P>who could get hold of and shut him up, the case would



<P>still have been hopeless, for Mrs. Rushworth did not



<P>appear again, and there was every reason to conclude



<P>her to be concealed somewhere with Mr. Crawford,



<P>who had quitted his uncle's house, as for a journey,



<P>on the very day of her absenting herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas, however, remained yet a little longer in town,



<P>in the hope of discovering and snatching her from farther vice,



<P>though all was lost on the side of character.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>_His_ present state Fanny could hardly bear to think of.



<P>There was but one of his children who was not at this time



<P>a source of misery to him.&nbsp; Tom's complaints had been



<P>greatly heightened by the shock of his sister's conduct,



<P>and his recovery so much thrown back by it, that even



<P>Lady Bertram had been struck by the difference, and all



<P>her alarms were regularly sent off to her husband;



<P>and Julia's elopement, the additional blow which had met



<P>him on his arrival in London, though its force had been



<P>deadened at the moment, must, she knew, be sorely felt.



<P>She saw that it was.&nbsp; His letters expressed how much he



<P>deplored it.&nbsp; Under any circumstances it would have been



<P>an unwelcome alliance; but to have it so clandestinely



<P>formed, and such a period chosen for its completion,



<P>placed Julia's feelings in a most unfavourable light,



<P>and severely aggravated the folly of her choice.



<P>He called it a bad thing, done in the worst manner,



<P>and at the worst time; and though Julia was yet as more



<P>pardonable than Maria as folly than vice, he could not



<P>but regard the step she had taken as opening the worst



<P>probabilities of a conclusion hereafter like her sister's.



<P>Such was his opinion of the set into which she had



<P>thrown herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny felt for him most acutely.&nbsp; He could have no comfort



<P>but in Edmund.&nbsp; Every other child must be racking his heart.



<P>His displeasure against herself she trusted, reasoning



<P>differently from Mrs. Norris, would now be done away.



<P>_She_ should be justified.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford would have



<P>fully acquitted her conduct in refusing him; but this,



<P>though most material to herself, would be poor consolation



<P>to Sir Thomas.&nbsp; Her uncle's displeasure was terrible to her;



<P>but what could her justification or her gratitude and



<P>attachment do for him?&nbsp; His stay must be on Edmund alone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was mistaken, however, in supposing that Edmund gave



<P>his father no present pain.&nbsp; It was of a much less poignant



<P>nature than what the others excited; but Sir Thomas



<P>was considering his happiness as very deeply involved



<P>in the offence of his sister and friend; cut off by it,



<P>as he must be, from the woman whom he had been pursuing



<P>with undoubted attachment and strong probability of success;



<P>and who, in everything but this despicable brother,



<P>would have been so eligible a connexion.&nbsp; He was aware



<P>of what Edmund must be suffering on his own behalf,



<P>in addition to all the rest, when they were in town:



<P>he had seen or conjectured his feelings; and, having reason



<P>to think that one interview with Miss Crawford had taken place,



<P>from which Edmund derived only increased distress, had been



<P>as anxious on that account as on others to get him out of town,



<P>and had engaged him in taking Fanny home to her aunt,



<P>with a view to his relief and benefit, no less than theirs.



<P>Fanny was not in the secret of her uncle's feelings,



<P>Sir Thomas not in the secret of Miss Crawford's character.



<P>Had he been privy to her conversation with his son, he would



<P>not have wished her to belong to him, though her twenty



<P>thousand pounds had been forty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>That Edmund must be for ever divided from Miss Crawford did



<P>not admit of a doubt with Fanny; and yet, till she knew



<P>that he felt the same, her own conviction was insufficient.



<P>She thought he did, but she wanted to be assured of it.



<P>If he would now speak to her with the unreserve which



<P>had sometimes been too much for her before, it would



<P>be most consoling; but _that_ she found was not to be.



<P>She seldom saw him:&nbsp; never alone.&nbsp; He probably avoided



<P>being alone with her.&nbsp; What was to be inferred?&nbsp; That his



<P>judgment submitted to all his own peculiar and bitter share



<P>of this family affliction, but that it was too keenly



<P>felt to be a subject of the slightest communication.



<P>This must be his state.&nbsp; He yielded, but it was with



<P>agonies which did not admit of speech.&nbsp; Long, long would



<P>it be ere Miss Crawford's name passed his lips again,



<P>or she could hope for a renewal of such confidential



<P>intercourse as had been.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It _was_ long.&nbsp; They reached Mansfield on Thursday,



<P>and it was not till Sunday evening that Edmund began



<P>to talk to her on the subject.&nbsp; Sitting with her on



<P>Sunday evening--a wet Sunday evening--the very time of



<P>all others when, if a friend is at hand, the heart must



<P>be opened, and everything told; no one else in the room,



<P>except his mother, who, after hearing an affecting sermon,



<P>had cried herself to sleep, it was impossible not to speak;



<P>and so, with the usual beginnings, hardly to be traced



<P>as to what came first, and the usual declaration that



<P>if she would listen to him for a few minutes, he should



<P>be very brief, and certainly never tax her kindness



<P>in the same way again; she need not fear a repetition;



<P>it would be a subject prohibited entirely:&nbsp; he entered



<P>upon the luxury of relating circumstances and sensations



<P>of the first interest to himself, to one of whose



<P>affectionate sympathy he was quite convinced

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>How Fanny listened, with what curiosity and concern,



<P>what pain and what delight, how the agitation of his



<P>voice was watched, and how carefully her own eyes were



<P>fixed on any object but himself, may be imagined.



<P>The opening was alarming.&nbsp; He had seen Miss Crawford.



<P>He had been invited to see her.&nbsp; He had received a note



<P>from Lady Stornaway to beg him to call; and regarding



<P>it as what was meant to be the last, last interview



<P>of friendship, and investing her with all the feelings



<P>of shame and wretchedness which Crawford's sister ought



<P>to have known, he had gone to her in such a state of mind,



<P>so softened, so devoted, as made it for a few moments



<P>impossible to Fanny's fears that it should be the last.



<P>But as he proceeded in his story, these fears were over.



<P>She had met him, he said, with a serious--certainly a serious--



<P>even an agitated air; but before he had been able



<P>to speak one intelligible sentence, she had introduced



<P>the subject in a manner which he owned had shocked him.



<P>"'I heard you were in town,' said she; 'I wanted to see you.



<P>Let us talk over this sad business.&nbsp; What can equal the folly



<P>of our two relations?'&nbsp; I could not answer, but I believe



<P>my looks spoke.&nbsp; She felt reproved.&nbsp; Sometimes how quick



<P>to feel!&nbsp; With a graver look and voice she then added,



<P>'I do not mean to defend Henry at your sister's expense.'



<P>So she began, but how she went on, Fanny, is not fit,



<P>is hardly fit to be repeated to you.&nbsp; I cannot recall



<P>all her words.&nbsp; I would not dwell upon them if I could.



<P>Their substance was great anger at the _folly_ of each.



<P>She reprobated her brother's folly in being drawn on



<P>by a woman whom he had never cared for, to do what must



<P>lose him the woman he adored; but still more the folly of



<P>poor Maria, in sacrificing such a situation, plunging into



<P>such difficulties, under the idea of being really loved



<P>by a man who had long ago made his indifference clear.



<P>Guess what I must have felt.&nbsp; To hear the woman whom--



<P>no harsher name than folly given!&nbsp; So voluntarily,



<P>so freely, so coolly to canvass it!&nbsp; No reluctance,



<P>no horror, no feminine, shall I say, no modest loathings?



<P>This is what the world does.&nbsp; For where, Fanny, shall we



<P>find a woman whom nature had so richly endowed?&nbsp; Spoilt,



<P>spoilt!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After a little reflection, he went on with a sort



<P>of desperate calmness.&nbsp; "I will tell you everything,



<P>and then have done for ever.&nbsp; She saw it only as folly,



<P>and that folly stamped only by exposure.&nbsp; The want of



<P>common discretion, of caution:&nbsp; his going down to Richmond



<P>for the whole time of her being at Twickenham; her putting



<P>herself in the power of a servant; it was the detection,



<P>in short--oh, Fanny! it was the detection, not the offence,



<P>which she reprobated.&nbsp; It was the imprudence which had



<P>brought things to extremity, and obliged her brother



<P>to give up every dearer plan in order to fly with her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He stopt.&nbsp; "And what," said Fanny (believing herself



<P>required to speak), "what could you say?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing, nothing to be understood.&nbsp; I was like a man stunned.



<P>She went on, began to talk of you; yes, then she began



<P>to talk of you, regretting, as well she might, the loss



<P>of such a--.&nbsp; There she spoke very rationally.&nbsp; But she



<P>has always done justice to you.&nbsp; 'He has thrown away,'



<P>said she, 'such a woman as he will never see again.



<P>She would have fixed him; she would have made him happy



<P>for ever.'&nbsp; My dearest Fanny, I am giving you, I hope,



<P>more pleasure than pain by this retrospect of what might



<P>have been--but what never can be now.&nbsp; You do not wish me



<P>to be silent?&nbsp; If you do, give me but a look, a word, and I



<P>have done."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No look or word was given.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank God," said he.&nbsp; "We were all disposed to wonder,



<P>but it seems to have been the merciful appointment



<P>of Providence that the heart which knew no guile



<P>should not suffer.&nbsp; She spoke of you with high praise



<P>and warm affection; yet, even here, there was alloy,



<P>a dash of evil; for in the midst of it she could exclaim,



<P>'Why would not she have him?&nbsp; It is all her fault.



<P>Simple girl!&nbsp; I shall never forgive her.&nbsp; Had she accepted



<P>him as she ought, they might now have been on the point



<P>of marriage, and Henry would have been too happy and too



<P>busy to want any other object.&nbsp; He would have taken



<P>no pains to be on terms with Mrs. Rushworth again.



<P>It would have all ended in a regular standing flirtation,



<P>in yearly meetings at Sotherton and Everingham.'&nbsp; Could you



<P>have believed it possible?&nbsp; But the charm is broken.



<P>My eyes are opened."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Cruel!" said Fanny, "quite cruel.&nbsp; At such a moment to



<P>give way to gaiety, to speak with lightness, and to you!



<P>Absolute cruelty."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Cruelty, do you call it?&nbsp; We differ there.&nbsp; No, hers is



<P>not a cruel nature.&nbsp; I do not consider her as meaning



<P>to wound my feelings.&nbsp; The evil lies yet deeper:



<P>in her total ignorance, unsuspiciousness of there being



<P>such feelings; in a perversion of mind which made it



<P>natural to her to treat the subject as she did.&nbsp; She was



<P>speaking only as she had been used to hear others speak,



<P>as she imagined everybody else would speak.&nbsp; Hers are



<P>not faults of temper.&nbsp; She would not voluntarily give



<P>unnecessary pain to any one, and though I may deceive myself,



<P>I cannot but think that for me, for my feelings, she would--



<P>Hers are faults of principle, Fanny; of blunted delicacy



<P>and a corrupted, vitiated mind.&nbsp; Perhaps it is best for me,



<P>since it leaves me so little to regret.&nbsp; Not so, however.



<P>Gladly would I submit to all the increased pain of



<P>losing her, rather than have to think of her as I do.



<P>I told her so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Did you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; when I left her I told her so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How long were you together?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Five-and-twenty minutes.&nbsp; Well, she went on to say that



<P>what remained now to be done was to bring about a marriage



<P>between them.&nbsp; She spoke of it, Fanny, with a steadier



<P>voice than I can."&nbsp; He was obliged to pause more than once



<P>as he continued.&nbsp; "'We must persuade Henry to marry her,'



<P>said she; 'and what with honour, and the certainty of having



<P>shut himself out for ever from Fanny, I do not despair



<P>of it.&nbsp; Fanny he must give up.&nbsp; I do not think that even



<P>_he_ could now hope to succeed with one of her stamp,



<P>and therefore I hope we may find no insuperable difficulty.



<P>My influence, which is not small shall all go that way;



<P>and when once married, and properly supported by her



<P>own family, people of respectability as they are, she may



<P>recover her footing in society to a certain degree.



<P>In some circles, we know, she would never be admitted,



<P>but with good dinners, and large parties, there will



<P>always be those who will be glad of her acquaintance;



<P>and there is, undoubtedly, more liberality and candour



<P>on those points than formerly.&nbsp; What I advise is,



<P>that your father be quiet.&nbsp; Do not let him injure his own



<P>cause by interference.&nbsp; Persuade him to let things take



<P>their course.&nbsp; If by any officious exertions of his,



<P>she is induced to leave Henry's protection, there will be



<P>much less chance of his marrying her than if she remain



<P>with him.&nbsp; I know how he is likely to be influenced.



<P>Let Sir Thomas trust to his honour and compassion, and it



<P>may all end well; but if he get his daughter away, it will



<P>be destroying the chief hold.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After repeating this, Edmund was so much affected that Fanny,



<P>watching him with silent, but most tender concern,



<P>was almost sorry that the subject had been entered



<P>on at all.&nbsp; It was long before he could speak again.



<P>At last, "Now, Fanny," said he, "I shall soon have done.



<P>I have told you the substance of all that she said.



<P>As soon as I could speak, I replied that I had not



<P>supposed it possible, coming in such a state of mind



<P>into that house as I had done, that anything could



<P>occur to make me suffer more, but that she had been



<P>inflicting deeper wounds in almost every sentence.



<P>That though I had, in the course of our acquaintance,



<P>been often sensible of some difference in our opinions,



<P>on points, too, of some moment, it had not entered my



<P>imagination to conceive the difference could be such as she



<P>had now proved it.&nbsp; That the manner in which she treated



<P>the dreadful crime committed by her brother and my sister



<P>(with whom lay the greater seduction I pretended not to say),



<P>but the manner in which she spoke of the crime itself,



<P>giving it every reproach but the right; considering its ill



<P>consequences only as they were to be braved or overborne



<P>by a defiance of decency and impudence in wrong; and last



<P>of all, and above all, recommending to us a compliance,



<P>a compromise, an acquiescence in the continuance of the sin,



<P>on the chance of a marriage which, thinking as I now thought



<P>of her brother, should rather be prevented than sought;



<P>all this together most grievously convinced me that I had



<P>never understood her before, and that, as far as related



<P>to mind, it had been the creature of my own imagination,



<P>not Miss Crawford, that I had been too apt to dwell on



<P>for many months past.&nbsp; That, perhaps, it was best for me;



<P>I had less to regret in sacrificing a friendship, feelings,



<P>hopes which must, at any rate, have been torn from me now.



<P>And yet, that I must and would confess that, could I



<P>have restored her to what she had appeared to me before,



<P>I would infinitely prefer any increase of the pain



<P>of parting, for the sake of carrying with me the right of



<P>tenderness and esteem.&nbsp; This is what I said, the purport



<P>of it; but, as you may imagine, not spoken so collectedly



<P>or methodically as I have repeated it to you.&nbsp; She was



<P>astonished, exceedingly astonished--more than astonished.



<P>I saw her change countenance.&nbsp; She turned extremely red.



<P>I imagined I saw a mixture of many feelings:&nbsp; a great,



<P>though short struggle; half a wish of yielding to truths,



<P>half a sense of shame, but habit, habit carried it.



<P>She would have laughed if she could.&nbsp; It was a sort of laugh,



<P>as she answered, 'A pretty good lecture, upon my word.



<P>Was it part of your last sermon?&nbsp; At this rate you will



<P>soon reform everybody at Mansfield and Thornton Lacey;



<P>and when I hear of you next, it may be as a celebrated preacher



<P>in some great society of Methodists, or as a missionary



<P>into foreign parts.'&nbsp; She tried to speak carelessly,



<P>but she was not so careless as she wanted to appear.



<P>I only said in reply, that from my heart I wished her well,



<P>and earnestly hoped that she might soon learn to think



<P>more justly, and not owe the most valuable knowledge we



<P>could any of us acquire, the knowledge of ourselves and of



<P>our duty, to the lessons of affliction, and immediately



<P>left the room.&nbsp; I had gone a few steps, Fanny, when I



<P>heard the door open behind me.&nbsp; 'Mr. Bertram,' said she.



<P>I looked back.&nbsp; 'Mr. Bertram,' said she, with a smile;



<P>but it was a smile ill-suited to the conversation that



<P>had passed, a saucy playful smile, seeming to invite



<P>in order to subdue me; at least it appeared so to me.



<P>I resisted; it was the impulse of the moment to resist,



<P>and still walked on.&nbsp; I have since, sometimes, for a moment,



<P>regretted that I did not go back, but I know I was right,



<P>and such has been the end of our acquaintance.&nbsp; And what



<P>an acquaintance has it been!&nbsp; How have I been deceived!



<P>Equally in brother and sister deceived!&nbsp; I thank you for



<P>your patience, Fanny.&nbsp; This has been the greatest relief,



<P>and now we will have done."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And such was Fanny's dependence on his words, that for five



<P>minutes she thought they _had_ done.&nbsp; Then, however, it all



<P>came on again, or something very like it, and nothing



<P>less than Lady Bertram's rousing thoroughly up could



<P>really close such a conversation.&nbsp; Till that happened,



<P>they continued to talk of Miss Crawford alone, and how she



<P>had attached him, and how delightful nature had made her,



<P>and how excellent she would have been, had she fallen into



<P>good hands earlier.&nbsp; Fanny, now at liberty to speak openly,



<P>felt more than justified in adding to his knowledge



<P>of her real character, by some hint of what share his



<P>brother's state of health might be supposed to have in



<P>her wish for a complete reconciliation.&nbsp; This was not an



<P>agreeable intimation.&nbsp; Nature resisted it for a while.



<P>It would have been a vast deal pleasanter to have had



<P>her more disinterested in her attachment; but his vanity



<P>was not of a strength to fight long against reason.



<P>He submitted to believe that Tom's illness had influenced her,



<P>only reserving for himself this consoling thought,



<P>that considering the many counteractions of opposing habits,



<P>she had certainly been _more_ attached to him than could



<P>have been expected, and for his sake been more near



<P>doing right.&nbsp; Fanny thought exactly the same; and they were



<P>also quite agreed in their opinion of the lasting effect,



<P>the indelible impression, which such a disappointment



<P>must make on his mind.&nbsp; Time would undoubtedly abate



<P>somewhat of his sufferings, but still it was a sort



<P>of thing which he never could get entirely the better of;



<P>and as to his ever meeting with any other woman who could--



<P>it was too impossible to be named but with indignation.



<P>Fanny's friendship was all that he had to cling to.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 45</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XLV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>At about the week's end from his return to Mansfield,



<P>Tom's immediate danger was over, and he was so far



<P>pronounced safe as to make his mother perfectly easy;



<P>for being now used to the sight of him in his suffering,



<P>helpless state, and hearing only the best, and never thinking



<P>beyond what she heard, with no disposition for alarm



<P>and no aptitude at a hint, Lady Bertram was the happiest



<P>subject in the world for a little medical imposition.



<P>The fever was subdued; the fever had been his complaint;



<P>of course he would soon be well again.&nbsp; Lady Bertram could



<P>think nothing less, and Fanny shared her aunt's security,



<P>till she received a few lines from Edmund, written purposely



<P>to give her a clearer idea of his brother's situation,



<P>and acquaint her with the apprehensions which he and his



<P>father had imbibed from the physician with respect to some



<P>strong hectic symptoms, which seemed to seize the frame



<P>on the departure of the fever.&nbsp; They judged it best



<P>that Lady Bertram should not be harassed by alarms which,



<P>it was to be hoped, would prove unfounded; but there was



<P>no reason why Fanny should not know the truth.&nbsp; They were



<P>apprehensive for his lungs.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A very few lines from Edmund shewed her the patient



<P>and the sickroom in a juster and stronger light than



<P>all Lady Bertram's sheets of paper could do.&nbsp; There was



<P>hardly any one in the house who might not have described,



<P>from personal observation, better than herself;



<P>not one who was not more useful at times to her son.



<P>She could do nothing but glide in quietly and look at him;



<P>but when able to talk or be talked to, or read to,



<P>Edmund was the companion he preferred.&nbsp; His aunt worried



<P>him by her cares, and Sir Thomas knew not how to bring down



<P>his conversation or his voice to the level of irritation



<P>and feebleness.&nbsp; Edmund was all in all.&nbsp; Fanny would



<P>certainly believe him so at least, and must find that her



<P>estimation of him was higher than ever when he appeared



<P>as the attendant, supporter, cheerer of a suffering brother.



<P>There was not only the debility of recent illness to assist:



<P>there was also, as she now learnt, nerves much affected,



<P>spirits much depressed to calm and raise, and her own



<P>imagination added that there must be a mind to be



<P>properly guided.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The family were not consumptive, and she was more inclined



<P>to hope than fear for her cousin, except when she thought



<P>of Miss Crawford; but Miss Crawford gave her the idea



<P>of being the child of good luck, and to her selfishness



<P>and vanity it would be good luck to have Edmund the only son.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Even in the sick chamber the fortunate Mary was



<P>not forgotten.&nbsp; Edmund's letter had this postscript.



<P>"On the subject of my last, I had actually begun a letter



<P>when called away by Tom's illness, but I have now changed



<P>my mind, and fear to trust the influence of friends.



<P>When Tom is better, I shall go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such was the state of Mansfield, and so it continued,



<P>with scarcely any change, till Easter.&nbsp; A line occasionally



<P>added by Edmund to his mother's letter was enough for



<P>Fanny's information.&nbsp; Tom's amendment was alarmingly slow.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Easter came particularly late this year, as Fanny had most



<P>sorrowfully considered, on first learning that she had



<P>no chance of leaving Portsmouth till after it.&nbsp; It came,



<P>and she had yet heard nothing of her return--nothing even



<P>of the going to London, which was to precede her return.



<P>Her aunt often expressed a wish for her, but there was



<P>no notice, no message from the uncle on whom all depended.



<P>She supposed he could not yet leave his son, but it was a cruel,



<P>a terrible delay to her.&nbsp; The end of April was coming on;



<P>it would soon be almost three months, instead of two,



<P>that she had been absent from them all, and that her days



<P>had been passing in a state of penance, which she loved



<P>them too well to hope they would thoroughly understand;



<P>and who could yet say when there might be leisure to think



<P>of or fetch her?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her eagerness, her impatience, her longings to be with them,



<P>were such as to bring a line or two of Cowper's Tirocinium



<P>for ever before her.&nbsp; "With what intense desire she wants



<P>her home," was continually on her tongue, as the truest



<P>description of a yearning which she could not suppose



<P>any schoolboy's bosom to feel more keenly.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When she had been coming to Portsmouth, she had loved to call



<P>it her home, had been fond of saying that she was going home;



<P>the word had been very dear to her, and so it still was,



<P>but it must be applied to Mansfield.&nbsp; _That_ was now



<P>the home.&nbsp; Portsmouth was Portsmouth; Mansfield was home.



<P>They had been long so arranged in the indulgence of her



<P>secret meditations, and nothing was more consolatory



<P>to her than to find her aunt using the same language:



<P>"I cannot but say I much regret your being from home



<P>at this distressing time, so very trying to my spirits.



<P>I trust and hope, and sincerely wish you may never be absent



<P>from home so long again," were most delightful sentences



<P>to her.&nbsp; Still, however, it was her private regale.



<P>Delicacy to her parents made her careful not to betray



<P>such a preference of her uncle's house.&nbsp; It was always:



<P>"When I go back into Northamptonshire, or when I return



<P>to Mansfield, I shall do so and so."&nbsp; For a great



<P>while it was so, but at last the longing grew stronger,



<P>it overthrew caution, and she found herself talking of what



<P>she should do when she went home before she was aware.



<P>She reproached herself, coloured, and looked fearfully towards



<P>her father and mother.&nbsp; She need not have been uneasy.



<P>There was no sign of displeasure, or even of hearing her.



<P>They were perfectly free from any jealousy of Mansfield.



<P>She was as welcome to wish herself there as to be there.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was sad to Fanny to lose all the pleasures of spring.



<P>She had not known before what pleasures she _had_ to lose



<P>in passing March and April in a town.&nbsp; She had not known



<P>before how much the beginnings and progress of vegetation



<P>had delighted her.&nbsp; What animation, both of body and mind,



<P>she had derived from watching the advance of that season



<P>which cannot, in spite of its capriciousness, be unlovely,



<P>and seeing its increasing beauties from the earliest



<P>flowers in the warmest divisions of her aunt's garden,



<P>to the opening of leaves of her uncle's plantations,



<P>and the glory of his woods.&nbsp; To be losing such pleasures



<P>was no trifle; to be losing them, because she was in



<P>the midst of closeness and noise, to have confinement,



<P>bad air, bad smells, substituted for liberty,



<P>freshness, fragrance, and verdure, was infinitely worse:



<P>but even these incitements to regret were feeble,



<P>compared with what arose from the conviction of being



<P>missed by her best friends, and the longing to be useful



<P>to those who were wanting her!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Could she have been at home, she might have been of service



<P>to every creature in the house.&nbsp; She felt that she must



<P>have been of use to all.&nbsp; To all she must have saved some



<P>trouble of head or hand; and were it only in supporting



<P>the spirits of her aunt Bertram, keeping her from the evil



<P>of solitude, or the still greater evil of a restless,



<P>officious companion, too apt to be heightening danger



<P>in order to enhance her own importance, her being there



<P>would have been a general good.&nbsp; She loved to fancy how she



<P>could have read to her aunt, how she could have talked



<P>to her, and tried at once to make her feel the blessing



<P>of what was, and prepare her mind for what might be;



<P>and how many walks up and down stairs she might have



<P>saved her, and how many messages she might have carried.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It astonished her that Tom's sisters could be satisfied



<P>with remaining in London at such a time, through an



<P>illness which had now, under different degrees of danger,



<P>lasted several weeks.&nbsp; _They_ might return to Mansfield



<P>when they chose; travelling could be no difficulty to _them_,



<P>and she could not comprehend how both could still keep away.



<P>If Mrs. Rushworth could imagine any interfering obligations,



<P>Julia was certainly able to quit London whenever she chose.



<P>It appeared from one of her aunt's letters that Julia



<P>had offered to return if wanted, but this was all.



<P>It was evident that she would rather remain where she was.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was disposed to think the influence of London



<P>very much at war with all respectable attachments.



<P>She saw the proof of it in Miss Crawford, as well as in



<P>her cousins; _her_ attachment to Edmund had been respectable,



<P>the most respectable part of her character; her friendship



<P>for herself had at least been blameless.&nbsp; Where was



<P>either sentiment now?&nbsp; It was so long since Fanny had had



<P>any letter from her, that she had some reason to think



<P>lightly of the friendship which had been so dwelt on.



<P>It was weeks since she had heard anything of Miss Crawford



<P>or of her other connexions in town, except through Mansfield,



<P>and she was beginning to suppose that she might never



<P>know whether Mr. Crawford had gone into Norfolk again



<P>or not till they met, and might never hear from his



<P>sister any more this spring, when the following letter



<P>was received to revive old and create some new sensations--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Forgive me, my dear Fanny, as soon as you can, for my



<P>long silence, and behave as if you could forgive me directly.



<P>This is my modest request and expectation, for you are so good,



<P>that I depend upon being treated better than I deserve,



<P>and I write now to beg an immediate answer.&nbsp; I want to know



<P>the state of things at Mansfield Park, and you, no doubt,



<P>are perfectly able to give it.&nbsp; One should be a brute not



<P>to feel for the distress they are in; and from what I hear,



<P>poor Mr. Bertram has a bad chance of ultimate recovery.



<P>I thought little of his illness at first.&nbsp; I looked



<P>upon him as the sort of person to be made a fuss with,



<P>and to make a fuss himself in any trifling disorder,



<P>and was chiefly concerned for those who had to nurse him;



<P>but now it is confidently asserted that he is really



<P>in a decline, that the symptoms are most alarming,



<P>and that part of the family, at least, are aware of it.



<P>If it be so, I am sure you must be included in that part,



<P>that discerning part, and therefore entreat you to let



<P>me know how far I have been rightly informed.&nbsp; I need



<P>not say how rejoiced I shall be to hear there has been



<P>any mistake, but the report is so prevalent that I confess



<P>I cannot help trembling.&nbsp; To have such a fine young man



<P>cut off in the flower of his days is most melancholy.



<P>Poor Sir Thomas will feel it dreadfully.&nbsp; I really am quite



<P>agitated on the subject.&nbsp; Fanny, Fanny, I see you smile



<P>and look cunning, but, upon my honour, I never bribed



<P>a physician in my life.&nbsp; Poor young man!&nbsp; If he is to die,



<P>there will be _two_ poor young men less in the world;



<P>and with a fearless face and bold voice would I say to any one,



<P>that wealth and consequence could fall into no hands



<P>more deserving of them.&nbsp; It was a foolish precipitation



<P>last Christmas, but the evil of a few days may be blotted



<P>out in part.&nbsp; Varnish and gilding hide many stains.



<P>It will be but the loss of the Esquire after his name.



<P>With real affection, Fanny, like mine, more might be overlooked.



<P>Write to me by return of post, judge of my anxiety,



<P>and do not trifle with it.&nbsp; Tell me the real truth,



<P>as you have it from the fountainhead.&nbsp; And now, do not



<P>trouble yourself to be ashamed of either my feelings or



<P>your own.&nbsp; Believe me, they are not only natural, they are



<P>philanthropic and virtuous.&nbsp; I put it to your conscience,



<P>whether 'Sir Edmund' would not do more good with all



<P>the Bertram property than any other possible 'Sir.'



<P>Had the Grants been at home I would not have troubled you,



<P>but you are now the only one I can apply to for the truth,



<P>his sisters not being within my reach.&nbsp; Mrs. R. has



<P>been spending the Easter with the Aylmers at Twickenham



<P>(as to be sure you know), and is not yet returned;



<P>and Julia is with the cousins who live near Bedford Square,



<P>but I forget their name and street.&nbsp; Could I immediately



<P>apply to either, however, I should still prefer you,



<P>because it strikes me that they have all along been so



<P>unwilling to have their own amusements cut up, as to shut



<P>their eyes to the truth.&nbsp; I suppose Mrs. R.'s Easter



<P>holidays will not last much longer; no doubt they are



<P>thorough holidays to her.&nbsp; The Aylmers are pleasant people;



<P>and her husband away, she can have nothing but enjoyment.



<P>I give her credit for promoting his going dutifully down



<P>to Bath, to fetch his mother; but how will she and the



<P>dowager agree in one house?&nbsp; Henry is not at hand, so I



<P>have nothing to say from him.&nbsp; Do not you think Edmund would



<P>have been in town again long ago, but for this illness?--



<P>Yours ever, Mary."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I had actually begun folding my letter when Henry walked in,



<P>but he brings no intelligence to prevent my sending it.



<P>Mrs. R. knows a decline is apprehended; he saw her this morning:



<P>she returns to Wimpole Street to-day; the old lady is come.



<P>Now do not make yourself uneasy with any queer fancies



<P>because he has been spending a few days at Richmond.



<P>He does it every spring.&nbsp; Be assured he cares for nobody



<P>but you.&nbsp; At this very moment he is wild to see you,



<P>and occupied only in contriving the means for doing so,



<P>and for making his pleasure conduce to yours.&nbsp; In proof,



<P>he repeats, and more eagerly, what he said at Portsmouth



<P>about our conveying you home, and I join him in it with all



<P>my soul.&nbsp; Dear Fanny, write directly, and tell us to come.



<P>It will do us all good.&nbsp; He and I can go to the Parsonage,



<P>you know, and be no trouble to our friends at Mansfield Park.



<P>It would really be gratifying to see them all again, and a



<P>little addition of society might be of infinite use to them;



<P>and as to yourself, you must feel yourself to be so wanted there,



<P>that you cannot in conscience--conscientious as you are--



<P>keep away, when you have the means of returning.



<P>I have not time or patience to give half Henry's messages;



<P>be satisfied that the spirit of each and every one is



<P>unalterable affection."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's disgust at the greater part of this letter,



<P>with her extreme reluctance to bring the writer of it



<P>and her cousin Edmund together, would have made her (as



<P>she felt) incapable of judging impartially whether



<P>the concluding offer might be accepted or not.



<P>To herself, individually, it was most tempting.&nbsp; To be



<P>finding herself, perhaps within three days, transported



<P>to Mansfield, was an image of the greatest felicity,



<P>but it would have been a material drawback to be owing



<P>such felicity to persons in whose feelings and conduct,



<P>at the present moment, she saw so much to condemn:



<P>the sister's feelings, the brother's conduct,



<P>_her_ cold-hearted ambition, _his_ thoughtless vanity.



<P>To have him still the acquaintance, the flirt perhaps,



<P>of Mrs. Rushworth!&nbsp; She was mortified.&nbsp; She had thought



<P>better of him.&nbsp; Happily, however, she was not left to weigh



<P>and decide between opposite inclinations and doubtful



<P>notions of right; there was no occasion to determine



<P>whether she ought to keep Edmund and Mary asunder or not.



<P>She had a rule to apply to, which settled everything.



<P>Her awe of her uncle, and her dread of taking a liberty



<P>with him, made it instantly plain to her what she



<P>had to do.&nbsp; She must absolutely decline the proposal.



<P>If he wanted, he would send for her; and even to offer



<P>an early return was a presumption which hardly anything



<P>would have seemed to justify.&nbsp; She thanked Miss Crawford,



<P>but gave a decided negative.&nbsp; "Her uncle, she understood,



<P>meant to fetch her; and as her cousin's illness had continued



<P>so many weeks without her being thought at all necessary,



<P>she must suppose her return would be unwelcome at present,



<P>and that she should be felt an encumbrance."
