<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her representation of her cousin's state at this time



<P>was exactly according to her own belief of it, and such



<P>as she supposed would convey to the sanguine mind of her



<P>correspondent the hope of everything she was wishing for.



<P>Edmund would be forgiven for being a clergyman, it seemed,



<P>under certain conditions of wealth; and this, she suspected,



<P>was all the conquest of prejudice which he was so ready



<P>to congratulate himself upon.&nbsp; She had only learnt to think



<P>nothing of consequence but money.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 44</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XLIV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Seven weeks of the two months were very nearly gone,



<P>when the one letter, the letter from Edmund, so long expected,



<P>was put into Fanny's hands.&nbsp; As she opened, and saw



<P>its length, she prepared herself for a minute detail



<P>of happiness and a profusion of love and praise towards



<P>the fortunate creature who was now mistress of his fate.



<P>These were the contents--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My Dear Fanny,--Excuse me that I have not written before.



<P>Crawford told me that you were wishing to hear from me,



<P>but I found it impossible to write from London,



<P>and persuaded myself that you would understand my silence.



<P>Could I have sent a few happy lines, they should not



<P>have been wanting, but nothing of that nature was ever



<P>in my power.&nbsp; I am returned to Mansfield in a less assured



<P>state that when I left it.&nbsp; My hopes are much weaker.



<P>You are probably aware of this already.&nbsp; So very fond of you



<P>as Miss Crawford is, it is most natural that she should tell



<P>you enough of her own feelings to furnish a tolerable guess



<P>at mine.&nbsp; I will not be prevented, however, from making my



<P>own communication.&nbsp; Our confidences in you need not clash.



<P>I ask no questions.&nbsp; There is something soothing in the



<P>idea that we have the same friend, and that whatever



<P>unhappy differences of opinion may exist between us,



<P>we are united in our love of you.&nbsp; It will be a comfort



<P>to me to tell you how things now are, and what are my



<P>present plans, if plans I can be said to have.&nbsp; I have been



<P>returned since Saturday.&nbsp; I was three weeks in London,



<P>and saw her (for London) very often.&nbsp; I had every attention



<P>from the Frasers that could be reasonably expected.



<P>I dare say I was not reasonable in carrying with me



<P>hopes of an intercourse at all like that of Mansfield.



<P>It was her manner, however, rather than any unfrequency



<P>of meeting.&nbsp; Had she been different when I did see her,



<P>I should have made no complaint, but from the very first



<P>she was altered:&nbsp; my first reception was so unlike



<P>what I had hoped, that I had almost resolved on leaving



<P>London again directly.&nbsp; I need not particularise.



<P>You know the weak side of her character, and may imagine



<P>the sentiments and expressions which were torturing me.



<P>She was in high spirits, and surrounded by those who



<P>were giving all the support of their own bad sense



<P>to her too lively mind.&nbsp; I do not like Mrs. Fraser.



<P>She is a cold-hearted, vain woman, who has married entirely



<P>from convenience, and though evidently unhappy in her marriage,



<P>places her disappointment not to faults of judgment,



<P>or temper, or disproportion of age, but to her being,



<P>after all, less affluent than many of her acquaintance,



<P>especially than her sister, Lady Stornaway, and is the



<P>determined supporter of everything mercenary and ambitious,



<P>provided it be only mercenary and ambitious enough.&nbsp; I look



<P>upon her intimacy with those two sisters as the greatest



<P>misfortune of her life and mine.&nbsp; They have been leading



<P>her astray for years.&nbsp; Could she be detached from them!--



<P>and sometimes I do not despair of it, for the affection



<P>appears to me principally on their side.&nbsp; They are very



<P>fond of her; but I am sure she does not love them as she



<P>loves you.&nbsp; When I think of her great attachment to you,



<P>indeed, and the whole of her judicious, upright conduct



<P>as a sister, she appears a very different creature,



<P>capable of everything noble, and I am ready to blame



<P>myself for a too harsh construction of a playful manner.



<P>I cannot give her up, Fanny.&nbsp; She is the only woman



<P>in the world whom I could ever think of as a wife.



<P>If I did not believe that she had some regard for me,



<P>of course I should not say this, but I do believe it.



<P>I am convinced that she is not without a decided preference.



<P>I have no jealousy of any individual.&nbsp; It is the influence



<P>of the fashionable world altogether that I am jealous of.



<P>It is the habits of wealth that I fear.&nbsp; Her ideas are



<P>not higher than her own fortune may warrant, but they



<P>are beyond what our incomes united could authorise.



<P>There is comfort, however, even here.&nbsp; I could better



<P>bear to lose her because not rich enough, than because



<P>of my profession.&nbsp; That would only prove her affection



<P>not equal to sacrifices, which, in fact, I am scarcely



<P>justified in asking; and, if I am refused, that, I think,



<P>will be the honest motive.&nbsp; Her prejudices, I trust,



<P>are not so strong as they were.&nbsp; You have my thoughts



<P>exactly as they arise, my dear Fanny; perhaps they are



<P>sometimes contradictory, but it will not be a less faithful



<P>picture of my mind.&nbsp; Having once begun, it is a pleasure



<P>to me to tell you all I feel.&nbsp; I cannot give her up.



<P>Connected as we already are, and, I hope, are to be,



<P>to give up Mary Crawford would be to give up the society



<P>of some of those most dear to me; to banish myself from



<P>the very houses and friends whom, under any other distress,



<P>I should turn to for consolation.&nbsp; The loss of Mary I must



<P>consider as comprehending the loss of Crawford and of Fanny.



<P>Were it a decided thing, an actual refusal, I hope I



<P>should know how to bear it, and how to endeavour to weaken



<P>her hold on my heart, and in the course of a few years--



<P>but I am writing nonsense.&nbsp; Were I refused, I must bear it;



<P>and till I am, I can never cease to try for her.



<P>This is the truth.&nbsp; The only question is _how_?&nbsp; What may



<P>be the likeliest means?&nbsp; I have sometimes thought of going



<P>to London again after Easter, and sometimes resolved on



<P>doing nothing till she returns to Mansfield.&nbsp; Even now,



<P>she speaks with pleasure of being in Mansfield in June;



<P>but June is at a great distance, and I believe I shall



<P>write to her.&nbsp; I have nearly determined on explaining



<P>myself by letter.&nbsp; To be at an early certainty is a



<P>material object.&nbsp; My present state is miserably irksome.



<P>Considering everything, I think a letter will be decidedly



<P>the best method of explanation.&nbsp; I shall be able to write



<P>much that I could not say, and shall be giving her time



<P>for reflection before she resolves on her answer,



<P>and I am less afraid of the result of reflection



<P>than of an immediate hasty impulse; I think I am.



<P>My greatest danger would lie in her consulting Mrs. Fraser,



<P>and I at a distance unable to help my own cause.



<P>A letter exposes to all the evil of consultation,



<P>and where the mind is anything short of perfect decision,



<P>an adviser may, in an unlucky moment, lead it to do what it



<P>may afterwards regret.&nbsp; I must think this matter over



<P>a little.&nbsp; This long letter, full of my own concerns alone,



<P>will be enough to tire even the friendship of a Fanny.



<P>The last time I saw Crawford was at Mrs. Fraser's party.



<P>I am more and more satisfied with all that I see and hear



<P>of him.&nbsp; There is not a shadow of wavering.&nbsp; He thoroughly



<P>knows his own mind, and acts up to his resolutions:



<P>an inestimable quality.&nbsp; I could not see him and my eldest



<P>sister in the same room without recollecting what you



<P>once told me, and I acknowledge that they did not meet



<P>as friends.&nbsp; There was marked coolness on her side.



<P>They scarcely spoke.&nbsp; I saw him draw back surprised,



<P>and I was sorry that Mrs. Rushworth should resent any



<P>former supposed slight to Miss Bertram.&nbsp; You will wish



<P>to hear my opinion of Maria's degree of comfort as a wife.



<P>There is no appearance of unhappiness.&nbsp; I hope they get



<P>on pretty well together.&nbsp; I dined twice in Wimpole Street,



<P>and might have been there oftener, but it is mortifying



<P>to be with Rushworth as a brother.&nbsp; Julia seems to enjoy



<P>London exceedingly.&nbsp; I had little enjoyment there,



<P>but have less here.&nbsp; We are not a lively party.&nbsp; You are



<P>very much wanted.&nbsp; I miss you more than I can express.



<P>My mother desires her best love, and hopes to hear



<P>from you soon.&nbsp; She talks of you almost every hour,



<P>and I am sorry to find how many weeks more she is likely



<P>to be without you.&nbsp; My father means to fetch you himself,



<P>but it will not be till after Easter, when he has



<P>business in town.&nbsp; You are happy at Portsmouth, I hope,



<P>but this must not be a yearly visit.&nbsp; I want you at home,



<P>that I may have your opinion about Thornton Lacey.



<P>I have little heart for extensive improvements till



<P>I know that it will ever have a mistress.&nbsp; I think I



<P>shall certainly write.&nbsp; It is quite settled that the



<P>Grants go to Bath; they leave Mansfield on Monday.



<P>I am glad of it.&nbsp; I am not comfortable enough to be fit



<P>for anybody; but your aunt seems to feel out of luck



<P>that such an article of Mansfield news should fall



<P>to my pen instead of hers.--Yours ever, my dearest



<P>Fanny."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I never will, no, I certainly never will wish for a



<P>letter again," was Fanny's secret declaration as she



<P>finished this.&nbsp; "What do they bring but disappointment



<P>and sorrow?&nbsp; Not till after Easter!&nbsp; How shall I bear it?



<P>And my poor aunt talking of me every hour!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny checked the tendency of these thoughts as well as



<P>she could, but she was within half a minute of starting



<P>the idea that Sir Thomas was quite unkind, both to her aunt



<P>and to herself.&nbsp; As for the main subject of the letter,



<P>there was nothing in that to soothe irritation.&nbsp; She was



<P>almost vexed into displeasure and anger against Edmund.



<P>"There is no good in this delay," said she.&nbsp; "Why is not



<P>it settled?&nbsp; He is blinded, and nothing will open his eyes;



<P>nothing can, after having had truths before him so long



<P>in vain.&nbsp; He will marry her, and be poor and miserable.



<P>God grant that her influence do not make him cease



<P>to be respectable!"&nbsp; She looked over the letter again.



<P>"'So very fond of me!' 'tis nonsense all.&nbsp; She loves



<P>nobody but herself and her brother.&nbsp; Her friends leading



<P>her astray for years!&nbsp; She is quite as likely to have led



<P>_them_ astray.&nbsp; They have all, perhaps, been corrupting



<P>one another; but if they are so much fonder of her than



<P>she is of them, she is the less likely to have been hurt,



<P>except by their flattery.&nbsp; 'The only woman in the world



<P>whom he could ever think of as a wife.'&nbsp; I firmly



<P>believe it.&nbsp; It is an attachment to govern his whole life.



<P>Accepted or refused, his heart is wedded to her for ever.



<P>'The loss of Mary I must consider as comprehending the loss



<P>of Crawford and Fanny.'&nbsp; Edmund, you do not know me.



<P>The families would never be connected if you did not



<P>connect them!&nbsp; Oh! write, write.&nbsp; Finish it at once.



<P>Let there be an end of this suspense.&nbsp; Fix, commit,



<P>condemn yourself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such sensations, however, were too near akin to



<P>resentment to be long guiding Fanny's soliloquies.



<P>She was soon more softened and sorrowful.&nbsp; His warm regard,



<P>his kind expressions, his confidential treatment,



<P>touched her strongly.&nbsp; He was only too good to everybody.



<P>It was a letter, in short, which she would not but have had



<P>for the world, and which could never be valued enough.



<P>This was the end of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Everybody at all addicted to letter-writing, without



<P>having much to say, which will include a large proportion



<P>of the female world at least, must feel with Lady Bertram



<P>that she was out of luck in having such a capital piece of



<P>Mansfield news as the certainty of the Grants going to Bath,



<P>occur at a time when she could make no advantage of it,



<P>and will admit that it must have been very mortifying



<P>to her to see it fall to the share of her thankless son,



<P>and treated as concisely as possible at the end of a



<P>long letter, instead of having it to spread over the largest



<P>part of a page of her own.&nbsp; For though Lady Bertram rather



<P>shone in the epistolary line, having early in her marriage,



<P>from the want of other employment, and the circumstance



<P>of Sir Thomas's being in Parliament, got into the way



<P>of making and keeping correspondents, and formed for



<P>herself a very creditable, common-place, amplifying style,



<P>so that a very little matter was enough for her:&nbsp; she could



<P>not do entirely without any; she must have something



<P>to write about, even to her niece; and being so soon



<P>to lose all the benefit of Dr. Grant's gouty symptoms



<P>and Mrs. Grant's morning calls, it was very hard upon her



<P>to be deprived of one of the last epistolary uses she could put



<P>them to.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a rich amends, however, preparing for her.



<P>Lady Bertram's hour of good luck came.&nbsp; Within a few days



<P>from the receipt of Edmund's letter, Fanny had one from



<P>her aunt, beginning thus--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My Dear Fanny,--I take up my pen to communicate some



<P>very alarming intelligence, which I make no doubt will



<P>give you much concern".

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was a great deal better than to have to take up the pen



<P>to acquaint her with all the particulars of the Grants'



<P>intended journey, for the present intelligence was of a



<P>nature to promise occupation for the pen for many days



<P>to come, being no less than the dangerous illness of her



<P>eldest son, of which they had received notice by express



<P>a few hours before.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tom had gone from London with a party of young men



<P>to Newmarket, where a neglected fall and a good deal



<P>of drinking had brought on a fever; and when the party



<P>broke up, being unable to move, had been left by himself



<P>at the house of one of these young men to the comforts of



<P>sickness and solitude, and the attendance only of servants.



<P>Instead of being soon well enough to follow his friends,



<P>as he had then hoped, his disorder increased considerably,



<P>and it was not long before he thought so ill of himself



<P>as to be as ready as his physician to have a letter



<P>despatched to Mansfield.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This distressing intelligence, as you may suppose,"



<P>observed her ladyship, after giving the substance of it,



<P>"has agitated us exceedingly, and we cannot prevent



<P>ourselves from being greatly alarmed and apprehensive



<P>for the poor invalid, whose state Sir Thomas fears may



<P>be very critical; and Edmund kindly proposes attending



<P>his brother immediately, but I am happy to add that Sir



<P>Thomas will not leave me on this distressing occasion,



<P>as it would be too trying for me.&nbsp; We shall greatly miss



<P>Edmund in our small circle, but I trust and hope he



<P>will find the poor invalid in a less alarming state than



<P>might be apprehended, and that he will be able to bring



<P>him to Mansfield shortly, which Sir Thomas proposes



<P>should be done, and thinks best on every account, and I



<P>flatter myself the poor sufferer will soon be able to bear



<P>the removal without material inconvenience or injury.



<P>As I have little doubt of your feeling for us, my dear Fanny,



<P>under these distressing circumstances, I will write again



<P>very soon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's feelings on the occasion were indeed considerably



<P>more warm and genuine than her aunt's style of writing.



<P>She felt truly for them all.&nbsp; Tom dangerously ill,



<P>Edmund gone to attend him, and the sadly small party



<P>remaining at Mansfield, were cares to shut out every



<P>other care, or almost every other.&nbsp; She could just find



<P>selfishness enough to wonder whether Edmund _had_ written



<P>to Miss Crawford before this summons came, but no sentiment



<P>dwelt long with her that was not purely affectionate and



<P>disinterestedly anxious.&nbsp; Her aunt did not neglect her:



<P>she wrote again and again; they were receiving frequent



<P>accounts from Edmund, and these accounts were as regularly



<P>transmitted to Fanny, in the same diffuse style,



<P>and the same medley of trusts, hopes, and fears,



<P>all following and producing each other at haphazard.



<P>It was a sort of playing at being frightened.



<P>The sufferings which Lady Bertram did not see had little



<P>power over her fancy; and she wrote very comfortably



<P>about agitation, and anxiety, and poor invalids, till Tom



<P>was actually conveyed to Mansfield, and her own eyes had



<P>beheld his altered appearance.&nbsp; Then a letter which she



<P>had been previously preparing for Fanny was finished



<P>in a different style, in the language of real feeling



<P>and alarm; then she wrote as she might have spoken.



<P>"He is just come, my dear Fanny, and is taken upstairs;



<P>and I am so shocked to see him, that I do not know



<P>what to do.&nbsp; I am sure he has been very ill.&nbsp; Poor Tom!



<P>I am quite grieved for him, and very much frightened,



<P>and so is Sir Thomas; and how glad I should be if you



<P>were here to comfort me.&nbsp; But Sir Thomas hopes he



<P>will be better to-morrow, and says we must consider



<P>his journey."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The real solicitude now awakened in the maternal bosom



<P>was not soon over.&nbsp; Tom's extreme impatience to be



<P>removed to Mansfield, and experience those comforts



<P>of home and family which had been little thought of in



<P>uninterrupted health, had probably induced his being



<P>conveyed thither too early, as a return of fever came on,



<P>and for a week he was in a more alarming state than ever.



<P>They were all very seriously frightened.&nbsp; Lady Bertram



<P>wrote her daily terrors to her niece, who might now be said



<P>to live upon letters, and pass all her time between suffering



<P>from that of to-day and looking forward to to-morrow's.



<P>Without any particular affection for her eldest cousin,



<P>her tenderness of heart made her feel that she could



<P>not spare him, and the purity of her principles added yet



<P>a keener solicitude, when she considered how little useful,



<P>how little self-denying his life had (apparently) been.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Susan was her only companion and listener on this, as on



<P>more common occasions.&nbsp; Susan was always ready to hear and



<P>to sympathise.&nbsp; Nobody else could be interested in so remote



<P>an evil as illness in a family above an hundred miles off;



<P>not even Mrs. Price, beyond a brief question or two,



<P>if she saw her daughter with a letter in her hand,



<P>and now and then the quiet observation of, "My poor



<P>sister Bertram must be in a great deal of trouble."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So long divided and so differently situated, the ties



<P>of blood were little more than nothing.&nbsp; An attachment,



<P>originally as tranquil as their tempers, was now become



<P>a mere name.&nbsp; Mrs. Price did quite as much for Lady



<P>Bertram as Lady Bertram would have done for Mrs. Price.



<P>Three or four Prices might have been swept away,



<P>any or all except Fanny and William, and Lady Bertram



<P>would have thought little about it; or perhaps might have



<P>caught from Mrs. Norris's lips the cant of its being



<P>a very happy thing and a great blessing to their poor



<P>dear sister Price to have them so well provided for.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 37</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXXVII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Mr. Crawford gone, Sir Thomas's next object was that he



<P>should be missed; and he entertained great hope that his



<P>niece would find a blank in the loss of those attentions



<P>which at the time she had felt, or fancied, an evil.



<P>She had tasted of consequence in its most flattering form;



<P>and he did hope that the loss of it, the sinking again



<P>into nothing, would awaken very wholesome regrets



<P>in her mind.&nbsp; He watched her with this idea; but he



<P>could hardly tell with what success.&nbsp; He hardly knew



<P>whether there were any difference in her spirits or not.



<P>She was always so gentle and retiring that her emotions



<P>were beyond his discrimination.&nbsp; He did not understand her:



<P>he felt that he did not; and therefore applied to Edmund



<P>to tell him how she stood affected on the present occasion,



<P>and whether she were more or less happy than she



<P>had been.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund did not discern any symptoms of regret, and thought



<P>his father a little unreasonable in supposing the first



<P>three or four days could produce any.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>What chiefly surprised Edmund was, that Crawford's sister,



<P>the friend and companion who had been so much to her,



<P>should not be more visibly regretted.&nbsp; He wondered that Fanny



<P>spoke so seldom of _her_, and had so little voluntarily



<P>to say of her concern at this separation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Alas! it was this sister, this friend and companion,



<P>who was now the chief bane of Fanny's comfort.&nbsp; If she



<P>could have believed Mary's future fate as unconnected



<P>with Mansfield as she was determined the brother's



<P>should be, if she could have hoped her return thither



<P>to be as distant as she was much inclined to think his,



<P>she would have been light of heart indeed; but the more



<P>she recollected and observed, the more deeply was she



<P>convinced that everything was now in a fairer train



<P>for Miss Crawford's marrying Edmund than it had ever



<P>been before.&nbsp; On his side the inclination was stronger,



<P>on hers less equivocal.&nbsp; His objections, the scruples of



<P>his integrity, seemed all done away, nobody could tell how;



<P>and the doubts and hesitations of her ambition were



<P>equally got over--and equally without apparent reason.



<P>It could only be imputed to increasing attachment.



<P>His good and her bad feelings yielded to love, and such



<P>love must unite them.&nbsp; He was to go to town as soon as



<P>some business relative to Thornton Lacey were completed--



<P>perhaps within a fortnight; he talked of going,



<P>he loved to talk of it; and when once with her again,



<P>Fanny could not doubt the rest.&nbsp; Her acceptance must



<P>be as certain as his offer; and yet there were bad



<P>feelings still remaining which made the prospect of it



<P>most sorrowful to her, independently, she believed,



<P>independently of self.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In their very last conversation, Miss Crawford, in spite



<P>of some amiable sensations, and much personal kindness,



<P>had still been Miss Crawford; still shewn a mind led astray



<P>and bewildered, and without any suspicion of being so;



<P>darkened, yet fancying itself light.&nbsp; She might love,



<P>but she did not deserve Edmund by any other sentiment.



<P>Fanny believed there was scarcely a second feeling



<P>in common between them; and she may be forgiven by older



<P>sages for looking on the chance of Miss Crawford's future



<P>improvement as nearly desperate, for thinking that if Edmund's



<P>influence in this season of love had already done so little



<P>in clearing her judgment, and regulating her notions,



<P>his worth would be finally wasted on her even in years



<P>of matrimony.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Experience might have hoped more for any young people



<P>so circumstanced, and impartiality would not have denied



<P>to Miss Crawford's nature that participation of the general



<P>nature of women which would lead her to adopt the opinions



<P>of the man she loved and respected as her own.&nbsp; But as such



<P>were Fanny's persuasions, she suffered very much from them,



<P>and could never speak of Miss Crawford without pain.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas, meanwhile, went on with his own hopes and



<P>his own observations, still feeling a right, by all his



<P>knowledge of human nature, to expect to see the effect



<P>of the loss of power and consequence on his niece's spirits,



<P>and the past attentions of the lover producing a craving



<P>for their return; and he was soon afterwards able to account



<P>for his not yet completely and indubitably seeing all this,



<P>by the prospect of another visitor, whose approach he



<P>could allow to be quite enough to support the spirits



<P>he was watching.&nbsp; William had obtained a ten days'



<P>leave of absence, to be given to Northamptonshire,



<P>and was coming, the happiest of lieutenants, because the



<P>latest made, to shew his happiness and describe his uniform.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He came; and he would have been delighted to shew his uniform



<P>there too, had not cruel custom prohibited its appearance



<P>except on duty.&nbsp; So the uniform remained at Portsmouth,



<P>and Edmund conjectured that before Fanny had any chance



<P>of seeing it, all its own freshness and all the freshness



<P>of its wearer's feelings must be worn away.&nbsp; It would be sunk



<P>into a badge of disgrace; for what can be more unbecoming,



<P>or more worthless, than the uniform of a lieutenant,



<P>who has been a lieutenant a year or two, and sees



<P>others made commanders before him?&nbsp; So reasoned Edmund,



<P>till his father made him the confidant of a scheme which



<P>placed Fanny's chance of seeing the second lieutenant



<P>of H.M.S. Thrush in all his glory in another light.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This scheme was that she should accompany her brother



<P>back to Portsmouth, and spend a little time with her



<P>own family.&nbsp; It had occurred to Sir Thomas, in one of his



<P>dignified musings, as a right and desirable measure;



<P>but before he absolutely made up his mind, he consulted



<P>his son.&nbsp; Edmund considered it every way, and saw nothing



<P>but what was right.&nbsp; The thing was good in itself,



<P>and could not be done at a better time; and he had no doubt



<P>of it being highly agreeable to Fanny.&nbsp; This was enough



<P>to determine Sir Thomas; and a decisive "then so it shall be"



<P>closed that stage of the business; Sir Thomas retiring



<P>from it with some feelings of satisfaction, and views



<P>of good over and above what he had communicated to his son;



<P>for his prime motive in sending her away had very little



<P>to do with the propriety of her seeing her parents again,



<P>and nothing at all with any idea of making her happy.



<P>He certainly wished her to go willingly, but he as certainly



<P>wished her to be heartily sick of home before her visit ended;



<P>and that a little abstinence from the elegancies and luxuries



<P>of Mansfield Park would bring her mind into a sober state,



<P>and incline her to a juster estimate of the value



<P>of that home of greater permanence, and equal comfort,



<P>of which she had the offer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a medicinal project upon his niece's understanding,



<P>which he must consider as at present diseased.



<P>A residence of eight or nine years in the abode of wealth



<P>and plenty had a little disordered her powers of comparing



<P>and judging.&nbsp; Her father's house would, in all probability,



<P>teach her the value of a good income; and he trusted that



<P>she would be the wiser and happier woman, all her life,



<P>for the experiment he had devised.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Had Fanny been at all addicted to raptures, she must have



<P>had a strong attack of them when she first understood



<P>what was intended, when her uncle first made her the offer



<P>of visiting the parents, and brothers, and sisters,



<P>from whom she had been divided almost half her life;



<P>of returning for a couple of months to the scenes of



<P>her infancy, with William for the protector and companion



<P>of her journey, and the certainty of continuing to see



<P>William to the last hour of his remaining on land.



<P>Had she ever given way to bursts of delight, it must have



<P>been then, for she was delighted, but her happiness was



<P>of a quiet, deep, heart-swelling sort; and though never



<P>a great talker, she was always more inclined to silence



<P>when feeling most strongly.&nbsp; At the moment she could



<P>only thank and accept.&nbsp; Afterwards, when familiarised



<P>with the visions of enjoyment so suddenly opened, she could



<P>speak more largely to William and Edmund of what she felt;



<P>but still there were emotions of tenderness that could



<P>not be clothed in words.&nbsp; The remembrance of all her



<P>earliest pleasures, and of what she had suffered in being



<P>torn from them, came over her with renewed strength,



<P>and it seemed as if to be at home again would heal



<P>every pain that had since grown out of the separation.



<P>To be in the centre of such a circle, loved by so many,



<P>and more loved by all than she had ever been before;



<P>to feel affection without fear or restraint; to feel



<P>herself the equal of those who surrounded her; to be at



<P>peace from all mention of the Crawfords, safe from every



<P>look which could be fancied a reproach on their account.



<P>This was a prospect to be dwelt on with a fondness that could



<P>be but half acknowledged.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund, too--to be two months from _him_ (and perhaps



<P>she might be allowed to make her absence three)



<P>must do her good.&nbsp; At a distance, unassailed by his looks



<P>or his kindness, and safe from the perpetual irritation



<P>of knowing his heart, and striving to avoid his confidence,



<P>she should be able to reason herself into a properer state;



<P>she should be able to think of him as in London,



<P>and arranging everything there, without wretchedness.



<P>What might have been hard to bear at Mansfield was to become



<P>a slight evil at Portsmouth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The only drawback was the doubt of her aunt Bertram's being



<P>comfortable without her.&nbsp; She was of use to no one else;



<P>but _there_ she might be missed to a degree that she did



<P>not like to think of; and that part of the arrangement



<P>was, indeed, the hardest for Sir Thomas to accomplish,



<P>and what only _he_ could have accomplished at all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But he was master at Mansfield Park.&nbsp; When he had really



<P>resolved on any measure, he could always carry it through;



<P>and now by dint of long talking on the subject,



<P>explaining and dwelling on the duty of Fanny's sometimes



<P>seeing her family, he did induce his wife to let her go;



<P>obtaining it rather from submission, however, than conviction,



<P>for Lady Bertram was convinced of very little more than



<P>that Sir Thomas thought Fanny ought to go, and therefore



<P>that she must.&nbsp; In the calmness of her own dressing-room,



<P>in the impartial flow of her own meditations, unbiassed by



<P>his bewildering statements, she could not acknowledge any



<P>necessity for Fanny's ever going near a father and mother



<P>who had done without her so long, while she was so useful



<P>to herself And as to the not missing her, which under



<P>Mrs. Norris's discussion was the point attempted to be proved,



<P>she set herself very steadily against admitting any such thing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas had appealed to her reason, conscience, and dignity.



<P>He called it a sacrifice, and demanded it of her goodness



<P>and self-command as such.&nbsp; But Mrs. Norris wanted to persuade



<P>her that Fanny could be very well spared--_she_ being



<P>ready to give up all her own time to her as requested--



<P>and, in short, could not really be wanted or missed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That may be, sister," was all Lady Bertram's reply.



<P>"I dare say you are very right; but I am sure I shall miss



<P>her very much."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next step was to communicate with Portsmouth.&nbsp; Fanny wrote



<P>to offer herself; and her mother's answer, though short,



<P>was so kind--a few simple lines expressed so natural and



<P>motherly a joy in the prospect of seeing her child again,



<P>as to confirm all the daughter's views of happiness in



<P>being with her--convincing her that she should now find



<P>a warm and affectionate friend in the "mama" who had



<P>certainly shewn no remarkable fondness for her formerly;



<P>but this she could easily suppose to have been her own



<P>fault or her own fancy.&nbsp; She had probably alienated love



<P>by the helplessness and fretfulness of a fearful temper,



<P>or been unreasonable in wanting a larger share than



<P>any one among so many could deserve.&nbsp; Now, when she



<P>knew better how to be useful, and how to forbear,



<P>and when her mother could be no longer occupied by the



<P>incessant demands of a house full of little children,



<P>there would be leisure and inclination for every comfort,



<P>and they should soon be what mother and daughter ought



<P>to be to each other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>William was almost as happy in the plan as his sister.



<P>It would be the greatest pleasure to him to have her there



<P>to the last moment before he sailed, and perhaps find



<P>her there still when he came in from his first cruise.



<P>And besides, he wanted her so very much to see the Thrush



<P>before she went out of harbour--the Thrush was certainly



<P>the finest sloop in the service--and there were several



<P>improvements in the dockyard, too, which he quite longed to



<P>shew her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He did not scruple to add that her being at home



<P>for a while would be a great advantage to everybody.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know how it is," said he; "but we seem to want



<P>some of your nice ways and orderliness at my father's. The



<P>house is always in confusion.&nbsp; You will set things going



<P>in a better way, I am sure.&nbsp; You will tell my mother how it



<P>all ought to be, and you will be so useful to Susan, and you



<P>will teach Betsey, and make the boys love and mind you.



<P>How right and comfortable it will all be!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By the time Mrs. Price's answer arrived, there remained



<P>but a very few days more to be spent at Mansfield;



<P>and for part of one of those days the young travellers



<P>were in a good deal of alarm on the subject of their



<P>journey, for when the mode of it came to be talked of,



<P>and Mrs. Norris found that all her anxiety to save her



<P>brother-in-law's money was vain, and that in spite of her



<P>wishes and hints for a less expensive conveyance of Fanny,



<P>they were to travel post; when she saw Sir Thomas actually



<P>give William notes for the purpose, she was struck with



<P>the idea of there being room for a third in the carriage,



<P>and suddenly seized with a strong inclination to go



<P>with them, to go and see her poor dear sister Price.



<P>She proclaimed her thoughts.&nbsp; She must say that she



<P>had more than half a mind to go with the young people;



<P>it would be such an indulgence to her; she had not seen



<P>her poor dear sister Price for more than twenty years;



<P>and it would be a help to the young people in their journey



<P>to have her older head to manage for them; and she could



<P>not help thinking her poor dear sister Price would feel it



<P>very unkind of her not to come by such an opportunity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>William and Fanny were horror-struck at the idea.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All the comfort of their comfortable journey would



<P>be destroyed at once.&nbsp; With woeful countenances they



<P>looked at each other.&nbsp; Their suspense lasted an hour



<P>or two.&nbsp; No one interfered to encourage or dissuade.



<P>Mrs. Norris was left to settle the matter by herself;



<P>and it ended, to the infinite joy of her nephew and niece,



<P>in the recollection that she could not possibly be spared



<P>from Mansfield Park at present; that she was a great deal



<P>too necessary to Sir Thomas and Lady Bertram for her to be



<P>able to answer it to herself to leave them even for a week,



<P>and therefore must certainly sacrifice every other pleasure



<P>to that of being useful to them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It had, in fact, occurred to her, that though taken



<P>to Portsmouth for nothing, it would be hardly possible



<P>for her to avoid paying her own expenses back again.



<P>So her poor dear sister Price was left to all the



<P>disappointment of her missing such an opportunity,



<P>and another twenty years' absence, perhaps, begun.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund's plans were affected by this Portsmouth journey,



<P>this absence of Fanny's. He too had a sacrifice to make



<P>to Mansfield Park as well as his aunt.&nbsp; He had intended,



<P>about this time, to be going to London; but he could



<P>not leave his father and mother just when everybody else



<P>of most importance to their comfort was leaving them;



<P>and with an effort, felt but not boasted of, he delayed



<P>for a week or two longer a journey which he was looking



<P>forward to with the hope of its fixing his happiness



<P>for ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He told Fanny of it.&nbsp; She knew so much already,



<P>that she must know everything.&nbsp; It made the substance



<P>of one other confidential discourse about Miss Crawford;



<P>and Fanny was the more affected from feeling it to be



<P>the last time in which Miss Crawford's name would ever



<P>be mentioned between them with any remains of liberty.



<P>Once afterwards she was alluded to by him.&nbsp; Lady Bertram had



<P>been telling her niece in the evening to write to her soon



<P>and often, and promising to be a good correspondent herself;



<P>and Edmund, at a convenient moment, then added in a whisper,



<P>"And _I_ shall write to you, Fanny, when I have anything



<P>worth writing about, anything to say that I think you



<P>will like to hear, and that you will not hear so soon



<P>from any other quarter."&nbsp; Had she doubted his meaning



<P>while she listened, the glow in his face, when she looked



<P>up at him, would have been decisive.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For this letter she must try to arm herself.&nbsp; That a



<P>letter from Edmund should be a subject of terror!



<P>She began to feel that she had not yet gone through all



<P>the changes of opinion and sentiment which the progress



<P>of time and variation of circumstances occasion in this



<P>world of changes.&nbsp; The vicissitudes of the human mind



<P>had not yet been exhausted by her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Fanny! though going as she did willingly and eagerly,



<P>the last evening at Mansfield Park must still



<P>be wretchedness.&nbsp; Her heart was completely sad at parting.



<P>She had tears for every room in the house, much more



<P>for every beloved inhabitant.&nbsp; She clung to her aunt,



<P>because she would miss her; she kissed the hand of her



<P>uncle with struggling sobs, because she had displeased him;



<P>and as for Edmund, she could neither speak, nor look,



<P>nor think, when the last moment came with _him_; and it



<P>was not till it was over that she knew he was giving



<P>her the affectionate farewell of a brother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All this passed overnight, for the journey was to



<P>begin very early in the morning; and when the small,



<P>diminished party met at breakfast, William and Fanny



<P>were talked of as already advanced one stage.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 23</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>"But why should Mrs. Grant ask Fanny?" said Lady Bertram.



<P>"How came she to think of asking Fanny?&nbsp; Fanny never



<P>dines there, you know, in this sort of way.&nbsp; I cannot



<P>spare her, and I am sure she does not want to go.



<P>Fanny, you do not want to go, do you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you put such a question to her," cried Edmund,



<P>preventing his cousin's speaking, "Fanny will immediately



<P>say No; but I am sure, my dear mother, she would like to go;



<P>and I can see no reason why she should not."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot imagine why Mrs. Grant should think of asking her?



<P>She never did before.&nbsp; She used to ask your sisters now



<P>and then, but she never asked Fanny."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If you cannot do without me, ma'am--" said Fanny,



<P>in a self-denying tone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But my mother will have my father with her all the evening."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure, so I shall."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Suppose you take my father's opinion, ma'am."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's well thought of.&nbsp; So I will, Edmund.&nbsp; I will



<P>ask Sir Thomas, as soon as he comes in, whether I can



<P>do without her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As you please, ma'am, on that head; but I meant my



<P>father's opinion as to the _propriety_ of the invitation's



<P>being accepted or not; and I think he will consider



<P>it a right thing by Mrs. Grant, as well as by Fanny,



<P>that being the _first_ invitation it should be accepted."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not know.&nbsp; We will ask him.&nbsp; But he will be very



<P>much surprised that Mrs. Grant should ask Fanny at all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was nothing more to be said, or that could be



<P>said to any purpose, till Sir Thomas were present;



<P>but the subject involving, as it did, her own evening's



<P>comfort for the morrow, was so much uppermost in Lady



<P>Bertram's mind, that half an hour afterwards, on his



<P>looking in for a minute in his way from his plantation



<P>to his dressing-room, she called him back again,



<P>when he had almost closed the door, with "Sir Thomas,



<P>stop a moment--I have something to say to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her tone of calm languor, for she never took the trouble



<P>of raising her voice, was always heard and attended to;



<P>and Sir Thomas came back.&nbsp; Her story began; and Fanny



<P>immediately slipped out of the room; for to hear herself



<P>the subject of any discussion with her uncle was more



<P>than her nerves could bear.&nbsp; She was anxious, she knew--



<P>more anxious perhaps than she ought to be--for what was



<P>it after all whether she went or staid? but if her uncle



<P>were to be a great while considering and deciding,



<P>and with very grave looks, and those grave looks directed



<P>to her, and at last decide against her, she might not



<P>be able to appear properly submissive and indifferent.



<P>Her cause, meanwhile, went on well.&nbsp; It began, on Lady



<P>Bertram's part, with--"I have something to tell you



<P>that will surprise you.&nbsp; Mrs. Grant has asked Fanny



<P>to dinner."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Sir Thomas, as if waiting more to accomplish



<P>the surprise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Edmund wants her to go.&nbsp; But how can I spare her?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She will be late," said Sir Thomas, taking out his watch;



<P>"but what is your difficulty?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund found himself obliged to speak and fill up



<P>the blanks in his mother's story.&nbsp; He told the whole;



<P>and she had only to add, "So strange! for Mrs. Grant



<P>never used to ask her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But is it not very natural," observed Edmund,



<P>"that Mrs. Grant should wish to procure so agreeable



<P>a visitor for her sister?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nothing can be more natural," said Sir Thomas, after a



<P>short deliberation; "nor, were there no sister in the case,



<P>could anything, in my opinion, be more natural.



<P>Mrs. Grant's shewing civility to Miss Price, to Lady



<P>Bertram's niece, could never want explanation.&nbsp; The only



<P>surprise I can feel is, that this should be the _first_



<P>time of its being paid.&nbsp; Fanny was perfectly right in



<P>giving only a conditional answer.&nbsp; She appears to feel



<P>as she ought.&nbsp; But as I conclude that she must wish to go,



<P>since all young people like to be together, I can see



<P>no reason why she should be denied the indulgence."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But can I do without her, Sir Thomas?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed I think you may."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She always makes tea, you know, when my sister is not here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your sister, perhaps, may be prevailed on to spend



<P>the day with us, and I shall certainly be at home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well, then, Fanny may go, Edmund."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The good news soon followed her.&nbsp; Edmund knocked at her



<P>door in his way to his own.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Fanny, it is all happily settled, and without



<P>the smallest hesitation on your uncle's side.



<P>He had but one opinion.&nbsp; You are to go."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, I am _so_ glad," was Fanny's instinctive reply;



<P>though when she had turned from him and shut the door,



<P>she could not help feeling, "And yet why should I be glad?



<P>for am I not certain of seeing or hearing something there



<P>to pain me?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In spite of this conviction, however, she was glad.



<P>Simple as such an engagement might appear in other eyes,



<P>it had novelty and importance in hers, for excepting the



<P>day at Sotherton, she had scarcely ever dined out before;



<P>and though now going only half a mile, and only to



<P>three people, still it was dining out, and all the little



<P>interests of preparation were enjoyments in themselves.



<P>She had neither sympathy nor assistance from those who ought



<P>to have entered into her feelings and directed her taste;



<P>for Lady Bertram never thought of being useful to anybody,



<P>and Mrs. Norris, when she came on the morrow, in consequence



<P>of an early call and invitation from Sir Thomas, was in



<P>a very ill humour, and seemed intent only on lessening



<P>her niece's pleasure, both present and future, as much



<P>as possible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word, Fanny, you are in high luck to meet



<P>with such attention and indulgence!&nbsp; You ought to be



<P>very much obliged to Mrs. Grant for thinking of you,



<P>and to your aunt for letting you go, and you ought to look



<P>upon it as something extraordinary; for I hope you are



<P>aware that there is no real occasion for your going into



<P>company in this sort of way, or ever dining out at all;



<P>and it is what you must not depend upon ever being repeated.



<P>Nor must you be fancying that the invitation is meant



<P>as any particular compliment to _you_; the compliment



<P>is intended to your uncle and aunt and me.&nbsp; Mrs. Grant



<P>thinks it a civility due to _us_ to take a little notice



<P>of you, or else it would never have come into her head,



<P>and you may be very certain that, if your cousin Julia



<P>had been at home, you would not have been asked at all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris had now so ingeniously done away all



<P>Mrs. Grant's part of the favour, that Fanny, who found



<P>herself expected to speak, could only say that she was



<P>very much obliged to her aunt Bertram for sparing her,



<P>and that she was endeavouring to put her aunt's evening



<P>work in such a state as to prevent her being missed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! depend upon it, your aunt can do very well without you,



<P>or you would not be allowed to go.&nbsp; _I_ shall be here, so you



<P>may be quite easy about your aunt.&nbsp; And I hope you will have



<P>a very _agreeable_ day, and find it all mighty _delightful_.



<P>But I must observe that five is the very awkwardest of



<P>all possible numbers to sit down to table; and I cannot



<P>but be surprised that such an _elegant_ lady as Mrs. Grant



<P>should not contrive better!&nbsp; And round their enormous great



<P>wide table, too, which fills up the room so dreadfully!



<P>Had the doctor been contented to take my dining-table when I



<P>came away, as anybody in their senses would have done,



<P>instead of having that absurd new one of his own,



<P>which is wider, literally wider than the dinner-table here,



<P>how infinitely better it would have been! and how much



<P>more he would have been respected! for people are never



<P>respected when they step out of their proper sphere.



<P>Remember that, Fanny.&nbsp; Five--only five to be sitting



<P>round that table.&nbsp; However, you will have dinner enough



<P>on it for ten, I dare say."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris fetched breath, and went on again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The nonsense and folly of people's stepping out of their



<P>rank and trying to appear above themselves, makes me



<P>think it right to give _you_ a hint, Fanny, now that you



<P>are going into company without any of us; and I do beseech



<P>and entreat you not to be putting yourself forward,



<P>and talking and giving your opinion as if you were one of



<P>your cousins--as if you were dear Mrs. Rushworth or Julia.



<P>_That_ will never do, believe me.&nbsp; Remember, wherever you are,



<P>you must be the lowest and last; and though Miss Crawford



<P>is in a manner at home at the Parsonage, you are not to



<P>be taking place of her.&nbsp; And as to coming away at night,



<P>you are to stay just as long as Edmund chuses.



<P>Leave him to settle _that_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, ma'am, I should not think of anything else."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And if it should rain, which I think exceedingly likely,



<P>for I never saw it more threatening for a wet evening



<P>in my life, you must manage as well as you can, and not be



<P>expecting the carriage to be sent for you.&nbsp; I certainly



<P>do not go home to-night, and, therefore, the carriage will



<P>not be out on my account; so you must make up your mind



<P>to what may happen, and take your things accordingly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her niece thought it perfectly reasonable.&nbsp; She rated her



<P>own claims to comfort as low even as Mrs. Norris could;



<P>and when Sir Thomas soon afterwards, just opening



<P>the door, said, "Fanny, at what time would you have the



<P>carriage come round?" she felt a degree of astonishment



<P>which made it impossible for her to speak.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Sir Thomas!" cried Mrs. Norris, red with anger,



<P>"Fanny can walk."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Walk!" repeated Sir Thomas, in a tone of most unanswerable



<P>dignity, and coming farther into the room.&nbsp; "My niece



<P>walk to a dinner engagement at this time of the year!



<P>Will twenty minutes after four suit you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir," was Fanny's humble answer, given with the



<P>feelings almost of a criminal towards Mrs. Norris;



<P>and not bearing to remain with her in what might seem



<P>a state of triumph, she followed her uncle out of the room,



<P>having staid behind him only long enough to hear these



<P>words spoken in angry agitation--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Quite unnecessary! a great deal too kind!



<P>But Edmund goes; true, it is upon Edmund's account.



<P>I observed he was hoarse on Thursday night."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But this could not impose on Fanny.&nbsp; She felt that



<P>the carriage was for herself, and herself alone:



<P>and her uncle's consideration of her, coming immediately



<P>after such representations from her aunt, cost her



<P>some tears of gratitude when she was alone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The coachman drove round to a minute; another minute



<P>brought down the gentleman; and as the lady had, with a



<P>most scrupulous fear of being late, been many minutes



<P>seated in the drawing-room, Sir Thomas saw them off



<P>in as good time as his own correctly punctual habits required.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now I must look at you, Fanny," said Edmund, with the



<P>kind smile of an affectionate brother, "and tell you



<P>how I like you; and as well as I can judge by this light,



<P>you look very nicely indeed.&nbsp; What have you got on?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The new dress that my uncle was so good as to give me



<P>on my cousin's marriage.&nbsp; I hope it is not too fine; but I



<P>thought I ought to wear it as soon as I could, and that I



<P>might not have such another opportunity all the winter.



<P>I hope you do not think me too fine."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A woman can never be too fine while she is all in white.&nbsp; No,

I



<P>see



<P>no finery about you; nothing but what is perfectly proper.



<P>Your gown seems very pretty.&nbsp; I like these glossy spots.



<P>Has not Miss Crawford a gown something the same?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In approaching the Parsonage they passed close by the



<P>stable-yard and coach-house.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Heyday!" said Edmund, "here's company, here's a carriage!



<P>who have they got to meet us?"&nbsp; And letting down the side-glass



<P>to distinguish, "'Tis Crawford's, Crawford's barouche,



<P>I protest!&nbsp; There are his own two men pushing it back



<P>into its old quarters.&nbsp; He is here, of course.&nbsp; This is



<P>quite a surprise, Fanny.&nbsp; I shall be very glad to see him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was no occasion, there was no time for Fanny



<P>to say how very differently she felt; but the idea



<P>of having such another to observe her was a great



<P>increase of the trepidation with which she performed



<P>the very awful ceremony of walking into the drawing-room.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the drawing-room Mr. Crawford certainly was, having been



<P>just long enough arrived to be ready for dinner; and the



<P>smiles and pleased looks of the three others standing



<P>round him, shewed how welcome was his sudden resolution



<P>of coming to them for a few days on leaving Bath.



<P>A very cordial meeting passed between him and Edmund;



<P>and with the exception of Fanny, the pleasure was general;



<P>and even to _her_ there might be some advantage in



<P>his presence, since every addition to the party must



<P>rather forward her favourite indulgence of being suffered



<P>to sit silent and unattended to.&nbsp; She was soon aware



<P>of this herself; for though she must submit, as her



<P>own propriety of mind directed, in spite of her aunt



<P>Norris's opinion, to being the principal lady in company,



<P>and to all the little distinctions consequent thereon,



<P>she found, while they were at table, such a happy flow



<P>of conversation prevailing, in which she was not required



<P>to take any part--there was so much to be said between



<P>the brother and sister about Bath, so much between



<P>the two young men about hunting, so much of politics



<P>between Mr. Crawford and Dr. Grant, and of everything



<P>and all together between Mr. Crawford and Mrs. Grant,



<P>as to leave her the fairest prospect of having only to



<P>listen in quiet, and of passing a very agreeable day.



<P>She could not compliment the newly arrived gentleman,



<P>however, with any appearance of interest, in a scheme



<P>for extending his stay at Mansfield, and sending for his



<P>hunters from Norfolk, which, suggested by Dr. Grant,



<P>advised by Edmund, and warmly urged by the two sisters,



<P>was soon in possession of his mind, and which he seemed



<P>to want to be encouraged even by her to resolve on.



<P>Her opinion was sought as to the probable continuance



<P>of the open weather, but her answers were as short



<P>and indifferent as civility allowed.&nbsp; She could not wish



<P>him to stay, and would much rather not have him speak



<P>to her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her two absent cousins, especially Maria, were much in her



<P>thoughts on seeing him; but no embarrassing remembrance



<P>affected _his_ spirits.&nbsp; Here he was again on the same



<P>ground where all had passed before, and apparently as



<P>willing to stay and be happy without the Miss Bertrams,



<P>as if he had never known Mansfield in any other state.



<P>She heard them spoken of by him only in a general way,



<P>till they were all re-assembled in the drawing-room,



<P>when Edmund, being engaged apart in some matter of business



<P>with Dr. Grant, which seemed entirely to engross them,



<P>and Mrs. Grant occupied at the tea-table, he began talking



<P>of them with more particularity to his other sister.



<P>With a significant smile, which made Fanny quite hate him,



<P>he said, "So!&nbsp; Rushworth and his fair bride are at Brighton,



<P>I understand; happy man!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, they have been there about a fortnight, Miss Price,



<P>have they not?&nbsp; And Julia is with them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And Mr. Yates, I presume, is not far off."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Yates!&nbsp; Oh! we hear nothing of Mr. Yates.&nbsp; I do not



<P>imagine he figures much in the letters to Mansfield Park;



<P>do you, Miss Price?&nbsp; I think my friend Julia knows better



<P>than to entertain her father with Mr. Yates."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Poor Rushworth and his two-and-forty speeches!"



<P>continued Crawford.&nbsp; "Nobody can ever forget them.



<P>Poor fellow!&nbsp; I see him now--his toil and his despair.



<P>Well, I am much mistaken if his lovely Maria will ever



<P>want him to make two-and-forty speeches to her"; adding,



<P>with a momentary seriousness, "She is too good for him--



<P>much too good."&nbsp; And then changing his tone again to one



<P>of gentle gallantry, and addressing Fanny, he said,



<P>"You were Mr. Rushworth's best friend.&nbsp; Your kindness and



<P>patience can never be forgotten, your indefatigable patience



<P>in trying to make it possible for him to learn his part--



<P>in trying to give him a brain which nature had denied--



<P>to mix up an understanding for him out of the superfluity



<P>of your own!&nbsp; _He_ might not have sense enough himself



<P>to estimate your kindness, but I may venture to say that it



<P>had honour from all the rest of the party."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny coloured, and said nothing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is as a dream, a pleasant dream!" he exclaimed,



<P>breaking forth again, after a few minutes' musing.&nbsp; "I shall



<P>always look back on our theatricals with exquisite pleasure.



<P>There was such an interest, such an animation, such a



<P>spirit diffused.&nbsp; Everybody felt it.&nbsp; We were all alive.



<P>There was employment, hope, solicitude, bustle, for every



<P>hour of the day.&nbsp; Always some little objection,



<P>some little doubt, some little anxiety to be got over.



<P>I never was happier."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With silent indignation Fanny repeated to herself,



<P>"Never happier!--never happier than when doing what



<P>you must know was not justifiable!--never happier



<P>than when behaving so dishonourably and unfeelingly!



<P>Oh! what a corrupted mind!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We were unlucky, Miss Price," he continued, in a lower tone,



<P>to avoid the possibility of being heard by Edmund,



<P>and not at all aware of her feelings, "we certainly



<P>were very unlucky.&nbsp; Another week, only one other week,



<P>would have been enough for us.&nbsp; I think if we had had the



<P>disposal of events--if Mansfield Park had had the government



<P>of the winds just for a week or two, about the equinox,



<P>there would have been a difference.&nbsp; Not that we would



<P>have endangered his safety by any tremendous weather--



<P>but only by a steady contrary wind, or a calm.&nbsp; I think,



<P>Miss Price, we would have indulged ourselves with a week's



<P>calm in the Atlantic at that season."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He seemed determined to be answered; and Fanny,



<P>averting her face, said, with a firmer tone than usual,



<P>"As far as _I_ am concerned, sir, I would not have



<P>delayed his return for a day.&nbsp; My uncle disapproved it



<P>all so entirely when he did arrive, that in my opinion



<P>everything had gone quite far enough."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had never spoken so much at once to him in her life before,



<P>and never so angrily to any one; and when her speech was over,



<P>she trembled and blushed at her own daring.&nbsp; He was surprised;



<P>but after a few moments' silent consideration of her,



<P>replied in a calmer, graver tone, and as if the candid



<P>result of conviction, "I believe you are right.&nbsp; It was



<P>more pleasant than prudent.&nbsp; We were getting too noisy."



<P>And then turning the conversation, he would have engaged



<P>her on some other subject, but her answers were so shy



<P>and reluctant that he could not advance in any.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford, who had been repeatedly eyeing Dr. Grant



<P>and Edmund, now observed, "Those gentlemen must have



<P>some very interesting point to discuss."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The most interesting in the world," replied her brother--



<P>"how to make money; how to turn a good income into a better.



<P>Dr. Grant is giving Bertram instructions about the living



<P>he is to step into so soon.&nbsp; I find he takes orders



<P>in a few weeks.&nbsp; They were at it in the dining-parlour.



<P>I am glad to hear Bertram will be so well off.&nbsp; He will



<P>have a very pretty income to make ducks and drakes with,



<P>and earned without much trouble.&nbsp; I apprehend he will



<P>not have less than seven hundred a year.&nbsp; Seven hundred



<P>a year is a fine thing for a younger brother; and as of



<P>course he will still live at home, it will be all for his



<P>_menus_ _plaisirs_; and a sermon at Christmas and Easter,



<P>I suppose, will be the sum total of sacrifice."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>His sister tried to laugh off her feelings by saying,



<P>"Nothing amuses me more than the easy manner with which everybody



<P>settles the abundance of those who have a great deal less



<P>than themselves.&nbsp; You would look rather blank, Henry, if your



<P>_menus_ _plaisirs_ were to be limited to seven hundred a year."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps I might; but all _that_ you know is



<P>entirely comparative.&nbsp; Birthright and habit must settle



<P>the business.&nbsp; Bertram is certainly well off for a cadet



<P>of even a baronet's family.&nbsp; By the time he is four or five



<P>and twenty he will have seven hundred a year, and nothing to do for



<P>it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford _could_ have said that there would



<P>be a something to do and to suffer for it, which she



<P>could not think lightly of; but she checked herself



<P>and let it pass; and tried to look calm and unconcerned



<P>when the two gentlemen shortly afterwards joined them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bertram," said Henry Crawford, "I shall make a point of



<P>coming to Mansfield to hear you preach your first sermon.



<P>I shall come on purpose to encourage a young beginner.



<P>When is it to be?&nbsp; Miss Price, will not you join me in



<P>encouraging your cousin?&nbsp; Will not you engage to attend



<P>with your eyes steadily fixed on him the whole time--



<P>as I shall do--not to lose a word; or only looking off



<P>just to note down any sentence preeminently beautiful?



<P>We will provide ourselves with tablets and a pencil.



<P>When will it be?&nbsp; You must preach at Mansfield, you know,



<P>that Sir Thomas and Lady Bertram may hear you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall keep clear of you, Crawford, as long as I can,"



<P>said Edmund; "for you would be more likely to disconcert me,



<P>and I should be more sorry to see you trying at it than



<P>almost any other man."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Will he not feel this?" thought Fanny.&nbsp; "No, he can feel



<P>nothing as he ought."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The party being now all united, and the chief talkers



<P>attracting each other, she remained in tranquillity;



<P>and as a whist-table was formed after tea--formed really



<P>for the amusement of Dr. Grant, by his attentive wife,



<P>though it was not to be supposed so--and Miss Crawford



<P>took her harp, she had nothing to do but to listen;



<P>and her tranquillity remained undisturbed the rest



<P>of the evening, except when Mr. Crawford now and then



<P>addressed to her a question or observation, which she



<P>could not avoid answering.&nbsp; Miss Crawford was too much



<P>vexed by what had passed to be in a humour for anything



<P>but music.&nbsp; With that she soothed herself and amused



<P>her friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The assurance of Edmund's being so soon to take orders,



<P>coming upon her like a blow that had been suspended,



<P>and still hoped uncertain and at a distance, was felt



<P>with resentment and mortification.&nbsp; She was very angry



<P>with him.&nbsp; She had thought her influence more.



<P>She _had_ begun to think of him; she felt that she had,



<P>with great regard, with almost decided intentions;



<P>but she would now meet him with his own cool feelings.



<P>It was plain that he could have no serious views, no true



<P>attachment, by fixing himself in a situation which he must



<P>know she would never stoop to.&nbsp; She would learn to match



<P>him in his indifference.&nbsp; She would henceforth admit his



<P>attentions without any idea beyond immediate amusement.



<P>If _he_ could so command his affections, _hers_ should do her



<P>no harm.



<P>
