</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 22</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Fanny's consequence increased on the departure of



<P>her cousins.&nbsp; Becoming, as she then did, the only young



<P>woman in the drawing-room, the only occupier of that



<P>interesting division of a family in which she had hitherto



<P>held so humble a third, it was impossible for her not



<P>to be more looked at, more thought of and attended to,



<P>than she had ever been before; and "Where is Fanny?"



<P>became no uncommon question, even without her being



<P>wanted for any one's convenience.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Not only at home did her value increase, but at the



<P>Parsonage too.&nbsp; In that house, which she had hardly



<P>entered twice a year since Mr. Norris's death, she became



<P>a welcome, an invited guest, and in the gloom and dirt



<P>of a November day, most acceptable to Mary Crawford.



<P>Her visits there, beginning by chance, were continued



<P>by solicitation.&nbsp; Mrs. Grant, really eager to get any



<P>change for her sister, could, by the easiest self-deceit,



<P>persuade herself that she was doing the kindest thing



<P>by Fanny, and giving her the most important opportunities



<P>of improvement in pressing her frequent calls.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, having been sent into the village on some errand



<P>by her aunt Norris, was overtaken by a heavy shower close



<P>to the Parsonage; and being descried from one of the



<P>windows endeavouring to find shelter under the branches



<P>and lingering leaves of an oak just beyond their premises,



<P>was forced, though not without some modest reluctance on



<P>her part, to come in.&nbsp; A civil servant she had withstood;



<P>but when Dr. Grant himself went out with an umbrella,



<P>there was nothing to be done but to be very much ashamed,



<P>and to get into the house as fast as possible; and to poor



<P>Miss Crawford, who had just been contemplating the dismal



<P>rain in a very desponding state of mind, sighing over



<P>the ruin of all her plan of exercise for that morning,



<P>and of every chance of seeing a single creature beyond



<P>themselves for the next twenty-four hours, the sound of



<P>a little bustle at the front door, and the sight of Miss



<P>Price dripping with wet in the vestibule, was delightful.



<P>The value of an event on a wet day in the country was



<P>most forcibly brought before her.&nbsp; She was all alive



<P>again directly, and among the most active in being useful



<P>to Fanny, in detecting her to be wetter than she would at



<P>first allow, and providing her with dry clothes; and Fanny,



<P>after being obliged to submit to all this attention,



<P>and to being assisted and waited on by mistresses



<P>and maids, being also obliged, on returning downstairs,



<P>to be fixed in their drawing-room for an hour while



<P>the rain continued, the blessing of something fresh



<P>to see and think of was thus extended to Miss Crawford,



<P>and might carry on her spirits to the period of dressing



<P>and dinner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The two sisters were so kind to her, and so pleasant,



<P>that Fanny might have enjoyed her visit could she have



<P>believed herself not in the way, and could she have



<P>foreseen that the weather would certainly clear at the



<P>end of the hour, and save her from the shame of having



<P>Dr. Grant's carriage and horses out to take her home,



<P>with which she was threatened.&nbsp; As to anxiety for any alarm



<P>that her absence in such weather might occasion at home,



<P>she had nothing to suffer on that score; for as her being



<P>out was known only to her two aunts, she was perfectly



<P>aware that none would be felt, and that in whatever cottage



<P>aunt Norris might chuse to establish her during the rain,



<P>her being in such cottage would be indubitable to aunt Bertram.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was beginning to look brighter, when Fanny,



<P>observing a harp in the room, asked some questions about it,



<P>which soon led to an acknowledgment of her wishing very



<P>much to hear it, and a confession, which could hardly



<P>be believed, of her having never yet heard it since its



<P>being in Mansfield.&nbsp; To Fanny herself it appeared a very



<P>simple and natural circumstance.&nbsp; She had scarcely ever



<P>been at the Parsonage since the instrument's arrival,



<P>there had been no reason that she should; but Miss Crawford,



<P>calling to mind an early expressed wish on the subject,



<P>was concerned at her own neglect; and "Shall I play



<P>to you now?" and "What will you have?" were questions



<P>immediately following with the readiest good-humour.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She played accordingly; happy to have a new listener,



<P>and a listener who seemed so much obliged, so full



<P>of wonder at the performance, and who shewed herself



<P>not wanting in taste.&nbsp; She played till Fanny's eyes,



<P>straying to the window on the weather's being evidently fair,



<P>spoke what she felt must be done.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Another quarter of an hour," said Miss Crawford, "and we



<P>shall see how it will be.&nbsp; Do not run away the first



<P>moment of its holding up.&nbsp; Those clouds look alarming."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But they are passed over," said Fanny.&nbsp; "I have been



<P>watching them.&nbsp; This weather is all from the south."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"South or north, I know a black cloud when I see it;



<P>and you must not set forward while it is so threatening.



<P>And besides, I want to play something more to you--a very



<P>pretty piece--and your cousin Edmund's prime favourite.



<P>You must stay and hear your cousin's favourite."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny felt that she must; and though she had not



<P>waited for that sentence to be thinking of Edmund,



<P>such a memento made her particularly awake to his idea,



<P>and she fancied him sitting in that room again and again,



<P>perhaps in the very spot where she sat now, listening with



<P>constant delight to the favourite air, played, as it



<P>appeared to her, with superior tone and expression;



<P>and though pleased with it herself, and glad to like whatever



<P>was liked by him, she was more sincerely impatient to go



<P>away at the conclusion of it than she had been before;



<P>and on this being evident, she was so kindly asked to



<P>call again, to take them in her walk whenever she could,



<P>to come and hear more of the harp, that she felt it



<P>necessary to be done, if no objection arose at home.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such was the origin of the sort of intimacy which took



<P>place between them within the first fortnight after



<P>the Miss Bertrams' going away--an intimacy resulting



<P>principally from Miss Crawford's desire of something new,



<P>and which had little reality in Fanny's feelings.



<P>Fanny went to her every two or three days:&nbsp; it seemed a kind



<P>of fascination:&nbsp; she could not be easy without going,



<P>and yet it was without loving her, without ever thinking



<P>like her, without any sense of obligation for being



<P>sought after now when nobody else was to be had;



<P>and deriving no higher pleasure from her conversation



<P>than occasional amusement, and _that_ often at the expense



<P>of her judgment, when it was raised by pleasantry on



<P>people or subjects which she wished to be respected.



<P>She went, however, and they sauntered about together



<P>many an half-hour in Mrs. Grant's shrubbery, the weather



<P>being unusually mild for the time of year, and venturing



<P>sometimes even to sit down on one of the benches now



<P>comparatively unsheltered, remaining there perhaps till,



<P>in the midst of some tender ejaculation of Fanny's on



<P>the sweets of so protracted an autumn, they were forced,



<P>by the sudden swell of a cold gust shaking down the last few



<P>yellow leaves about them, to jump up and walk for warmth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is pretty, very pretty," said Fanny, looking around



<P>her as they were thus sitting together one day; "every time



<P>I come into this shrubbery I am more struck with its



<P>growth and beauty.&nbsp; Three years ago, this was nothing



<P>but a rough hedgerow along the upper side of the field,



<P>never thought of as anything, or capable of becoming anything;



<P>and now it is converted into a walk, and it would be



<P>difficult to say whether most valuable as a convenience



<P>or an ornament; and perhaps, in another three years,



<P>we may be forgetting--almost forgetting what it was before.



<P>How wonderful, how very wonderful the operations of time,



<P>and the changes of the human mind!"&nbsp; And following



<P>the latter train of thought, she soon afterwards added:



<P>"If any one faculty of our nature may be called _more_



<P>wonderful than the rest, I do think it is memory.



<P>There seems something more speakingly incomprehensible



<P>in the powers, the failures, the inequalities



<P>of memory, than in any other of our intelligences.



<P>The memory is sometimes so retentive, so serviceable,



<P>so obedient; at others, so bewildered and so weak;



<P>and at others again, so tyrannic, so beyond control!



<P>We are, to be sure, a miracle every way; but our powers



<P>of recollecting and of forgetting do seem peculiarly past



<P>finding out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford, untouched and inattentive, had nothing



<P>to say; and Fanny, perceiving it, brought back her own



<P>mind to what she thought must interest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It may seem impertinent in _me_ to praise, but I must



<P>admire the taste Mrs. Grant has shewn in all this.



<P>There is such a quiet simplicity in the plan of the walk!



<P>Not too much attempted!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," replied Miss Crawford carelessly, "it does



<P>very well for a place of this sort.&nbsp; One does not think



<P>of extent _here_; and between ourselves, till I came



<P>to Mansfield, I had not imagined a country parson



<P>ever aspired to a shrubbery, or anything of the kind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am so glad to see the evergreens thrive!" said Fanny,



<P>in reply.&nbsp; "My uncle's gardener always says the soil here



<P>is better than his own, and so it appears from the growth



<P>of the laurels and evergreens in general.&nbsp; The evergreen!



<P>How beautiful, how welcome, how wonderful the evergreen!



<P>When one thinks of it, how astonishing a variety of nature!



<P>In some countries we know the tree that sheds its leaf



<P>is the variety, but that does not make it less amazing



<P>that the same soil and the same sun should nurture plants



<P>differing in the first rule and law of their existence.



<P>You will think me rhapsodising; but when I am out of doors,



<P>especially when I am sitting out of doors, I am very apt



<P>to get into this sort of wondering strain.&nbsp; One cannot fix



<P>one's eyes on the commonest natural production without



<P>finding food for a rambling fancy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To say the truth," replied Miss Crawford, "I am something



<P>like the famous Doge at the court of Lewis XIV.;



<P>and may declare that I see no wonder in this shrubbery



<P>equal to seeing myself in it.&nbsp; If anybody had told



<P>me a year ago that this place would be my home,



<P>that I should be spending month after month here, as I



<P>have done, I certainly should not have believed them.



<P>I have now been here nearly five months; and, moreover,



<P>the quietest five months I ever passed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_Too_ quiet for you, I believe."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should have thought so _theoretically_ myself, but,"



<P>and her eyes brightened as she spoke, "take it all



<P>and all, I never spent so happy a summer.&nbsp; But then,"



<P>with a more thoughtful air and lowered voice, "there is



<P>no saying what it may lead to."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's heart beat quick, and she felt quite unequal



<P>to surmising or soliciting anything more.&nbsp; Miss Crawford,



<P>however, with renewed animation, soon went on--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am conscious of being far better reconciled to a country



<P>residence than I had ever expected to be.&nbsp; I can even



<P>suppose it pleasant to spend _half_ the year in the country,



<P>under certain circumstances, very pleasant.&nbsp; An elegant,



<P>moderate-sized house in the centre of family connexions;



<P>continual engagements among them; commanding the first society



<P>in the neighbourhood; looked up to, perhaps, as leading



<P>it even more than those of larger fortune, and turning



<P>from the cheerful round of such amusements to nothing



<P>worse than a _tete-a-tete_ with the person one feels



<P>most agreeable in the world.&nbsp; There is nothing frightful



<P>in such a picture, is there, Miss Price?&nbsp; One need not



<P>envy the new Mrs. Rushworth with such a home as _that_."



<P>"Envy Mrs. Rushworth!" was all that Fanny attempted to say.



<P>"Come, come, it would be very un-handsome in us to be



<P>severe on Mrs. Rushworth, for I look forward to our owing



<P>her a great many gay, brilliant, happy hours.&nbsp; I expect



<P>we shall be all very much at Sotherton another year.



<P>Such a match as Miss Bertram has made is a public blessing;



<P>for the first pleasures of Mr. Rushworth's wife must be to



<P>fill her house, and give the best balls in the country."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was silent, and Miss Crawford relapsed into



<P>thoughtfulness, till suddenly looking up at the end



<P>of a few minutes, she exclaimed, "Ah! here he is."



<P>It was not Mr. Rushworth, however, but Edmund,



<P>who then appeared walking towards them with Mrs. Grant.



<P>"My sister and Mr. Bertram.&nbsp; I am so glad your eldest



<P>cousin is gone, that he may be Mr. Bertram again.&nbsp; There is



<P>something in the sound of Mr. _Edmund_ Bertram so formal,



<P>so pitiful, so younger-brother-like, that I detest it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How differently we feel!" cried Fanny.&nbsp; "To me,



<P>the sound of _Mr._ Bertram is so cold and nothing-meaning,



<P>so entirely without warmth or character!&nbsp; It just stands



<P>for a gentleman, and that's all.&nbsp; But there is nobleness



<P>in the name of Edmund.&nbsp; It is a name of heroism and renown;



<P>of kings, princes, and knights; and seems to breathe



<P>the spirit of chivalry and warm affections."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I grant you the name is good in itself, and _Lord_ Edmund



<P>or _Sir_ Edmund sound delightfully; but sink it under the chill,



<P>the annihilation of a Mr., and Mr. Edmund is no more than



<P>Mr. John or Mr. Thomas.&nbsp; Well, shall we join and disappoint



<P>them of half their lecture upon sitting down out of doors



<P>at this time of year, by being up before they can begin?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund met them with particular pleasure.&nbsp; It was the



<P>first time of his seeing them together since the beginning



<P>of that better acquaintance which he had been hearing



<P>of with great satisfaction.&nbsp; A friendship between two so



<P>very dear to him was exactly what he could have wished:



<P>and to the credit of the lover's understanding, be it stated,



<P>that he did not by any means consider Fanny as the only,



<P>or even as the greater gainer by such a friendship.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Miss Crawford, "and do you not scold us for



<P>our imprudence?&nbsp; What do you think we have been sitting



<P>down for but to be talked to about it, and entreated



<P>and supplicated never to do so again?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps I might have scolded," said Edmund, "if either



<P>of you had been sitting down alone; but while you



<P>do wrong together, I can overlook a great deal."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"They cannot have been sitting long," cried Mrs. Grant,



<P>"for when I went up for my shawl I saw them from the



<P>staircase window, and then they were walking."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And really," added Edmund, "the day is so mild,



<P>that your sitting down for a few minutes can be hardly



<P>thought imprudent.&nbsp; Our weather must not always be judged



<P>by the calendar.&nbsp; We may sometimes take greater liberties



<P>in November than in May."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word," cried Miss Crawford, "you are two of the most



<P>disappointing and unfeeling kind friends I ever met with!



<P>There is no giving you a moment's uneasiness.&nbsp; You do not



<P>know how much we have been suffering, nor what chills



<P>we have felt!&nbsp; But I have long thought Mr. Bertram one



<P>of the worst subjects to work on, in any little manoeuvre



<P>against common sense, that a woman could be plagued with.



<P>I had very little hope of _him_ from the first; but you,



<P>Mrs. Grant, my sister, my own sister, I think I had a right



<P>to alarm you a little."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do not flatter yourself, my dearest Mary.&nbsp; You have not



<P>the smallest chance of moving me.&nbsp; I have my alarms,



<P>but they are quite in a different quarter; and if I could



<P>have altered the weather, you would have had a good sharp



<P>east wind blowing on you the whole time--for here are



<P>some of my plants which Robert _will_ leave out because



<P>the nights are so mild, and I know the end of it will be,



<P>that we shall have a sudden change of weather, a hard frost



<P>setting in all at once, taking everybody (at least Robert)



<P>by surprise, and I shall lose every one; and what is worse,



<P>cook has just been telling me that the turkey, which I



<P>particularly wished not to be dressed till Sunday,



<P>because I know how much more Dr. Grant would enjoy it



<P>on Sunday after the fatigues of the day, will not keep



<P>beyond to-morrow. These are something like grievances,



<P>and make me think the weather most unseasonably close."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The sweets of housekeeping in a country village!"



<P>said Miss Crawford archly.&nbsp; "Commend me to the nurseryman



<P>and the poulterer."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear child, commend Dr. Grant to the deanery



<P>of Westminster or St. Paul's, and I should be as glad



<P>of your nurseryman and poulterer as you could be.&nbsp; But we



<P>have no such people in Mansfield.&nbsp; What would you have me do?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! you can do nothing but what you do already:



<P>be plagued very often, and never lose your temper."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you; but there is no escaping these little vexations,



<P>Mary, live where we may; and when you are settled in town



<P>and I come to see you, I dare say I shall find you



<P>with yours, in spite of the nurseryman and the poulterer,



<P>perhaps on their very account.&nbsp; Their remoteness



<P>and unpunctuality, or their exorbitant charges and frauds,



<P>will be drawing forth bitter lamentations."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I mean to be too rich to lament or to feel anything



<P>of the sort.&nbsp; A large income is the best recipe for



<P>happiness I ever heard of.&nbsp; It certainly may secure



<P>all the myrtle and turkey part of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You intend to be very rich?" said Edmund, with a look which,



<P>to Fanny's eye, had a great deal of serious meaning.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure.&nbsp; Do not you?&nbsp; Do not we all?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot intend anything which it must be so completely



<P>beyond my power to command.&nbsp; Miss Crawford may chuse her



<P>degree of wealth.&nbsp; She has only to fix on her number of



<P>thousands a year, and there can be no doubt of their coming.



<P>My intentions are only not to be poor."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"By moderation and economy, and bringing down your wants



<P>to your income, and all that.&nbsp; I understand you--and a



<P>very proper plan it is for a person at your time of life,



<P>with such limited means and indifferent connexions.



<P>What can _you_ want but a decent maintenance?&nbsp; You have



<P>not much time before you; and your relations are in no



<P>situation to do anything for you, or to mortify you



<P>by the contrast of their own wealth and consequence.



<P>Be honest and poor, by all means--but I shall not



<P>envy you; I do not much think I shall even respect you.



<P>I have a much greater respect for those that are honest



<P>and rich."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your degree of respect for honesty, rich or poor,



<P>is precisely what I have no manner of concern with.



<P>I do not mean to be poor.&nbsp; Poverty is exactly what I have



<P>determined against.&nbsp; Honesty, in the something between,



<P>in the middle state of worldly circumstances, is all that I



<P>am anxious for your not looking down on."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I do look down upon it, if it might have been higher.



<P>I must look down upon anything contented with obscurity



<P>when it might rise to distinction."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But how may it rise?&nbsp; How may my honesty at least rise



<P>to any distinction?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was not so very easy a question to answer,



<P>and occasioned an "Oh!" of some length from the fair lady



<P>before she could add, "You ought to be in parliament,



<P>or you should have gone into the army ten years ago."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_That_ is not much to the purpose now; and as to my being



<P>in parliament, I believe I must wait till there is an



<P>especial assembly for the representation of younger sons



<P>who have little to live on.&nbsp; No, Miss Crawford," he added,



<P>in a more serious tone, "there _are_ distinctions which I



<P>should be miserable if I thought myself without any chance--



<P>absolutely without chance or possibility of obtaining--



<P>but they are of a different character."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A look of consciousness as he spoke, and what seemed



<P>a consciousness of manner on Miss Crawford's side



<P>as she made some laughing answer, was sorrowfull food



<P>for Fanny's observation; and finding herself quite



<P>unable to attend as she ought to Mrs. Grant, by whose



<P>side she was now following the others, she had nearly



<P>resolved on going home immediately, and only waited



<P>for courage to say so, when the sound of the great clock



<P>at Mansfield Park, striking three, made her feel that she



<P>had really been much longer absent than usual, and brought



<P>the previous self-inquiry of whether she should take



<P>leave or not just then, and how, to a very speedy issue.



<P>With undoubting decision she directly began her adieus;



<P>and Edmund began at the same time to recollect that



<P>his mother had been inquiring for her, and that he



<P>had walked down to the Parsonage on purpose to bring her back.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's hurry increased; and without in the least expecting



<P>Edmund's attendance, she would have hastened away alone;



<P>but the general pace was quickened, and they all accompanied



<P>her into the house, through which it was necessary to pass.



<P>Dr. Grant was in the vestibule, and as they stopt to



<P>speak to him she found, from Edmund's manner, that he



<P>_did_ mean to go with her.&nbsp; He too was taking leave.



<P>She could not but be thankful.&nbsp; In the moment of parting,



<P>Edmund was invited by Dr. Grant to eat his mutton



<P>with him the next day; and Fanny had barely time for an



<P>unpleasant feeling on the occasion, when Mrs. Grant,



<P>with sudden recollection, turned to her and asked for the



<P>pleasure of her company too.&nbsp; This was so new an attention,



<P>so perfectly new a circumstance in the events of



<P>Fanny's life, that she was all surprise and embarrassment;



<P>and while stammering out her great obligation, and her



<P>"but she did not suppose it would be in her power,"



<P>was looking at Edmund for his opinion and help.&nbsp; But Edmund,



<P>delighted with her having such an happiness offered,



<P>and ascertaining with half a look, and half a sentence,



<P>that she had no objection but on her aunt's account,



<P>could not imagine that his mother would make any difficulty



<P>of sparing her, and therefore gave his decided open advice



<P>that the invitation should be accepted; and though Fanny



<P>would not venture, even on his encouragement, to such



<P>a flight of audacious independence, it was soon settled,



<P>that if nothing were heard to the contrary, Mrs. Grant



<P>might expect her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And you know what your dinner will be,"



<P>said Mrs. Grant, smiling--"the turkey, and I assure you



<P>a very fine one; for, my dear," turning to her husband,



<P>"cook insists upon the turkey's being dressed to-morrow."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well, very well," cried Dr. Grant, "all the better;



<P>I am glad to hear you have anything so good in the house.



<P>But Miss Price and Mr. Edmund Bertram, I dare say, would take



<P>their chance.&nbsp; We none of us want to hear the bill of fare.



<P>A friendly meeting, and not a fine dinner, is all we



<P>have in view.&nbsp; A turkey, or a goose, or a leg of mutton,



<P>or whatever you and your cook chuse to give us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The two cousins walked home together; and, except in the



<P>immediate discussion of this engagement, which Edmund



<P>spoke of with the warmest satisfaction, as so particularly



<P>desirable for her in the intimacy which he saw with



<P>so much pleasure established, it was a silent walk;



<P>for having finished that subject, he grew thoughtful



<P>and indisposed for any other.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 36</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXXVI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Edmund now believed himself perfectly acquainted with all



<P>that Fanny could tell, or could leave to be conjectured



<P>of her sentiments, and he was satisfied.&nbsp; It had been,



<P>as he before presumed, too hasty a measure on Crawford's side,



<P>and time must be given to make the idea first familiar,



<P>and then agreeable to her.&nbsp; She must be used to the



<P>consideration of his being in love with her, and then



<P>a return of affection might not be very distant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He gave this opinion as the result of the conversation



<P>to his father; and recommended there being nothing more said



<P>to her:&nbsp; no farther attempts to influence or persuade;



<P>but that everything should be left to Crawford's assiduities,



<P>and the natural workings of her own mind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas promised that it should be so.&nbsp; Edmund's account



<P>of Fanny's disposition he could believe to be just;



<P>he supposed she had all those feelings, but he must consider



<P>it as very unfortunate that she _had_; for, less willing



<P>than his son to trust to the future, he could not help



<P>fearing that if such very long allowances of time and habit



<P>were necessary for her, she might not have persuaded



<P>herself into receiving his addresses properly before



<P>the young man's inclination for paying them were over.



<P>There was nothing to be done, however, but to submit



<P>quietly and hope the best.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The promised visit from "her friend," as Edmund called



<P>Miss Crawford, was a formidable threat to Fanny,



<P>and she lived in continual terror of it.&nbsp; As a sister,



<P>so partial and so angry, and so little scrupulous of what



<P>she said, and in another light so triumphant and secure,



<P>she was in every way an object of painful alarm.



<P>Her displeasure, her penetration, and her happiness were



<P>all fearful to encounter; and the dependence of having



<P>others present when they met was Fanny's only support



<P>in looking forward to it.&nbsp; She absented herself as little



<P>as possible from Lady Bertram, kept away from the East room,



<P>and took no solitary walk in the shrubbery, in her caution



<P>to avoid any sudden attack.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She succeeded.&nbsp; She was safe in the breakfast-room, with her aunt,



<P>when Miss Crawford did come; and the first misery over,



<P>and Miss Crawford looking and speaking with much less



<P>particularity of expression than she had anticipated,



<P>Fanny began to hope there would be nothing worse



<P>to be endured than a half-hour of moderate agitation.



<P>But here she hoped too much; Miss Crawford was not the slave



<P>of opportunity.&nbsp; She was determined to see Fanny alone,



<P>and therefore said to her tolerably soon, in a low voice,



<P>"I must speak to you for a few minutes somewhere";



<P>words that Fanny felt all over her, in all her pulses



<P>and all her nerves.&nbsp; Denial was impossible.&nbsp; Her habits



<P>of ready submission, on the contrary, made her almost



<P>instantly rise and lead the way out of the room.



<P>She did it with wretched feelings, but it was inevitable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were no sooner in the hall than all restraint



<P>of countenance was over on Miss Crawford's side.



<P>She immediately shook her head at Fanny with arch,



<P>yet affectionate reproach, and taking her hand,



<P>seemed hardly able to help beginning directly.



<P>She said nothing, however, but, "Sad, sad girl!



<P>I do not know when I shall have done scolding you,"



<P>and had discretion enough to reserve the rest till they



<P>might be secure of having four walls to themselves.



<P>Fanny naturally turned upstairs, and took her guest to the



<P>apartment which was now always fit for comfortable use;



<P>opening the door, however, with a most aching heart,



<P>and feeling that she had a more distressing scene before



<P>her than ever that spot had yet witnessed.&nbsp; But the evil



<P>ready to burst on her was at least delayed by the sudden



<P>change in Miss Crawford's ideas; by the strong effect



<P>on her mind which the finding herself in the East room



<P>again produced.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ha!" she cried, with instant animation, "am I here again?



<P>The East room!&nbsp; Once only was I in this room before";



<P>and after stopping to look about her, and seemingly



<P>to retrace all that had then passed, she added, "Once



<P>only before.&nbsp; Do you remember it?&nbsp; I came to rehearse.



<P>Your cousin came too; and we had a rehearsal.&nbsp; You were



<P>our audience and prompter.&nbsp; A delightful rehearsal.



<P>I shall never forget it.&nbsp; Here we were, just in this



<P>part of the room:&nbsp; here was your cousin, here was I,



<P>here were the chairs.&nbsp; Oh! why will such things ever



<P>pass away?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Happily for her companion, she wanted no answer.



<P>Her mind was entirely self-engrossed. She was in a reverie



<P>of sweet remembrances.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The scene we were rehearsing was so very remarkable!



<P>The subject of it so very--very--what shall I say?



<P>He was to be describing and recommending matrimony to me.



<P>I think I see him now, trying to be as demure and composed



<P>as Anhalt ought, through the two long speeches.



<P>'When two sympathetic hearts meet in the marriage state,



<P>matrimony may be called a happy life.'&nbsp; I suppose no time



<P>can ever wear out the impression I have of his looks



<P>and voice as he said those words.&nbsp; It was curious,



<P>very curious, that we should have such a scene to play!



<P>If I had the power of recalling any one week of my existence,



<P>it should be that week--that acting week.&nbsp; Say what



<P>you would, Fanny, it should be _that_; for I never knew



<P>such exquisite happiness in any other.&nbsp; His sturdy spirit



<P>to bend as it did!&nbsp; Oh! it was sweet beyond expression.



<P>But alas, that very evening destroyed it all.&nbsp; That very



<P>evening brought your most unwelcome uncle.&nbsp; Poor Sir Thomas,



<P>who was glad to see you?&nbsp; Yet, Fanny, do not imagine I would



<P>now speak disrespectfully of Sir Thomas, though I certainly



<P>did hate him for many a week.&nbsp; No, I do him justice now.



<P>He is just what the head of such a family should be.



<P>Nay, in sober sadness, I believe I now love you all."



<P>And having said so, with a degree of tenderness and



<P>consciousness which Fanny had never seen in her before,



<P>and now thought only too becoming, she turned away



<P>for a moment to recover herself.&nbsp; "I have had a little



<P>fit since I came into this room, as you may perceive,"



<P>said she presently, with a playful smile, "but it is



<P>over now; so let us sit down and be comfortable; for as to



<P>scolding you, Fanny, which I came fully intending to do,



<P>I have not the heart for it when it comes to the point."



<P>And embracing her very affectionately, "Good, gentle Fanny!



<P>when I think of this being the last time of seeing you for I



<P>do not know how long, I feel it quite impossible to do anything



<P>but love you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was affected.&nbsp; She had not foreseen anything of this,



<P>and her feelings could seldom withstand the melancholy



<P>influence of the word "last."&nbsp; She cried as if she



<P>had loved Miss Crawford more than she possibly could;



<P>and Miss Crawford, yet farther softened by the sight



<P>of such emotion, hung about her with fondness, and said,



<P>"I hate to leave you.&nbsp; I shall see no one half so amiable



<P>where I am going.&nbsp; Who says we shall not be sisters?



<P>I know we shall.&nbsp; I feel that we are born to be connected;



<P>and those tears convince me that you feel it too,



<P>dear Fanny."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny roused herself, and replying only in part, said,



<P>"But you are only going from one set of friends to another.



<P>You are going to a very particular friend."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, very true.&nbsp; Mrs. Fraser has been my intimate friend



<P>for years.&nbsp; But I have not the least inclination to go



<P>near her.&nbsp; I can think only of the friends I am leaving:



<P>my excellent sister, yourself, and the Bertrams in general.



<P>You have all so much more _heart_ among you than one



<P>finds in the world at large.&nbsp; You all give me a feeling



<P>of being able to trust and confide in you, which in common



<P>intercourse one knows nothing of.&nbsp; I wish I had settled



<P>with Mrs. Fraser not to go to her till after Easter, a much



<P>better time for the visit, but now I cannot put her off.



<P>And when I have done with her I must go to her sister,



<P>Lady Stornaway, because _she_ was rather my most particular



<P>friend of the two, but I have not cared much for _her_



<P>these three years."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After this speech the two girls sat many minutes silent,



<P>each thoughtful:&nbsp; Fanny meditating on the different sorts



<P>of friendship in the world, Mary on something of less



<P>philosophic tendency.&nbsp; _She_ first spoke again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How perfectly I remember my resolving to look for



<P>you upstairs, and setting off to find my way to the



<P>East room, without having an idea whereabouts it was!



<P>How well I remember what I was thinking of as I came along,



<P>and my looking in and seeing you here sitting at this



<P>table at work; and then your cousin's astonishment,



<P>when he opened the door, at seeing me here!&nbsp; To be sure,



<P>your uncle's returning that very evening!&nbsp; There never



<P>was anything quite like it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Another short fit of abstraction followed, when,



<P>shaking it off, she thus attacked her companion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why, Fanny, you are absolutely in a reverie.



<P>Thinking, I hope, of one who is always thinking of you.



<P>Oh! that I could transport you for a short time into



<P>our circle in town, that you might understand how your



<P>power over Henry is thought of there!&nbsp; Oh! the envyings



<P>and heartburnings of dozens and dozens; the wonder,



<P>the incredulity that will be felt at hearing what you



<P>have done!&nbsp; For as to secrecy, Henry is quite the hero



<P>of an old romance, and glories in his chains.&nbsp; You should



<P>come to London to know how to estimate your conquest.



<P>If you were to see how he is courted, and how I am courted



<P>for his sake!&nbsp; Now, I am well aware that I shall not be



<P>half so welcome to Mrs. Fraser in consequence of his



<P>situation with you.&nbsp; When she comes to know the truth



<P>she will, very likely, wish me in Northamptonshire again;



<P>for there is a daughter of Mr. Fraser, by a first wife,



<P>whom she is wild to get married, and wants Henry to take.



<P>Oh! she has been trying for him to such a degree.



<P>Innocent and quiet as you sit here, you cannot have an



<P>idea of the _sensation_ that you will be occasioning,



<P>of the curiosity there will be to see you, of the endless



<P>questions I shall have to answer!&nbsp; Poor Margaret Fraser



<P>will be at me for ever about your eyes and your teeth,



<P>and how you do your hair, and who makes your shoes.



<P>I wish Margaret were married, for my poor friend's sake,



<P>for I look upon the Frasers to be about as unhappy as most



<P>other married people.&nbsp; And yet it was a most desirable



<P>match for Janet at the time.&nbsp; We were all delighted.



<P>She could not do otherwise than accept him, for he was rich,



<P>and she had nothing; but he turns out ill-tempered



<P>and _exigeant_, and wants a young woman, a beautiful young



<P>woman of five-and-twenty, to be as steady as himself.



<P>And my friend does not manage him well; she does not seem



<P>to know how to make the best of it.&nbsp; There is a spirit



<P>of irritation which, to say nothing worse, is certainly



<P>very ill-bred. In their house I shall call to mind the



<P>conjugal manners of Mansfield Parsonage with respect.



<P>Even Dr. Grant does shew a thorough confidence in my sister,



<P>and a certain consideration for her judgment, which makes



<P>one feel there _is_ attachment; but of that I shall



<P>see nothing with the Frasers.&nbsp; I shall be at Mansfield



<P>for ever, Fanny.&nbsp; My own sister as a wife, Sir Thomas



<P>Bertram as a husband, are my standards of perfection.



<P>Poor Janet has been sadly taken in, and yet there was



<P>nothing improper on her side:&nbsp; she did not run into the



<P>match inconsiderately; there was no want of foresight.



<P>She took three days to consider of his proposals,



<P>and during those three days asked the advice of everybody



<P>connected with her whose opinion was worth having,



<P>and especially applied to my late dear aunt, whose



<P>knowledge of the world made her judgment very generally



<P>and deservedly looked up to by all the young people



<P>of her acquaintance, and she was decidedly in favour



<P>of Mr. Fraser.&nbsp; This seems as if nothing were a security



<P>for matrimonial comfort.&nbsp; I have not so much to say



<P>for my friend Flora, who jilted a very nice young man



<P>in the Blues for the sake of that horrid Lord Stornaway,



<P>who has about as much sense, Fanny, as Mr. Rushworth,



<P>but much worse-looking, and with a blackguard character.



<P>I _had_ my doubts at the time about her being right,



<P>for he has not even the air of a gentleman, and now I am



<P>sure she was wrong.&nbsp; By the bye, Flora Ross was dying



<P>for Henry the first winter she came out.&nbsp; But were I



<P>to attempt to tell you of all the women whom I have



<P>known to be in love with him, I should never have done.



<P>It is you, only you, insensible Fanny, who can think



<P>of him with anything like indifference.&nbsp; But are you



<P>so insensible as you profess yourself?&nbsp; No, no, I see you



<P>are not."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was, indeed, so deep a blush over Fanny's face



<P>at that moment as might warrant strong suspicion



<P>in a predisposed mind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Excellent creature!&nbsp; I will not tease you.&nbsp; Everything shall



<P>take its course.&nbsp; But, dear Fanny, you must allow that you



<P>were not so absolutely unprepared to have the question asked



<P>as your cousin fancies.&nbsp; It is not possible but that you



<P>must have had some thoughts on the subject, some surmises



<P>as to what might be.&nbsp; You must have seen that he was



<P>trying to please you by every attention in his power.



<P>Was not he devoted to you at the ball?&nbsp; And then before



<P>the ball, the necklace!&nbsp; Oh! you received it just as it



<P>was meant.&nbsp; You were as conscious as heart could desire.



<P>I remember it perfectly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you mean, then, that your brother knew of the



<P>necklace beforehand?&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; Miss Crawford, _that_ was not fair."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Knew of it!&nbsp; It was his own doing entirely, his own thought.



<P>I am ashamed to say that it had never entered my head,



<P>but I was delighted to act on his proposal for both



<P>your sakes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will not say," replied Fanny, "that I was not half



<P>afraid at the time of its being so, for there was something



<P>in your look that frightened me, but not at first;



<P>I was as unsuspicious of it at first--indeed, indeed I was.



<P>It is as true as that I sit here.&nbsp; And had I had an idea of it,



<P>nothing should have induced me to accept the necklace.



<P>As to your brother's behaviour, certainly I was sensible of



<P>a particularity:&nbsp; I had been sensible of it some little time,



<P>perhaps two or three weeks; but then I considered it as



<P>meaning nothing:&nbsp; I put it down as simply being his way,



<P>and was as far from supposing as from wishing him to have



<P>any serious thoughts of me.&nbsp; I had not, Miss Crawford,



<P>been an inattentive observer of what was passing between him



<P>and some part of this family in the summer and autumn.



<P>I was quiet, but I was not blind.&nbsp; I could not but see



<P>that Mr. Crawford allowed himself in gallantries which did



<P>mean nothing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah!&nbsp; I cannot deny it.&nbsp; He has now and then been a sad flirt,



<P>and cared very little for the havoc he might be making in



<P>young ladies' affections.&nbsp; I have often scolded him for it,



<P>but it is his only fault; and there is this to be said,



<P>that very few young ladies have any affections worth



<P>caring for.&nbsp; And then, Fanny, the glory of fixing one



<P>who has been shot at by so many; of having it in one's



<P>power to pay off the debts of one's sex!&nbsp; Oh!&nbsp; I am sure



<P>it is not in woman's nature to refuse such a triumph."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny shook her head.&nbsp; "I cannot think well of a man



<P>who sports with any woman's feelings; and there may often



<P>be a great deal more suffered than a stander-by can judge of."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not defend him.&nbsp; I leave him entirely to your mercy,



<P>and when he has got you at Everingham, I do not care how much



<P>you lecture him.&nbsp; But this I will say, that his fault,



<P>the liking to make girls a little in love with him, is not



<P>half so dangerous to a wife's happiness as a tendency to fall



<P>in love himself, which he has never been addicted to.



<P>And I do seriously and truly believe that he is attached



<P>to you in a way that he never was to any woman before;



<P>that he loves you with all his heart, and will love you



<P>as nearly for ever as possible.&nbsp; If any man ever loved



<P>a woman for ever, I think Henry will do as much for you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny could not avoid a faint smile, but had nothing



<P>to say.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot imagine Henry ever to have been happier,"



<P>continued Mary presently, "than when he had succeeded



<P>in getting your brother's commission."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had made a sure push at Fanny's feelings here.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! yes.&nbsp; How very, very kind of him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know he must have exerted himself very much, for I know



<P>the parties he had to move.&nbsp; The Admiral hates trouble,



<P>and scorns asking favours; and there are so many



<P>young men's claims to be attended to in the same way,



<P>that a friendship and energy, not very determined,



<P>is easily put by.&nbsp; What a happy creature William must be!



<P>I wish we could see him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Poor Fanny's mind was thrown into the most distressing



<P>of all its varieties.&nbsp; The recollection of what had



<P>been done for William was always the most powerful



<P>disturber of every decision against Mr. Crawford;



<P>and she sat thinking deeply of it till Mary, who had been



<P>first watching her complacently, and then musing on



<P>something else, suddenly called her attention by saying:



<P>"I should like to sit talking with you here all day,



<P>but we must not forget the ladies below, and so good-bye,



<P>my dear, my amiable, my excellent Fanny, for though we



<P>shall nominally part in the breakfast-parlour, I must



<P>take leave of you here.&nbsp; And I do take leave, longing for



<P>a happy reunion, and trusting that when we meet again,



<P>it will be under circumstances which may open our hearts



<P>to each other without any remnant or shadow of reserve."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A very, very kind embrace, and some agitation of manner,



<P>accompanied these words.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall see your cousin in town soon:&nbsp; he talks of



<P>being there tolerably soon; and Sir Thomas, I dare say,



<P>in the course of the spring; and your eldest cousin,



<P>and the Rushworths, and Julia, I am sure of meeting again



<P>and again, and all but you.&nbsp; I have two favours to ask,



<P>Fanny:&nbsp; one is your correspondence.&nbsp; You must write to me.



<P>And the other, that you will often call on Mrs. Grant,



<P>and make her amends for my being gone."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The first, at least, of these favours Fanny would rather



<P>not have been asked; but it was impossible for her to refuse



<P>the correspondence; it was impossible for her even not to



<P>accede to it more readily than her own judgment authorised.



<P>There was no resisting so much apparent affection.



<P>Her disposition was peculiarly calculated to value a fond



<P>treatment, and from having hitherto known so little of it,



<P>she was the more overcome by Miss Crawford's. Besides,



<P>there was gratitude towards her, for having made their



<P>_tete-a-tete_ so much less painful than her fears had predicted.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was over, and she had escaped without reproaches



<P>and without detection.&nbsp; Her secret was still her own;



<P>and while that was the case, she thought she could resign



<P>herself to almost everything.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the evening there was another parting.&nbsp; Henry Crawford



<P>came and sat some time with them; and her spirits not being



<P>previously in the strongest state, her heart was softened



<P>for a while towards him, because he really seemed to feel.



<P>Quite unlike his usual self, he scarcely said anything.



<P>He was evidently oppressed, and Fanny must grieve for him,



<P>though hoping she might never see him again till he were the



<P>husband of some other woman.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When it came to the moment of parting, he would take her hand,



<P>he would not be denied it; he said nothing, however,



<P>or nothing that she heard, and when he had left the room,



<P>she was better pleased that such a token of friendship



<P>had passed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On the morrow the Crawfords were gone.



<P>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 20</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Edmund's first object the next morning was to see his



<P>father alone, and give him a fair statement of the whole



<P>acting scheme, defending his own share in it as far only



<P>as he could then, in a soberer moment, feel his motives



<P>to deserve, and acknowledging, with perfect ingenuousness,



<P>that his concession had been attended with such partial



<P>good as to make his judgment in it very doubtful.



<P>He was anxious, while vindicating himself, to say nothing



<P>unkind of the others:&nbsp; but there was only one amongst them



<P>whose conduct he could mention without some necessity



<P>of defence or palliation.&nbsp; "We have all been more or less



<P>to blame," said he, "every one of us, excepting Fanny.



<P>Fanny is the only one who has judged rightly throughout;



<P>who has been consistent.&nbsp; _Her_ feelings have been steadily



<P>against it from first to last.&nbsp; She never ceased to think



<P>of what was due to you.&nbsp; You will find Fanny everything you



<P>could wish."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas saw all the impropriety of such a scheme among



<P>such a party, and at such a time, as strongly as his son



<P>had ever supposed he must; he felt it too much, indeed,



<P>for many words; and having shaken hands with Edmund,



<P>meant to try to lose the disagreeable impression,



<P>and forget how much he had been forgotten himself as soon



<P>as he could, after the house had been cleared of every



<P>object enforcing the remembrance, and restored to its



<P>proper state.&nbsp; He did not enter into any remonstrance with



<P>his other children:&nbsp; he was more willing to believe they



<P>felt their error than to run the risk of investigation.



<P>The reproof of an immediate conclusion of everything,



<P>the sweep of every preparation, would be sufficient.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was one person, however, in the house, whom he could



<P>not leave to learn his sentiments merely through his conduct.



<P>He could not help giving Mrs. Norris a hint of his having



<P>hoped that her advice might have been interposed to prevent



<P>what her judgment must certainly have disapproved.&nbsp; The young



<P>people had been very inconsiderate in forming the plan;



<P>they ought to have been capable of a better decision themselves;



<P>but they were young; and, excepting Edmund, he believed,



<P>of unsteady characters; and with greater surprise, therefore,



<P>he must regard her acquiescence in their wrong measures,



<P>her countenance of their unsafe amusements, than that such



<P>measures and such amusements should have been suggested.



<P>Mrs. Norris was a little confounded and as nearly being



<P>silenced as ever she had been in her life; for she



<P>was ashamed to confess having never seen any of the



<P>impropriety which was so glaring to Sir Thomas, and would



<P>not have admitted that her influence was insufficient--



<P>that she might have talked in vain.&nbsp; Her only resource



<P>was to get out of the subject as fast as possible, and turn



<P>the current of Sir Thomas's ideas into a happier channel.



<P>She had a great deal to insinuate in her own praise



<P>as to _general_ attention to the interest and comfort



<P>of his family, much exertion and many sacrifices to glance



<P>at in the form of hurried walks and sudden removals from



<P>her own fireside, and many excellent hints of distrust



<P>and economy to Lady Bertram and Edmund to detail,



<P>whereby a most considerable saving had always arisen,



<P>and more than one bad servant been detected.&nbsp; But her chief



<P>strength lay in Sotherton.&nbsp; Her greatest support and glory



<P>was in having formed the connexion with the Rushworths.



<P>_There_ she was impregnable.&nbsp; She took to herself all



<P>the credit of bringing Mr. Rushworth's admiration of Maria



<P>to any effect.&nbsp; "If I had not been active," said she,



<P>"and made a point of being introduced to his mother,



<P>and then prevailed on my sister to pay the first visit,



<P>I am as certain as I sit here that nothing would have



<P>come of it; for Mr. Rushworth is the sort of amiable



<P>modest young man who wants a great deal of encouragement,



<P>and there were girls enough on the catch for him if we



<P>had been idle.&nbsp; But I left no stone unturned.&nbsp; I was



<P>ready to move heaven and earth to persuade my sister,



<P>and at last I did persuade her.&nbsp; You know the distance



<P>to Sotherton; it was in the middle of winter, and the roads



<P>almost impassable, but I did persuade her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I know how great, how justly great, your influence



<P>is with Lady Bertram and her children, and am the more



<P>concerned that it should not have been."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Sir Thomas, if you had seen the state of the



<P>roads _that_ day!&nbsp; I thought we should never have got



<P>through them, though we had the four horses of course;



<P>and poor old coachman would attend us, out of his great love



<P>and kindness, though he was hardly able to sit the box



<P>on account of the rheumatism which I had been doctoring



<P>him for ever since Michaelmas.&nbsp; I cured him at last;



<P>but he was very bad all the winter--and this was such a day,



<P>I could not help going to him up in his room before we set



<P>off to advise him not to venture:&nbsp; he was putting on his wig;



<P>so I said, 'Coachman, you had much better not go; your Lady



<P>and I shall be very safe; you know how steady Stephen is,



<P>and Charles has been upon the leaders so often now,



<P>that I am sure there is no fear.'&nbsp; But, however, I soon



<P>found it would not do; he was bent upon going, and as I



<P>hate to be worrying and officious, I said no more; but my



<P>heart quite ached for him at every jolt, and when we got



<P>into the rough lanes about Stoke, where, what with frost



<P>and snow upon beds of stones, it was worse than anything



<P>you can imagine, I was quite in an agony about him.



<P>And then the poor horses too!&nbsp; To see them straining away!



<P>You know how I always feel for the horses.&nbsp; And when we got



<P>to the bottom of Sandcroft Hill, what do you think I did?



<P>You will laugh at me; but I got out and walked up.



<P>I did indeed.&nbsp; It might not be saving them much, but it



<P>was something, and I could not bear to sit at my ease



<P>and be dragged up at the expense of those noble animals.



<P>I caught a dreadful cold, but _that_ I did not regard.



<P>My object was accomplished in the visit."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope we shall always think the acquaintance worth



<P>any trouble that might be taken to establish it.



<P>There is nothing very striking in Mr. Rushworth's manners,



<P>but I was pleased last night with what appeared to be his



<P>opinion on one subject:&nbsp; his decided preference of a quiet



<P>family party to the bustle and confusion of acting.



<P>He seemed to feel exactly as one could wish."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, indeed, and the more you know of him the better



<P>you will like him.&nbsp; He is not a shining character,



<P>but he has a thousand good qualities; and is so disposed



<P>to look up to you, that I am quite laughed at about it,



<P>for everybody considers it as my doing.&nbsp; 'Upon my word,



<P>Mrs. Norris,' said Mrs. Grant the other day, 'if Mr. Rushworth



<P>were a son of your own, he could not hold Sir Thomas



<P>in greater respect.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas gave up the point, foiled by her evasions,



<P>disarmed by her flattery; and was obliged to rest



<P>satisfied with the conviction that where the present



<P>pleasure of those she loved was at stake, her kindness



<P>did sometimes overpower her judgment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a busy morning with him.&nbsp; Conversation with any



<P>of them occupied but a small part of it.&nbsp; He had to



<P>reinstate himself in all the wonted concerns of his



<P>Mansfield life:&nbsp; to see his steward and his bailiff;



<P>to examine and compute, and, in the intervals



<P>of business, to walk into his stables and his gardens,



<P>and nearest plantations; but active and methodical,



<P>he had not only done all this before he resumed his seat



<P>as master of the house at dinner, he had also set the



<P>carpenter to work in pulling down what had been so lately



<P>put up in the billiard-room, and given the scene-painter



<P>his dismissal long enough to justify the pleasing belief



<P>of his being then at least as far off as Northampton.



<P>The scene-painter was gone, having spoilt only the



<P>floor of one room, ruined all the coachman's sponges,



<P>and made five of the under-servants idle and dissatisfied;



<P>and Sir Thomas was in hopes that another day or two would



<P>suffice to wipe away every outward memento of what had been,



<P>even to the destruction of every unbound copy of Lovers'



<P>Vows in the house, for he was burning all that met his eye

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Yates was beginning now to understand Sir Thomas's intentions,



<P>though as far as ever from understanding their source.



<P>He and his friend had been out with their guns the chief of



<P>the morning, and Tom had taken the opportunity of explaining,



<P>with proper apologies for his father's particularity,



<P>what was to be expected.&nbsp; Mr. Yates felt it as acutely



<P>as might be supposed.&nbsp; To be a second time disappointed



<P>in the same way was an instance of very severe ill-luck;



<P>and his indignation was such, that had it not been for delicacy



<P>towards his friend, and his friend's youngest sister,



<P>he believed he should certainly attack the baronet on



<P>the absurdity of his proceedings, and argue him into a



<P>little more rationality.&nbsp; He believed this very stoutly



<P>while he was in Mansfield Wood, and all the way home;



<P>but there was a something in Sir Thomas, when they sat



<P>round the same table, which made Mr. Yates think it wiser



<P>to let him pursue his own way, and feel the folly of it



<P>without opposition.&nbsp; He had known many disagreeable



<P>fathers before, and often been struck with the inconveniences



<P>they occasioned, but never, in the whole course of his life,



<P>had he seen one of that class so unintelligibly moral,



<P>so infamously tyrannical as Sir Thomas.&nbsp; He was not a man



<P>to be endured but for his children's sake, and he might



<P>be thankful to his fair daughter Julia that Mr. Yates



<P>did yet mean to stay a few days longer under his roof.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The evening passed with external smoothness, though almost



<P>every mind was ruffled; and the music which Sir Thomas



<P>called for from his daughters helped to conceal the want



<P>of real harmony.&nbsp; Maria was in a good deal of agitation.



<P>It was of the utmost consequence to her that Crawford



<P>should now lose no time in declaring himself, and she



<P>was disturbed that even a day should be gone by without



<P>seeming to advance that point.&nbsp; She had been expecting



<P>to see him the whole morning, and all the evening, too,



<P>was still expecting him.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth had set off early



<P>with the great news for Sotherton; and she had fondly hoped



<P>for such an immediate _eclaircissement_ as might save him



<P>the trouble of ever coming back again.&nbsp; But they had seen



<P>no one from the Parsonage, not a creature, and had heard



<P>no tidings beyond a friendly note of congratulation



<P>and inquiry from Mrs. Grant to Lady Bertram.&nbsp; It was



<P>the first day for many, many weeks, in which the families



<P>had been wholly divided.&nbsp; Four-and-twenty hours had never



<P>passed before, since August began, without bringing them



<P>together in some way or other.&nbsp; It was a sad, anxious day;



<P>and the morrow, though differing in the sort of evil,



<P>did by no means bring less.&nbsp; A few moments of feverish



<P>enjoyment were followed by hours of acute suffering.



<P>Henry Crawford was again in the house:&nbsp; he walked up



<P>with Dr. Grant, who was anxious to pay his respects to



<P>Sir Thomas, and at rather an early hour they were ushered



<P>into the breakfast-room, where were most of the family.



<P>Sir Thomas soon appeared, and Maria saw with delight



<P>and agitation the introduction of the man she loved to



<P>her father.&nbsp; Her sensations were indefinable, and so were



<P>they a few minutes afterwards upon hearing Henry Crawford,



<P>who had a chair between herself and Tom, ask the latter



<P>in an undervoice whether there were any plans for resuming



<P>the play after the present happy interruption (with



<P>a courteous glance at Sir Thomas), because, in that case,



<P>he should make a point of returning to Mansfield at any time



<P>required by the party:&nbsp; he was going away immediately,



<P>being to meet his uncle at Bath without delay; but if there



<P>were any prospect of a renewal of Lovers' Vows, he should



<P>hold himself positively engaged, he should break through



<P>every other claim, he should absolutely condition with his



<P>uncle for attending them whenever he might be wanted.



<P>The play should not be lost by _his_ absence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"From Bath, Norfolk, London, York, wherever I may be,"



<P>said he; "I will attend you from any place in England,



<P>at an hour's notice."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was well at that moment that Tom had to speak, and not



<P>his sister.&nbsp; He could immediately say with easy fluency,



<P>"I am sorry you are going; but as to our play, _that_ is



<P>all over--entirely at an end" (looking significantly



<P>at his father). "The painter was sent off yesterday,



<P>and very little will remain of the theatre to-morrow. I knew



<P>how _that_ would be from the first.&nbsp; It is early for Bath.



<P>You will find nobody there."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is about my uncle's usual time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When do you think of going?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I may, perhaps, get as far as Banbury to-day."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Whose stables do you use at Bath?" was the next question;



<P>and while this branch of the subject was under discussion,



<P>Maria, who wanted neither pride nor resolution, was preparing



<P>to encounter her share of it with tolerable calmness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To her he soon turned, repeating much of what he had



<P>already said, with only a softened air and stronger



<P>expressions of regret.&nbsp; But what availed his expressions



<P>or his air?&nbsp; He was going, and, if not voluntarily going,



<P>voluntarily intending to stay away; for, excepting what might



<P>be due to his uncle, his engagements were all self-imposed.



<P>He might talk of necessity, but she knew his independence.



<P>The hand which had so pressed hers to his heart! the hand



<P>and the heart were alike motionless and passive now!



<P>Her spirit supported her, but the agony of her mind was severe.



<P>She had not long to endure what arose from listening



<P>to language which his actions contradicted, or to bury



<P>the tumult of her feelings under the restraint of society;



<P>for general civilities soon called his notice from her,



<P>and the farewell visit, as it then became openly acknowledged,



<P>was a very short one.&nbsp; He was gone--he had touched her



<P>hand for the last time, he had made his parting bow,



<P>and she might seek directly all that solitude could do



<P>for her.&nbsp; Henry Crawford was gone, gone from the house,



<P>and within two hours afterwards from the parish;



<P>and so ended all the hopes his selfish vanity had raised



<P>in Maria and Julia Bertram.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Julia could rejoice that he was gone.&nbsp; His presence was



<P>beginning to be odious to her; and if Maria gained him not,



<P>she was now cool enough to dispense with any other revenge.



<P>She did not want exposure to be added to desertion.



<P>Henry Crawford gone, she could even pity her sister.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With a purer spirit did Fanny rejoice in the intelligence.



<P>She heard it at dinner, and felt it a blessing.



<P>By all the others it was mentioned with regret;



<P>and his merits honoured with due gradation of feeling--



<P>from the sincerity of Edmund's too partial regard,



<P>to the unconcern of his mother speaking entirely by rote.



<P>Mrs. Norris began to look about her, and wonder that



<P>his falling in love with Julia had come to nothing;



<P>and could almost fear that she had been remiss herself



<P>in forwarding it; but with so many to care for, how was



<P>it possible for even _her_ activity to keep pace with



<P>her wishes?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Another day or two, and Mr. Yates was gone likewise.



<P>In _his_ departure Sir Thomas felt the chief interest:



<P>wanting to be alone with his family, the presence of a



<P>stranger superior to Mr. Yates must have been irksome;



<P>but of him, trifling and confident, idle and expensive,



<P>it was every way vexatious.&nbsp; In himself he was wearisome,



<P>but as the friend of Tom and the admirer of Julia he



<P>became offensive.&nbsp; Sir Thomas had been quite indifferent



<P>to Mr. Crawford's going or staying:&nbsp; but his good



<P>wishes for Mr. Yates's having a pleasant journey,



<P>as he walked with him to the hall-door, were given with



<P>genuine satisfaction.&nbsp; Mr. Yates had staid to see the



<P>destruction of every theatrical preparation at Mansfield,



<P>the removal of everything appertaining to the play:



<P>he left the house in all the soberness of its general



<P>character; and Sir Thomas hoped, in seeing him out of it,



<P>to be rid of the worst object connected with the scheme,



<P>and the last that must be inevitably reminding him of



<P>its existence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris contrived to remove one article from his sight



<P>that might have distressed him.&nbsp; The curtain, over which



<P>she had presided with such talent and such success,



<P>went off with her to her cottage, where she happened



<P>to be particularly in want of green baize.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 34</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXXIV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Edmund had great things to hear on his return.&nbsp; Many surprises



<P>were awaiting him.&nbsp; The first that occurred was not least



<P>in interest:&nbsp; the appearance of Henry Crawford and his sister



<P>walking together through the village as he rode into it.



<P>He had concluded--he had meant them to be far distant.



<P>His absence had been extended beyond a fortnight purposely



<P>to avoid Miss Crawford.&nbsp; He was returning to Mansfield



<P>with spirits ready to feed on melancholy remembrances,



<P>and tender associations, when her own fair self was



<P>before him, leaning on her brother's arm, and he found



<P>himself receiving a welcome, unquestionably friendly,



<P>from the woman whom, two moments before, he had been



<P>thinking of as seventy miles off, and as farther,



<P>much farther, from him in inclination than any distance



<P>could express.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her reception of him was of a sort which he could not



<P>have hoped for, had he expected to see her.&nbsp; Coming as he



<P>did from such a purport fulfilled as had taken him away,



<P>he would have expected anything rather than a look



<P>of satisfaction, and words of simple, pleasant meaning.



<P>It was enough to set his heart in a glow, and to bring him



<P>home in the properest state for feeling the full value



<P>of the other joyful surprises at hand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>William's promotion, with all its particulars, he was soon



<P>master of; and with such a secret provision of comfort



<P>within his own breast to help the joy, he found in it



<P>a source of most gratifying sensation and unvarying



<P>cheerfulness all dinner-time.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After dinner, when he and his father were alone,



<P>he had Fanny's history; and then all the great events



<P>of the last fortnight, and the present situation



<P>of matters at Mansfield were known to him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny suspected what was going on.&nbsp; They sat so much



<P>longer than usual in the dining-parlour, that she was sure



<P>they must be talking of her; and when tea at last brought



<P>them away, and she was to be seen by Edmund again, she felt



<P>dreadfully guilty.&nbsp; He came to her, sat down by her,



<P>took her hand, and pressed it kindly; and at that moment



<P>she thought that, but for the occupation and the scene



<P>which the tea-things afforded, she must have betrayed



<P>her emotion in some unpardonable excess.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was not intending, however, by such action,



<P>to be conveying to her that unqualified approbation



<P>and encouragement which her hopes drew from it.



<P>It was designed only to express his participation in all



<P>that interested her, and to tell her that he had been



<P>hearing what quickened every feeling of affection.&nbsp; He was,



<P>in fact, entirely on his father's side of the question.



<P>His surprise was not so great as his father's at her



<P>refusing Crawford, because, so far from supposing



<P>her to consider him with anything like a preference,



<P>he had always believed it to be rather the reverse,



<P>and could imagine her to be taken perfectly unprepared,



<P>but Sir Thomas could not regard the connexion as more



<P>desirable than he did.&nbsp; It had every recommendation to him;



<P>and while honouring her for what she had done under the



<P>influence of her present indifference, honouring her in



<P>rather stronger terms than Sir Thomas could quite echo,



<P>he was most earnest in hoping, and sanguine in believing,



<P>that it would be a match at last, and that, united by



<P>mutual affection, it would appear that their dispositions



<P>were as exactly fitted to make them blessed in each other,



<P>as he was now beginning seriously to consider them.



<P>Crawford had been too precipitate.&nbsp; He had not given her



<P>time to attach herself.&nbsp; He had begun at the wrong end.



<P>With such powers as his, however, and such a disposition



<P>as hers, Edmund trusted that everything would work



<P>out a happy conclusion.&nbsp; Meanwhile, he saw enough



<P>of Fanny's embarrassment to make him scrupulously guard



<P>against exciting it a second time, by any word, or look,



<P>or movement.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Crawford called the next day, and on the score of Edmund's



<P>return, Sir Thomas felt himself more than licensed to ask



<P>him to stay dinner; it was really a necessary compliment.



<P>He staid of course, and Edmund had then ample opportunity



<P>for observing how he sped with Fanny, and what degree



<P>of immediate encouragement for him might be extracted from



<P>her manners; and it was so little, so very, very little--



<P>every chance, every possibility of it, resting upon her



<P>embarrassment only; if there was not hope in her confusion,



<P>there was hope in nothing else--that he was almost ready



<P>to wonder at his friend's perseverance.&nbsp; Fanny was worth



<P>it all; he held her to be worth every effort of patience,



<P>every exertion of mind, but he did not think he could have



<P>gone on himself with any woman breathing, without something



<P>more to warm his courage than his eyes could discern in hers.



<P>He was very willing to hope that Crawford saw clearer,



<P>and this was the most comfortable conclusion for his



<P>friend that he could come to from all that he observed



<P>to pass before, and at, and after dinner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the evening a few circumstances occurred which he thought



<P>more promising.&nbsp; When he and Crawford walked into the



<P>drawing-room, his mother and Fanny were sitting as intently



<P>and silently at work as if there were nothing else to care for.



<P>Edmund could not help noticing their apparently deep tranquillity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We have not been so silent all the time," replied his mother.



<P>"Fanny has been reading to me, and only put the book



<P>down upon hearing you coming."&nbsp; And sure enough there



<P>was a book on the table which had the air of being



<P>very recently closed:&nbsp; a volume of Shakespeare.



<P>"She often reads to me out of those books; and she



<P>was in the middle of a very fine speech of that man's--



<P>what's his name, Fanny?--when we heard your footsteps."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Crawford took the volume.&nbsp; "Let me have the pleasure



<P>of finishing that speech to your ladyship," said he.



<P>"I shall find it immediately."&nbsp; And by carefully giving



<P>way to the inclination of the leaves, he did find it,



<P>or within a page or two, quite near enough to satisfy



<P>Lady Bertram, who assured him, as soon as he mentioned the



<P>name of Cardinal Wolsey, that he had got the very speech.



<P>Not a look or an offer of help had Fanny given; not a syllable



<P>for or against.&nbsp; All her attention was for her work.



<P>She seemed determined to be interested by nothing else.



<P>But taste was too strong in her.&nbsp; She could not abstract



<P>her mind five minutes:&nbsp; she was forced to listen; his reading



<P>was capital, and her pleasure in good reading extreme.



<P>To _good_ reading, however, she had been long used:



<P>her uncle read well, her cousins all, Edmund very well,



<P>but in Mr. Crawford's reading there was a variety of



<P>excellence beyond what she had ever met with.&nbsp; The King,



<P>the Queen, Buckingham, Wolsey, Cromwell, all were given



<P>in turn; for with the happiest knack, the happiest



<P>power of jumping and guessing, he could always alight



<P>at will on the best scene, or the best speeches of each;



<P>and whether it were dignity, or pride, or tenderness,



<P>or remorse, or whatever were to be expressed, he could



<P>do it with equal beauty.&nbsp; It was truly dramatic.



<P>His acting had first taught Fanny what pleasure a play



<P>might give, and his reading brought all his acting before



<P>her again; nay, perhaps with greater enjoyment, for it



<P>came unexpectedly, and with no such drawback as she had



<P>been used to suffer in seeing him on the stage with Miss



<P>Bertram.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund watched the progress of her attention, and was



<P>amused and gratified by seeing how she gradually slackened



<P>in the needlework, which at the beginning seemed to



<P>occupy her totally:&nbsp; how it fell from her hand while



<P>she sat motionless over it, and at last, how the eyes



<P>which had appeared so studiously to avoid him throughout



<P>the day were turned and fixed on Crawford--fixed on him



<P>for minutes, fixed on him, in short, till the attraction



<P>drew Crawford's upon her, and the book was closed,



<P>and the charm was broken.&nbsp; Then she was shrinking again



<P>into herself, and blushing and working as hard as ever;



<P>but it had been enough to give Edmund encouragement



<P>for his friend, and as he cordially thanked him,



<P>he hoped to be expressing Fanny's secret feelings too.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That play must be a favourite with you," said he;



<P>"you read as if you knew it well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It will be a favourite, I believe, from this hour,"



<P>replied Crawford; "but I do not think I have had a volume



<P>of Shakespeare in my hand before since I was fifteen.



<P>I once saw Henry the Eighth acted, or I have heard



<P>of it from somebody who did, I am not certain which.



<P>But Shakespeare one gets acquainted with without knowing how.



<P>It is a part of an Englishman's constitution.&nbsp; His thoughts



<P>and beauties are so spread abroad that one touches



<P>them everywhere; one is intimate with him by instinct.



<P>No man of any brain can open at a good part of one



<P>of his plays without falling into the flow of his



<P>meaning immediately."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No doubt one is familiar with Shakespeare in a degree,"



<P>said Edmund, "from one's earliest years.&nbsp; His celebrated



<P>passages are quoted by everybody; they are in half



<P>the books we open, and we all talk Shakespeare,



<P>use his similes, and describe with his descriptions;



<P>but this is totally distinct from giving his sense as you



<P>gave it.&nbsp; To know him in bits and scraps is common enough;



<P>to know him pretty thoroughly is, perhaps, not uncommon;



<P>but to read him well aloud is no everyday talent."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sir, you do me honour," was Crawford's answer, with a bow



<P>of mock gravity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Both gentlemen had a glance at Fanny, to see if a word



<P>of accordant praise could be extorted from her; yet both



<P>feeling that it could not be.&nbsp; Her praise had been given



<P>in her attention; _that_ must content them.

<BR>&nbsp;
