<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram's admiration was expressed, and strongly too.



<P>"It was really like being at a play," said she.&nbsp; "I wish



<P>Sir Thomas had been here."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Crawford was excessively pleased.&nbsp; If Lady Bertram,



<P>with all her incompetency and languor, could feel this,



<P>the inference of what her niece, alive and enlightened



<P>as she was, must feel, was elevating.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have a great turn for acting, I am sure, Mr. Crawford,"



<P>said her ladyship soon afterwards; "and I will tell you what,



<P>I think you will have a theatre, some time or other,



<P>at your house in Norfolk.&nbsp; I mean when you are settled there.



<P>I do indeed.&nbsp; I think you will fit up a theatre at your



<P>house in Norfolk."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you, ma'am?" cried he, with quickness.&nbsp; "No, no,



<P>that will never be.&nbsp; Your ladyship is quite mistaken.



<P>No theatre at Everingham!&nbsp; Oh no!"&nbsp; And he looked at Fanny



<P>with an expressive smile, which evidently meant, "That lady



<P>will never allow a theatre at Everingham."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund saw it all, and saw Fanny so determined _not_ to see it,



<P>as to make it clear that the voice was enough to convey



<P>the full meaning of the protestation; and such a quick



<P>consciousness of compliment, such a ready comprehension



<P>of a hint, he thought, was rather favourable than not.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The subject of reading aloud was farther discussed.



<P>The two young men were the only talkers, but they,



<P>standing by the fire, talked over the too common neglect



<P>of the qualification, the total inattention to it, in the



<P>ordinary school-system for boys, the consequently natural,



<P>yet in some instances almost unnatural, degree of ignorance



<P>and uncouthness of men, of sensible and well-informed men,



<P>when suddenly called to the necessity of reading aloud,



<P>which had fallen within their notice, giving instances



<P>of blunders, and failures with their secondary causes,



<P>the want of management of the voice, of proper modulation



<P>and emphasis, of foresight and judgment, all proceeding



<P>from the first cause:&nbsp; want of early attention and habit;



<P>and Fanny was listening again with great entertainment.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Even in my profession," said Edmund, with a smile,



<P>"how little the art of reading has been studied! how little



<P>a clear manner, and good delivery, have been attended to!



<P>I speak rather of the past, however, than the present.



<P>There is now a spirit of improvement abroad; but among



<P>those who were ordained twenty, thirty, forty years ago,



<P>the larger number, to judge by their performance,



<P>must have thought reading was reading, and preaching



<P>was preaching.&nbsp; It is different now.&nbsp; The subject is more



<P>justly considered.&nbsp; It is felt that distinctness and energy



<P>may have weight in recommending the most solid truths;



<P>and besides, there is more general observation and taste,



<P>a more critical knowledge diffused than formerly;



<P>in every congregation there is a larger proportion



<P>who know a little of the matter, and who can judge



<P>and criticise."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund had already gone through the service once since



<P>his ordination; and upon this being understood, he had



<P>a variety of questions from Crawford as to his feelings



<P>and success; questions, which being made, though with the



<P>vivacity of friendly interest and quick taste, without any



<P>touch of that spirit of banter or air of levity which Edmund



<P>knew to be most offensive to Fanny, he had true pleasure



<P>in satisfying; and when Crawford proceeded to ask his



<P>opinion and give his own as to the properest manner in which



<P>particular passages in the service should be delivered,



<P>shewing it to be a subject on which he had thought before,



<P>and thought with judgment, Edmund was still more and



<P>more pleased.&nbsp; This would be the way to Fanny's heart.



<P>She was not to be won by all that gallantry and wit and



<P>good-nature together could do; or, at least, she would



<P>not be won by them nearly so soon, without the assistance



<P>of sentiment and feeling, and seriousness on serious subjects

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Our liturgy," observed Crawford, "has beauties, which not



<P>even a careless, slovenly style of reading can destroy;



<P>but it has also redundancies and repetitions which require



<P>good reading not to be felt.&nbsp; For myself, at least, I must



<P>confess being not always so attentive as I ought to be"



<P>(here was a glance at Fanny); "that nineteen times out of



<P>twenty I am thinking how such a prayer ought to be read,



<P>and longing to have it to read myself.&nbsp; Did you speak?"



<P>stepping eagerly to Fanny, and addressing her in a



<P>softened voice; and upon her saying "No," he added,



<P>"Are you sure you did not speak?&nbsp; I saw your lips move.



<P>I fancied you might be going to tell me I ought to be



<P>more attentive, and not _allow_ my thoughts to wander.



<P>Are not you going to tell me so?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, indeed, you know your duty too well for me to--



<P>even supposing--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She stopt, felt herself getting into a puzzle, and could



<P>not be prevailed on to add another word, not by dint



<P>of several minutes of supplication and waiting.&nbsp; He then



<P>returned to his former station, and went on as if there



<P>had been no such tender interruption.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A sermon, well delivered, is more uncommon even than prayers



<P>well read.&nbsp; A sermon, good in itself, is no rare thing.



<P>It is more difficult to speak well than to compose well;



<P>that is, the rules and trick of composition are



<P>oftener an object of study.&nbsp; A thoroughly good sermon,



<P>thoroughly well delivered, is a capital gratification.



<P>I can never hear such a one without the greatest admiration



<P>and respect, and more than half a mind to take orders



<P>and preach myself.&nbsp; There is something in the eloquence



<P>of the pulpit, when it is really eloquence, which is entitled



<P>to the highest praise and honour.&nbsp; The preacher who can



<P>touch and affect such an heterogeneous mass of hearers,



<P>on subjects limited, and long worn threadbare in all



<P>common hands; who can say anything new or striking,



<P>anything that rouses the attention without offending the taste,



<P>or wearing out the feelings of his hearers, is a man whom



<P>one could not, in his public capacity, honour enough.



<P>I should like to be such a man."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund laughed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should indeed.&nbsp; I never listened to a distinguished



<P>preacher in my life without a sort of envy.&nbsp; But then,



<P>I must have a London audience.&nbsp; I could not preach but



<P>to the educated; to those who were capable of estimating



<P>my composition.&nbsp; And I do not know that I should be fond



<P>of preaching often; now and then, perhaps once or twice



<P>in the spring, after being anxiously expected for half



<P>a dozen Sundays together; but not for a constancy;



<P>it would not do for a constancy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here Fanny, who could not but listen, involuntarily shook



<P>her head, and Crawford was instantly by her side again,



<P>entreating to know her meaning; and as Edmund perceived,



<P>by his drawing in a chair, and sitting down close by her,



<P>that it was to be a very thorough attack, that looks



<P>and undertones were to be well tried, he sank as quietly



<P>as possible into a corner, turned his back, and took up



<P>a newspaper, very sincerely wishing that dear little



<P>Fanny might be persuaded into explaining away that shake



<P>of the head to the satisfaction of her ardent lover;



<P>and as earnestly trying to bury every sound of the business



<P>from himself in murmurs of his own, over the various



<P>advertisements of "A most desirable Estate in South



<P>Wales"; "To Parents and Guardians"; and a "Capital



<P>season'd Hunter."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, meanwhile, vexed with herself for not having been



<P>as motionless as she was speechless, and grieved to the heart



<P>to see Edmund's arrangements, was trying by everything



<P>in the power of her modest, gentle nature, to repulse



<P>Mr. Crawford, and avoid both his looks and inquiries;



<P>and he, unrepulsable, was persisting in both.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What did that shake of the head mean?" said he.&nbsp; "What was



<P>it meant to express?&nbsp; Disapprobation, I fear.&nbsp; But of what?



<P>What had I been saying to displease you?&nbsp; Did you think me



<P>speaking improperly, lightly, irreverently on the subject?



<P>Only tell me if I was.&nbsp; Only tell me if I was wrong.



<P>I want to be set right.&nbsp; Nay, nay, I entreat you;



<P>for one moment put down your work.&nbsp; What did that shake



<P>of the head mean?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In vain was her "Pray, sir, don't; pray, Mr. Crawford,"



<P>repeated twice over; and in vain did she try to move away.



<P>In the same low, eager voice, and the same close neighbourhood,



<P>he went on, reurging the same questions as before.



<P>She grew more agitated and displeased.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How can you, sir?&nbsp; You quite astonish me; I wonder



<P>how you can--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do I astonish you?" said he.&nbsp; "Do you wonder?&nbsp; Is there



<P>anything in my present entreaty that you do not understand?



<P>I will explain to you instantly all that makes me urge



<P>you in this manner, all that gives me an interest in



<P>what you look and do, and excites my present curiosity.



<P>I will not leave you to wonder long."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In spite of herself, she could not help half a smile,



<P>but she said nothing.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You shook your head at my acknowledging that I should



<P>not like to engage in the duties of a clergyman always



<P>for a constancy.&nbsp; Yes, that was the word.&nbsp; Constancy:&nbsp;

I am



<P>not afraid of the word.&nbsp; I would spell it, read it,



<P>write it with anybody.&nbsp; I see nothing alarming in the word.



<P>Did you think I ought?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Perhaps, sir," said Fanny, wearied at last into speaking--



<P>"perhaps, sir, I thought it was a pity you did not always



<P>know yourself as well as you seemed to do at that moment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Crawford, delighted to get her to speak at any rate,



<P>was determined to keep it up; and poor Fanny, who had



<P>hoped to silence him by such an extremity of reproof,



<P>found herself sadly mistaken, and that it was only a change



<P>from one object of curiosity and one set of words to another.



<P>He had always something to entreat the explanation of.



<P>The opportunity was too fair.&nbsp; None such had occurred



<P>since his seeing her in her uncle's room, none such might



<P>occur again before his leaving Mansfield.&nbsp; Lady Bertram's



<P>being just on the other side of the table was a trifle,



<P>for she might always be considered as only half-awake, and



<P>Edmund's advertisements were still of the first utility.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," said Crawford, after a course of rapid questions



<P>and reluctant answers; "I am happier than I was, because I



<P>now understand more clearly your opinion of me.&nbsp; You think



<P>me unsteady:&nbsp; easily swayed by the whim of the moment,



<P>easily tempted, easily put aside.&nbsp; With such an opinion,



<P>no wonder that.&nbsp; But we shall see.&nbsp; It is not by protestations



<P>that I shall endeavour to convince you I am wronged;



<P>it is not by telling you that my affections are steady.



<P>My conduct shall speak for me; absence, distance, time shall



<P>speak for me.&nbsp; _They_ shall prove that, as far as you



<P>can be deserved by anybody, I do deserve you.&nbsp; You are



<P>infinitely my superior in merit; all _that_ I know.



<P>You have qualities which I had not before supposed



<P>to exist in such a degree in any human creature.



<P>You have some touches of the angel in you beyond what--



<P>not merely beyond what one sees, because one never sees



<P>anything like it--but beyond what one fancies might be.



<P>But still I am not frightened.&nbsp; It is not by equality of



<P>merit that you can be won.&nbsp; That is out of the question.



<P>It is he who sees and worships your merit the strongest,



<P>who loves you most devotedly, that has the best



<P>right to a return.&nbsp; There I build my confidence.



<P>By that right I do and will deserve you; and when once



<P>convinced that my attachment is what I declare it,



<P>I know you too well not to entertain the warmest hopes.



<P>Yes, dearest, sweetest Fanny.&nbsp; Nay" (seeing her draw back



<P>displeased), "forgive me.&nbsp; Perhaps I have as yet no right;



<P>but by what other name can I call you?&nbsp; Do you suppose



<P>you are ever present to my imagination under any other?



<P>No, it is 'Fanny' that I think of all day, and dream



<P>of all night.&nbsp; You have given the name such reality



<P>of sweetness, that nothing else can now be descriptive



<P>of you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny could hardly have kept her seat any longer,



<P>or have refrained from at least trying to get away in



<P>spite of all the too public opposition she foresaw to it,



<P>had it not been for the sound of approaching relief,



<P>the very sound which she had been long watching for,



<P>and long thinking strangely delayed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The solemn procession, headed by Baddeley, of tea-board, urn,



<P>and cake-bearers, made its appearance, and delivered



<P>her from a grievous imprisonment of body and mind.



<P>Mr. Crawford was obliged to move.&nbsp; She was at liberty,



<P>she was busy, she was protected.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund was not sorry to be admitted again among the



<P>number of those who might speak and hear.&nbsp; But though



<P>the conference had seemed full long to him, and though



<P>on looking at Fanny he saw rather a flush of vexation,



<P>he inclined to hope that so much could not have been



<P>said and listened to without some profit to the speaker.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 08</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER VIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Fanny's rides recommenced the very next day; and as it



<P>was a pleasant fresh-feeling morning, less hot than the



<P>weather had lately been, Edmund trusted that her losses,



<P>both of health and pleasure, would be soon made good.



<P>While she was gone Mr. Rushworth arrived, escorting his mother,



<P>who came to be civil and to shew her civility especially,



<P>in urging the execution of the plan for visiting Sotherton,



<P>which had been started a fortnight before, and which,



<P>in consequence of her subsequent absence from home,



<P>had since lain dormant.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris and her nieces were all



<P>well pleased with its revival, and an early day was named



<P>and agreed to, provided Mr. Crawford should be disengaged:



<P>the young ladies did not forget that stipulation, and though



<P>Mrs. Norris would willingly have answered for his being so,



<P>they would neither authorise the liberty nor run the risk;



<P>and at last, on a hint from Miss Bertram, Mr. Rushworth



<P>discovered that the properest thing to be done was for



<P>him to walk down to the Parsonage directly, and call on



<P>Mr. Crawford, and inquire whether Wednesday would suit him



<P>or not.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Before his return Mrs. Grant and Miss Crawford came in.



<P>Having been out some time, and taken a different route



<P>to the house, they had not met him.&nbsp; Comfortable hopes,



<P>however, were given that he would find Mr. Crawford



<P>at home.&nbsp; The Sotherton scheme was mentioned of course.



<P>It was hardly possible, indeed, that anything else should



<P>be talked of, for Mrs. Norris was in high spirits about it;



<P>and Mrs. Rushworth, a well-meaning, civil, prosing,



<P>pompous woman, who thought nothing of consequence, but as it



<P>related to her own and her son's concerns, had not yet



<P>given over pressing Lady Bertram to be of the party.



<P>Lady Bertram constantly declined it; but her placid manner



<P>of refusal made Mrs. Rushworth still think she wished



<P>to come, till Mrs. Norris's more numerous words and louder



<P>tone convinced her of the truth.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The fatigue would be too much for my sister, a great



<P>deal too much, I assure you, my dear Mrs. Rushworth.



<P>Ten miles there, and ten back, you know.&nbsp; You must



<P>excuse my sister on this occasion, and accept of our



<P>two dear girls and myself without her.&nbsp; Sotherton is



<P>the only place that could give her a _wish_ to go so far,



<P>but it cannot be, indeed.&nbsp; She will have a companion



<P>in Fanny Price, you know, so it will all do very well;



<P>and as for Edmund, as he is not here to speak for himself,



<P>I will answer for his being most happy to join the party.



<P>He can go on horseback, you know."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Rushworth being obliged to yield to Lady Bertram's



<P>staying at home, could only be sorry.&nbsp; "The loss of her



<P>ladyship's company would be a great drawback, and she



<P>should have been extremely happy to have seen the young



<P>lady too, Miss Price, who had never been at Sotherton yet,



<P>and it was a pity she should not see the place."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are very kind, you are all kindness, my dear madam,"



<P>cried Mrs. Norris; "but as to Fanny, she will have



<P>opportunities in plenty of seeing Sotherton.&nbsp; She has



<P>time enough before her; and her going now is quite out



<P>of the question.&nbsp; Lady Bertram could not possibly spare her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh no!&nbsp; I cannot do without Fanny."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Rushworth proceeded next, under the conviction that



<P>everybody must be wanting to see Sotherton, to include



<P>Miss Crawford in the invitation; and though Mrs. Grant,



<P>who had not been at the trouble of visiting Mrs. Rushworth,



<P>on her coming into the neighbourhood, civilly declined it



<P>on her own account, she was glad to secure any pleasure



<P>for her sister; and Mary, properly pressed and persuaded,



<P>was not long in accepting her share of the civility.



<P>Mr. Rushworth came back from the Parsonage successful;



<P>and Edmund made his appearance just in time to learn what



<P>had been settled for Wednesday, to attend Mrs. Rushworth



<P>to her carriage, and walk half-way down the park with the two



<P>other ladies.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>On his return to the breakfast-room, he found Mrs. Norris



<P>trying to make up her mind as to whether Miss Crawford's



<P>being of the party were desirable or not, or whether



<P>her brother's barouche would not be full without her.



<P>The Miss Bertrams laughed at the idea, assuring her



<P>that the barouche would hold four perfectly well,



<P>independent of the box, on which _one_ might go with him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But why is it necessary," said Edmund, "that Crawford's carriage,



<P>or his _only_, should be employed?&nbsp; Why is no use to be



<P>made of my mother's chaise?&nbsp; I could not, when the scheme



<P>was first mentioned the other day, understand why a visit



<P>from the family were not to be made in the carriage of the family."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What!" cried Julia:&nbsp; "go boxed up three in a postchaise



<P>in this weather, when we may have seats in a barouche!



<P>No, my dear Edmund, that will not quite do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Besides," said Maria, "I know that Mr. Crawford depends



<P>upon taking us.&nbsp; After what passed at first, he would



<P>claim it as a promise."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And, my dear Edmund," added Mrs. Norris, "taking out _two_



<P>carriages when _one_ will do, would be trouble for nothing;



<P>and, between ourselves, coachman is not very fond of the



<P>roads between this and Sotherton:&nbsp; he always complains



<P>bitterly of the narrow lanes scratching his carriage,



<P>and you know one should not like to have dear Sir Thomas,



<P>when he comes home, find all the varnish scratched off."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That would not be a very handsome reason for using



<P>Mr. Crawford's," said Maria; "but the truth is, that Wilcox



<P>is a stupid old fellow, and does not know how to drive.



<P>I will answer for it that we shall find no inconvenience



<P>from narrow roads on Wednesday."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There is no hardship, I suppose, nothing unpleasant,"



<P>said Edmund, "in going on the barouche box."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Unpleasant!" cried Maria:&nbsp; "oh dear!&nbsp; I believe it would



<P>be generally thought the favourite seat.&nbsp; There can



<P>be no comparison as to one's view of the country.



<P>Probably Miss Crawford will choose the barouche-box herself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There can be no objection, then, to Fanny's going with you;



<P>there can be no doubt of your having room for her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fanny!" repeated Mrs. Norris; "my dear Edmund, there is



<P>no idea of her going with us.&nbsp; She stays with her aunt.



<P>I told Mrs. Rushworth so.&nbsp; She is not expected."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You can have no reason, I imagine, madam," said he,



<P>addressing his mother, "for wishing Fanny _not_



<P>to be of the party, but as it relates to yourself,



<P>to your own comfort.&nbsp; If you could do without her,



<P>you would not wish to keep her at home?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To be sure not, but I _cannot_ do without her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You can, if I stay at home with you, as I mean to do."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a general cry out at this.&nbsp; "Yes," he continued,



<P>"there is no necessity for my going, and I mean to stay



<P>at home.&nbsp; Fanny has a great desire to see Sotherton.



<P>I know she wishes it very much.&nbsp; She has not often a



<P>gratification of the kind, and I am sure, ma'am, you would



<P>be glad to give her the pleasure now?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes! very glad, if your aunt sees no objection."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris was very ready with the only objection which



<P>could remain--their having positively assured Mrs. Rushworth



<P>that Fanny could not go, and the very strange appearance



<P>there would consequently be in taking her, which seemed



<P>to her a difficulty quite impossible to be got over.



<P>It must have the strangest appearance!&nbsp; It would be



<P>something so very unceremonious, so bordering on disrespect



<P>for Mrs. Rushworth, whose own manners were such a pattern



<P>of good-breeding and attention, that she really did not



<P>feel equal to it.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris had no affection for Fanny,



<P>and no wish of procuring her pleasure at any time;



<P>but her opposition to Edmund _now_, arose more from



<P>partiality for her own scheme, because it _was_ her own,



<P>than from anything else.&nbsp; She felt that she had arranged



<P>everything extremely well, and that any alteration must be



<P>for the worse.&nbsp; When Edmund, therefore, told her in reply,



<P>as he did when she would give him the hearing, that she



<P>need not distress herself on Mrs. Rushworth's account,



<P>because he had taken the opportunity, as he walked with



<P>her through the hall, of mentioning Miss Price as one



<P>who would probably be of the party, and had directly



<P>received a very sufficient invitation for his cousin,



<P>Mrs. Norris was too much vexed to submit with a very



<P>good grace, and would only say, "Very well, very well,



<P>just as you chuse, settle it your own way, I am sure I



<P>do not care about it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It seems very odd," said Maria, "that you should be



<P>staying at home instead of Fanny."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am sure she ought to be very much obliged to you,"



<P>added Julia, hastily leaving the room as she spoke,



<P>from a consciousness that she ought to offer to stay at



<P>home herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fanny will feel quite as grateful as the occasion requires,"



<P>was Edmund's only reply, and the subject dropt.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's gratitude, when she heard the plan, was, in fact,



<P>much greater than her pleasure.&nbsp; She felt Edmund's kindness



<P>with all, and more than all, the sensibility which he,



<P>unsuspicious of her fond attachment, could be aware of;



<P>but that he should forego any enjoyment on her account gave



<P>her pain, and her own satisfaction in seeing Sotherton would



<P>be nothing without him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The next meeting of the two Mansfield families produced



<P>another alteration in the plan, and one that was admitted



<P>with general approbation.&nbsp; Mrs. Grant offered herself as



<P>companion for the day to Lady Bertram in lieu of her son,



<P>and Dr. Grant was to join them at dinner.&nbsp; Lady Bertram



<P>was very well pleased to have it so, and the young ladies



<P>were in spirits again.&nbsp; Even Edmund was very thankful for an



<P>arrangement which restored him to his share of the party;



<P>and Mrs. Norris thought it an excellent plan, and had it



<P>at her tongue's end, and was on the point of proposing it,



<P>when Mrs. Grant spoke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Wednesday was fine, and soon after breakfast the barouche



<P>arrived, Mr. Crawford driving his sisters; and as everybody



<P>was ready, there was nothing to be done but for Mrs. Grant



<P>to alight and the others to take their places.&nbsp; The place



<P>of all places, the envied seat, the post of honour,



<P>was unappropriated.&nbsp; To whose happy lot was it to fall?



<P>While each of the Miss Bertrams were meditating how best,



<P>and with the most appearance of obliging the others,



<P>to secure it, the matter was settled by Mrs. Grant's saying,



<P>as she stepped from the carriage, "As there are five



<P>of you, it will be better that one should sit with Henry;



<P>and as you were saying lately that you wished you



<P>could drive, Julia, I think this will be a good opportunity



<P>for you to take a lesson."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Happy Julia!&nbsp; Unhappy Maria!&nbsp; The former was on the



<P>barouche-box in a moment, the latter took her seat within,



<P>in gloom and mortification; and the carriage drove



<P>off amid the good wishes of the two remaining ladies,



<P>and the barking of Pug in his mistress's arms.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their road was through a pleasant country; and Fanny,



<P>whose rides had never been extensive, was soon beyond



<P>her knowledge, and was very happy in observing all that



<P>was new, and admiring all that was pretty.&nbsp; She was not



<P>often invited to join in the conversation of the others,



<P>nor did she desire it.&nbsp; Her own thoughts and reflections



<P>were habitually her best companions; and, in observing



<P>the appearance of the country, the bearings of the roads,



<P>the difference of soil, the state of the harvest, the cottages,



<P>the cattle, the children, she found entertainment



<P>that could only have been heightened by having Edmund



<P>to speak to of what she felt.&nbsp; That was the only point



<P>of resemblance between her and the lady who sat by her:



<P>in everything but a value for Edmund, Miss Crawford was



<P>very unlike her.&nbsp; She had none of Fanny's delicacy of taste,



<P>of mind, of feeling; she saw Nature, inanimate Nature,



<P>with little observation; her attention was all for men



<P>and women, her talents for the light and lively.



<P>In looking back after Edmund, however, when there was



<P>any stretch of road behind them, or when he gained on



<P>them in ascending a considerable hill, they were united,



<P>and a "there he is" broke at the same moment from them both,



<P>more than once.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For the first seven miles Miss Bertram had very little



<P>real comfort:&nbsp; her prospect always ended in Mr. Crawford



<P>and her sister sitting side by side, full of conversation



<P>and merriment; and to see only his expressive profile



<P>as he turned with a smile to Julia, or to catch the laugh



<P>of the other, was a perpetual source of irritation,



<P>which her own sense of propriety could but just smooth over.



<P>When Julia looked back, it was with a countenance of delight,



<P>and whenever she spoke to them, it was in the highest spirits:



<P>"her view of the country was charming, she wished they



<P>could all see it," etc.; but her only offer of exchange



<P>was addressed to Miss Crawford, as they gained the summit



<P>of a long hill, and was not more inviting than this:



<P>"Here is a fine burst of country.&nbsp; I wish you had my seat,



<P>but I dare say you will not take it, let me press you ever



<P>so much;" and Miss Crawford could hardly answer before they



<P>were moving again at a good pace.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When they came within the influence of Sotherton associations,



<P>it was better for Miss Bertram, who might be said to have



<P>two strings to her bow.&nbsp; She had Rushworth feelings,



<P>and Crawford feelings, and in the vicinity of Sotherton



<P>the former had considerable effect.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth's



<P>consequence was hers.&nbsp; She could not tell Miss Crawford



<P>that "those woods belonged to Sotherton," she could not



<P>carelessly observe that "she believed that it was now



<P>all Mr. Rushworth's property on each side of the road,"



<P>without elation of heart; and it was a pleasure to increase



<P>with their approach to the capital freehold mansion,



<P>and ancient manorial residence of the family, with all



<P>its rights of court-leet and court-baron.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now we shall have no more rough road, Miss Crawford;



<P>our difficulties are over.&nbsp; The rest of the way is such



<P>as it ought to be.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth has made it since he



<P>succeeded to the estate.&nbsp; Here begins the village.



<P>Those cottages are really a disgrace.&nbsp; The church spire



<P>is reckoned remarkably handsome.&nbsp; I am glad the church



<P>is not so close to the great house as often happens in



<P>old places.&nbsp; The annoyance of the bells must be terrible.



<P>There is the parsonage:&nbsp; a tidy-looking house, and I



<P>understand the clergyman and his wife are very decent people.



<P>Those are almshouses, built by some of the family.



<P>To the right is the steward's house; he is a very



<P>respectable man.&nbsp; Now we are coming to the lodge-gates;



<P>but we have nearly a mile through the park still.



<P>It is not ugly, you see, at this end; there is some



<P>fine timber, but the situation of the house is dreadful.



<P>We go down hill to it for half a mile, and it is a pity,



<P>for it would not be an ill-looking place if it had a



<P>better approach."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford was not slow to admire; she pretty well guessed



<P>Miss Bertram's feelings, and made it a point of honour



<P>to promote her enjoyment to the utmost.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris was



<P>all delight and volubility; and even Fanny had something



<P>to say in admiration, and might be heard with complacency.



<P>Her eye was eagerly taking in everything within her reach;



<P>and after being at some pains to get a view of the house,



<P>and observing that "it was a sort of building which she



<P>could not look at but with respect," she added, "Now, where



<P>is the avenue?&nbsp; The house fronts the east, I perceive.



<P>The avenue, therefore, must be at the back of it.



<P>Mr. Rushworth talked of the west front."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, it is exactly behind the house; begins at a little



<P>distance, and ascends for half a mile to the extremity



<P>of the grounds.&nbsp; You may see something of it here--



<P>something of the more distant trees.&nbsp; It is oak entirely."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Bertram could now speak with decided information



<P>of what she had known nothing about when Mr. Rushworth



<P>had asked her opinion; and her spirits were in as happy



<P>a flutter as vanity and pride could furnish, when they drove



<P>up to the spacious stone steps before the principal entrance.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 09</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER IX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Rushworth was at the door to receive his fair lady;



<P>and the whole party were welcomed by him with due attention.



<P>In the drawing-room they were met with equal cordiality



<P>by the mother, and Miss Bertram had all the distinction



<P>with each that she could wish.&nbsp; After the business



<P>of arriving was over, it was first necessary to eat,



<P>and the doors were thrown open to admit them through one



<P>or two intermediate rooms into the appointed dining-parlour,



<P>where a collation was prepared with abundance and elegance.



<P>Much was said, and much was ate, and all went well.



<P>The particular object of the day was then considered.



<P>How would Mr. Crawford like, in what manner would he chuse,



<P>to take a survey of the grounds?&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth mentioned



<P>his curricle.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford suggested the greater desirableness



<P>of some carriage which might convey more than two.



<P>"To be depriving themselves of the advantage of other eyes



<P>and other judgments, might be an evil even beyond the loss



<P>of present pleasure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Rushworth proposed that the chaise should be taken also;



<P>but this was scarcely received as an amendment:&nbsp; the young



<P>ladies neither smiled nor spoke.&nbsp; Her next proposition,



<P>of shewing the house to such of them as had not been



<P>there before, was more acceptable, for Miss Bertram was



<P>pleased to have its size displayed, and all were glad



<P>to be doing something.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The whole party rose accordingly, and under Mrs. Rushworth's



<P>guidance were shewn through a number of rooms, all lofty,



<P>and many large, and amply furnished in the taste of fifty



<P>years back, with shining floors, solid mahogany, rich damask,



<P>marble, gilding, and carving, each handsome in its way.



<P>Of pictures there were abundance, and some few good,



<P>but the larger part were family portraits, no longer



<P>anything to anybody but Mrs. Rushworth, who had been at



<P>great pains to learn all that the housekeeper could teach,



<P>and was now almost equally well qualified to shew the house.



<P>On the present occasion she addressed herself chiefly



<P>to Miss Crawford and Fanny, but there was no comparison



<P>in the willingness of their attention; for Miss Crawford,



<P>who had seen scores of great houses, and cared for none



<P>of them, had only the appearance of civilly listening,



<P>while Fanny, to whom everything was almost as interesting



<P>as it was new, attended with unaffected earnestness to all



<P>that Mrs. Rushworth could relate of the family in former times,



<P>its rise and grandeur, regal visits and loyal efforts,



<P>delighted to connect anything with history already known,



<P>or warm her imagination with scenes of the past.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The situation of the house excluded the possibility



<P>of much prospect from any of the rooms; and while Fanny



<P>and some of the others were attending Mrs. Rushworth,



<P>Henry Crawford was looking grave and shaking his head



<P>at the windows.&nbsp; Every room on the west front looked



<P>across a lawn to the beginning of the avenue immediately



<P>beyond tall iron palisades and gates.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having visited many more rooms than could be supposed to be



<P>of any other use than to contribute to the window-tax, and



<P>find employment for housemaids, "Now," said Mrs. Rushworth,



<P>"we are coming to the chapel, which properly we ought



<P>to enter from above, and look down upon; but as we



<P>are quite among friends, I will take you in this way,



<P>if you will excuse me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They entered.&nbsp; Fanny's imagination had prepared her



<P>for something grander than a mere spacious, oblong room,



<P>fitted up for the purpose of devotion:&nbsp; with nothing more



<P>striking or more solemn than the profusion of mahogany,



<P>and the crimson velvet cushions appearing over the ledge



<P>of the family gallery above.&nbsp; "I am disappointed,"



<P>said she, in a low voice, to Edmund.&nbsp; "This is not



<P>my idea of a chapel.&nbsp; There is nothing awful here,



<P>nothing melancholy, nothing grand.&nbsp; Here are no aisles,



<P>no arches, no inscriptions, no banners.&nbsp; No banners,



<P>cousin, to be 'blown by the night wind of heaven.'



<P>No signs that a 'Scottish monarch sleeps below.'"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You forget, Fanny, how lately all this has been built,



<P>and for how confined a purpose, compared with the old



<P>chapels of castles and monasteries.&nbsp; It was only for



<P>the private use of the family.&nbsp; They have been buried,



<P>I suppose, in the parish church.&nbsp; _There_ you must look



<P>for the banners and the achievements."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was foolish of me not to think of all that; but I



<P>am disappointed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Rushworth began her relation.&nbsp; "This chapel was fitted up



<P>as you see it, in James the Second's time.&nbsp; Before that period,



<P>as I understand, the pews were only wainscot; and there



<P>is some reason to think that the linings and cushions



<P>of the pulpit and family seat were only purple cloth;



<P>but this is not quite certain.&nbsp; It is a handsome chapel,



<P>and was formerly in constant use both morning and evening.



<P>Prayers were always read in it by the domestic chaplain,



<P>within the memory of many; but the late Mr. Rushworth left



<P>it off."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Every generation has its improvements," said Miss Crawford,



<P>with a smile, to Edmund.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Rushworth was gone to repeat her lesson to Mr. Crawford;



<P>and Edmund, Fanny, and Miss Crawford remained in a cluster



<P>together.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is a pity," cried Fanny, "that the custom should have



<P>been discontinued.&nbsp; It was a valuable part of former times.



<P>There is something in a chapel and chaplain so much



<P>in character with a great house, with one's ideas of what



<P>such a household should be!&nbsp; A whole family assembling



<P>regularly for the purpose of prayer is fine!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very fine indeed," said Miss Crawford, laughing.&nbsp; "It must



<P>do the heads of the family a great deal of good to force



<P>all the poor housemaids and footmen to leave business



<P>and pleasure, and say their prayers here twice a day,



<P>while they are inventing excuses themselves for staying



<P>away."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_That_ is hardly Fanny's idea of a family assembling,"



<P>said Edmund.&nbsp; "If the master and mistress do _not_



<P>attend themselves, there must be more harm than good



<P>in the custom."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"At any rate, it is safer to leave people to their own



<P>devices on such subjects.&nbsp; Everybody likes to go their



<P>own way--to chuse their own time and manner of devotion.



<P>The obligation of attendance, the formality, the restraint,



<P>the length of time--altogether it is a formidable thing,



<P>and what nobody likes; and if the good people who used



<P>to kneel and gape in that gallery could have foreseen



<P>that the time would ever come when men and women might lie



<P>another ten minutes in bed, when they woke with a headache,



<P>without danger of reprobation, because chapel was missed,



<P>they would have jumped with joy and envy.&nbsp; Cannot you



<P>imagine with what unwilling feelings the former belles



<P>of the house of Rushworth did many a time repair to



<P>this chapel?&nbsp; The young Mrs. Eleanors and Mrs. Bridgets--



<P>starched up into seeming piety, but with heads full



<P>of something very different--especially if the poor



<P>chaplain were not worth looking at--and, in those days,



<P>I fancy parsons were very inferior even to what they



<P>are now."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For a few moments she was unanswered.&nbsp; Fanny coloured



<P>and looked at Edmund, but felt too angry for speech;



<P>and he needed a little recollection before he could say,



<P>"Your lively mind can hardly be serious even on serious subjects.



<P>You have given us an amusing sketch, and human nature



<P>cannot say it was not so.&nbsp; We must all feel _at_ _times_



<P>the difficulty of fixing our thoughts as we could wish;



<P>but if you are supposing it a frequent thing, that is to say,



<P>a weakness grown into a habit from neglect, what could



<P>be expected from the _private_ devotions of such persons?



<P>Do you think the minds which are suffered, which are



<P>indulged in wanderings in a chapel, would be more collected



<P>in a closet?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, very likely.&nbsp; They would have two chances at least



<P>in their favour.&nbsp; There would be less to distract the



<P>attention from without, and it would not be tried so long."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The mind which does not struggle against itself under



<P>_one_ circumstance, would find objects to distract it



<P>in the _other_, I believe; and the influence of the place



<P>and of example may often rouse better feelings than are



<P>begun with.&nbsp; The greater length of the service, however,



<P>I admit to be sometimes too hard a stretch upon the mind.



<P>One wishes it were not so; but I have not yet left



<P>Oxford long enough to forget what chapel prayers are."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While this was passing, the rest of the party being scattered



<P>about the chapel, Julia called Mr. Crawford's attention to



<P>her sister, by saying, "Do look at Mr. Rushworth and Maria,



<P>standing side by side, exactly as if the ceremony were



<P>going to be performed.&nbsp; Have not they completely the air of it?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Crawford smiled his acquiescence, and stepping forward



<P>to Maria, said, in a voice which she only could hear,



<P>"I do not like to see Miss Bertram so near the altar."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Starting, the lady instinctively moved a step or two,



<P>but recovering herself in a moment, affected to laugh,



<P>and asked him, in a tone not much louder, "If he would give



<P>her away?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am afraid I should do it very awkwardly," was his reply,



<P>with a look of meaning.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Julia, joining them at the moment, carried on the joke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Upon my word, it is really a pity that it should not



<P>take place directly, if we had but a proper licence,



<P>for here we are altogether, and nothing in the world



<P>could be more snug and pleasant."&nbsp; And she talked and



<P>laughed about it with so little caution as to catch the



<P>comprehension of Mr. Rushworth and his mother, and expose



<P>her sister to the whispered gallantries of her lover,



<P>while Mrs. Rushworth spoke with proper smiles and dignity



<P>of its being a most happy event to her whenever it took place.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If Edmund were but in orders!" cried Julia, and running



<P>to where he stood with Miss Crawford and Fanny:



<P>"My dear Edmund, if you were but in orders now, you might



<P>perform the ceremony directly.&nbsp; How unlucky that you



<P>are not ordained; Mr. Rushworth and Maria are quite ready."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford's countenance, as Julia spoke, might have



<P>amused a disinterested observer.&nbsp; She looked almost aghast



<P>under the new idea she was receiving.&nbsp; Fanny pitied her.



<P>"How distressed she will be at what she said just now,"



<P>passed across her mind.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ordained!" said Miss Crawford; "what, are you to be



<P>a clergyman?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; I shall take orders soon after my father's return--



<P>probably at Christmas."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford, rallying her spirits, and recovering



<P>her complexion, replied only, "If I had known this before,



<P>I would have spoken of the cloth with more respect,"



<P>and turned the subject.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The chapel was soon afterwards left to the silence and stillness



<P>which reigned in it, with few interruptions, throughout the year.



<P>Miss Bertram, displeased with her sister, led the way,



<P>and all seemed to feel that they had been there long enough.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The lower part of the house had been now entirely shewn,



<P>and Mrs. Rushworth, never weary in the cause, would have



<P>proceeded towards the principal staircase, and taken



<P>them through all the rooms above, if her son had not



<P>interposed with a doubt of there being time enough.



<P>"For if," said he, with the sort of self-evident proposition



<P>which many a clearer head does not always avoid, "we are



<P>_too_ long going over the house, we shall not have time



<P>for what is to be done out of doors.&nbsp; It is past two,



<P>and we are to dine at five."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Rushworth submitted; and the question of surveying



<P>the grounds, with the who and the how, was likely to be more



<P>fully agitated, and Mrs. Norris was beginning to arrange



<P>by what junction of carriages and horses most could be done,



<P>when the young people, meeting with an outward door,



<P>temptingly open on a flight of steps which led immediately



<P>to turf and shrubs, and all the sweets of pleasure-grounds,



<P>as by one impulse, one wish for air and liberty, all walked out.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Suppose we turn down here for the present," said Mrs. Rushworth,



<P>civilly taking the hint and following them.&nbsp; "Here are the



<P>greatest number of our plants, and here are the curious pheasants."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Query," said Mr. Crawford, looking round him,



<P>"whether we may not find something to employ us here



<P>before we go farther?&nbsp; I see walls of great promise.



<P>Mr. Rushworth, shall we summon a council on this lawn?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"James," said Mrs. Rushworth to her son, "I believe



<P>the wilderness will be new to all the party.&nbsp; The Miss



<P>Bertrams have never seen the wilderness yet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>No objection was made, but for some time there seemed



<P>no inclination to move in any plan, or to any distance.



<P>All were attracted at first by the plants or the pheasants,



<P>and all dispersed about in happy independence.



<P>Mr. Crawford was the first to move forward to examine



<P>the capabilities of that end of the house.&nbsp; The lawn,



<P>bounded on each side by a high wall, contained beyond



<P>the first planted area a bowling-green, and beyond



<P>the bowling-green a long terrace walk, backed by iron



<P>palisades, and commanding a view over them into the tops



<P>of the trees of the wilderness immediately adjoining.



<P>It was a good spot for fault-finding. Mr. Crawford was soon



<P>followed by Miss Bertram and Mr. Rushworth; and when,



<P>after a little time, the others began to form into parties,



<P>these three were found in busy consultation on the terrace



<P>by Edmund, Miss Crawford, and Fanny, who seemed as naturally



<P>to unite, and who, after a short participation of their



<P>regrets and difficulties, left them and walked on.



<P>The remaining three, Mrs. Rushworth, Mrs. Norris,



<P>and Julia, were still far behind; for Julia, whose happy



<P>star no longer prevailed, was obliged to keep by the side



<P>of Mrs. Rushworth, and restrain her impatient feet to that



<P>lady's slow pace, while her aunt, having fallen in with



<P>the housekeeper, who was come out to feed the pheasants,



<P>was lingering behind in gossip with her.&nbsp; Poor Julia,



<P>the only one out of the nine not tolerably satisfied



<P>with their lot, was now in a state of complete penance,



<P>and as different from the Julia of the barouche-box



<P>as could well be imagined.&nbsp; The politeness which she had



<P>been brought up to practise as a duty made it impossible



<P>for her to escape; while the want of that higher species



<P>of self-command, that just consideration of others,



<P>that knowledge of her own heart, that principle of right,



<P>which had not formed any essential part of her education,



<P>made her miserable under it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is insufferably hot," said Miss Crawford, when they



<P>had taken one turn on the terrace, and were drawing



<P>a second time to the door in the middle which opened to



<P>the wilderness.&nbsp; "Shall any of us object to being comfortable?



<P>Here is a nice little wood, if one can but get into it.



<P>What happiness if the door should not be locked! but of



<P>course it is; for in these great places the gardeners



<P>are the only people who can go where they like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The door, however, proved not to be locked, and they were



<P>all agreed in turning joyfully through it, and leaving



<P>the unmitigated glare of day behind.&nbsp; A considerable



<P>flight of steps landed them in the wilderness, which was



<P>a planted wood of about two acres, and though chiefly



<P>of larch and laurel, and beech cut down, and though laid



<P>out with too much regularity, was darkness and shade,



<P>and natural beauty, compared with the bowling-green



<P>and the terrace.&nbsp; They all felt the refreshment of it,



<P>and for some time could only walk and admire.&nbsp; At length,



<P>after a short pause, Miss Crawford began with, "So you



<P>are to be a clergyman, Mr. Bertram.&nbsp; This is rather



<P>a surprise to me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why should it surprise you?&nbsp; You must suppose me designed



<P>for some profession, and might perceive that I am neither



<P>a lawyer, nor a soldier, nor a sailor."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true; but, in short, it had not occurred to me.



<P>And you know there is generally an uncle or a grandfather



<P>to leave a fortune to the second son."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"A very praiseworthy practice," said Edmund,



<P>"but not quite universal.&nbsp; I am one of the exceptions,



<P>and _being_ one, must do something for myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"'But why are you to be a clergyman?&nbsp; I thought _that_



<P>was always the lot of the youngest, where there were



<P>many to chuse before him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you think the church itself never chosen, then?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_Never_ is a black word.&nbsp; But yes, in the _never_



<P>of conversation, which means _not_ _very_ _often_,



<P>I do think it.&nbsp; For what is to be done in the church?



<P>Men love to distinguish themselves, and in either of the other



<P>lines distinction may be gained, but not in the church.



<P>A clergyman is nothing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The _nothing_ of conversation has its gradations, I hope,



<P>as well as the _never_.&nbsp; A clergyman cannot be high in



<P>state or fashion.&nbsp; He must not head mobs, or set the ton



<P>in dress.&nbsp; But I cannot call that situation nothing which



<P>has the charge of all that is of the first importance



<P>to mankind, individually or collectively considered,



<P>temporally and eternally, which has the guardianship



<P>of religion and morals, and consequently of the manners



<P>which result from their influence.&nbsp; No one here can call



<P>the _office_ nothing.&nbsp; If the man who holds it is so,



<P>it is by the neglect of his duty, by foregoing its



<P>just importance, and stepping out of his place to appear



<P>what he ought not to appear."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_You_ assign greater consequence to the clergyman than one



<P>has been used to hear given, or than I can quite comprehend.



<P>One does not see much of this influence and importance



<P>in society, and how can it be acquired where they are



<P>so seldom seen themselves?&nbsp; How can two sermons a week,



<P>even supposing them worth hearing, supposing the preacher



<P>to have the sense to prefer Blair's to his own, do all



<P>that you speak of? govern the conduct and fashion the



<P>manners of a large congregation for the rest of the week?



<P>One scarcely sees a clergyman out of his pulpit."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_You_ are speaking of London, _I_ am speaking of the



<P>nation at large."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The metropolis, I imagine, is a pretty fair sample



<P>of the rest."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not, I should hope, of the proportion of virtue to vice



<P>throughout the kingdom.&nbsp; We do not look in great cities



<P>for our best morality.&nbsp; It is not there that respectable



<P>people of any denomination can do most good; and it



<P>certainly is not there that the influence of the clergy can



<P>be most felt.&nbsp; A fine preacher is followed and admired;



<P>but it is not in fine preaching only that a good clergyman



<P>will be useful in his parish and his neighbourhood,



<P>where the parish and neighbourhood are of a size capable



<P>of knowing his private character, and observing his



<P>general conduct, which in London can rarely be the case.



<P>The clergy are lost there in the crowds of their parishioners.



<P>They are known to the largest part only as preachers.



<P>And with regard to their influencing public manners,



<P>Miss Crawford must not misunderstand me, or suppose I mean



<P>to call them the arbiters of good-breeding, the regulators



<P>of refinement and courtesy, the masters of the ceremonies



<P>of life.&nbsp; The _manners_ I speak of might rather be



<P>called _conduct_, perhaps, the result of good principles;



<P>the effect, in short, of those doctrines which it



<P>is their duty to teach and recommend; and it will,



<P>I believe, be everywhere found, that as the clergy are,



<P>or are not what they ought to be, so are the rest of



<P>the nation."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly," said Fanny, with gentle earnestness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"There," cried Miss Crawford, "you have quite convinced



<P>Miss Price already."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I wish I could convince Miss Crawford too."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not think you ever will," said she, with an arch smile;



<P>"I am just as much surprised now as I was at first



<P>that you should intend to take orders.&nbsp; You really are



<P>fit for something better.&nbsp; Come, do change your mind.



<P>It is not too late.&nbsp; Go into the law."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Go into the law!&nbsp; With as much ease as I was told to go



<P>into this wilderness."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Now you are going to say something about law being



<P>the worst wilderness of the two, but I forestall you;



<P>remember, I have forestalled you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You need not hurry when the object is only to prevent



<P>my saying a _bon_ _mot_, for there is not the least wit in



<P>my nature.&nbsp; I am a very matter-of-fact, plain-spoken being,



<P>and may blunder on the borders of a repartee for half



<P>an hour together without striking it out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A general silence succeeded.&nbsp; Each was thoughtful.



<P>Fanny made the first interruption by saying, "I wonder



<P>that I should be tired with only walking in this sweet wood;



<P>but the next time we come to a seat, if it is not disagreeable



<P>to you, I should be glad to sit down for a little while."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Fanny," cried Edmund, immediately drawing her arm



<P>within his, "how thoughtless I have been!&nbsp; I hope you



<P>are not very tired.&nbsp; Perhaps," turning to Miss Crawford,



<P>"my other companion may do me the honour of taking an arm."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you, but I am not at all tired."&nbsp; She took it,



<P>however, as she spoke, and the gratification of having



<P>her do so, of feeling such a connexion for the first time,



<P>made him a little forgetful of Fanny.&nbsp; "You scarcely



<P>touch me," said he.&nbsp; "You do not make me of any use.



<P>What a difference in the weight of a woman's arm from



<P>that of a man!&nbsp; At Oxford I have been a good deal used



<P>to have a man lean on me for the length of a street,



<P>and you are only a fly in the comparison."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am really not tired, which I almost wonder at;



<P>for we must have walked at least a mile in this wood.



<P>Do not you think we have?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not half a mile," was his sturdy answer; for he was not yet



<P>so much in love as to measure distance, or reckon time,



<P>with feminine lawlessness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! you do not consider how much we have wound about.



<P>We have taken such a very serpentine course, and the wood



<P>itself must be half a mile long in a straight line,



<P>for we have never seen the end of it yet since we left



<P>the first great path."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But if you remember, before we left that first great path,



<P>we saw directly to the end of it.&nbsp; We looked down the



<P>whole vista, and saw it closed by iron gates, and it



<P>could not have been more than a furlong in length."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; I know nothing of your furlongs, but I am sure



<P>it is a very long wood, and that we have been winding



<P>in and out ever since we came into it; and therefore,



<P>when I say that we have walked a mile in it, I must speak



<P>within compass."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We have been exactly a quarter of an hour here,"



<P>said Edmund, taking out his watch.&nbsp; "Do you think we



<P>are walking four miles an hour?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! do not attack me with your watch.&nbsp; A watch is always



<P>too fast or too slow.&nbsp; I cannot be dictated to by a watch."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A few steps farther brought them out at the bottom of the



<P>very walk they had been talking of; and standing back,



<P>well shaded and sheltered, and looking over a ha-ha into



<P>the park, was a comfortable-sized bench, on which they



<P>all sat down.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am afraid you are very tired, Fanny," said Edmund,



<P>observing her; "why would not you speak sooner?&nbsp; This will be



<P>a bad day's amusement for you if you are to be knocked up.



<P>Every sort of exercise fatigues her so soon, Miss Crawford,



<P>except riding."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How abominable in you, then, to let me engross her horse



<P>as I did all last week!&nbsp; I am ashamed of you and of myself,



<P>but it shall never happen again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_Your_ attentiveness and consideration makes me more



<P>sensible of my own neglect.&nbsp; Fanny's interest seems



<P>in safer hands with you than with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That she should be tired now, however, gives me no surprise;



<P>for there is nothing in the course of one's duties



<P>so fatiguing as what we have been doing this morning:



<P>seeing a great house, dawdling from one room to another,



<P>straining one's eyes and one's attention, hearing what one



<P>does not understand, admiring what one does not care for.



<P>It is generally allowed to be the greatest bore in the world,



<P>and Miss Price has found it so, though she did not



<P>know it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I shall soon be rested," said Fanny; "to sit



<P>in the shade on a fine day, and look upon verdure,



<P>is the most perfect refreshment."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After sitting a little while Miss Crawford was up again.



<P>"I must move," said she; "resting fatigues me.



<P>I have looked across the ha-ha till I am weary.&nbsp; I must



<P>go and look through that iron gate at the same view,



<P>without being able to see it so well."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund left the seat likewise.&nbsp; "Now, Miss Crawford,



<P>if you will look up the walk, you will convince yourself



<P>that it cannot be half a mile long, or half half a mile."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is an immense distance," said she; "I see _that_



<P>with a glance."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He still reasoned with her, but in vain.&nbsp; She would



<P>not calculate, she would not compare.&nbsp; She would only



<P>smile and assert.&nbsp; The greatest degree of rational



<P>consistency could not have been more engaging, and they



<P>talked with mutual satisfaction.&nbsp; At last it was agreed



<P>that they should endeavour to determine the dimensions



<P>of the wood by walking a little more about it.&nbsp; They would



<P>go to one end of it, in the line they were then in--



<P>for there was a straight green walk along the bottom



<P>by the side of the ha-ha--and perhaps turn a little way



<P>in some other direction, if it seemed likely to assist them,



<P>and be back in a few minutes.&nbsp; Fanny said she was rested,



<P>and would have moved too, but this was not suffered.



<P>Edmund urged her remaining where she was with an



<P>earnestness which she could not resist, and she was left



<P>on the bench to think with pleasure of her cousin's care,



<P>but with great regret that she was not stronger.



<P>She watched them till they had turned the corner,



<P>and listened till all sound of them had ceased.



<P>
