   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 35</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXXV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Edmund had determined that it belonged entirely to Fanny



<P>to chuse whether her situation with regard to Crawford



<P>should be mentioned between them or not; and that if she



<P>did not lead the way, it should never be touched on by him;



<P>but after a day or two of mutual reserve, he was induced



<P>by his father to change his mind, and try what his influence



<P>might do for his friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A day, and a very early day, was actually fixed for



<P>the Crawfords' departure; and Sir Thomas thought it



<P>might be as well to make one more effort for the young



<P>man before he left Mansfield, that all his professions



<P>and vows of unshaken attachment might have as much



<P>hope to sustain them as possible.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas was most cordially anxious for the perfection



<P>of Mr. Crawford's character in that point.&nbsp; He wished him



<P>to be a model of constancy; and fancied the best means



<P>of effecting it would be by not trying him too long.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund was not unwilling to be persuaded to engage



<P>in the business; he wanted to know Fanny's feelings.



<P>She had been used to consult him in every difficulty,



<P>and he loved her too well to bear to be denied her



<P>confidence now; he hoped to be of service to her, he thought



<P>he must be of service to her; whom else had she to open



<P>her heart to?&nbsp; If she did not need counsel, she must need



<P>the comfort of communication.&nbsp; Fanny estranged from him,



<P>silent and reserved, was an unnatural state of things;



<P>a state which he must break through, and which he could



<P>easily learn to think she was wanting him to break through.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will speak to her, sir:&nbsp; I will take the first opportunity



<P>of speaking to her alone," was the result of such thoughts



<P>as these; and upon Sir Thomas's information of her



<P>being at that very time walking alone in the shrubbery,



<P>he instantly joined her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am come to walk with you, Fanny," said he.&nbsp; "Shall I?"



<P>Drawing her arm within his.&nbsp; "It is a long while since we



<P>have had a comfortable walk together."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She assented to it all rather by look than word.



<P>Her spirits were low.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But, Fanny," he presently added, "in order to have a



<P>comfortable walk, something more is necessary than merely



<P>pacing this gravel together.&nbsp; You must talk to me.



<P>I know you have something on your mind.&nbsp; I know what you



<P>are thinking of.&nbsp; You cannot suppose me uninformed.



<P>Am I to hear of it from everybody but Fanny herself?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, at once agitated and dejected, replied, "If you



<P>hear of it from everybody, cousin, there can be nothing



<P>for me to tell."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not of facts, perhaps; but of feelings, Fanny.



<P>No one but you can tell me them.&nbsp; I do not mean to



<P>press you, however.&nbsp; If it is not what you wish yourself,



<P>I have done.&nbsp; I had thought it might be a relief."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am afraid we think too differently for me to find



<P>any relief in talking of what I feel."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you suppose that we think differently?&nbsp; I have no idea



<P>of it.&nbsp; I dare say that, on a comparison of our opinions,



<P>they would be found as much alike as they have been used to be:



<P>to the point--I consider Crawford's proposals as most



<P>advantageous and desirable, if you could return his affection.



<P>I consider it as most natural that all your family



<P>should wish you could return it; but that, as you cannot,



<P>you have done exactly as you ought in refusing him.



<P>Can there be any disagreement between us here?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh no!&nbsp; But I thought you blamed me.&nbsp; I thought you



<P>were against me.&nbsp; This is such a comfort!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This comfort you might have had sooner, Fanny, had you



<P>sought it.&nbsp; But how could you possibly suppose me against you?



<P>How could you imagine me an advocate for marriage without love?



<P>Were I even careless in general on such matters, how could



<P>you imagine me so where your happiness was at stake?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My uncle thought me wrong, and I knew he had been talking



<P>to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As far as you have gone, Fanny, I think you perfectly right.



<P>I may be sorry, I may be surprised--though hardly _that_,



<P>for you had not had time to attach yourself--but I think



<P>you perfectly right.&nbsp; Can it admit of a question?



<P>It is disgraceful to us if it does.&nbsp; You did not love him;



<P>nothing could have justified your accepting him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny had not felt so comfortable for days and days.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"So far your conduct has been faultless, and they were quite



<P>mistaken who wished you to do otherwise.&nbsp; But the matter



<P>does not end here.&nbsp; Crawford's is no common attachment;



<P>he perseveres, with the hope of creating that regard



<P>which had not been created before.&nbsp; This, we know,



<P>must be a work of time.&nbsp; But" (with an affectionate smile)



<P>"let him succeed at last, Fanny, let him succeed at last.



<P>You have proved yourself upright and disinterested,



<P>prove yourself grateful and tender-hearted; and then you



<P>will be the perfect model of a woman which I have always



<P>believed you born for."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! never, never, never! he never will succeed with me."



<P>And she spoke with a warmth which quite astonished Edmund,



<P>and which she blushed at the recollection of herself,



<P>when she saw his look, and heard him reply, "Never!&nbsp; Fanny!--



<P>so very determined and positive!&nbsp; This is not like yourself,



<P>your rational self."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I mean," she cried, sorrowfully correcting herself,



<P>"that I _think_ I never shall, as far as the future can



<P>be answered for; I think I never shall return his regard."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I must hope better things.&nbsp; I am aware, more aware



<P>than Crawford can be, that the man who means to make



<P>you love him (you having due notice of his intentions)



<P>must have very uphill work, for there are all your early



<P>attachments and habits in battle array; and before he



<P>can get your heart for his own use he has to unfasten it



<P>from all the holds upon things animate and inanimate,



<P>which so many years' growth have confirmed, and which are



<P>considerably tightened for the moment by the very idea



<P>of separation.&nbsp; I know that the apprehension of being



<P>forced to quit Mansfield will for a time be arming you



<P>against him.&nbsp; I wish he had not been obliged to tell you



<P>what he was trying for.&nbsp; I wish he had known you as well as



<P>I do, Fanny.&nbsp; Between us, I think we should have won you.



<P>My theoretical and his practical knowledge together could



<P>not have failed.&nbsp; He should have worked upon my plans.



<P>I must hope, however, that time, proving him (as I firmly



<P>believe it will) to deserve you by his steady affection,



<P>will give him his reward.&nbsp; I cannot suppose that you have



<P>not the _wish_ to love him--the natural wish of gratitude.



<P>You must have some feeling of that sort.&nbsp; You must be sorry



<P>for your own indifference."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We are so totally unlike," said Fanny, avoiding a



<P>direct answer, "we are so very, very different in all



<P>our inclinations and ways, that I consider it as quite



<P>impossible we should ever be tolerably happy together,



<P>even if I _could_ like him.&nbsp; There never were two people



<P>more dissimilar.&nbsp; We have not one taste in common.



<P>We should be miserable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are mistaken, Fanny.&nbsp; The dissimilarity is not so strong.



<P>You are quite enough alike.&nbsp; You _have_ tastes in common.



<P>You have moral and literary tastes in common.&nbsp; You have



<P>both warm hearts and benevolent feelings; and, Fanny,



<P>who that heard him read, and saw you listen to Shakespeare



<P>the other night, will think you unfitted as companions?



<P>You forget yourself:&nbsp; there is a decided difference



<P>in your tempers, I allow.&nbsp; He is lively, you are serious;



<P>but so much the better:&nbsp; his spirits will support yours.



<P>It is your disposition to be easily dejected and to fancy



<P>difficulties greater than they are.&nbsp; His cheerfulness



<P>will counteract this.&nbsp; He sees difficulties nowhere:



<P>and his pleasantness and gaiety will be a constant support



<P>to you.&nbsp; Your being so far unlike, Fanny, does not in



<P>the smallest degree make against the probability of your



<P>happiness together:&nbsp; do not imagine it.&nbsp; I am myself



<P>convinced that it is rather a favourable circumstance.



<P>I am perfectly persuaded that the tempers had better be unlike:



<P>I mean unlike in the flow of the spirits, in the manners,



<P>in the inclination for much or little company, in the



<P>propensity to talk or to be silent, to be grave or to be gay.



<P>Some opposition here is, I am thoroughly convinced,



<P>friendly to matrimonial happiness.&nbsp; I exclude extremes,



<P>of course; and a very close resemblance in all those



<P>points would be the likeliest way to produce an extreme.



<P>A counteraction, gentle and continual, is the best safeguard



<P>of manners and conduct."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Full well could Fanny guess where his thoughts were now:



<P>Miss Crawford's power was all returning.&nbsp; He had been



<P>speaking of her cheerfully from the hour of his coming home.



<P>His avoiding her was quite at an end.&nbsp; He had dined at the



<P>Parsonage only the preceding day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>After leaving him to his happier thoughts for some minutes,



<P>Fanny, feeling it due to herself, returned to Mr. Crawford,



<P>and said, "It is not merely in _temper_ that I consider



<P>him as totally unsuited to myself; though, in _that_



<P>respect, I think the difference between us too great,



<P>infinitely too great:&nbsp; his spirits often oppress me;



<P>but there is something in him which I object to still more.



<P>I must say, cousin, that I cannot approve his character.



<P>I have not thought well of him from the time of the play.



<P>I then saw him behaving, as it appeared to me, so very



<P>improperly and unfeelingly--I may speak of it now because



<P>it is all over--so improperly by poor Mr. Rushworth,



<P>not seeming to care how he exposed or hurt him,



<P>and paying attentions to my cousin Maria, which--in short,



<P>at the time of the play, I received an impression which



<P>will never be got over."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Fanny," replied Edmund, scarcely hearing her



<P>to the end, "let us not, any of us, be judged by what we



<P>appeared at that period of general folly.&nbsp; The time of the



<P>play is a time which I hate to recollect.&nbsp; Maria was wrong,



<P>Crawford was wrong, we were all wrong together; but none



<P>so wrong as myself.&nbsp; Compared with me, all the rest



<P>were blameless.&nbsp; I was playing the fool with my eyes open."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As a bystander," said Fanny, "perhaps I saw more than



<P>you did; and I do think that Mr. Rushworth was sometimes



<P>very jealous."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very possibly.&nbsp; No wonder.&nbsp; Nothing could be more improper



<P>than the whole business.&nbsp; I am shocked whenever I think



<P>that Maria could be capable of it; but, if she could



<P>undertake the part, we must not be surprised at the rest."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Before the play, I am much mistaken if _Julia_ did



<P>not think he was paying her attentions.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Julia!&nbsp; I have heard before from some one of his being



<P>in love with Julia; but I could never see anything of it.



<P>And, Fanny, though I hope I do justice to my sisters'



<P>good qualities, I think it very possible that they might,



<P>one or both, be more desirous of being admired by Crawford,



<P>and might shew that desire rather more unguardedly than was



<P>perfectly prudent.&nbsp; I can remember that they were evidently



<P>fond of his society; and with such encouragement, a man



<P>like Crawford, lively, and it may be, a little unthinking,



<P>might be led on to--there could be nothing very striking,



<P>because it is clear that he had no pretensions:&nbsp; his heart



<P>was reserved for you.&nbsp; And I must say, that its being



<P>for you has raised him inconceivably in my opinion.



<P>It does him the highest honour; it shews his proper estimation



<P>of the blessing of domestic happiness and pure attachment.



<P>It proves him unspoilt by his uncle.&nbsp; It proves him, in short,



<P>everything that I had been used to wish to believe him,



<P>and feared he was not."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am persuaded that he does not think, as he ought,



<P>on serious subjects."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Say, rather, that he has not thought at all upon serious



<P>subjects, which I believe to be a good deal the case.



<P>How could it be otherwise, with such an education and adviser?



<P>Under the disadvantages, indeed, which both have had,



<P>is it not wonderful that they should be what they are?



<P>Crawford's _feelings_, I am ready to acknowledge, have hitherto



<P>been too much his guides.&nbsp; Happily, those feelings have



<P>generally been good.&nbsp; You will supply the rest; and a most



<P>fortunate man he is to attach himself to such a creature--



<P>to a woman who, firm as a rock in her own principles, has a



<P>gentleness of character so well adapted to recommend them.



<P>He has chosen his partner, indeed, with rare felicity.



<P>He will make you happy, Fanny; I know he will make you happy;



<P>but you will make him everything."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I would not engage in such a charge," cried Fanny, in a



<P>shrinking accent; "in such an office of high responsibility!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"As usual, believing yourself unequal to anything!



<P>fancying everything too much for you!&nbsp; Well, though I



<P>may not be able to persuade you into different feelings,



<P>you will be persuaded into them, I trust.



<P>I confess myself sincerely anxious that you may.



<P>I have no common interest in Crawford's well-doing. Next



<P>to your happiness, Fanny, his has the first claim on me.



<P>You are aware of my having no common interest in Crawford."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was too well aware of it to have anything to say;



<P>and they walked on together some fifty yards in mutual



<P>silence and abstraction.&nbsp; Edmund first began again--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I was very much pleased by her manner of speaking



<P>of it yesterday, particularly pleased, because I had not



<P>depended upon her seeing everything in so just a light.



<P>I knew she was very fond of you; but yet I was afraid



<P>of her not estimating your worth to her brother quite



<P>as it deserved, and of her regretting that he had not



<P>rather fixed on some woman of distinction or fortune.



<P>I was afraid of the bias of those worldly maxims, which she



<P>has been too much used to hear.&nbsp; But it was very different.



<P>She spoke of you, Fanny, just as she ought.&nbsp; She desires



<P>the connexion as warmly as your uncle or myself.



<P>We had a long talk about it.&nbsp; I should not have mentioned



<P>the subject, though very anxious to know her sentiments;



<P>but I had not been in the room five minutes before she



<P>began introducing it with all that openness of heart,



<P>and sweet peculiarity of manner, that spirit and ingenuousness



<P>which are so much a part of herself.&nbsp; Mrs. Grant laughed



<P>at her for her rapidity."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Was Mrs. Grant in the room, then?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, when I reached the house I found the two sisters



<P>together by themselves; and when once we had begun,



<P>we had not done with you, Fanny, till Crawford and Dr. Grant



<P>came in."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is above a week since I saw Miss Crawford."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, she laments it; yet owns it may have been best.



<P>You will see her, however, before she goes.&nbsp; She is very



<P>angry with you, Fanny; you must be prepared for that.



<P>She calls herself very angry, but you can imagine her anger.



<P>It is the regret and disappointment of a sister,



<P>who thinks her brother has a right to everything he may



<P>wish for, at the first moment.&nbsp; She is hurt, as you would



<P>be for William; but she loves and esteems you with all



<P>her heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I knew she would be very angry with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dearest Fanny," cried Edmund, pressing her arm closer



<P>to him, "do not let the idea of her anger distress you.



<P>It is anger to be talked of rather than felt.&nbsp; Her heart



<P>is made for love and kindness, not for resentment.



<P>I wish you could have overheard her tribute of praise;



<P>I wish you could have seen her countenance, when she said



<P>that you _should_ be Henry's wife.&nbsp; And I observed that she



<P>always spoke of you as 'Fanny,' which she was never used to do;



<P>and it had a sound of most sisterly cordiality."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And Mrs. Grant, did she say--did she speak; was she



<P>there all the time?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, she was agreeing exactly with her sister.&nbsp; The surprise



<P>of your refusal, Fanny, seems to have been unbounded.



<P>That you could refuse such a man as Henry Crawford seems



<P>more than they can understand.&nbsp; I said what I could for you;



<P>but in good truth, as they stated the case--you must



<P>prove yourself to be in your senses as soon as you can



<P>by a different conduct; nothing else will satisfy them.



<P>But this is teasing you.&nbsp; I have done.&nbsp; Do not turn away



<P>from me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I _should_ have thought," said Fanny, after a pause



<P>of recollection and exertion, "that every woman must



<P>have felt the possibility of a man's not being approved,



<P>not being loved by some one of her sex at least, let him



<P>be ever so generally agreeable.&nbsp; Let him have all the



<P>perfections in the world, I think it ought not to be set



<P>down as certain that a man must be acceptable to every



<P>woman he may happen to like himself.&nbsp; But, even supposing



<P>it is so, allowing Mr. Crawford to have all the claims



<P>which his sisters think he has, how was I to be prepared



<P>to meet him with any feeling answerable to his own?



<P>He took me wholly by surprise.&nbsp; I had not an idea that



<P>his behaviour to me before had any meaning; and surely I



<P>was not to be teaching myself to like him only because



<P>he was taking what seemed very idle notice of me.



<P>In my situation, it would have been the extreme of vanity



<P>to be forming expectations on Mr. Crawford.&nbsp; I am sure



<P>his sisters, rating him as they do, must have thought it so,



<P>supposing he had meant nothing.&nbsp; How, then, was I to be--



<P>to be in love with him the moment he said he was with me?



<P>How was I to have an attachment at his service, as soon



<P>as it was asked for?&nbsp; His sisters should consider me



<P>as well as him.&nbsp; The higher his deserts, the more improper



<P>for me ever to have thought of him.&nbsp; And, and--we think



<P>very differently of the nature of women, if they can imagine



<P>a woman so very soon capable of returning an affection



<P>as this seems to imply."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear, dear Fanny, now I have the truth.&nbsp; I know this



<P>to be the truth; and most worthy of you are such feelings.



<P>I had attributed them to you before.&nbsp; I thought I could



<P>understand you.&nbsp; You have now given exactly the explanation



<P>which I ventured to make for you to your friend and Mrs. Grant,



<P>and they were both better satisfied, though your warm-hearted



<P>friend was still run away with a little by the enthusiasm



<P>of her fondness for Henry.&nbsp; I told them that you were



<P>of all human creatures the one over whom habit had most



<P>power and novelty least; and that the very circumstance



<P>of the novelty of Crawford's addresses was against him.



<P>Their being so new and so recent was all in their disfavour;



<P>that you could tolerate nothing that you were not used to;



<P>and a great deal more to the same purpose, to give them



<P>a knowledge of your character.&nbsp; Miss Crawford made us



<P>laugh by her plans of encouragement for her brother.



<P>She meant to urge him to persevere in the hope of being



<P>loved in time, and of having his addresses most kindly



<P>received at the end of about ten years' happy marriage."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny could with difficulty give the smile that was



<P>here asked for.&nbsp; Her feelings were all in revolt.



<P>She feared she had been doing wrong:&nbsp; saying too much,



<P>overacting the caution which she had been fancying necessary;



<P>in guarding against one evil, laying herself open



<P>to another; and to have Miss Crawford's liveliness



<P>repeated to her at such a moment, and on such a subject,



<P>was a bitter aggravation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund saw weariness and distress in her face,



<P>and immediately resolved to forbear all farther discussion;



<P>and not even to mention the name of Crawford again,



<P>except as it might be connected with what _must_ be agreeable



<P>to her.&nbsp; On this principle, he soon afterwards observed--



<P>"They go on Monday.&nbsp; You are sure, therefore, of seeing



<P>your friend either to-morrow or Sunday.&nbsp; They really go



<P>on Monday; and I was within a trifle of being persuaded



<P>to stay at Lessingby till that very day!&nbsp; I had almost



<P>promised it.&nbsp; What a difference it might have made!



<P>Those five or six days more at Lessingby might have been



<P>felt all my life."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You were near staying there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very.&nbsp; I was most kindly pressed, and had nearly consented.



<P>Had I received any letter from Mansfield, to tell me how you



<P>were all going on, I believe I should certainly have staid;



<P>but I knew nothing that had happened here for a fortnight,



<P>and felt that I had been away long enough."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You spent your time pleasantly there?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes; that is, it was the fault of my own mind if I did not.



<P>They were all very pleasant.&nbsp; I doubt their finding me so.



<P>I took uneasiness with me, and there was no getting rid



<P>of it till I was in Mansfield again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The Miss Owens--you liked them, did not you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, very well.&nbsp; Pleasant, good-humoured, unaffected girls.



<P>But I am spoilt, Fanny, for common female society.



<P>Good-humoured, unaffected girls will not do for a man



<P>who has been used to sensible women.&nbsp; They are two distinct



<P>orders of being.&nbsp; You and Miss Crawford have made me



<P>too nice."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Still, however, Fanny was oppressed and wearied;



<P>he saw it in her looks, it could not be talked away;



<P>and attempting it no more, he led her directly, with the



<P>kind authority of a privileged guardian, into the house.



<P>

   <TITLE>Chapter 21</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Sir Thomas's return made a striking change in the ways of



<P>the family, independent of Lovers' Vows.&nbsp; Under his government,



<P>Mansfield was an altered place.&nbsp; Some members of their



<P>society sent away, and the spirits of many others saddened--



<P>it was all sameness and gloom compared with the past--



<P>a sombre family party rarely enlivened.&nbsp; There was little



<P>intercourse with the Parsonage.&nbsp; Sir Thomas, drawing back



<P>from intimacies in general, was particularly disinclined,



<P>at this time, for any engagements but in one quarter.



<P>The Rushworths were the only addition to his own domestic



<P>circle which he could solicit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund did not wonder that such should be his father's feelings,



<P>nor could he regret anything but the exclusion of the Grants.



<P>"But they," he observed to Fanny, "have a claim.&nbsp; They seem



<P>to belong to us; they seem to be part of ourselves.



<P>I could wish my father were more sensible of their very



<P>great attention to my mother and sisters while he was away.



<P>I am afraid they may feel themselves neglected.



<P>But the truth is, that my father hardly knows them.



<P>They had not been here a twelvemonth when he left England.



<P>If he knew them better, he would value their society



<P>as it deserves; for they are in fact exactly the sort



<P>of people he would like.&nbsp; We are sometimes a little



<P>in want of animation among ourselves:&nbsp; my sisters seem



<P>out of spirits, and Tom is certainly not at his ease.



<P>Dr. and Mrs. Grant would enliven us, and make our evenings



<P>pass away with more enjoyment even to my father."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Do you think so?" said Fanny:&nbsp; "in my opinion,



<P>my uncle would not like _any_ addition.&nbsp; I think he



<P>values the very quietness you speak of, and that the



<P>repose of his own family circle is all he wants.



<P>And it does not appear to me that we are more serious



<P>than we used to be--I mean before my uncle went abroad.



<P>As well as I can recollect, it was always much the same.



<P>There was never much laughing in his presence; or,



<P>if there is any difference, it is not more, I think,



<P>than such an absence has a tendency to produce at first.



<P>There must be a sort of shyness; but I cannot recollect



<P>that our evenings formerly were ever merry, except when



<P>my uncle was in town.&nbsp; No young people's are, I suppose,



<P>when those they look up to are at home".

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I believe you are right, Fanny," was his reply, after a



<P>short consideration.&nbsp; "I believe our evenings are rather



<P>returned to what they were, than assuming a new character.



<P>The novelty was in their being lively.&nbsp; Yet, how strong



<P>the impression that only a few weeks will give!



<P>I have been feeling as if we had never lived so before."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I suppose I am graver than other people," said Fanny.



<P>"The evenings do not appear long to me.&nbsp; I love to hear



<P>my uncle talk of the West Indies.&nbsp; I could listen to him



<P>for an hour together.&nbsp; It entertains _me_ more than many



<P>other things have done; but then I am unlike other people,



<P>I dare say."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Why should you dare say _that_?" (smiling). "Do you



<P>want to be told that you are only unlike other people



<P>in being more wise and discreet?&nbsp; But when did you,



<P>or anybody, ever get a compliment from me, Fanny?



<P>Go to my father if you want to be complimented.



<P>He will satisfy you.&nbsp; Ask your uncle what he thinks,



<P>and you will hear compliments enough:&nbsp; and though they



<P>may be chiefly on your person, you must put up with it,



<P>and trust to his seeing as much beauty of mind in time."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Such language was so new to Fanny that it quite embarrassed her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your uncle thinks you very pretty, dear Fanny--



<P>and that is the long and the short of the matter.



<P>Anybody but myself would have made something more of it,



<P>and anybody but you would resent that you had not been



<P>thought very pretty before; but the truth is, that your



<P>uncle never did admire you till now--and now he does.



<P>Your complexion is so improved!--and you have gained



<P>so much countenance!--and your figure--nay, Fanny, do not



<P>turn away about it--it is but an uncle.&nbsp; If you cannot



<P>bear an uncle's admiration, what is to become of you?



<P>You must really begin to harden yourself to the idea of



<P>being worth looking at.&nbsp; You must try not to mind growing



<P>up into a pretty woman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! don't talk so, don't talk so," cried Fanny,



<P>distressed by more feelings than he was aware of; but seeing



<P>that she was distressed, he had done with the subject,



<P>and only added more seriously--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Your uncle is disposed to be pleased with you in



<P>every respect; and I only wish you would talk to him more.



<P>You are one of those who are too silent in the evening circle."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I do talk to him more than I used.&nbsp; I am sure I do.



<P>Did not you hear me ask him about the slave-trade



<P>last night?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I did--and was in hopes the question would be followed



<P>up by others.&nbsp; It would have pleased your uncle to be



<P>inquired of farther."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I longed to do it--but there was such a dead silence!



<P>And while my cousins were sitting by without speaking a word,



<P>or seeming at all interested in the subject, I did not like--



<P>I thought it would appear as if I wanted to set myself



<P>off at their expense, by shewing a curiosity and pleasure



<P>in his information which he must wish his own daughters



<P>to feel."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Miss Crawford was very right in what she said of you



<P>the other day:&nbsp; that you seemed almost as fearful of notice



<P>and praise as other women were of neglect.&nbsp; We were talking



<P>of you at the Parsonage, and those were her words.



<P>She has great discernment.&nbsp; I know nobody who distinguishes



<P>characters better.&nbsp; For so young a woman it is remarkable!



<P>She certainly understands _you_ better than you are



<P>understood by the greater part of those who have known you



<P>so long; and with regard to some others, I can perceive,



<P>from occasional lively hints, the unguarded expressions



<P>of the moment, that she could define _many_ as accurately,



<P>did not delicacy forbid it.&nbsp; I wonder what she thinks



<P>of my father!&nbsp; She must admire him as a fine-looking man,



<P>with most gentlemanlike, dignified, consistent manners;



<P>but perhaps, having seen him so seldom, his reserve



<P>may be a little repulsive.&nbsp; Could they be much together,



<P>I feel sure of their liking each other.&nbsp; He would enjoy



<P>her liveliness and she has talents to value his powers.



<P>I wish they met more frequently!&nbsp; I hope she does not suppose



<P>there is any dislike on his side."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She must know herself too secure of the regard of all



<P>the rest of you," said Fanny, with half a sigh, "to have



<P>any such apprehension.&nbsp; And Sir Thomas's wishing just at



<P>first to be only with his family, is so very natural,



<P>that she can argue nothing from that.&nbsp; After a little while,



<P>I dare say, we shall be meeting again in the same sort



<P>of way, allowing for the difference of the time of year."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is the first October that she has passed in the country



<P>since her infancy.&nbsp; I do not call Tunbridge or Cheltenham



<P>the country; and November is a still more serious month,



<P>and I can see that Mrs. Grant is very anxious for her



<P>not finding Mansfield dull as winter comes on."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny could have said a great deal, but it was safer to



<P>say nothing, and leave untouched all Miss Crawford's resources--



<P>her accomplishments, her spirits, her importance,



<P>her friends, lest it should betray her into any observations



<P>seemingly unhandsome.&nbsp; Miss Crawford's kind opinion



<P>of herself deserved at least a grateful forbearance,



<P>and she began to talk of something else.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To-morrow, I think, my uncle dines at Sotherton, and you



<P>and Mr. Bertram too.&nbsp; We shall be quite a small party at home.



<P>I hope my uncle may continue to like Mr. Rushworth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That is impossible, Fanny.&nbsp; He must like him less



<P>after to-morrow's visit, for we shall be five hours



<P>in his company.&nbsp; I should dread the stupidity of the day,



<P>if there were not a much greater evil to follow--



<P>the impression it must leave on Sir Thomas.&nbsp; He cannot much



<P>longer deceive himself.&nbsp; I am sorry for them all, and would



<P>give something that Rushworth and Maria had never met."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In this quarter, indeed, disappointment was impending



<P>over Sir Thomas.&nbsp; Not all his good-will for Mr. Rushworth,



<P>not all Mr. Rushworth's deference for him, could prevent



<P>him from soon discerning some part of the truth--



<P>that Mr. Rushworth was an inferior young man, as ignorant



<P>in business as in books, with opinions in general unfixed,



<P>and without seeming much aware of it himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had expected a very different son-in-law; and beginning



<P>to feel grave on Maria's account, tried to understand



<P>_her_ feelings.&nbsp; Little observation there was necessary



<P>to tell him that indifference was the most favourable



<P>state they could be in.&nbsp; Her behaviour to Mr. Rushworth



<P>was careless and cold.&nbsp; She could not, did not like him.



<P>Sir Thomas resolved to speak seriously to her.



<P>Advantageous as would be the alliance, and long standing



<P>and public as was the engagement, her happiness must not be



<P>sacrificed to it.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth had, perhaps, been accepted



<P>on too short an acquaintance, and, on knowing him better,



<P>she was repenting.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With solemn kindness Sir Thomas addressed her:&nbsp; told her



<P>his fears, inquired into her wishes, entreated her to be



<P>open and sincere, and assured her that every inconvenience



<P>should be braved, and the connexion entirely given up,



<P>if she felt herself unhappy in the prospect of it.



<P>He would act for her and release her.&nbsp; Maria had a moment's



<P>struggle as she listened, and only a moment's: when her



<P>father ceased, she was able to give her answer immediately,



<P>decidedly, and with no apparent agitation.&nbsp; She thanked



<P>him for his great attention, his paternal kindness, but he



<P>was quite mistaken in supposing she had the smallest desire



<P>of breaking through her engagement, or was sensible of any



<P>change of opinion or inclination since her forming it.



<P>She had the highest esteem for Mr. Rushworth's character



<P>and disposition, and could not have a doubt of her happiness with



<P>him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas was satisfied; too glad to be satisfied,



<P>perhaps, to urge the matter quite so far as his judgment



<P>might have dictated to others.&nbsp; It was an alliance which



<P>he could not have relinquished without pain; and thus



<P>he reasoned.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth was young enough to improve.



<P>Mr. Rushworth must and would improve in good society;



<P>and if Maria could now speak so securely of her happiness



<P>with him, speaking certainly without the prejudice,



<P>the blindness of love, she ought to be believed.



<P>Her feelings, probably, were not acute; he had never



<P>supposed them to be so; but her comforts might not



<P>be less on that account; and if she could dispense



<P>with seeing her husband a leading, shining character,



<P>there would certainly be everything else in her favour.



<P>A well-disposed young woman, who did not marry for love,



<P>was in general but the more attached to her own family;



<P>and the nearness of Sotherton to Mansfield must naturally hold



<P>out the greatest temptation, and would, in all probability,



<P>be a continual supply of the most amiable and innocent enjoyments.



<P>Such and such-like were the reasonings of Sir Thomas,



<P>happy to escape the embarrassing evils of a rupture,



<P>the wonder, the reflections, the reproach that must



<P>attend it; happy to secure a marriage which would bring



<P>him such an addition of respectability and influence,



<P>and very happy to think anything of his daughter's



<P>disposition that was most favourable for the purpose.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To her the conference closed as satisfactorily as to him.



<P>She was in a state of mind to be glad that she had secured



<P>her fate beyond recall:&nbsp; that she had pledged herself



<P>anew to Sotherton; that she was safe from the possibility



<P>of giving Crawford the triumph of governing her actions,



<P>and destroying her prospects; and retired in proud resolve,



<P>determined only to behave more cautiously to Mr. Rushworth



<P>in future, that her father might not be again suspecting her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Had Sir Thomas applied to his daughter within the first



<P>three or four days after Henry Crawford's leaving Mansfield,



<P>before her feelings were at all tranquillised, before she



<P>had given up every hope of him, or absolutely resolved on



<P>enduring his rival, her answer might have been different;



<P>but after another three or four days, when there was no return,



<P>no letter, no message, no symptom of a softened heart,



<P>no hope of advantage from separation, her mind became



<P>cool enough to seek all the comfort that pride and self



<P>revenge could give.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Henry Crawford had destroyed her happiness, but he



<P>should not know that he had done it; he should not



<P>destroy her credit, her appearance, her prosperity, too.



<P>He should not have to think of her as pining in the



<P>retirement of Mansfield for _him_, rejecting Sotherton



<P>and London, independence and splendour, for _his_ sake.



<P>Independence was more needful than ever; the want of it



<P>at Mansfield more sensibly felt.&nbsp; She was less and less



<P>able to endure the restraint which her father imposed.



<P>The liberty which his absence had given was now become



<P>absolutely necessary.&nbsp; She must escape from him and Mansfield



<P>as soon as possible, and find consolation in fortune



<P>and consequence, bustle and the world, for a wounded spirit.



<P>Her mind was quite determined, and varied not.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To such feelings delay, even the delay of much preparation,



<P>would have been an evil, and Mr. Rushworth could hardly



<P>be more impatient for the marriage than herself.



<P>In all the important preparations of the mind she



<P>was complete:&nbsp; being prepared for matrimony by an hatred



<P>of home, restraint, and tranquillity; by the misery



<P>of disappointed affection, and contempt of the man she



<P>was to marry.&nbsp; The rest might wait.&nbsp; The preparations



<P>of new carriages and furniture might wait for London



<P>and spring, when her own taste could have fairer play.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The principals being all agreed in this respect, it soon



<P>appeared that a very few weeks would be sufficient



<P>for such arrangements as must precede the wedding.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Rushworth was quite ready to retire, and make way for



<P>the fortunate young woman whom her dear son had selected;



<P>and very early in November removed herself, her maid,



<P>her footman, and her chariot, with true dowager propriety,



<P>to Bath, there to parade over the wonders of Sotherton



<P>in her evening parties; enjoying them as thoroughly,



<P>perhaps, in the animation of a card-table, as she had



<P>ever done on the spot; and before the middle of the same



<P>month the ceremony had taken place which gave Sotherton



<P>another mistress.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a very proper wedding.&nbsp; The bride was elegantly dressed;



<P>the two bridesmaids were duly inferior; her father gave



<P>her away; her mother stood with salts in her hand,



<P>expecting to be agitated; her aunt tried to cry;



<P>and the service was impressively read by Dr. Grant.



<P>Nothing could be objected to when it came under the



<P>discussion of the neighbourhood, except that the carriage



<P>which conveyed the bride and bridegroom and Julia



<P>from the church-door to Sotherton was the same chaise



<P>which Mr. Rushworth had used for a twelvemonth before.



<P>In everything else the etiquette of the day might stand



<P>the strictest investigation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was done, and they were gone.&nbsp; Sir Thomas felt as an



<P>anxious father must feel, and was indeed experiencing much



<P>of the agitation which his wife had been apprehensive



<P>of for herself, but had fortunately escaped.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris,



<P>most happy to assist in the duties of the day,



<P>by spending it at the Park to support her sister's spirits,



<P>and drinking the health of Mr. and Mrs. Rushworth in



<P>a supernumerary glass or two, was all joyous delight;



<P>for she had made the match; she had done everything;



<P>and no one would have supposed, from her confident triumph,



<P>that she had ever heard of conjugal infelicity in her life,



<P>or could have the smallest insight into the disposition



<P>of the niece who had been brought up under her eye.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The plan of the young couple was to proceed,



<P>after a few days, to Brighton, and take a house there



<P>for some weeks.&nbsp; Every public place was new to Maria,



<P>and Brighton is almost as gay in winter as in summer.



<P>When the novelty of amusement there was over, it would



<P>be time for the wider range of London.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Julia was to go with them to Brighton.&nbsp; Since rivalry



<P>between the sisters had ceased, they had been gradually



<P>recovering much of their former good understanding;



<P>and were at least sufficiently friends to make each of them



<P>exceedingly glad to be with the other at such a time.



<P>Some other companion than Mr. Rushworth was of the first



<P>consequence to his lady; and Julia was quite as eager



<P>for novelty and pleasure as Maria, though she might not



<P>have struggled through so much to obtain them, and could



<P>better bear a subordinate situation.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Their departure made another material change at Mansfield,



<P>a chasm which required some time to fill up.&nbsp; The family



<P>circle became greatly contracted; and though the Miss



<P>Bertrams had latterly added little to its gaiety,



<P>they could not but be missed.&nbsp; Even their mother missed them;



<P>and how much more their tenderhearted cousin, who wandered



<P>about the house, and thought of them, and felt for them,



<P>with a degree of affectionate regret which they had never



<P>done much to deserve!



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 19</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XIX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>How is the consternation of the party to be described?



<P>To the greater number it was a moment of absolute horror.



<P>Sir Thomas in the house!&nbsp; All felt the instantaneous conviction.



<P>Not a hope of imposition or mistake was harboured anywhere.



<P>Julia's looks were an evidence of the fact that made



<P>it indisputable; and after the first starts and exclamations,



<P>not a word was spoken for half a minute:&nbsp; each with



<P>an altered countenance was looking at some other,



<P>and almost each was feeling it a stroke the most unwelcome,



<P>most ill-timed, most appalling!&nbsp; Mr. Yates might consider



<P>it only as a vexatious interruption for the evening,



<P>and Mr. Rushworth might imagine it a blessing; but every



<P>other heart was sinking under some degree of self-condemnation



<P>or undefined alarm, every other heart was suggesting,



<P>"What will become of us? what is to be done now?"



<P>It was a terrible pause; and terrible to every ear were the



<P>corroborating sounds of opening doors and passing footsteps.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Julia was the first to move and speak again.&nbsp; Jealousy and



<P>bitterness had been suspended:&nbsp; selfishness was lost



<P>in the common cause; but at the moment of her appearance,



<P>Frederick was listening with looks of devotion to



<P>Agatha's narrative, and pressing her hand to his heart;



<P>and as soon as she could notice this, and see that,



<P>in spite of the shock of her words, he still kept his



<P>station and retained her sister's hand, her wounded



<P>heart swelled again with injury, and looking as red



<P>as she had been white before, she turned out of the room,



<P>saying, "_I_ need not be afraid of appearing before him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her going roused the rest; and at the same moment



<P>the two brothers stepped forward, feeling the necessity



<P>of doing something.&nbsp; A very few words between them



<P>were sufficient.&nbsp; The case admitted no difference



<P>of opinion:&nbsp; they must go to the drawing-room directly.



<P>Maria joined them with the same intent, just then the



<P>stoutest of the three; for the very circumstance which



<P>had driven Julia away was to her the sweetest support.



<P>Henry Crawford's retaining her hand at such a moment,



<P>a moment of such peculiar proof and importance,



<P>was worth ages of doubt and anxiety.&nbsp; She hailed it



<P>as an earnest of the most serious determination, and was



<P>equal even to encounter her father.&nbsp; They walked off,



<P>utterly heedless of Mr. Rushworth's repeated question of,



<P>"Shall I go too?&nbsp; Had not I better go too?&nbsp; Will not it



<P>be right for me to go too?" but they were no sooner



<P>through the door than Henry Crawford undertook to answer



<P>the anxious inquiry, and, encouraging him by all means



<P>to pay his respects to Sir Thomas without delay,



<P>sent him after the others with delighted haste.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was left with only the Crawfords and Mr. Yates.



<P>She had been quite overlooked by her cousins; and as her



<P>own opinion of her claims on Sir Thomas's affection



<P>was much too humble to give her any idea of classing



<P>herself with his children, she was glad to remain



<P>behind and gain a little breathing-time. Her agitation



<P>and alarm exceeded all that was endured by the rest,



<P>by the right of a disposition which not even innocence



<P>could keep from suffering.&nbsp; She was nearly fainting:



<P>all her former habitual dread of her uncle was returning,



<P>and with it compassion for him and for almost every one



<P>of the party on the development before him, with solicitude



<P>on Edmund's account indescribable.&nbsp; She had found a seat,



<P>where in excessive trembling she was enduring all these



<P>fearful thoughts, while the other three, no longer under



<P>any restraint, were giving vent to their feelings of vexation,



<P>lamenting over such an unlooked-for premature arrival



<P>as a most untoward event, and without mercy wishing



<P>poor Sir Thomas had been twice as long on his passage,



<P>or were still in Antigua.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The Crawfords were more warm on the subject than Mr. Yates,



<P>from better understanding the family, and judging more



<P>clearly of the mischief that must ensue.&nbsp; The ruin of



<P>the play was to them a certainty:&nbsp; they felt the total



<P>destruction of the scheme to be inevitably at hand;



<P>while Mr. Yates considered it only as a temporary interruption,



<P>a disaster for the evening, and could even suggest the



<P>possibility of the rehearsal being renewed after tea,



<P>when the bustle of receiving Sir Thomas were over,



<P>and he might be at leisure to be amused by it.



<P>The Crawfords laughed at the idea; and having soon



<P>agreed on the propriety of their walking quietly home



<P>and leaving the family to themselves, proposed Mr. Yates's



<P>accompanying them and spending the evening at the Parsonage.



<P>But Mr. Yates, having never been with those who thought much



<P>of parental claims, or family confidence, could not perceive



<P>that anything of the kind was necessary; and therefore,



<P>thanking them, said, "he preferred remaining where he was,



<P>that he might pay his respects to the old gentleman



<P>handsomely since he _was_ come; and besides, he did not



<P>think it would be fair by the others to have everybody run away."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was just beginning to collect herself,



<P>and to feel that if she staid longer behind it might



<P>seem disrespectful, when this point was settled, and being



<P>commissioned with the brother and sister's apology,



<P>saw them preparing to go as she quitted the room herself



<P>to perform the dreadful duty of appearing before her uncle.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Too soon did she find herself at the drawing-room door;



<P>and after pausing a moment for what she knew would not come,



<P>for a courage which the outside of no door had ever supplied



<P>to her, she turned the lock in desperation, and the lights



<P>of the drawing-room, and all the collected family,



<P>were before her.&nbsp; As she entered, her own name caught



<P>her ear.&nbsp; Sir Thomas was at that moment looking round him,



<P>and saying, "But where is Fanny?&nbsp; Why do not I see



<P>my little Fanny?"--and on perceiving her, came forward



<P>with a kindness which astonished and penetrated her,



<P>calling her his dear Fanny, kissing her affectionately,



<P>and observing with decided pleasure how much she was grown!



<P>Fanny knew not how to feel, nor where to look.&nbsp; She was



<P>quite oppressed.&nbsp; He had never been so kind, so _very_



<P>kind to her in his life.&nbsp; His manner seemed changed,



<P>his voice was quick from the agitation of joy; and all that



<P>had been awful in his dignity seemed lost in tenderness.



<P>He led her nearer the light and looked at her again--



<P>inquired particularly after her health, and then,



<P>correcting himself, observed that he need not inquire,



<P>for her appearance spoke sufficiently on that point.&nbsp; A fine



<P>blush having succeeded the previous paleness of her face,



<P>he was justified in his belief of her equal improvement



<P>in health and beauty.&nbsp; He inquired next after her family,



<P>especially William:&nbsp; and his kindness altogether was such



<P>as made her reproach herself for loving him so little,



<P>and thinking his return a misfortune; and when, on having



<P>courage to lift her eyes to his face, she saw that he



<P>was grown thinner, and had the burnt, fagged, worn look



<P>of fatigue and a hot climate, every tender feeling



<P>was increased, and she was miserable in considering



<P>how much unsuspected vexation was probably ready to burst



<P>on him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas was indeed the life of the party, who at



<P>his suggestion now seated themselves round the fire.



<P>He had the best right to be the talker; and the delight



<P>of his sensations in being again in his own house,



<P>in the centre of his family, after such a separation,



<P>made him communicative and chatty in a very unusual degree;



<P>and he was ready to give every information as to his voyage,



<P>and answer every question of his two sons almost before



<P>it was put.&nbsp; His business in Antigua had latterly been



<P>prosperously rapid, and he came directly from Liverpool,



<P>having had an opportunity of making his passage thither



<P>in a private vessel, instead of waiting for the packet;



<P>and all the little particulars of his proceedings and events,



<P>his arrivals and departures, were most promptly delivered,



<P>as he sat by Lady Bertram and looked with heartfelt



<P>satisfaction on the faces around him--interrupting himself



<P>more than once, however, to remark on his good fortune



<P>in finding them all at home--coming unexpectedly as he did--



<P>all collected together exactly as he could have wished,



<P>but dared not depend on.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth was not forgotten:



<P>a most friendly reception and warmth of hand-shaking



<P>had already met him, and with pointed attention he was



<P>now included in the objects most intimately connected



<P>with Mansfield.&nbsp; There was nothing disagreeable in



<P>Mr. Rushworth's appearance, and Sir Thomas was liking



<P>him already.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>By not one of the circle was he listened to with such unbroken,



<P>unalloyed enjoyment as by his wife, who was really



<P>extremely happy to see him, and whose feelings were



<P>so warmed by his sudden arrival as to place her nearer



<P>agitation than she had been for the last twenty years.



<P>She had been _almost_ fluttered for a few minutes,



<P>and still remained so sensibly animated as to put away



<P>her work, move Pug from her side, and give all her



<P>attention and all the rest of her sofa to her husband.



<P>She had no anxieties for anybody to cloud _her_ pleasure:



<P>her own time had been irreproachably spent during his absence:



<P>she had done a great deal of carpet-work, and made many



<P>yards of fringe; and she would have answered as freely



<P>for the good conduct and useful pursuits of all the young



<P>people as for her own.&nbsp; It was so agreeable to her to see



<P>him again, and hear him talk, to have her ear amused



<P>and her whole comprehension filled by his narratives,



<P>that she began particularly to feel how dreadfully she



<P>must have missed him, and how impossible it would have



<P>been for her to bear a lengthened absence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris was by no means to be compared in happiness



<P>to her sister.&nbsp; Not that _she_ was incommoded by many



<P>fears of Sir Thomas's disapprobation when the present



<P>state of his house should be known, for her judgment



<P>had been so blinded that, except by the instinctive



<P>caution with which she had whisked away Mr. Rushworth's



<P>pink satin cloak as her brother-in-law entered,



<P>she could hardly be said to shew any sign of alarm;



<P>but she was vexed by the _manner_ of his return.



<P>It had left her nothing to do.&nbsp; Instead of being sent



<P>for out of the room, and seeing him first, and having



<P>to spread the happy news through the house, Sir Thomas,



<P>with a very reasonable dependence, perhaps, on the nerves



<P>of his wife and children, had sought no confidant but



<P>the butler, and had been following him almost instantaneously



<P>into the drawing-room. Mrs. Norris felt herself defrauded



<P>of an office on which she had always depended, whether his



<P>arrival or his death were to be the thing unfolded;



<P>and was now trying to be in a bustle without having



<P>anything to bustle about, and labouring to be important



<P>where nothing was wanted but tranquillity and silence.



<P>Would Sir Thomas have consented to eat, she might have gone



<P>to the housekeeper with troublesome directions, and insulted



<P>the footmen with injunctions of despatch; but Sir Thomas



<P>resolutely declined all dinner:&nbsp; he would take nothing,



<P>nothing till tea came--he would rather wait for tea.



<P>Still Mrs. Norris was at intervals urging something different;



<P>and in the most interesting moment of his passage to England,



<P>when the alarm of a French privateer was at the height,



<P>she burst through his recital with the proposal of soup.



<P>"Sure, my dear Sir Thomas, a basin of soup would be



<P>a much better thing for you than tea.&nbsp; Do have a basin



<P>of soup."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas could not be provoked.&nbsp; "Still the same



<P>anxiety for everybody's comfort, my dear Mrs. Norris,"



<P>was his answer.&nbsp; "But indeed I would rather have nothing



<P>but tea."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, then, Lady Bertram, suppose you speak for



<P>tea directly; suppose you hurry Baddeley a little;



<P>he seems behindhand to-night." She carried this point,



<P>and Sir Thomas's narrative proceeded.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At length there was a pause.&nbsp; His immediate communications



<P>were exhausted, and it seemed enough to be looking joyfully



<P>around him, now at one, now at another of the beloved circle;



<P>but the pause was not long:&nbsp; in the elation of her



<P>spirits Lady Bertram became talkative, and what were



<P>the sensations of her children upon hearing her say,



<P>"How do you think the young people have been amusing



<P>themselves lately, Sir Thomas?&nbsp; They have been acting.



<P>We have been all alive with acting."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed! and what have you been acting?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! they'll tell you all about it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The _all_ will soon be told," cried Tom hastily,



<P>and with affected unconcern; "but it is not worth



<P>while to bore my father with it now.&nbsp; You will hear



<P>enough of it to-morrow, sir.&nbsp; We have just been trying,



<P>by way of doing something, and amusing my mother,



<P>just within the last week, to get up a few scenes,



<P>a mere trifle.&nbsp; We have had such incessant rains almost



<P>since October began, that we have been nearly confined



<P>to the house for days together.&nbsp; I have hardly taken out



<P>a gun since the 3rd.&nbsp; Tolerable sport the first three days,



<P>but there has been no attempting anything since.



<P>The first day I went over Mansfield Wood, and Edmund took



<P>the copses beyond Easton, and we brought home six brace



<P>between us, and might each have killed six times as many,



<P>but we respect your pheasants, sir, I assure you,



<P>as much as you could desire.&nbsp; I do not think you will find



<P>your woods by any means worse stocked than they were.



<P>_I_ never saw Mansfield Wood so full of pheasants in my



<P>life as this year.&nbsp; I hope you will take a day's sport



<P>there yourself, sir, soon."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>For the present the danger was over, and Fanny's sick



<P>feelings subsided; but when tea was soon afterwards



<P>brought in, and Sir Thomas, getting up, said that he found



<P>that he could not be any longer in the house without



<P>just looking into his own dear room, every agitation



<P>was returning.&nbsp; He was gone before anything had been



<P>said to prepare him for the change he must find there;



<P>and a pause of alarm followed his disappearance.



<P>Edmund was the first to speak--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Something must be done," said he.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is time to think of our visitors," said Maria,



<P>still feeling her hand pressed to Henry Crawford's heart,



<P>and caring little for anything else.&nbsp; "Where did you leave



<P>Miss Crawford, Fanny?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny told of their departure, and delivered their message.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then poor Yates is all alone," cried Tom.&nbsp; "I will go



<P>and fetch him.&nbsp; He will be no bad assistant when it



<P>all comes out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To the theatre he went, and reached it just in time to



<P>witness the first meeting of his father and his friend.



<P>Sir Thomas had been a good deal surprised to find candles



<P>burning in his room; and on casting his eye round it,



<P>to see other symptoms of recent habitation and a general



<P>air of confusion in the furniture.&nbsp; The removal of the



<P>bookcase from before the billiard-room door struck



<P>him especially, but he had scarcely more than time



<P>to feel astonished at all this, before there were sounds



<P>from the billiard-room to astonish him still farther.



<P>Some one was talking there in a very loud accent; he did



<P>not know the voice--more than talking--almost hallooing.



<P>He stepped to the door, rejoicing at that moment in having



<P>the means of immediate communication, and, opening it,



<P>found himself on the stage of a theatre, and opposed



<P>to a ranting young man, who appeared likely to knock him



<P>down backwards.&nbsp; At the very moment of Yates perceiving



<P>Sir Thomas, and giving perhaps the very best start he



<P>had ever given in the whole course of his rehearsals,



<P>Tom Bertram entered at the other end of the room;



<P>and never had he found greater difficulty in keeping



<P>his countenance.&nbsp; His father's looks of solemnity and



<P>amazement on this his first appearance on any stage,



<P>and the gradual metamorphosis of the impassioned Baron



<P>Wildenheim into the well-bred and easy Mr. Yates,



<P>making his bow and apology to Sir Thomas Bertram, was such



<P>an exhibition, such a piece of true acting, as he would



<P>not have lost upon any account.&nbsp; It would be the last--



<P>in all probability--the last scene on that stage; but he



<P>was sure there could not be a finer.&nbsp; The house would



<P>close with the greatest eclat.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was little time, however, for the indulgence



<P>of any images of merriment.&nbsp; It was necessary for him



<P>to step forward, too, and assist the introduction,



<P>and with many awkward sensations he did his best.



<P>Sir Thomas received Mr. Yates with all the appearance



<P>of cordiality which was due to his own character,



<P>but was really as far from pleased with the necessity of



<P>the acquaintance as with the manner of its commencement.



<P>Mr. Yates's family and connexions were sufficiently known



<P>to him to render his introduction as the "particular friend,"



<P>another of the hundred particular friends of his son,



<P>exceedingly unwelcome; and it needed all the felicity of being



<P>again at home, and all the forbearance it could supply,



<P>to save Sir Thomas from anger on finding himself thus



<P>bewildered in his own house, making part of a ridiculous



<P>exhibition in the midst of theatrical nonsense, and forced



<P>in so untoward a moment to admit the acquaintance of a young



<P>man whom he felt sure of disapproving, and whose easy



<P>indifference and volubility in the course of the first



<P>five minutes seemed to mark him the most at home of the two.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tom understood his father's thoughts, and heartily



<P>wishing he might be always as well disposed to give them



<P>but partial expression, began to see, more clearly than



<P>he had ever done before, that there might be some ground



<P>of offence, that there might be some reason for the glance



<P>his father gave towards the ceiling and stucco of the room;



<P>and that when he inquired with mild gravity after the fate



<P>of the billiard-table, he was not proceeding beyond



<P>a very allowable curiosity.&nbsp; A few minutes were enough



<P>for such unsatisfactory sensations on each side; and Sir



<P>Thomas having exerted himself so far as to speak a few



<P>words of calm approbation in reply to an eager appeal



<P>of Mr. Yates, as to the happiness of the arrangement,



<P>the three gentlemen returned to the drawing-room together,



<P>Sir Thomas with an increase of gravity which was not



<P>lost on all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I come from your theatre," said he composedly, as he



<P>sat down; "I found myself in it rather unexpectedly.



<P>Its vicinity to my own room--but in every respect, indeed,



<P>it took me by surprise, as I had not the smallest suspicion



<P>of your acting having assumed so serious a character.



<P>It appears a neat job, however, as far as I could judge



<P>by candlelight, and does my friend Christopher Jackson credit."



<P>And then he would have changed the subject, and sipped



<P>his coffee in peace over domestic matters of a calmer hue;



<P>but Mr. Yates, without discernment to catch Sir Thomas's meaning,



<P>or diffidence, or delicacy, or discretion enough to allow



<P>him to lead the discourse while he mingled among the others



<P>with the least obtrusiveness himself, would keep him on



<P>the topic of the theatre, would torment him with questions



<P>and remarks relative to it, and finally would make him hear



<P>the whole history of his disappointment at Ecclesford.



<P>Sir Thomas listened most politely, but found much to



<P>offend his ideas of decorum, and confirm his ill-opinion



<P>of Mr. Yates's habits of thinking, from the beginning



<P>to the end of the story; and when it was over, could give



<P>him no other assurance of sympathy than what a slight bow conveyed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This was, in fact, the origin of _our_ acting," said Tom,



<P>after a moment's thought.&nbsp; "My friend Yates brought the



<P>infection from Ecclesford, and it spread--as those things



<P>always spread, you know, sir--the faster, probably,



<P>from _your_ having so often encouraged the sort of thing



<P>in us formerly.&nbsp; It was like treading old ground again."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Yates took the subject from his friend as soon as possible,



<P>and immediately gave Sir Thomas an account of what they



<P>had done and were doing:&nbsp; told him of the gradual



<P>increase of their views, the happy conclusion of their



<P>first difficulties, and present promising state of affairs;



<P>relating everything with so blind an interest as made him



<P>not only totally unconscious of the uneasy movements of many



<P>of his friends as they sat, the change of countenance,



<P>the fidget, the hem! of unquietness, but prevented him



<P>even from seeing the expression of the face on which his



<P>own eyes were fixed--from seeing Sir Thomas's dark brow



<P>contract as he looked with inquiring earnestness at his



<P>daughters and Edmund, dwelling particularly on the latter,



<P>and speaking a language, a remonstrance, a reproof,



<P>which _he_ felt at his heart.&nbsp; Not less acutely was it



<P>felt by Fanny, who had edged back her chair behind her



<P>aunt's end of the sofa, and, screened from notice herself,



<P>saw all that was passing before her.&nbsp; Such a look



<P>of reproach at Edmund from his father she could never



<P>have expected to witness; and to feel that it was in any



<P>degree deserved was an aggravation indeed.&nbsp; Sir Thomas's



<P>look implied, "On your judgment, Edmund, I depended;



<P>what have you been about?"&nbsp; She knelt in spirit to her uncle,



<P>and her bosom swelled to utter, "Oh, not to _him_!



<P>Look so to all the others, but not to _him_!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Yates was still talking.&nbsp; "To own the truth, Sir Thomas,



<P>we were in the middle of a rehearsal when you arrived



<P>this evening.&nbsp; We were going through the three first acts,



<P>and not unsuccessfully upon the whole.&nbsp; Our company is



<P>now so dispersed, from the Crawfords being gone home,



<P>that nothing more can be done to-night; but if you will



<P>give us the honour of your company to-morrow evening,



<P>I should not be afraid of the result.&nbsp; We bespeak



<P>your indulgence, you understand, as young performers;



<P>we bespeak your indulgence."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My indulgence shall be given, sir," replied Sir



<P>Thomas gravely, "but without any other rehearsal."



<P>And with a relenting smile, he added, "I come home



<P>to be happy and indulgent."&nbsp; Then turning away towards



<P>any or all of the rest, he tranquilly said, "Mr. and Miss



<P>Crawford were mentioned in my last letters from Mansfield.



<P>Do you find them agreeable acquaintance?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Tom was the only one at all ready with an answer, but he



<P>being entirely without particular regard for either,



<P>without jealousy either in love or acting, could speak



<P>very handsomely of both.&nbsp; "Mr. Crawford was a most pleasant,



<P>gentleman-like man; his sister a sweet, pretty, elegant,



<P>lively girl."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Rushworth could be silent no longer.&nbsp; "I do not say



<P>he is not gentleman-like, considering; but you should



<P>tell your father he is not above five feet eight,



<P>or he will be expecting a well-looking man."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas did not quite understand this, and looked



<P>with some surprise at the speaker.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I must say what I think," continued Mr. Rushworth, "in my



<P>opinion it is very disagreeable to be always rehearsing.



<P>It is having too much of a good thing.&nbsp; I am not so fond



<P>of acting as I was at first.&nbsp; I think we are a great deal



<P>better employed, sitting comfortably here among ourselves,



<P>and doing nothing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas looked again, and then replied with an approving



<P>smile, "I am happy to find our sentiments on this subject



<P>so much the same.&nbsp; It gives me sincere satisfaction.



<P>That I should be cautious and quick-sighted, and feel many



<P>scruples which my children do _not_ feel, is perfectly natural;



<P>and equally so that my value for domestic tranquillity,



<P>for a home which shuts out noisy pleasures, should much



<P>exceed theirs.&nbsp; But at your time of life to feel all this,



<P>is a most favourable circumstance for yourself,



<P>and for everybody connected with you; and I am sensible



<P>of the importance of having an ally of such weight."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas meant to be giving Mr. Rushworth's opinion



<P>in better words than he could find himself.&nbsp; He was



<P>aware that he must not expect a genius in Mr. Rushworth;



<P>but as a well-judging, steady young man, with better notions



<P>than his elocution would do justice to, he intended to value



<P>him very highly.&nbsp; It was impossible for many of the others



<P>not to smile.&nbsp; Mr. Rushworth hardly knew what to do



<P>with so much meaning; but by looking, as he really felt,



<P>most exceedingly pleased with Sir Thomas's good opinion,



<P>and saying scarcely anything, he did his best towards



<P>preserving that good opinion a little longer.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 25</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The intercourse of the two families was at this period



<P>more nearly restored to what it had been in the autumn,



<P>than any member of the old intimacy had thought ever



<P>likely to be again.&nbsp; The return of Henry Crawford,



<P>and the arrival of William Price, had much to do with it,



<P>but much was still owing to Sir Thomas's more than toleration



<P>of the neighbourly attempts at the Parsonage.&nbsp; His mind,



<P>now disengaged from the cares which had pressed on him



<P>at first, was at leisure to find the Grants and their



<P>young inmates really worth visiting; and though infinitely



<P>above scheming or contriving for any the most advantageous



<P>matrimonial establishment that could be among the apparent



<P>possibilities of any one most dear to him, and disdaining



<P>even as a littleness the being quick-sighted on such points,



<P>he could not avoid perceiving, in a grand and careless way,



<P>that Mr. Crawford was somewhat distinguishing his niece--



<P>nor perhaps refrain (though unconsciously) from giving a



<P>more willing assent to invitations on that account.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>His readiness, however, in agreeing to dine at the Parsonage,



<P>when the general invitation was at last hazarded,



<P>after many debates and many doubts as to whether it were



<P>worth while, "because Sir Thomas seemed so ill inclined,



<P>and Lady Bertram was so indolent!" proceeded from



<P>good-breeding and goodwill alone, and had nothing to do



<P>with Mr. Crawford, but as being one in an agreeable group:



<P>for it was in the course of that very visit that he first



<P>began to think that any one in the habit of such idle



<P>observations _would_ _have_ _thought_ that Mr. Crawford



<P>was the admirer of Fanny Price.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The meeting was generally felt to be a pleasant one,



<P>being composed in a good proportion of those who would talk



<P>and those who would listen; and the dinner itself was elegant



<P>and plentiful, according to the usual style of the Grants,



<P>and too much according to the usual habits of all to raise



<P>any emotion except in Mrs. Norris, who could never behold



<P>either the wide table or the number of dishes on it



<P>with patience, and who did always contrive to experience



<P>some evil from the passing of the servants behind her chair,



<P>and to bring away some fresh conviction of its being



<P>impossible among so many dishes but that some must be cold.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In the evening it was found, according to the predetermination



<P>of Mrs. Grant and her sister, that after making up



<P>the whist-table there would remain sufficient for a



<P>round game, and everybody being as perfectly complying



<P>and without a choice as on such occasions they always are,



<P>speculation was decided on almost as soon as whist;



<P>and Lady Bertram soon found herself in the critical situation



<P>of being applied to for her own choice between the games,



<P>and being required either to draw a card for whist or not.



<P>She hesitated.&nbsp; Luckily Sir Thomas was at hand.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What shall I do, Sir Thomas?&nbsp; Whist and speculation;



<P>which will amuse me most?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas, after a moment's thought, recommended speculation.



<P>He was a whist player himself, and perhaps might feel



<P>that it would not much amuse him to have her for a partner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very well," was her ladyship's contented answer;



<P>"then speculation, if you please, Mrs. Grant.&nbsp; I know



<P>nothing about it, but Fanny must teach me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here Fanny interposed, however, with anxious protestations



<P>of her own equal ignorance; she had never played the



<P>game nor seen it played in her life; and Lady Bertram



<P>felt a moment's indecision again; but upon everybody's



<P>assuring her that nothing could be so easy, that it



<P>was the easiest game on the cards, and Henry Crawford's



<P>stepping forward with a most earnest request to be allowed



<P>to sit between her ladyship and Miss Price, and teach



<P>them both, it was so settled; and Sir Thomas, Mrs. Norris,



<P>and Dr. and Mrs. Grant being seated at the table of prime



<P>intellectual state and dignity, the remaining six,



<P>under Miss Crawford's direction, were arranged round



<P>the other.&nbsp; It was a fine arrangement for Henry Crawford,



<P>who was close to Fanny, and with his hands full of business,



<P>having two persons' cards to manage as well as his own;



<P>for though it was impossible for Fanny not to feel herself



<P>mistress of the rules of the game in three minutes,



<P>he had yet to inspirit her play, sharpen her avarice,



<P>and harden her heart, which, especially in any competition



<P>with William, was a work of some difficulty; and as for



<P>Lady Bertram, he must continue in charge of all her fame



<P>and fortune through the whole evening; and if quick enough



<P>to keep her from looking at her cards when the deal began,



<P>must direct her in whatever was to be done with them



<P>to the end of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was in high spirits, doing everything with happy ease,



<P>and preeminent in all the lively turns, quick resources,



<P>and playful impudence that could do honour to the game;



<P>and the round table was altogether a very comfortable



<P>contrast to the steady sobriety and orderly silence of



<P>the other.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Twice had Sir Thomas inquired into the enjoyment and



<P>success of his lady, but in vain; no pause was long enough



<P>for the time his measured manner needed; and very little



<P>of her state could be known till Mrs. Grant was able,



<P>at the end of the first rubber, to go to her and pay



<P>her compliments.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I hope your ladyship is pleased with the game."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh dear, yes! very entertaining indeed.&nbsp; A very odd game.



<P>I do not know what it is all about.&nbsp; I am never to see



<P>my cards; and Mr. Crawford does all the rest."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Bertram," said Crawford, some time afterwards, taking the



<P>opportunity of a little languor in the game, "I have never



<P>told you what happened to me yesterday in my ride home."



<P>They had been hunting together, and were in the midst of a



<P>good run, and at some distance from Mansfield, when his horse



<P>being found to have flung a shoe, Henry Crawford had been



<P>obliged to give up, and make the best of his way back.



<P>"I told you I lost my way after passing that old farmhouse



<P>with the yew-trees, because I can never bear to ask;



<P>but I have not told you that, with my usual luck--for I



<P>never do wrong without gaining by it--I found myself in due



<P>time in the very place which I had a curiosity to see.



<P>I was suddenly, upon turning the corner of a steepish



<P>downy field, in the midst of a retired little village
