<P>between gently rising hills; a small stream before me to



<P>be forded, a church standing on a sort of knoll to my right--



<P>which church was strikingly large and handsome for



<P>the place, and not a gentleman or half a gentleman's house



<P>to be seen excepting one--to be presumed the Parsonage--



<P>within a stone's throw of the said knoll and church.



<P>I found myself, in short, in Thornton Lacey."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It sounds like it," said Edmund; "but which way did you



<P>turn after passing Sewell's farm?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I answer no such irrelevant and insidious questions;



<P>though were I to answer all that you could put in the course



<P>of an hour, you would never be able to prove that it



<P>was _not_ Thornton Lacey--for such it certainly was."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You inquired, then?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I never inquire.&nbsp; But I _told_ a man mending a hedge



<P>that it was Thornton Lacey, and he agreed to it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have a good memory.&nbsp; I had forgotten having ever



<P>told you half so much of the place."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Thornton Lacey was the name of his impending living,



<P>as Miss Crawford well knew; and her interest in a negotiation



<P>for William Price's knave increased.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well," continued Edmund, "and how did you like what



<P>you saw?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very much indeed.&nbsp; You are a lucky fellow.&nbsp; There will be



<P>work for five summers at least before the place is liveable."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no, not so bad as that.&nbsp; The farmyard must be moved,



<P>I grant you; but I am not aware of anything else.



<P>The house is by no means bad, and when the yard is removed,



<P>there may be a very tolerable approach to it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The farmyard must be cleared away entirely, and planted



<P>up to shut out the blacksmith's shop.&nbsp; The house must



<P>be turned to front the east instead of the north--



<P>the entrance and principal rooms, I mean, must be on



<P>that side, where the view is really very pretty; I am



<P>sure it may be done.&nbsp; And _there_ must be your approach,



<P>through what is at present the garden.&nbsp; You must make



<P>a new garden at what is now the back of the house;



<P>which will be giving it the best aspect in the world,



<P>sloping to the south-east. The ground seems precisely



<P>formed for it.&nbsp; I rode fifty yards up the lane,



<P>between the church and the house, in order to look about me;



<P>and saw how it might all be.&nbsp; Nothing can be easier.



<P>The meadows beyond what _will_ _be_ the garden, as well



<P>as what now _is_, sweeping round from the lane I stood



<P>in to the north-east, that is, to the principal road



<P>through the village, must be all laid together, of course;



<P>very pretty meadows they are, finely sprinkled with timber.



<P>They belong to the living, I suppose; if not, you must



<P>purchase them.&nbsp; Then the stream--something must be done



<P>with the stream; but I could not quite determine what.



<P>I had two or three ideas."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I have two or three ideas also," said Edmund,



<P>"and one of them is, that very little of your plan



<P>for Thornton Lacey will ever be put in practice.



<P>I must be satisfied with rather less ornament and beauty.



<P>I think the house and premises may be made comfortable,



<P>and given the air of a gentleman's residence, without any



<P>very heavy expense, and that must suffice me; and, I hope,



<P>may suffice all who care about me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford, a little suspicious and resentful of a



<P>certain tone of voice, and a certain half-look attending



<P>the last expression of his hope, made a hasty finish



<P>of her dealings with William Price; and securing his knave



<P>at an exorbitant rate, exclaimed, "There, I will stake



<P>my last like a woman of spirit.&nbsp; No cold prudence for me.



<P>I am not born to sit still and do nothing.&nbsp; If I lose



<P>the game, it shall not be from not striving for it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The game was hers, and only did not pay her for what



<P>she had given to secure it.&nbsp; Another deal proceeded,



<P>and Crawford began again about Thornton Lacey.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My plan may not be the best possible:&nbsp; I had not many



<P>minutes to form it in; but you must do a good deal.



<P>The place deserves it, and you will find yourself not



<P>satisfied with much less than it is capable of.&nbsp; (Excuse me,



<P>your ladyship must not see your cards.&nbsp; There, let them



<P>lie just before you.) The place deserves it, Bertram.



<P>You talk of giving it the air of a gentleman's residence.



<P>_That_ will be done by the removal of the farmyard;



<P>for, independent of that terrible nuisance, I never saw



<P>a house of the kind which had in itself so much the air



<P>of a gentleman's residence, so much the look of a something



<P>above a mere parsonage-house--above the expenditure of a few



<P>hundreds a year.&nbsp; It is not a scrambling collection of low



<P>single rooms, with as many roofs as windows; it is not



<P>cramped into the vulgar compactness of a square farmhouse:



<P>it is a solid, roomy, mansion-like looking house, such as one



<P>might suppose a respectable old country family had lived



<P>in from generation to generation, through two centuries



<P>at least, and were now spending from two to three thousand



<P>a year in."&nbsp; Miss Crawford listened, and Edmund agreed



<P>to this.&nbsp; "The air of a gentleman's residence, therefore,



<P>you cannot but give it, if you do anything.&nbsp; But it is



<P>capable of much more.&nbsp; (Let me see, Mary; Lady Bertram



<P>bids a dozen for that queen; no, no, a dozen is more



<P>than it is worth.&nbsp; Lady Bertram does not bid a dozen.



<P>She will have nothing to say to it.&nbsp; Go on, go on.)



<P>By some such improvements as I have suggested (I do not really



<P>require you to proceed upon my plan, though, by the bye,



<P>I doubt anybody's striking out a better) you may give it



<P>a higher character.&nbsp; You may raise it into a _place_.



<P>From being the mere gentleman's residence, it becomes,



<P>by judicious improvement, the residence of a man



<P>of education, taste, modern manners, good connexions.



<P>All this may be stamped on it; and that house receive



<P>such an air as to make its owner be set down as the great



<P>landholder of the parish by every creature travelling



<P>the road; especially as there is no real squire's house



<P>to dispute the point--a circumstance, between ourselves,



<P>to enhance the value of such a situation in point



<P>of privilege and independence beyond all calculation.



<P>_You_ think with me, I hope" (turning with a softened



<P>voice to Fanny). "Have you ever seen the place?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny gave a quick negative, and tried to hide her interest



<P>in the subject by an eager attention to her brother,



<P>who was driving as hard a bargain, and imposing on her



<P>as much as he could; but Crawford pursued with "No, no,



<P>you must not part with the queen.&nbsp; You have bought



<P>her too dearly, and your brother does not offer half



<P>her value.&nbsp; No, no, sir, hands off, hands off.&nbsp; Your sister



<P>does not part with the queen.&nbsp; She is quite determined.



<P>The game will be yours," turning to her again; "it will



<P>certainly be yours."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And Fanny had much rather it were William's," said Edmund,



<P>smiling at her.&nbsp; "Poor Fanny! not allowed to cheat herself



<P>as she wishes!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Mr. Bertram," said Miss Crawford, a few minutes afterwards,



<P>"you know Henry to be such a capital improver, that you



<P>cannot possibly engage in anything of the sort at Thornton



<P>Lacey without accepting his help.&nbsp; Only think how useful



<P>he was at Sotherton!&nbsp; Only think what grand things were



<P>produced there by our all going with him one hot day



<P>in August to drive about the grounds, and see his genius



<P>take fire.&nbsp; There we went, and there we came home again;



<P>and what was done there is not to be told!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's eyes were turned on Crawford for a moment



<P>with an expression more than grave--even reproachful;



<P>but on catching his, were instantly withdrawn.



<P>With something of consciousness he shook his head at



<P>his sister, and laughingly replied, "I cannot say there



<P>was much done at Sotherton; but it was a hot day, and we



<P>were all walking after each other, and bewildered."



<P>As soon as a general buzz gave him shelter, he added,



<P>in a low voice, directed solely at Fanny, "I should be



<P>sorry to have my powers of _planning_ judged of by the



<P>day at Sotherton.&nbsp; I see things very differently now.



<P>Do not think of me as I appeared then."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sotherton was a word to catch Mrs. Norris, and being



<P>just then in the happy leisure which followed securing



<P>the odd trick by Sir Thomas's capital play and her own



<P>against Dr. and Mrs. Grant's great hands, she called out,



<P>in high good-humour, "Sotherton!&nbsp; Yes, that is a place,



<P>indeed, and we had a charming day there.&nbsp; William, you are



<P>quite out of luck; but the next time you come, I hope dear



<P>Mr. and Mrs. Rushworth will be at home, and I am sure



<P>I can answer for your being kindly received by both.



<P>Your cousins are not of a sort to forget their relations,



<P>and Mr. Rushworth is a most amiable man.&nbsp; They are at



<P>Brighton now, you know; in one of the best houses there,



<P>as Mr. Rushworth's fine fortune gives them a right to be.



<P>I do not exactly know the distance, but when you get back



<P>to Portsmouth, if it is not very far off, you ought to go



<P>over and pay your respects to them; and I could send



<P>a little parcel by you that I want to get conveyed to



<P>your cousins."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should be very happy, aunt; but Brighton is almost



<P>by Beachey Head; and if I could get so far, I could



<P>not expect to be welcome in such a smart place as that--



<P>poor scrubby midshipman as I am."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris was beginning an eager assurance of the



<P>affability he might depend on, when she was stopped



<P>by Sir Thomas's saying with authority, "I do not advise



<P>your going to Brighton, William, as I trust you may soon



<P>have more convenient opportunities of meeting; but my



<P>daughters would be happy to see their cousins anywhere;



<P>and you will find Mr. Rushworth most sincerely disposed



<P>to regard all the connexions of our family as his own."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I would rather find him private secretary to the First



<P>Lord than anything else," was William's only answer,



<P>in an undervoice, not meant to reach far, and the



<P>subject dropped.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As yet Sir Thomas had seen nothing to remark in Mr. Crawford's



<P>behaviour; but when the whist-table broke up at the end



<P>of the second rubber, and leaving Dr. Grant and Mrs. Norris



<P>to dispute over their last play, he became a looker-on



<P>at the other, he found his niece the object of attentions,



<P>or rather of professions, of a somewhat pointed character.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Henry Crawford was in the first glow of another scheme



<P>about Thornton Lacey; and not being able to catch



<P>Edmund's ear, was detailing it to his fair neighbour



<P>with a look of considerable earnestness.&nbsp; His scheme



<P>was to rent the house himself the following winter,



<P>that he might have a home of his own in that neighbourhood;



<P>and it was not merely for the use of it in the hunting-season



<P>(as he was then telling her), though _that_ consideration



<P>had certainly some weight, feeling as he did that,



<P>in spite of all Dr. Grant's very great kindness, it was



<P>impossible for him and his horses to be accommodated



<P>where they now were without material inconvenience;



<P>but his attachment to that neighbourhood did not depend



<P>upon one amusement or one season of the year:&nbsp; he had set



<P>his heart upon having a something there that he could



<P>come to at any time, a little homestall at his command,



<P>where all the holidays of his year might be spent, and he



<P>might find himself continuing, improving, and _perfecting_



<P>that friendship and intimacy with the Mansfield Park



<P>family which was increasing in value to him every day.



<P>Sir Thomas heard and was not offended.&nbsp; There was no want



<P>of respect in the young man's address; and Fanny's reception



<P>of it was so proper and modest, so calm and uninviting,



<P>that he had nothing to censure in her.&nbsp; She said little,



<P>assented only here and there, and betrayed no inclination



<P>either of appropriating any part of the compliment to herself,



<P>or of strengthening his views in favour of Northamptonshire.



<P>Finding by whom he was observed, Henry Crawford addressed



<P>himself on the same subject to Sir Thomas, in a more



<P>everyday tone, but still with feeling.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I want to be your neighbour, Sir Thomas, as you have,



<P>perhaps, heard me telling Miss Price.&nbsp; May I hope



<P>for your acquiescence, and for your not influencing



<P>your son against such a tenant?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas, politely bowing, replied, "It is the only way,



<P>sir, in which I could _not_ wish you established as a



<P>permanent neighbour; but I hope, and believe, that Edmund will



<P>occupy his own house at Thornton Lacey.&nbsp; Edmund, am I saying too



<P>much?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund, on this appeal, had first to hear what was going on;



<P>but, on understanding the question, was at no loss for an answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Certainly, sir, I have no idea but of residence.



<P>But, Crawford, though I refuse you as a tenant,



<P>come to me as a friend.&nbsp; Consider the house as half



<P>your own every winter, and we will add to the stables



<P>on your own improved plan, and with all the improvements



<P>of your improved plan that may occur to you this spring."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"We shall be the losers," continued Sir Thomas.



<P>"His going, though only eight miles, will be an unwelcome



<P>contraction of our family circle; but I should have been



<P>deeply mortified if any son of mine could reconcile



<P>himself to doing less.&nbsp; It is perfectly natural that you



<P>should not have thought much on the subject, Mr. Crawford.



<P>But a parish has wants and claims which can be known



<P>only by a clergyman constantly resident, and which no



<P>proxy can be capable of satisfying to the same extent.



<P>Edmund might, in the common phrase, do the duty of Thornton,



<P>that is, he might read prayers and preach, without giving



<P>up Mansfield Park:&nbsp; he might ride over every Sunday, to a



<P>house nominally inhabited, and go through divine service;



<P>he might be the clergyman of Thornton Lacey every seventh day,



<P>for three or four hours, if that would content him.



<P>But it will not.&nbsp; He knows that human nature needs more



<P>lessons than a weekly sermon can convey; and that if he



<P>does not live among his parishioners, and prove himself,



<P>by constant attention, their well-wisher and friend, he does



<P>very little either for their good or his own."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Crawford bowed his acquiescence.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I repeat again," added Sir Thomas, "that Thornton Lacey



<P>is the only house in the neighbourhood in which I should



<P>_not_ be happy to wait on Mr. Crawford as occupier."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Crawford bowed his thanks.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sir Thomas," said Edmund, "undoubtedly understands



<P>the duty of a parish priest.&nbsp; We must hope his son



<P>may prove that _he_ knows it too."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Whatever effect Sir Thomas's little harangue might really



<P>produce on Mr. Crawford, it raised some awkward sensations



<P>in two of the others, two of his most attentive listeners--



<P>Miss Crawford and Fanny.&nbsp; One of whom, having never before



<P>understood that Thornton was so soon and so completely



<P>to be his home, was pondering with downcast eyes on what it



<P>would be _not_ to see Edmund every day; and the other,



<P>startled from the agreeable fancies she had been previously



<P>indulging on the strength of her brother's description,



<P>no longer able, in the picture she had been forming of a



<P>future Thornton, to shut out the church, sink the clergyman,



<P>and see only the respectable, elegant, modernised,



<P>and occasional residence of a man of independent fortune,



<P>was considering Sir Thomas, with decided ill-will,



<P>as the destroyer of all this, and suffering the more



<P>from that involuntary forbearance which his character



<P>and manner commanded, and from not daring to relieve



<P>herself by a single attempt at throwing ridicule on his cause.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>All the agreeable of _her_ speculation was over for that hour.



<P>It was time to have done with cards, if sermons prevailed;



<P>and she was glad to find it necessary to come to a conclusion,



<P>and be able to refresh her spirits by a change of place



<P>and neighbour.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The chief of the party were now collected irregularly



<P>round the fire, and waiting the final break-up. William



<P>and Fanny were the most detached.&nbsp; They remained



<P>together at the otherwise deserted card-table, talking



<P>very comfortably, and not thinking of the rest, till some



<P>of the rest began to think of them.&nbsp; Henry Crawford's



<P>chair was the first to be given a direction towards them,



<P>and he sat silently observing them for a few minutes;



<P>himself, in the meanwhile, observed by Sir Thomas,



<P>who was standing in chat with Dr. Grant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is the assembly night," said William.&nbsp; "If I were



<P>at Portsmouth I should be at it, perhaps."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you do not wish yourself at Portsmouth, William?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, Fanny, that I do not.&nbsp; I shall have enough of Portsmouth



<P>and of dancing too, when I cannot have you.&nbsp; And I do not



<P>know that there would be any good in going to the assembly,



<P>for I might not get a partner.&nbsp; The Portsmouth girls turn



<P>up their noses at anybody who has not a commission.



<P>One might as well be nothing as a midshipman.



<P>One _is_ nothing, indeed.&nbsp; You remember the Gregorys;



<P>they are grown up amazing fine girls, but they will hardly



<P>speak to _me_, because Lucy is courted by a lieutenant."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! shame, shame!&nbsp; But never mind it, William" (her own



<P>cheeks in a glow of indignation as she spoke). "It is not



<P>worth minding.&nbsp; It is no reflection on _you_; it is no



<P>more than what the greatest admirals have all experienced,



<P>more or less, in their time.&nbsp; You must think of that,



<P>you must try to make up your mind to it as one of the



<P>hardships which fall to every sailor's share, like bad



<P>weather and hard living, only with this advantage,



<P>that there will be an end to it, that there will come



<P>a time when you will have nothing of that sort to endure.



<P>When you are a lieutenant! only think, William, when you



<P>are a lieutenant, how little you will care for any nonsense



<P>of this kind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I begin to think I shall never be a lieutenant, Fanny.



<P>Everybody gets made but me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! my dear William, do not talk so; do not be so desponding.



<P>My uncle says nothing, but I am sure he will do everything



<P>in his power to get you made.&nbsp; He knows, as well as you do,



<P>of what consequence it is."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was checked by the sight of her uncle much nearer



<P>to them than she had any suspicion of, and each found



<P>it necessary to talk of something else.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Are you fond of dancing, Fanny?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, very; only I am soon tired."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I should like to go to a ball with you and see



<P>you dance.&nbsp; Have you never any balls at Northampton?



<P>I should like to see you dance, and I'd dance with you



<P>if you _would_, for nobody would know who I was here,



<P>and I should like to be your partner once more.



<P>We used to jump about together many a time, did not we?



<P>when the hand-organ was in the street?&nbsp; I am a pretty



<P>good dancer in my way, but I dare say you are a better."



<P>And turning to his uncle, who was now close to them,



<P>"Is not Fanny a very good dancer, sir?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, in dismay at such an unprecedented question,



<P>did not know which way to look, or how to be prepared



<P>for the answer.&nbsp; Some very grave reproof, or at least



<P>the coldest expression of indifference, must be coming



<P>to distress her brother, and sink her to the ground.



<P>But, on the contrary, it was no worse than, "I am sorry



<P>to say that I am unable to answer your question.



<P>I have never seen Fanny dance since she was a little girl;



<P>but I trust we shall both think she acquits herself like



<P>a gentlewoman when we do see her, which, perhaps, we may



<P>have an opportunity of doing ere long."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I have had the pleasure of seeing your sister dance,



<P>Mr. Price," said Henry Crawford, leaning forward,



<P>"and will engage to answer every inquiry which you can



<P>make on the subject, to your entire satisfaction.



<P>But I believe" (seeing Fanny looked distressed) "it must



<P>be at some other time.&nbsp; There is _one_ person in company



<P>who does not like to have Miss Price spoken of."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>True enough, he had once seen Fanny dance; and it was



<P>equally true that he would now have answered for her gliding



<P>about with quiet, light elegance, and in admirable time;



<P>but, in fact, he could not for the life of him recall



<P>what her dancing had been, and rather took it for granted



<P>that she had been present than remembered anything about her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He passed, however, for an admirer of her dancing;



<P>and Sir Thomas, by no means displeased, prolonged the



<P>conversation on dancing in general, and was so well



<P>engaged in describing the balls of Antigua, and listening



<P>to what his nephew could relate of the different modes



<P>of dancing which had fallen within his observation,



<P>that he had not heard his carriage announced, and was first



<P>called to the knowledge of it by the bustle of Mrs. Norris.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Come, Fanny, Fanny, what are you about?&nbsp; We are going.



<P>Do not you see your aunt is going?&nbsp; Quick, quick!&nbsp; I cannot



<P>bear to keep good old Wilcox waiting.&nbsp; You should always



<P>remember the coachman and horses.&nbsp; My dear Sir Thomas,



<P>we have settled it that the carriage should come back for you,



<P>and Edmund and William."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas could not dissent, as it had been his



<P>own arrangement, previously communicated to his wife



<P>and sister; but _that_ seemed forgotten by Mrs. Norris,



<P>who must fancy that she settled it all herself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's last feeling in the visit was disappointment:



<P>for the shawl which Edmund was quietly taking from the



<P>servant to bring and put round her shoulders was seized



<P>by Mr. Crawford's quicker hand, and she was obliged to be



<P>indebted to his more prominent attention.



<P>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <TITLE>Chapter 31</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXXI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Henry Crawford was at Mansfield Park again the next morning,



<P>and at an earlier hour than common visiting warrants.



<P>The two ladies were together in the breakfast-room, and,



<P>fortunately for him, Lady Bertram was on the very point



<P>of quitting it as he entered.&nbsp; She was almost at the door,



<P>and not chusing by any means to take so much trouble in vain,



<P>she still went on, after a civil reception, a short sentence



<P>about being waited for, and a "Let Sir Thomas know"



<P>to the servant.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Henry, overjoyed to have her go, bowed and watched her off,



<P>and without losing another moment, turned instantly to Fanny,



<P>and, taking out some letters, said, with a most animated look,



<P>"I must acknowledge myself infinitely obliged to any creature



<P>who gives me such an opportunity of seeing you alone:



<P>I have been wishing it more than you can have any idea.



<P>Knowing as I do what your feelings as a sister are, I could



<P>hardly have borne that any one in the house should share



<P>with you in the first knowledge of the news I now bring.



<P>He is made.&nbsp; Your brother is a lieutenant.&nbsp; I have



<P>the infinite satisfaction of congratulating you on your



<P>brother's promotion.&nbsp; Here are the letters which announce it,



<P>this moment come to hand.&nbsp; You will, perhaps, like to see them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny could not speak, but he did not want her to speak.



<P>To see the expression of her eyes, the change



<P>of her complexion, the progress of her feelings,



<P>their doubt, confusion, and felicity, was enough.



<P>She took the letters as he gave them.&nbsp; The first was



<P>from the Admiral to inform his nephew, in a few words,



<P>of his having succeeded in the object he had undertaken,



<P>the promotion of young Price, and enclosing two more,



<P>one from the Secretary of the First Lord to a friend,



<P>whom the Admiral had set to work in the business,



<P>the other from that friend to himself, by which it



<P>appeared that his lordship had the very great happiness



<P>of attending to the recommendation of Sir Charles;



<P>that Sir Charles was much delighted in having such an



<P>opportunity of proving his regard for Admiral Crawford,



<P>and that the circumstance of Mr. William Price's commission



<P>as Second Lieutenant of H.M. Sloop Thrush being made



<P>out was spreading general joy through a wide circle



<P>of great people.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While her hand was trembling under these letters,



<P>her eye running from one to the other, and her heart



<P>swelling with emotion, Crawford thus continued,



<P>with unfeigned eagerness, to express his interest in the event--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will not talk of my own happiness," said he, "great as



<P>it is, for I think only of yours.&nbsp; Compared with you,



<P>who has a right to be happy?&nbsp; I have almost grudged myself



<P>my own prior knowledge of what you ought to have known



<P>before all the world.&nbsp; I have not lost a moment, however.



<P>The post was late this morning, but there has not been



<P>since a moment's delay.&nbsp; How impatient, how anxious,



<P>how wild I have been on the subject, I will not attempt



<P>to describe; how severely mortified, how cruelly disappointed,



<P>in not having it finished while I was in London!



<P>I was kept there from day to day in the hope of it,



<P>for nothing less dear to me than such an object would



<P>have detained me half the time from Mansfield.



<P>But though my uncle entered into my wishes with all the



<P>warmth I could desire, and exerted himself immediately,



<P>there were difficulties from the absence of one friend,



<P>and the engagements of another, which at last I could no longer



<P>bear to stay the end of, and knowing in what good hands I



<P>left the cause, I came away on Monday, trusting that many



<P>posts would not pass before I should be followed by such



<P>very letters as these.&nbsp; My uncle, who is the very best man



<P>in the world, has exerted himself, as I knew he would,



<P>after seeing your brother.&nbsp; He was delighted with him.



<P>I would not allow myself yesterday to say how delighted,



<P>or to repeat half that the Admiral said in his praise.



<P>I deferred it all till his praise should be proved



<P>the praise of a friend, as this day _does_ prove it.



<P>_Now_ I may say that even I could not require William



<P>Price to excite a greater interest, or be followed



<P>by warmer wishes and higher commendation, than were most



<P>voluntarily bestowed by my uncle after the evening they had



<P>passed together."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Has this been all _your_ doing, then?" cried Fanny.



<P>"Good heaven! how very, very kind!&nbsp; Have you really--



<P>was it by _your_ desire?&nbsp; I beg your pardon, but I



<P>am bewildered.&nbsp; Did Admiral Crawford apply?&nbsp; How was it?



<P>I am stupefied."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Henry was most happy to make it more intelligible,



<P>by beginning at an earlier stage, and explaining very



<P>particularly what he had done.&nbsp; His last journey to London



<P>had been undertaken with no other view than that of



<P>introducing her brother in Hill Street, and prevailing



<P>on the Admiral to exert whatever interest he might



<P>have for getting him on.&nbsp; This had been his business.



<P>He had communicated it to no creature:&nbsp; he had not



<P>breathed a syllable of it even to Mary; while uncertain



<P>of the issue, he could not have borne any participation



<P>of his feelings, but this had been his business; and he



<P>spoke with such a glow of what his solicitude had been,



<P>and used such strong expressions, was so abounding



<P>in the _deepest_ _interest_, in _twofold_ _motives_,



<P>in _views_ _and_ _wishes_ _more_ _than_ _could_ _be_ _told_,



<P>that Fanny could not have remained insensible of his drift,



<P>had she been able to attend; but her heart was so full



<P>and her senses still so astonished, that she could listen



<P>but imperfectly even to what he told her of William,



<P>and saying only when he paused, "How kind! how very kind!



<P>Oh, Mr. Crawford, we are infinitely obliged to you!



<P>Dearest, dearest William!"&nbsp; She jumped up and moved in haste



<P>towards the door, crying out, "I will go to my uncle.



<P>My uncle ought to know it as soon as possible."&nbsp; But this



<P>could not be suffered.&nbsp; The opportunity was too fair,



<P>and his feelings too impatient.&nbsp; He was after her immediately.



<P>"She must not go, she must allow him five minutes longer,"



<P>and he took her hand and led her back to her seat,



<P>and was in the middle of his farther explanation,



<P>before she had suspected for what she was detained.



<P>When she did understand it, however, and found herself



<P>expected to believe that she had created sensations which



<P>his heart had never known before, and that everything



<P>he had done for William was to be placed to the account



<P>of his excessive and unequalled attachment to her,



<P>she was exceedingly distressed, and for some moments



<P>unable to speak.&nbsp; She considered it all as nonsense,



<P>as mere trifling and gallantry, which meant only to deceive



<P>for the hour; she could not but feel that it was treating



<P>her improperly and unworthily, and in such a way as she



<P>had not deserved; but it was like himself, and entirely



<P>of a piece with what she had seen before; and she would



<P>not allow herself to shew half the displeasure she felt,



<P>because he had been conferring an obligation, which no



<P>want of delicacy on his part could make a trifle to her.



<P>While her heart was still bounding with joy and gratitude



<P>on William's behalf, she could not be severely resentful



<P>of anything that injured only herself; and after having



<P>twice drawn back her hand, and twice attempted in vain



<P>to turn away from him, she got up, and said only,



<P>with much agitation, "Don't, Mr. Crawford, pray don't! I



<P>beg you would not.&nbsp; This is a sort of talking which is very



<P>unpleasant to me.&nbsp; I must go away.&nbsp; I cannot bear it."



<P>But he was still talking on, describing his affection,



<P>soliciting a return, and, finally, in words so plain



<P>as to bear but one meaning even to her, offering himself,



<P>hand, fortune, everything, to her acceptance.&nbsp; It was so;



<P>he had said it.&nbsp; Her astonishment and confusion increased;



<P>and though still not knowing how to suppose him serious,



<P>she could hardly stand.&nbsp; He pressed for an answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no, no!" she cried, hiding her face.&nbsp; "This is all nonsense.



<P>Do not distress me.&nbsp; I can hear no more of this.



<P>Your kindness to William makes me more obliged to you



<P>than words can express; but I do not want, I cannot bear,



<P>I must not listen to such--No, no, don't think of me.



<P>But you are _not_ thinking of me.&nbsp; I know it is all nothing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had burst away from him, and at that moment Sir Thomas



<P>was heard speaking to a servant in his way towards the room



<P>they were in.&nbsp; It was no time for farther assurances



<P>or entreaty, though to part with her at a moment when her



<P>modesty alone seemed, to his sanguine and preassured mind,



<P>to stand in the way of the happiness he sought, was a



<P>cruel necessity.&nbsp; She rushed out at an opposite door



<P>from the one her uncle was approaching, and was walking



<P>up and down the East room ill the utmost confusion



<P>of contrary feeling, before Sir Thomas's politeness



<P>or apologies were over, or he had reached the beginning



<P>of the joyful intelligence which his visitor came to communicate.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was feeling, thinking, trembling about everything;



<P>agitated, happy, miserable, infinitely obliged,



<P>absolutely angry.&nbsp; It was all beyond belief!



<P>He was inexcusable, incomprehensible!&nbsp; But such were



<P>his habits that he could do nothing without a mixture



<P>of evil.&nbsp; He had previously made her the happiest



<P>of human beings, and now he had insulted--she knew



<P>not what to say, how to class, or how to regard it.



<P>She would not have him be serious, and yet what could



<P>excuse the use of such words and offers, if they meant but to



<P>trifle?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But William was a lieutenant.&nbsp; _That_ was a fact beyond



<P>a doubt, and without an alloy.&nbsp; She would think of it



<P>for ever and forget all the rest.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford would



<P>certainly never address her so again:&nbsp; he must have



<P>seen how unwelcome it was to her; and in that case,



<P>how gratefully she could esteem him for his friendship



<P>to William!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She would not stir farther from the East room than



<P>the head of the great staircase, till she had satisfied



<P>herself of Mr. Crawford's having left the house;



<P>but when convinced of his being gone, she was eager to go



<P>down and be with her uncle, and have all the happiness



<P>of his joy as well as her own, and all the benefit



<P>of his information or his conjectures as to what would



<P>now be William's destination.&nbsp; Sir Thomas was as joyful



<P>as she could desire, and very kind and communicative;



<P>and she had so comfortable a talk with him about William



<P>as to make her feel as if nothing had occurred to vex her,



<P>till she found, towards the close, that Mr. Crawford



<P>was engaged to return and dine there that very day.



<P>This was a most unwelcome hearing, for though he might



<P>think nothing of what had passed, it would be quite



<P>distressing to her to see him again so soon.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She tried to get the better of it; tried very hard,



<P>as the dinner hour approached, to feel and appear as usual;



<P>but it was quite impossible for her not to look most shy



<P>and uncomfortable when their visitor entered the room.



<P>She could not have supposed it in the power of any concurrence



<P>of circumstances to give her so many painful sensations on



<P>the first day of hearing of William's promotion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Crawford was not only in the room--he was soon close



<P>to her.&nbsp; He had a note to deliver from his sister.



<P>Fanny could not look at him, but there was no consciousness



<P>of past folly in his voice.&nbsp; She opened her note immediately,



<P>glad to have anything to do, and happy, as she read it,



<P>to feel that the fidgetings of her aunt Norris, who was



<P>also to dine there, screened her a little from view.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Fanny,--for so I may now always call you,



<P>to the infinite relief of a tongue that has been stumbling



<P>at _Miss_ _Price_ for at least the last six weeks--



<P>I cannot let my brother go without sending you a few lines



<P>of general congratulation, and giving my most joyful consent



<P>and approval.&nbsp; Go on, my dear Fanny, and without fear;



<P>there can be no difficulties worth naming.&nbsp; I chuse to



<P>suppose that the assurance of my consent will be something;



<P>so you may smile upon him with your sweetest smiles



<P>this afternoon, and send him back to me even happier



<P>than he goes.--Yours affectionately, M. C."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>These were not expressions to do Fanny any good;



<P>for though she read in too much haste and confusion



<P>to form the clearest judgment of Miss Crawford's meaning,



<P>it was evident that she meant to compliment her on her



<P>brother's attachment, and even to _appear_ to believe



<P>it serious.&nbsp; She did not know what to do, or what to think.



<P>There was wretchedness in the idea of its being serious;



<P>there was perplexity and agitation every way.



<P>She was distressed whenever Mr. Crawford spoke to her,



<P>and he spoke to her much too often; and she was afraid



<P>there was a something in his voice and manner in addressing



<P>her very different from what they were when he talked



<P>to the others.&nbsp; Her comfort in that day's dinner



<P>was quite destroyed:&nbsp; she could hardly eat anything;



<P>and when Sir Thomas good-humouredly observed that joy had



<P>taken away her appetite, she was ready to sink with shame,



<P>from the dread of Mr. Crawford's interpretation;



<P>for though nothing could have tempted her to turn her eyes



<P>to the right hand, where he sat, she felt that _his_



<P>were immediately directed towards her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was more silent than ever.&nbsp; She would hardly join



<P>even when William was the subject, for his commission



<P>came all from the right hand too, and there was pain



<P>in the connexion.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She thought Lady Bertram sat longer than ever, and began



<P>to be in despair of ever getting away; but at last they



<P>were in the drawing-room, and she was able to think



<P>as she would, while her aunts finished the subject



<P>of William's appointment in their own style.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris seemed as much delighted with the saving



<P>it would be to Sir Thomas as with any part of it.



<P>"_Now_ William would be able to keep himself, which would



<P>make a vast difference to his uncle, for it was unknown



<P>how much he had cost his uncle; and, indeed, it would make



<P>some difference in _her_ presents too.&nbsp; She was very glad



<P>that she had given William what she did at parting,



<P>very glad, indeed, that it had been in her power,



<P>without material inconvenience, just at that time to give



<P>him something rather considerable; that is, for_her_,



<P>with _her_ limited means, for now it would all be useful



<P>in helping to fit up his cabin.&nbsp; She knew he must be at



<P>some expense, that he would have many things to buy,



<P>though to be sure his father and mother would be able



<P>to put him in the way of getting everything very cheap;



<P>but she was very glad she had contributed her mite



<P>towards it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am glad you gave him something considerable,"



<P>said Lady Bertram, with most unsuspicious calmness,



<P>"for _I_ gave him only 10."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed!" cried Mrs. Norris, reddening.&nbsp; "Upon my word,



<P>he must have gone off with his pockets 1 well lined,



<P>and at no expense for his journey to London either!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sir Thomas told me 10 would be enough."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris, being not at all inclined to question



<P>its sufficiency, began to take the matter in another point.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It is amazing," said she, "how much young people cost



<P>their friends, what with bringing them up and putting them



<P>out in the world!&nbsp; They little think how much it comes to,



<P>or what their parents, or their uncles and aunts, pay for



<P>them in the course of the year.&nbsp; Now, here are my sister



<P>Price's children; take them all together, I dare say nobody



<P>would believe what a sum they cost Sir Thomas every year,



<P>to say nothing of what _I_ do for them."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Very true, sister, as you say.&nbsp; But, poor things!



<P>they cannot help it; and you know it makes very little



<P>difference to Sir Thomas.&nbsp; Fanny, William must not forget



<P>my shawl if he goes to the East Indies; and I shall give



<P>him a commission for anything else that is worth having.



<P>I wish he may go to the East Indies, that I may have my shawl.



<P>I think I will have two shawls, Fanny."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, meanwhile, speaking only when she could not help it,



<P>was very earnestly trying to understand what Mr. and Miss



<P>Crawford were at.&nbsp; There was everything in the world



<P>_against_ their being serious but his words and manner.



<P>Everything natural, probable, reasonable, was against it;



<P>all their habits and ways of thinking, and all



<P>her own demerits.&nbsp; How could _she_ have excited



<P>serious attachment in a man who had seen so many,



<P>and been admired by so many, and flirted with so many,



<P>infinitely her superiors; who seemed so little open



<P>to serious impressions, even where pains had been taken



<P>to please him; who thought so slightly, so carelessly,



<P>so unfeelingly on all such points; who was everything



<P>to everybody, and seemed to find no one essential to him?



<P>And farther, how could it be supposed that his sister,



<P>with all her high and worldly notions of matrimony,



<P>would be forwarding anything of a serious nature in such



<P>a quarter?&nbsp; Nothing could be more unnatural in either.



<P>Fanny was ashamed of her own doubts.&nbsp; Everything might



<P>be possible rather than serious attachment, or serious



<P>approbation of it toward her.&nbsp; She had quite convinced herself



<P>of this before Sir Thomas and Mr. Crawford joined them.



<P>The difficulty was in maintaining the conviction quite



<P>so absolutely after Mr. Crawford was in the room;



<P>for once or twice a look seemed forced on her which she



<P>did not know how to class among the common meaning;



<P>in any other man, at least, she would have said



<P>that it meant something very earnest, very pointed.



<P>But she still tried to believe it no more than what he



<P>might often have expressed towards her cousins and fifty



<P>other women.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She thought he was wishing to speak to her unheard



<P>by the rest.&nbsp; She fancied he was trying for it the



<P>whole evening at intervals, whenever Sir Thomas was



<P>out of the room, or at all engaged with Mrs. Norris,



<P>and she carefully refused him every opportunity.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>At last--it seemed an at last to Fanny's nervousness,



<P>though not remarkably late--he began to talk of going away;



<P>but the comfort of the sound was impaired by his turning



<P>to her the next moment, and saying, "Have you nothing to send



<P>to Mary?&nbsp; No answer to her note?&nbsp; She will be disappointed



<P>if she receives nothing from you.&nbsp; Pray write to her,



<P>if it be only a line."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes! certainly," cried Fanny, rising in haste,



<P>the haste of embarrassment and of wanting to get away--



<P>"I will write directly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She went accordingly to the table, where she was in the



<P>habit of writing for her aunt, and prepared her materials



<P>without knowing what in the world to say.&nbsp; She had read



<P>Miss Crawford's note only once, and how to reply to



<P>anything so imperfectly understood was most distressing.



<P>Quite unpractised in such sort of note-writing, had



<P>there been time for scruples and fears as to style she



<P>would have felt them in abundance:&nbsp; but something must



<P>be instantly written; and with only one decided feeling,



<P>that of wishing not to appear to think anything really intended,



<P>she wrote thus, in great trembling both of spirits and hand--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very much obliged to you, my dear Miss Crawford,



<P>for your kind congratulations, as far as they relate to my



<P>dearest William.&nbsp; The rest of your note I know means nothing;



<P>but I am so unequal to anything of the sort, that I hope



<P>you will excuse my begging you to take no farther notice.



<P>I have seen too much of Mr. Crawford not to understand



<P>his manners; if he understood me as well, he would,



<P>I dare say, behave differently.&nbsp; I do not know what I write,



<P>but it would be a great favour of you never to mention



<P>the subject again.&nbsp; With thanks for the honour of your note,



<P>I remain, dear Miss Crawford, etc., etc."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The conclusion was scarcely intelligible from increasing



<P>fright, for she found that Mr. Crawford, under pretence



<P>of receiving the note, was coming towards her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You cannot think I mean to hurry you," said he,



<P>in an undervoice, perceiving the amazing trepidation



<P>with which she made up the note, "you cannot think



<P>I have any such object.&nbsp; Do not hurry yourself, I entreat."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!&nbsp; I thank you; I have quite done, just done; it will



<P>be ready in a moment; I am very much obliged to you;



<P>if you will be so good as to give _that_ to Miss Crawford."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The note was held out, and must be taken; and as she



<P>instantly and with averted eyes walked towards the fireplace,



<P>where sat the others, he had nothing to do but to go



<P>in good earnest.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny thought she had never known a day of greater agitation,



<P>both of pain and pleasure; but happily the pleasure



<P>was not of a sort to die with the day; for every day



<P>would restore the knowledge of William's advancement,



<P>whereas the pain, she hoped, would return no more.



<P>She had no doubt that her note must appear excessively



<P>ill-written, that the language would disgrace a child,



<P>for her distress had allowed no arrangement; but at least



<P>it would assure them both of her being neither imposed



<P>on nor gratified by Mr. Crawford's attentions.



<P>

</HTML>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
