   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 30</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXX</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Miss Crawford's uneasiness was much lightened by



<P>this conversation, and she walked home again in spirits



<P>which might have defied almost another week of the same



<P>small party in the same bad weather, had they been put



<P>to the proof; but as that very evening brought her brother



<P>down from London again in quite, or more than quite,



<P>his usual cheerfulness, she had nothing farther to try



<P>her own.&nbsp; His still refusing to tell her what he had gone



<P>for was but the promotion of gaiety; a day before it



<P>might have irritated, but now it was a pleasant joke--



<P>suspected only of concealing something planned as a pleasant



<P>surprise to herself.&nbsp; And the next day _did_ bring a



<P>surprise to her.&nbsp; Henry had said he should just go and ask



<P>the Bertrams how they did, and be back in ten minutes,



<P>but he was gone above an hour; and when his sister,



<P>who had been waiting for him to walk with her in the garden,



<P>met him at last most impatiently in the sweep, and cried out,



<P>"My dear Henry, where can you have been all this time?"



<P>he had only to say that he had been sitting with Lady



<P>Bertram and Fanny.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sitting with them an hour and a half!" exclaimed Mary.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But this was only the beginning of her surprise.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Mary," said he, drawing her arm within his,



<P>and walking along the sweep as if not knowing where he was:



<P>"I could not get away sooner; Fanny looked so lovely!



<P>I am quite determined, Mary.&nbsp; My mind is entirely made up.



<P>Will it astonish you?&nbsp; No: you must be aware that I am quite



<P>determined to marry Fanny Price."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The surprise was now complete; for, in spite of whatever



<P>his consciousness might suggest, a suspicion of his having



<P>any such views had never entered his sister's imagination;



<P>and she looked so truly the astonishment she felt, that he



<P>was obliged to repeat what he had said, and more fully



<P>and more solemnly.&nbsp; The conviction of his determination



<P>once admitted, it was not unwelcome.&nbsp; There was even



<P>pleasure with the surprise.&nbsp; Mary was in a state of mind



<P>to rejoice in a connexion with the Bertram family,



<P>and to be not displeased with her brother's marrying



<P>a little beneath him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, Mary," was Henry's concluding assurance.&nbsp; "I am



<P>fairly caught.&nbsp; You know with what idle designs I began;



<P>but this is the end of them.&nbsp; I have, I flatter myself,



<P>made no inconsiderable progress in her affections;



<P>but my own are entirely fixed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Lucky, lucky girl!" cried Mary, as soon as she could speak;



<P>"what a match for her!&nbsp; My dearest Henry, this must



<P>be my _first_ feeling; but my _second_, which you shall



<P>have as sincerely, is, that I approve your choice from



<P>my soul, and foresee your happiness as heartily as I



<P>wish and desire it.&nbsp; You will have a sweet little wife;



<P>all gratitude and devotion.&nbsp; Exactly what you deserve.



<P>What an amazing match for her!&nbsp; Mrs. Norris often talks



<P>of her luck; what will she say now?&nbsp; The delight of all



<P>the family, indeed!&nbsp; And she has some _true_ friends in it!



<P>How _they_ will rejoice!&nbsp; But tell me all about it!



<P>Talk to me for ever.&nbsp; When did you begin to think seriously



<P>about her?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nothing could be more impossible than to answer such



<P>a question, though nothing could be more agreeable than



<P>to have it asked.&nbsp; "How the pleasing plague had stolen



<P>on him" he could not say; and before he had expressed



<P>the same sentiment with a little variation of words



<P>three times over, his sister eagerly interrupted him with,



<P>"Ah, my dear Henry, and this is what took you to London!



<P>This was your business!&nbsp; You chose to consult the Admiral



<P>before you made up your mind."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But this he stoutly denied.&nbsp; He knew his uncle too well



<P>to consult him on any matrimonial scheme.&nbsp; The Admiral



<P>hated marriage, and thought it never pardonable in a young



<P>man of independent fortune.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"When Fanny is known to him," continued Henry, "he will doat



<P>on her.&nbsp; She is exactly the woman to do away every prejudice



<P>of such a man as the Admiral, for she he would describe,



<P>if indeed he has now delicacy of language enough to embody



<P>his own ideas.&nbsp; But till it is absolutely settled--



<P>settled beyond all interference, he shall know nothing



<P>of the matter.&nbsp; No, Mary, you are quite mistaken.



<P>You have not discovered my business yet."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, well, I am satisfied.&nbsp; I know now to whom



<P>it must relate, and am in no hurry for the rest.



<P>Fanny Price! wonderful, quite wonderful!&nbsp; That Mansfield



<P>should have done so much for--that _you_ should have



<P>found your fate in Mansfield!&nbsp; But you are quite right;



<P>you could not have chosen better.&nbsp; There is not a better



<P>girl in the world, and you do not want for fortune;



<P>and as to her connexions, they are more than good.



<P>The Bertrams are undoubtedly some of the first people



<P>in this country.&nbsp; She is niece to Sir Thomas Bertram;



<P>that will be enough for the world.&nbsp; But go on, go on.



<P>Tell me more.&nbsp; What are your plans?&nbsp; Does she know her



<P>own happiness?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"What are you waiting for?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"For--for very little more than opportunity.&nbsp; Mary, she is



<P>not like her cousins; but I think I shall not ask in vain."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh no! you cannot.&nbsp; Were you even less pleasing--



<P>supposing her not to love you already (of which,



<P>however, I can have little doubt)--you would be safe.



<P>The gentleness and gratitude of her disposition would



<P>secure her all your own immediately.&nbsp; From my soul I do



<P>not think she would marry you _without_ love; that is,



<P>if there is a girl in the world capable of being uninfluenced



<P>by ambition, I can suppose it her; but ask her to love you,



<P>and she will never have the heart to refuse."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As soon as her eagerness could rest in silence,



<P>he was as happy to tell as she could be to listen;



<P>and a conversation followed almost as deeply interesting



<P>to her as to himself, though he had in fact nothing



<P>to relate but his own sensations, nothing to dwell on



<P>but Fanny's charms.&nbsp; Fanny's beauty of face and figure,



<P>Fanny's graces of manner and goodness of heart, were the



<P>exhaustless theme.&nbsp; The gentleness, modesty, and sweetness



<P>of her character were warmly expatiated on; that sweetness



<P>which makes so essential a part of every woman's worth



<P>in the judgment of man, that though he sometimes loves



<P>where it is not, he can never believe it absent.



<P>Her temper he had good reason to depend on and to praise.



<P>He had often seen it tried.&nbsp; Was there one of the family,



<P>excepting Edmund, who had not in some way or other



<P>continually exercised her patience and forbearance?



<P>Her affections were evidently strong.&nbsp; To see her with



<P>her brother!&nbsp; What could more delightfully prove that



<P>the warmth of her heart was equal to its gentleness?



<P>What could be more encouraging to a man who had her love



<P>in view?&nbsp; Then, her understanding was beyond every suspicion,



<P>quick and clear; and her manners were the mirror of



<P>her own modest and elegant mind.&nbsp; Nor was this all.



<P>Henry Crawford had too much sense not to feel the worth of good



<P>principles in a wife, though he was too little accustomed



<P>to serious reflection to know them by their proper name;



<P>but when he talked of her having such a steadiness



<P>and regularity of conduct, such a high notion of honour,



<P>and such an observance of decorum as might warrant any man



<P>in the fullest dependence on her faith and integrity,



<P>he expressed what was inspired by the knowledge of her



<P>being well principled and religious.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I could so wholly and absolutely confide in her," said he;



<P>"and _that_ is what I want."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Well might his sister, believing as she really did that his



<P>opinion of Fanny Price was scarcely beyond her merits,



<P>rejoice in her prospects.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The more I think of it," she cried, "the more am I convinced



<P>that you are doing quite right; and though I should never have



<P>selected Fanny Price as the girl most likely to attach you,



<P>I am now persuaded she is the very one to make you happy.



<P>Your wicked project upon her peace turns out a clever



<P>thought indeed.&nbsp; You will both find your good in it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It was bad, very bad in me against such a creature;



<P>but I did not know her then; and she shall have no reason



<P>to lament the hour that first put it into my head.



<P>I will make her very happy, Mary; happier than she has ever



<P>yet been herself, or ever seen anybody else.&nbsp; I will not



<P>take her from Northamptonshire.&nbsp; I shall let Everingham,



<P>and rent a place in this neighbourhood; perhaps Stanwix Lodge.



<P>I shall let a seven years' lease of Everingham.



<P>I am sure of an excellent tenant at half a word.



<P>I could name three people now, who would give me my own



<P>terms and thank me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ha!" cried Mary; "settle in Northamptonshire!



<P>That is pleasant!&nbsp; Then we shall be all together."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When she had spoken it, she recollected herself,



<P>and wished it unsaid; but there was no need of confusion;



<P>for her brother saw her only as the supposed inmate



<P>of Mansfield parsonage, and replied but to invite her



<P>in the kindest manner to his own house, and to claim



<P>the best right in her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must give us more than half your time," said he.



<P>"I cannot admit Mrs. Grant to have an equal claim with



<P>Fanny and myself, for we shall both have a right in you.



<P>Fanny will be so truly your sister!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mary had only to be grateful and give general assurances;



<P>but she was now very fully purposed to be the guest of



<P>neither brother nor sister many months longer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You will divide your year between London and Northamptonshire?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"That's right; and in London, of course, a house of



<P>your own:&nbsp; no longer with the Admiral.&nbsp; My dearest Henry,



<P>the advantage to you of getting away from the Admiral



<P>before your manners are hurt by the contagion of his,



<P>before you have contracted any of his foolish opinions,



<P>or learned to sit over your dinner as if it were the best



<P>blessing of life!&nbsp; _You_ are not sensible of the gain,



<P>for your regard for him has blinded you; but, in my estimation,



<P>your marrying early may be the saving of you.&nbsp; To have seen



<P>you grow like the Admiral in word or deed, look or gesture,



<P>would have broken my heart."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, well, we do not think quite alike here.



<P>The Admiral has his faults, but he is a very good man,



<P>and has been more than a father to me.&nbsp; Few fathers would



<P>have let me have my own way half so much.&nbsp; You must



<P>not prejudice Fanny against him.&nbsp; I must have them love



<P>one another."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mary refrained from saying what she felt, that there could



<P>not be two persons in existence whose characters and manners



<P>were less accordant:&nbsp; time would discover it to him;



<P>but she could not help _this_ reflection on the Admiral.



<P>"Henry, I think so highly of Fanny Price, that if I could



<P>suppose the next Mrs. Crawford would have half the reason



<P>which my poor ill-used aunt had to abhor the very name,



<P>I would prevent the marriage, if possible; but I know you:



<P>I know that a wife you _loved_ would be the happiest



<P>of women, and that even when you ceased to love, she would



<P>yet find in you the liberality and good-breeding of



<P>a gentleman."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The impossibility of not doing everything in the world to



<P>make Fanny Price happy, or of ceasing to love Fanny Price,



<P>was of course the groundwork of his eloquent answer.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Had you seen her this morning, Mary," he continued,



<P>"attending with such ineffable sweetness and patience to



<P>all the demands of her aunt's stupidity, working with her,



<P>and for her, her colour beautifully heightened as she



<P>leant over the work, then returning to her seat to finish



<P>a note which she was previously engaged in writing



<P>for that stupid woman's service, and all this with such



<P>unpretending gentleness, so much as if it were a matter



<P>of course that she was not to have a moment at her



<P>own command, her hair arranged as neatly as it always is,



<P>and one little curl falling forward as she wrote, which she



<P>now and then shook back, and in the midst of all this,



<P>still speaking at intervals to _me_, or listening,



<P>and as if she liked to listen, to what I said.



<P>Had you seen her so, Mary, you would not have implied



<P>the possibility of her power over my heart ever ceasing."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dearest Henry," cried Mary, stopping short, and smiling



<P>in his face, "how glad I am to see you so much in love!



<P>It quite delights me.&nbsp; But what will Mrs. Rushworth and



<P>Julia say?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I care neither what they say nor what they feel.



<P>They will now see what sort of woman it is that can attach me,



<P>that can attach a man of sense.&nbsp; I wish the discovery



<P>may do them any good.&nbsp; And they will now see their cousin



<P>treated as she ought to be, and I wish they may be heartily



<P>ashamed of their own abominable neglect and unkindness.



<P>They will be angry," he added, after a moment's silence,



<P>and in a cooler tone; "Mrs. Rushworth will be very angry.



<P>It will be a bitter pill to her; that is, like other



<P>bitter pills, it will have two moments' ill flavour, and then



<P>be swallowed and forgotten; for I am not such a coxcomb



<P>as to suppose her feelings more lasting than other women's,



<P>though _I_ was the object of them.&nbsp; Yes, Mary, my Fanny



<P>will feel a difference indeed:&nbsp; a daily, hourly difference,



<P>in the behaviour of every being who approaches her;



<P>and it will be the completion of my happiness to know



<P>that I am the doer of it, that I am the person to give



<P>the consequence so justly her due.&nbsp; Now she is dependent,



<P>helpless, friendless, neglected, forgotten."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Nay, Henry, not by all; not forgotten by all; not friendless



<P>or forgotten.&nbsp; Her cousin Edmund never forgets her."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Edmund!&nbsp; True, I believe he is, generally speaking,



<P>kind to her, and so is Sir Thomas in his way; but it is



<P>the way of a rich, superior, long-worded, arbitrary uncle.



<P>What can Sir Thomas and Edmund together do, what do they



<P>_do_ for her happiness, comfort, honour, and dignity in



<P>the world, to what I _shall_ do?"



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 24</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXIV</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Henry Crawford had quite made up his mind by the



<P>next morning to give another fortnight to Mansfield,



<P>and having sent for his hunters, and written a few



<P>lines of explanation to the Admiral, he looked round at



<P>his sister as he sealed and threw the letter from him,



<P>and seeing the coast clear of the rest of the family,



<P>said, with a smile, "And how do you think I mean to



<P>amuse myself, Mary, on the days that I do not hunt?



<P>I am grown too old to go out more than three times a week;



<P>but I have a plan for the intermediate days, and what do you think



<P>it is?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"To walk and ride with me, to be sure."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Not exactly, though I shall be happy to do both, but _that_



<P>would be exercise only to my body, and I must take care



<P>of my mind.&nbsp; Besides, _that_ would be all recreation



<P>and indulgence, without the wholesome alloy of labour,



<P>and I do not like to eat the bread of idleness.&nbsp; No, my plan



<P>is to make Fanny Price in love with me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fanny Price!&nbsp; Nonsense!&nbsp; No, no.&nbsp; You ought to be



<P>satisfied with her two cousins."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But I cannot be satisfied without Fanny Price,



<P>without making a small hole in Fanny Price's heart.



<P>You do not seem properly aware of her claims to notice.



<P>When we talked of her last night, you none of you



<P>seemed sensible of the wonderful improvement that has



<P>taken place in her looks within the last six weeks.



<P>You see her every day, and therefore do not notice it;



<P>but I assure you she is quite a different creature



<P>from what she was in the autumn.&nbsp; She was then merely



<P>a quiet, modest, not plain-looking girl, but she is now



<P>absolutely pretty.&nbsp; I used to think she had neither



<P>complexion nor countenance; but in that soft skin of hers,



<P>so frequently tinged with a blush as it was yesterday,



<P>there is decided beauty; and from what I observed of her



<P>eyes and mouth, I do not despair of their being capable



<P>of expression enough when she has anything to express.



<P>And then, her air, her manner, her _tout_ _ensemble_,



<P>is so indescribably improved!&nbsp; She must be grown two inches,



<P>at least, since October."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Phoo! phoo!&nbsp; This is only because there were no tall women



<P>to compare her with, and because she has got a new gown,



<P>and you never saw her so well dressed before.&nbsp; She is



<P>just what she was in October, believe me.&nbsp; The truth is,



<P>that she was the only girl in company for you to notice,



<P>and you must have a somebody.&nbsp; I have always thought



<P>her pretty--not strikingly pretty--but 'pretty enough,'



<P>as people say; a sort of beauty that grows on one.



<P>Her eyes should be darker, but she has a sweet smile;



<P>but as for this wonderful degree of improvement, I am



<P>sure it may all be resolved into a better style of dress,



<P>and your having nobody else to look at; and therefore,



<P>if you do set about a flirtation with her, you never



<P>will persuade me that it is in compliment to her beauty,



<P>or that it proceeds from anything but your own idleness



<P>and folly."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her brother gave only a smile to this accusation,



<P>and soon afterwards said, "I do not quite know what to make



<P>of Miss Fanny.&nbsp; I do not understand her.&nbsp; I could not tell



<P>what she would be at yesterday.&nbsp; What is her character?



<P>Is she solemn?&nbsp; Is she queer?&nbsp; Is she prudish?&nbsp; Why did



<P>she draw back and look so grave at me?&nbsp; I could hardly get



<P>her to speak.&nbsp; I never was so long in company with a girl



<P>in my life, trying to entertain her, and succeed so ill!



<P>Never met with a girl who looked so grave on me!



<P>I must try to get the better of this.&nbsp; Her looks say,



<P>'I will not like you, I am determined not to like you';



<P>and I say she shall."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Foolish fellow!&nbsp; And so this is her attraction after all!



<P>This it is, her not caring about you, which gives



<P>her such a soft skin, and makes her so much taller,



<P>and produces all these charms and graces!&nbsp; I do desire



<P>that you will not be making her really unhappy;



<P>a _little_ love, perhaps, may animate and do her good,



<P>but I will not have you plunge her deep, for she is as



<P>good a little creature as ever lived, and has a great



<P>deal of feeling."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"It can be but for a fortnight," said Henry; "and if a



<P>fortnight can kill her, she must have a constitution



<P>which nothing could save.&nbsp; No, I will not do her any harm,



<P>dear little soul! only want her to look kindly on me,



<P>to give me smiles as well as blushes, to keep a chair



<P>for me by herself wherever we are, and be all animation



<P>when I take it and talk to her; to think as I think,



<P>be interested in all my possessions and pleasures,



<P>try to keep me longer at Mansfield, and feel when I



<P>go away that she shall be never happy again.&nbsp; I want



<P>nothing more."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Moderation itself!" said Mary.&nbsp; "I can have no scruples now.



<P>Well, you will have opportunities enough of endeavouring



<P>to recommend yourself, for we are a great deal together."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And without attempting any farther remonstrance, she left



<P>Fanny to her fate, a fate which, had not Fanny's heart



<P>been guarded in a way unsuspected by Miss Crawford,



<P>might have been a little harder than she deserved;



<P>for although there doubtless are such unconquerable young



<P>ladies of eighteen (or one should not read about them)



<P>as are never to be persuaded into love against their judgment



<P>by all that talent, manner, attention, and flattery can do,



<P>I have no inclination to believe Fanny one of them,



<P>or to think that with so much tenderness of disposition,



<P>and so much taste as belonged to her, she could have



<P>escaped heart-whole from the courtship (though the



<P>courtship only of a fortnight) of such a man as Crawford,



<P>in spite of there being some previous ill opinion of him



<P>to be overcome, had not her affection been engaged elsewhere.



<P>With all the security which love of another and disesteem



<P>of him could give to the peace of mind he was attacking,



<P>his continued attentions--continued, but not obtrusive,



<P>and adapting themselves more and more to the gentleness



<P>and delicacy of her character--obliged her very soon



<P>to dislike him less than formerly.&nbsp; She had by no means



<P>forgotten the past, and she thought as ill of him as ever;



<P>but she felt his powers:&nbsp; he was entertaining; and his



<P>manners were so improved, so polite, so seriously and



<P>blamelessly polite, that it was impossible not to be civil



<P>to him in return.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>A very few days were enough to effect this; and at the end



<P>of those few days, circumstances arose which had a tendency



<P>rather to forward his views of pleasing her, inasmuch as



<P>they gave her a degree of happiness which must dispose



<P>her to be pleased with everybody.&nbsp; William, her brother,



<P>the so long absent and dearly loved brother, was in



<P>England again.&nbsp; She had a letter from him herself, a few



<P>hurried happy lines, written as the ship came up Channel,



<P>and sent into Portsmouth with the first boat that left



<P>the Antwerp at anchor in Spithead; and when Crawford walked



<P>up with the newspaper in his hand, which he had hoped



<P>would bring the first tidings, he found her trembling



<P>with joy over this letter, and listening with a glowing,



<P>grateful countenance to the kind invitation which her



<P>uncle was most collectedly dictating in reply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was but the day before that Crawford had made himself



<P>thoroughly master of the subject, or had in fact become



<P>at all aware of her having such a brother, or his being



<P>in such a ship, but the interest then excited had been



<P>very properly lively, determining him on his return to



<P>town to apply for information as to the probable period



<P>of the Antwerp's return from the Mediterranean, etc.;



<P>and the good luck which attended his early examination



<P>of ship news the next morning seemed the reward of his



<P>ingenuity in finding out such a method of pleasing her,



<P>as well as of his dutiful attention to the Admiral,



<P>in having for many years taken in the paper esteemed



<P>to have the earliest naval intelligence.&nbsp; He proved,



<P>however, to be too late.&nbsp; All those fine first feelings,



<P>of which he had hoped to be the exciter, were already given.



<P>But his intention, the kindness of his intention,



<P>was thankfully acknowledged:&nbsp; quite thankfully and warmly,



<P>for she was elevated beyond the common timidity of her



<P>mind by the flow of her love for William.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This dear William would soon be amongst them.&nbsp; There could



<P>be no doubt of his obtaining leave of absence immediately,



<P>for he was still only a midshipman; and as his parents,



<P>from living on the spot, must already have seen him,



<P>and be seeing him perhaps daily, his direct holidays



<P>might with justice be instantly given to the sister,



<P>who had been his best correspondent through a period of



<P>seven years, and the uncle who had done most for his support



<P>and advancement; and accordingly the reply to her reply,



<P>fixing a very early day for his arrival, came as soon



<P>as possible; and scarcely ten days had passed since Fanny



<P>had been in the agitation of her first dinner-visit,



<P>when she found herself in an agitation of a higher nature,



<P>watching in the hall, in the lobby, on the stairs,



<P>for the first sound of the carriage which was to bring her



<P>a brother.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It came happily while she was thus waiting; and there



<P>being neither ceremony nor fearfulness to delay the moment



<P>of meeting, she was with him as he entered the house,



<P>and the first minutes of exquisite feeling had no interruption



<P>and no witnesses, unless the servants chiefly intent



<P>upon opening the proper doors could be called such.



<P>This was exactly what Sir Thomas and Edmund had been



<P>separately conniving at, as each proved to the other



<P>by the sympathetic alacrity with which they both advised



<P>Mrs. Norris's continuing where she was, instead of rushing



<P>out into the hall as soon as the noises of the arrival



<P>reached them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>William and Fanny soon shewed themselves; and Sir Thomas



<P>had the pleasure of receiving, in his protege, certainly a



<P>very different person from the one he had equipped seven



<P>years ago, but a young man of an open, pleasant countenance,



<P>and frank, unstudied, but feeling and respectful manners,



<P>and such as confirmed him his friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was long before Fanny could recover from the agitating



<P>happiness of such an hour as was formed by the last



<P>thirty minutes of expectation, and the first of fruition;



<P>it was some time even before her happiness could be said



<P>to make her happy, before the disappointment inseparable



<P>from the alteration of person had vanished, and she could



<P>see in him the same William as before, and talk to him,



<P>as her heart had been yearning to do through many



<P>a past year.&nbsp; That time, however, did gradually come,



<P>forwarded by an affection on his side as warm as her own,



<P>and much less encumbered by refinement or self-distrust.



<P>She was the first object of his love, but it was a love



<P>which his stronger spirits, and bolder temper, made it



<P>as natural for him to express as to feel.&nbsp; On the morrow



<P>they were walking about together with true enjoyment,



<P>and every succeeding morrow renewed a _tete-a-tete_



<P>which Sir Thomas could not but observe with complacency,



<P>even before Edmund had pointed it out to him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Excepting the moments of peculiar delight, which any marked



<P>or unlooked-for instance of Edmund's consideration of her



<P>in the last few months had excited, Fanny had never known



<P>so much felicity in her life, as in this unchecked, equal,



<P>fearless intercourse with the brother and friend who was opening



<P>all his heart to her, telling her all his hopes and fears,



<P>plans, and solicitudes respecting that long thought of,



<P>dearly earned, and justly valued blessing of promotion;



<P>who could give her direct and minute information of the



<P>father and mother, brothers and sisters, of whom she



<P>very seldom heard; who was interested in all the comforts



<P>and all the little hardships of her home at Mansfield;



<P>ready to think of every member of that home as she directed,



<P>or differing only by a less scrupulous opinion, and more



<P>noisy abuse of their aunt Norris, and with whom (perhaps



<P>the dearest indulgence of the whole) all the evil and



<P>good of their earliest years could be gone over again,



<P>and every former united pain and pleasure retraced



<P>with the fondest recollection.&nbsp; An advantage this,



<P>a strengthener of love, in which even the conjugal tie



<P>is beneath the fraternal.&nbsp; Children of the same family,



<P>the same blood, with the same first associations and habits,



<P>have some means of enjoyment in their power, which no



<P>subsequent connexions can supply; and it must be by a



<P>long and unnatural estrangement, by a divorce which no



<P>subsequent connexion can justify, if such precious remains



<P>of the earliest attachments are ever entirely outlived.



<P>Too often, alas! it is so.&nbsp; Fraternal love, sometimes



<P>almost everything, is at others worse than nothing.



<P>But with William and Fanny Price it was still a sentiment



<P>in all its prime and freshness, wounded by no opposition



<P>of interest, cooled by no separate attachment, and feeling



<P>the influence of time and absence only in its increase.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>An affection so amiable was advancing each in the opinion



<P>of all who had hearts to value anything good.&nbsp; Henry Crawford



<P>was as much struck with it as any.&nbsp; He honoured the



<P>warm-hearted, blunt fondness of the young sailor, which led



<P>him to say, with his hands stretched towards Fanny's head,



<P>"Do you know, I begin to like that queer fashion already,



<P>though when I first heard of such things being done



<P>in England, I could not believe it; and when Mrs. Brown,



<P>and the other women at the Commissioner's at Gibraltar,



<P>appeared in the same trim, I thought they were mad; but Fanny



<P>can reconcile me to anything"; and saw, with lively admiration,



<P>the glow of Fanny's cheek, the brightness of her eye,



<P>the deep interest, the absorbed attention, while her



<P>brother was describing any of the imminent hazards,



<P>or terrific scenes, which such a period at sea must supply.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was a picture which Henry Crawford had moral taste enough



<P>to value.&nbsp; Fanny's attractions increased--increased twofold;



<P>for the sensibility which beautified her complexion and



<P>illumined her countenance was an attraction in itself.



<P>He was no longer in doubt of the capabilities of her heart.



<P>She had feeling, genuine feeling.&nbsp; It would be something



<P>to be loved by such a girl, to excite the first ardours



<P>of her young unsophisticated mind!&nbsp; She interested him



<P>more than he had foreseen.&nbsp; A fortnight was not enough.



<P>His stay became indefinite.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>William was often called on by his uncle to be the talker.



<P>His recitals were amusing in themselves to Sir Thomas,



<P>but the chief object in seeking them was to understand



<P>the reciter, to know the young man by his histories;



<P>and he listened to his clear, simple, spirited details with



<P>full satisfaction, seeing in them the proof of good principles,



<P>professional knowledge, energy, courage, and cheerfulness,



<P>everything that could deserve or promise well.



<P>Young as he was, William had already seen a great deal.



<P>He had been in the Mediterranean; in the West Indies;



<P>in the Mediterranean again; had been often taken on shore



<P>by the favour of his captain, and in the course of seven



<P>years had known every variety of danger which sea and war



<P>together could offer.&nbsp; With such means in his power he



<P>had a right to be listened to; and though Mrs. Norris could



<P>fidget about the room, and disturb everybody in quest



<P>of two needlefuls of thread or a second-hand shirt button,



<P>in the midst of her nephew's account of a shipwreck



<P>or an engagement, everybody else was attentive; and even



<P>Lady Bertram could not hear of such horrors unmoved,



<P>or without sometimes lifting her eyes from her work to say,



<P>"Dear me! how disagreeable!&nbsp; I wonder anybody can ever go



<P>to sea."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To Henry Crawford they gave a different feeling.&nbsp; He longed



<P>to have been at sea, and seen and done and suffered as much.



<P>His heart was warmed, his fancy fired, and he felt



<P>the highest respect for a lad who, before he was twenty,



<P>had gone through such bodily hardships and given such



<P>proofs of mind.&nbsp; The glory of heroism, of usefulness,



<P>of exertion, of endurance, made his own habits of selfish



<P>indulgence appear in shameful contrast; and he wished



<P>he had been a William Price, distinguishing himself and



<P>working his way to fortune and consequence with so much



<P>self-respect and happy ardour, instead of what he was!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The wish was rather eager than lasting.&nbsp; He was roused from



<P>the reverie of retrospection and regret produced by it,



<P>by some inquiry from Edmund as to his plans for the next



<P>day's hunting; and he found it was as well to be a man



<P>of fortune at once with horses and grooms at his command.



<P>In one respect it was better, as it gave him the means



<P>of conferring a kindness where he wished to oblige.



<P>With spirits, courage, and curiosity up to anything,



<P>William expressed an inclination to hunt; and Crawford could



<P>mount him without the slightest inconvenience to himself,



<P>and with only some scruples to obviate in Sir Thomas,



<P>who knew better than his nephew the value of such a loan,



<P>and some alarms to reason away in Fanny.&nbsp; She feared



<P>for William; by no means convinced by all that he could



<P>relate of his own horsemanship in various countries,



<P>of the scrambling parties in which he had been engaged,



<P>the rough horses and mules he had ridden, or his many narrow



<P>escapes from dreadful falls, that he was at all equal to the



<P>management of a high-fed hunter in an English fox-chase;



<P>nor till he returned safe and well, without accident



<P>or discredit, could she be reconciled to the risk,



<P>or feel any of that obligation to Mr. Crawford for lending



<P>the horse which he had fully intended it should produce.



<P>When it was proved, however, to have done William no harm,



<P>she could allow it to be a kindness, and even reward



<P>the owner with a smile when the animal was one minute



<P>tendered to his use again; and the next, with the



<P>greatest cordiality, and in a manner not to be resisted,



<P>made over to his use entirely so long as he remained



<P>in Northamptonshire.

<BR>&nbsp;



<P><B>&nbsp;(End of&nbsp; Volume One)</B>

<BR>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 18</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XVIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Everything was now in a regular train:&nbsp; theatre, actors,



<P>actresses, and dresses, were all getting forward;



<P>but though no other great impediments arose, Fanny found,



<P>before many days were past, that it was not all uninterrupted



<P>enjoyment to the party themselves, and that she had



<P>not to witness the continuance of such unanimity and



<P>delight as had been almost too much for her at first.



<P>Everybody began to have their vexation.&nbsp; Edmund had many.



<P>Entirely against _his_ judgment, a scene-painter arrived



<P>from town, and was at work, much to the increase



<P>of the expenses, and, what was worse, of the eclat of



<P>their proceedings; and his brother, instead of being really



<P>guided by him as to the privacy of the representation,



<P>was giving an invitation to every family who came in his way.



<P>Tom himself began to fret over the scene-painter's



<P>slow progress, and to feel the miseries of waiting.



<P>He had learned his part--all his parts, for he took



<P>every trifling one that could be united with the Butler,



<P>and began to be impatient to be acting; and every day



<P>thus unemployed was tending to increase his sense of



<P>the insignificance of all his parts together, and make



<P>him more ready to regret that some other play had not been chosen.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, being always a very courteous listener, and often



<P>the only listener at hand, came in for the complaints



<P>and the distresses of most of them.&nbsp; _She_ knew that



<P>Mr. Yates was in general thought to rant dreadfully;



<P>that Mr. Yates was disappointed in Henry Crawford;



<P>that Tom Bertram spoke so quick he would be unintelligible;



<P>that Mrs. Grant spoiled everything by laughing; that Edmund



<P>was behindhand with his part, and that it was misery



<P>to have anything to do with Mr. Rushworth, who was wanting



<P>a prompter through every speech.&nbsp; She knew, also, that poor



<P>Mr. Rushworth could seldom get anybody to rehearse with him:



<P>_his_ complaint came before her as well as the rest;



<P>and so decided to her eye was her cousin Maria's



<P>avoidance of him, and so needlessly often the rehearsal



<P>of the first scene between her and Mr. Crawford, that she



<P>had soon all the terror of other complaints from _him_.



<P>So far from being all satisfied and all enjoying,



<P>she found everybody requiring something they had not,



<P>and giving occasion of discontent to the others.



<P>Everybody had a part either too long or too short;



<P>nobody would attend as they ought; nobody would remember on



<P>which side they were to come in; nobody but the complainer



<P>would observe any directions.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny believed herself to derive as much innocent enjoyment



<P>from the play as any of them; Henry Crawford acted well,



<P>and it was a pleasure to _her_ to creep into the theatre,



<P>and attend the rehearsal of the first act, in spite of the



<P>feelings it excited in some speeches for Maria.&nbsp; Maria, she



<P>also thought, acted well, too well; and after the first



<P>rehearsal or two, Fanny began to be their only audience;



<P>and sometimes as prompter, sometimes as spectator,



<P>was often very useful.&nbsp; As far as she could judge,



<P>Mr. Crawford was considerably the best actor of all:



<P>he had more confidence than Edmund, more judgment than Tom,



<P>more talent and taste than Mr. Yates.&nbsp; She did not like him



<P>as a man, but she must admit him to be the best actor,



<P>and on this point there were not many who differed from her.



<P>Mr. Yates, indeed, exclaimed against his tameness



<P>and insipidity; and the day came at last, when Mr. Rushworth



<P>turned to her with a black look, and said, "Do you think



<P>there is anything so very fine in all this?&nbsp; For the life



<P>and soul of me, I cannot admire him; and, between ourselves,



<P>to see such an undersized, little, mean-looking man,



<P>set up for a fine actor, is very ridiculous in my opinion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>From this moment there was a return of his former jealousy,



<P>which Maria, from increasing hopes of Crawford, was at



<P>little pains to remove; and the chances of Mr. Rushworth's



<P>ever attaining to the knowledge of his two-and-forty



<P>speeches became much less.&nbsp; As to his ever making anything



<P>_tolerable_ of them, nobody had the smallest idea of that



<P>except his mother; _she_, indeed, regretted that his part



<P>was not more considerable, and deferred coming over to



<P>Mansfield till they were forward enough in their rehearsal



<P>to comprehend all his scenes; but the others aspired at



<P>nothing beyond his remembering the catchword, and the first



<P>line of his speech, and being able to follow the prompter



<P>through the rest.&nbsp; Fanny, in her pity and kindheartedness,



<P>was at great pains to teach him how to learn, giving him



<P>all the helps and directions in her power, trying to make



<P>an artificial memory for him, and learning every word



<P>of his part herself, but without his being much the forwarder.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Many uncomfortable, anxious, apprehensive feelings she



<P>certainly had; but with all these, and other claims



<P>on her time and attention, she was as far from finding



<P>herself without employment or utility amongst them,



<P>as without a companion in uneasiness; quite as far from



<P>having no demand on her leisure as on her compassion.



<P>The gloom of her first anticipations was proved to have



<P>been unfounded.&nbsp; She was occasionally useful to all;



<P>she was perhaps as much at peace as any.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a great deal of needlework to be done, moreover,



<P>in which her help was wanted; and that Mrs. Norris



<P>thought her quite as well off as the rest, was evident



<P>by the manner in which she claimed it--"Come, Fanny,"



<P>she cried, "these are fine times for you, but you must



<P>not be always walking from one room to the other,



<P>and doing the lookings-on at your ease, in this way;



<P>I want you here.&nbsp; I have been slaving myself till I



<P>can hardly stand, to contrive Mr. Rushworth's cloak



<P>without sending for any more satin; and now I think



<P>you may give me your help in putting it together.



<P>There are but three seams; you may do them in a trice.



<P>It would be lucky for me if I had nothing but the executive



<P>part to do.&nbsp; _You_ are best off, I can tell you:



<P>but if nobody did more than _you_, we should not get on



<P>very fast"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny took the work very quietly, without attempting



<P>any defence; but her kinder aunt Bertram observed on her behalf--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"One cannot wonder, sister, that Fanny _should_ be delighted:



<P>it is all new to her, you know; you and I used to be



<P>very fond of a play ourselves, and so am I still;



<P>and as soon as I am a little more at leisure, _I_ mean



<P>to look in at their rehearsals too.&nbsp; What is the play about,



<P>Fanny? you have never told me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh! sister, pray do not ask her now; for Fanny is not



<P>one of those who can talk and work at the same time.



<P>It is about Lovers' Vows."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I believe," said Fanny to her aunt Bertram, "there will



<P>be three acts rehearsed to-morrow evening, and that will



<P>give you an opportunity of seeing all the actors at once."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You had better stay till the curtain is hung," interposed



<P>Mrs. Norris; "the curtain will be hung in a day or two--



<P>there is very little sense in a play without a curtain--



<P>and I am much mistaken if you do not find it draw up



<P>into very handsome festoons."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram seemed quite resigned to waiting.&nbsp; Fanny did



<P>not share her aunt's composure:&nbsp; she thought of the morrow



<P>a great deal, for if the three acts were rehearsed,



<P>Edmund and Miss Crawford would then be acting together



<P>for the first time; the third act would bring a scene



<P>between them which interested her most particularly,



<P>and which she was longing and dreading to see how they



<P>would perform.&nbsp; The whole subject of it was love--



<P>a marriage of love was to be described by the gentleman,



<P>and very little short of a declaration of love be made by



<P>the lady.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had read and read the scene again with many painful,



<P>many wondering emotions, and looked forward to their



<P>representation of it as a circumstance almost too interesting.



<P>She did not _believe_ they had yet rehearsed it,



<P>even in private.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The morrow came, the plan for the evening continued,



<P>and Fanny's consideration of it did not become less agitated.



<P>She worked very diligently under her aunt's directions,



<P>but her diligence and her silence concealed a very absent,



<P>anxious mind; and about noon she made her escape with her



<P>work to the East room, that she might have no concern



<P>in another, and, as she deemed it, most unnecessary



<P>rehearsal of the first act, which Henry Crawford was



<P>just proposing, desirous at once of having her time



<P>to herself, and of avoiding the sight of Mr. Rushworth.



<P>A glimpse, as she passed through the hall, of the two



<P>ladies walking up from the Parsonage made no change



<P>in her wish of retreat, and she worked and meditated



<P>in the East room, undisturbed, for a quarter of an hour,



<P>when a gentle tap at the door was followed by the entrance



<P>of Miss Crawford.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Am I right?&nbsp; Yes; this is the East room.&nbsp; My dear



<P>Miss Price, I beg your pardon, but I have made my way



<P>to you on purpose to entreat your help."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, quite surprised, endeavoured to shew herself



<P>mistress of the room by her civilities, and looked



<P>at the bright bars of her empty grate with concern.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Thank you; I am quite warm, very warm.&nbsp; Allow me to stay



<P>here a little while, and do have the goodness to hear me



<P>my third act.&nbsp; I have brought my book, and if you would



<P>but rehearse it with me, I should be _so_ obliged!



<P>I came here to-day intending to rehearse it with Edmund--



<P>by ourselves--against the evening, but he is not in the way;



<P>and if he _were_, I do not think I could go through



<P>it with _him_, till I have hardened myself a little;



<P>for really there is a speech or two.&nbsp; You will be so good,



<P>won't you?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny was most civil in her assurances, though she could



<P>not give them in a very steady voice.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have you ever happened to look at the part I mean?"



<P>continued Miss Crawford, opening her book.&nbsp; "Here it is.



<P>I did not think much of it at first--but, upon my word.



<P>There, look at _that_ speech, and _that_, and _that_.



<P>How am I ever to look him in the face and say such things?



<P>Could you do it?&nbsp; But then he is your cousin, which makes



<P>all the difference.&nbsp; You must rehearse it with me, that I



<P>may fancy _you_ him, and get on by degrees.&nbsp; You _have_ a look



<P>of _his_ sometimes."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Have I?&nbsp; I will do my best with the greatest readiness;



<P>but I must _read_ the part, for I can say very little



<P>of it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"_None_ of it, I suppose.&nbsp; You are to have the book,



<P>of course.&nbsp; Now for it.&nbsp; We must have two chairs at hand



<P>for you to bring forward to the front of the stage.



<P>There--very good school-room chairs, not made for a theatre,



<P>I dare say; much more fitted for little girls to sit and



<P>kick their feet against when they are learning a lesson.



<P>What would your governess and your uncle say to see them



<P>used for such a purpose?&nbsp; Could Sir Thomas look in upon us



<P>just now, he would bless himself, for we are rehearsing



<P>all over the house.&nbsp; Yates is storming away in the



<P>dining-room. I heard him as I came upstairs, and the theatre



<P>is engaged of course by those indefatigable rehearsers,



<P>Agatha and Frederick.&nbsp; If _they_ are not perfect,



<P>I _shall_ be surprised.&nbsp; By the bye, I looked in upon



<P>them five minutes ago, and it happened to be exactly at



<P>one of the times when they were trying _not_ to embrace,



<P>and Mr. Rushworth was with me.&nbsp; I thought he began to look



<P>a little queer, so I turned it off as well as I could,



<P>by whispering to him, 'We shall have an excellent Agatha;



<P>there is something so _maternal_ in her manner,



<P>so completely _maternal_ in her voice and countenance.'



<P>Was not that well done of me?&nbsp; He brightened up directly.



<P>Now for my soliloquy."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She began, and Fanny joined in with all the modest feeling



<P>which the idea of representing Edmund was so strongly



<P>calculated to inspire; but with looks and voice so truly



<P>feminine as to be no very good picture of a man.&nbsp; With such



<P>an Anhalt, however, Miss Crawford had courage enough;



<P>and they had got through half the scene, when a tap at



<P>the door brought a pause, and the entrance of Edmund,



<P>the next moment, suspended it all.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Surprise, consciousness, and pleasure appeared in each



<P>of the three on this unexpected meeting; and as Edmund



<P>was come on the very same business that had brought



<P>Miss Crawford, consciousness and pleasure were likely



<P>to be more than momentary in _them_.&nbsp; He too had his book,



<P>and was seeking Fanny, to ask her to rehearse with him,



<P>and help him to prepare for the evening, without knowing



<P>Miss Crawford to be in the house; and great was the joy and



<P>animation of being thus thrown together, of comparing schemes,



<P>and sympathising in praise of Fanny's kind offices.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>_She_ could not equal them in their warmth.&nbsp; _Her_ spirits



<P>sank under the glow of theirs, and she felt herself becoming



<P>too nearly nothing to both to have any comfort in having



<P>been sought by either.&nbsp; They must now rehearse together.



<P>Edmund proposed, urged, entreated it, till the lady,



<P>not very unwilling at first, could refuse no longer,



<P>and Fanny was wanted only to prompt and observe them.



<P>She was invested, indeed, with the office of judge and critic,



<P>and earnestly desired to exercise it and tell them all



<P>their faults; but from doing so every feeling within



<P>her shrank--she could not, would not, dared not attempt it:



<P>had she been otherwise qualified for criticism, her conscience



<P>must have restrained her from venturing at disapprobation.



<P>She believed herself to feel too much of it in the aggregate



<P>for honesty or safety in particulars.&nbsp; To prompt them must



<P>be enough for her; and it was sometimes _more_ than enough;



<P>for she could not always pay attention to the book.



<P>In watching them she forgot herself; and, agitated by the



<P>increasing spirit of Edmund's manner, had once closed



<P>the page and turned away exactly as he wanted help.



<P>It was imputed to very reasonable weariness, and she was



<P>thanked and pitied; but she deserved their pity more than



<P>she hoped they would ever surmise.&nbsp; At last the scene



<P>was over, and Fanny forced herself to add her praise to



<P>the compliments each was giving the other; and when again



<P>alone and able to recall the whole, she was inclined



<P>to believe their performance would, indeed, have such



<P>nature and feeling in it as must ensure their credit,



<P>and make it a very suffering exhibition to herself.



<P>Whatever might be its effect, however, she must stand



<P>the brunt of it again that very day.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The first regular rehearsal of the three first acts



<P>was certainly to take place in the evening:&nbsp; Mrs. Grant



<P>and the Crawfords were engaged to return for that purpose



<P>as soon as they could after dinner; and every one concerned



<P>was looking forward with eagerness.&nbsp; There seemed



<P>a general diffusion of cheerfulness on the occasion.



<P>Tom was enjoying such an advance towards the end;



<P>Edmund was in spirits from the morning's rehearsal,



<P>and little vexations seemed everywhere smoothed away.



<P>All were alert and impatient; the ladies moved soon,



<P>the gentlemen soon followed them, and with the exception



<P>of Lady Bertram, Mrs. Norris, and Julia, everybody was



<P>in the theatre at an early hour; and having lighted it up



<P>as well as its unfinished state admitted, were waiting only



<P>the arrival of Mrs. Grant and the Crawfords to begin.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They did not wait long for the Crawfords, but there



<P>was no Mrs. Grant.&nbsp; She could not come.&nbsp; Dr. Grant,



<P>professing an indisposition, for which he had little credit



<P>with his fair sister-in-law, could not spare his wife.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dr. Grant is ill," said she, with mock solemnity.



<P>"He has been ill ever since he did not eat any of the



<P>pheasant today.&nbsp; He fancied it tough, sent away his plate,



<P>and has been suffering ever since".

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here was disappointment!&nbsp; Mrs. Grant's non-attendance



<P>was sad indeed.&nbsp; Her pleasant manners and cheerful



<P>conformity made her always valuable amongst them;



<P>but _now_ she was absolutely necessary.&nbsp; They could not act,



<P>they could not rehearse with any satisfaction without her.



<P>The comfort of the whole evening was destroyed.



<P>What was to be done?&nbsp; Tom, as Cottager, was in despair.



<P>After a pause of perplexity, some eyes began to be



<P>turned towards Fanny, and a voice or two to say,



<P>"If Miss Price would be so good as to _read_ the part."



<P>She was immediately surrounded by supplications;



<P>everybody asked it; even Edmund said, "Do, Fanny, if it is



<P>not _very_ disagreeable to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Fanny still hung back.&nbsp; She could not endure the idea



<P>of it.&nbsp; Why was not Miss Crawford to be applied to as well?



<P>Or why had not she rather gone to her own room,



<P>as she had felt to be safest, instead of attending



<P>the rehearsal at all?&nbsp; She had known it would irritate



<P>and distress her; she had known it her duty to keep away.



<P>She was properly punished.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You have only to _read_ the part," said Henry Crawford,



<P>with renewed entreaty.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"And I do believe she can say every word of it,"



<P>added Maria, "for she could put Mrs. Grant right the other



<P>day in twenty places.&nbsp; Fanny, I am sure you know the part."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny could not say she did _not_; and as they all persevered,



<P>as Edmund repeated his wish, and with a look of even



<P>fond dependence on her good-nature, she must yield.



<P>She would do her best.&nbsp; Everybody was satisfied; and she



<P>was left to the tremors of a most palpitating heart,



<P>while the others prepared to begin.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They _did_ begin; and being too much engaged in their



<P>own noise to be struck by an unusual noise in the other



<P>part of the house, had proceeded some way when the door



<P>of the room was thrown open, and Julia, appearing at it,



<P>with a face all aghast, exclaimed, "My father is come!



<P>He is in the hall at this moment."



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 32</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXXII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>Fanny had by no means forgotten Mr. Crawford when she



<P>awoke the next morning; but she remembered the purport



<P>of her note, and was not less sanguine as to its effect



<P>than she had been the night before.&nbsp; If Mr. Crawford would



<P>but go away!&nbsp; That was what she most earnestly desired:



<P>go and take his sister with him, as he was to do,



<P>and as he returned to Mansfield on purpose to do.



<P>And why it was not done already she could not devise,



<P>for Miss Crawford certainly wanted no delay.&nbsp; Fanny had hoped,



<P>in the course of his yesterday's visit, to hear the day named;



<P>but he had only spoken of their journey as what would take



<P>place ere long.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having so satisfactorily settled the conviction her note



<P>would convey, she could not but be astonished to see



<P>Mr. Crawford, as she accidentally did, coming up to the



<P>house again, and at an hour as early as the day before.



<P>His coming might have nothing to do with her, but she



<P>must avoid seeing him if possible; and being then



<P>on her way upstairs, she resolved there to remain,



<P>during the whole of his visit, unless actually sent for;



<P>and as Mrs. Norris was still in the house, there seemed



<P>little danger of her being wanted.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She sat some time in a good deal of agitation, listening,



<P>trembling, and fearing to be sent for every moment;



<P>but as no footsteps approached the East room, she grew



<P>gradually composed, could sit down, and be able to



<P>employ herself, and able to hope that Mr. Crawford had come



<P>and would go without her being obliged to know anything of the



<P>matter.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nearly half an hour had passed, and she was growing



<P>very comfortable, when suddenly the sound of a step



<P>in regular approach was heard; a heavy step, an unusual



<P>step in that part of the house:&nbsp; it was her uncle's;



<P>she knew it as well as his voice; she had trembled at it



<P>as often, and began to tremble again, at the idea of his



<P>coming up to speak to her, whatever might be the subject.



<P>It was indeed Sir Thomas who opened the door and asked



<P>if she were there, and if he might come in.&nbsp; The terror



<P>of his former occasional visits to that room seemed



<P>all renewed, and she felt as if he were going to examine



<P>her again in French and English.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was all attention, however, in placing a chair for him,



<P>and trying to appear honoured; and, in her agitation,



<P>had quite overlooked the deficiencies of her apartment, till he,



<P>stopping short as he entered, said, with much surprise,



<P>"Why have you no fire to-day?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was snow on the ground, and she was sitting in a shawl.



<P>She hesitated.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am not cold, sir:&nbsp; I never sit here long at this time



<P>of year."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"But you have a fire in general?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"How comes this about?&nbsp; Here must be some mistake.



<P>I understood that you had the use of this room by way



<P>of making you perfectly comfortable.&nbsp; In your bedchamber



<P>I know you _cannot_ have a fire.&nbsp; Here is some great



<P>misapprehension which must be rectified.&nbsp; It is highly



<P>unfit for you to sit, be it only half an hour a day,



<P>without a fire.&nbsp; You are not strong.&nbsp; You are chilly.



<P>Your aunt cannot be aware of this."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny would rather have been silent; but being obliged



<P>to speak, she could not forbear, in justice to the aunt



<P>she loved best, from saying something in which the words



<P>"my aunt Norris" were distinguishable.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I understand," cried her uncle, recollecting himself,



<P>and not wanting to hear more:&nbsp; "I understand.&nbsp; Your aunt



<P>Norris has always been an advocate, and very judiciously,



<P>for young people's being brought up without unnecessary



<P>indulgences; but there should be moderation in everything.



<P>She is also very hardy herself, which of course will



<P>influence her in her opinion of the wants of others.



<P>And on another account, too, I can perfectly comprehend.



<P>I know what her sentiments have always been.



<P>The principle was good in itself, but it may have been,



<P>and I believe _has_ _been_, carried too far in your case.



<P>I am aware that there has been sometimes, in some points,



<P>a misplaced distinction; but I think too well of you, Fanny,



<P>to suppose you will ever harbour resentment on that account.



<P>You have an understanding which will prevent you from



<P>receiving things only in part, and judging partially



<P>by the event.&nbsp; You will take in the whole of the past,



<P>you will consider times, persons, and probabilities,



<P>and you will feel that _they_ were not least your



<P>friends who were educating and preparing you for that



<P>mediocrity of condition which _seemed_ to be your lot.



<P>Though their caution may prove eventually unnecessary,



<P>it was kindly meant; and of this you may be assured,



<P>that every advantage of affluence will be doubled by the little



<P>privations and restrictions that may have been imposed.



<P>I am sure you will not disappoint my opinion of you,



<P>by failing at any time to treat your aunt Norris



<P>with the respect and attention that are due to her.



<P>But enough of this.&nbsp; Sit down, my dear.&nbsp; I must speak



<P>to you for a few minutes, but I will not detain



<P>you long."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny obeyed, with eyes cast down and colour rising.



<P>After a moment's pause, Sir Thomas, trying to suppress



<P>a smile, went on.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are not aware, perhaps, that I have had a visitor



<P>this morning.&nbsp; I had not been long in my own room,



<P>after breakfast, when Mr. Crawford was shewn in.



<P>His errand you may probably conjecture."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny's colour grew deeper and deeper; and her uncle,



<P>perceiving that she was embarrassed to a degree that



<P>made either speaking or looking up quite impossible,



<P>turned away his own eyes, and without any farther pause



<P>proceeded in his account of Mr. Crawford's visit.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mr. Crawford's business had been to declare himself



<P>the lover of Fanny, make decided proposals for her,



<P>and entreat the sanction of the uncle, who seemed to stand



<P>in the place of her parents; and he had done it all so well,



<P>so openly, so liberally, so properly, that Sir Thomas,



<P>feeling, moreover, his own replies, and his own remarks



<P>to have been very much to the purpose, was exceedingly



<P>happy to give the particulars of their conversation;



<P>and little aware of what was passing in his niece's mind,



<P>conceived that by such details he must be gratifying her



<P>far more than himself.&nbsp; He talked, therefore, for several



<P>minutes without Fanny's daring to interrupt him.



<P>She had hardly even attained the wish to do it.&nbsp; Her mind



<P>was in too much confusion.&nbsp; She had changed her position;



<P>and, with her eyes fixed intently on one of the windows,



<P>was listening to her uncle in the utmost perturbation



<P>and dismay.&nbsp; For a moment he ceased, but she had barely



<P>become conscious of it, when, rising from his chair, he said,



<P>"And now, Fanny, having performed one part of my commission,



<P>and shewn you everything placed on a basis the most assured



<P>and satisfactory, I may execute the remainder by prevailing



<P>on you to accompany me downstairs, where, though I cannot



<P>but presume on having been no unacceptable companion myself,



<P>I must submit to your finding one still better worth



<P>listening to.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford, as you have perhaps foreseen,



<P>is yet in the house.&nbsp; He is in my room, and hoping to see



<P>you there."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>There was a look, a start, an exclamation on hearing this,



<P>which astonished Sir Thomas; but what was his increase of



<P>astonishment on hearing her exclaim--"Oh! no, sir, I cannot,



<P>indeed I cannot go down to him.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford ought to know--



<P>he must know that:&nbsp; I told him enough yesterday to convince him;



<P>he spoke to me on this subject yesterday, and I told him



<P>without disguise that it was very disagreeable to me,



<P>and quite out of my power to return his good opinion."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I do not catch your meaning," said Sir Thomas, sitting



<P>down again.&nbsp; "Out of your power to return his good opinion?



<P>What is all this?&nbsp; I know he spoke to you yesterday,



<P>and (as far as I understand) received as much encouragement



<P>to proceed as a well-judging young woman could permit



<P>herself to give.&nbsp; I was very much pleased with what I



<P>collected to have been your behaviour on the occasion;



<P>it shewed a discretion highly to be commended.&nbsp; But now,



<P>when he has made his overtures so properly, and honourably--



<P>what are your scruples _now_?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are mistaken, sir," cried Fanny, forced by the anxiety



<P>of the moment even to tell her uncle that he was wrong;



<P>"you are quite mistaken.&nbsp; How could Mr. Crawford say



<P>such a thing?&nbsp; I gave him no encouragement yesterday.



<P>On the contrary, I told him, I cannot recollect my exact words,



<P>but I am sure I told him that I would not listen to him,



<P>that it was very unpleasant to me in every respect, and that



<P>I begged him never to talk to me in that manner again.



<P>I am sure I said as much as that and more; and I should



<P>have said still more, if I had been quite certain of his



<P>meaning anything seriously; but I did not like to be,



<P>I could not bear to be, imputing more than might be intended.



<P>I thought it might all pass for nothing with _him_."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could say no more; her breath was almost gone.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Am I to understand," said Sir Thomas, after a few moments'



<P>silence, "that you mean to _refuse_ Mr. Crawford?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Refuse him?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Refuse Mr. Crawford!&nbsp; Upon what plea?&nbsp; For what reason?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I--I cannot like him, sir, well enough to marry him."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"This is very strange!" said Sir Thomas, in a voice of



<P>calm displeasure.&nbsp; "There is something in this which my



<P>comprehension does not reach.&nbsp; Here is a young man wishing



<P>to pay his addresses to you, with everything to recommend him:



<P>not merely situation in life, fortune, and character,



<P>but with more than common agreeableness, with address



<P>and conversation pleasing to everybody.&nbsp; And he is not an



<P>acquaintance of to-day; you have now known him some time.



<P>His sister, moreover, is your intimate friend, and he has



<P>been doing _that_ for your brother, which I should suppose



<P>would have been almost sufficient recommendation to you,



<P>had there been no other.&nbsp; It is very uncertain when my



<P>interest might have got William on.&nbsp; He has done it already."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," said Fanny, in a faint voice, and looking down



<P>with fresh shame; and she did feel almost ashamed



<P>of herself, after such a picture as her uncle had drawn,



<P>for not liking Mr. Crawford.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must have been aware," continued Sir Thomas presently,



<P>"you must have been some time aware of a particularity



<P>in Mr. Crawford's manners to you.&nbsp; This cannot have taken



<P>you by surprise.&nbsp; You must have observed his attentions;



<P>and though you always received them very properly (I have



<P>no accusation to make on that head), I never perceived them



<P>to be unpleasant to you.&nbsp; I am half inclined to think,



<P>Fanny, that you do not quite know your own feelings."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes, sir! indeed I do.&nbsp; His attentions were always--



<P>what I did not like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas looked at her with deeper surprise.



<P>"This is beyond me," said he.&nbsp; "This requires explanation.



<P>Young as you are, and having seen scarcely any one,



<P>it is hardly possible that your affections--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He paused and eyed her fixedly.&nbsp; He saw her lips



<P>formed into a _no_, though the sound was inarticulate,



<P>but her face was like scarlet.&nbsp; That, however, in so



<P>modest a girl, might be very compatible with innocence;



<P>and chusing at least to appear satisfied, he quickly added,



<P>"No, no, I know _that_ is quite out of the question;



<P>quite impossible.&nbsp; Well, there is nothing more to be said."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And for a few minutes he did say nothing.&nbsp; He was deep



<P>in thought.&nbsp; His niece was deep in thought likewise, trying to



<P>harden and prepare herself against farther questioning.



<P>She would rather die than own the truth; and she hoped,



<P>by a little reflection, to fortify herself beyond



<P>betraying it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Independently of the interest which Mr. Crawford's _choice_



<P>seemed to justify" said Sir Thomas, beginning again,



<P>and very composedly, "his wishing to marry at all so



<P>early is recommendatory to me.&nbsp; I am an advocate for



<P>early marriages, where there are means in proportion,



<P>and would have every young man, with a sufficient income,



<P>settle as soon after four-and-twenty as he can.&nbsp; This is



<P>so much my opinion, that I am sorry to think how little



<P>likely my own eldest son, your cousin, Mr. Bertram,



<P>is to marry early; but at present, as far as I can judge,



<P>matrimony makes no part of his plans or thoughts.



<P>I wish he were more likely to fix."&nbsp; Here was a glance



<P>at Fanny.&nbsp; "Edmund, I consider, from his dispositions



<P>and habits, as much more likely to marry early than



<P>his brother.&nbsp; _He_, indeed, I have lately thought,



<P>has seen the woman he could love, which, I am convinced,



<P>my eldest son has not.&nbsp; Am I right?&nbsp; Do you agree with me,



<P>my dear?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was gently, but it was calmly said, and Sir Thomas was



<P>easy on the score of the cousins.&nbsp; But the removal of his



<P>alarm did his niece no service:&nbsp; as her unaccountableness



<P>was confirmed his displeasure increased; and getting up



<P>and walking about the room with a frown, which Fanny could



<P>picture to herself, though she dared not lift up her eyes,



<P>he shortly afterwards, and in a voice of authority, said,



<P>"Have you any reason, child, to think ill of Mr. Crawford's



<P>temper?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, sir."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She longed to add, "But of his principles I have"; but her



<P>heart sunk under the appalling prospect of discussion,



<P>explanation, and probably non-conviction. Her ill opinion



<P>of him was founded chiefly on observations, which,



<P>for her cousins' sake, she could scarcely dare mention



<P>to their father.&nbsp; Maria and Julia, and especially Maria,



<P>were so closely implicated in Mr. Crawford's misconduct,



<P>that she could not give his character, such as she



<P>believed it, without betraying them.&nbsp; She had hoped that,



<P>to a man like her uncle, so discerning, so honourable,



<P>so good, the simple acknowledgment of settled _dislike_



<P>on her side would have been sufficient.&nbsp; To her infinite



<P>grief she found it was not.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas came towards the table where she sat



<P>in trembling wretchedness, and with a good deal of



<P>cold sternness, said, "It is of no use, I perceive,



<P>to talk to you.&nbsp; We had better put an end to this



<P>most mortifying conference.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford must not be



<P>kept longer waiting.&nbsp; I will, therefore, only add,



<P>as thinking it my duty to mark my opinion of your conduct,



<P>that you have disappointed every expectation I had formed,



<P>and proved yourself of a character the very reverse



<P>of what I had supposed.&nbsp; For I _had_, Fanny, as I think



<P>my behaviour must have shewn, formed a very favourable



<P>opinion of you from the period of my return to England.



<P>I had thought you peculiarly free from wilfulness of temper,



<P>self-conceit, and every tendency to that independence



<P>of spirit which prevails so much in modern days,



<P>even in young women, and which in young women is offensive



<P>and disgusting beyond all common offence.&nbsp; But you



<P>have now shewn me that you can be wilful and perverse;



<P>that you can and will decide for yourself, without any



<P>consideration or deference for those who have surely some



<P>right to guide you, without even asking their advice.



<P>You have shewn yourself very, very different from anything



<P>that I had imagined.&nbsp; The advantage or disadvantage of



<P>your family, of your parents, your brothers and sisters,



<P>never seems to have had a moment's share in your thoughts



<P>on this occasion.&nbsp; How _they_ might be benefited,



<P>how _they_ must rejoice in such an establishment for you,



<P>is nothing to _you_.&nbsp; You think only of yourself,



<P>and because you do not feel for Mr. Crawford exactly what a



<P>young heated fancy imagines to be necessary for happiness,



<P>you resolve to refuse him at once, without wishing



<P>even for a little time to consider of it, a little more



<P>time for cool consideration, and for really examining



<P>your own inclinations; and are, in a wild fit of folly,



<P>throwing away from you such an opportunity of being



<P>settled in life, eligibly, honourably, nobly settled,



<P>as will, probably, never occur to you again.&nbsp; Here is a



<P>young man of sense, of character, of temper, of manners,



<P>and of fortune, exceedingly attached to you, and seeking



<P>your hand in the most handsome and disinterested way;



<P>and let me tell you, Fanny, that you may live eighteen years



<P>longer in the world without being addressed by a man of half



<P>Mr. Crawford's estate, or a tenth part of his merits.



<P>Gladly would I have bestowed either of my own daughters



<P>on him.&nbsp; Maria is nobly married; but had Mr. Crawford



<P>sought Julia's hand, I should have given it to him with



<P>superior and more heartfelt satisfaction than I gave



<P>Maria's to Mr. Rushworth."&nbsp; After half a moment's pause:



<P>"And I should have been very much surprised had either



<P>of my daughters, on receiving a proposal of marriage at any



<P>time which might carry with it only _half_ the eligibility



<P>of _this_, immediately and peremptorily, and without paying



<P>my opinion or my regard the compliment of any consultation,



<P>put a decided negative on it.&nbsp; I should have been much



<P>surprised and much hurt by such a proceeding.&nbsp; I should



<P>have thought it a gross violation of duty and respect.



<P>_You_ are not to be judged by the same rule.&nbsp; You do not



<P>owe me the duty of a child.&nbsp; But, Fanny, if your heart



<P>can acquit you of _ingratitude_--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He ceased.&nbsp; Fanny was by this time crying so bitterly that,



<P>angry as he was, he would not press that article farther.



<P>Her heart was almost broke by such a picture of what



<P>she appeared to him; by such accusations, so heavy,



<P>so multiplied, so rising in dreadful gradation!



<P>Self-willed, obstinate, selfish, and ungrateful.



<P>He thought her all this.&nbsp; She had deceived his expectations;



<P>she had lost his good opinion.&nbsp; What was to become



<P>of her?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I am very sorry," said she inarticulately, through her tears,



<P>"I am very sorry indeed."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Sorry! yes, I hope you are sorry; and you will probably



<P>have reason to be long sorry for this day's transactions."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If it were possible for me to do otherwise" said she,



<P>with another strong effort; "but I am so perfectly



<P>convinced that I could never make him happy, and that I



<P>should be miserable myself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Another burst of tears; but in spite of that burst,



<P>and in spite of that great black word _miserable_,



<P>which served to introduce it, Sir Thomas began to think



<P>a little relenting, a little change of inclination,



<P>might have something to do with it; and to augur favourably



<P>from the personal entreaty of the young man himself.



<P>He knew her to be very timid, and exceedingly nervous;



<P>and thought it not improbable that her mind might be



<P>in such a state as a little time, a little pressing,



<P>a little patience, and a little impatience, a judicious



<P>mixture of all on the lover's side, might work their



<P>usual effect on.&nbsp; If the gentleman would but persevere,



<P>if he had but love enough to persevere, Sir Thomas began



<P>to have hopes; and these reflections having passed across



<P>his mind and cheered it, "Well," said he, in a tone



<P>of becoming gravity, but of less anger, "well, child,



<P>dry up your tears.&nbsp; There is no use in these tears;



<P>they can do no good.&nbsp; You must now come downstairs with me.



<P>Mr. Crawford has been kept waiting too long already.



<P>You must give him your own answer:&nbsp; we cannot expect him
