<P>to be satisfied with less; and you only can explain to him



<P>the grounds of that misconception of your sentiments, which,



<P>unfortunately for himself, he certainly has imbibed.&nbsp; I am



<P>totally unequal to it."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Fanny shewed such reluctance, such misery, at the



<P>idea of going down to him, that Sir Thomas, after a



<P>little consideration, judged it better to indulge her.



<P>His hopes from both gentleman and lady suffered a small



<P>depression in consequence; but when he looked at his niece,



<P>and saw the state of feature and complexion which her



<P>crying had brought her into, he thought there might



<P>be as much lost as gained by an immediate interview.



<P>With a few words, therefore, of no particular meaning,



<P>he walked off by himself, leaving his poor niece to sit



<P>and cry over what had passed, with very wretched feelings

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her mind was all disorder.&nbsp; The past, present, future,



<P>everything was terrible.&nbsp; But her uncle's anger gave



<P>her the severest pain of all.&nbsp; Selfish and ungrateful!



<P>to have appeared so to him!&nbsp; She was miserable for ever.



<P>She had no one to take her part, to counsel, or speak



<P>for her.&nbsp; Her only friend was absent.&nbsp; He might have



<P>softened his father; but all, perhaps all, would think



<P>her selfish and ungrateful.&nbsp; She might have to endure



<P>the reproach again and again; she might hear it, or see it,



<P>or know it to exist for ever in every connexion about her.



<P>She could not but feel some resentment against Mr. Crawford;



<P>yet, if he really loved her, and were unhappy too!



<P>It was all wretchedness together.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In about a quarter of an hour her uncle returned;



<P>she was almost ready to faint at the sight of him.



<P>He spoke calmly, however, without austerity, without reproach,



<P>and she revived a little.&nbsp; There was comfort, too,



<P>in his words, as well as his manner, for he began with,



<P>"Mr. Crawford is gone:&nbsp; he has just left me.&nbsp; I need not



<P>repeat what has passed.&nbsp; I do not want to add to anything



<P>you may now be feeling, by an account of what he has felt.



<P>Suffice it, that he has behaved in the most gentlemanlike



<P>and generous manner, and has confirmed me in a most



<P>favourable opinion of his understanding, heart, and temper.



<P>Upon my representation of what you were suffering,



<P>he immediately, and with the greatest delicacy,



<P>ceased to urge to see you for the present."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here Fanny, who had looked up, looked down again.&nbsp; "Of course,"



<P>continued her uncle, "it cannot be supposed but that he should



<P>request to speak with you alone, be it only for five minutes;



<P>a request too natural, a claim too just to be denied.



<P>But there is no time fixed; perhaps to-morrow, or whenever



<P>your spirits are composed enough.&nbsp; For the present you



<P>have only to tranquillise yourself.&nbsp; Check these tears;



<P>they do but exhaust you.&nbsp; If, as I am willing to suppose,



<P>you wish to shew me any observance, you will not give



<P>way to these emotions, but endeavour to reason yourself



<P>into a stronger frame of mind.&nbsp; I advise you to go out:



<P>the air will do you good; go out for an hour on the gravel;



<P>you will have the shrubbery to yourself, and will be the



<P>better for air and exercise.&nbsp; And, Fanny" (turning back



<P>again for a moment), "I shall make no mention below of



<P>what has passed; I shall not even tell your aunt Bertram.



<P>There is no occasion for spreading the disappointment;



<P>say nothing about it yourself."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was an order to be most joyfully obeyed; this was



<P>an act of kindness which Fanny felt at her heart.



<P>To be spared from her aunt Norris's interminable



<P>reproaches! he left her in a glow of gratitude.



<P>Anything might be bearable rather than such reproaches.



<P>Even to see Mr. Crawford would be less overpowering.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She walked out directly, as her uncle recommended,



<P>and followed his advice throughout, as far as she could;



<P>did check her tears; did earnestly try to compose her spirits



<P>and strengthen her mind.&nbsp; She wished to prove to him that she



<P>did desire his comfort, and sought to regain his favour;



<P>and he had given her another strong motive for exertion,



<P>in keeping the whole affair from the knowledge of her aunts.



<P>Not to excite suspicion by her look or manner was now



<P>an object worth attaining; and she felt equal to almost



<P>anything that might save her from her aunt Norris.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She was struck, quite struck, when, on returning from her



<P>walk and going into the East room again, the first thing



<P>which caught her eye was a fire lighted and burning.



<P>A fire! it seemed too much; just at that time to be giving



<P>her such an indulgence was exciting even painful gratitude.



<P>She wondered that Sir Thomas could have leisure to think



<P>of such a trifle again; but she soon found, from the voluntary



<P>information of the housemaid, who came in to attend it,



<P>that so it was to be every day.&nbsp; Sir Thomas had given



<P>orders for it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I must be a brute, indeed, if I can be really ungrateful!"



<P>said she, in soliloquy.&nbsp; "Heaven defend me from



<P>being ungrateful!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She saw nothing more of her uncle, nor of her aunt Norris,



<P>till they met at dinner.&nbsp; Her uncle's behaviour to her



<P>was then as nearly as possible what it had been before;



<P>she was sure he did not mean there should be any change,



<P>and that it was only her own conscience that could fancy any;



<P>but her aunt was soon quarrelling with her; and when she



<P>found how much and how unpleasantly her having only walked



<P>out without her aunt's knowledge could be dwelt on,



<P>she felt all the reason she had to bless the kindness



<P>which saved her from the same spirit of reproach,



<P>exerted on a more momentous subject.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If I had known you were going out, I should have got you



<P>just to go as far as my house with some orders for Nanny,"



<P>said she, "which I have since, to my very great inconvenience,



<P>been obliged to go and carry myself.&nbsp; I could very ill



<P>spare the time, and you might have saved me the trouble,



<P>if you would only have been so good as to let us know you



<P>were going out.&nbsp; It would have made no difference to you,



<P>I suppose, whether you had walked in the shrubbery or gone



<P>to my house."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I recommended the shrubbery to Fanny as the driest place,"



<P>said Sir Thomas.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh!" said Mrs. Norris, with a moment's check,



<P>"that was very kind of you, Sir Thomas; but you do not



<P>know how dry the path is to my house.&nbsp; Fanny would have



<P>had quite as good a walk there, I assure you, with the



<P>advantage of being of some use, and obliging her aunt:



<P>it is all her fault.&nbsp; If she would but have let us know



<P>she was going out but there is a something about Fanny,



<P>I have often observed it before--she likes to go her



<P>own way to work; she does not like to be dictated to;



<P>she takes her own independent walk whenever she can;



<P>she certainly has a little spirit of secrecy, and independence,



<P>and nonsense, about her, which I would advise her to get



<P>the better of."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As a general reflection on Fanny, Sir Thomas thought



<P>nothing could be more unjust, though he had been so lately



<P>expressing the same sentiments himself, and he tried to turn



<P>the conversation:&nbsp; tried repeatedly before he could succeed;



<P>for Mrs. Norris had not discernment enough to perceive,



<P>either now, or at any other time, to what degree he



<P>thought well of his niece, or how very far he was from



<P>wishing to have his own children's merits set off by



<P>the depreciation of hers.&nbsp; She was talking _at_ Fanny,



<P>and resenting this private walk half through the dinner.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was over, however, at last; and the evening set in with



<P>more composure to Fanny, and more cheerfulness of spirits



<P>than she could have hoped for after so stormy a morning;



<P>but she trusted, in the first place, that she had done right:



<P>that her judgment had not misled her.&nbsp; For the purity



<P>of her intentions she could answer; and she was willing



<P>to hope, secondly, that her uncle's displeasure was abating,



<P>and would abate farther as he considered the matter with



<P>more impartiality, and felt, as a good man must feel,



<P>how wretched, and how unpardonable, how hopeless,



<P>and how wicked it was to marry without affection.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>When the meeting with which she was threatened for the



<P>morrow was past, she could not but flatter herself that



<P>the subject would be finally concluded, and Mr. Crawford



<P>once gone from Mansfield, that everything would soon



<P>be as if no such subject had existed.&nbsp; She would not,



<P>could not believe, that Mr. Crawford's affection for her



<P>could distress him long; his mind was not of that sort.



<P>London would soon bring its cure.&nbsp; In London he would



<P>soon learn to wonder at his infatuation, and be thankful



<P>for the right reason in her which had saved him from its



<P>evil consequences.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>While Fanny's mind was engaged in these sort of hopes,



<P>her uncle was, soon after tea, called out of the room;



<P>an occurrence too common to strike her, and she thought nothing



<P>of it till the butler reappeared ten minutes afterwards,



<P>and advancing decidedly towards herself, said, "Sir Thomas



<P>wishes to speak with you, ma'am, in his own room."



<P>Then it occurred to her what might be going on; a suspicion



<P>rushed over her mind which drove the colour from her cheeks;



<P>but instantly rising, she was preparing to obey, when Mrs. Norris



<P>called out, "Stay, stay, Fanny! what are you about? where



<P>are you going? don't be in such a hurry.&nbsp; Depend upon it,



<P>it is not you who are wanted; depend upon it, it is me"



<P>(looking at the butler); "but you are so very eager to put



<P>yourself forward.&nbsp; What should Sir Thomas want you for?



<P>It is me, Baddeley, you mean; I am coming this moment.



<P>You mean me, Baddeley, I am sure; Sir Thomas wants me,



<P>not Miss Price."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>But Baddeley was stout.&nbsp; "No, ma'am, it is Miss Price;



<P>I am certain of its being Miss Price."&nbsp; And there was



<P>a half-smile with the words, which meant, "I do not think



<P>you would answer the purpose at all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris, much discontented, was obliged to compose



<P>herself to work again; and Fanny, walking off in



<P>agitating consciousness, found herself, as she anticipated,



<P>in another minute alone with Mr. Crawford.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 26</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXVI</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>William's desire of seeing Fanny dance made more than a



<P>momentary impression on his uncle.&nbsp; The hope of an opportunity,



<P>which Sir Thomas had then given, was not given to be thought



<P>of no more.&nbsp; He remained steadily inclined to gratify



<P>so amiable a feeling; to gratify anybody else who might



<P>wish to see Fanny dance, and to give pleasure to the young



<P>people in general; and having thought the matter over,



<P>and taken his resolution in quiet independence,



<P>the result of it appeared the next morning at breakfast,



<P>when, after recalling and commending what his nephew



<P>had said, he added, "I do not like, William, that you



<P>should leave Northamptonshire without this indulgence.



<P>It would give me pleasure to see you both dance.



<P>You spoke of the balls at Northampton.&nbsp; Your cousins have



<P>occasionally attended them; but they would not altogether



<P>suit us now.&nbsp; The fatigue would be too much for your aunt.



<P>I believe we must not think of a Northampton ball.



<P>A dance at home would be more eligible; and if--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Ah, my dear Sir Thomas!" interrupted Mrs. Norris, "I knew



<P>what was coming.&nbsp; I knew what you were going to say.&nbsp; If dear



<P>Julia were at home, or dearest Mrs. Rushworth at Sotherton,



<P>to afford a reason, an occasion for such a thing, you would



<P>be tempted to give the young people a dance at Mansfield.



<P>I know you would.&nbsp; If _they_ were at home to grace



<P>the ball, a ball you would have this very Christmas.



<P>Thank your uncle, William, thank your uncle!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My daughters," replied Sir Thomas, gravely interposing,



<P>"have their pleasures at Brighton, and I hope are very happy;



<P>but the dance which I think of giving at Mansfield



<P>will be for their cousins.&nbsp; Could we be all assembled,



<P>our satisfaction would undoubtedly be more complete,



<P>but the absence of some is not to debar the others



<P>of amusement."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris had not another word to say.&nbsp; She saw decision



<P>in his looks, and her surprise and vexation required



<P>some minutes' silence to be settled into composure.



<P>A ball at such a time!&nbsp; His daughters absent and herself



<P>not consulted!&nbsp; There was comfort, however, soon at hand.



<P>_She_ must be the doer of everything:&nbsp; Lady Bertram



<P>would of course be spared all thought and exertion,



<P>and it would all fall upon _her_.&nbsp; She should have to do



<P>the honours of the evening; and this reflection quickly



<P>restored so much of her good-humour as enabled her to join



<P>in with the others, before their happiness and thanks were



<P>all expressed.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund, William, and Fanny did, in their different ways,



<P>look and speak as much grateful pleasure in the promised



<P>ball as Sir Thomas could desire.&nbsp; Edmund's feelings



<P>were for the other two.&nbsp; His father had never conferred



<P>a favour or shewn a kindness more to his satisfaction.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram was perfectly quiescent and contented,



<P>and had no objections to make.&nbsp; Sir Thomas engaged



<P>for its giving her very little trouble; and she assured



<P>him "that she was not at all afraid of the trouble;



<P>indeed, she could not imagine there would be any."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris was ready with her suggestions as to the rooms he



<P>would think fittest to be used, but found it all prearranged;



<P>and when she would have conjectured and hinted about



<P>the day, it appeared that the day was settled too.



<P>Sir Thomas had been amusing himself with shaping a very



<P>complete outline of the business; and as soon as she



<P>would listen quietly, could read his list of the families



<P>to be invited, from whom he calculated, with all necessary



<P>allowance for the shortness of the notice, to collect



<P>young people enough to form twelve or fourteen couple:



<P>and could detail the considerations which had induced



<P>him to fix on the 22nd as the most eligible day.



<P>William was required to be at Portsmouth on the 24th;



<P>the 22nd would therefore be the last day of his visit;



<P>but where the days were so few it would be unwise to fix



<P>on any earlier.&nbsp; Mrs. Norris was obliged to be satisfied



<P>with thinking just the same, and with having been on the



<P>point of proposing the 22nd herself, as by far the best day



<P>for the purpose.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The ball was now a settled thing, and before the evening



<P>a proclaimed thing to all whom it concerned.&nbsp; Invitations were



<P>sent with despatch, and many a young lady went to bed that



<P>night with her head full of happy cares as well as Fanny.



<P>To her the cares were sometimes almost beyond the happiness;



<P>for young and inexperienced, with small means of choice



<P>and no confidence in her own taste, the "how she



<P>should be dressed" was a point of painful solicitude;



<P>and the almost solitary ornament in her possession,



<P>a very pretty amber cross which William had brought



<P>her from Sicily, was the greatest distress of all,



<P>for she had nothing but a bit of ribbon to fasten it to;



<P>and though she had worn it in that manner once, would it



<P>be allowable at such a time in the midst of all the rich



<P>ornaments which she supposed all the other young ladies



<P>would appear in?&nbsp; And yet not to wear it!&nbsp; William had



<P>wanted to buy her a gold chain too, but the purchase had



<P>been beyond his means, and therefore not to wear the cross



<P>might be mortifying him.&nbsp; These were anxious considerations;



<P>enough to sober her spirits even under the prospect



<P>of a ball given principally for her gratification.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The preparations meanwhile went on, and Lady Bertram continued



<P>to sit on her sofa without any inconvenience from them.



<P>She had some extra visits from the housekeeper, and her



<P>maid was rather hurried in making up a new dress for her:



<P>Sir Thomas gave orders, and Mrs. Norris ran about;



<P>but all this gave _her_ no trouble, and as she had foreseen,



<P>"there was, in fact, no trouble in the business."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund was at this time particularly full of cares:



<P>his mind being deeply occupied in the consideration of two



<P>important events now at hand, which were to fix his fate



<P>in life--ordination and matrimony--events of such a serious



<P>character as to make the ball, which would be very quickly



<P>followed by one of them, appear of less moment in his



<P>eyes than in those of any other person in the house.



<P>On the 23rd he was going to a friend near Peterborough,



<P>in the same situation as himself, and they were to



<P>receive ordination in the course of the Christmas week.



<P>Half his destiny would then be determined, but the other



<P>half might not be so very smoothly wooed.&nbsp; His duties would



<P>be established, but the wife who was to share, and animate,



<P>and reward those duties, might yet be unattainable.



<P>He knew his own mind, but he was not always perfectly assured



<P>of knowing Miss Crawford's. There were points on which they



<P>did not quite agree; there were moments in which she did



<P>not seem propitious; and though trusting altogether to



<P>her affection, so far as to be resolved--almost resolved--



<P>on bringing it to a decision within a very short time,



<P>as soon as the variety of business before him were arranged,



<P>and he knew what he had to offer her, he had many



<P>anxious feelings, many doubting hours as to the result.



<P>His conviction of her regard for him was sometimes very strong;



<P>he could look back on a long course of encouragement,



<P>and she was as perfect in disinterested attachment as



<P>in everything else.&nbsp; But at other times doubt and alarm



<P>intermingled with his hopes; and when he thought of her



<P>acknowledged disinclination for privacy and retirement,



<P>her decided preference of a London life, what could he expect



<P>but a determined rejection? unless it were an acceptance



<P>even more to be deprecated, demanding such sacrifices



<P>of situation and employment on his side as conscience



<P>must forbid.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The issue of all depended on one question.&nbsp; Did she



<P>love him well enough to forego what had used to be



<P>essential points?&nbsp; Did she love him well enough to make



<P>them no longer essential?&nbsp; And this question, which he



<P>was continually repeating to himself, though oftenest



<P>answered with a "Yes," had sometimes its "No."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Miss Crawford was soon to leave Mansfield, and on this



<P>circumstance the "no" and the "yes" had been very recently



<P>in alternation.&nbsp; He had seen her eyes sparkle as she spoke



<P>of the dear friend's letter, which claimed a long visit from



<P>her in London, and of the kindness of Henry, in engaging



<P>to remain where he was till January, that he might convey



<P>her thither; he had heard her speak of the pleasure of such



<P>a journey with an animation which had "no" in every tone.



<P>But this had occurred on the first day of its being settled,



<P>within the first hour of the burst of such enjoyment,



<P>when nothing but the friends she was to visit was before her.



<P>He had since heard her express herself differently,



<P>with other feelings, more chequered feelings:&nbsp; he had heard



<P>her tell Mrs. Grant that she should leave her with regret;



<P>that she began to believe neither the friends nor



<P>the pleasures she was going to were worth those she



<P>left behind; and that though she felt she must go,



<P>and knew she should enjoy herself when once away, she was



<P>already looking forward to being at Mansfield again.



<P>Was there not a "yes" in all this?

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With such matters to ponder over, and arrange, and re-arrange,



<P>Edmund could not, on his own account, think very much



<P>of the evening which the rest of the family were looking



<P>forward to with a more equal degree of strong interest.



<P>Independent of his two cousins' enjoyment in it,



<P>the evening was to him of no higher value than any



<P>other appointed meeting of the two families might be.



<P>In every meeting there was a hope of receiving farther



<P>confirmation of Miss Crawford's attachment; but the whirl



<P>of a ballroom, perhaps, was not particularly favourable



<P>to the excitement or expression of serious feelings.



<P>To engage her early for the two first dances was all the



<P>command of individual happiness which he felt in his power,



<P>and the only preparation for the ball which he could



<P>enter into, in spite of all that was passing around him



<P>on the subject, from morning till night.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Thursday was the day of the ball; and on Wednesday



<P>morning Fanny, still unable to satisfy herself as to what



<P>she ought to wear, determined to seek the counsel of the



<P>more enlightened, and apply to Mrs. Grant and her sister,



<P>whose acknowledged taste would certainly bear her blameless;



<P>and as Edmund and William were gone to Northampton,



<P>and she had reason to think Mr. Crawford likewise out,



<P>she walked down to the Parsonage without much fear of wanting



<P>an opportunity for private discussion; and the privacy of



<P>such a discussion was a most important part of it to Fanny,



<P>being more than half-ashamed of her own solicitude.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She met Miss Crawford within a few yards of the Parsonage,



<P>just setting out to call on her, and as it seemed to her



<P>that her friend, though obliged to insist on turning back,



<P>was unwilling to lose her walk, she explained her business



<P>at once, and observed, that if she would be so kind



<P>as to give her opinion, it might be all talked over as



<P>well without doors as within.&nbsp; Miss Crawford appeared



<P>gratified by the application, and after a moment's thought,



<P>urged Fanny's returning with her in a much more cordial



<P>manner than before, and proposed their going up into



<P>her room, where they might have a comfortable coze,



<P>without disturbing Dr. and Mrs. Grant, who were together



<P>in the drawing-room. It was just the plan to suit Fanny;



<P>and with a great deal of gratitude on her side for such ready



<P>and kind attention, they proceeded indoors, and upstairs,



<P>and were soon deep in the interesting subject.&nbsp; Miss Crawford,



<P>pleased with the appeal, gave her all her best judgment



<P>and taste, made everything easy by her suggestions,



<P>and tried to make everything agreeable by her encouragement.



<P>The dress being settled in all its grander parts--



<P>"But what shall you have by way of necklace?" said Miss



<P>Crawford.&nbsp; "Shall not you wear your brother's cross?"



<P>And as she spoke she was undoing a small parcel,



<P>which Fanny had observed in her hand when they met.



<P>Fanny acknowledged her wishes and doubts on this point:



<P>she did not know how either to wear the cross, or to



<P>refrain from wearing it.&nbsp; She was answered by having



<P>a small trinket-box placed before her, and being requested



<P>to chuse from among several gold chains and necklaces.



<P>Such had been the parcel with which Miss Crawford



<P>was provided, and such the object of her intended visit:



<P>and in the kindest manner she now urged Fanny's taking one



<P>for the cross and to keep for her sake, saying everything



<P>she could think of to obviate the scruples which were



<P>making Fanny start back at first with a look of horror at



<P>the proposal.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You see what a collection I have," said she; "more by half



<P>than I ever use or think of.&nbsp; I do not offer them as new.



<P>I offer nothing but an old necklace.&nbsp; You must forgive



<P>the liberty, and oblige me."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny still resisted, and from her heart.&nbsp; The gift was



<P>too valuable.&nbsp; But Miss Crawford persevered, and argued



<P>the case with so much affectionate earnestness through



<P>all the heads of William and the cross, and the ball,



<P>and herself, as to be finally successful.&nbsp; Fanny found



<P>herself obliged to yield, that she might not be accused



<P>of pride or indifference, or some other littleness;



<P>and having with modest reluctance given her consent,



<P>proceeded to make the selection.&nbsp; She looked and looked,



<P>longing to know which might be least valuable; and was



<P>determined in her choice at last, by fancying there was



<P>one necklace more frequently placed before her eyes than



<P>the rest.&nbsp; It was of gold, prettily worked; and though Fanny



<P>would have preferred a longer and a plainer chain as more



<P>adapted for her purpose, she hoped, in fixing on this,



<P>to be chusing what Miss Crawford least wished to keep.



<P>Miss Crawford smiled her perfect approbation; and hastened



<P>to complete the gift by putting the necklace round her,



<P>and making her see how well it looked.&nbsp; Fanny had not a



<P>word to say against its becomingness, and, excepting what



<P>remained of her scruples, was exceedingly pleased with an



<P>acquisition so very apropos.&nbsp; She would rather, perhaps,



<P>have been obliged to some other person.&nbsp; But this was



<P>an unworthy feeling.&nbsp; Miss Crawford had anticipated her



<P>wants with a kindness which proved her a real friend.



<P>"When I wear this necklace I shall always think of you,"



<P>said she, "and feel how very kind you were."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You must think of somebody else too, when you wear



<P>that necklace," replied Miss Crawford.&nbsp; "You must think



<P>of Henry, for it was his choice in the first place.



<P>He gave it to me, and with the necklace I make over



<P>to you all the duty of remembering the original giver.



<P>It is to be a family remembrancer.&nbsp; The sister is not to be



<P>in your mind without bringing the brother too."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, in great astonishment and confusion, would have



<P>returned the present instantly.&nbsp; To take what had



<P>been the gift of another person, of a brother too,



<P>impossible! it must not be! and with an eagerness and



<P>embarrassment quite diverting to her companion, she laid



<P>down the necklace again on its cotton, and seemed resolved



<P>either to take another or none at all.&nbsp; Miss Crawford



<P>thought she had never seen a prettier consciousness.



<P>"My dear child," said she, laughing, "what are you afraid of?



<P>Do you think Henry will claim the necklace as mine,



<P>and fancy you did not come honestly by it? or are you



<P>imagining he would be too much flattered by seeing



<P>round your lovely throat an ornament which his money



<P>purchased three years ago, before he knew there was such



<P>a throat in the world? or perhaps"--looking archly--



<P>"you suspect a confederacy between us, and that what



<P>I am now doing is with his knowledge and at his desire?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>With the deepest blushes Fanny protested against such



<P>a thought.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, then," replied Miss Crawford more seriously,



<P>but without at all believing her, "to convince me that you



<P>suspect no trick, and are as unsuspicious of compliment



<P>as I have always found you, take the necklace and say



<P>no more about it.&nbsp; Its being a gift of my brother's need



<P>not make the smallest difference in your accepting it,



<P>as I assure you it makes none in my willingness to part



<P>with it.&nbsp; He is always giving me something or other.



<P>I have such innumerable presents from him that it is quite



<P>impossible for me to value or for him to remember half.



<P>And as for this necklace, I do not suppose I have worn it



<P>six times:&nbsp; it is very pretty, but I never think of it;



<P>and though you would be most heartily welcome to any



<P>other in my trinket-box, you have happened to fix on



<P>the very one which, if I have a choice, I would rather



<P>part with and see in your possession than any other.



<P>Say no more against it, I entreat you.&nbsp; Such a trifle is



<P>not worth half so many words."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny dared not make any farther opposition; and with



<P>renewed but less happy thanks accepted the necklace again,



<P>for there was an expression in Miss Crawford's eyes



<P>which she could not be satisfied with.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was impossible for her to be insensible of Mr. Crawford's



<P>change of manners.&nbsp; She had long seen it.&nbsp; He evidently



<P>tried to please her:&nbsp; he was gallant, he was attentive,



<P>he was something like what he had been to her cousins:



<P>he wanted, she supposed, to cheat her of her tranquillity



<P>as he had cheated them; and whether he might not have some



<P>concern in this necklace--she could not be convinced that



<P>he had not, for Miss Crawford, complaisant as a sister,



<P>was careless as a woman and a friend.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Reflecting and doubting, and feeling that the possession



<P>of what she had so much wished for did not bring much



<P>satisfaction, she now walked home again, with a change rather



<P>than a diminution of cares since her treading that path before.



<P>

<HR WIDTH="100%">

</BODY>

</HTML>



<HTML>

<HEAD>

   <META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

   <META NAME="Author" CONTENT="Yuan Ping">

   <META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="Mozilla/4.04 [en] (Win95; I) [Netscape]">

   <TITLE>Chapter 27</TITLE>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXVII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>On reaching home Fanny went immediately upstairs to



<P>deposit this unexpected acquisition, this doubtful good



<P>of a necklace, in some favourite box in the East room,



<P>which held all her smaller treasures; but on opening



<P>the door, what was her surprise to find her cousin Edmund



<P>there writing at the table!&nbsp; Such a sight having never



<P>occurred before, was almost as wonderful as it was welcome.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fanny," said he directly, leaving his seat and his pen,



<P>and meeting her with something in his hand, "I beg



<P>your pardon for being here.&nbsp; I came to look for you,



<P>and after waiting a little while in hope of your coming in,



<P>was making use of your inkstand to explain my errand.



<P>You will find the beginning of a note to yourself;



<P>but I can now speak my business, which is merely to beg



<P>your acceptance of this little trifle--a chain for



<P>William's cross.&nbsp; You ought to have had it a week ago,



<P>but there has been a delay from my brother's not



<P>being in town by several days so soon as I expected;



<P>and I have only just now received it at Northampton.



<P>I hope you will like the chain itself, Fanny.&nbsp; I endeavoured



<P>to consult the simplicity of your taste; but, at any rate,



<P>I know you will be kind to my intentions, and consider it,



<P>as it really is, a token of the love of one of your



<P>oldest friends."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>And so saying, he was hurrying away, before Fanny,



<P>overpowered by a thousand feelings of pain and pleasure,



<P>could attempt to speak; but quickened by one sovereign wish,



<P>she then called out, "Oh! cousin, stop a moment,



<P>pray stop!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He turned back.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I cannot attempt to thank you," she continued, in a



<P>very agitated manner; "thanks are out of the question.



<P>I feel much more than I can possibly express.



<P>Your goodness in thinking of me in such a way is beyond--



<P>"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If that is all you have to say, Fanny" smiling and turning



<P>away again.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, no, it is not.&nbsp; I want to consult you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Almost unconsciously she had now undone the parcel he



<P>had just put into her hand, and seeing before her,



<P>in all the niceness of jewellers' packing, a plain



<P>gold chain, perfectly simple and neat, she could not help



<P>bursting forth again, "Oh, this is beautiful indeed!



<P>This is the very thing, precisely what I wished for!



<P>This is the only ornament I have ever had a desire to possess.



<P>It will exactly suit my cross.&nbsp; They must and shall be



<P>worn together.&nbsp; It comes, too, in such an acceptable moment.



<P>Oh, cousin, you do not know how acceptable it is."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear Fanny, you feel these things a great deal too much.



<P>I am most happy that you like the chain, and that it



<P>should be here in time for to-morrow; but your thanks are



<P>far beyond the occasion.&nbsp; Believe me, I have no pleasure



<P>in the world superior to that of contributing to yours.



<P>No, I can safely say, I have no pleasure so complete,



<P>so unalloyed.&nbsp; It is without a drawback."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Upon such expressions of affection Fanny could have



<P>lived an hour without saying another word; but Edmund,



<P>after waiting a moment, obliged her to bring down her



<P>mind from its heavenly flight by saying, "But what is it



<P>that you want to consult me about?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was about the necklace, which she was now most earnestly



<P>longing to return, and hoped to obtain his approbation



<P>of her doing.&nbsp; She gave the history of her recent visit,



<P>and now her raptures might well be over; for Edmund was so



<P>struck with the circumstance, so delighted with what Miss



<P>Crawford had done, so gratified by such a coincidence



<P>of conduct between them, that Fanny could not but admit



<P>the superior power of one pleasure over his own mind,



<P>though it might have its drawback.&nbsp; It was some time



<P>before she could get his attention to her plan, or any



<P>answer to her demand of his opinion:&nbsp; he was in a reverie



<P>of fond reflection, uttering only now and then a few



<P>half-sentences of praise; but when he did awake and understand,



<P>he was very decided in opposing what she wished.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Return the necklace!&nbsp; No, my dear Fanny, upon no account.



<P>It would be mortifying her severely.&nbsp; There can hardly



<P>be a more unpleasant sensation than the having anything



<P>returned on our hands which we have given with a reasonable



<P>hope of its contributing to the comfort of a friend.



<P>Why should she lose a pleasure which she has shewn herself



<P>so deserving of?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"If it had been given to me in the first instance,"



<P>said Fanny, "I should not have thought of returning it;



<P>but being her brother's present, is not it fair to suppose



<P>that she would rather not part with it, when it is



<P>not wanted?"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"She must not suppose it not wanted, not acceptable,



<P>at least:&nbsp; and its having been originally her brother's



<P>gift makes no difference; for as she was not prevented



<P>from offering, nor you from taking it on that account,



<P>it ought not to prevent you from keeping it.&nbsp; No doubt it



<P>is handsomer than mine, and fitter for a ballroom."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, it is not handsomer, not at all handsomer



<P>in its way, and, for my purpose, not half so fit.



<P>The chain will agree with William's cross beyond



<P>all comparison better than the necklace."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"For one night, Fanny, for only one night, if it _be_



<P>a sacrifice; I am sure you will, upon consideration,



<P>make that sacrifice rather than give pain to one who has been



<P>so studious of your comfort.&nbsp; Miss Crawford's attentions



<P>to you have been--not more than you were justly entitled to--



<P>I am the last person to think that _could_ _be_,



<P>but they have been invariable; and to be returning them



<P>with what must have something the _air_ of ingratitude,



<P>though I know it could never have the _meaning_, is not



<P>in your nature, I am sure.&nbsp; Wear the necklace, as you



<P>are engaged to do, to-morrow evening, and let the chain,



<P>which was not ordered with any reference to the ball,



<P>be kept for commoner occasions.&nbsp; This is my advice.



<P>I would not have the shadow of a coolness between the two whose



<P>intimacy I have been observing with the greatest pleasure,



<P>and in whose characters there is so much general resemblance



<P>in true generosity and natural delicacy as to make the few



<P>slight differences, resulting principally from situation,



<P>no reasonable hindrance to a perfect friendship.&nbsp; I would



<P>not have the shadow of a coolness arise," he repeated,



<P>his voice sinking a little, "between the two dearest objects



<P>I have on earth."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was gone as he spoke; and Fanny remained to tranquillise



<P>herself as she could.&nbsp; She was one of his two dearest--



<P>that must support her.&nbsp; But the other:&nbsp; the first!



<P>She had never heard him speak so openly before, and though



<P>it told her no more than what she had long perceived,



<P>it was a stab, for it told of his own convictions and views.



<P>They were decided.&nbsp; He would marry Miss Crawford.



<P>It was a stab, in spite of every long-standing expectation;



<P>and she was obliged to repeat again and again, that she



<P>was one of his two dearest, before the words gave



<P>her any sensation.&nbsp; Could she believe Miss Crawford to



<P>deserve him, it would be--oh, how different would it be--



<P>how far more tolerable!&nbsp; But he was deceived in her:



<P>he gave her merits which she had not; her faults were



<P>what they had ever been, but he saw them no longer.



<P>Till she had shed many tears over this deception,



<P>Fanny could not subdue her agitation; and the dejection



<P>which followed could only be relieved by the influence of



<P>fervent prayers for his happiness.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was her intention, as she felt it to be her duty,



<P>to try to overcome all that was excessive, all that



<P>bordered on selfishness, in her affection for Edmund.



<P>To call or to fancy it a loss, a disappointment, would be



<P>a presumption for which she had not words strong enough to



<P>satisfy her own humility.&nbsp; To think of him as Miss Crawford



<P>might be justified in thinking, would in her be insanity.



<P>To her he could be nothing under any circumstances;



<P>nothing dearer than a friend.&nbsp; Why did such an idea occur



<P>to her even enough to be reprobated and forbidden?&nbsp; It ought



<P>not to have touched on the confines of her imagination.



<P>She would endeavour to be rational, and to deserve



<P>the right of judging of Miss Crawford's character,



<P>and the privilege of true solicitude for him by a sound



<P>intellect and an honest heart.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She had all the heroism of principle, and was determined



<P>to do her duty; but having also many of the feelings of youth



<P>and nature, let her not be much wondered at, if, after making



<P>all these good resolutions on the side of self-government,



<P>she seized the scrap of paper on which Edmund had begun



<P>writing to her, as a treasure beyond all her hopes,



<P>and reading with the tenderest emotion these words,



<P>"My very dear Fanny, you must do me the favour to accept"



<P>locked it up with the chain, as the dearest part of the gift.



<P>It was the only thing approaching to a letter which she



<P>had ever received from him; she might never receive another;



<P>it was impossible that she ever should receive another



<P>so perfectly gratifying in the occasion and the style.



<P>Two lines more prized had never fallen from the pen



<P>of the most distinguished author--never more completely



<P>blessed the researches of the fondest biographer.



<P>The enthusiasm of a woman's love is even beyond



<P>the biographer's. To her, the handwriting itself,



<P>independent of anything it may convey, is a blessedness.



<P>Never were such characters cut by any other human being



<P>as Edmund's commonest handwriting gave!&nbsp; This specimen,



<P>written in haste as it was, had not a fault; and there



<P>was a felicity in the flow of the first four words,



<P>in the arrangement of "My very dear Fanny," which she



<P>could have looked at for ever.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Having regulated her thoughts and comforted her feelings



<P>by this happy mixture of reason and weakness, she was able



<P>in due time to go down and resume her usual employments



<P>near her aunt Bertram, and pay her the usual observances



<P>without any apparent want of spirits.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Thursday, predestined to hope and enjoyment, came; and opened



<P>with more kindness to Fanny than such self-willed,



<P>unmanageable days often volunteer, for soon after breakfast



<P>a very friendly note was brought from Mr. Crawford



<P>to William, stating that as he found himself obliged



<P>to go to London on the morrow for a few days, he could



<P>not help trying to procure a companion; and therefore



<P>hoped that if William could make up his mind to leave



<P>Mansfield half a day earlier than had been proposed,



<P>he would accept a place in his carriage.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford meant



<P>to be in town by his uncle's accustomary late dinner-hour,



<P>and William was invited to dine with him at the Admiral's.



<P>The proposal was a very pleasant one to William himself,



<P>who enjoyed the idea of travelling post with four horses,



<P>and such a good-humoured, agreeable friend; and, in likening



<P>it to going up with despatches, was saying at once everything



<P>in favour of its happiness and dignity which his imagination



<P>could suggest; and Fanny, from a different motive,



<P>was exceedingly pleased; for the original plan was that



<P>William should go up by the mail from Northampton the



<P>following night, which would not have allowed him an hour's



<P>rest before he must have got into a Portsmouth coach;



<P>and though this offer of Mr. Crawford's would rob her



<P>of many hours of his company, she was too happy in having



<P>William spared from the fatigue of such a journey,



<P>to think of anything else.&nbsp; Sir Thomas approved of it



<P>for another reason.&nbsp; His nephew's introduction to Admiral



<P>Crawford might be of service.&nbsp; The Admiral, he believed,



<P>had interest.&nbsp; Upon the whole, it was a very joyous note.



<P>Fanny's spirits lived on it half the morning, deriving



<P>some accession of pleasure from its writer being himself to go



<P>away.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As for the ball, so near at hand, she had too many



<P>agitations and fears to have half the enjoyment in



<P>anticipation which she ought to have had, or must have



<P>been supposed to have by the many young ladies looking



<P>forward to the same event in situations more at ease,



<P>but under circumstances of less novelty, less interest,



<P>less peculiar gratification, than would be attributed



<P>to her.&nbsp; Miss Price, known only by name to half the



<P>people invited, was now to make her first appearance,



<P>and must be regarded as the queen of the evening.



<P>Who could be happier than Miss Price?&nbsp; But Miss Price



<P>had not been brought up to the trade of _coming_ _out_;



<P>and had she known in what light this ball was, in general,



<P>considered respecting her, it would very much have lessened



<P>her comfort by increasing the fears she already had of doing



<P>wrong and being looked at.&nbsp; To dance without much observation



<P>or any extraordinary fatigue, to have strength and partners



<P>for about half the evening, to dance a little with Edmund,



<P>and not a great deal with Mr. Crawford, to see William



<P>enjoy himself, and be able to keep away from her aunt Norris,



<P>was the height of her ambition, and seemed to comprehend



<P>her greatest possibility of happiness.&nbsp; As these were



<P>the best of her hopes, they could not always prevail;



<P>and in the course of a long morning, spent principally



<P>with her two aunts, she was often under the influence



<P>of much less sanguine views.&nbsp; William, determined to



<P>make this last day a day of thorough enjoyment,



<P>was out snipe-shooting; Edmund, she had too much reason



<P>to suppose, was at the Parsonage; and left alone to bear



<P>the worrying of Mrs. Norris, who was cross because the



<P>housekeeper would have her own way with the supper,



<P>and whom _she_ could not avoid though the housekeeper might,



<P>Fanny was worn down at last to think everything an evil



<P>belonging to the ball, and when sent off with a parting worry



<P>to dress, moved as languidly towards her own room, and felt



<P>as incapable of happiness as if she had been allowed no share in



<P>it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>As she walked slowly upstairs she thought of yesterday;



<P>it had been about the same hour that she had returned



<P>from the Parsonage, and found Edmund in the East room.



<P>"Suppose I were to find him there again to-day!" said she



<P>to herself, in a fond indulgence of fancy.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Fanny," said a voice at that moment near her.



<P>Starting and looking up, she saw, across the lobby she



<P>had just reached, Edmund himself, standing at the head



<P>of a different staircase.&nbsp; He came towards her.&nbsp; "You look



<P>tired and fagged, Fanny.&nbsp; You have been walking too far."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, I have not been out at all."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Then you have had fatigues within doors, which are worse.



<P>You had better have gone out."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny, not liking to complain, found it easiest to make



<P>no answer; and though he looked at her with his usual kindness,



<P>she believed he had soon ceased to think of her countenance.



<P>He did not appear in spirits:&nbsp; something unconnected with



<P>her was probably amiss.&nbsp; They proceeded upstairs together,



<P>their rooms being on the same floor above.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I come from Dr. Grant's," said Edmund presently.



<P>"You may guess my errand there, Fanny."&nbsp; And he looked



<P>so conscious, that Fanny could think but of one errand,



<P>which turned her too sick for speech.&nbsp; "I wished to



<P>engage Miss Crawford for the two first dances," was the



<P>explanation that followed, and brought Fanny to life again,



<P>enabling her, as she found she was expected to speak,



<P>to utter something like an inquiry as to the result.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Yes," he answered, "she is engaged to me; but" (with a smile



<P>that did not sit easy) "she says it is to be the last time



<P>that she ever will dance with me.&nbsp; She is not serious.



<P>I think, I hope, I am sure she is not serious; but I would



<P>rather not hear it.&nbsp; She never has danced with a clergyman,



<P>she says, and she never _will_.&nbsp; For my own sake, I could



<P>wish there had been no ball just at--I mean not this



<P>very week, this very day; to-morrow I leave home."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny struggled for speech, and said, "I am very sorry



<P>that anything has occurred to distress you.&nbsp; This ought



<P>to be a day of pleasure.&nbsp; My uncle meant it so."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Oh yes, yes! and it will be a day of pleasure.



<P>It will all end right.&nbsp; I am only vexed for a moment.



<P>In fact, it is not that I consider the ball as ill-timed;



<P>what does it signify?&nbsp; But, Fanny," stopping her,



<P>by taking her hand, and speaking low and seriously,



<P>"you know what all this means.&nbsp; You see how it is;



<P>and could tell me, perhaps better than I could tell you,



<P>how and why I am vexed.&nbsp; Let me talk to you a little.



<P>You are a kind, kind listener.&nbsp; I have been pained



<P>by her manner this morning, and cannot get the better



<P>of it.&nbsp; I know her disposition to be as sweet and



<P>faultless as your own, but the influence of her former



<P>companions makes her seem--gives to her conversation,



<P>to her professed opinions, sometimes a tinge of wrong.



<P>She does not _think_ evil, but she speaks it, speaks it



<P>in playfulness; and though I know it to be playfulness,



<P>it grieves me to the soul."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"The effect of education," said Fanny gently.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Edmund could not but agree to it.&nbsp; "Yes, that uncle and aunt!



<P>They have injured the finest mind; for sometimes,



<P>Fanny, I own to you, it does appear more than manner:



<P>it appears as if the mind itself was tainted."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny imagined this to be an appeal to her judgment,



<P>and therefore, after a moment's consideration, said, "If you



<P>only want me as a listener, cousin, I will be as useful



<P>as I can; but I am not qualified for an adviser.



<P>Do not ask advice of _me_.&nbsp; I am not competent."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"You are right, Fanny, to protest against such an office,



<P>but you need not be afraid.&nbsp; It is a subject on which I



<P>should never ask advice; it is the sort of subject on



<P>which it had better never be asked; and few, I imagine,



<P>do ask it, but when they want to be influenced against



<P>their conscience.&nbsp; I only want to talk to you."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"One thing more.&nbsp; Excuse the liberty; but take care



<P>_how_ you talk to me.&nbsp; Do not tell me anything now,



<P>which hereafter you may be sorry for.&nbsp; The time may come--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The colour rushed into her cheeks as she spoke.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Dearest Fanny!" cried Edmund, pressing her hand to



<P>his lips with almost as much warmth as if it had been



<P>Miss Crawford's, "you are all considerate thought!



<P>But it is unnecessary here.&nbsp; The time will never come.



<P>No such time as you allude to will ever come.&nbsp; I begin to



<P>think it most improbable:&nbsp; the chances grow less and less;



<P>and even if it should, there will be nothing to be



<P>remembered by either you or me that we need be afraid of,



<P>for I can never be ashamed of my own scruples; and if they



<P>are removed, it must be by changes that will only raise



<P>her character the more by the recollection of the faults



<P>she once had.&nbsp; You are the only being upon earth to whom



<P>I should say what I have said; but you have always known



<P>my opinion of her; you can bear me witness, Fanny, that I



<P>have never been blinded.&nbsp; How many a time have we



<P>talked over her little errors!&nbsp; You need not fear me;



<P>I have almost given up every serious idea of her;



<P>but I must be a blockhead indeed, if, whatever befell me,



<P>I could think of your kindness and sympathy without the



<P>sincerest gratitude."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He had said enough to shake the experience of eighteen.



<P>He had said enough to give Fanny some happier feelings



<P>than she had lately known, and with a brighter look,



<P>she answered, "Yes, cousin, I am convinced that _you_



<P>would be incapable of anything else, though perhaps some



<P>might not.&nbsp; I cannot be afraid of hearing anything you



<P>wish to say.&nbsp; Do not check yourself.&nbsp; Tell me whatever



<P>you like."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>They were now on the second floor, and the appearance



<P>of a housemaid prevented any farther conversation.



<P>For Fanny's present comfort it was concluded, perhaps,



<P>at the happiest moment:&nbsp; had he been able to talk another



<P>five minutes, there is no saying that he might not have talked



<P>away all Miss Crawford's faults and his own despondence.



<P>But as it was, they parted with looks on his side of



<P>grateful affection, and with some very precious sensations



<P>on hers.&nbsp; She had felt nothing like it for hours.



<P>Since the first joy from Mr. Crawford's note to William had



<P>worn away, she had been in a state absolutely the reverse;



<P>there had been no comfort around, no hope within her.



<P>Now everything was smiling.&nbsp; William's good fortune



<P>returned again upon her mind, and seemed of greater



<P>value than at first.&nbsp; The ball, too--such an evening



<P>of pleasure before her!&nbsp; It was now a real animation;



<P>and she began to dress for it with much of the happy



<P>flutter which belongs to a ball.&nbsp; All went well:



<P>she did not dislike her own looks; and when she came



<P>to the necklaces again, her good fortune seemed complete,



<P>for upon trial the one given her by Miss Crawford would



<P>by no means go through the ring of the cross.&nbsp; She had,



<P>to oblige Edmund, resolved to wear it; but it was too



<P>large for the purpose.&nbsp; His, therefore, must be worn;



<P>and having, with delightful feelings, joined the chain



<P>and the cross--those memorials of the two most beloved



<P>of her heart, those dearest tokens so formed for each



<P>other by everything real and imaginary--and put them



<P>round her neck, and seen and felt how full of William



<P>and Edmund they were, she was able, without an effort,



<P>to resolve on wearing Miss Crawford's necklace too.



<P>She acknowledged it to be right.&nbsp; Miss Crawford had a claim;



<P>and when it was no longer to encroach on, to interfere



<P>with the stronger claims, the truer kindness of another,



<P>she could do her justice even with pleasure to herself.



<P>The necklace really looked very well; and Fanny left her



<P>room at last, comfortably satisfied with herself and all



<P>about her.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Her aunt Bertram had recollected her on this occasion with



<P>an unusual degree of wakefulness.&nbsp; It had really occurred



<P>to her, unprompted, that Fanny, preparing for a ball,



<P>might be glad of better help than the upper housemaid's,



<P>and when dressed herself, she actually sent her own maid



<P>to assist her; too late, of course, to be of any use.



<P>Mrs. Chapman had just reached the attic floor, when Miss



<P>Price came out of her room completely dressed, and only



<P>civilities were necessary; but Fanny felt her aunt's



<P>attention almost as much as Lady Bertram or Mrs. Chapman



<P>could do themselves.



<P>

   <TITLE>Chapter 33</TITLE>

<BODY>

<B>CHAPTER XXXIII</B>

<BR>

<HR WIDTH="100%">



<P>The conference was neither so short nor so conclusive



<P>as the lady had designed.&nbsp; The gentleman was not



<P>so easily satisfied.&nbsp; He had all the disposition to



<P>persevere that Sir Thomas could wish him.&nbsp; He had vanity,



<P>which strongly inclined him in the first place to think



<P>she did love him, though she might not know it herself;



<P>and which, secondly, when constrained at last to admit



<P>that she did know her own present feelings, convinced him



<P>that he should be able in time to make those feelings



<P>what he wished.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He was in love, very much in love; and it was a love which,



<P>operating on an active, sanguine spirit, of more warmth



<P>than delicacy, made her affection appear of greater



<P>consequence because it was withheld, and determined him



<P>to have the glory, as well as the felicity, of forcing



<P>her to love him.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>He would not despair:&nbsp; he would not desist.&nbsp; He had every



<P>well-grounded reason for solid attachment; he knew her



<P>to have all the worth that could justify the warmest



<P>hopes of lasting happiness with her; her conduct at this



<P>very time, by speaking the disinterestedness and delicacy



<P>of her character (qualities which he believed most rare



<P>indeed), was of a sort to heighten all his wishes,



<P>and confirm all his resolutions.&nbsp; He knew not that he had a



<P>pre-engaged heart to attack.&nbsp; Of _that_ he had no suspicion.



<P>He considered her rather as one who had never thought



<P>on the subject enough to be in danger; who had been



<P>guarded by youth, a youth of mind as lovely as of person;



<P>whose modesty had prevented her from understanding



<P>his attentions, and who was still overpowered by the



<P>suddenness of addresses so wholly unexpected, and the novelty



<P>of a situation which her fancy had never taken into account.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Must it not follow of course, that, when he was understood,



<P>he should succeed?&nbsp; He believed it fully.&nbsp; Love such as his,



<P>in a man like himself, must with perseverance secure a return,



<P>and at no great distance; and he had so much delight in



<P>the idea of obliging her to love him in a very short time,



<P>that her not loving him now was scarcely regretted.



<P>A little difficulty to be overcome was no evil to



<P>Henry Crawford.&nbsp; He rather derived spirits from it.



<P>He had been apt to gain hearts too easily.&nbsp; His situation



<P>was new and animating.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>To Fanny, however, who had known too much opposition all her



<P>life to find any charm in it, all this was unintelligible.



<P>She found that he did mean to persevere; but how he could,



<P>after such language from her as she felt herself obliged



<P>to use, was not to be understood.&nbsp; She told him that she



<P>did not love him, could not love him, was sure she never



<P>should love him; that such a change was quite impossible;



<P>that the subject was most painful to her; that she must



<P>entreat him never to mention it again, to allow her to leave



<P>him at once, and let it be considered as concluded for ever.



<P>And when farther pressed, had added, that in her opinion



<P>their dispositions were so totally dissimilar as to make



<P>mutual affection incompatible; and that they were unfitted



<P>for each other by nature, education, and habit.&nbsp; All this



<P>she had said, and with the earnestness of sincerity;



<P>yet this was not enough, for he immediately denied there



<P>being anything uncongenial in their characters, or anything



<P>unfriendly in their situations; and positively declared,



<P>that he would still love, and still hope!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny knew her own meaning, but was no judge of her own manner.



<P>Her manner was incurably gentle; and she was not aware



<P>how much it concealed the sternness of her purpose.



<P>Her diffidence, gratitude, and softness made every expression



<P>of indifference seem almost an effort of self-denial;



<P>seem, at least, to be giving nearly as much pain to herself



<P>as to him.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford was no longer the Mr. Crawford who,



<P>as the clandestine, insidious, treacherous admirer of



<P>Maria Bertram, had been her abhorrence, whom she had hated



<P>to see or to speak to, in whom she could believe no good



<P>quality to exist, and whose power, even of being agreeable,



<P>she had barely acknowledged.&nbsp; He was now the Mr. Crawford



<P>who was addressing herself with ardent, disinterested love;



<P>whose feelings were apparently become all that was



<P>honourable and upright, whose views of happiness were all



<P>fixed on a marriage of attachment; who was pouring out



<P>his sense of her merits, describing and describing again



<P>his affection, proving as far as words could prove it,



<P>and in the language, tone, and spirit of a man of talent too,



<P>that he sought her for her gentleness and her goodness;



<P>and to complete the whole, he was now the Mr. Crawford



<P>who had procured William's promotion!

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Here was a change, and here were claims which could



<P>not but operate!&nbsp; She might have disdained him in all



<P>the dignity of angry virtue, in the grounds of Sotherton,



<P>or the theatre at Mansfield Park; but he approached



<P>her now with rights that demanded different treatment.



<P>She must be courteous, and she must be compassionate.



<P>She must have a sensation of being honoured, and whether



<P>thinking of herself or her brother, she must have a strong



<P>feeling of gratitude.&nbsp; The effect of the whole was a



<P>manner so pitying and agitated, and words intermingled



<P>with her refusal so expressive of obligation and concern,



<P>that to a temper of vanity and hope like Crawford's,



<P>the truth, or at least the strength of her indifference,



<P>might well be questionable; and he was not so irrational



<P>as Fanny considered him, in the professions of persevering,



<P>assiduous, and not desponding attachment which closed



<P>the interview.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>It was with reluctance that he suffered her to go; but there



<P>was no look of despair in parting to belie his words,



<P>or give her hopes of his being less unreasonable than he



<P>professed himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Now she was angry.&nbsp; Some resentment did arise at a



<P>perseverance so selfish and ungenerous.&nbsp; Here was again



<P>a want of delicacy and regard for others which had formerly



<P>so struck and disgusted her.&nbsp; Here was again a something



<P>of the same Mr. Crawford whom she had so reprobated before.



<P>How evidently was there a gross want of feeling and humanity



<P>where his own pleasure was concerned; and alas! how always



<P>known no principle to supply as a duty what the heart



<P>was deficient in!&nbsp; Had her own affections been as free



<P>as perhaps they ought to have been, he never could have engaged



<P>them.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>So thought Fanny, in good truth and sober sadness,



<P>as she sat musing over that too great indulgence and luxury



<P>of a fire upstairs:&nbsp; wondering at the past and present;



<P>wondering at what was yet to come, and in a nervous



<P>agitation which made nothing clear to her but the persuasion



<P>of her being never under any circumstances able to love



<P>Mr. Crawford, and the felicity of having a fire to sit



<P>over and think of it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas was obliged, or obliged himself, to wait till



<P>the morrow for a knowledge of what had passed between



<P>the young people.&nbsp; He then saw Mr. Crawford, and received



<P>his account.&nbsp; The first feeling was disappointment:



<P>he had hoped better things; he had thought that an hour's



<P>entreaty from a young man like Crawford could not have worked



<P>so little change on a gentle-tempered girl like Fanny;



<P>but there was speedy comfort in the determined views



<P>and sanguine perseverance of the lover; and when seeing



<P>such confidence of success in the principal, Sir Thomas



<P>was soon able to depend on it himself.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Nothing was omitted, on his side, of civility, compliment,



<P>or kindness, that might assist the plan.&nbsp; Mr. Crawford's



<P>steadiness was honoured, and Fanny was praised, and the



<P>connexion was still the most desirable in the world.



<P>At Mansfield Park Mr. Crawford would always be welcome;



<P>he had only to consult his own judgment and feelings as



<P>to the frequency of his visits, at present or in future.



<P>In all his niece's family and friends, there could be



<P>but one opinion, one wish on the subject; the influence



<P>of all who loved her must incline one way.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Everything was said that could encourage, every encouragement



<P>received with grateful joy, and the gentlemen parted



<P>the best of friends.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Satisfied that the cause was now on a footing the most



<P>proper and hopeful, Sir Thomas resolved to abstain



<P>from all farther importunity with his niece, and to



<P>shew no open interference.&nbsp; Upon her disposition he



<P>believed kindness might be the best way of working.



<P>Entreaty should be from one quarter only.&nbsp; The forbearance



<P>of her family on a point, respecting which she could



<P>be in no doubt of their wishes, might be their surest



<P>means of forwarding it.&nbsp; Accordingly, on this principle,



<P>Sir Thomas took the first opportunity of saying to her,



<P>with a mild gravity, intended to be overcoming,



<P>"Well, Fanny, I have seen Mr. Crawford again, and learn



<P>from him exactly how matters stand between you.&nbsp; He is



<P>a most extraordinary young man, and whatever be the event,



<P>you must feel that you have created an attachment of no



<P>common character; though, young as you are, and little



<P>acquainted with the transient, varying, unsteady nature



<P>of love, as it generally exists, you cannot be struck



<P>as I am with all that is wonderful in a perseverance



<P>of this sort against discouragement.&nbsp; With him it is



<P>entirely a matter of feeling:&nbsp; he claims no merit in it;



<P>perhaps is entitled to none.&nbsp; Yet, having chosen so well,



<P>his constancy has a respectable stamp.&nbsp; Had his choice



<P>been less unexceptionable, I should have condemned



<P>his persevering."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Indeed, sir," said Fanny, "I am very sorry that Mr. Crawford



<P>should continue to know that it is paying me a very



<P>great compliment, and I feel most undeservedly honoured;



<P>but I am so perfectly convinced, and I have told him so,



<P>that it never will be in my power--"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear," interrupted Sir Thomas, "there is no



<P>occasion for this.&nbsp; Your feelings are as well known



<P>to me as my wishes and regrets must be to you.



<P>There is nothing more to be said or done.&nbsp; From this



<P>hour the subject is never to be revived between us.



<P>You will have nothing to fear, or to be agitated about.



<P>You cannot suppose me capable of trying to persuade you



<P>to marry against your inclinations.&nbsp; Your happiness



<P>and advantage are all that I have in view, and nothing is



<P>required of you but to bear with Mr. Crawford's endeavours



<P>to convince you that they may not be incompatible with his.



<P>He proceeds at his own risk.&nbsp; You are on safe ground.



<P>I have engaged for your seeing him whenever he calls,



<P>as you might have done had nothing of this sort occurred.



<P>You will see him with the rest of us, in the same manner,



<P>and, as much as you can, dismissing the recollection of



<P>everything unpleasant.&nbsp; He leaves Northamptonshire so soon,



<P>that even this slight sacrifice cannot be often demanded.



<P>The future must be very uncertain.&nbsp; And now, my dear Fanny,



<P>this subject is closed between us."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>The promised departure was all that Fanny could think



<P>of with much satisfaction.&nbsp; Her uncle's kind expressions,



<P>however, and forbearing manner, were sensibly felt;



<P>and when she considered how much of the truth was unknown



<P>to him, she believed she had no right to wonder at the line



<P>of conduct he pursued.&nbsp; He, who had married a daughter



<P>to Mr. Rushworth:&nbsp; romantic delicacy was certainly not



<P>to be expected from him.&nbsp; She must do her duty, and trust



<P>that time might make her duty easier than it now was.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>She could not, though only eighteen, suppose Mr. Crawford's



<P>attachment would hold out for ever; she could not



<P>but imagine that steady, unceasing discouragement from



<P>herself would put an end to it in time.&nbsp; How much time



<P>she might, in her own fancy, allot for its dominion,



<P>is another concern.&nbsp; It would not be fair to inquire



<P>into a young lady's exact estimate of her own perfections.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>In spite of his intended silence, Sir Thomas found himself



<P>once more obliged to mention the subject to his niece,



<P>to prepare her briefly for its being imparted to her aunts;



<P>a measure which he would still have avoided, if possible,



<P>but which became necessary from the totally opposite



<P>feelings of Mr. Crawford as to any secrecy of proceeding.



<P>He had no idea of concealment.&nbsp; It was all known at



<P>the Parsonage, where he loved to talk over the future



<P>with both his sisters, and it would be rather gratifying



<P>to him to have enlightened witnesses of the progress



<P>of his success.&nbsp; When Sir Thomas understood this, he felt



<P>the necessity of making his own wife and sister-in-law



<P>acquainted with the business without delay; though,



<P>on Fanny's account, he almost dreaded the effect of the



<P>communication to Mrs. Norris as much as Fanny herself.



<P>He deprecated her mistaken but well-meaning zeal.



<P>Sir Thomas, indeed, was, by this time, not very far from



<P>classing Mrs. Norris as one of those well-meaning people



<P>who are always doing mistaken and very disagreeable things.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Mrs. Norris, however, relieved him.&nbsp; He pressed



<P>for the strictest forbearance and silence towards



<P>their niece; she not only promised, but did observe it.



<P>She only looked her increased ill-will. Angry she was:



<P>bitterly angry; but she was more angry with Fanny for



<P>having received such an offer than for refusing it.



<P>It was an injury and affront to Julia, who ought to have



<P>been Mr. Crawford's choice; and, independently of that,



<P>she disliked Fanny, because she had neglected her;



<P>and she would have grudged such an elevation to one whom



<P>she had been always trying to depress.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Sir Thomas gave her more credit for discretion on the



<P>occasion than she deserved; and Fanny could have blessed



<P>her for allowing her only to see her displeasure,



<P>and not to hear it.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Lady Bertram took it differently.&nbsp; She had been a beauty,



<P>and a prosperous beauty, all her life; and beauty



<P>and wealth were all that excited her respect.&nbsp; To know



<P>Fanny to be sought in marriage by a man of fortune,



<P>raised her, therefore, very much in her opinion.



<P>By convincing her that Fanny _was_ very pretty, which she



<P>had been doubting about before, and that she would be



<P>advantageously married, it made her feel a sort of credit



<P>in calling her niece.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"Well, Fanny," said she, as soon as they were alone



<P>together afterwards, and she really had known something



<P>like impatience to be alone with her, and her countenance,



<P>as she spoke, had extraordinary animation; "Well, Fanny,



<P>I have had a very agreeable surprise this morning.&nbsp; I must



<P>just speak of it _once_, I told Sir Thomas I must _once_,



<P>and then I shall have done.&nbsp; I give you joy, my dear niece."



<P>And looking at her complacently, she added, "Humph, we



<P>certainly are a handsome family!"

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>Fanny coloured, and doubted at first what to say;



<P>when, hoping to assail her on her vulnerable side,



<P>she presently answered--

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"My dear aunt, _you_ cannot wish me to do differently from



<P>what I have done, I am sure.&nbsp; _You_ cannot wish me to marry;



<P>for you would miss me, should not you?&nbsp; Yes, I am sure



<P>you would miss me too much for that."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"No, my dear, I should not think of missing you,



<P>when such an offer as this comes in your way.



<P>I could do very well without you, if you were married



<P>to a man of such good estate as Mr. Crawford.&nbsp; And you



<P>must be aware, Fanny, that it is every young woman's



<P>duty to accept such a very unexceptionable offer as this."

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>This was almost the only rule of conduct, the only piece



<P>of advice, which Fanny had ever received from her aunt



<P>in the course of eight years and a half.&nbsp; It silenced her.



<P>She felt how unprofitable contention would be.



<P>If her aunt's feelings were against her, nothing could



<P>be hoped from attacking her understanding.&nbsp; Lady Bertram



<P>was quite talkative.

<BR>&nbsp;

<BR>&nbsp;



<P>"I will tell you what, Fanny," said she, "I am sure he



<P>fell in love with you at the ball; I am sure the mischief



<P>was done that evening.&nbsp; You did look remarkably well.



<P>Everybody said so.&nbsp; Sir Thomas said so.&nbsp; And you know



<P>you had Chapman to help you to dress.&nbsp; I am very glad



<P>I sent Chapman to you.&nbsp; I shall tell Sir Thomas that I



<P>am sure it was done that evening."&nbsp; And still pursuing



<P>the same cheerful thoughts, she soon afterwards added,



<P>"And will tell you what, Fanny, which is more than I did



<P>for Maria:&nbsp; the next time Pug has a litter you shall have



<P>a puppy."



<P>
